text: title
Learning Phrase Representations using RNN Encoder - Decoder for Statistical Machine Translation
heading: title

text: abstract
In this paper , we propose a novel neural network model called RNN Encoder - Decoder that consists of two recurrent neural networks ( RNN ) .
heading: abstract

text: One RNN encodes a sequence of symbols into a fixedlength vector representation , and the other decodes the representation into another sequence of symbols .
heading: abstract

text: The encoder and decoder of the proposed model are jointly trained to maximize the conditional probability of a target sequence given a source sequence .
heading: abstract

text: The performance of a statistical machine translation system is empirically found to improve by using the conditional probabilities of phrase pairs computed by the RNN Encoder - Decoder as an additional feature in the existing log - linear model .
heading: abstract

text: Qualitatively , we show that the proposed model learns a semantically and syntactically meaningful representation of linguistic phrases .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Deep neural networks have shown great success in various applications such as objection recognition ( see , e.g. , ) and speech recognition ( see , e.g. , ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Furthermore , many recent works showed that neural networks can be successfully used in a number of tasks in natural language processing ( NLP ) .
heading: Introduction

text: These include , but are not limited to , language modeling , paraphrase detection and word embedding extraction .
heading: Introduction

text: In the field of statistical machine translation ( SMT ) , deep neural networks have begun to show promising results .
heading: Introduction

text: summarizes a successful usage of feedforward neural networks in the framework of phrase - based SMT system .
heading: Introduction

text: Along this line of research on using neural networks for SMT , this paper focuses on a novel neural network architecture that can be used as apart of the conventional phrase - based SMT system .
heading: Introduction

text: The proposed neural network architecture , which we will refer to as an RNN Encoder - Decoder , consists of two recurrent neural networks ( RNN ) that act as an encoder and a decoder pair .
heading: Introduction

text: The encoder maps a variable - length source sequence to a fixed - length vector , and the decoder maps the vector representation back to a variable - length target sequence .
heading: Introduction

text: The two networks are trained jointly to maximize the conditional probability of the target sequence given a source sequence .
heading: Introduction

text: Additionally , we propose to use a rather sophisticated hidden unit in order to improve both the memory capacity and the ease of training .
heading: Introduction

text: The proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder with a novel hidden unit is empirically evaluated on the task of translating from English to French .
heading: Introduction

text: We train the model to learn the translation probability of an English phrase to a corresponding French phrase .
heading: Introduction

text: The model is then used as apart of a standard phrase - based SMT system by scoring each phrase pair in the phrase table .
heading: Introduction

text: The empirical evaluation reveals that this approach of scoring phrase pairs with an RNN Encoder - Decoder improves the translation performance .
heading: Introduction

text: We qualitatively analyze the trained RNN Encoder - Decoder by comparing its phrase scores with those given by the existing translation model .
heading: Introduction

text: The qualitative analysis shows that the RNN Encoder - Decoder is better at capturing the linguistic regularities in the phrase table , indirectly explaining the quantitative improvements in the overall translation performance .
heading: Introduction

text: The further analysis of the model reveals that the RNN Encoder - Decoder learns a continuous space representation of a phrase that preserves both the semantic and syntactic structure of the phrase .
heading: Introduction

text: A recurrent neural network ( RNN ) is a neural network that consists of a hidden state hand an optional output y which operates on a variablelength sequence x = ( x 1 , . . . , x T ) .
heading: Introduction

text: At each time step t , the hidden state ht of the RNN is updated by

text: where f is a non-linear activation function .
heading: Introduction

text: f maybe as simple as an elementwise logistic sigmoid function and as complex as along short - term memory ( LSTM ) unit ) .
heading: Introduction

text: An RNN can learn a probability distribution over a sequence by being trained to predict the next symbol in a sequence .
heading: Introduction

text: In that case , the output at each timestep t is the conditional distribution p ( x t | x t?1 , . . . , x 1 ) .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , a multinomial distribution ( 1 - of - K coding ) can be output using a softmax activation function
heading: Introduction

text: for all possible symbols j = 1 , . . . , K , where w j are the rows of a weight matrix W. By combining these probabilities , we can compute the probability of the sequence x using
heading: Introduction

text: From this learned distribution , it is straightforward to sample anew sequence by iteratively sampling a symbol at each time step .
heading: Introduction

text: RNN Encoder - Decoder
heading: Introduction

text: The RNN Encoder - Decoder used in the experiment had 1000 hidden units with the proposed gates at the encoder and at the decoder .
heading: Introduction

text: The input matrix between each input symbol x t and the hidden unit is approximated with two lower - rank matrices , and the output matrix is approximated similarly .
heading: Introduction

text: We used rank - 100 matrices , equivalent to learning an embedding of dimension 100 for each word .
heading: Introduction

text: The activation function used forh in Eq. ( 8 ) is a hyperbolic tangent function .
heading: Introduction

text: The computation from the hidden state in the decoder to the output is implemented as a deep neural network ( Pascanu et al. , 2014 ) with a single intermediate layer having 500 maxout units each pooling 2 inputs .
heading: Introduction

text: All the weight parameters in the RNN Encoder - Decoder were initialized by sampling from an isotropic zero-mean ( white ) Gaussian distribution with its standard deviation fixed to 0.01 , except for the recurrent weight parameters .
heading: Introduction

text: For the recurrent weight matrices , we first sampled from a white Gaussian distribution and used its left singular vectors matrix , following .
heading: Introduction

text: We used Adadelta and stochastic gradient descent to train the RNN Encoder - Decoder with hyperparameters = 10 ?6 and ? = 0.95 ( Zeiler , 2012 ) .
heading: Introduction

text: At each update , we used 64 randomly selected phrase pairs from a phrase table ( which was created from 348 M words ) .
heading: Introduction

text: The model was trained for approximately three days .
heading: Introduction

text: Details of the architecture used in the experiments are explained in more depth in the supplementary material .
heading: Introduction

In addition to a novel model architecture , we also propose anew type of hidden unit ( f in Eq .

heading: Hidden Unit that Adaptively Remembers and Forgets

text: In this formulation , when the reset gate is close to 0 , the hidden state is forced to ignore the previous hidden state and reset with the current input only .
heading: Hidden Unit that Adaptively Remembers and Forgets

text: This effectively allows the hidden state to drop any information that is found to be irrelevant later in the future , thus , allowing a more compact representation .
heading: Hidden Unit that Adaptively Remembers and Forgets

text: On the other hand , the update gate controls how much information from the previous hidden state will carryover to the current hidden state .
heading: Hidden Unit that Adaptively Remembers and Forgets

text: This acts similarly to the memory cell in the LSTM network and helps the RNN to remember longterm information .
heading: Hidden Unit that Adaptively Remembers and Forgets

text: Furthermore , this maybe considered an adaptive variant of a leaky - integration unit .
heading: Hidden Unit that Adaptively Remembers and Forgets

text: As each hidden unit has separate reset and update gates , each hidden unit will learn to capture dependencies over different time scales .
heading: Hidden Unit that Adaptively Remembers and Forgets

text: Those units that learn to capture short - term dependencies will tend to have reset gates that are frequently active , but those that capture longer - term dependencies will have update gates that are mostly active .
heading: Hidden Unit that Adaptively Remembers and Forgets

text: In our preliminary experiments , we found that it is crucial to use this new unit with gating units .
heading: Hidden Unit that Adaptively Remembers and Forgets

text: We were notable to get meaningful result with an oft - used tanh unit without any gating .
heading: Hidden Unit that Adaptively Remembers and Forgets

text: Statistical Machine Translation
Ina commonly used statistical machine translation system ( SMT ) , the goal of the system ( decoder , specifically ) is to find a translation f given a source sentence e , which maximizes
heading: Statistical Machine Translation

text: where the first term at the right hand side is called translation model and the latter language model ( see , e.g. , ) .
heading: Statistical Machine Translation

text: In practice , however , most SMT systems model log p ( f | e ) as a loglinear model with additional features and corre - sponding weights : where f n and w n are the n - th feature and weight , respectively .
heading: Statistical Machine Translation

text: Z ( e ) is a normalization constant that does not depend on the weights .
heading: Statistical Machine Translation

text: The weights are often optimized to maximize the BLEU score on a development set .
heading: Statistical Machine Translation

text: In the phrase - based SMT framework introduced in and , the translation model log p ( e | f ) is factorized into the translation probabilities of matching phrases in the source and target sentences .
heading: Statistical Machine Translation

text: These probabilities are once again considered additional features in the log - linear model ( see Eq. ) and are weighted accordingly to maximize the BLEU score .
heading: Statistical Machine Translation

text: Since the neural net language model was proposed in , neural networks have been used widely in SMT systems .
heading: Statistical Machine Translation

text: In many cases , neural networks have been used to rescore translation hypotheses ( n- best lists ) ( see , e.g. , ) .
heading: Statistical Machine Translation

text: Recently , however , there has been interest in training neural networks to score the translated sentence ( or phrase pairs ) using a representation of the source sentence as an additional input .
heading: Statistical Machine Translation

text: See , e.g. , , and .
heading: Statistical Machine Translation

text: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

Here we propose to train the RNN Encoder - Decoder ( see Sec. 2.2 ) on a table of phrase pairs and use its scores as additional features in the loglinear model in Eq. ( 9 ) when tuning the SMT decoder .
heading: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

text: When we train the RNN Encoder - Decoder , we ignore the ( normalized ) frequencies of each phrase pair in the original corpora .
heading: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

text: This measure was taken in order ( 1 ) to reduce the computational expense of randomly selecting phrase pairs from a large phrase table according to the normalized frequencies and ( 2 ) to ensure that the RNN Encoder - Decoder does not simply learn to rank the phrase pairs according to their numbers of occurrences .
heading: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

text: One underlying reason for this choice was that the existing translation probability in the phrase table already reflects the frequencies of the phrase pairs in the original corpus .
heading: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

text: With a fixed capacity of the RNN Encoder - Decoder , we try to ensure that most of the capacity of the model is focused toward learning linguistic regularities , i.e. , distinguishing between plausible and implausible translations , or learning the " manifold " ( region of probability concentration ) of plausible translations .
heading: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

text: Once the RNN Encoder - Decoder is trained , we add anew score for each phrase pair to the existing phrase table .
heading: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

text: This allows the new scores to enter into the existing tuning algorithm with minimal additional overhead in computation .
heading: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

text: As Schwenk pointed out in , it is possible to completely replace the existing phrase table with the proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder .
heading: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

text: In that case , fora given source phrase , the RNN Encoder - Decoder will need to generate a list of ( good ) target phrases .
heading: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

text: This requires , however , an expensive sampling procedure to be performed repeatedly .
heading: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

text: In this paper , thus , we only consider rescoring the phrase pairs in the phrase table .
heading: Scoring Phrase Pairs with RNN Encoder - Decoder

text: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation
Before presenting the empirical results , we discuss a number of recent works that have proposed to use neural networks in the context of SMT .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: Schwenk in proposed a similar approach of scoring phrase pairs .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: Instead of the RNN - based neural network , he used a feedforward neural network that has fixed - size inputs ( 7 words in his case , with zero - padding for shorter phrases ) and fixed - size outputs ( 7 words in the target language ) .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: When it is used specifically for scoring phrases for the SMT system , the maximum phrase length is often chosen to be small .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: However , as the length of phrases increases or as we apply neural networks to other variable - length sequence data , it is important that the neural network can handle variable - length input and output .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: The proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder is well - suited for these applications .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: Similar to , Devlin et al. proposed to use a feedforward neural network to model a translation model , however , by predicting one word in a target phrase at a time .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: They reported an impressive improvement , but their approach still requires the maximum length of the input phrase ( or context words ) to be fixed a priori .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: Although it is not exactly a neural network they train , the authors of proposed to learn a bilingual embedding of words / phrases .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: They use the learned embedding to compute the distance between a pair of phrases which is used as an additional score of the phrase pair in an SMT system .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: In , a feedforward neural network was trained to learn a mapping from a bag - of - words representation of an input phrase to an output phrase .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: This is closely related to both the proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder and the model proposed in , except that their input representation of a phrase is a bag - of - words .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: A similar approach of using bag - of - words representations was proposed in as well .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: Earlier , a similar encoder - decoder model using two recursive neural networks was proposed in ) , but their model was restricted to a monolingual setting , i.e. the model reconstructs an input sentence .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: More recently , another encoder - decoder model using an RNN was proposed in , where the decoder is conditioned on a representation of either a source sentence or a source context .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: One important difference between the proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder and the approaches in and is that the order of the words in source and target phrases is taken into account .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: The RNN Encoder - Decoder naturally distinguishes between sequences that have the same words but in a different order , whereas the aforementioned approaches effectively ignore order information .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: The closest approach related to the proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder is the Recurrent Continuous Translation Model ( Model 2 ) proposed in .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: In their paper , they proposed a similar model that consists of an encoder and decoder .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: The difference with our model is that they used a convolutional n-gram model ( CGM ) for the encoder and the hybrid of an inverse CGM and a recurrent neural network for the decoder .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: They , however , evaluated their model on rescoring the n-best list proposed by the conventional SMT system and computing the perplexity of the gold standard translations .
heading: Related Approaches : Neural Networks in Machine Translation

text: Experiments
We evaluate our approach on the English / French translation task of the WMT ' 14 workshop .
heading: Experiments

text: Data and Baseline System
Large amounts of resources are available to build an English / French SMT system in the framework of the WMT ' 14 translation task .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: The bilingual corpora include Europarl ( 61M words ) , news commentary ( 5.5 M ) , UN ( 421 M ) , and two crawled corpora of 90 M and 780M words respectively .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: The last two corpora are quite noisy .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: To train the French language model , about 712M words of crawled newspaper material is available in addition to the target side of the bitexts .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: All the word counts refer to French words after tokenization .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: It is commonly acknowledged that training statistical models on the concatenation of all this data does not necessarily lead to optimal performance , and results in extremely large models which are difficult to handle .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: Instead , one should focus on the most relevant subset of the data fora given task .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: We have done so by applying the data selection method proposed in , and its extension to bitexts .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: By these means we selected a subset of 418 M words out of more than 2G words for language modeling and a subset of 348 M out of 850 M words for training the RNN Encoder - Decoder .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: We used the test set newstest2012 and 2013 for data selection and weight tuning with MERT , and newstest2014 as our test set .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: Each set has more than 70 thousand words and a single reference translation .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: For training the neural networks , including the proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder , we limited the source and target vocabulary to the most frequent 15,000 words for both English and French .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: This covers approximately 93 % of the dataset .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: All the out - of - vocabulary words were mapped to a special token ( [ UNK ] ) .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: The baseline phrase - based SMT system was built using Moses with default settings .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: This system achieves a BLEU score of 30.64 and 33.3 on the development and test sets , respectively ( see Table 1 ) .
heading: Data and Baseline System

text: Neural Language Model

In order to assess the effectiveness of scoring phrase pairs with the proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder , we also tried a more traditional approach of using a neural network for learning a target language model ( CSLM ) .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: Especially , the comparison between the SMT system using CSLM and that using the proposed approach of phrase scoring by RNN Encoder - Decoder will clarify whether the contributions from multiple neural networks in different parts of the SMT sys - tem add up or are redundant .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: We trained the CSLM model on 7 - grams from the target corpus .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: Each input word was projected into the embedding space R 512 , and they were concatenated to form a 3072 dimensional vector .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: The concatenated vector was fed through two rectified layers ( of size 1536 and 1024 ) .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: The output layer was a simple softmax layer ( see Eq. ) .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: All the weight parameters were initialized uniformly between ? 0.01 and 0.01 , and the model was trained until the validation perplexity did not improve for 10 epochs .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: After training , the language model achieved a perplexity of 45.80 .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: The validation set was a random selection of 0.1 % of the corpus .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: The model was used to score partial translations during the decoding process , which generally leads to higher gains in BLEU score than n-best list rescoring .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: To address the computational complexity of using a CSLM in the decoder a buffer was used to aggregate n-grams during the stacksearch performed by the decoder .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: Only when the buffer is full , or a stack is about to be pruned , the n-grams are scored by the CSLM .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: This allows us to perform fast matrixmatrix multiplication on GPU using Theano .
heading: Neural Language Model

text: Qualitative Analysis

In order to understand where the performance improvement comes from , we analyze the phrase pair scores computed by the RNN Encoder - Decoder against the corresponding p ( f | e ) from the translation model .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: Since the existing translation model relies solely on the statistics of the phrase pairs in the corpus , we expect its scores to be better estimated for the frequent phrases but badly estimated for rare phrases .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: Also , as we mentioned earlier in Sec. 3.1 , we further expect the RNN Encoder - Decoder which was trained without any frequency information to score the phrase pairs based rather on the linguistic regularities than on the statistics of their occurrences in the corpus .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: We focus on those pairs whose source phrase is long ( more than 3 words per source phrase ) and
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: As a result , the probability of words not in the shortlist is always overestimated .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: It is possible to address this issue by backing off to an existing model that contain non-shortlisted words ( see ) In this paper , however , we opt for introducing a word penalty instead , which counteracts the word probability overestimation .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: frequent .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: For each such source phrase , we look at the target phrases that have been scored high either by the translation probability p ( f | e ) or by the RNN Encoder - Decoder .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: Similarly , we perform the same procedure with those pairs whose source phrase is long but rare in the corpus .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: lists the top - 3 target phrases per source phrase favored either by the translation model or by the RNN Encoder - Decoder .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: The source phrases were randomly chosen among long ones having more than 4 or 5 words .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: In most cases , the choices of the target phrases by the RNN Encoder - Decoder are closer to actual or literal translations .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: We can observe that the RNN Encoder - Decoder prefers shorter phrases in general .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: Interestingly , many phrase pairs were scored similarly by both the translation model and the RNN Encoder - Decoder , but there were as many other phrase pairs that were scored radically different ( see ) .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: This could arise from the proposed approach of training the RNN Encoder - Decoder on a set of unique phrase pairs , discouraging the RNN Encoder - Decoder from learning simply the frequencies of the phrase pairs from the corpus , as explained earlier . , we show for each of the source phrases in , the generated samples from the RNN Encoder - Decoder .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: For each source phrase , we generated 50 samples and show the top - five phrases accordingly to their scores .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: We can see that the RNN Encoder - Decoder is able to propose well - formed target phrases without looking at the actual phrase table .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: Importantly , the generated phrases do not overlap completely with the target phrases from the phrase table .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: This encourages us to further investigate the possibility of replacing the whole or apart of the phrase table with the proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder in the future .
heading: Qualitative Analysis

text: Word and Phrase Representations
Since the proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder is not specifically designed only for the task of machine translation , here we briefly look at the properties of the trained model .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: It has been known for sometime that continuous space language models using neural networks are able to learn semantically meaningful embeddings ( See , e.g. , ) .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: Since the proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder also projects to and maps back from a sequence of words into a continuous space vector , we expect to see a similar property with the proposed model as well .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: The left plot in shows the 2 - D embedding of the words using the word embedding matrix learned by the RNN Encoder - Decoder .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: The projection was done by the recently proposed Barnes - Hut - SNE .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: We can clearly see that semantically similar words are clustered with each other ( see the zoomed - in plots in .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: The proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder naturally generates a continuous - space representation of a phrase .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: The representation ( c in ) in this case is a 1000 - dimensional vector .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: Similarly to the word representations , we visualize the representations of the phrases that consists of four or more words using the Barnes - Hut - SNE in .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: From the visualization , it is clear that the RNN Encoder - Decoder captures both semantic and syntactic structures of the phrases .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: For instance , in the bottom - left plot , most of the phrases are about the duration of time , while those phrases that are syntactically similar are clustered together .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: The bottom - right plot shows the cluster of phrases that are semantically similar ( countries or regions ) .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: On the other hand , the top - right plot shows the phrases that are syntactically similar .
heading: Word and Phrase Representations

text: Conclusion

In this paper , we proposed anew neural network architecture , called an RNN Encoder - Decoder that is able to learn the mapping from a sequence of an arbitrary length to another sequence , possibly from a different set , of an arbitrary length .
heading: Conclusion

text: The proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder is able to either score a pair of sequences ( in terms of a conditional probability ) or generate a target sequence given a source sequence .
heading: Conclusion

text: Along with the new architecture , we proposed a novel hidden unit that includes a reset gate and an update gate that adaptively control how much each hidden unit remembers or forgets while reading / generating a sequence .
heading: Conclusion

text: We evaluated the proposed model with the task of statistical machine translation , where we used the RNN Encoder - Decoder to score each phrase pair in the phrase table .
heading: Conclusion

text: Qualitatively , we were able to show that the new model is able to capture linguistic regularities in the phrase pairs well and also that the RNN Encoder - Decoder is able to propose well - formed target phrases .
heading: Conclusion

text: The scores by the RNN Encoder - Decoder were found to improve the overall translation performance in terms of BLEU scores .
heading: Conclusion

text: Also , we found that the contribution by the RNN Encoder - Decoder is rather orthogonal to the existing approach of using neural networks in the SMT system , so that we can improve further the performance by using , for instance , the RNN Encoder - Decoder and the neural net language model together .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our qualitative analysis of the trained model shows that it indeed captures the linguistic regularities in multiple levels i.e. at the word level as well as phrase level .
heading: Conclusion

text: This suggests that there maybe more natural language related applications that may benefit from the proposed RNN Encoder - Decoder .
heading: Conclusion

text: The proposed architecture has large potential for further improvement and analysis .
heading: Conclusion

text: One approach that was not investigated here is to replace the whole , or apart of the phrase table by letting the RNN Encoder - Decoder propose target phrases .
heading: Conclusion

text: Also , noting that the proposed model is not limited to being used with written language , it will bean important future research to apply the proposed architecture to other applications such as speech transcription .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Neural Machine Translation in Linear Time
abstract
We present a novel neural network for processing sequences .
heading: abstract

text: The ByteNet is a one-dimensional convolutional neural network that is composed of two parts , one to encode the source sequence and the other to decode the target sequence .
heading: abstract

text: The two network parts are connected by stacking the decoder on top of the encoder and preserving the temporal resolution of the sequences .
heading: abstract

text: To address the differing lengths of the source and the target , we introduce an efficient mechanism by which the decoder is dynamically unfolded over the representation of the encoder .
heading: abstract

text: The ByteNet uses dilation in the convolutional layers to increase its receptive field .
heading: abstract

text: The resulting network has two core properties : it runs in time that is linear in the length of the sequences and it sidesteps the need for excessive memorization .
heading: abstract

text: The ByteNet decoder attains state - of - the - art performance on character - level language modelling and outperforms the previous best results obtained with recurrent networks .
heading: abstract

text: The ByteNet also achieves state - of - the - art performance on character - to - character machine translation on the English - to - German WMT translation task , surpassing comparable neural translation models that are based on recurrent networks with attentional pooling and run in quadratic time .
heading: abstract

text: We find that the latent alignment structure contained in the representations reflects the expected alignment between the tokens .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
In neural language modelling , a neural network estimates a distribution over sequences of words or characters that belong to a given language .
heading: Introduction

text: In neural machine translation , the network estimates a distribution over sequences in the target language conditioned on a given sequence in the source language .
heading: Introduction

text: The network can bethought of as composed of two parts : a source network ( the encoder ) that encodes the source sequence into a representation and a target network ( the decoder ) that uses the representation of the source encoder to generate the target sequence .
heading: Introduction

text: Recurrent neural networks ( RNN ) are powerful sequence models and are widely used in language modelling ) , yet they have a potential drawback .
heading: Introduction

text: RNNs have an inherently serial structure that prevents them from being run in parallel along the sequence length during training and evaluation .
heading: Introduction

text: Forward and backward signals in a RNN also need to traverse the full distance of the serial path to reach from one token in the sequence to another .
heading: Introduction

text: The larger the distance , the harder it is to learn the dependencies between the tokens .
heading: Introduction

text: A number of neural architectures have been proposed for modelling translation , such as encoder - decoder networks , networks with attentional pooling and twodimensional networks .
heading: Introduction

text: Despite the generally good performance , the proposed models ar Xiv : 1610.10099v2 [ cs. CL ] 15 Mar 2017 EOS EOS EOS | s | | t | | t| .
heading: Introduction

text: Dynamic unfolding in the ByteNet architecture .
heading: Introduction

text: At each step the decoder is conditioned on the source representation produced by the encoder for that step , or simply on no representation for steps beyond the extended length | t | .
heading: Introduction

text: The decoding ends when the target network produces an end - of - sequence ( EOS ) symbol .
heading: Introduction

text: either have running time that is super - linear in the length of the source and target sequences , or they process the source sequence into a constant size representation , burdening the model with a memorization step .
heading: Introduction

text: Both of these drawbacks grow more severe as the length of the sequences increases .
heading: Introduction

text: We present a family of encoder - decoder neural networks that are characterized by two architectural mechanisms aimed to address the drawbacks of the conventional approaches mentioned above .
heading: Introduction

text: The first mechanism involves the stacking of the decoder on top of the representation of the encoder in a manner that preserves the temporal resolution of the sequences ; this is in contrast with architectures that encode the source into a fixed - size representation .
heading: Introduction

text: The second mechanism is the dynamic unfolding mechanism that allows the network to process in a simple and efficient way source and target sequences of different lengths ( Sect. 3.2 ) .
heading: Introduction

text: The ByteNet is the instance within this family of models that uses one - dimensional convolutional neural networks ( CNN ) of fixed depth for both the encoder and the decoder ) .
heading: Introduction

text: The two CNNs use increasing factors of dilation to rapidly grow the receptive fields ; a similar technique is also used in .
heading: Introduction

text: The convolutions in the decoder CNN are masked to prevent the network from seeing future tokens in the target sequence .
heading: Introduction

text: The network has beneficial computational and learning properties .
heading: Introduction

text: From a computational perspective , the network has a running time that is linear in the length of the source and target sequences ( up to a constant c ?
heading: Introduction

text: log d where dis the size of the desired dependency field ) .
heading: Introduction

text: The computation in the encoder during training and decoding and in the decoder during training can also be run efficiently in parallel along the sequences ( Sect. 2 ) .
heading: Introduction

text: From a learning perspective , the representation of the source sequence in the ByteNet is resolution preserving ; the representation sidesteps the need for memorization and allows for maximal bandwidth between encoder and decoder .
heading: Introduction

text: In addition , the distance traversed by forward and backward signals between any input and output tokens corresponds to the fixed depth of the networks and is largely independent of the dis - tance between the tokens .
heading: Introduction

text: Dependencies overlarge distances are connected by short paths and can be learnt more easily .
heading: Introduction

text: We apply the ByteNet model to strings of characters for character - level language modelling and character - tocharacter machine translation .
heading: Introduction

text: We evaluate the decoder network on the Hutter Prize Wikipedia task where it achieves the state - of - the - art performance of 1.31 bits / character .
heading: Introduction

text: We further evaluate the encoderdecoder network on character - to - character machine translation on the English - to - German WMT benchmark where it achieves a state - of - the - art BLEU score of 22.85 ( 0.380 bits / character ) and 25.53 ( 0.389 bits / character ) on the 2014 and 2015 test sets , respectively .
heading: Introduction

text: On the character - level machine translation task , ByteNet betters a comparable version of GNMT that is a state - of - the - art system .
heading: Introduction

text: These results show that deep CNNs are simple , scalable and effective architectures for challenging linguistic processing tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: The paper is organized as follows .
heading: Introduction

text: Section 2 lays out the background and some desiderata for neural architectures underlying translation models .
heading: Introduction

text: Section 3 defines the proposed family of architectures and the specific convolutional instance ( ByteNet ) used in the experiments .
heading: Introduction

text: Section 4 analyses ByteNet as well as existing neural translation models based on the desiderata set out in Section 2 .
heading: Introduction

text: Section 5 reports the experiments on language modelling and Section 6 reports the experiments on character - to - character machine translation .
heading: Introduction

text: Neural Translation Model
Given a string s from a source language , a neural translation model estimates a distribution p ( t |s ) over strings t of a target language .
heading: Neural Translation Model

text: The distribution indicates the probability of a string t being a translation of s .
heading: Neural Translation Model

text: A product of conditionals over the tokens in the target t = t 0 , ... , t N leads to a tractable formulation of the distribution :
heading: Neural Translation Model

text: Each conditional factor expresses complex and long - range dependencies among the source and target tokens .
heading: Neural Translation Model

text: The strings are usually sentences of the respective languages ; the tokens are words or , as in the our case , characters .
heading: Neural Translation Model

text: The network that models p ( t | s ) is composed of two parts : a source network ( the encoder ) that processes the source string into a representation and a target network ( the decoder ) that uses the source representation to generate the target string .
heading: Neural Translation Model

text: The decoder functions as a language model for the target language .
heading: Neural Translation Model

text: A neural translation model has some basic properties .
heading: Neural Translation Model

text: The decoder is autoregressive in the target tokens and the model is sensitive to the ordering of the tokens in the source and target strings .
heading: Neural Translation Model

text: It is also useful for the model to be able to assign a non-zero probability to any string in the target language and retain an open vocabulary .
heading: Neural Translation Model

text: Desiderata
Beyond these basic properties the definition of a neural translation model does not determine a unique neural architecture , so we aim at identifying some desiderata .
heading: Desiderata

text: First , the running time of the network should be linear in the length of the source and target strings .
heading: Desiderata

text: This ensures that the model is scalable to longer strings , which is the case when using characters as tokens .
heading: Desiderata

text: The use of operations that run in parallel along the sequence length can also be beneficial for reducing computation time .
heading: Desiderata

text: Second , the size of the source representation should be linear in the length of the source string , i.e. it should be resolution preserving , and not have constant size .
heading: Desiderata

text: This is to avoid burdening the model with an additional memorization step before translation .
heading: Desiderata

text: In more general terms , the size of a representation should be proportional to the amount of information it represents or predicts .
heading: Desiderata

text: Third , the path traversed by forward and backward signals in the network ( between input and ouput tokens ) should be short .
heading: Desiderata

text: Shorter paths whose length is largely decoupled from the sequence distance between the two tokens have the potential to better propagate the signals and to let the network learn long - range dependencies more easily .
heading: Desiderata

text: Byte Net
We aim at building neural language and translation models that capture the desiderata set out in Sect. 2.1 .
heading: Byte Net

text: The proposed ByteNet architecture is composed of a decoder that is stacked on an encoder ( Sect. 3.1 ) and generates variable - length outputs via dynamic unfolding ( Sect. 3.2 ) .
heading: Byte Net

text: The decoder is a language model that is formed of one - dimensional convolutional layers that are masked ( Sect. 3.4 ) and use dilation ( Sect. 3.5 ) .
heading: Byte Net

text: The encoder processes the source string into a representation and is formed of one - dimensional convolutional layers that use dilation but are not masked .
heading: Byte Net

text: depicts the two networks and their combination .
heading: Byte Net

text: Encoder - Decoder Stacking
A notable feature of the proposed family of architectures is the way the encoder and the decoder are connected .
heading: Encoder - Decoder Stacking

text: To maximize the representational bandwidth between the encoder and the decoder , we place the decoder on top of the representation computed by the encoder .
heading: Encoder - Decoder Stacking

text: This is in contrast to models that compress the source representation into a fixed - size vector or that pool over the source representation with a mechanism such as attentional pooling .
heading: Encoder - Decoder Stacking

text: Dynamic Unfolding
An encoder and a decoder network that process sequences of different lengths can not be directly connected due to the different sizes of the computed representations .
heading: Dynamic Unfolding

text: We circumvent this issue via a mechanism which we call dynamic unfolding , which works as follows .
heading: Dynamic Unfolding

text: Given source and target sequences sand t with respective lengths | s | and | t| , one first chooses a sufficiently tight upper bound | t| on the target length | t | as a linear function of the source length | s | : |
heading: Dynamic Unfolding

text: The tight upper bound | t| is chosen in such away that , on the one hand , it is greater than the actual length | t | in almost all cases and , on the other hand , it does not increase excessively the amount of computation that is required .
heading: Dynamic Unfolding

text: Once a linear relationship is chosen , one designs the source encoder so that , given a source sequence of length | s | , the encoder outputs a representation of the established lengt ?
heading: Dynamic Unfolding

text: In our case , we let a = 1.20 and b = 0 when translating from English into German , as German sentences tend to be somewhat longer than their English counterparts .
heading: Dynamic Unfolding

text: In this manner the representation produced by the encoder can be efficiently computed , while maintaining high bandwidth and being resolution - preserving .
heading: Dynamic Unfolding

text: Once the encoder representation is computed , we let the decoder unfold stepby - step over the encoder representation until the decoder itself outputs an end - of - sequence symbol ; the unfolding process may freely proceed beyond the estimated length | t| of the encoder representation .
heading: Dynamic Unfolding

text: gives an example of dynamic unfolding .
heading: Dynamic Unfolding

text: Input Embedding Tensor

Given the target sequence t = t 0 , ... , tn the ByteNet decoder embeds each of the first n tokens t 0 , ... , t n?1 via a look - up table ( the n tokens t 1 , ... , tn serve as targets for the predictions ) .
heading: Input Embedding Tensor

text: The resulting embeddings are concatenated into a tensor of size n 2 d where dis the number of inner channels in the network .
heading: Input Embedding Tensor

text: Masked One-dimensional
Convolutions
The decoder applies masked one - dimensional convolutions ( van den to the input embedding tensor that have a masked kernel of size k.
heading: Convolutions

text: The masking ensures that information from future tokens does not affect the prediction of the current token .
heading: Convolutions

text: The operation can be implemented either by zeroing out some of the weights of a wider kernel of size 2 k ?
heading: Convolutions

text: 1 or by padding the input map .
heading: Convolutions

text: Dilation
The masked convolutions use dilation to increase the receptive field of the target network .
heading: Dilation

text: Dilation makes the receptive field grow exponentially in terms of the depth of the networks , as opposed to linearly .
heading: Dilation

text: We use a dilation scheme whereby the dilation rates are doubled every layer up to a maximum rater ( for our experiments r = 16 ) .
heading: Dilation

text: The scheme is repeated multiple times in the network always starting from a dilation rate of 1 ( van den .
heading: Dilation

text: Residual Blocks

Each layer is wrapped in a residual block that contains additional convolutional layers with filters of size 1 1 . We adopt two variants of the residual blocks : one with ReLUs , which is used in the machine translation experiments , and one with Multiplicative Units , which is used in the language modelling experiments .
heading: Residual Blocks

text: diagrams the two variants of the blocks .
heading: Residual Blocks

text: In both cases , we use layer normalization before the activation function , as it is well suited to sequence processing where computing the activation statistics over the following future tokens ( as would be done by batch normalization ) must be avoided .
heading: Residual Blocks

text: After a series of residual blocks of increased dilation , the network applies one more convolution and ReLU followed by a convolution and a final softmax layer .
heading: Residual Blocks

text: Model Comparison
In this section we analyze the properties of various previously introduced neural translation models as well as the ByteNet family of models .
heading: Model Comparison

text: For the sake of a more complete analysis , we include two recurrent ByteNet variants ( which we do not evaluate in the experiments ) .
heading: Model Comparison

text: Recurrent ByteNets
The ByteNet is composed of two stacked encoder and decoder networks where the decoder network dynamically adapts to the output length .
heading: Recurrent ByteNets

text: This way of combining the networks is not tied to the networks being strictly convolutional .
heading: Recurrent ByteNets

text: We may consider two variants of the ByteNet that use recurrent networks for one or both of the networks ( see ) .
heading: Recurrent ByteNets

text: The first variant replaces the convolutional decoder with a recurrent one that is similarly stacked and dynamically unfolded .
heading: Recurrent ByteNets

text: The second variant also replaces the convolutional encoder with a recurrent encoder , e.g. a bidirectional RNN .
heading: Recurrent ByteNets

text: The target RNN is then placed on top of the source RNN .
heading: Recurrent ByteNets

text: Considering the latter Recurrent ByteNet , we can see that the RNN Enc - Dec network ) is a Recurrent ByteNet where all connections between source and target - except for the first one that connects s 0 and t 0 - have been severed .
heading: Recurrent ByteNets

text: The Recurrent ByteNet is a generalization of the RNN Enc - Dec and , modulo the type of weight - sharing scheme , so is the convolutional ByteNet .
heading: Recurrent ByteNets

text: Comparison of Properties

In our comparison we consider the following neural translation models : the Recurrent Continuous Translation Model ( RCTM ) 1 and 2 ; the RNN Enc - Dec ; the RNN Enc - Dec Att with the attentional pooling mechanism of which there area few variations ; the Grid LSTM translation model ) that uses a multi-dimensional architecture ; the Extended Neural GPU model ) that has a convolutional RNN architecture ; the ByteNet and the two Recurrent ByteNet variants .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: Our comparison criteria reflect the desiderata set out in Sect. 2.1 .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: We separate the first ( computation time ) desider - atum into three columns .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: The first column indicates the time complexity of the network as a function of the length of the sequences and is denoted by Time .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: The other two columns Net Sand Net T indicate , respectively , whether the source and the target network use a convolutional structure ( CNN ) or a recurrent one ( RNN ) ; a CNN structure has the advantage that it can be run in parallel along the length of the sequence .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: The second ( resolution preservation ) desideratum corresponds to the RP column , which indicates whether the source representation in the network is resolution preserving .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: Finally , the third desideratum ( short forward and backward flow paths ) is reflected by two columns .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: The Path S column corresponds to the length in layer steps of the shortest path between a source token and any output target token .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: Similarly , the Path T column corresponds to the length of the shortest path between an input target token and any output target token .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: Shorter paths lead to better forward and backward signal propagation .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: summarizes the properties of the models .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: The ByteNet , the Recurrent ByteNets and the RNN Enc - Dec are the only networks that have linear running time ( up to the constant c ) .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: The RNN Enc - Dec , however , does not preserve the source sequence resolution , a feature that aggravates learning for long sequences such as those that appear in character - to - character machine translation .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: The RCTM 2 , the RNN Enc - Dec Att , the Grid LSTM and the Extended Neural GPU do preserve the resolution , but at a cost of a quadratic running time .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: The ByteNet stands out also for its Path properties .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: The dilated structure of the convolutions connects any two source or target tokens in the sequences byway of a small number of network layers corresponding to the depth of the source or target networks .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: For character sequences where learning long - range dependencies is important , paths that are sublinear in the distance are advantageous .
heading: Comparison of Properties

text: Character Prediction
We first evaluate the ByteNet Decoder separately on a character - level language modelling benchmark .
heading: Character Prediction

text: We use the Hutter Prize version of the Wikipedia dataset and follow the standard split where the first 90 million bytes are used for training , the next 5 million bytes are used for validation and the last 5 million bytes are used for testing .
heading: Character Prediction

text: The total number of characters in the vocabulary is 205 .
heading: Character Prediction

text: The ByteNet Decoder that we use for the result has 30 residual blocks split into six sets of five blocks each ; for the five blocks in each set the dilation rates are , respectively , 1 , 2 , 4 , 8 and 16 .
heading: Character Prediction

text: The masked kernel has size 3 .
heading: Character Prediction

text: This gives a receptive field of 315 characters .
heading: Character Prediction

text: The number of hidden units dis 512 .
heading: Character Prediction

text: For this task we use residual multiplicative blocks .
heading: Character Prediction

text: For the optimization we use Adam with a learning rate of 0.0003 and a weight decay term of 0.0001 .
heading: Character Prediction

text: We apply dropout to the last ReLU layer before the softmax dropping units with a probability of 0.1 .
heading: Character Prediction

text: We do not reduce the learning rate during training .
heading: Character Prediction

text: At each step we sample a batch of sequences of 500 characters each , use the first 100 characters as the minimum context and predict the latter 400 characters .
heading: Character Prediction

text: lists recent results of various neural sequence models on the Wikipedia dataset .
heading: Character Prediction

text: All the results except for the ByteNet result are obtained using some variant of the LSTM recurrent neural network .
heading: Character Prediction

text: The ByteNet decoder achieves 1.31 bits / character on the test set .
heading: Character Prediction

text: Character - Level Machine Translation
We evaluate the full ByteNet on the WMT English to German translation task .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: We use NewsTest 2013 for validation and NewsTest 2014 and 2015 for testing .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: The English and German strings are encoded as sequences of characters ; no explicit segmentation into words or morphemes is applied to the strings .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: The outputs of the network are strings of characters in the target language .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: We keep 323 characters in the German vocabulary and 296 in the English vocabulary .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: The ByteNet used in the experiments has 30 residual blocks in the encoder and 30 residual blocks in the decoder .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: As in the ByteNet Decoder , the residual blocks are arranged in sets of five with corresponding dilation rates of 1 , 2 , 4 , 8 and 16 .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: For this task we use the residual blocks with ReLUs ( .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: The number of hidden units dis 800 .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: The size of the kernel in the source network is 3 , whereas the size of the masked kernel in the target network is 3 .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: For the optimization we use Adam with a learning rate of 0.0003 .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: Each sentence is padded with special characters to the nearest greater multiple of 50 ; 20 % of further padding is ap - plied to each source sentence as apart of dynamic unfolding ( eq. 2 ) .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: Each pair of sentences is mapped to a bucket based on the pair of padded lengths for efficient batching during training .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: We use vanilla beam search according to the total likelihood of the generated candidate and accept only candidates which end in a end -of - sentence token .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: We use abeam of size 12 .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: We do not use length normalization , nor do we keep score of which parts of the source sentence have been translated .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: and contain the results of the experiments .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: On NewsTest 2014 the ByteNet achieves the highest performance in character - level and subword - level neural machine translation , and compared to the word - level systems it is second only to the version of GNMT that uses word - pieces .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: On NewsTest 2015 , to our knowledge , ByteNet achieves the best published results to date .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: contains some of the unaltered generated translations from the ByteNet that highlight reordering and other phenomena such as transliteration .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: The character - level aspect of the model makes post -processing unnecessary in principle .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: We further visualize the sensitivity of the ByteNet 's predictions to specific source and target inputs using gradient - based visualization .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: represents a heatmap of the magnitude of the gradients of the generated outputs with respect to the source and target inputs .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: For visual clarity , we sum the gradients for all the characters that makeup each word and normalize the values along each column .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: In contrast with the attentional pooling mechanism , this general technique allows us to inspect not just dependencies of the outputs on the source inputs , but also dependencies of the outputs on previous target inputs , or on any other neural network layers .
heading: Character - Level Machine Translation

text: Conclusion
We have introduced the ByteNet , a neural translation model that has linear running time , decouples translation from memorization and has short signal propagation paths for tokens in sequences .
heading: Conclusion

text: We have shown that the ByteNet decoder is a state - of - the - art character - level language model based on a convolutional neural network that outperforms recurrent neural language models .
heading: Conclusion

text: We have also shown that the ByteNet generalizes the RNN Enc - Dec architecture and achieves state - of - the - art results for character - to - character machine translation and excellent results in general , while maintaining linear running time complexity .
heading: Conclusion

text: We have revealed the latent structure learnt by the ByteNet and found it to mirror the expected alignment between the tokens in the sentences ..
heading: Conclusion

text: Magnitude of gradients of the predicted outputs with respect to the source and target inputs .
heading: Conclusion

text: The gradients are summed for all the characters in a given word .
heading: Conclusion

text: In the bottom heatmap the magnitudes are nonzero on the diagonal , since the prediction of a target character depends highly on the preceding target character in the same word .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Attention Is All You Need
abstract
The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder .
heading: abstract

text: The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism .
heading: abstract

text: We propose anew simple network architecture , the Transformer , based solely on attention mechanisms , dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely .
heading: abstract

text: Experiments on two machine translation tasks show these models to be superior in quality while being more parallelizable and requiring significantly less time to train .
heading: abstract

text: Our model achieves 28.4 BLEU on the WMT 2014 Englishto - German translation task , improving over the existing best results , including ensembles , by over 2 BLEU .
heading: abstract

text: On the WMT 2014 English - to - French translation task , our model establishes anew single - model state - of - the - art BLEU score of 41.8 after training for 3.5 days on eight GPUs , a small fraction of the training costs of the best models from the literature .
heading: abstract

text: We show that the Transformer generalizes well to other tasks by applying it successfully to English constituency parsing both with large and limited training data .
heading: abstract

text: * Equal contribution .
heading: abstract

text: Listing order is random .
heading: abstract

text: Jakob proposed replacing RNNs with self - attention and started the effort to evaluate this idea .
heading: abstract

text: Ashish , with Illia , designed and implemented the first Transformer models and has been crucially involved in every aspect of this work .
heading: abstract

text: Noam proposed scaled dot-product attention , multi-head attention and the parameter - free position representation and became the other person involved in nearly every detail .
heading: abstract

heading: abstract

text: Llion also experimented with novel model variants , was responsible for our initial codebase , and efficient inference and visualizations .
heading: abstract
