text: Over-fitting
Deep models have more parameters , and thus have a stronger ability to fit the large data set .
heading: Over-fitting

text: However , our experimental results suggest that deep models are less prone to the problem of over-fitting .
heading: Over-fitting

text: In , we show three results from models with a different depth on the English - to - French task .
heading: Over-fitting

text: These three models are evaluated by token error rate , which is defined as the ratio of incorrectly predicted words in the whole target sequence with correct historical input .
heading: Over-fitting

text: The curve with square marks corresponds to Deep - Att with n e = 9 and n d = 7 .
heading: Over-fitting

text: The curve with circle marks corresponds ton e = 5 and n d = 3 .
heading: Over-fitting

text: The curve with triangle marks corresponds ton e = 1 and n d = 1 .
heading: Over-fitting

text: We find that the deep model has better performance on the test set when the token error rate is the same as that of the shallow models on the training set .
heading: Over-fitting

text: This shows that , with decreased token error rate , the deep model is more advantageous in avoiding the over - fitting phenomenon .
heading: Over-fitting

text: We only plot the early training stage curves because , during the late training stage , the curves are not smooth .
heading: Over-fitting

text: Conclusion

With the introduction of fast - forward connections to the deep LSTM network , we build a fast path with neither non-linear transformations nor recurrent computation to propagate the gradients from the top to the deep bottom .
heading: Conclusion

text: On this path , gradients decay much slower compared to the standard deep network .
heading: Conclusion

text: This enables us to build the deep topology of NMT models .
heading: Conclusion

text: We trained NMT models with depth of 16 including 25 LSTM layers and evaluated them mainly on the WMT ' 14 English - to - French translation task .
heading: Conclusion

text: This is the deepest topology that has been investigated in the NMT area on this task .
heading: Conclusion

text: We showed that our Deep - Att exhibits 6.2 BLEU points improvement over the previous best single model , achieving a 37.7 BLEU score .
heading: Conclusion

text: This single end - toend NMT model outperforms the best conventional SMT system and achieves a state - of - the - art performance .
heading: Conclusion

text: After utilizing unknown word processing and model ensemble of three models , we obtained a BLEU score of 40.4 , an improvement of 2.9 BLEU points over the previous best result .
heading: Conclusion

text: When evaluated on the subset of the test corpus without unknown words , our model achieves 41.4 .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our model is also validated on the more difficult English - to - German task .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our model is also efficient in sequence generation .
heading: Conclusion

text: The best results from both a single model and model ensemble are obtained with abeam size of 3 , much smaller than previous NMT systems where beam size is about 12
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Unsupervised Neural Machine Translation with Weight Sharing
abstract
Unsupervised neural machine translation ( NMT ) is a recently proposed approach for machine translation which aims to train the model without using any labeled data .
heading: abstract

text: The models proposed for unsupervised NMT often use only one shared encoder to map the pairs of sentences from different languages to a shared - latent space , which is weak in keeping the unique and internal characteristics of each language , such as the style , terminology , and sentence structure .
heading: abstract

text: To address this issue , we introduce an extension by utilizing two independent encoders but sharing some partial weights which are responsible for extracting high - level representations of the input sentences .
heading: abstract

text: Besides , two different generative adversarial networks ( GANs ) , namely the local GAN and global GAN , are proposed to enhance the cross - language translation .
heading: abstract

text: With this new approach , we achieve significant improvements on English - German , English - French and Chinese - to - English translation tasks .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Neural machine translation , directly applying a single neural network to transform the source sentence into the target sentence , has now reached impressive performance .
heading: Introduction

text: The NMT typically consists of two sub neural networks .
heading: Introduction

text: The encoder network reads and encodes the source sentence into a 1 Feng Wang is the corresponding author of this paper context vector , and the decoder network generates the target sentence iteratively based on the context vector .
heading: Introduction

text: NMT can be studied in supervised and unsupervised learning settings .
heading: Introduction

text: In the supervised setting , bilingual corpora is available for training the NMT model .
heading: Introduction

text: In the unsupervised setting , we only have two independent monolingual corpora with one for each language and there is no bilingual training example to provide alignment information for the two languages .
heading: Introduction

text: Due to lack of alignment information , the unsupervised NMT is considered more challenging .
heading: Introduction

text: However , this task is very promising , since the monolingual corpora is usually easy to be collected .
heading: Introduction

text: Motivated by recent success in unsupervised cross - lingual embeddings , the models proposed for unsupervised NMT often assume that a pair of sentences from two different languages can be mapped to a same latent representation in a shared - latent space .
heading: Introduction

text: Following this assumption , use a single encoder and a single decoder for both the source and target languages .
heading: Introduction

text: The encoder and decoder , acting as a standard auto - encoder ( AE ) , are trained to reconstruct the inputs .
heading: Introduction

text: And utilize a shared encoder but two independent decoders .
heading: Introduction

text: With some good performance , they share a glaring defect , i.e. , only one encoder is shared by the source and target languages .
heading: Introduction

text: Although the shared encoder is vital for mapping sentences from different languages into the shared - latent space , it is weak in keeping the uniqueness and internal characteristics of each language , such as the style , terminology and sentence structure .
heading: Introduction

text: Since each language has its own characteristics , the source and target languages should be encoded and learned independently .
heading: Introduction

text: Therefore , we conjecture that the shared encoder maybe a factor limit - ing the potential translation performance .
heading: Introduction

text: In order to address this issue , we extend the encoder - shared model , i.e. , the model with one shared encoder , by leveraging two independent encoders with each for one language .
heading: Introduction

text: Similarly , two independent decoders are utilized .
heading: Introduction

text: For each language , the encoder and its corresponding decoder perform an AE , where the encoder generates the latent representations from the perturbed input sentences and the decoder reconstructs the sentences from the latent representations .
heading: Introduction

text: To map the latent representations from different languages to a shared - latent space , we propose the weightsharing constraint to the two AEs .
heading: Introduction

text: Specifically , we share the weights of the last few layers of two encoders that are responsible for extracting highlevel representations of input sentences .
heading: Introduction

text: Similarly , we share the weights of the first few layers of two decoders .
heading: Introduction

text: To enforce the shared - latent space , the word embeddings are used as a reinforced encoding component in our encoders .
heading: Introduction

text: For cross - language translation , we utilize the backtranslation following .
heading: Introduction

text: Additionally , two different generative adversarial networks ( GAN ) , namely the local and global GAN , are proposed to further improve the cross - language translation .
heading: Introduction

text: We utilize the local GAN to constrain the source and target latent representations to have the same distribution , whereby the encoder tries to fool a local discriminator which is simultaneously trained to distinguish the language of a given latent representation .
heading: Introduction

text: We apply the global GAN to finetune the corresponding generator , i.e. , the composition of the encoder and decoder of the other language , where a global discriminator is leveraged to guide the training of the generator by assessing how far the generated sentence is from the true data distribution 1 .
heading: Introduction

text: In summary , we mainly make the following contributions :
heading: Introduction

text: We propose the weight - sharing constraint to unsupervised NMT , enabling the model to utilize an independent encoder for each language .
heading: Introduction

text: To enforce the shared - latent space , we also propose the embedding - reinforced encoders and two different GANs for our model .
heading: Introduction

text: We conduct extensive experiments on The code that we utilized to train and evaluate our models can be found at https://github.com/ZhenYangIACAS/unsupervised-NMT
heading: Introduction

text: English - German , English - French and Chinese - to - English translation tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: Experimental results show that the proposed approach consistently achieves great success .
heading: Introduction

text: Last but not least , we introduce the directional self - attention to model temporal order information for the proposed model .
heading: Introduction

text: Experimental results reveal that it deserves more efforts for researchers to investigate the temporal order information within self - attention layers of NMT .
heading: Introduction

text: Related Work
Several approaches have been proposed to train NMT models without direct parallel corpora .
heading: Related Work

text: The scenario that has been widely investigated is one where two languages have little parallel data between them but are well connected by one pivot language .
heading: Related Work

text: The most typical approach in this scenario is to independently translate from the source language to the pivot language and from the pivot language to the target language ( Saha et al .
heading: Related Work

text: The two works mentioned above both use a single shared encoder to guarantee the shared latent space .
heading: Related Work

text: However , a concomitant defect is that the shared encoder is weak in keeping the uniqueness of each language .
heading: Related Work

text: Our work also belongs to this more ambitious scenario , and to the best of our knowledge , we are one among the first endeavors to investigate how to train an NMT model with monolingual corpora only .
heading: Related Work

text: is the translation in reversed direction .
heading: Related Work

text: D l is utilized to assess whether the hidden representation of the encoder is from the source or target language .
heading: Related Work

text: D g 1 and D g 2 are used to evaluate whether the translated sentences are realistic for each language respectively .
heading: Related Work

text: Z represents the shared - latent space .
heading: Related Work

text: The Approach
Model Architecture
The model architecture , as illustrated in figure 1 , is based on the AE and GAN .
heading: Model Architecture

text: It consists of seven sub networks : including two encoders Enc sand Enc t , two decoders Dec sand Dec t , the local discriminator D l , and the global discriminators D g 1 and D g 2 .
heading: Model Architecture

text: For the encoder and decoder , we follow the newly emerged Transformer .
heading: Model Architecture

text: Specifically , the encoder is composed of a stack of four identical layers
heading: Model Architecture

text: Each layer consists of a multi-head self - attention and a simple position - wise fully connected feed - forward network .
heading: Model Architecture

text: The decoder is also composed of four identical layers .
heading: Model Architecture

text: In addition to the two sub-layers in each encoder layer , the decoder inserts a third sublayer , which performs multi-head attention over the output of the encoder stack .
heading: Model Architecture

text: For more details about the multi-head self - attention layer , we refer the reader to .
heading: Model Architecture

text: We implement the local discriminator as a multi -layer perceptron and implement the global discriminator based on the convolutional neural network ( CNN ) .
heading: Model Architecture

text: Several ways exist to interpret the roles of the sub networks are summarised in table
heading: Model Architecture

text: The proposed system has several striking components , which are critical either for the system to be trained in an 2 The layer number is selected according to our preliminary experiment , which is presented in appendix A. unsupervised manner or for improving the translation performance .
heading: Model Architecture

text: Networks
Roles : Interpretation of the roles for the subnetworks in the proposed system .
heading: Networks

text: Directional self - attention
heading: Networks

text: Compared to recurrent neural network , a disadvantage of the simple self - attention mechanism is that the temporal order information is lost .
heading: Networks

text: Although the Transformer applies the positional encoding to the sequence before processed by the self - attention , how to model temporal order information within an attention is still an open question .
heading: Networks

text: Following , we build the encoders in our model on the directional self - attention which utilizes the positional masks to encode temporal order information into attention output .
heading: Networks

text: More concretely , two positional masks , namely the forward mask M f and backward mask Mb , are calculated as :
heading: Networks

text: With the forward mask M f , the later token only makes attention connections to the early tokens in the sequence , and vice versa with the backward mask .
heading: Networks

text: Similar to , we utilize a self - attention network to process the input sequence in forward direction .
heading: Networks

text: The output of this layer is taken by an upper self - attention network as input , processed in the reverse direction .
heading: Networks

text: Weight sharing
Based on the shared - latent space assumption , we apply the weight sharing constraint to relate the two AEs .
heading: Weight sharing

text: Specifically , we share the weights of the last few layers of the Enc sand Enc t , which are responsible for extracting high - level representations of the input sentences .
heading: Weight sharing

text: Similarly , we also share the first few layers of the Dec sand Dec t , which are expected to decode high - level representations that are vital for reconstructing the input sentences .
heading: Weight sharing

text: Compared to which use the fully shared encoder , we only share partial weights for the encoders and decoders .
heading: Weight sharing

text: In the proposed model , the independent weights of the two encoders are expected to learn and encode the hidden features about the internal characteristics of each language , such as the terminology , style , and sentence structure .
heading: Weight sharing

text: The shared weights are utilized to map the hidden features extracted by the independent weights to the shared - latent space .
heading: Weight sharing

text: Embedding reinforced encoder
heading: Weight sharing

text: We use pretrained cross - lingual embeddings in the encoders that are kept fixed during training .
heading: Weight sharing

text: And the fixed embeddings are used as a reinforced encoding component in our encoder .
heading: Weight sharing

text: Formally , given the input sequence embedding vectors E = {e 1 , . . . , e t } and the initial output sequence of the encoder stack H = {h 1 , . . . , ht } , we compute H r as :
heading: Weight sharing

text: where H r is the final output sequence of the encoder which will be attended by the decoder ( In Transformer , H is the final output of the encoder ) , g is agate unit and computed as :
heading: Weight sharing

text: where W 1 , W 2 and bare trainable parameters and they are shared by the two encoders .
heading: Weight sharing

text: The motivation behind is twofold .
heading: Weight sharing

text: Firstly , taking the fixed cross - lingual embedding as the other encoding component is helpful to reinforce the sharedlatent space .
heading: Weight sharing

text: Additionally , from the point of multichannel encoders , providing encoding components with different levels of composition enables the decoder to take pieces of source sentence at varying composition levels suiting its own linguistic structure .
heading: Weight sharing

text: Unsupervised Training
Based on the architecture proposed above , we train the NMT model with the monolingual corpora only using the following four strategies :
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: Denoising auto - encoding
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: Firstly , we train the two AEs to reconstruct their inputs respectively .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: In this form , each encoder should learn to compose the embeddings of its corresponding language and each decoder is expected to learn to decompose this representation into its corresponding language .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: Nevertheless , without any constraint , the AE quickly learns to merely copy every word one by one , without capturing any internal structure of the language involved .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: To address this problem , we utilize the same strategy of denoising AE and add some noise to the input sentences .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: To this end , we shuffle the input sentences randomly .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: Specifically , we apply a random permutation ?
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: to the input sentence , verifying the condition :
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: where n is the length of the input sentence , steps is the global steps the model has been updated , k and s are the tunable parameters which can beset by users beforehand .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: This way , the system needs to learn some useful structure of the involved languages to be able to recover the correct word order .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: In practice , we set k = 2 and s = 100000 .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: Back - translation
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: In spite of denoising autoencoding , the training procedure still involves a single language at each time , without considering our final goal of mapping an input sentence from the source / target language to the target / source language .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: For the cross language training , we utilize the back - translation approach for our unsupervised training procedure .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: Back - translation has shown its great effectiveness on improving NMT model with monolingual data and has been widely investigated by .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: In our approach , given an input sentence in a given language , we apply the corresponding encoder and the decoder of the other language to translate it to the other language 3 .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: By combining the translation with its original sentence , we get a pseudo - parallel corpus which is utilized to train the model to reconstruct the original sentence from its translation .
heading: Unsupervised Training

text: Local GAN

Although the weight sharing constraint is vital for the shared - latent space assumption , it alone does not guarantee that the corresponding sentences in two languages will have the same or similar latent code .
heading: Local GAN

text: To further enforce the shared - latent space , we train a discriminative neural network , referred to as the local discriminator , to classify between the encoding of source sentences and the encoding of target sentences .
heading: Local GAN

text: The local discriminator , implemented as a multilayer perceptron with two hidden layers of size 256 , takes the output of the encoder , i.e. , H r calculated as equation 3 , as input , and produces a binary prediction about the language of the input sentence .
heading: Local GAN

text: The local discriminator is trained to predict the language by minimizing the following crossentropy loss :
heading: Local GAN

text: where ?
heading: Local GAN

text: D l represents the parameters of the local discriminator and f ? {s , t}.
heading: Local GAN

text: The encoders are trained to fool the local discriminator :
heading: Local GAN

text: where ?
heading: Local GAN

text: Encs and ?
heading: Local GAN

text: Enct are the parameters of the two encoders .
heading: Local GAN

text: Global GAN
We apply the global GANs to fine tune the whole model so that the model is able to generate sentences undistinguishable from the true data , i.e. , sentences in the training corpus .
heading: Global GAN

text: Different from the local GANs which updates the parameters of the encoders locally , the global GANs are utilized to update the whole parameters of the proposed model , including the parameters of encoders and decoders .
heading: Global GAN

text: The proposed model has two global GANs : GAN g 1 and GAN g 2 .
heading: Global GAN

text: In GAN g 1 , the Enc t and Dec s act as the generator , which generates the sentencex t 4 from x t .
heading: Global GAN

text: The D g 1 , implemented based on CNN , assesses whether the generated sentencex t is the true target - language sentence or the generated sentence .
heading: Global GAN

text: The global discriminator aims to distinguish among the true sentences and generated sentences , and it is trained to minimize its classification error rate .
heading: Global GAN

text: During training , the D g 1 feeds back its assessment to finetune the encoder Enc t and decoder Dec s .
heading: Global GAN

text: Since the machine translation is a sequence generation problem , following , we leverage policy gradient reinforcement training to back - propagate the assessment .
heading: Global GAN

text: We apply a similar processing to GAN g2 ( The details about the architecture of the global discriminator and the training procedure of the global GANs can be seen in appendix B and C ) .
heading: Global GAN

text: There are two stages in the proposed unsupervised training .
heading: Global GAN

text: In the first stage , we train the proposed model with denoising auto - encoding , backtranslation and the local GANs , until no improvement is achieved on the development set .
heading: Global GAN

text: Specifically , we perform one batch of denoising autoencoding for the source and target languages , one batch of back - translation for the two languages , and another batch of local GAN for the two languages .
heading: Global GAN

text: In the second stage , we fine tune the proposed model with the global GANs .
heading: Global GAN

text: Experiments and Results
We evaluate the proposed approach on English - German , English - French and Chinese - to - English translation tasks
heading: Experiments and Results

text: We firstly describe the datasets , pre-processing and model hyper - parameters we used , then we introduce the baseline systems , and finally we present our experimental results .
heading: Experiments and Results

text: Data Sets and Preprocessing
In English - German and English - French translation , we make our experiments comparable with previous work by using the datasets from the WMT 2014 and WMT 2016 shared tasks respectively .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: For Chinese - to - English translation , we use the datasets from LDC , which has been widely utilized by previous works .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: WMT14 English - French Similar to , we use the full training set of 36M sentence pairs and we lower - case them and remove sentences longer than 50 words , resulting in a parallel corpus of about 30M pairs of sentences .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: To guarantee no exact correspondence between the source and target monolingual sets , we build monolingual corpora by selecting English sentences from 15M random pairs , and selecting the French sentences from the complementary set .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: Sentences are encoded with byte - pair encoding , which has an English vocabulary of about 32000 tokens , and French vocabulary of about 33000 tokens .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: We report results on newstest2014 .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: WMT16 English - German
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: We follow the same procedure mentioned above to create monolingual training corpora for English - German translation , and we get two monolingual training data of 1.8 M sentences each .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: The two languages share a vocabulary of about 32000 tokens .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: We report results on newstest2016 .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: LDC Chinese - English For Chinese - to - English translation , our training data consists of 1.6 M sentence pairs randomly extracted from LDC corpora
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: Since the data set is not big enough , we just build the monolingual data set by randomly shuffling the Chinese and English sentences respectively .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: In spite of the fact that some correspondence between examples in these two monolingual sets may exist , we never utilize this alignment information in our training procedure ( see Section 3.2 ) .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: Both the Chinese and English sentences are encoded with byte - pair encoding .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: We get an English vocabulary of about 34000 tokens , and Chinese vocabulary of about 38000 tokens .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: The results are reported on N IST 02 .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: Since the proposed system relies on the pretrained cross - lingual embeddings , we utilize the monolingual corpora described above to train the embeddings for each language independently by using word2 vec .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: We then apply the public implementation 7 of the method proposed by to map these 6 LDC2002L27 , LDC2002T01 , LDC2002E18 , LDC2003E07 , LDC2004T08 , LDC2004E12 , LDC2005T10 7 https://github.com/artetxem/vecmap
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: embeddings to a shared - latent space 8 .
heading: Data Sets and Preprocessing

text: Model Hyper - parameters and Evaluation
Following the base model in , we set the dimension of word embedding as 512 , dropout rate as 0.1 and the head number as 8 .
heading: Model Hyper - parameters and Evaluation

text: We use beam search with abeam size of 4 and length penalty ? = 0.6 .
heading: Model Hyper - parameters and Evaluation

text: The model is implemented in TensorFlow and trained on up to four K80 GPUs synchronously in a multi - GPU setup on a single machine .
heading: Model Hyper - parameters and Evaluation

text: For model selection , we stop training when the model achieves no improvement for the tenth evaluation on the development set , which is comprised of 3000 source and target sentences extracted randomly from the monolingual training corpora .
heading: Model Hyper - parameters and Evaluation

text: Following ( Lample et al. , 2017 ) , we translate the source sentences to the target language , and then translate the resulting sentences back to the source language .
heading: Model Hyper - parameters and Evaluation

text: The quality of the model is then evaluated by computing the BLEU score over the original inputs and their reconstructions via this two - step translation process .
heading: Model Hyper - parameters and Evaluation

text: The performance is finally averaged over two directions , i.e. , from source to target and from target to source .
heading: Model Hyper - parameters and Evaluation

text: BLEU is utilized as the evaluation metric .
heading: Model Hyper - parameters and Evaluation

text: For Chinese - to - English , we apply the script mteval - v11 b. pl to evaluate the translation performance .
heading: Model Hyper - parameters and Evaluation

text: For English - German and English - French , we evaluate the translation performance with the script multi-belu.pl 9 .
heading: Model Hyper - parameters and Evaluation

text: Baseline Systems
Word - by - word translation ( WBW ) The first baseline we consider is a system that performs word - by - word translations using the inferred bilingual dictionary .
heading: Baseline Systems

text: Specifically , it translates a sentence word - by - word , replacing each word with its nearest neighbor in the other language .
heading: Baseline Systems

text: Lample et al .
heading: Baseline Systems

text: The second baseline is a previous work that uses the same training and testing sets with this paper .
heading: Baseline Systems

text: Their model belongs to the standard attention - based encoder - decoder framework , which implements the encoder using a bidirectional long short term memory network ( LSTM ) and implements the decoder using a sim - 8 The configuration we used to run these open - source toolkits can be found in appendix D 9 https://github.com/mosessmt/mosesdecoder/blob/617e8c8/scripts/generic/multibleu.perl;mteval-v11b.pl
heading: Baseline Systems

text: en - de de - en en - fr fr- en zh - en are copied directly from their paper .
heading: Baseline Systems

text: We do not present the results of ( Artetxe et al. , 2017 b ) since we use different training sets .
heading: Baseline Systems

text: ple forward LSTM .
heading: Baseline Systems

text: They apply one single encoder and decoder for the source and target languages .
heading: Baseline Systems

text: Supervised training
We finally consider exactly the same model as ours , but trained using the standard cross - entropy loss on the original parallel sentences .
heading: Supervised training

text: This model can be viewed as an upper bound for the proposed unsupervised model .
heading: Supervised training

text: Results and Analysis
Number of weight - sharing layers
heading: Results and Analysis

text: We firstly investigate how the number of weightsharing layers affects the translation performance .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: In this experiment , we vary the number of weightsharing layers in the AEs from 0 to 4 .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: Sharing one layer in AEs means sharing one layer for the encoders and in the meanwhile , sharing one layer for the decoders .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: The BLEU scores of English - to - German , English - to - French and Chinese - to - English translation tasks are reported in figure
heading: Results and Analysis

text: 2 . Each curve corresponds to a different translation task and the x - axis denotes the number of weight - sharing layers for the AEs .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: We find that the number of weight - sharing layers shows much effect on the translation performance .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: And the best translation performance is achieved when only one layer is shared in our system .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: When all of the four layers are shared , i.e. , only one shared encoder is utilized , we get poor translation performance in all of the three translation tasks .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: This verifies our conjecture that the shared encoder is detrimental to the performance of unsupervised NMT especially for the translation tasks on distant language pairs .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: More concretely , for the related language pair translation , i.e. , English - to - French , the encoder - shared model achieves - 0.53 BLEU points decline than the best model where only one layer is shared .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: For the more distant language pair English - to - German , the encoder - shared model achieves more significant decline , i.e. , - 0.85 BLEU points decline .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: And for the most distant language pair Chinese - to - English , the decline is as large as - 1.66 BLEU points .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: We explain this as that the more distant the language pair is , the more different characteristics they have .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: And the shared encoder is weak in keeping the unique characteristic of each language .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: Additionally , we also notice that using two completely independent encoders , i.e. , setting the number of weight - sharing layers as 0 , results in poor translation performance too .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: This confirms our intuition that the shared layers are vital to map the source and target latent representations to a shared - latent space .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: In the rest of our experiments , we set the number of weightsharing layer as 1 . model only trained with monolingual data effectively learns to use the context information and the internal structure of each language .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: Compared to the work of ( Lample et al. , 2017 ) , our model also achieves up to + 1.92 BLEU points improvement on English - to - French translation task .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: We believe that the unsupervised NMT is very promising .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: However , there is still a large room for improvement compared to the supervised upper bound .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: The gap between the supervised and unsupervised model is as large as 12.3 - 25.5 BLEU points depending on the language pair and translation direction .
heading: Results and Analysis

text: Translation results
Ablation study

To understand the importance of different components of the proposed system , we perform an ablation study by training multiple versions of our model with some missing components : the local GANs , the global GANs , the directional self - attention , the weight - sharing , the embeddingreinforced encoders , etc .
heading: Ablation study

text: Results are reported in table 3 .
heading: Ablation study

text: We do not test the the importance of the auto - encoding , back - translation and the pre-trained embeddings because they have been widely tested in .
heading: Ablation study

text: shows that the best performance is obtained with the simultaneous use of all the tested elements .
heading: Ablation study

text: The most critical component is the weight - sharing constraint , which is vital to map sentences of different languages to the shared - latent space .
heading: Ablation study

text: The embedding - reinforced encoder also brings some improvement on all of the translation tasks .
heading: Ablation study

text: When we remove the directional self - attention , we getup to - 0.3 BLEU points decline .
heading: Ablation study

text: This indicates that it deserves more efforts to investigate the temporal order information in self - attention mechanism .
heading: Ablation study

text: The GANs also significantly improve the translation performance of our system .
heading: Ablation study

text: Specifically , the global GANs achieve improvement up to + 0.78 BLEU points on English - to - French translation and the local GANs also obtain improvement up to + 0.57 BLEU points on English - to - French translation .
heading: Ablation study

text: This reveals that the proposed model benefits a lot from the crossdomain loss defined by GANs .
heading: Ablation study

text: Conclusion and Future work
The models proposed recently for unsupervised NMT use a single encoder to map sentences from different languages to a shared - latent space .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: We conjecture that the shared encoder is problematic for keeping the unique and inherent characteristic of each language .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: In this paper , we propose the weight - sharing constraint in unsupervised NMT to address this issue .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: To enhance the cross - language translation performance , we also propose the embedding - reinforced encoders , local GAN and global GAN into the proposed system .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: Additionally , the directional self - attention is introduced to model the temporal order information for our system .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: We test the proposed model on English - German , English - French and Chinese - to - English translation tasks .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: The experimental results reveal that our approach achieves significant improvement and verify our conjecture that the shared encoder is really a bottleneck for improving the unsupervised NMT .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: The ablation study shows that each component of our system achieves some improvement for the final translation performance .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: Unsupervised NMT opens exciting opportunities for the future research .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: However , there is still a large room for improvement compared to the supervised NMT .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: In the future , we would like to investigate how to utilize the monolingual data more effectively , such as incorporating the language model and syntactic information into unsupervised NMT .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: Besides , we decide to make more efforts to explore how to reinforce the temporal order information for the proposed model .
heading: Conclusion and Future work

text: title
Tilde 's Machine Translation Systems for WMT 2018
heading: title

text: abstract
The paper describes the development process of the Tilde 's NMT systems that were submitted for the WMT 2018 shared task on news translation .
heading: abstract

text: We describe the data filtering and pre-processing workflows , the NMT system training architectures , and automatic evaluation results .
heading: abstract

text: For the WMT 2018 shared task , we submitted seven systems ( both constrained and unconstrained ) for English - Estonian and Estonian - English translation directions .
heading: abstract

text: The submitted systems were trained using Transformer models .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Neural machine translation ( NMT ) is a rapidly changing research area .
heading: Introduction

text: Since 2016 when NMT systems first showed to achieve significantly better results than statistical machine translation ( SMT ) systems , the dominant neural network ( NN ) architectures for NMT have changed on a yearly ( and even more frequent ) basis .
heading: Introduction

text: The state - of - the - art in 2016 were shallow attention - based recurrent neural networks ( RNN ) with gated recurrent units ( GRU ) in recurrent layers .
heading: Introduction

text: In 2017 , multiplicative long short - term memory ( MLSTM ) units and deep GRU models were introduced in NMT .
heading: Introduction

text: The same year , selfattentional ( Transformer ) models were introduced .
heading: Introduction

text: Consequently , in 2018 , most of the top scoring systems in the shared task on news translation of the Third Conference on Machine Translation ( WMT ) were trained using Transformer models
heading: Introduction

text: However , it is already evident that the state - of - the - art architectures will 1 All 14 of the best automatically scored systems according to the information provided by participants in the official submission portal http://matrix.statmt.org were indicated as being based on Transformer models .
heading: Introduction

text: be pushed even further in 2018 .
heading: Introduction

text: For instance , have recently proposed RNMT + models that combine deep LSTM - based models with multi-head attention and showed that the models outperform Transformer models .
heading: Introduction

text: In WMT 2017 , Tilde participated with MLSTM - based NMT systems .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we compare the MLSTMbased models with Transformer models for English - Estonian and Estonian - English and we show that the state - of - the - art of WMT 2017 is well behind the new models .
heading: Introduction

text: Therefore , for WMT 2018 , Tilde submitted NMT systems that were trained using Transformer models .
heading: Introduction

text: The paper is further structured as follows :
heading: Introduction

text: Section 2 provides an overview of systems submitted for the WMT 2018 shared task on news translation , Section 3 describes the data used to train the NMT systems and the data pre-processing workflows , Section 4 describes all NMT systems trained and experiments on handling of named entities and combination of systems , Section 5 provides automatic evaluation results , and Section 6 concludes the paper .
heading: Introduction

text: System Overview
For the WMT 2018 shared task on news translation , Tilde submitted both constrained and unconstrained NMT systems ( 7 in total ) .
heading: System Overview

text: The following is a list of the five MT systems submitted :
heading: System Overview

text: Constrained English - Estonian and Estonian - English NMT systems ( tilde - c-nmt ) that were deployed as ensembles of averaged factored data ( see Section 3 ) Transformer models .
heading: System Overview

text: The models were trained using parallel data and back - translated data in a 1 - to - 1 proportion .
heading: System Overview

text: Unconstrained English - Estonian and Estonian - English NMT systems ( tilde - nc - nmt ) that were deployed as averaged Transformer models .
heading: System Overview

text: These models were also trained using back - translated data similarly to the constrained systems , however , the data , taking into account their relatively large size , were not factored .
heading: System Overview

text: A constrained Estonian - English NMT system ( tilde - c - nmt - comb ) that is a system combination of six factored data NMT systems .
heading: System Overview

text: Constrained English - Estonian and Estonian - English NMT systems ( tilde - c - nmt - 2 bt ) averaged from multiple best NMT models .
heading: System Overview

text: The models were trained using two sets of back - translated data in a 1 - to - 1 proportion to the clean parallel data - one set was backtranslated using a system trained on parallelonly data and the other set -using an NMT system trained on parallel data and the first set of back - translated data .
heading: System Overview

text: Data
Data preparation was done using one of two distinct workflows - we used the full workflow for tilde - c - nmt , tilde - nc - nmt and tilde - c - nmt - comb submissions .
heading: Data

text: For the tilde - c - nmt - 2 bt submission we used the light data preparation workflow .
heading: Data

text: Full Workflow
First , we trained constrained system baseline models using the filtered datasets .
heading: Full Workflow

text: For baseline models , we used the MLSTM and transf configurations ( see ) .
heading: Full Workflow

text: Then , we used the best - performing models ( based on translation quality on the vali -dation set ) , which were the Transformer models ( see , and back - translated monolingual data .
heading: Full Workflow

text: As mentioned before , for the unconstrained systems , we back - translated the monolingual data using pre-existing MLSTM - based NMT systems .
heading: Full Workflow

text: Then , using the final training data ( parallel and the two synthetic corpora ) , we trained final Transformer models .
heading: Full Workflow

text: For the constrained scenario , we trained multiple models ( three for each translation direction ) by experimenting with multiple model configurations .
heading: Full Workflow

text: For the unconstrained scenario , we trained one model in each of the directions .
heading: Full Workflow

text: In order to acquire the translations for the submissions , we performed model averaging and ensembling as follows :
heading: Full Workflow

text: For the tilde - c - nmt ( constrained NMT ) systems , we performed model averaging of the best four models ( according to perplexity ) of the three different run NMT systems and deployed the averaged models in an ensemble .
heading: Full Workflow

text: For the tilde - nc - nmt ( unconstrained NMT ) systems , we performed model averaging of the best four models .
heading: Full Workflow

text: For the tilde - c - nmt - comb Estonian - English system , we performed majority voting ( see Section 4.3 ) of translations produced by six different runs of different constrained systems ( using best BLEU models , averaged models , ensembled averaged models , ensembled models , and larger beam search ( 10 instead of 5 ) ) .
heading: Full Workflow

text: Data Filtering
As NMT systems are sensitive to noise in parallel data , all parallel data were filtered using the parallel data filtering methods described by .
heading: Data Filtering

text: The parallel corpora filtering methods remove sentence pairs that have indications of data corruption or low parallelity ( e.g. , source - target length ratio , content overlap , digit mismatch , language adherence , etc. ) issues .
heading: Data Filtering

text: Contrary to Tilde 's submissions for WMT 2017 , isolated sentence pair filtering for the WMT 2018 submissions was supplemented with a maximum content overlap filter ( i.e. only one target sentence for each source sentence was preserved and vice versa based on the content overlap filter 's score for each sentence pair ) .
heading: Data Filtering

text: For filtering , we required probabilistic dictionaries , which were obtained from the parallel corpora ( different dictionaries for the constrained and unconstrained scenarios ) using fast align .
heading: Data Filtering

text: The dictionaries were filtered using the transliteration - based probabilistic dictionary filtering method by .
heading: Data Filtering

text: During filtering , we identified that one of the corpora that were provided by the organisers contained a significant amount of data corruption .
heading: Data Filtering

text: It was the Estonian ?
heading: Data Filtering

text: English ParaCrawl corpus
heading: Data Filtering

text: The corpus consisted of 1.30 million sentence pairs out of which 0.77 million were identified as being corrupt .
heading: Data Filtering

text: To reduce the high level of noise , this corpus was filtered using stricter content overlap ( a threshold of 0.3 instead of 0.1 ) and language adherence filters ( both the language detection and the valid alphabet filters had to validate a sentence pair instead of just one of the filters ) than all other corpora .
heading: Data Filtering

text: As a result , only 0.17 million sentence pairs from the ParaCrawl corpus were used for training of the constrained systems .
heading: Data Filtering

text: Due to the quality concerns , the corpus was not used for training of the unconstrained systems .
heading: Data Filtering

text: The corpora statistics before and after filtering are provided in .
heading: Data Filtering

text: Data Pre-processing
All corpora were pre-processed using the parallel data pre-processing workflow from the Tilde MT platform ) that performs the following pre-processing steps :
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: First , parallel corpora are cleaned by removing HTML and XML tags , decoding escaped symbols , normalising whitespaces and punctuation marks , replacing control characters with spaces , etc .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: This step is performed only on the training data .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: Then , non-translatable entities , such as email addresses , URLs , file paths , etc. are identified and replaced with place - holders .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: This allows reducing data sparsity where it is not needed .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: Then , the data are tokenised using the Tilde MT regular expression - based tokeniser .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: The Moses truecasing script truecase .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: perl is used to truecase the first word of every sentence .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: Then , tokens are split into sub - word units using byte - pair encoding ( BPE ) .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: For the constrained and unconstrained systems , we use BPE models consisting of 24,500 and 49,500 merging operations respectively .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: Finally , data for the constrained systems are factored using an averaged perceptron - based morpho-syntactic tagger for Estonian and the lexicalized probabilistic parser , we introduce also a factor indicating a word part 's position in a word ( beginning , middle , end , or the word part represents the whole word - B , I , E , or O ) .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: As a result , the Estonian data consist of the the following factors : word part , position , lemma , and morpho-syntactic tag .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: The English data consist of the following factors : word part , position , lemma , part - of - speech tag , and syntactic function .
heading: Data Pre-processing

text: Synthetic Data
Similarly to Tilde 's 2017 systems , we submitted systems that were trained using synthetic data :
heading: Synthetic Data

text: 1 ) back - translated data , and 2 ) data infused with unknown token identifiers .
heading: Synthetic Data

text: The back - translated data allow performing domain adaptation and the second type of synthetic data allow training NMT models that are robust to unknown phenomena ( e.g. , code - mixed content , target language words in the source text , rare or unseen words , etc . ) .
heading: Synthetic Data

text: To create the synthetic corpora with unknown phenomena , we extracted fast align the parallel corpora and randomly replaced one to three unambiguously ( one - to - one ) aligned content words with unknown word identifiers .
heading: Synthetic Data

text: These synthetic corpora were added to the parallel corpora , thereby almost doubling the sizes of the available training data .
heading: Synthetic Data

text: The back - translated data were acquired from two sources :
heading: Synthetic Data

text: 1 ) the constrained system data were acquired from initial Transformer - based NMT systems that were trained on the filtered and preprocessed parallel data , which were supplemented with the unknown phenomena infused data , and 2 ) the unconstrained system data were acquired from pre-existing unconstrained MLSTM - based NMT systems - the NMT systems that were developed by Tilde for the Estonian EU Council Presidency in 2017 .
heading: Synthetic Data

text: In order to limit noise , the back - translated data were filtered using the same parallel data filtering methods that were described in Section 3.1.1 ( although with a higher threshold for the content overlap filter ) .
heading: Synthetic Data

text: Furthermore , in order to train the final systems , we also generated unknown phenomena infused data for the back - translated filtered data , thereby also almost doubling the sizes of the back - translated data .
heading: Synthetic Data

text: The synthetic corpora statistics and the sizes of the total training data are given in .
heading: Synthetic Data

text: Light Workflow
The light workflow was used to produce the tilde - c - nmt - 2 bt ( constrained NMT with two sets of back - translated data ) systems .
heading: Light Workflow

text: First , we trained baseline models using only filtered parallel datasets ( Parallel - only in ) .
heading: Light Workflow

text: Then , we back - translated the first batches of monolingual news data and trained intermediate NMT systems ( Parallel + First Back - translated ) .
heading: Light Workflow

text: Finally , we used the intermediate NMT systems to backtranslate the second batches of monolingual news data and trained final NMT systems ( Parallel + Second Back - translated ) .
heading: Light Workflow

text: The training progress in shows that the English - Estonian system benefits from the additional data , but the system in the other direction - not so much .
heading: Light Workflow

text: For the final translations , we used a postprocessing script to replace consecutive repeating n-grams and repeating ngrams that have a preposition between them ( i.e. , victim of the victim ) with a single n-gram .
heading: Light Workflow

text: This problem was more apparent in RNN - based NMT systems , but it was also noticable in our Transformer model outputs .
heading: Light Workflow

text: NMT
Systems
In order to train the NMT systems , we used the Nematus ( Sennrich et al. , 2017 b ) ( for MLSTM models ) and Sockeye ) ( for Transformer models ) toolkits .
heading: Systems

text: All models were trained until convergence ( i.e. , until an early stopping criterion was met ) .
heading: Systems

text: Figure 1 : NMT system training progress ( BLEU scores on the validation set ) for English - Estonian ( left ) and
heading: Systems

text: Estonian - English ( right ) .
heading: Systems

text: Note that batch size may differ between different architectures and BLEU scores are calculated on raw ( token level ) pre-processed validation sets , therefore , the scores are slightly higher than evaluation results for the final translations !
heading: Systems

text: Automatic Post - editing of Named Entities
NMT models so far have struggled with translating rare or unseen words ( not different surface forms , but rather different words ) correctly .
heading: Automatic Post - editing of Named Entities

text: Named entities and non-translatable entities ( various product names , identifiers , etc. ) are often rare or unknown .
heading: Automatic Post - editing of Named Entities

text: In order to aid the NMT model in translating such tokens better , we extracted named entity and non-translatable token dictionaries from the parallel corpora .
heading: Automatic Post - editing of Named Entities

text: This was done by performing word alignment of the parallel corpora using fast align and searching ( in a language - agnostic manner ) for transliterated source - target word pairs using a similarity metric based on Levenshtein distance , which start with upper-case letters .
heading: Automatic Post - editing of Named Entities

text: The dictionaries consist of 15.6 ( 94.7 ) thousand and 6.2 ( 149.8 ) thousand entries for the constrained ( unconstrained ) English - Estonian and Estonian - English NMT systems respectively .
heading: Automatic Post - editing of Named Entities

text: When the NMT systems had translated a sentence , source - to - target word alignment was extracted from the source sentence and the translation .
heading: Automatic Post - editing of Named Entities

text: Then named entity recognition ( based on dictionary look - up ) was performed on the source text and , if a named entity was found , the target translation was validated against the entries in the dic-tionary .
heading: Automatic Post - editing of Named Entities

text: In order to capture different surface forms , a stemming tool was used .
heading: Automatic Post - editing of Named Entities

text: If a translation was contradicting the entries in the dictionary , it was replaced with the closest matching ( by looking for the longest matching suffix ) translation from the dictionary .
heading: Automatic Post - editing of Named Entities

text: The automatic post-editing method for named entities has a marginal impact on translation quality , however , manual analysis showed that more named entities were corrected than ruined .
heading: Automatic Post - editing of Named Entities

text: System Combination
We attempted to increase the quality of existing translations by employing a voting scheme in which multiple machine translation outputs are combined to produce a single translation .
heading: System Combination

text: We used a custom implementation of the majority voting algorithm to combine six of our best - scoring outputs in the Estonian - English translation direction in the constrained scenario .
heading: System Combination

text: We did not perform the combination for English - Estonian due to lack of support for alignment extraction for Estonian in Meteor .
heading: System Combination

text: MT system translation combination happens on the sentence level .
heading: System Combination

text: The majority voting scheme assumes a single base translation hypothesis ( primary hypothesis ) which is aligned at the word level to each of the other hypotheses ( secondary hypotheses ) .
heading: System Combination

text: The alignments are used to generate a table of all possible word translations relative to each position in the primary hypothesis .
heading: System Combination

text: The table is then used to count the number of occurrences of different translations .
heading: System Combination

text: The word translations with the highest count at each position constitute the resulting combined hypothesis .
heading: System Combination

text: To acquire the necessary word alignments we used Meteor .
heading: System Combination

text: Meteor outputs were then converted to a more easily manageable form using the Jane toolkit ) ( we used an awk script distributed with Jane ) .
heading: System Combination

text: The majority voting algorithm was implemented in Python .
heading: System Combination

text: Results
We performed automatic evaluation of the NMT systems using the SacreBLEU evaluation tool .
heading: Results

text: The results ( see ) show that the Transformer models achieved better results than the MLSTM - based models .
heading: Results

text: For the constrained scenarios , both ensembles of averaged models achieved higher scores than each individual averaged model .
heading: Results

text: It is also evident that the unconstrained models ( tilde - nc - nmt ) achieved the best results .
heading: Results

text: Although the unconstrained models were not trained on factored data , the datasets were 17 times larger than the constrained datasets .
heading: Results

text: However , the difference is rather minimal and shows that the current NMT architectures may notable to learn effectively from large datasets .
heading: Results

text: The official human evaluation results ( see Table 5 ) from the WMT 2018 shared task on news translation our unconstrained scenario systems ( tilde - nc - nmt ) ranked significantly higher than any other submission for both translation directions .
heading: Results

text: Our best constrained systems were the second highest ranked systems among all constrained scenario systems , at the same time sharing the same cluster with the highest ranked systems .
heading: Results

text: Conclusion
The paper described the development process of the Tilde 's NMT systems that were submitted for the WMT 2018 shared task on news translation .
heading: Conclusion

text: We compared Transformer models to MLSTMbased models and showed that the Transformer models outperform the older NMT architecture .
heading: Conclusion

text: We also showed that double back - translation may improve translation quality further than single back - translation .
heading: Conclusion

text: In terms of model ensembling and averaging , we showed that the best results in the constrained scenario were achieved by en - :
heading: Conclusion

text: Top three systems for the constrained ( C ) and unconstrained ( U ) scenarios according to the official results of the WMT 2018 shared task on news translation ; ordered by the direct assessment ( DA ) standardized mean score sembling different run averaged models .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
FRAGE : Frequency - Agnostic Word Representation
heading: title

text: abstract
Continuous word representation ( aka word embedding ) is a basic building block in many neural network - based models used in natural language processing tasks .
heading: abstract

text: Although it is widely accepted that words with similar semantics should be close to each other in the embedding space , we find that word embeddings learned in several tasks are biased towards word frequency : the embeddings of highfrequency and low - frequency words lie in different subregions of the embedding space , and the embedding of a rare word and a popular word can be far from each other even if they are semantically similar .
heading: abstract

text: This makes learned word embeddings ineffective , especially for rare words , and consequently limits the performance of these neural network models .
heading: abstract

text: In this paper , we develop a neat , simple yet effective way to learn FRequency - AGnostic word Embedding ( FRAGE ) using adversarial training .
heading: abstract

text: We conducted comprehensive studies on ten datasets across four natural language processing tasks , including word similarity , language modeling , machine translation and text classification .
heading: abstract

text: Results show that with FRAGE , we achieve higher performance than the baselines in all tasks .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction

Word embeddings , which are distributed and continuous vector representations for word tokens , have been one of the basic building blocks for many neural network - based models used in natural language processing ( NLP ) tasks , such as language modeling , text classification and machine translation .
heading: Introduction

text: Different from classic one - hot representation , the learned word embeddings contain semantic information which can measure the semantic similarity between words , and can also be transferred into other learning tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: In deep learning approaches for NLP tasks , word embeddings act as the inputs of the neural network and are usually trained together with neural network parameters .
heading: Introduction

text: As the inputs of the neural network , word embeddings carryall the information of words that will be further processed by the network , and the quality of embeddings is critical and highly impacts the final performance of the learning task .
heading: Introduction

text: Unfortunately , we find the word embeddings learned by many deep learning approaches are far from perfect .
heading: Introduction

text: As shown in ( a ) and 1 ( b ) , in the embedding space learned by word2 vec model , the nearest neighbors of word " Peking " includes " quickest " , " multicellular " , and " epigenetic " , which are not semantically similar , while semantically related words such as " Beijing " and " China " are far from it .
heading: Introduction

text: Similar phenomena are observed from the word embeddings learned from translation tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: With a careful study , we find a more general problem which is rooted in low - frequency words in the text corpus .
heading: Introduction

text: Without any confusion , we also call high - frequency words as popular words and call low - frequency words as rare words .
heading: Introduction

text: As is well known , the frequency distribution of words roughly follows a simple mathematical form known as Zipf 's law .
heading: Introduction

text: When the size of a text corpus grows , the frequency of rare words is much smaller than popular words while the number of unique rare words is much larger than popular words .
heading: Introduction

text: Interestingly , the learned embeddings of rare words and popular words behave differently .
heading: Introduction

text: In the embedding space , a popular word usually has semantically related neighbors , while a rare word usually does not .
heading: Introduction

text: Moreover , the nearest neighbors of more than 85 % rare words are rare words .
heading: Introduction

text: Word embeddings encode frequency information .
heading: Introduction

text: As shown in ( a ) and 1 ( b ) , the embeddings of rare words and popular words actually lie in different subregions of the space .
heading: Introduction

text: Such a phenomenon is also observed in .
heading: Introduction

text: We argue that the different behaviors of the embeddings of popular words and rare words are problematic .
heading: Introduction

text: First , such embeddings will affect the semantic understanding of words .
heading: Introduction

text: We observe more than half of the rare words are nouns or variants of popular words .
heading: Introduction

text: Those rare words should have similar meanings or share the same topics with popular words .
heading: Introduction

text: Second , the neighbors of a large number of rare words are semantically unrelated rare words .
heading: Introduction

text: To some extent , those word embeddings encode more frequency information than semantic information which is not good from the view of semantic understanding .
heading: Introduction

text: It will consequently limit the performance of down - stream tasks using the embeddings .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , in text classification , it can not be well guaranteed that the label of a sentence does not change when you replace one popular / rare word in the sentence by its rare / popular alternatives .
heading: Introduction

text: To address this problem , in this paper , we propose an adversarial training method to learn FRequency - AGnostic word Embedding ( FRAGE ) .
heading: Introduction

text: For a given NLP task , in addition to minimize the task - specific loss by optimizing the task - specific parameters together with word embeddings , we introduce another discriminator , which takes a word embedding as input and classifies whether it is a popular / rare word .
heading: Introduction

text: The discriminator optimizes its parameters to maximize its classification accuracy , while word embeddings are optimized towards a low task - dependent loss as well as fooling the discriminator to mis-classify the popular and rare words .
heading: Introduction

text: When the whole training process converges and the system achieves an equilibrium , the discriminator can not well differentiate popular words from rare words .
heading: Introduction

text: Consequently , rare words lie in the same region as and are mixed with popular words in the embedding space .
heading: Introduction

text: Then FRAGE will catch better semantic information and help the task - specific model to perform better .
heading: Introduction

text: We conduct experiments on four types of NLP tasks , including three word similarity tasks , two language modeling tasks , three sentiment classification tasks and two machine translation tasks to test our method .
heading: Introduction

text: In all tasks , FRAGE outperforms the baselines .
heading: Introduction

text: Specifically , in language modeling and machine translation , we achieve better performance than the state - of - the - art results on PTB , WT2 and WMT14 English - German datasets .
heading: Introduction

text: Background
Word Representation

Words are the basic units of natural languages , and distributed word representations ( i.e. , word embeddings ) are the basic units of many models in NLP tasks including language modeling and machine translation .
heading: Word Representation

text: It has been demonstrated that word representations learned from one task can be transferred to other tasks and achieve competitive performance .
heading: Word Representation

text: While word embeddings play an important role in neural network - based models in NLP and achieve great success , one technical challenge is that the embeddings of rare words are difficult to train due to their low frequency of occurrences .
heading: Word Representation

text: develops a novel way to split word into sub- word units which is widely used in neural machine translation .
heading: Word Representation

text: However , the low - frequency sub- word units are still difficult to train : provides a comprehensive study which shows that the rare ( sub ) words are usually under-estimated in neural machine translation : during inference step , the model tends to choose popular words over their rare alternatives .
heading: Word Representation

text: Adversarial Training
The basic idea of our work to address the above problem is adversarial training , in which two or more models learn together by pursuing competing goals .
heading: Adversarial Training

text: A representative example of adversarial training is Generative Adversarial Networks ( GANs ) for image generation , in which a discriminator and a generator compete with each other : the generator aims to generate images similar to the natural ones , and the discriminator aims to detect the generated ones from the natural ones .
heading: Adversarial Training

text: Recently , adversarial training has been successfully applied to NLP tasks .
heading: Adversarial Training

text: introduce an additional discriminator to differentiate the semantics learned from different languages in non-parallel bilingual data .
heading: Adversarial Training

text: develops a discriminator to classify whether a sentence is created by human or generated by a model .
heading: Adversarial Training

text: Our proposed method is under the adversarial training framework but not exactly the conventional generator - discriminator approach since there is no generator in our scenario .
heading: Adversarial Training

text: For an NLP task and its neural network model ( including word embeddings ) , we introduce a discriminator to differentiate embeddings of popular words and rare words ; while the NN model aims to fool the discriminator and minimize the task - specific loss simultaneously .
heading: Adversarial Training

text: Our work is also weakly related to adversarial domain adaptation which attempts to mitigate the negative effects of domain shift between training and testing .
heading: Adversarial Training

text: The difference between this work and adversarial domain adaptation is that we do not target at the mismatch between training and testing ; instead , we aim to improve the effectiveness of word embeddings and consequently improve the performance of end - to - end NLP tasks .
heading: Adversarial Training

text: Empirical Study

In this section , we study the embeddings of popular words and rare words based on the models trained from Google News corpora using word2vec 1 and trained from WMT14 English - German translation task using Transformer .
heading: Empirical Study

text: The implementation details can be found in the supplementary material ( part A ) .
heading: Empirical Study

text: Experimental Design

In both tasks , we simply set the top 20 % frequent words in vocabulary as popular words and denote the rest as rare words ( roughly speaking , we set a word as a rare word if it s relative frequency is lower than 10 ? 6 in WMT14 dataset and 10 ? 7 in Google News dataset ) .
heading: Experimental Design

text: We have tried other thresholds such as 10 % or 25 % and found the observations are similar .
heading: Experimental Design

text: We study whether the semantic relationship between two words is reasonable .
heading: Experimental Design

text: To achieve this , we randomly sampled some rare / popular words and checked the embeddings trained from different tasks .
heading: Experimental Design

text: For each sampled word , we determined its nearest neighbors based on the cosine similarity between its embeddings and others '.
heading: Experimental Design

text: We also manually chose words which are semantically similar to it .
heading: Experimental Design

text: For simplicity , for each word , we call the nearest words predicted from the embeddings as model - predicted neighbors , and call our chosen words as semantic neighbors .
heading: Experimental Design

text: Observation
To visualize word embeddings , we reduce their dimensionalities by SVD and plot two cases in .
heading: Observation

text: More cases and other studies without dimensionality reduction can be found in the supplementary material ( part C ) .
heading: Observation

text: We find that the embeddings trained from different tasks share some common patterns .
heading: Observation

text: For both tasks , more than 90 % of model - predicted neighbors of rare words are rare words .
heading: Observation

text: For each rare word , the model - predicted neighbor is usually not semantically related to this word , and semantic neighbors we chose are faraway from it in the embedding space .
heading: Observation

text: In contrast , the model - predicted neighbors of popular words are very reasonable .
heading: Observation

text: As the patterns in rare words are different from that of popular words , we further check the whole embedding matrix to make a general understanding .
heading: Observation

text: We also visualize the word embeddings using SVD by keeping the two directions with top - 2 largest eigenvalues as in and plot them in
heading: Observation

heading: Input Tokens Word Embeddings

text: Model

Rare / Popular Labels Discriminator
Loss predict predict :
heading: Rare / Popular Labels Discriminator

text: The proposed learning framework includes a task - specific predictor and a discriminator , whose function is to classify rare and popular words .
heading: Rare / Popular Labels Discriminator

text: Both modules use word embeddings as the input .
heading: Rare / Popular Labels Discriminator

text: a certain degree : the rare words and popular words lie in different regions after this linear projection , and thus they occupy different regions in the original embedding space .
heading: Rare / Popular Labels Discriminator

text: This strange phenomenon is also observed in other learned embeddings ( e.g. CBOW and GLOVE ) and mentioned in .
heading: Rare / Popular Labels Discriminator

text: Explanation
From the empirical study above , we can see that the occupied spaces of popular words and rare words are different and here we intuitively explain a possible reason .
heading: Explanation

text: We simply take word2vec as an example which is trained by stochastic gradient descent .
heading: Explanation

text: During training , the sample rate of a popular word is high and the embedding of a popular word updates frequently .
heading: Explanation

text: For a rare word , the sample rate is low and its embedding rarely updates .
heading: Explanation

text: According to our study , on average , the moving distance of the embedding fora popular word is twice longer than that of a rare word during training .
heading: Explanation

text: As all word embeddings are usually initialized around the origin with a small variance , we observe in the final model , the embeddings of rare words are still around the origin and the popular words have moved faraway .
heading: Explanation

text: Discussion
We have strong evidence that the current phenomena are problematic .
heading: Discussion

text: First , according to our study , in both tasks , more than half of the rare words are nouns , e.g. , company names , city names .
heading: Discussion

text: They may share some similar topics to popular entities , e.g. , big companies and cities ; around 10 % percent of rare words include a hyphen ( which is usually used to join popular words ) , and over 30 % rare words are different PoSs of popular words .
heading: Discussion

text: These words should have mixed or similar semantics to some popular words .
heading: Discussion

text: These facts show that rare words and popular words should lie in the same region of the embedding space , which is different from what we observed .
heading: Discussion

text: Second , as we can see from the cases , for rare words , model - predicted neighbors are usually not semantically related words but frequency - related words ( rare words ) .
heading: Discussion

text: This shows , for rare words , the embeddings encode more frequency information than semantic information .
heading: Discussion

text: It is not good to use such word embeddings into semantic understanding tasks , e.g. , text classification , language modeling , language understanding and translation .
heading: Discussion

text: Our Method
In this section , we present our method to improve word representations .
heading: Our Method

text: As we have a strong prior that many rare words should share the same region in the embedding space as popular words , the basic idea of our algorithm is to train the word embeddings in an adversarial framework :
heading: Our Method

text: We introduce a discriminator to categorize word embeddings into two classes : popular ones or rare ones .
heading: Our Method

text: We hope the learned word embeddings not only minimize the task - specific training loss but also fool the discriminator .
heading: Our Method

text: By doing so , the frequency information is removed from the embedding and we call our method frequency - agnostic word embedding ( FRAGE ) .
heading: Our Method

text: We first define some notations and then introduce our algorithm .
heading: Our Method

text: We develop three types of notations : embeddings , task - specific parameters / loss , and discriminator parameters / loss .

text: The only difference is that we use the original task - specific loss function with an additional adversarial loss as in Eqn..
