text: The model architecture of the end - to - end neural network is illustrated in , which is effectively an auto - encoder with a Gumbel - softmax middle layer .
heading: Each component

text: The whole neural network for coding learning has five parameters ( ? , b , ? , b , A ) .
heading: Each component

text: Once the coding learning model is trained , the code C w for each word can be easily obtained by applying argmax to the one - hot vectors d 1 w , ... , d M w .
heading: Each component

text: The basis vectors ( codewords ) for composing the embeddings can be found as the row vectors in the weight matrix A.
heading: Each component

text: For general NLP tasks , one can learn the compositional codes from publicly available word vectors such as GloVe vectors .
heading: Each component

text: However , for some tasks such as machine translation , the word embeddings are usually jointly learned with other parts of the neural network .
heading: Each component

text: For such tasks , one has to first train a normal model to obtain the baseline embeddings .
heading: Each component

text: Then , based on the trained embedding matrix , one can learn a set of task - specific codes .
heading: Each component

text: As the reconstructed embeddings E( C w ) are not identical to the original embeddings ? ( w ) , the model parameters other than the embedding matrix have to be retrained again .
heading: Each component

text: The code learning model can not be jointly trained with the machine translation model as it takes far more iterations for the coding layer to converge to one - hot vectors .
heading: Each component

text: EXPERIMENTS
In our experiments , we focus on evaluating the maximum loss - free compression rate of word embeddings on two typical NLP tasks : sentiment analysis and machine translation .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We compare the model performance and the size of embedding layer with the baseline model and the iterative pruning method .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Please note that the sizes of other parts in the neural networks are not included in our results .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: For dense matrices , we report the size of dumped numpy arrays .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: For the sparse matrices , we report the size of dumped compressed sparse column matrices ( csc matrix ) in scipy .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: All float numbers take 32 bits storage .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We enable the " compressed " option when dumping the matrices , without this option , the file size is about 1.1 times bigger .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: CODE LEARNING
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: To learn efficient compact codes for each word , our proposed method requires a set of baseline embedding vectors .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: For the sentiment analysis task , we learn the codes based on the publicly available GloVe vectors .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: For the machine translation task , we first train a normal neural machine translation ( NMT ) model to obtain task - specific word embeddings .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Then we learn the codes using the pre-trained embeddings .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We train the end - to - end network described in Section 4 to learn the codes automatically .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: In each iteration , a small batch of the embeddings is sampled uniformly from the baseline embedding matrix .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The network parameters are optimized to minimize the reconstruction loss of the sampled embeddings .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: In our experiments , the batch size is set to 128 .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We use Adam optimizer with a fixed learning rate of 0.0001 .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The training is run for 200K iterations .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Every 1,000 iterations , we examine the loss on a fixed validation set and save the parameters if the loss decreases .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We evenly distribute the model training to 4 GPUs using the nccl package , so that one round of code learning takes around 15 minutes to complete .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: SENTIMENT ANALYSIS
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Dataset : For sentiment analysis , we use a standard separation of IMDB movie review dataset , which contains 25 k reviews for training and 25 K reviews for testing purpose .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We lowercase and tokenize all texts with the nltk package .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We choose the 300 - dimensional uncased Glo Ve word vectors ( trained on 42B tokens of Common Crawl data ) as our baseline embeddings .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The vocabulary for the model training contains all words appears both in the IMDB dataset and the GloVe vocabulary , which results in around 75 K words .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We truncate the texts of reviews to assure they are not longer than 400 words .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Model architecture :
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Both the baseline model and the compressed models have the same computational graph except the embedding layer .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The model is composed of a single LSTM layer with 150 hidden units and a softmax layer for predicting the binary label .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: For the baseline model , the embedding layer contains a large 75 K 300 embedding matrix initialized by GloVe embeddings .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: For the compressed models based on the compositional coding , the embedding layer maintains a matrix of basis vectors .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Suppose we use a 32 16 coding scheme , the basis matrix will then have a shape of 512 300 , which is initialized by the concatenated weight matrices [ A 1 ; A 2 ; ... ; AM ] in the code learning model .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The embedding parameters for both models remain fixed during the training .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: For the models with network pruning , the sparse embedding matrix is finetuned during training .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Training details :
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The models are trained with Adam optimizer for 15 epochs with a fixed learning rate of 0.0001 .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: At the end of each epoch , we evaluate the loss on a small validation set .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The parameters with lowest validation loss are saved .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Results : For different settings of the number of components M and the number of codewords K , we train the code learning network .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The average reconstruction loss on a fixed validation set is summarized in the left of .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: For reference , we also report the total size ( MB ) of the embedding layer in the right table , which includes the sizes of the basis matrix and the hash table .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We can see that increasing either M or K can effectively decrease the reconstruction loss .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: However , setting M to a large number will result in longer hash codes , thus significantly increase the size of the embedding layer .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Hence , it is important to choose correct numbers for M and K to balance the performance and model size .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: To see how the reconstructed loss translates to the classification accuracy , we train the sentiment analysis model for different settings of code schemes and report the results in : Trade - off between the model performance and the size of embedding layer on IMDB sentiment analysis task
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We also show the results using normalized product quantization ( NPQ ) .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We quantize the filtered Glo Ve embeddings with the codes provided by the authors , and train the models based on the quantized embeddings .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: To make the results comparable , we report the codebook size in numpy format .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: For our proposed methods , the maximum loss - free compression rate is achieved by a 16 32 coding scheme .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: In this case , the total size of the embedding layer is 1.23 MB , which is equivalent to a compression rate of 98.4 % .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We also found the classification accuracy can be substantially improved with a slightly lower compression rate .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The improved model performance maybe a byproduct of the strong regularization .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: MACHINE TRANSLATION
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Dataset : For machine translation tasks , we experiment on IWSLT 2014 German - to - English translation task and ASPEC English - to - Japanese translation task .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The IWSLT14 training data contains 178K sentence pairs , which is a small dataset for machine translation .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We utilize moses toolkit to tokenize and lowercase both sides of the texts .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Then we concatenate all five TED / TEDx development and test corpus to form a test set containing 6750 sentence pairs .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We apply byte - pair encoding to transform the texts to subword level so that the vocabulary has a size of 20 K for each language .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: For evaluation , we report tokenized BLEU using " multi -bleu.perl " .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The ASPEC dataset contains 300M bilingual pairs in the training data with the automatically estimated quality scores provided for each pair .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We only use the first 150M pairs for training the models .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The English texts are tokenized by moses toolkit whereas the Japanese texts are tokenized by kytea .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The vocabulary size for each language is reduced to 40K using byte - pair encoding .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The evaluation is performed using a standard kytea - based post -processing script for this dataset .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Model architecture :
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: In our preliminary experiments , we found a 32 16 coding works well fora vanilla NMT model .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: As it is more meaningful to test on a high - performance model , we applied several techniques to improve the performance .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The model has a standard bi-directional encoder composed of two LSTM layers similar to .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The decoder contains two LSTM layers .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Residual connection with a scaling factor of 1 / 2 is applied to the two decoder states to compute the outputs .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: All LSTMs and embeddings have 256 hidden units in the IWSLT14 task and 1000 hidden units in ASPEC task .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The decoder states are firstly linearly transformed to 600 - dimensional vectors before computing the final softmax .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Dropout with a rate of 0.2 is applied everywhere except the recurrent computation .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We apply Key - Value Attention to the first decoder , where the query is the sum of the feedback embedding and the previous decoder state and the keys are computed by linear transformation of encoder states .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Training details :
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: All models are trained by Nesterov 's accelerated gradient with an initial learning rate of 0.25 .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We evaluate the smoothed BLEU ) on a validation set composed of 50 batches every 7,000 iterations .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The learning rate is reduced by a factor of 10 if no improvement is observed in 3 validation runs .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The training ends after the learning rate is reduced three times .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Similar to the code learning , the training is distributed to 4 GPUs , each GPU computes a mini-batch of 16 samples .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We firstly train a baseline NMT model to obtain the task - specific embeddings for all in - vocabulary words in both languages .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Then based on these baseline embeddings , we obtain the hash codes and basis vectors by training the code learning model .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Finally , the NMT models using compositional coding are retrained by plugging in the reconstructed embeddings .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Note that the embedding layer is fixed in this phase , other parameters are retrained from random initial values .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Results :
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The experimental results are summarized in .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: All translations are decoded by the beam search with abeam size of 5 .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The performance of iterative pruning varies between tasks .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The loss - free compression rate reaches 92 % on ASPEC dataset by pruning 90 % of the connections .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: However , with the same pruning ratio , a modest performance loss is observed in IWSLT14 dataset .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: For the models using compositional coding , the loss - free compression rate is 94 % for the IWSLT14 dataset and 99 % for the ASPEC dataset .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Similar to the sentiment analysis task , a significant performance improvement can be observed by slightly lowering the compression rate .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Note that the sizes of NMT models are still quite large due to the big softmax layer and the recurrent layers , which are not reported in the , we show some examples of learned codes based on the 300 - dimensional uncased GloVe embeddings used in the sentiment analysis task .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We can see that the model learned to assign similar codes to the words with similar meanings .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Such a code - sharing mechanism can significantly reduce the redundancy of the word embeddings , thus helping to achieve a high compression rate .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: ANALYSIS OF CODE EFFICIENCY
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Besides the performance , we also care about the storage efficiency of the codes .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: In the ideal situation , all codewords shall be fully utilized to convey a fraction of meaning .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: However , as the codes are category word 8 8 code 16 16 code dog 0 7 0 1 7 3 7 0 7 7 0 8 3 5 8 5 B 2 E E 0 B 0 A animal cat 7 7 0 1 7 3 7 0 7 7 2 8 B 5 8 CB 2 E E 4 B 0 A penguin 0 7 0 1 7 3 6 0 7 7 E 8 7 6 4 CF DE 3 D 8 0 A go 7 7 0 6 4 3 3 0 2 C C 8 2 C 1 1 B D 0 E 0 B 5 8 verb went 4 0 7 6 4 3 2 0 BC C 6 BC 7 5 B 8 6 E 0 D 0 4 gone 7 7 0 6 4 3 3 0 2 C C 8 0 B 1 5 B D 6 E 0 2 5 A : Examples of learned compositional codes based on Glo Ve embedding vectors automatically learned , it is possible that some codewords are abandoned during the training .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: In extreme cases , some " dead " codewords can be used by none of the words .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: To analyze the code efficiency , we count the number of words that contain a specific subcode in each component .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: gives a visualization of the code balance for three coding schemes .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Each column shows the counts of the subcodes of a specific component .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: In our experiments , when using a 8 8 coding scheme , we found 31 % of the words have a subcode " 0 " for the first component , while the subcode " 1 " is only used by 5 % of the words .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The assignment of codes is more balanced for larger coding schemes .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: In any coding scheme , even the most unpopular codeword is used by about 1000 words .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: This result indicates that the code learning model is capable of assigning codes efficiently without wasting a codeword .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The results show that any codeword is assigned to more than 1000 words without wasting .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: CONCLUSION
In this work , we propose a novel method for reducing the number of parameters required in word embeddings .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: Instead of assigning each unique word an embedding vector , we compose the embedding vectors using a small set of basis vectors .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: The selection of basis vectors is governed by the hash code of each word .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: We apply the compositional coding approach to maximize the storage efficiency .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: The proposed method works by eliminating the redundancy inherent in representing similar words with independent embeddings .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: In our work , we propose a simple way to directly learn the discrete codes in a neural network with Gumbel - softmax trick .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: The results show that the size of the embedding layer was reduced by 98 % in IMDB sentiment analysis task and 94 % ? 99 % in machine translation tasks without affecting the performance .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: Our approach achieves a high loss - free compression rate by considering the semantic inter-similarity among different words .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: In qualitative analysis , we found the learned codes of similar words are very close in Hamming space .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: As our approach maintains a dense basis matrix , it has the potential to be further compressed by applying pruning techniques to the dense matrix .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: The advantage of compositional coding approach will be more significant if the size of embedding layer is dominated by the hash codes .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: title
0,000 + Times Accelerated Robust Subset Selection ( ARSS )
heading: title

text: abstract
Subset selection from massive data with noised information is increasingly popular for various applications .
heading: abstract

text: This problem is still highly challenging as current methods are generally slow in speed and sensitive to outliers .
heading: abstract

text: To address the above two issues , we propose an accelerated robust subset selection ( ARSS ) method .
heading: abstract

text: Specifically in the subset selection area , this is the first attempt to employ the p ( 0 < p ? 1 ) - norm based measure for the representation loss , preventing large errors from dominating our objective .
heading: abstract

text: As a result , the robustness against outlier elements is greatly enhanced .
heading: abstract

text: Actually , data size is generally much larger than feature length , i.e. N L. Based on this observation , we propose a speedup solver ( via ALM and equivalent derivations ) to highly reduce the computational cost , theoretically from ON 4 to ON 2 L .
heading: abstract

text: Extensive experiments on ten benchmark datasets verify that our method not only outperforms state of the art methods , but also runs 10,000 + times faster than the most related method .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Due to the explosive growth of data , subset selection methods are increasingly popular fora wide range of machine learning and computer vision applications .
heading: Introduction

text: This kind of methods offer the potential to select a few highly representative samples or exemplars to describe the entire dataset .
heading: Introduction

text: By analyzing a few , we can roughly know all .
heading: Introduction

text: Such case is very important to summarize and visualize huge datasets of texts , images and videos etc . .
heading: Introduction

text: Besides , by only using the selected exemplars for succeeding tasks , the cost of memories and computational time will be greatly reduced .
heading: Introduction

text: Additionally , as outliers are generally less representative , the side effect of outliers will be reduced , thus boosting the performance of subsequent applications .
heading: Introduction

text: There have been several subset selection methods .
heading: Introduction

text: The most intuitional method is to randomly select a fixed number of samples .
heading: Introduction

text: Although highly efficient , there is no guarantee for an effective selection .
heading: Introduction

text: For the other methods , depending on the mechanism of representative exemplars , there are mainly three categories of selection methods .
heading: Introduction

text: One category Data size ( N ) Selection Time
heading: Introduction

text: Classifiers
Classification Accuracy Performance TED RRSSNie RRSSour ARSSour : Comparisons of four algorithms on Optdigit .
heading: Classifiers

text: Two conclusions can be drawn .
heading: Classifiers

text: First , our method ( ARSSour ) is highly faster than all others ; with the help of an elegant new theorem , RRSSour is significantly faster than the authorial algorithm RRSSNie.
heading: Classifiers

text: Second , ARSSour achieves highly promising prediction accuracies .
heading: Classifiers

text: relies on the assumption that the data points lie in one or multiple low - dimensional subspaces .
heading: Classifiers

text: Specifically , the Rank Revealing QR ( RRQR ) selects the subsets that give the best conditional sub-matrix .
heading: Classifiers

text: Unfortunately , this method has suboptimal properties , as it is not assured to find the globally optimum in polynomial time .
heading: Classifiers

text: Another category assumes that the samples are distributed around centers .
heading: Classifiers

text: The center or its nearest neighbour are selected as exemplars .
heading: Classifiers

text: Perhaps , Kmeans and Kmedoids are the most typical methods ( Kmedoids is a variant of Kmeans ) .
heading: Classifiers

text: Both methods employ an EM - like algorithm .
heading: Classifiers

text: Thus , the results depend tightly on the initialization , and they are highly unstable for large K ( i.e. the number of centers or selected samples ) .
heading: Classifiers

text: Recently , there area few methods that assume exemplars are the samples that can best represent the whole dataset .
heading: Classifiers

text: However , for , the optimization is a combinatorial problem ( NP - hard ) , which is computationally intractable to solve .
heading: Classifiers

text: Besides , the representation loss is measured by the least square measure , which is sensitive to outliers in data .
heading: Classifiers

text: Then improves by employing a robust loss via the 2 , 1 - norm ; the 1 - norm is applied to samples , and the 2 - norm is used for features .
heading: Classifiers

text: In this way , the side effect of outlier samples is relieved .
heading: Classifiers

text: The solver of ) is theoretically perfect due to its ability of convergence to global optima .
heading: Classifiers

text: Unfortunately , in terms of computational costs , the solver is highly complex .
heading: Classifiers

text: It takes ON 4 for one iteration as shown in .
heading: Classifiers

text: This is infeasible for the case of large N ( e.g. it takes 2000 + hours fora case of N = 13000 ) .
heading: Classifiers

text: Moreover , the representation loss is only robust against outlier samples .
heading: Classifiers

text: Such case is worth improvement , as there may exist outlier elements in real data .
heading: Classifiers

text: Contributions .
In this paper , we propose an accelerated robust subset selection method to highly raise the speed on the one hand , and to boost the robustness on the other .
heading: Contributions .

text: To this end , we use the p ( 0 < p ? 1 ) - norm based robust measure for the representation loss , preventing large errors from dominating our objective .
heading: Contributions .

text: As a result , the robustness against outliers is greatly boosted .
heading: Contributions .

text: Then , based on the observation that data size is generally much larger than feature length , i.e. N L , we propose a speedup solver .
heading: Contributions .

text: The main acceleration is owing to the Augmented Lagrange Multiplier ( ALM ) and an equivalent derivation .
heading: Contributions .

text: Via them , we reduce the computational complexity from ON 4 to ON 2 L .
heading: Contributions .

text: Extensive results on ten benchmark datasets demonstrate that in average , our method is 10,000 + times faster than Nie 's method .
heading: Contributions .

text: The selection quality is highly encouraging as shown in .
heading: Contributions .

text: Additionally , via another equivalent derivation , we give an accelerated solver for Nie 's method , theoretically reducing the computational complexity from ON 4 to ON 2 L + N L 3 as listed in , empirically obtaining a 500 + times speedup compared with the authorial solver .
heading: Contributions .

heading: Subset Selection via Self - Representation

text: Conclusion
To deal with tremendous data of varying quality , we propose an accelerated robust subset selection ( ARSS ) method .

text: title
Neural Architectures for Named Entity Recognition
abstract

State - of - the - art named entity recognition systems rely heavily on hand - crafted features and domain - specific knowledge in order to learn effectively from the small , supervised training corpora that are available .
heading: abstract

text: In this paper , we introduce two new neural architectures - one based on bidirectional LSTMs and conditional random fields , and the other that constructs and labels segments using a transition - based approach inspired by shift - reduce parsers .
heading: abstract

text: Our models rely on two sources of information about words : character - based word representations learned from the supervised corpus and unsupervised word representations learned from unannotated corpora .
heading: abstract

text: Our models obtain state - of - the - art performance in NER in four languages without resorting to any language - specific knowledge or resources such as gazetteers .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Named entity recognition ( NER ) is a challenging learning problem .
heading: Introduction

text: One the one hand , inmost languages and domains , there is only a very small amount of supervised training data available .
heading: Introduction

text: On the other , there are few constraints on the kinds of words that can be names , so generalizing from this small sample of data is difficult .
heading: Introduction

text: As a result , carefully constructed orthographic features and language - specific knowledge resources , such as gazetteers , are widely used for solving this task .
heading: Introduction

text: Unfortunately , languagespecific resources and features are costly to develop in new languages and new domains , making NER a challenge to adapt .
heading: Introduction

text: Unsupervised learning from unannotated corpora offers an alternative strategy for obtaining better generalization from small amounts of supervision .
heading: Introduction

text: However , even systems that have relied extensively on unsupervised features have used these to augment , rather than replace , hand - engineered features ( e.g. , knowledge about capitalization patterns and character classes in a particular language ) and specialized knowledge resources ( e.g. , gazetteers ) .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we present neural architectures for NER that use no language - specific resources or features beyond a small amount of supervised training data and unlabeled corpora .
heading: Introduction

text: Our models are designed to capture two intuitions .
heading: Introduction

text: First , since names often consist of multiple tokens , reasoning jointly over tagging decisions for each token is important .
heading: Introduction

text: We compare two models here , ( i ) a bidirectional LSTM with a sequential conditional random layer above it ( LSTM - CRF ; 2 ) , and ( ii ) anew model that constructs and labels chunks of input sentences using an algorithm inspired by transition - based parsing with states represented by stack LSTMs ( S - LSTM ; 3 ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Second , token - level evidence for " being a name " includes both orthographic evidence ( what does the word being tagged as a name look like ? ) and distributional evidence ( where does the word being tagged tend to occur in a corpus ? ) .
heading: Introduction

text: To capture orthographic sensitivity , we use character - based word representation model to capture distributional sensitivity , we combine these representations with distributional representations .
heading: Introduction

text: Our word representations combine both of these , and dropout training is used to encourage the model to learn to trust both sources of evidence ( 4 ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Experiments in English , Dutch , German , and Spanish show that we are able to obtain state - of - the - art NER performance with the LSTM - CRF model in Dutch , German , and Spanish , and very near the state - of - the - art in English without any hand - engineered features or gazetteers ( 5 ) .
heading: Introduction

text: The transition - based algorithm likewise surpasses the best previously published results in several languages , although it performs less well than the LSTM - CRF model .
heading: Introduction

text: LSTM - CRF
heading: Introduction

text: Model
We provide a brief description of LSTMs and CRFs , and present a hybrid tagging architecture .
heading: Model

text: This architecture is similar to the ones presented by .
heading: Model

text: LSTM
Recurrent neural networks ( RNNs ) area family of neural networks that operate on sequential data .
heading: LSTM

text: They take as input a sequence of vectors ( x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n ) and return another sequence ( h 1 , h 2 , . . . , h n ) that represents some information about the sequence at every step in the input .
heading: LSTM

text: Although RNNs can , in theory , learn long dependencies , in practice they fail to do so and tend to be biased towards their most recent inputs in the sequence .
heading: LSTM

text: Long Short - term Memory Networks ( LSTMs ) have been designed to combat this issue by incorporating a memory - cell and have been shown to capture long - range dependencies .
heading: LSTM

text: They do so using several gates that control the proportion of the input to give to the memory cell , and the proportion from the previous state to forget .
heading: LSTM

text: We use the following implementation :
heading: LSTM

text: where ?
heading: LSTM

text: is the element - wise sigmoid function , and is the element - wise product .
heading: LSTM

text: For a given sentence ( x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n ) containing n words , each represented as a d-dimensional vector , an LSTM computes a representation ? ?
heading: LSTM

text: ht of the left context of the sentence at every word t.
heading: LSTM

text: Naturally , generating a representation of the right context ? ?
heading: LSTM

text: ht as well should add useful information .
heading: LSTM

text: This can be achieved using a second LSTM that reads the same sequence in reverse .
heading: LSTM

text: We will refer to the former as the forward LSTM and the latter as the backward LSTM .
heading: LSTM

text: These are two distinct networks with different parameters .
heading: LSTM

text: This forward and backward LSTM pair is referred to as a bidirectional LSTM .
heading: LSTM

text: The representation of a word using this model is obtained by concatenating its left and right context representations ,
heading: LSTM

text: These representations effectively include a representation of a word in context , which is useful for numerous tagging applications .
heading: LSTM

text: CRF
Tagging Models
Avery simple - but surprisingly effective - tagging model is to use the ht 's as features to make independent tagging decisions for each output y t.
heading: Tagging Models

text: Despite this model 's success in simple problems like POS tagging , its independent classification decisions are limiting when there are strong dependencies across output labels .
heading: Tagging Models

text: NER is one such task , since the " grammar " that characterizes interpretable sequences of tags imposes several hard constraints ( e.g. , I - PER can not follow B - LOC ; see 2.4 for details ) that would be impossible to model with independence assumptions .
heading: Tagging Models

text: Therefore , instead of modeling tagging decisions independently , we model them jointly using a conditional random field .
heading: Tagging Models

text: For an input sentence
heading: Tagging Models

text: we consider P to be the matrix of scores output by the bidirectional LSTM network .
heading: Tagging Models

text: P is of size n k , where k is the number of distinct tags , and P i , j corresponds to the score of the j th tag of the i th word in a sentence .
heading: Tagging Models

text: For a sequence of predictions y = ( y 1 , y 2 , . . . , y n ) , we define it s score to be
heading: Tagging Models

text: where A is a matrix of transition scores such that A i , j represents the score of a transition from the tag i to tag j. y 0 and y n are the start and end tags of a sentence , that we add to the set of possible tags .
heading: Tagging Models

text: A is therefore a square matrix of size k + 2 .
heading: Tagging Models

text: A softmax overall possible tag sequences yields a probability for the sequence y:
heading: Tagging Models

text: y ?Y Xe s ( X , y) .
heading: Tagging Models

text: During training , we maximize the log-probability of the correct tag sequence :
heading: Tagging Models

text: where Y X represents all possible tag sequences ( even those that do not verify the IOB format ) fora sentence X .
heading: Tagging Models

text: From the formulation above , it is evident that we encourage our network to produce a valid sequence of output labels .
heading: Tagging Models

text: While decoding , we predict the output sequence that obtains the maximum score given by :
heading: Tagging Models

text: Since we are only modeling bigram interactions between outputs , both the summation in Eq. 1 and the maximum a posteriori sequence y * in Eq.
heading: Tagging Models

text: 2 can be computed using dynamic programming .
heading: Tagging Models

text: Parameterization and Training

The scores associated with each tagging decision for each token ( i.e. , the P i , y 's ) are defined to be the dot product between the embedding of a wordin - context computed with a bidirectional LSTMexactly the same as the POS tagging model of and these are combined with bigram compatibility scores ( i.e. , the A y , y 's ) .
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: This architecture is shown in figure
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: 1 . Circles represent observed variables , diamonds are deterministic functions of their parents , and double circles are random variables .
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: The parameters of this model are thus the matrix of bigram compatibility scores A , and the parameters that give rise to the matrix P , namely the parameters of the bidirectional LSTM , the linear feature weights , and the word embeddings .
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: As in part 2.2 , let x i denote the sequence of word embeddings for every word in a sentence , and y i be their associated tags .
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: We return to a discussion of how the embeddings xi are modeled in Section 4 .
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: The sequence of word embeddings is given as input to a bidirectional LSTM , which returns a representation of the left and right context for each word as explained in 2.1 .
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: These representations are concatenated ( c i ) and linearly projected onto a layer whose size is equal to the number of distinct tags .
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: Instead of using the softmax output from this layer , we use a CRF as previously described to take into account neighboring tags , yielding the final predictions for every wordy i .
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: Additionally , we observed that adding a hidden layer between c i and the CRF layer marginally improved our results .
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: All results reported with this model incorporate this extra-layer .
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: The parameters are trained to maximize Eq. 1 of observed sequences of NER tags in an annotated corpus , given the observed words .
heading: Parameterization and Training

text: Tagging Schemes
The task of named entity recognition is to assign a named entity label to every word in a sentence .
heading: Tagging Schemes

text: A single named entity could span several tokens within a sentence .
heading: Tagging Schemes

text: Sentences are usually represented in the IOB format ( Inside , Outside , Beginning ) where every token is labeled as B- label if the token is the beginning of a named entity , I-label if it is inside a named entity but not the first token within the named entity , or O otherwise .
heading: Tagging Schemes

text: However , we decided to use the IOBES tagging scheme , a variant of IOB commonly used for named entity recognition , which encodes information about singleton entities ( S ) and explicitly marks the end of named entities ( E ) .
heading: Tagging Schemes

text: Using this scheme , tagging a word as I-label with high - confidence narrows down the choices for the subsequent word to I-label or E-label , however , the IOB scheme is only capable of determining that the subsequent word can not be the interior of another label .
heading: Tagging Schemes

text: Ratinov and Roth and showed that using a more expressive tagging scheme like IOBES improves model performance marginally .
heading: Tagging Schemes

text: However , we did not observe a significant improvement over the IOB tagging scheme .
heading: Tagging Schemes

text: Transition - Based Chunking Model

As an alternative to the LSTM - CRF discussed in the previous section , we explore anew architecture that chunks and labels a sequence of inputs using an algorithm similar to transition - based dependency parsing .
heading: Transition - Based Chunking Model

text: This model directly constructs representations of the multi-token names ( e.g. , the name Mark Watney is composed into a single representation ) .
heading: Transition - Based Chunking Model

text: This model relies on a stack data structure to incrementally construct chunks of the input .
heading: Transition - Based Chunking Model

text: To obtain representations of this stack used for predicting subsequent actions , we use the Stack - LSTM presented by , in which the LSTM is augmented with a " stack pointer . "
heading: Transition - Based Chunking Model

text: While sequential LSTMs model sequences from left to right , stack LSTMs permit embedding of a stack of objects that are both added to ( using a push operation ) and removed from ( using a pop operation ) .
heading: Transition - Based Chunking Model

text: This allows the Stack - LSTM to work like a stack that maintains a " summary embedding " of its contents .
heading: Transition - Based Chunking Model

text: We refer to this model as Stack - LSTM or S - LSTM model for simplicity .
heading: Transition - Based Chunking Model

text: Finally , we refer interested readers to the original paper for details about the Stack - LSTM model since in this paper we merely use the same architecture through anew transition - based algorithm presented in the following Section .
heading: Transition - Based Chunking Model

text: Chunking Algorithm
We designed a transition inventory which is given in that is inspired by transition - based parsers , in particular the arc-standard parser of .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: In this algorithm , we make use of two stacks ( designated output and stack representing , respectively , completed chunks and scratch space ) and a buffer that contains the words that have yet to be processed .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: The transition inventory contains the following transitions :
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: The SHIFT transition moves a word from the buffer to the stack , the OUT transition moves a word from the buffer directly into the output stack while the REDUCE ( y ) transition pops all items from the top of the stack creating a " chunk , " labels this with label y , and pushes a representation of this chunk onto the output stack .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: The algorithm completes when the stack and buffer are both empty .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: The algorithm is depicted in , which shows the sequence of operations required to process the sentence Mark Watney visited Mars .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: The model is parameterized by defining a probability distribution over actions at each time step , given the current contents of the stack , buffer , and output , as well as the history of actions taken .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: Following , we use stack LSTMs to compute a fixed dimensional embedding of each of these , and take a concatenation of these to obtain the full algorithm state .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: This representation is used to define a distribution over the possible actions that can betaken at each time step .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: The model is trained to maximize the conditional probability of sequences of reference actions ( extracted from a labeled training corpus ) given the input sentences .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: To label anew input sequence attest time , the maximum probability action is chosen greedily until the algorithm reaches a termination state .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: Although this is not guaranteed to find a global optimum , it is effective in practice .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: Since each token is either moved directly to the output ( 1 action ) or first to the stack and then the output ( 2 actions ) , the total number of actions fora sequence of length n is maximally 2n .
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: It is worth noting that the nature of this algorithm
heading: Chunking Algorithm

text: Representing Labeled Chunks
When the REDUCE ( y ) operation is executed , the algorithm shifts a sequence of tokens ( together with their vector embeddings ) from the stack to the output buffer as a single completed chunk .
heading: Representing Labeled Chunks

text: To compute an embedding of this sequence , we run a bidirectional LSTM over the embeddings of its constituent tokens together with a token representing the type of the chunk being identified ( i.e. , y ) .
heading: Representing Labeled Chunks

text: This function is given as g ( u , . . . , v , r y ) , where r y is a learned embedding of a label type .
heading: Representing Labeled Chunks

text: Thus , the output buffer contains a single vector representation for each labeled chunk that is generated , regardless of its length .
heading: Representing Labeled Chunks

text: Input Word Embeddings
The input layers to both of our models are vector representations of individual words .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: Learning independent representations for word types from the limited NER training data is a difficult problem : there are simply too many parameters to reliably estimate .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: Since many languages have orthographic or morphological evidence that something is a name ( or not a name ) , we want representations that are sensitive to the spelling of words .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: We therefore use a model that constructs representations of words from representations of the characters they are composed of ( 4.1 ) .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: Our second intuition is that names , which may individually be quite varied , appear in regular contexts in large corpora .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: Therefore we use embed - dings learned from a large corpus that are sensitive to word order ( 4.2 ) .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: Finally , to prevent the models from depending on one representation or the other too strongly , we use dropout training and find this is crucial for good generalization performance ( 4.3 ) .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: Character - based models of words
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: An important distinction of our work from most previous approaches is that we learn character - level features while training instead of hand - engineering prefix and suffix information about words .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: Learning character - level embeddings has the advantage of learning representations specific to the task and domain at hand .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: They have been found useful for morphologically rich languages and to handle the outof - vocabulary problem for tasks like part - of - speech tagging and language modeling or dependency parsing . describes our architecture to generate a word embedding fora word from its characters .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: A character lookup table initialized at random contains an embedding for every character .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: The character embeddings corresponding to every character in a word are given indirect and reverse order to a forward and a backward LSTM .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: The embedding fora word derived from its characters is the concatenation of its forward and backward representations from the bidirectional LSTM .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: This character - level representation is then concatenated with a word - level representation from a word lookup - table .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: During testing , words that do not have an embedding in the lookup table are mapped to a UNK embedding .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: To train the UNK embedding , we replace singletons with the UNK embedding with a probability 0.5 .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: In all our experiments , the hidden dimension of the forward and backward character LSTMs are 25 each , which results in our character - based representation of words being of dimension 50 .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: Recurrent models like RNNs and LSTMs are capable of encoding very long sequences , however , they have a representation biased towards their most recent inputs .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: As a result , we expect the final representation of the forward LSTM to bean accurate representation of the suffix of the word , and the final state of the backward LSTM to be a better representation of its prefix .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: Alternative approachesmost notably like convolutional networks - have been proposed to learn representations of words from their characters .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: However , convnets are designed to discover position - invariant features of their inputs .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: While this is appropriate for many problems , e.g. , image recognition ( a cat can appear anywhere in a picture ) , we argue that important information is position dependent ( e.g. , prefixes and suffixes encode different information than stems ) , making LSTMs an a priori better function class for modeling the relationship between words and their characters .
heading: Input Word Embeddings

text: Pretrained embeddings
As in , we use pretrained word embeddings to initialize our lookup table .
heading: Pretrained embeddings

text: We observe significant improvements using pretrained word embeddings over randomly initialized ones .
heading: Pretrained embeddings

text: Embeddings are pretrained using skip - n- gram ( Ling et al. , 2015 a ) , a variation of word2vec that accounts for word order .
heading: Pretrained embeddings

text: These embeddings are fine - tuned during training .
heading: Pretrained embeddings

text: Word embeddings for Spanish , Dutch , German and English are trained using the Spanish Gigaword version 3 , the Leipzig corpora collection , the German monolingual training data from the 2010 Machine Translation Workshop and the English Gigaword version 4 ( with the LA Times and NY Times portions removed ) respectively .
heading: Pretrained embeddings

text: We use an embedding dimension of 100 for English , 64 for other languages , a minimum word frequency cutoff of 4 , and a window size of 8 .
heading: Pretrained embeddings

text: Dropout training
Initial experiments showed that character - level embeddings did not improve our overall performance when used in conjunction with pretrained word representations .
heading: Dropout training

text: To encourage the model to depend on both representations , we use dropout training , applying a dropout mask to the final embedding layer just before the input to the bidirectional LSTM in .
heading: Dropout training

text: We observe a significant improvement in our model 's performance after using dropout ( see ) .
heading: Dropout training

text: Experiments
This section presents the methods we use to train our models , the results we obtained on various tasks and the impact of our networks ' configuration on model performance .
heading: Experiments

text: Training

For both models presented , we train our networks using the back - propagation algorithm updating our parameters on every training example , one at a time , using stochastic gradient descent ( SGD ) with a learning rate of 0.01 and a gradient clipping of 5.0 .
heading: Training

text: Several methods have been proposed to enhance the performance of SGD , such as Adadelta or Adam ( Kingma and Ba , 2014 ) .
heading: Training

text: Although we observe faster convergence using these methods , none of them perform as well as SGD with gradient clipping .
heading: Training

text: Our LSTM - CRF model uses a single layer for the forward and backward LSTMs whose dimensions are set to 100 .
heading: Training

text: Tuning this dimension did not significantly impact model performance .
heading: Training

text: We set the dropout rate to 0.5 .
heading: Training

text: Using higher rates negatively impacted our results , while smaller rates led to longer training time .
heading: Training

text: The stack - LSTM model uses two layers each of dimension 100 for each stack .
heading: Training

text: The embeddings of the actions used in the composition functions have 16 dimensions each , and the output embedding is of dimension 20 .
heading: Training

text: We experimented with different dropout rates and reported the scores using the best dropout rate for each language .
heading: Training

text: It is a greedy model that apply locally optimal actions until the entire sentence is processed , further improvements might be obtained with beam search or training with exploration .
heading: Training

text: Data Sets
We test our model on different datasets for named entity recognition .
heading: Data Sets

text: To demonstrate our model 's ability to generalize to different languages , we present results on the ) that contain independent named entity labels for English , Spanish , German and Dutch .
heading: Data Sets

text: All datasets contain four different types of named entities : locations , persons , organizations , and miscellaneous entities that do not belong in any of the three previous categories .
heading: Data Sets

text: Although POS tags were made available for all datasets , we did not include them in our models .
heading: Data Sets

text: We did not perform any dataset preprocessing , apart from replacing every digit with a zero in the English NER dataset .
heading: Data Sets

text: presents our comparisons with other models for named entity recognition in English .
heading: Data Sets

text: To make the comparison between our model and others fair , we report the scores of other models with and without the use of external labeled data such as gazetteers and knowledge bases .
heading: Data Sets

text: Our models do not use gazetteers or any external labeled resources .
heading: Data Sets

text: The best score reported on this task is by .
heading: Data Sets

text: They obtained a F 1 of 91.2 by jointly modeling the NER and entity linking tasks .
heading: Data Sets

text: Their model uses a lot of hand - engineered features including spelling features , WordNet clusters , Brown clusters , POS tags , chunks tags , as well as stemming and external knowledge bases like Freebase and Wikipedia .
heading: Data Sets

text: Our LSTM - CRF model outperforms all other systems , including the ones using external labeled data like gazetteers .
heading: Data Sets

text: Our Stack - LSTM model also outperforms all previous models that do not incorporate external features , apart from the one presented by .
heading: Data Sets

text: and 4 present our results on NER for German , Dutch and Spanish respectively in comparison to other models .
heading: Data Sets

text: On these three languages , the LSTM - CRF model significantly outperforms all previous methods , including the ones using external labeled data .
heading: Data Sets

text: The only exception is Dutch , where the model of can perform better by leveraging the information from other NER datasets .
heading: Data Sets

text: The Stack - LSTM also consistently presents statethe - art ( or close to ) results compared to systems that do not use external data .
heading: Data Sets

text: Results

As we can see in the tables , the Stack - LSTM model is more dependent on character - based representations to achieve competitive performance ; we hypothesize that the LSTM - CRF model requires less orthographic information since it gets more contextual information out of the bidirectional LSTMs ; however , the Stack - LSTM model consumes the words one by one and it just relies on the word representations when it chunks words .
heading: Results

text: Network architectures
Our models had several components that we could tweak to understand their impact on the overall performance .
heading: Network architectures

text: We explored the impact that the CRF , the character - level representations , pretraining of our presented a model similar to our LSTM - CRF , but using hand - crafted spelling features .
heading: Network architectures

text: also used a similar model and adapted it to the semantic role labeling task .
heading: Network architectures

text: used a linear chain CRF with L 2 regularization , they added phrase cluster features extracted from the web data and spelling features .
heading: Network architectures

text: also used a linear chain CRF with spelling features and gazetteers .
heading: Network architectures

text: Language independent
NER models like ours have also been proposed in the past .
heading: Language independent

text: present semi-supervised bootstrapping algorithms for named entity recognition by co-training character - level ( word - internal ) and token - level ( context ) features .
heading: Language independent

text: use Bayesian nonparametrics to construct a database of named entities in an almost unsupervised setting .
heading: Language independent

text: Ratinov and Roth quantitatively compare several approaches for NER and build their own supervised model using a regularized average perceptron and aggregating context information .
heading: Language independent

text: Finally , there is currently a lot of interest in models for NER that use letter - based representations .
heading: Language independent

text: model the task of sequencelabeling as a sequence to sequence learning problem and incorporate character - based representations into their encoder model .
heading: Language independent

text: employ an architecture similar to ours , but instead use CNNs to learn character - level features , in away similar to the work by .
heading: Language independent

text: Conclusion

This paper presents two neural architectures for sequence labeling that provide the best NER results ever reported in standard evaluation settings , even compared with models that use external resources , such as gazetteers .
heading: Conclusion

text: A key aspect of our models are that they model output label dependencies , either via a simple CRF architecture , or using a transition - based algorithm to explicitly construct and label chunks of the input .
heading: Conclusion

text: Word representations are also crucially important for success : we use both pre-trained word representations and " character - based " representations that capture morphological and orthographic information .
heading: Conclusion

text: To prevent the learner from depending too heavily on one representation class , dropout is used .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Fast and Accurate Entity Recognition with Iterated Dilated Convolutions
abstract
Today when many practitioners run basic NLP on the entire web and large - volume traffic , faster methods are paramount to saving time and energy costs .
heading: abstract

text: Recent advances in GPU hardware have led to the emergence of bi-directional LSTMs as a standard method for obtaining pertoken vector representations serving as input to labeling tasks such as NER ( often followed by prediction in a linear - chain CRF ) .
heading: abstract

text: Though expressive and accurate , these models fail to fully exploit GPU parallelism , limiting their computational efficiency .
heading: abstract

text: This paper proposes a faster alternative to Bi - LSTMs for NER : Iterated Dilated Convolutional Neural Networks ( ID - CNNs ) , which have better capacity than traditional CNNs for large context and structured prediction .
heading: abstract

text: Unlike LSTMs whose sequential processing on sentences of length N requires O(N ) time even in the face of parallelism , ID - CNNs permit fixed - depth convolutions to run in parallel across entire documents .
heading: abstract

text: We describe a distinct combination of network structure , parameter sharing and training procedures that enable dramatic 14 - 20x testtime speedups while retaining accuracy comparable to the Bi - LSTM - CRF .
heading: abstract

text: Moreover , ID - CNNs trained to aggregate context from the entire document are even more accurate while maintaining 8 x faster test time speeds .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction

In order to democratize large - scale NLP and information extraction while minimizing our environmental footprint , we require fast , resource - efficient methods for sequence tagging tasks such as part - of - speech tagging and named entity recognition ( NER ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Speed is not sufficient of course : they must also be expressive enough to tolerate the tremendous lexical variation in input data .
heading: Introduction

text: The massively parallel computation facilitated by GPU hardware has led to a surge of successful neural network architectures for sequence labeling .
heading: Introduction

text: While these models are expressive and accurate , they fail to fully exploit the parallelism opportunities of a GPU , and thus their speed is limited .
heading: Introduction

text: Specifically , they employ either recurrent neural networks ( RNNs ) for feature extraction , or Viterbi inference in a structured output model , both of which require sequential computation across the length of the input .
heading: Introduction

text: Instead , parallelized runtime independent of the length of the sequence saves time and energy costs , maximizing GPU resource usage and minimizing the amount of time it takes to train and evaluate models .
heading: Introduction

text: Convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ) provide exactly this property .
heading: Introduction

text: Rather than composing representations incrementally over each token in a sequence , they apply filters in parallel across the entire sequence at once .
heading: Introduction

text: Their computational cost grows with the number of layers , but not the input size , up to the memory and threading limitations of the hardware .
heading: Introduction

text: This provides , for example , audio generation models that can be trained in parallel ( van den .
heading: Introduction

text: Despite the clear computational advantages of CNNs , RNNs have become the standard method for composing deep representations of text .
heading: Introduction

text: This is because a token encoded by a bidirectional RNN will incorporate evidence from the entire input sequence , but the CNN 's representation is limited by the effective input width 1 of the network : the size of the input context which is observed , directly or indirectly , by the representation of a token at a given layer in the network .
heading: Introduction

text: Specifically , in a network composed of a series of stacked convolutional layers of convolution width w , the number r of context tokens incorporated into a token 's representation at a given layer l , is given by r = l ( w ?
heading: Introduction

text: 1 ) + 1 . The number of layers required to incorporate the entire input context grows linearly with the length of the sequence .
heading: Introduction

text: To avoid this scaling , one could pool representations across the sequence , but this is not appropriate for sequence labeling , since it reduces the output resolution of the representation .
heading: Introduction

text: In response , this paper presents an application of dilated convolutions for sequence labeling ) .
heading: Introduction

text: For dilated convolutions , the effective input width can grow exponentially with the depth , with no loss in resolution at each layer and with a modest number of parameters to estimate .
heading: Introduction

text: Like typical CNN layers , dilated convolutions operate on a sliding window of context over the sequence , but unlike conventional convolutions , the context need not be consecutive ; the dilated window skips over every dilation width d inputs .
heading: Introduction

text: By stacking layers of dilated convolutions of exponentially increasing dilation width , we can expand the size of the effective input width to cover the entire length of most sequences using only a few layers :
heading: Introduction

text: The size of the effective input width fora token at layer l is now given by 2 l +1 ?1 .
heading: Introduction

text: More concretely , just four stacked dilated convolutions of width 3 produces token representations with an effective input width of 31 tokens - longer than the average sentence length ( 23 ) in the Penn TreeBank .
heading: Introduction

text: Our overall iterated dilated CNN architecture ( ID - CNN ) repeatedly applies the same block of dilated convolutions to token - wise representations .
heading: Introduction

text: This parameter sharing prevents overfitting and also provides opportunities to inject supervision on intermediate activations of the network .
heading: Introduction

text: Similar to models that use logits produced by an RNN , the ID - CNN provides two methods for performing prediction : we can predict each token 's label independently , or by running Viterbi inference in a chain structured graphical model .
heading: Introduction

text: In experiments on CoNLL 2003 and OntoNotes 1 What we call effective input width here is known as the receptive field in the vision literature , drawing an analogy to the visual receptive field of a neuron in the retina . :
heading: Introduction

text: A dilated CNN block with maximum dilation width 4 and filter width 3 .
heading: Introduction

text: Neurons contributing to a single highlighted neuron in the last layer are also highlighted .
heading: Introduction

text: 5.0 English NER , we demonstrate significant speed gains of our ID - CNNs over various recurrent models , while maintaining similar F1 performance .
heading: Introduction

text: When performing prediction using independent classification , the ID - CNN consistently outperforms a bidirectional LSTM ( Bi - LSTM ) , and performs on par with inference in a CRF with logits from a Bi - LSTM ( Bi - LSTM - CRF ) .
heading: Introduction

text: As an extractor of per-token logits fora CRF , our model out - performs the Bi - LSTM - CRF .
heading: Introduction

text: We also apply ID - CNNs to entire documents , where independent token classification is as accurate as the Bi - LSTM - CRF while decoding almost 8 faster .
heading: Introduction

text: The clear accuracy gains resulting from incorporating broader context suggest that these models could similarly benefit many other contextsensitive NLP tasks which have until now been limited by the computational complexity of existing context - rich models .
heading: Introduction

heading: Introduction

Models for Tagging
Let x = [ x 1 , . . . , x T ] be our input text and y = [ y 1 , . . . , y T ] be per-token output tags .
heading: Models for Tagging

text: Let D be the domain size of each y i .
heading: Models for Tagging

heading: Models for Tagging

heading: Models for Tagging

heading: Models for Tagging

text: Given these features , O ( D ) prediction is simple and parallelizable across the length of the sequence .
heading: Models for Tagging

text: However , feature extraction may not necessarily be parallelizable .
heading: Models for Tagging

text: For example , RNN - based features require iterative passes along the length of x .
heading: Models for Tagging

text: We also consider a linear - chain CRF model that couples all of y together :

text: Viterbi algorithm .
heading: Models for Tagging

text: CRF prediction explicitly reasons about interactions among neighboring output tags , whereas prediction in the first model compiles this reasoning into the feature extraction step .
heading: Models for Tagging

text: The suitability of such compilation depends on the properties and quantity of the data .
heading: Models for Tagging

text: While CRF prediction requires non-trivial search in output space , it can guarantee that certain output constraints , such as for IOB tagging , will always be satisfied .
heading: Models for Tagging

text: It may also have better sample complexity , as it imposes more prior knowledge about the structure of the interactions among the tags .
heading: Models for Tagging

text: However , it has worse computational complexity than independent prediction .
heading: Models for Tagging

text: Dilated Convolutions
CNNs in NLP are typically one - dimensional , applied to a sequence of vectors representing tokens rather than to a two -dimensional grid of vectors representing pixels .
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: In this setting , a convolutional neural network layer is equivalent to applying an affine transformation , W c to a sliding window of width r tokens on either side of each token in the sequence .
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: Here , and throughout the paper , we do not explicitly write the bias terms in affine transformations .
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: The convolutional operator applied to each token x t with output ct is defined as :
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: where ?
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: is vector concatenation .
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: Dilated convolutions perform the same operation , except rather than transforming adjacent in - puts , the convolution is defined over a wider effective input width by skipping over ?
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: inputs at a time , where ?
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: is the dilation width .
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: We define the dilated convolution operator :
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: A dilated convolution of width 1 is equivalent to a simple convolution .
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: Using the same number of parameters as a simple convolution with the same radius ( i.e. W c has the same dimensionality ) , the ? > 1 dilated convolution incorporates broader context into the representation of a token than a simple convolution .
heading: Dilated Convolutions

text: Multi - Scale Context Aggregation
We can leverage the ability of dilated convolutions to incorporate global context without losing important local information by stacking dilated convolutions of increasing width .
heading: Multi - Scale Context Aggregation

text: First described for pixel classification in computer vision , achieve state - of - the - art results on image segmentation benchmarks by stacking dilated convolutions with exponentially increasing rates of dilation , a technique they refer to as multiscale context aggregation .
heading: Multi - Scale Context Aggregation

text: By feeding the outputs of each dilated convolution as the input to the next , increasingly non-local information is incorporated into each pixel 's representation .
heading: Multi - Scale Context Aggregation

text: Performing a dilation - 1 convolution in the first layer ensures that no pixels within the effective input width of any pixel are excluded .
heading: Multi - Scale Context Aggregation

text: By doubling the dilation width at each layer , the size of the effective input width grows exponentially while the number of parameters grows only linearly with the number of layers , so a pixel representation quickly incorporates rich global evidence from the entire image .
heading: Multi - Scale Context Aggregation

text: Unfortunately , simply increasing the depth of stacked dilated CNNs causes considerable overfitting in our experiments .
heading: Multi - Scale Context Aggregation

text: In response , we present Iterated Dilated CNNs ( ID - CNNs ) , which instead apply the same small stack of dilated convolutions multiple times , each iterate taking as input the result of the last application .
heading: Multi - Scale Context Aggregation

text: Repeatedly employing the same parameters in a recurrent fashion provides both broad effective input width and desirable generalization capabilities .
heading: Multi - Scale Context Aggregation

text: We also obtain significant accuracy gains with a training objective that strives for accurate labeling after each iterate , allowing follow - on iterations to observe and resolve dependency violations .
heading: Multi - Scale Context Aggregation
