text: Training

Our main focus is to apply the ID - CNN an encoder to produce per-token logits for the first conditional model described in Sec. 2.1 , where tags are conditionally independent given deep features , since this will enable prediction that is parallelizable across the length of the input sequence .
heading: Training

text: Here , maximum likelihood training is straightforward because the likelihood decouples into the sum of the likelihoods of independent logistic regression problems for every tag , with natural parameters given by Eqn. :
heading: Training

text: We can also use the ID - CNN as logits for the CRF model ( Eqn. ( 2 ) ) , where the partition function and its gradient are computed using the forward - backward algorithm .
heading: Training

text: We next present an alternative training method that helps bridge the gap between these two techniques .
heading: Training

text: Sec. 2.1 identifies that the CRF has preferable sample complexity and accuracy since prediction directly reasons in the space of structured outputs .
heading: Training

text: In response , we compile some of this reasoning in output space into ID - CNN feature extraction .
heading: Training

text: Instead of explicit reasoning over output labels during inference , we train the network such that each block is predictive of output labels .
heading: Training

text: Subsequent blocks learn to correct dependency violations of their predecessors , refining the final sequence prediction .
heading: Training

text: To do so , we first define predictions of the model after each of the L b applications of the block .
heading: Training

text: Let ht ( k ) be the result of applying the matrix W o from ( 9 ) to b t ( k ) , the output of block k.
heading: Training

text: We minimize the average of the losses for each application of the block :
heading: Training

text: By rewarding accurate predictions after each application of the block , we learn a model where later blocks are used to refine initial predictions .
heading: Training

text: The loss also helps reduce the vanishing gradient problem for deep architectures .
heading: Training

text: Such an approach has been applied in a variety of contexts for training very deep networks in computer vision , but not to our knowledge in NLP .
heading: Training

text: We apply dropout to the raw inputs x t and to each block 's output b t ( b ) to help prevent overfitting .
heading: Training

text: The version of dropout typically used in practice has the undesirable property that the randomized predictor used at train time differs from the fixed one used attest time .
heading: Training

text: present dropout with expectationlinear regularization , which explicitly regularizes these two predictors to behave similarly .
heading: Training

text: All of our best reported results include such regularization .
heading: Training

text: This is the first investigation of the technique 's effectiveness for NLP , including for RNNs .
heading: Training

text: We encourage its further application .
heading: Training

text: Related work

The state - of - the art models for sequence labeling include an inference step that searches the space of possible output sequences of a chain - structured graphical model , or approximates this search with abeam .
heading: Related work

text: These outperform similar systems that use the same features , but independent local predictions .
heading: Related work

text: On the other hand , the greedy sequential prediction ) approach of , which employs lexicalized features , gazetteers , and word clusters , outperforms CRFs with similar features .
heading: Related work

text: LSTMs were used for NER as early as the CoNLL shared task in 2003 .
heading: Related work

text: More recently , a wide variety of neural network architectures for NER have been proposed .
heading: Related work

text: employ a one - layer CNN with pre-trained word embeddings , capitalization and lexicon features , and CRF - based prediction .
heading: Related work

text: achieved state - of - the - art accuracy on partof - speech , chunking and NER using a Bi - LSTM - CRF. proposed two models which incorporated Bi - LSTM - composed character embeddings alongside words : a Bi - LSTM - CRF , and a greedy stack LSTM which uses a simple shift - reduce grammar to compose words into labeled entities .
heading: Related work

text: Their Bi - LSTM - CRF obtained the state - of - the - art on four languages without word shape or lexicon features .
heading: Related work

text: use CNNs rather than LSTMs to compose characters in a Bi - LSTM - CRF , achieving state - of the - art performance on part - of - speech tagging and CoNLL NER without lexicons .
heading: Related work

text: Chiu and Nichols ( 2016 ) evaluate a similar network but propose a novel method for encoding lexicon matches , presenting results on CoNLL and OntoNotes NER .
heading: Related work

text: use GRU - CRFs with GRUcomposed character embeddings of words to train a single network on many tasks and languages .
heading: Related work

text: In general , distributed representations for text can provide useful generalization capabilities for NER systems , since they can leverage unsupervised pre-training of distributed word representations .
heading: Related work

text: Though our models would also likely benefit from additional features such as character representations and lexicons , we focus on simpler models which use word - embeddings alone , leaving more elaborate input representations to future work .
heading: Related work

text: In these NER approaches , CNNs were used for low - level feature extraction that feeds into alternative architectures .
heading: Related work

text: Overall , end - to - end CNNs have mainly been used in NLP for sentence classification , where the output representation is lower resolution than that of the input Kim Our work draws on the use of dilated convolutions for image segmentation in the computer vision community .
heading: Related work

text: Similar to our block , Yu and Koltun ( 2016 ) employ a context - module of stacked dilated convolutions of exponentially increasing dilation width .
heading: Related work

text: Dilated convolutions were recently applied to the task of speech generation , and concurrent with this work , posted a pre-print describing the similar ByteNet network for machine translation that uses dilated convolutions in the encoder and decoder components .
heading: Related work

text: Our basic model architecture is similar to that of the ByteNet encoder , except that the inputs to our model are tokens and not bytes .
heading: Related work

text: Additionally , we present a novel loss and parameter sharing scheme to facilitate training models on much smaller datasets than those used by .
heading: Related work

text: We are the first to use dilated convolutions for sequence labeling .
heading: Related work

text: The broad effective input width of the ID - CNN helps aggregate document - level context .
heading: Related work

text: incorporate document context in their greedy model by adding features based on tagged entities within a large , fixed window of tokens .
heading: Related work

text: Prior work has also posed a structured model that couples predictions across the whole document .
heading: Related work

text: Experimental Results
We describe experiments on two benchmark English named entity recognition datasets .
heading: Experimental Results

text: On CoNLL - 2003 English NER , our ID - CNN performs on par with a Bi - LSTM not only when used to produce per-token logits for structured inference , but the ID - CNN with greedy decoding also performs on - par with the Bi - LSTM - CRF while running at more than 14 times the speed .
heading: Experimental Results

text: We also observe a performance boost in almost all models when broadening the context to incorporate entire documents , achieving an average F1 of 90.65 on CoNLL - 2003 , out - performing the sentence - level model while still decoding at nearly 8 times the speed of the Bi - LSTM - CRF .
heading: Experimental Results

text: Data and Evaluation
We evaluate using labeled data from the CoNLL - 2003 shared task ( Tjong and OntoNotes 5.0 .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: Following previous work , we use the same OntoNotes data split used for co-reference resolution in the CoNLL - 2012 shared task .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: For both datasets , we convert the IOB boundary encoding to BILOU as previous work found this encoding to result in improved performance .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: As in previous work we evaluate the performance of our models using segment - level micro -averaged F1 score .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: Hyperparameters that resulted in the best performance on the validation set were selected via grid search .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: A more detailed description of the data , evaluation , optimization and data pre-processing can be found in the Appendix .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: Baselines
We compare our ID - CNN against strong LSTM and CNN baselines : a Bi - LSTM with local decoding , and one with CRF decoding ( Bi - LSTM - CRF ) .
heading: Baselines

text: We also compare against a non-dilated CNN architecture with the same number of convolutional layers as our dilated network ( 4 - layer CNN ) and one with enough layers to incorporate an effective input width of the same size as that of the dilated network ( 5 - layer CNN ) to demonstrate that the dilated convolutions more effectively aggregate contextual information than simple convolutions ( i.e. using fewer parameters ) .
heading: Baselines

text: We also compare our document - level ID - CNNs to a baseline which does not share parameters between blocks ( noshare ) and one that computes loss only at the last block , rather than after every iterated block of dilated convolutions ( 1 - loss ) .
heading: Baselines

text: We do not compare with deeper or more elaborate CNN architectures fora number of reasons :
heading: Baselines

text: 1 ) Fast train and test performance are highly desirable for NLP practitioners , and deeper models require more computation time 2 ) more complicated models tend to over - fit on this relatively small dataset and 3 ) most accurate deep CNN architectures repeatedly up - sample and down - sample the inputs .
heading: Baselines

text: We do not compare to stacked LSTMs for similar reasons - a single LSTM is already slower than a 4 - layer CNN .
heading: Baselines

text: Since our task is sequence labeling , we desire a model that maintains the token - level resolution of the input , making dilated convolutions an elegant solution .
heading: Baselines

text: 6.3 CoNLL - 2003 English NER 6.3.1 Sentence - level prediction lists F 1 scores of models predicting with sentence - level context on CoNLL - 2003 .
heading: Baselines

text: For models that we trained , we report F1 and standard deviation obtained by averaging over 10 random restarts .
heading: Baselines

text: The Viterbi - decoding Bi - LSTM - CRF and ID - CNN - CRF and greedy ID - CNN obtain the highest average scores , with the ID - CNN - CRF outperforming the Bi - LSTM - CRF by 0.11 points of F1 on average , and the Bi - LSTM - CRF out - performing the greedy ID - CNN by 0.11 as well .
heading: Baselines

text: Our greedy ID - CNN outperforms the Bi - LSTM and the 4 - layer CNN , which uses the same number of parameters as the ID - CNN , and performs similarly to the 5 - layer CNN which uses more parameters but covers the same effective input width .
heading: Baselines

text: All CNN models out - perform the Bi-Model F1 86.96 90.33 Bi-LSTM 89.34 0.28 4 - layer CNN 89.97 0.20 5 - layer CNN 90.23 0.16 ID- CNN 90.32 0.26 88.67 90.05 90.20 Bi-LSTM-CRF ( re-impl ) 90.43 0.12 ID-CNN- CRF 90.54 0.18 LSTM when paired with greedy decoding , suggesting that CNNs are better token encoders than Bi - LSTMs for independent logistic regression .
heading: Baselines

text: When paired with Viterbi decoding , our ID - CNN performs on par with the Bi - LSTM , showing that the ID - CNN is also an effective token encoder for structured inference .
heading: Baselines

text: Our ID - CNN is not only a better token encoder than the Bi - LSTM but it is also faster .
heading: Baselines

text: lists relative decoding times on the CoNLL development set , compared to the Bi - LSTM - CRF .
heading: Baselines

text: We report decoding times using the fastest batch size for each method .
heading: Baselines

text: The ID - CNN model decodes nearly 50 % faster than the Bi - LSTM .
heading: Baselines

text: With Viterbi decoding , the gap closes somewhat but the ID - CNN - CRF still comes out ahead , about 30 % faster than the Bi - LSTM - CRF .
heading: Baselines

text: The most vast speed improvements come when comparing the greedy ID - CNN to the Bi - LSTM - CRF - our ID - CNN is more than 14 times faster than the Bi - LSTM - CRF attest time , with comparable accuracy .
heading: Baselines

text: The 5 - layer CNN , which observes the same effective input width as the ID - CNN but with more parameters , performs at about the same speed as the ID - CNN in our experiments .
heading: Baselines

text: With a better implementation of dilated convolutions than currently included in TensorFlow , we would expect the ID - CNN to be notably faster than the 5 - layer CNN .
heading: Baselines

text: We emphasize the importance of the dropout regularizer of in , where we observe increased F1 for every model trained with expectation - linear dropout regularization .
heading: Baselines

text: Dropout is important for training neural network models that generalize well , especially on relatively small NLP datasets such as .
heading: Baselines

text: We recommend this regularizer as a simple and helpful tool for practitioners training neural networks for NLP .
heading: Baselines

text: Document - level prediction
heading: Baselines

text: In we show that adding document - level context improves every model on CoNLL - 2003 .
heading: Baselines

text: Incorporating document - level context further improves our greedy ID - CNN model , attaining 90.65 average F1 .
heading: Baselines

text: We believe this model sees greater improvement with the addition of document - level context than the Bi - LSTM - CRF due to the ID - CNN learning a feature function better suited for representing broad context , in contrast with the Bi - LSTM which , though better than a simple RNN at encoding long memories of sequences , may reach its limit when provided with sequences more than 1,000 tokens long such as entire documents .
heading: Baselines

text: We also note that our combination of training objective ( Eqn. 11 ) and tied parameters ( Eqn. : Comparing ID - CNNs with 1 ) backpropagating loss only from the final layer ( 1 - loss ) and 2 ) untied parameters across blocks ( noshare ) 8 ) more effectively learns to aggregate this broad context than a vanilla cross - entropy loss or deep CNN back - propagated from the final neural network layer .
heading: Baselines

text: compares models trained to incorporate entire document context using the document baselines described in Section 6.2 .
heading: Baselines

text: In we show that , in addition to being more accurate , our ID - CNN model is also much faster than the Bi - LSTM - CRF when incorporating context from entire documents , decoding at almost 8 times the speed .
heading: Baselines

text: On these long sequences , it also tags at more than 4.5 times the speed of the greedy Bi - LSTM , demonstrative of the benefit of our ID - CNNs context - aggregating computation that does not depend on the length of the sequence .
heading: Baselines

text: OntoNotes 5.0 English NER
heading: Baselines

text: We observe similar patterns on OntoNotes as we do on CoNLL. lists overall F 1 scores of our models compared to those in the existing literature .
heading: Baselines

text: The greedy Bi - LSTM out - performs the lex -
heading: Baselines

text: Model
Speed Bi-LSTM-CRF 1 Bi-LSTM 4.60 ID- CNN 7.96 85.76 0.13 21.19 ID-CNN 85.27 0.24 13.21 ID - CNN ( 1 block ) 84.28 0.10 26.01 : F1 score of sentence and document models on OntoNotes .
heading: Model

text: icalized greedy model of , and our ID - CNN out - performs the Bi - LSTM as well as the more complex model of which leverages the parallel coreference annotation available in the OntoNotes corpus to predict named entities jointly with entity linking and co-reference .
heading: Model

text: Our greedy model is out - performed by the Bi - LSTM - CRF reported in Chiu and Nichols ( 2016 ) as well as our own re-implementation , which appears to be the new state - of - the - art on this dataset .
heading: Model

text: The gap between our greedy model and those using Viterbi decoding is wider than on CoNLL .
heading: Model

text: We believe this is due to the more diverse set of entities in OntoNotes , which also tend to be much longer - the average length of a multi-token named entity segment in CoNLL is about one token shorter than in OntoNotes .
heading: Model

text: These long entities benefit more from explicit structured constraints enforced in Viterbi decoding .
heading: Model

text: Still , our ID - CNN outperforms all other greedy methods , achieving our goal of learning a better token encoder for structured prediction .
heading: Model

text: Incorporating greater context significantly boosts the score of our greedy model on OntoNotes , whereas the Bi - LSTM - CRF performs more poorly .
heading: Model

text: In , we also list the F1 of our ID - CNN model and the Bi - LSTM - CRF model trained on entire document context .
heading: Model

text: For the first time , we seethe score decrease when more context is added to the Bi - LSTM - CRF model , though the ID - CNN , whose sentence model a lower score than that of the Bi - LSTM - CRF , sees an increase .
heading: Model

text: We believe the decrease in the Bi - LSTM - CRF model occurs because of the nature of the OntoNotes dataset compared to contains a particularly high proportion of ambiguous entities , 7 perhaps leading to more benefit from document context that helps with disambiguation .
heading: Model

text: In this scenario , adding the wider context may just add noise to the high - scoring Bi - LSTM - CRF model , whereas the less accurate dilated model can still benefit from the refined predictions of the iterated dilated convolutions .
heading: Model

text: Conclusion
We present iterated dilated convolutional neural networks , fast token encoders that efficiently aggregate broad context without losing resolution .
heading: Conclusion

text: These provide impressive speed improvements for sequence labeling , particularly when processing entire documents at a time .
heading: Conclusion

text: In the future we hope to extend this work to NLP tasks with richer structured output , such as parsing .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Semi-supervised sequence tagging with bidirectional language models
abstract
Pre-trained word embeddings learned from unlabeled text have become a standard component of neural network architectures for NLP tasks .
heading: abstract

text: However , inmost cases , the recurrent network that operates on word - level representations to produce context sensitive representations is trained on relatively little labeled data .
heading: abstract

text: In this paper , we demonstrate a general semi-supervised approach for adding pretrained context embeddings from bidirectional language models to NLP systems and apply it to sequence labeling tasks .
heading: abstract

text: We evaluate our model on two standard datasets for named entity recognition ( NER ) and chunking , and in both cases achieve state of the art results , surpassing previous systems that use other forms of transfer or joint learning with additional labeled data and task specific gazetteers .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Due to their simplicity and efficacy , pre-trained word embedding have become ubiquitous in NLP systems .
heading: Introduction

text: Many prior studies have shown that they capture useful semantic and syntactic information and including them in NLP systems has been shown to be enormously helpful fora variety of downstream tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: However , in many NLP tasks it is essential to represent not just the meaning of a word , but also the word in context .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , in the two phrases " A Central Bank spokesman " and " The Central African Republic " , the word ' Central ' is used as part of both an Organization and Location .
heading: Introduction

text: Accordingly , current state of the art sequence tagging models typically include a bidirectional re-current neural network ( RNN ) that encodes token sequences into a context sensitive representation before making token specific predictions .
heading: Introduction

text: Although the token representation is initialized with pre-trained embeddings , the parameters of the bidirectional RNN are typically learned only on labeled data .
heading: Introduction

text: Previous work has explored methods for jointly learning the bidirectional RNN with supplemental labeled data from other tasks ( e.g. , .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we explore an alternate semisupervised approach which does not require additional labeled data .
heading: Introduction

text: We use a neural language model ( LM ) , pre-trained on a large , unlabeled corpus to compute an encoding of the context at each position in the sequence ( hereafter an LM embedding ) and use it in the supervised sequence tagging model .
heading: Introduction

text: Since the LM embeddings are used to compute the probability of future words in a neural LM , they are likely to encode both the semantic and syntactic roles of words in context .
heading: Introduction

text: Our main contribution is to show that the context sensitive representation captured in the LM embeddings is useful in the supervised sequence tagging setting .
heading: Introduction

text: When we include the LM embeddings in our system overall performance increases from 90. 87 % to 91.93 % F 1 for the CoNLL 2003 NER task , a more then 1 % absolute F1 increase , and a substantial improvement over the previous state of the art .
heading: Introduction

text: We also establish anew state of the art result ( 96.37 % F 1 ) for the CoNLL 2000 Chunking task .
heading: Introduction

text: As a secondary contribution , we show that using both forward and backward LM embeddings boosts performance over a forward only LM .
heading: Introduction

text: We also demonstrate that domain specific pre-training is not necessary by applying a LM trained in the news domain to scientific papers .
heading: Introduction

text: The main components in our language - modelaugmented sequence tagger ( TagLM ) are illustrated in .
heading: Introduction

text: After pre-training word embeddings and a neural LM on large , unlabeled corpora ( Step 1 ) , we extract the word and LM embeddings for every token in a given input sequence Step 2 ) and use them in the supervised sequence tagging model (
heading: Introduction

text: Step 3 ) .
Baseline sequence tagging model
Our baseline sequence tagging model is a hierarchical neural tagging model , closely following a number of recent studies ) ( left side of ) .
heading: Baseline sequence tagging model

text: Given a sentence of tokens ( t 1 , t 2 , . . . , t N ) it first forms a representation , x k , for each token by concatenating a character based representation ck with a token embedding wk :
heading: Baseline sequence tagging model

text: The character representation ck captures morphological information and is either a convolutional neural network ( CNN ) or RNN .
heading: Baseline sequence tagging model

text: It is parameterized by C ( , ? c ) with parameters ? c .
heading: Baseline sequence tagging model

text: The token embeddings , wk , are obtained as a lookup E ( , ? w ) , initialized using pre-trained word embeddings , and fine tuned during training .
heading: Baseline sequence tagging model

text: To learn a context sensitive representation , we employ multiple layers of bidirectional RNNs .
heading: Baseline sequence tagging model

text: For each token position , k , the hidden state h k , i of RNN layer i is formed by concatenating the hidden states from the forward ( ? ? h k , i ) and backward ( ? ? h k , i ) RNNs .
heading: Baseline sequence tagging model

text: As a result , the bidirectional RNN is able to use both past and future information to make a prediction at token k.
heading: Baseline sequence tagging model

text: More formally , for the first RNN layer that operates on x k to output h k,1 :
heading: Baseline sequence tagging model

text: Step 2 : Prepare word embedding and LM embedding for each token in the input sequence .
heading: Baseline sequence tagging model

text: Two representations of the word " York "
Step 3 : Use both word embeddings and LM embeddings in the sequence tagging model .
heading: Two representations of the word " York "

text: New York is located :
heading: Two representations of the word " York "

text: The main components in TagLM , our language - model - augmented sequence tagging system .
heading: Two representations of the word " York "

text: The language model component ( in orange ) is used to augment the input token representation in a traditional sequence tagging models ( in grey ) .
heading: Two representations of the word " York "

text: The second RNN layer is similar and uses h k , 1 to output h k ,2 .
heading: Two representations of the word " York "

text: In this paper , we use L = 2 layers of RNNs in all experiments and parameterize R i as either Gated Recurrent Units ( GRU ) or Long Short - Term Memory units ( LSTM ) depending on the task .
heading: Two representations of the word " York "

text: Finally , the output of the final RNN layer h k,L is used to predict a score for each possible tag using a single dense layer .
heading: Two representations of the word " York "

text: Due to the dependencies between successive tags in our sequence labeling tasks ( e.g. using the BIOES labeling scheme , it is not possible for I - PER to follow B - LOC ) , it is beneficial to model and decode each sentence jointly instead of independently predicting the label for each token .
heading: Two representations of the word " York "

text: Accordingly , we add another layer with parameters for each label bigram , computing the sentence conditional random field ( CRF ) loss using the forward - backward algorithm at training time , and using the Viterbi algorithm to find the most likely tag sequence attest time , similar to Collobert et al .
heading: Two representations of the word " York "

text: Bidirectional LM
A language model computes the probability of a token sequence ( t 1 , t 2 , . . . , t N )
heading: Bidirectional LM

text: Recent state of the art neural language models ) use a similar architecture to our baseline sequence tagger where they pass a token representation ( either from a CNN over characters or as token embeddings ) through multiple layers of LSTMs to embed the history ( t 1 , t 2 , . . . , t k ) into a fixed dimensional vector ? ? h LM k .
heading: Bidirectional LM

text: This is the forward LM embedding of the token at position k and is the output of the top LSTM layer in the language model .
heading: Bidirectional LM

text: Finally , the language model predicts the probability of token t k + 1 using a softmax layer over words in the vocabulary .
heading: Bidirectional LM

text: The need to capture future context in the LM embeddings suggests it is beneficial to also consider a backward LM in additional to the traditional forward LM .
heading: Bidirectional LM

text: A backward LM predicts the previous token given the future context .
heading: Bidirectional LM

text: Given a sentence with N tokens , it computes
A backward LM can be implemented in an analogous way to a forward LM and produces the backward LM embedding ? ?
heading: Given a sentence with N tokens , it computes

text: h LM k , for the sequence ( t k , t k+1 , . . . , t N ) , the output embeddings of the top layer LSTM .
heading: Given a sentence with N tokens , it computes

text: In our final system , after pre-training the forward and backward LMs separately , we remove the top layer softmax and concatenate the forward and backward LM embeddings to form bidirectional LM embeddings , i.e. , h LM
heading: Given a sentence with N tokens , it computes

text: Note that in our formulation , the forward and backward LMs are independent , without any shared parameters .
heading: Given a sentence with N tokens , it computes

text: Combining LM with sequence model
Our combined system , TagLM , uses the LM embeddings as additional inputs to the sequence tagging model .
heading: Combining LM with sequence model

text: In particular , we concatenate the LM embeddings h LM with the output from one of the bidirectional RNN layers in the sequence model .
heading: Combining LM with sequence model

text: In our experiments , we found that introducing the LM embeddings at the output of the first layer performed the best .
heading: Combining LM with sequence model

text: More formally , we simply replace ( 2 ) with
heading: Combining LM with sequence model

text: There are alternate possibilities for adding the LM embeddings to the sequence model .
heading: Combining LM with sequence model

text: One pos-sibility adds a non-linear mapping after the concatenation and before the second RNN ( e.g. re -
heading: Combining LM with sequence model

text: where f is a non-linear function ) .
heading: Combining LM with sequence model

text: Another possibility introduces an attention - like mechanism that weights the all LM embeddings in a sentence before including them in the sequence model .
heading: Combining LM with sequence model

text: Our initial results with the simple concatenation were encouraging so we did not explore these alternatives in this study , preferring to leave them for future work .
heading: Combining LM with sequence model

text: Experiments
We evaluate our approach on two well benchmarked sequence tagging tasks , the CoNLL 2003 NER task and the CoNLL 2000 Chunking task .
heading: Experiments

text: We report the official evaluation metric ( micro - averaged F 1 ) .
heading: Experiments

text: In both cases , we use the BIOES labeling scheme for the output tags , following previous work which showed it outperforms other options ( e.g. , ) .
heading: Experiments

text: Following , we use the Senna word embeddings and pre-processed the text by lowercasing all tokens and replacing all digits with 0 .
heading: Experiments

text: CoNLL 2003 NER .
The CoNLL 2003 NER task consists of newswire from the Reuters RCV1 corpus tagged with four different entity types ( PER , LOC , ORG , MISC ) .
heading: CoNLL 2003 NER .

text: It includes standard train , development and test sets .
heading: CoNLL 2003 NER .

text: Following previous work we trained on both the train and development sets after tuning hyperparameters on the development set .
heading: CoNLL 2003 NER .

text: The hyperparameters for our baseline model are similar to .
heading: CoNLL 2003 NER .

text: We use two bidirectional GRUs with 80 hidden units and 25 dimensional character embeddings for the token character encoder .
heading: CoNLL 2003 NER .

text: The sequence layer uses two bidirectional GRUs with 300 hidden units each .
heading: CoNLL 2003 NER .

text: For regularization , we add 25 % dropout to the input of each GRU , but not to the recurrent connections .
heading: CoNLL 2003 NER .

text: CoNLL 2000 chunking .
The CoNLL 2000 chunking task uses sections 15 - 18 from the Wall Street Journal corpus for training and section 20 for testing .
heading: CoNLL 2000 chunking .

text: It defines 11 syntactic chunk types ( e.g. , NP , VP , ADJP ) in addition to other .
heading: CoNLL 2000 chunking .

text: We randomly sampled 1000 sentences from the training set as a held - out development set .
heading: CoNLL 2000 chunking .

text: The baseline sequence tagger uses 30 dimensional character embeddings and a CNN with 30 filters of width 3 characters followed by a tanh non-linearity for the token character encoder .
heading: CoNLL 2000 chunking .

text: The sequence layer uses two bidirectional LSTMs with 200 hidden units .
heading: CoNLL 2000 chunking .

text: Following we added 50 % dropout to the character embeddings , the input to each LSTM layer ( but not recurrent connections ) and to the output of the final LSTM layer .
heading: CoNLL 2000 chunking .

text: Pre-trained language models .
The primary bidirectional LMs we used in this study were trained on the 1B Word Benchmark , a publicly available benchmark for largescale language modeling .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: The training split has approximately 800 million tokens , about a 4000X increase over the number training tokens in the CoNLL datasets .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: explored several model architectures and released their best single model and training recipes .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: Following , they used linear projection layers at the output of each LSTM layer to reduce the computation time but still maintain a large LSTM state .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: Their single best model took three weeks to train on 32 GPUs and achieved 30.0 test perplexity .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: It uses a character CNN with 4096 filters for input , followed by two stacked LSTMs , each with 8192 hidden units and a 1024 dimensional projection layer .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: We use CNN - BIG - LSTM to refer to this language model in our results .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: In addition to CNN - BIG - LSTM from , 1 we used the same corpus to train two additional language models with fewer parameters : forward LSTM - 2048-512 and backward LSTM - 2048-512 .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: Both language models use token embeddings as input to a single layer LSTM with 2048 units and a 512 dimension projection layer .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: We closely followed the procedure outlined in , except we used synchronous parameter updates across four GPUs instead of asynchronous updates across 32 GPUs and ended training after 10 epochs .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: The test set perplexities for our forward and backward LSTM - 2048 - 512 language models are 47.7 and 47.3 , respectively .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: Model F 1 std 90.91 0.20 90.94 91.37 Our baseline without LM 90.87 0.13 TagLM 91.93 0.19 Training .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: All experiments use the Adam optimizer ( Kingma and Ba , 2015 ) with gradient norms clipped at 5.0 .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: In all experiments , we fine tune the pre-trained Senna word embeddings but fix all weights in the pre-trained language models .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: In addition to explicit dropout regularization , we also use early stopping to prevent over-fitting and use the following process to determine when to stop training .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: We first train with a constant learning rate ? = 0.001 on the training data and monitor the development set performance at each epoch .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: Then , at the epoch with the highest development performance , we start a simple learning rate annealing schedule : decrease ?
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: an order of magnitude ( i.e. , divide by ten ) , train for five epochs , decrease ?
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: an order of magnitude again , train for five more epochs and stop .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: Following , we train each final model configuration ten times with different random seeds and report the mean and standard deviation F 1 .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: It is important to estimate the variance of model performance since the test data sets are relatively small .
heading: Pre-trained language models .

text: Overall system results
Tables 1 and 2 compare results from Tag LM with previously published state of the art results without additional labeled data or task specific gazetteers .
heading: Overall system results

text: compare results of
heading: Overall system results

text: Tag LM to other systems that include additional labeled data or gazetteers .
heading: Overall system results

text: In both tasks , Tag LM establishes anew state of the art using bidirectional LMs ( the forward CNN - BIG - LSTM and the backward LSTM - 2048 - 512 ) .
heading: Overall system results

text: In the CoNLL 2003 NER task , our model scores 91.93 mean F 1 , which is a statistically significant increase over the previous best result of 91.62 0.33 from that used gazetteers ( at 95 % , two - sided Welch t- test , p = 0.021 ) .
heading: Overall system results

text: In the CoNLL 2000 Chunking task , Tag LM achieves 96.37 mean F 1 , exceeding all previously published results without additional labeled data by more then 1 % absolute F 1 .
heading: Overall system results

text: The improvement over the previous best result of 95.77 in that jointly trains with Penn Treebank ( PTB ) POS tags is statistically significant at 95 % ( p < 0.001 assuming standard deviation of 0.1 ) .
heading: Overall system results

text: Importantly , the LM embeddings amounts to an average absolute improvement of 1.06 and 1.37 F 1 in the NER and Chunking tasks , respectively .
heading: Overall system results

text: Adding external resources .

Although we do not use external labeled data or gazetteers , we found that TagLM outperforms previous state of the art results in both tasks when external resources ( labeled data or task specific gazetteers ) are available .
heading: Adding external resources .

text: Furthermore , show that , inmost cases , the improvements we obtain by adding LM embeddings are larger then the improvements previously obtained by adding other forms of transfer or joint learning .
heading: Adding external resources .

text: For example , noted an improvement of only 0.06 F 1 in the NER task when transfer learning from both CoNLL 2000 chunks and PTB POS tags and reported an increase of 0.71 F 1 when adding gazetteers to their baseline .
heading: Adding external resources .

text: In the Chunking task , previous work has reported from 0.28 to 0.75 improvement in F 1 when including supervised labels from the PTB POS tags or CoNLL 2003 entities .
heading: Adding external resources .

text: Analysis
To elucidate the characteristics of our LM augmented sequence tagger , we ran a number of additional experiments on the CoNLL 2003 NER task .
heading: Analysis

text: How to use LM embeddings ?
heading: Analysis

text: In this experiment , we concatenate the LM embeddings at dif - shows that the second alternative performs best .
heading: Analysis

text: We speculate that the second RNN layer in the sequence tagging model is able to capture interactions between task specific context as expressed in the first RNN layer and general context as expressed in the LM embeddings in away that improves overall system performance .
heading: Analysis

text: These results are consistent with who found that chunking performance was sensitive to the level at which additional POS supervision was added .
heading: Analysis

text: Does it matter which language model to use ?
heading: Analysis

text: In this experiment , we compare six different configurations of the forward and backward language models ( including the baseline model which does not use any language models ) .
heading: Analysis

text: The results are reported in .

We find that adding backward LM embeddings consistently outperforms forward - only LM embeddings , with F 1 improvements between 0.22 and 0.27 % , even with the relatively small backward LSTM - 2048-512 LM .
heading: The results are reported in .

text: LM size is important , and replacing the forward LSTM - 2048 - 512 with CNN - BIG - LSTM ( test perplexities of 47.7 to 30.0 on 1B Word Benchmark ) improves F 1 by 0.26 - 0.31 % , about as much as adding backward LM .
heading: The results are reported in .

text: Accordingly , we hypothesize ( but have not tested ) that replacing the backward LSTM - 2048 - 512 with a backward LM analogous to the CNN - BIG - LSTM would further improve performance .
heading: The results are reported in .

text: To highlight the importance of including language models trained on a large scale data , we also experimented with training a language model on just the CoNLL 2003 training and development data .
heading: The results are reported in .

text: Due to the much smaller size of this data Including embeddings from these language models decreased performance slightly compared to the baseline system without any LM .
heading: The results are reported in .

text: This result supports the hypothesis that adding language models help because they learn composition functions ( i.e. , the RNN parameters in the language model ) from much larger data compared to the composition functions in the baseline tagger , which are only learned from labeled data .
heading: The results are reported in .

text: Importance of task specific RNN .

To understand the importance of including a task specific sequence RNN we ran an experiment that removed the task specific sequence RNN and used only the LM embeddings with a dense layer and CRF to predict output tags .
heading: Importance of task specific RNN .

text: In this setup , performance was very low , 88.17 F 1 , well below our baseline .
heading: Importance of task specific RNN .

text: This result confirms that the RNNs in the baseline tagger encode essential information which is not encoded in the LM embeddings .
heading: Importance of task specific RNN .

text: Does the LM transfer across domains ?
heading: Importance of task specific RNN .

text: One artifact of our evaluation framework is that both the labeled data in the chunking and NER tasks and the unlabeled text in the 1 Billion Word Benchmark used to train the bidirectional LMs are derived from news articles .
heading: Importance of task specific RNN .

text: To test the sensitivity to the LM training domain , we also applied Tag LM with a LM trained on news articles to the SemEval 2017 Shared Task 10 , Science IE .
heading: Importance of task specific RNN .

text: 5 Scien - ce IE requires end - to - end joint entity and relationship extraction from scientific publications across three diverse fields ( computer science , material sciences , and physics ) and defines three broad entity types ( Task , Material and Process ) .
heading: Importance of task specific RNN .

text: For this task , Tag LM increased F 1 on the development set by 4.12 % ( from 49.93 to to 54.05 % ) for entity extraction over our baseline without LM embeddings and it was a major component in our winning submission to Science IE , Scenario 1 .
heading: Importance of task specific RNN .

text: We conclude that LM embeddings can improve the performance of a sequence tagger even when the data comes from a different domain .
heading: Importance of task specific RNN .

text: Related work
Unlabeled data .
Tag LM was inspired by the widespread use of pre-trained word embeddings in supervised sequence tagging models .
heading: Unlabeled data .

text: Besides pre-trained word embeddings , our method is most closely related to .
heading: Unlabeled data .

text: Instead of using a LM , uses a probabilistic generative model to infer contextsensitive latent variables for each token , which are then used as extra features in a supervised CRF tagger .
heading: Unlabeled data .

text: Other semisupervised learning methods for structured prediction problems include co-training , expectation maximization , structural learning ( Ando and Zhang , 2005 ) and maximum discriminant functions .
heading: Unlabeled data .

text: It is easy to combine Tag LM with any of the above methods by including LM embeddings as additional features in the discriminative components of the model ( except for expectation maximization ) .
heading: Unlabeled data .

text: A detailed discussion of semisupervised learning methods in NLP can be found in .
heading: Unlabeled data .

text: learned a context encoder from unlabeled data with an objective function similar to a bi-directional LM and applied it to several NLP tasks closely related to the unlabeled objective function : sentence completion , lexical substitution and word sense disambiguation .
heading: Unlabeled data .

text: LM embeddings are related to a class of methods ( e.g. , for learning sentence and document encoders from unlabeled data , which can be used for text classification and textual entailment among other tasks .
heading: Unlabeled data .

text: Dai and Le pre-trained LSTMs using language models and sequence autoencoders then fine tuned the weights for classification tasks .
heading: Unlabeled data .

text: In contrast to our method that uses unlabeled data to learn token - in - context embeddings , all of these methods use unlabeled data to learn an encoder for an entire text sequence ( sentence or document ) .
heading: Unlabeled data .

text: Neural language models .
LMs have always been a critical component in statistical machine translation systems .
heading: Neural language models .

text: Recently , neural LMs have also been integrated in neural machine translation systems ( e.g. , to score candidate translations .
heading: Neural language models .

text: In contrast , Tag LM uses neural LMs to encode words in the input sequence .
heading: Neural language models .

text: Unlike forward LMs , bidirectional LMs have received little prior attention .
heading: Neural language models .

text: Most similar to our formulation , used a bidirectional neural LM in a statistical machine translation system for instance selection .
heading: Neural language models .

text: They tied the input token embeddings and softmax weights in the forward and backward directions , unlike our approach which uses two distinct models without any shared parameters .
heading: Neural language models .

text: Frinken et al. ( 2012 ) also used a bidirectional n-gram LM for handwriting recognition .
heading: Neural language models .

text: Interpreting RNN states .
Recently , there has been some interest in interpreting the activations of RNNs .
heading: Interpreting RNN states .

text: showed that single LSTM units can learn to predict singular - plural distinctions .
heading: Interpreting RNN states .

text: visualized character level LSTM states and showed that individual cells capture long - range dependencies such as line lengths , quotes and brackets .
heading: Interpreting RNN states .

text: Our work complements these studies by showing that LM states are useful for downstream tasks as away of interpreting what they learn .
heading: Interpreting RNN states .

text: Other sequence tagging models .
Current state of the art results in sequence tagging problems are based on bidirectional RNN models .
heading: Other sequence tagging models .

text: However , many other sequence tagging models have been proposed in the literature for this class of problems ( e.g. , .
heading: Other sequence tagging models .

text: LM embeddings could also be used as additional features in other models , although it is not clear whether the model complexity would be sufficient to effectively make use of them .
heading: Other sequence tagging models .

text: Conclusion
In this paper , we proposed a simple and general semi-supervised method using pre-trained neural language models to augment token representations in sequence tagging models .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our method significantly outperforms current state of the art models in two popular datasets for NER and Chunking .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our analysis shows that adding a backward LM in addition to traditional forward LMs consistently improves performance .
heading: Conclusion

text: The proposed method is robust even when the LM is trained on unlabeled data from a different domain , or when the baseline model is trained on a large number of labeled examples .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Deep contextualized word representations
abstract

We introduce anew type of deep contextualized word representation that models both ( 1 ) complex characteristics of word use ( e.g. , syntax and semantics ) , and ( 2 ) how these uses vary across linguistic contexts ( i.e. , to model polysemy ) .
heading: abstract

text: Our word vectors are learned functions of the internal states of a deep bidirectional language model ( biLM ) , which is pretrained on a large text corpus .
heading: abstract

text: We show that these representations can be easily added to existing models and significantly improve the state of the art across six challenging NLP problems , including question answering , textual entailment and sentiment analysis .
heading: abstract

text: We also present an analysis showing that exposing the deep internals of the pre-trained network is crucial , allowing downstream models to mix different types of semi-supervision signals .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Pre-trained word representations area key component in many neural language understanding models .
heading: Introduction

text: However , learning high quality representations can be challenging .
heading: Introduction

text: They should ideally model both ( 1 ) complex characteristics of word use ( e.g. , syntax and semantics ) , and ( 2 ) how these uses vary across linguistic contexts ( i.e. , to model polysemy ) .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we introduce anew type of deep contextualized word representation that directly addresses both challenges , can be easily integrated into existing models , and significantly improves the state of the art in every considered case across a range of challenging language understanding problems .
heading: Introduction

text: Our representations differ from traditional word type embeddings in that each token is assigned a representation that is a function of the entire input sentence .
heading: Introduction

text: We use vectors derived from a bidirectional LSTM that is trained with a coupled lan - guage model ( LM ) objective on a large text corpus .
heading: Introduction

text: For this reason , we call them ELMo ( Embeddings from Language Models ) representations .
heading: Introduction

text: Unlike previous approaches for learning contextualized word vectors , ELMo representations are deep , in the sense that they area function of all of the internal layers of the biLM .
heading: Introduction

text: More specifically , we learn a linear combination of the vectors stacked above each input word for each end task , which markedly improves performance over just using the top LSTM layer .
heading: Introduction

text: Combining the internal states in this manner allows for very rich word representations .
heading: Introduction

text: Using intrinsic evaluations , we show that the higher - level LSTM states capture context - dependent aspects of word meaning ( e.g. , they can be used without modification to perform well on supervised word sense disambiguation tasks ) while lowerlevel states model aspects of syntax ( e.g. , they can be used to do part - of - speech tagging ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Simultaneously exposing all of these signals is highly beneficial , allowing the learned models select the types of semi-supervision that are most useful for each end task .
heading: Introduction

text: Extensive experiments demonstrate that ELMo representations work extremely well in practice .
heading: Introduction

text: We first show that they can be easily added to existing models for six diverse and challenging language understanding problems , including textual entailment , question answering and sentiment analysis .
heading: Introduction

text: The addition of ELMo representations alone significantly improves the state of the art in every case , including up to 20 % relative error reductions .
heading: Introduction

text: For tasks where direct comparisons are possible , ELMo outperforms CoVe , which computes contextualized representations using a neural machine translation encoder .
heading: Introduction

text: Finally , an analysis of both ELMo and CoVe reveals that deep representations outperform ar Xiv : 1802.05365v2 [ cs. CL ] 22 Mar 2018 those derived from just the top layer of an LSTM .
heading: Introduction

text: Our trained models and code are publicly available , and we expect that ELMo will provide similar gains for many other NLP problems .
heading: Introduction

text: 2 Related work Due to their ability to capture syntactic and semantic information of words from large scale unlabeled text , pretrained word vectors area standard component of most state - of the - art NLP architectures , including for question answering , textual entailment and semantic role labeling .
heading: Introduction

text: However , these approaches for learning word vectors only allow a single contextindependent representation for each word .
heading: Introduction

text: Previously proposed methods overcome some of the shortcomings of traditional word vectors by either enriching them with subword information ( e.g. , or learning separate vectors for each word sense ( e.g. , .
heading: Introduction

text: Our approach also benefits from subword units through the use of character convolutions , and we seamlessly incorporate multi-sense information into downstream tasks without explicitly training to predict predefined sense classes .
heading: Introduction

text: Other recent work has also focused on learning context - dependent representations .
heading: Introduction

text: context2vec
heading: Introduction

text: ( Melamud et al. , 2016 ) uses a bidirectional Long Short Term Memory ( LSTM ; Hochreiter and Schmidhuber , 1997 ) to encode the context around a pivot word .
heading: Introduction

text: Other approaches for learning contextual embeddings include the pivot word itself in the representation and are computed with the encoder of either a supervised neural machine translation ( MT ) system or an unsupervised language model .
heading: Introduction

text: Both of these approaches benefit from large datasets , although the MT approach is limited by the size of parallel corpora .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we take full advantage of access to plentiful monolingual data , and train our biLM on a corpus with approximately 30 million sentences .
heading: Introduction

text: We also generalize these approaches to deep contextual representations , which we show work well across abroad range of diverse NLP tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: 1 http://allennlp.org/elmo
heading: Introduction

text: Previous work has also shown that different layers of deep biRNNs encode different types of information .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , introducing multi-task syntactic supervision ( e.g. , part - of - speech tags ) at the lower levels of a deep LSTM can improve overall performance of higher level tasks such as dependency parsing or CCG super tagging .
heading: Introduction

text: In an RNN - based encoder - decoder machine translation system , showed that the representations learned at the first layer in a 2 layer LSTM encoder are better at predicting POS tags then second layer .
heading: Introduction

text: Finally , the top layer of an LSTM for encoding word context has been shown to learn representations of word sense .
heading: Introduction

text: We show that similar signals are also induced by the modified language model objective of our ELMo representations , and it can be very beneficial to learn models for downstream tasks that mix these different types of semi-supervision .
heading: Introduction

text: and pretrain encoder - decoder pairs using language models and sequence autoencoders and then fine tune with task specific supervision .
heading: Introduction

text: In contrast , after pretraining the biLM with unlabeled data , we fix the weights and add additional taskspecific model capacity , allowing us to leverage large , rich and universal biLM representations for cases where downstream training data size dictates a smaller supervised model .
heading: Introduction

text: Dai and Le
Bidirectional language models

Given a sequence of N tokens , ( t 1 , t 2 , ... , t N ) , a forward language model computes the probability of the sequence by modeling the probability of to - ken t k given the history ( t 1 , ... , t k?1 ) :
heading: Bidirectional language models

text: Recent state - of - the - art neural language models compute a context - independent token representation x LM k ( via token embeddings or a CNN over characters ) then pass it through L layers of forward LSTMs .
heading: Bidirectional language models

text: At each position k , each LSTM layer outputs a context - dependent representation ? ? h LM k , j where j = 1 , . . . , L. The top layer LSTM output , ? ? h LM k , L , is used to predict the next token t k +1 with a Softmax layer .
heading: Bidirectional language models

text: A backward LM is similar to a forward LM , except it runs over the sequence in reverse , predicting the previous token given the future context :
heading: Bidirectional language models

text: It can be implemented in an analogous way to a forward LM , with each backward LSTM layer j in a L layer deep model producing representations ? ? h LM k , j oft k given ( t k+1 , . . . , t N ) .
heading: Bidirectional language models

text: A bi LM combines both a forward and backward LM .
heading: Bidirectional language models

text: Our formulation jointly maximizes the log likelihood of the forward and backward directions :
heading: Bidirectional language models

text: We tie the parameters for both the token representation (? x ) and Softmax layer (? s ) in the forward and backward direction while maintaining separate parameters for the LSTMs in each direction .
heading: Bidirectional language models

text: Overall , this formulation is similar to the approach of Peters et al. , with the exception that we share some weights between directions instead of using completely independent parameters .
heading: Bidirectional language models

text: In the next section , we depart from previous work by introducing anew approach for learning word representations that area linear combination of the biLM layers .
heading: Bidirectional language models

text: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks
Given a pre-trained biLM and a supervised architecture fora target NLP task , it is a simple process to use the biLM to improve the task model .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: We simply run the biLM and record all of the layer representations for each word .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: Then , we let the end task model learn a linear combination of these representations , as described below .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: First consider the lowest layers of the supervised model without the biLM .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: Most supervised NLP models share a common architecture at the lowest layers , allowing us to add ELMo in a consistent , unified manner .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: Given a sequence of tokens ( t 1 , . . . , t N ) , it is standard to form a context - independent token representation x k for each token position using pre-trained word embeddings and optionally character - based representations .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: Then , the model forms a context - sensitive representation h k , typically using either bidirectional RNNs , CNNs , or feed forward networks .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: To add ELMo to the supervised model , we first freeze the weights of the biLM and then concatenate the ELMo vector ELMo task k with x k and pass the ELMo enhanced representation [ x k ; ELMo task k ] into the task RNN .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: For some tasks ( e.g. , SNLI , SQuAD ) , we observe further improvements by also including ELMo at the output of the task RNN by introducing another set of output specific linear weights and replacing h k with [ h k ; ELMo task k ] .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: As the remainder of the supervised model remains unchanged , these additions can happen within the context of more complex neural models .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: For example , seethe SNLI experiments in Sec. 4 where a bi-attention layer follows the biLSTMs , or the coreference resolution experiments where a clustering model is layered on top of the biLSTMs .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: Finally , we found it beneficial to add a moderate amount of dropout to and in some cases to regularize the ELMo weights by adding ?
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: w 2 2 to the loss .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: This imposes an inductive bias on the ELMo weights to stay close to an average of all biLM layers .
heading: Using biLMs for supervised NLP tasks

text: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

The pre-trained biLMs in this paper are similar to the architectures in Jzefowicz et al. and , but modified to support joint training of both directions and add a residual connection between LSTM layers .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: We focus on large scale biLMs in this work , as Peters et al .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: highlighted the importance of using biLMs over forward - only LMs and large scale training .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: To balance overall language model perplexity with model size and computational requirements for downstream tasks while maintaining a purely character - based input representation , we halved all embedding and hidden dimensions from the single best model CNN - BIG - LSTM in Jzefowicz et al ..
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: The final model uses L = 2 biLSTM layers with 4096 units and 512 dimension projections and a residual connection from the first to second layer .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: The context insensitive type representation uses 2048 character n-gram convolutional filters followed by two highway layers and a linear projection down to a 512 representation .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: As a result , the biLM provides three layers of representations for each input token , including those outside the training set due to the purely character input .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: In contrast , traditional word embedding methods only provide one layer of representation for tokens in a fixed vocabulary .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: After training for 10 epochs on the 1B Word Benchmark , the average forward and backward perplexities is 39.7 , compared to 30.0 for the forward CNN - BIG - LSTM .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: Generally , we found the forward and backward perplexities to be approximately equal , with the backward value slightly lower .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: Once pretrained , the biLM can compute representations for any task .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: In some cases , fine tuning the biLM on domain specific data leads to significant drops in perplexity and an increase in downstream task performance .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: This can be seen as a type of domain transfer for the biLM .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

text: As a result , inmost cases we used a fine - tuned biLM in the downstream task .
heading: Pre-trained bidirectional language model architecture

shows the performance of ELMo across a diverse set of six benchmark NLP tasks .
heading: See supplemental material for details .

text: In every task considered , simply adding ELMo establishes anew state - of - the - art result , with relative error reductions ranging from 6 - 20 % over strong base models .
heading: See supplemental material for details .

text: This is a very general result across a diverse set model architectures and language understanding tasks .
heading: See supplemental material for details .

text: Evaluation
Question Textual entailment
Textual entailment is the task of determining whether a " hypothesis " is true , given a " premise " .
heading: Question Textual entailment

text: The Stanford Natural Language Inference ( SNLI ) corpus provides approximately 550K hypothesis / premise pairs .
heading: Question Textual entailment

text: Our baseline , the ESIM sequence model from Chen et al. , uses a biL - STM to encode the premise and hypothesis , followed by a matrix attention layer , a local inference layer , another biLSTM inference composition layer , and finally a pooling operation before the output layer .
heading: Question Textual entailment

text: Overall , adding ELMo to the ESIM model improves accuracy by an average of 0.7 % across five random seeds .
heading: Question Textual entailment

text: A five member ensemble pushes the overall accuracy to 89.3 % , exceeding the previous ensemble best of 88.9 % .
heading: Question Textual entailment

text: Semantic role labeling
A semantic role labeling ( SRL ) system models the predicate - argument structure of a sentence , and is often described as answering " Who did what to whom " .
heading: Semantic role labeling

text: He et al .
( 2017 ) modeled SRL as a BIO tagging problem and used an 8 - layer deep biLSTM with forward and backward directions interleaved , following .
heading: He et al .

text: As shown in Coreference resolution Coreference resolution is the task of clustering mentions in text that refer to the same underlying real world entities .
heading: He et al .

text: Our baseline model is the end - to - end span - based neural model of .
heading: He et al .

text: It uses a biLSTM and attention mechanism to first compute span representations and then applies a softmax mention ranking model to find coreference chains .
heading: He et al .

text: In our experiments with the OntoNotes coreference annotations from the CoNLL 2012 shared task , adding ELMo improved the average F 1 by 3.2 % from 67.2 to 70.4 , establishing anew state of the art , again improving over the previous best ensemble result by 1.6 % F 1 .
heading: He et al .

text: Analysis
This section provides an ablation analysis to validate our chief claims and to elucidate some interesting aspects of ELMo representations .
heading: Analysis

text: Sec. 5.1 shows that using deep contextual representations in downstream tasks improves performance over previous work that uses just the top layer , regardless of whether they are produced from a biLM or MT encoder , and that ELMo representations provide the best overall performance .
heading: Analysis

text: Sec. 5.3 explores the different types of contextual information captured in biLMs and uses two intrinsic evaluations to show that syntactic information is better represented at lower layers while semantic information is captured a higher layers , consistent with MT encoders .
heading: Analysis

text: It also shows that our biLM consistently provides richer representations then CoVe .
heading: Analysis

text: Additionally , we analyze the sensitivity to where ELMo is included in the task model ( Sec. 5.2 ) , training set size ( Sec. 5.4 ) , and visualize the ELMo learned weights across the tasks ( Sec. 5.5 ) .
heading: Analysis

text: Alternate layer weighting schemes
There are many alternatives to Equation 1 for combining the biLM layers .
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: Previous work on contextual representations used only the last layer , whether it be from a biLM or an MT encoder ( CoVe ; .
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: The choice of the regularization parameter ?
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: is also important , as large values such as ? = 1 effectively reduce the weighting function to a simple average over the layers , while smaller values ( e.g. , ? = 0.001 ) allow the layer weights to vary .
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: compares these alternatives for SQuAD , SNLI and SRL .
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: Including representations from all layers improves overall performance over just using the last layer , and including contextual representations from the last layer improves performance over the baseline .
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: For example , in the case of SQuAD , using just the last biLM layer improves development F 1 by 3.9 % over the baseline .
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: For SNLI , averaging all layers with ?= 1 improves development accuracy from 88.2 to 88.7 % over using just the last layer .

text: Where to include ELMo ?
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: All of the task architectures in this paper include word embeddings only as input to the lowest layer biRNN .
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: However , we find that including ELMo at the output of the biRNN in task - specific architectures improves overall results for some tasks .
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: As shown in , including ELMo at both the input and output layers for SNLI and SQuAD improves over just the input layer , but for SRL ( and coreference resolution , not shown ) performance is highest when it is included at just the input layer .
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: One possible explanation for this result is that both the SNLI and SQuAD architectures use attention layers after the biRNN , so introducing ELMo at this layer allows the model to attend directly to the biLM 's internal representations .
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: What information is captured by the biLM 's representations ?
heading: Alternate layer weighting schemes

text: Since adding
ELMo improves task performance over word vectors alone , the biLM 's contextual representations must encode information generally useful for NLP tasks that is not captured in word vectors .
heading: Since adding

text: Intuitively , the biLM must be disambiguating the meaning of words using their context .
heading: Since adding

text: Consider " play " , a highly polysemous word .
heading: Since adding

text: The top of lists nearest neighbors to " play " using GloVe vectors .
heading: Since adding

text: They are spread across several parts of speech ( e.g. , " played " , " playing " as verbs , and " player " , " game " as nouns ) but concentrated in the sportsrelated senses of " play " .
heading: Since adding

text: In contrast , the bottom two rows show nearest neighbor sentences from the SemCor dataset ( see below ) using the biLM 's context representation of " play " in the source sentence .
heading: Since adding

text: In these cases , the biLM is able to disambiguate both the part of speech and word sense in the source sentence .
heading: Since adding

text: These observations can be quantified using an intrinsic evaluation of the contextual representations similar to .
heading: Since adding

text: To isolate the information encoded by the biLM , the representations are used to directly make predictions fora fine grained word sense disambiguation ( WSD ) task and a POS tagging task .
heading: Since adding

text: Using this approach , it is also possible to compare to CoVe , and across each of the individual layers .
heading: Since adding

text: Word sense disambiguation Given a sentence , we can use the biLM representations to predict the sense of a target word using a simple 1nearest neighbor approach , similar to .
heading: Since adding

text: To do so , we first use the biLM to compute representations for all words in Sem - Cor 3.0 , our training corpus , and then take the average representation for each sense .
heading: Since adding

text: At test time , we again use the biLM to compute representations fora given target word and take the nearest neighbor sense from the training set , falling back to the first sense from WordNet for lemmas not observed during training .
heading: Since adding

text: compares WSD results using the evaluation framework from across the same suite of four test sets in .
heading: Since adding

text: Overall , the biLM top layer rep-resentations have F 1 of 69.0 and are better at WSD then the first layer .
heading: Since adding

text: This is competitive with a state - of - the - art WSD - specific supervised model using hand crafted features and a task specific biLSTM that is also trained with auxiliary coarse - grained semantic labels and POS tags .
heading: Since adding

text: The CoVe biLSTM layers follow a similar pattern to those from the biLM ( higher overall performance at the second layer compared to the first ) ; however , our biLM outperforms the CoVe biLSTM , which trails the WordNet first sense baseline .
heading: Since adding

text: POS tagging

To examine whether the biLM captures basic syntax , we used the context representations as input to a linear classifier that predicts POS tags with the Wall Street Journal portion of the Penn Treebank ( PTB ) .
heading: POS tagging

text: As the linear classifier adds only a small amount of model capacity , this is direct test of the biLM 's representations .
heading: POS tagging

text: Similar to WSD , the biLM representations are competitive with carefully tuned , task specific biLSTMs .
heading: POS tagging

text: However , unlike WSD , accuracies using the first biLM layer are higher than the top layer , consistent with results from deep biL - STMs in multi-task training and MT .
heading: POS tagging

text: CoVe POS tagging accuracies follow the same pattern as those from the biLM , and just like for WSD , the biLM achieves higher accuracies than the CoVe encoder .
heading: POS tagging

text: Implications for supervised tasks Taken together , these experiments confirm different layers in the biLM represent different types of information and explain why including all biLM layers is important for the highest performance in downstream tasks .
heading: POS tagging

text: In addition , the biLM 's representations are more transferable to WSD and POS tagging than those in CoVe , helping to illustrate why ELMo outperforms CoVe in downstream tasks .
heading: POS tagging

text: Sample efficiency
Adding ELMo to a model increases the sample efficiency considerably , both in terms of number of parameter updates to reach state - of - the - art performance and the overall training set size .
heading: Sample efficiency

text: For example , the SRL model reaches a maximum development F 1 after 486 epochs of training without ELMo .
heading: Sample efficiency

text: After adding ELMo , the model exceeds the baseline maximum at epoch 10 , a 98 % relative decrease in the number of updates needed to reach In addition , ELMo - enhanced models use smaller training sets more efficiently than models without ELMo.
heading: Sample efficiency

text: compares the performance of baselines models with and without ELMo as the percentage of the full training set is varied from 0.1 % to 100 % .
heading: Sample efficiency

text: Improvements with ELMo are largest for smaller training sets and significantly reduce the amount of training data needed to reach a given level of performance .
heading: Sample efficiency

text: In the SRL case , the ELMo model with 1 % of the training set has about the same F 1 as the baseline model with 10 % of the training set .
heading: Sample efficiency

text: visualizes the softmax - normalized learned layer weights .
heading: Sample efficiency

text: At the input layer , the task model favors the first biLSTM layer .
heading: Sample efficiency

text: For coreference and SQuAD , the this is strongly favored , but the distribution is less peaked for the other tasks .
heading: Sample efficiency

text: The output layer weights are relatively balanced , with a slight preference for the lower layers .
heading: Sample efficiency

text: Visualization of learned weights
We have introduced a general approach for learning high - quality deep context - dependent representations from biLMs , and shown large improvements when applying ELMo to abroad range of NLP tasks .
heading: Visualization of learned weights

text: Through ablations and other controlled experiments , we have also confirmed that the biLM layers efficiently encode different types of syntactic and semantic information about wordsin - context , and that using all layers improves overall task performance .

text: Fine tuning biLM
As noted in Sec. 3.4 , fine tuning the biLM on task specific data typically resulted in significant drops in perplexity .
heading: Fine tuning biLM

text: To fine tune on a given task , the supervised labels were temporarily ignored , the biLM fine tuned for one epoch on the training split and evaluated on the development split .
heading: Fine tuning biLM

text: Once fine tuned , the biLM weights were fixed during task training .
heading: Fine tuning biLM

text: lists the development set perplexities for the considered tasks .
heading: Fine tuning biLM

text: In every case except CoNLL 2012 , fine tuning results in a large improvement in perplexity , e.g. , from 72.1 to 16.8 for SNLI .
heading: Fine tuning biLM

text: The impact of fine tuning on supervised performance is task dependent .
heading: Fine tuning biLM

text: In the case of SNLI , fine tuning the biLM increased development accuracy 0.6 % from 88.9 % to 89.5 % for our single best model .
heading: Fine tuning biLM

text: However , for sentiment classification development set accuracy is approximately the same regardless whether a fine tuned biLM was used .
heading: Fine tuning biLM
