text: title
Sentence - State LSTM for Text Representation
abstract
Bi-directional
LSTMs area powerful tool for text representation .
heading: Bi-directional

text: On the other hand , they have been shown to suffer various limitations due to their sequential nature .
heading: Bi-directional

text: We investigate an alternative LSTM structure for encoding text , which consists of a parallel state for each word .
heading: Bi-directional

text: Recurrent steps are used to perform local and global information exchange between words simultaneously , rather than incremental reading of a sequence of words .
heading: Bi-directional

text: Results on various classification and sequence labelling benchmarks show that the proposed model has strong representation power , giving highly competitive performances compared to stacked BiLSTM models with similar parameter numbers .
heading: Bi-directional

text: Introduction
Neural models have become the dominant approach in the NLP literature .
heading: Introduction

text: Compared to handcrafted indicator features , neural sentence representations are less sparse , and more flexible in encoding intricate syntactic and semantic information .
heading: Introduction

text: Among various neural networks for encoding sentences , bi-directional LSTMs ( BiLSTM ) have been a dominant method , giving state - of - the - art results in language modelling , machine translation , syntactic parsing and question answering .
heading: Introduction

text: Despite their success , BiLSTMs have been shown to suffer several limitations .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , their inherently sequential nature endows computation non-parallel within the same sentence , which can lead to a computational bottleneck , hindering their use in the in - dustry .
heading: Introduction

text: In addition , local ngrams , which have been shown a highly useful source of contextual information for NLP , are not explicitly modelled .
heading: Introduction

text: Finally , sequential information flow leads to relatively weaker power in capturing longrange dependencies , which results in lower performance in encoding longer sentences .
heading: Introduction

text: We investigate an alternative recurrent neural network structure for addressing these issues .
heading: Introduction

text: As shown in , the main idea is to model the hidden states of all words simultaneously at each recurrent step , rather than one word at a time .
heading: Introduction

text: In particular , we view the whole sentence as a single state , which consists of sub-states for individual words and an overall sentence - level state .
heading: Introduction

text: To capture local and non-local contexts , states are updated recurrently by exchanging information between each other .
heading: Introduction

text: Consequently , we refer to our model as sentence - state LSTM , or S - LSTM in short .
heading: Introduction

text: Empirically , S - LSTM can give effective sentence encoding after 3 - 6 recurrent steps .
heading: Introduction

text: In contrast , the number of recurrent steps necessary for BiLSTM scales with the size of the sentence .
heading: Introduction

text: At each recurrent step , information exchange is conducted between consecutive words in the sentence , and between the sentence - level state and each word .
heading: Introduction

text: In particular , each word receives information from its predecessor and successor simultaneously .
heading: Introduction

text: From an initial state without information exchange , each word - level state can obtain 3 - gram , 5 - gram and 7 - gram information after 1 , 2 and 3 recurrent steps , respectively .
heading: Introduction

text: Being connected with every word , the sentence - level state vector serves to exchange non-local information with each word .
heading: Introduction

text: In addition , it can also be used as a global sentence - level representation for classification tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: Results on both classification and sequence labelling show that S - LSTM gives better accuracies compared to BiLSTM using the same number of parameters , while being faster .
heading: Introduction

text: We release our code and models at https://github.com/ leuchine /S - LSTM , which include all baselines and the final model .
heading: Introduction

text: Related Work
LSTM showed its early potentials in NLP when a neural machine translation system that leverages LSTM source encoding gave highly competitive results compared to the best SMT models .
heading: Related Work

text: LSTM encoders have since been explored for other tasks , including syntactic parsing , text classification and machine reading .
heading: Related Work

text: Bidirectional extensions have become a standard configuration for achieving state - of - the - art accuracies among various tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: S- LSTMs are similar to BiLSTMs in their recurrent bi-directional message flow between words , but different in the design of state transition .
heading: Related Work

text: CNNs ) also allow better parallelisation compared to LSTMs for sentence encoding , thanks to parallelism among convolution filters .
heading: Related Work

text: On the other hand , convolution features embody only fix - sized local ngram information , whereas sentence - level feature aggregation via pooling can lead to loss of information .
heading: Related Work

text: In contrast , S - LSTM uses a global sentence - level node to assemble and back - distribute local information in the recurrent state transition process , suffering less information loss compared to pooling .
heading: Related Work

text: Attention has recently been explored as a standalone method for sentence encoding , giving competitive results compared to Bi - LSTM encoders for neural machine translation .
heading: Related Work

text: The attention mechanism allows parallelisation , and can play a similar role to the sentence - level state in S - LSTMs , which uses neural gates to integrate word - level information compared to hierarchical attention .
heading: Related Work

text: S - LSTM further allows local communication between neighbouring words .
heading: Related Work

text: Hierarchical stacking of CNN layers allows better interaction between non-local components in a sentence via incremental levels of abstraction .
heading: Related Work

text: S - LSTM is similar to hierarchical attention and stacked CNN in this respect , incrementally refining sentence representations .
heading: Related Work

text: However , S - LSTM models hierarchical encoding of sentence structure as a recurrent state transition process .
heading: Related Work

text: In nature , our work belongs to the family of LSTM sentence representations .
heading: Related Work

text: S - LSTM is inspired by message passing over graphs ) .
heading: Related Work

text: Graph - structure neural models have been used for computer program verification and image object detection .
heading: Related Work

text: The closest previous work in NLP includes the use of convolutional neural networks and DAG LSTMs for modelling syntactic structures .
heading: Related Work

text: Compared to our work , their motivations and network structures are highly different .
heading: Related Work

text: In particular , the DAG LSTM of is a natural extension of tree LSTM , and is sequential rather than parallel in nature .
heading: Related Work

text: To our knowledge , we are the first to investigate a graph RNN for encoding sentences , proposing parallel graph states for integrating word - level and sentence - level information .
heading: Related Work

text: In this perspective , our contribution is similar to that of and in introducing a neural representation to the NLP literature .
heading: Related Work

heading: Model

heading: Model

heading: Model

text: S- LSTM vs BiLSTM : As shown in , BiLSTM gives significantly better accuracies compared to uni-directional LSTM 2 , with the training time per epoch growing from 67 seconds to 106 seconds .
heading: Model

text: Stacking 2 layers of BiLSTM gives further improvements to development results , with a larger time of 207 seconds .
heading: Model

text: 3 layers of stacked BiLSTM does not further improve the results .
heading: Model

text: In contrast , S - LSTM gives a development result of 82 . 64 % , which is significantly better compared to 2 - layer stacked BiLSTM , with a smaller number of model parameters and a shorter time of 65 seconds .
heading: Model

text: We additionally make comparisons with stacked CNNs and hierarchical attention , shown in ( the CNN and Transformer rows ) , where N indicates the number of attention layers .
heading: Model

text: CNN is the most efficient among all models compared , with the smallest model size .
heading: Model

text: On the other hand , a 3 - layer stacked CNN gives an accuracy of 81 . 46 % , which is also the lowest compared with BiLSTM , hierarchical attention and S - LSTM .
heading: Model

text: The best performance of hierarchical attention is between single - layer and two - layer BiLSTMs in terms of both accuracy and efficiency .
heading: Model

text: S - LSTM gives significantly better accuracies compared with both CNN and hierarchical attention .
heading: Model

text: Influence of external attention mechanism .
heading: Model

text: additionally shows the results of BiLSTM and S - LSTM when external attention is used as described in Section 3.3 .
heading: Model

text: Attention leads to improved accuracies for both BiLSTM and S - LSTM in classification , with S - LSTM still outperforming BiLSTM significantly .
heading: Model

text: The result suggests that external techniques such as attention can play orthogonal roles compared with internal recurrent structures , therefore benefiting both BiLSTMs and S - LSTMs .
heading: Model

text: Similar observations are found using external CRF layers for sequence labelling .
heading: Model

text: Contrast with BiLSTM
The difference between S - LSTM and BiLSTM can be understood with respect to their recurrent states .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: While BiL - STM uses only one state in each direction to represent the subsequence from the beginning to a certain word , S - LSTM uses a structural state to represent the full sentence , which consists of a sentence - level sub state and n + 2 word - level sub states , simultaneously .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: Different from BiLSTMs , for which ht at different time steps are used to represent w 0 , . . . , w n + 1 , respectively , the word - level states ht i and sentence - level state gt of S - LSTMs directly correspond to the goal outputs hi and g , as introduced in the beginning of this section .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: As t increases from 0 , ht i and gt are enriched with increasingly deeper context information .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: From the perspective of information flow , BiL - STM passes information from one end of the sentence to the other .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: As a result , the number of time steps scales with the size of the input .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: In contrast , S - LSTM allows bi-directional information flow at each word simultaneously , and additionally between the sentence - level state and every wordlevel state .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: At each step , each hi captures an increasing larger ngram context , while additionally communicating globally to all other h j via g.
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: The optimal number of recurrent steps is decided by the end - task performance , and does not necessarily scale with the sentence size .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: As a result , S - LSTM can potentially be both more efficient and more accurate compared with BiLSTMs .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: Increasing window size .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: By default S - LSTM exchanges information only between neighbouring words , which can be seen as adopting a 1 word window on each side .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: The window size can be extended to 2 , 3 or more words in order to allow more communication in a state transition , expediting information exchange .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: To this end , we modify Eq 2 , integrating additional context words to ? ti , with extended gates and cells .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: For example , with a window size of 2 ,
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: We study the effectiveness of window size in our experiments .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: Additional sentence - level nodes .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: By default S - LSTM uses one sentence - level node .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: One way of enriching the parameter space is to add more sentence - level nodes , each communicating with word - level nodes in the same way as described by Eq 3 .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: In addition , different sentence - level nodes can communicate with each other during state transition .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: When one sentence - level node is used for classification outputs , the other sentencelevel node can serve as hidden memory units , or latent features .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: We study the effectiveness of multiple sentence - level nodes empirically .
heading: Contrast with BiLSTM

text: In , the number of recurrent state transition steps of S - LSTM is decided according to the best development performance .
heading: Development Experiments

heading: Development Experiments

text: As can be seen from the figure , when the number of time steps increases from 1 to 11 , the accuracies generally increase , before reaching a maximum value .
heading: Development Experiments

text: This shows the effectiveness of recurrent information exchange in S - LSTM state transition .
heading: Development Experiments

text: On the other hand , no significant differences are observed on the peak accuracies given by different window sizes , although a larger window size ( e.g.
heading: Development Experiments

text: Final Results for Classification
The final results on the movie review and rich text classification datasets are shown in Tables 4 and 5 , respectively .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: In addition to training time per epoch , test times are additionally reported .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: We use the best settings on the movie review development dataset for both S - LSTMs and BiLSTMs .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: The step number for S - LSTMs is set to 9 .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: As shown in , the final results on the movie review dataset are consistent with the development results , where S - LSTM outperforms BiL - STM significantly , with a faster speed .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: Observations on CNN and hierarchical attention are consistent with the development results .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: S - LSTM also gives highly competitive results when compared with existing methods in the literature .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: As shown in , among the 16 datasets of , S - LSTM gives the best results on 12 , compared with BiLSTM and 2 layered BiL - STM models .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: The average accuracy of S - LSTM is 85.6 % , significantly higher compared with 84.9 % by 2 - layer stacked BiLSTM .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: 3 - layer stacked BiL - STM gives an average accuracy of 84. 57 % , which is lower compared to a 2 - layer stacked BiLSTM , with a training time per epoch of 423.6 seconds .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: The relative speed advantage of S - LSTM over BiLSTM is larger on the 16 datasets as compared to the movie review test test .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: This is because the average length of inputs is larger on the 16 datasets ( see Section 4.5 ) .
heading: Final Results for Classification

text: Final Results for Sequence Labelling
Bi-directional
RNN - CRF structures , and in particular BiLSTM - CRFs , have achieved the state of the art in the literature for sequence labelling tasks , including POS - tagging and NER .
heading: Bi-directional

text: We compare S - LSTM - CRF with BiLSTM - CRF for sequence labelling , using the same settings as decided on the movie review development experiments for both BiLSTMs and S - LSTMs .
heading: Bi-directional

text: For the latter , we decide the number of recurrent stepson the respective development sets for sequence labelling .
heading: Bi-directional

text: The POS accuracies and NER F1 - scores against the number of recurrent steps are shown in ( a ) and ( b ) , respectively .
heading: Bi-directional

text: For POS tagging , the best step number is set to 7 , with a development accuracy of 97.58 % .
heading: Bi-directional

text: For NER , the step number is set to 9 , with a development F1 - score of 94.98 % .
heading: Bi-directional

text: As can be seen in with three layers of stacked LSTMs .
heading: Bi-directional

text: For NER , S - LSTM gives an F1 - score of 91.57 % on the CoNLL test set , which is significantly better compared with BiLSTMs .
heading: Bi-directional

text: Stacking more layers of BiLSTMs leads to slightly better F1 - scores compared with a single - layer BiL - STM .
heading: Bi-directional

text: Our BiLSTM results are comparable to the results reported by and , who also use bidirectional RNN - CRF structures .
heading: Bi-directional

text: In contrast , S - LSTM gives the best reported results under the same settings .
heading: Bi-directional

text: In the second section of learning using additional language model objectives , obtaining an F-score of 86 . 26 % ; leverage character - level language models , obtaining an F- score of 91. 93 % , which is the current best result on the dataset .
heading: Bi-directional

text: All the three models are based on BiLSTM - CRF .
heading: Bi-directional

text: On the other hand , these semi-supervised learning techniques are orthogonal to our work , and can potentially be used for S - LSTM also .
heading: Bi-directional

text: Analysis
Figure 4 ( a ) and ( b ) show the accuracies against the sentence length on the movie review and CoNLL datasets , respectively , where test samples are binned in batches of 80 .
heading: Analysis

text: We find that the performances of both S - LSTM and BiLSTM decrease as the sentence length increases .
heading: Analysis

text: On the other hand , S - LSTM demonstrates relatively better robustness compared to BiLSTMs .
heading: Analysis

text: This confirms our intuition that a sentence - level node can facilitate better non-local communication .
heading: Analysis

text: these comparisons , we mix all training instances , order them by the size , and put them into 10 equal groups , the medium sentence lengths of which are shown .
heading: Analysis

text: As can be seen from the figure , the speed advantage of S - LSTM is larger when the size of the input text increases , thanks to a fixed number of recurrent steps .
heading: Analysis

text: Similar to hierarchical attention , there is a relative disadvantage of S - LSTM in comparison with BiLSTM , which is that the memory consumption is relatively larger .
heading: Analysis

text: For example , over the movie review development set , the actual GPU memory consumption by S - LSTM , Bi LSTM , 2 - layer stacked BiLSTM and 4 - layer stacked BiLSTM are 252M , 89M , 146 M and 253M , respectively .
heading: Analysis

text: This is due to the fact that computation is performed in parallel by S - LSTM and hierarchical attention .
heading: Analysis

text: Conclusion
We have investigated S - LSTM , a recurrent neural network for encoding sentences , which offers richer contextual information exchange with more parallelism compared to BiLSTMs .
heading: Conclusion

text: Results on a range of classification and sequence labelling tasks show that S - LSTM outperforms BiLSTMs using the same number of parameters , demonstrating that S - LSTM can be a useful addition to the neural toolbox for encoding sentences .
heading: Conclusion

text: The structural nature in S - LSTM states allows straightforward extension to tree structures , resulting in highly parallelisable tree LSTMs .
heading: Conclusion

text: We leave such investigation to future work .
heading: Conclusion

text: Next directions also include the investigation of S - LSTM to more NLP tasks , such as machine translation .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Robust Lexical Features for Improved Neural Network Named - Entity Recognition
heading: title

text: abstract
Neural network approaches to Named - Entity Recognition reduce the need for carefully handcrafted features .
heading: abstract

text: While some features do remain in state - of - the - art systems , lexical features have been mostly discarded , with the exception of gazetteers .
heading: abstract

text: In this work , we show that this is unfair : lexical features are actually quite useful .
heading: abstract

text: We propose to embed words and entity types into a lowdimensional vector space we train from annotated data produced by distant supervision thanks to Wikipedia .
heading: abstract

text: From this , we compute - offline - a feature vector representing each word .
heading: abstract

text: When used with a vanilla recurrent neural network model , this representation yields substantial improvements .
heading: abstract

text: We establish anew state - of - the - art F1 score of 87.95 on ONTONOTES 5.0 , while matching state - of - the - art performance with a F 1 score of 91.73 on the over - studied CONLL - 2003 dataset .
heading: abstract

text: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License .
heading: abstract

text: License details :
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Named - Entity Recognition ( NER ) is the task of identifying textual mentions and classifying them into a predefined set of types .
heading: Introduction

text: Various approaches have been proposed to tackle the task , from hand - crafted feature - based machine learning models like conditional random fields and perceptron , to deep neural models .
heading: Introduction

text: Word representations , also known as word embeddings , area key element for multiple NLP tasks including NER .
heading: Introduction

text: Due to the small amount of named - entity annotated data , embeddings are used to extend , rather than replace , hand - crafted features in order to obtain state - of - the - art performance .
heading: Introduction

text: Recent studies have explored methods for supplying deep sequential taggers with complementary features to standard embeddings .
heading: Introduction

text: and tested special embeddings extracted from a neural language model ( LM ) trained on a large corpus .
heading: Introduction

text: LM embeddings capture context - dependent aspects of word meaning using future ( forward LM ) and previous ( backward LM ) context words .
heading: Introduction

text: When this information is added to standard features , it leads to significant improvements in NER .
heading: Introduction

text: Also , showed that external knowledge resources ( namely gazetteers ) are crucial to NER performance .
heading: Introduction

text: Gazetteer features encode the presence of word n-grams in predefined lists of NEs .
heading: Introduction

text: In this work , we discuss some of the limitations of gazetteer features and propose an alternative lexical representation which is trained offline and that can be added to any neural NER system .
heading: Introduction

text: Ina nutshell , we embed words and entity types into a joint vector space by leveraging WiFiNE , a ressource which automatically annotates mentions in Wikipedia with 120 entity types .
heading: Introduction

text: From this vector space , we compute for each word a 120 - dimensional vector , where each dimension encodes the similarity of the word with an entity type .
heading: Introduction

text: We call this vector an LS representation , for Lexical Similarity .
heading: Introduction

text: When included in a vanilla LSTM - CRF NER model , LS representations lead to significant gains .
heading: Introduction

text: We establish anew state - of - the - art F 1 score of 87.95 on ONTONOTES 5.0 , while matching state - of - the - art performance on the over - studied In the rest of this paper , we motivate our work in Section 2 .
heading: Introduction

text: We describe how we compute LS vectors in Section 3 .
heading: Introduction

text: We present our system in Section 4 and report results in Section 5 . In Section 6 , we discuss related works before concluding in Section 7 .
heading: Introduction

text: Motivation
Gazetteers are lists of entities that are associated with specific NE categories .
heading: Motivation

text: They are widely used as a feature source in NER , and have been successfully included in feature - based models .
heading: Motivation

text: Typically , lists of entities are compiled from structured data sources such as DBpedia or Freebase .
heading: Motivation

text: The surface form of the title of a Wikipedia article , as well as aliases and redirects are mapped to an entity type using the object type attribute of the related DBpedia ( or Freebase ) page .
heading: Motivation

text: use this methodology to compile 30 lists of fine - grained entity types extracted from Wikipedia , while Chiu and Nichols ( 2016 ) create 4 gazetteers that map to CoNLL categories ( PER , LOC , ORG and MISC ) .
heading: Motivation

text: Despite their importance , gazetteer - based features suffer from a number of limitations .
heading: Motivation

text: Binary representation .
heading: Motivation

text: Gazetteer features encode only the presence of an n-gram in each list and omit its relative frequency .
heading: Motivation

text: For example , the word " France " can be used as a person , an organization , or a location , while it likely refers to the country most of the time .
heading: Motivation

text: Binary features can not capture this preference .
heading: Motivation

text: Generation .
At test time , we need to match every n-gram ( up to the length of the longest lexicon entry ) in a sentence against entries in the lexicons , which is time consuming .
heading: Generation .

text: In their work , Chiu and Nichols ( 2016 ) use 4 lists that count over 2.3 M entries .
heading: Generation .

text: Non-entity words .
heading: Generation .

text: Gazetteer features do not capture signal from non-entity words , while earlier feature - based models strived to encode that some words ( or n-grams ) trigger specific entity types .
heading: Generation .

text: For instance , words such as " eat " , " directed " or " born " are words that typically appear after a mention of type PER .
heading: Generation .

text: To overcome those limitations , we propose an alternative approach where we embed annotations mined from Wikipedia into a vector space from which we compute a feature vector that represent words .
heading: Generation .

text: This vector compactly and efficiently encodes both gazetteer and lexical information .
heading: Generation .

text: Note that attest time , we only have to feed our model with this feature vector , which is efficient .
heading: Generation .

text: Our Method
Embedding Words and Entity Types
Turning Wikipedia into a corpus of named - entities annotated with types is a task that received continuous attention over the years .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: It consists mainly in exploiting the hyperlink structure of Wikipedia in order to detect entity mentions .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: Then , structured data from a knowledge base ( for instance Freebase ) are used to map hyperlinks to entity types .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: Because the number of anchored strings in Wikipedia is no more than 3 % of the text tokens , proposed to augment Wikipedia articles with mentions unmarked in Wikipedia , thanks to a mix of heuristics that benefit the Wikipedia structure , as well as a coreference resolution system adapted specifically to Wikipedia .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: The authors applied their approach on English Wikipedia and produce coarse ( 4 classes ) and finegrained ( 120 labels ) named- entity annotations , leading to WiNER and WiFiNE .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: In this work , we adopt WiFiNE which is publicly available at http://rali.iro.umontreal.ca/rali/en/wifiner-wikipedia-for-et as our source of annotations .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: Each entity mention is mapped ( via it s Freebase object type attribute ) to a pre-defined set of 120 entity types .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: Types are stored in a 2 - level hierarchical structure ( e.g. / person and / person / musician ) .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: The corpus consist of 3.2 M Wikipedia articles , comprising 1.3G tokens that we annotated with 157.4 M named - entity mentions and their types .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: We used this very large quantity of automatically annotated data for jointly embedding words and entity types into the same low - dimensional space .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: The key idea consists in learning an embedding for each entity type using its surrounding words .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: For instance , the embedding for / product / software will be trained using context words that surround all entities that were ( automatically ) labelled as / product / software in Wikipedia .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: In practice , we found that simply concatenating a sentence ( v1 ) with its annotated version ( v 2 ) , as illustrated in , offers a simple but efficient way of combining words and entity types so that embeddings can make good use of them .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: We use the FastText toolkit to learn the uncased embeddings for both words and entity types .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: We train a skipgram model to learn 100 - dimensional vectors with a minimum word frequency cutoff of 5 , and a window size of 5 .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: This configuration ( recommended by the authors ) performs the best in the experiments described in Section 5 .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: Since FastText learns representations of character ngrams , it has the ability to produce vectors for unknown words .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: For visualization proposes , we only plot single - word mentions that were annotated in WiFiNE with one of those 6 types .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: Words were randomly and proportionally sampled according to the frequency of each entity type .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: In addition , words have the color associated with the most frequent type they were annotated within WiFiNE .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: We observe that mentions often annotated by a given type in our resource tend to cluster around this entity type .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: For instance , " firefox " is close to the type / product / software , while " enzyme " is close to the / biology entity type .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: We also notice that words that are labelled with different types tend to appear between types they were annotated with .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: For instance , " gpx2 " , which is used both as a software and as a gene , has it s embedding in between / product / software and / biology .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: We inspected some of the words plotted in , and found that " jrun " and " xp " are incorrectly labelled as / product / weapon in WiFiNE .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: But since these words are seen in a software context , their embeddings are closer to the / product / software embedding than the / product / weapon one .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: We feel this tolerance to noise is a desirable feature , one that hopefully allows a more efficient use of distant supervision .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: Last , we also observe the tendency of rare words to cluster around their entity type .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: For instance , " iota " and " x.org " are embedded near their respective types , despite the fact that they appear less than 30 times in the version of Wikipedia used to compile WiFiNE .
heading: Embedding Words and Entity Types

text: LS Representation

This joint vector space only serves the purpose of associating to each word a LS representation , that is , a 120 - dimensional vector where the ith coefficient is a value in the [ ? 1 , + 1 ] interval , equal to the cosine similarity 1 between the word embedding and the embedding of the ith entity type ( we have 120 types ) .
heading: LS Representation

text: Word
Entity .
shows the topmost similar entity types for proper names ( left column ) and common words ( right column ) .
heading: Entity .

text: We observe that ambiguous mentions ( those annotated with several types ) are adequately handled .
heading: Entity .

text: For instance , the LS representation of the word " hilton " encodes that it more often refers to a hotel or a restaurant than to an actress .
heading: Entity .

text: Also , we observe that entity words that are either not or rarely annotated in WiFiNE are still adequately associated with their right type .
heading: Entity .

text: For instance , " dammstadt " , which appears only 5 times in WiFiNE , and which refers to the Damm city in Germany , is most similar to / location / city and / location / railway .
heading: Entity .

text: Interestingly , this mention does not have its page in English Wikipedia .
heading: Entity .

text: Furthermore , we observe that non-entity context words have a strong similarity to types they precede or succeed .
heading: Entity .

text: For instance the verb " directed " is very close to / person / director , an entity type that usually precedes it , and to / art / film , that usually follows it .
heading: Entity .

text: Likewise , the preposition " in " is near / date and / location / city , which frequently follow " in " .
heading: Entity .

text: Strength of the LS Representation
To summarize , we propose a compact lexical representation which is computed offline , therefore incurring no computation burden attest time
heading: Strength of the LS Representation

text: This representation encodes the preference of an entity - mention word fora given type , an information out of reach of binary gazetteer features .
heading: Strength of the LS Representation

text: It also lends itself nicely to the inclusion of lexical features that have been successfully used in earlier feature - based systems .
heading: Strength of the LS Representation

text: Also , because entity types are well represented in WiFiNE , their embeddings are robust :
heading: Strength of the LS Representation

text: Our representation does accommodate unfrequent words and seems tolerant to the inherent noise of distant supervision .
heading: Strength of the LS Representation

text: Our NER System
In order to test the efficiency of our lexical feature representation , we implemented a state - of - the - art NER system we now describe .
heading: Our NER System

text: Bi-LSTM- CRF
heading: Our NER System

text: Model
We adopt the popular Bi - LSTM - CRF architecture , a de facto baseline in many sequential tagging tasks .
heading: Model

text: Features
In addition to the LS vector , we incorporate publicly available pre-trained embeddings , as well as character - level , and capitalization features .
heading: Features

text: Those features have been shown to be crucial for stateof - the - art performance .
heading: Features

text: Word Embeddings
We experimented with several publicly available word embeddings , such as Senna , Word2 Vec , GloVe , and SSKIP .
heading: Word Embeddings

text: We find that the latter performs the best in our experiments .
heading: Word Embeddings

text: SSKIP embeddings are 100 - dimensional case sensitive vectors that where trained using a n-skip - gram model on 42B tokens .
heading: Word Embeddings

text: These embeddings were previously used by , who report good performance on CONLL , and state - of - the - art results on ONTONOTES respectively .
heading: Word Embeddings

text: Note that these pre-trained embeddings are adjusted during training .
heading: Word Embeddings

text: Character Embeddings
Following , we use a forward and a backward LSTM to derive a representation of each word from its characters ( right part of .
heading: Character Embeddings

text: A character lookup table is randomly initialized , then trained at the same time as the Bi - LSTM model sketched in Section 4.1 .
heading: Character Embeddings

text: Capitalization Features

Similarly to previous works , we use capitalization features for characterizing certain categories of capitalization patterns : all Upper , allLower , upperFirst , upperNotFirst , numeric or noAlphaNum .
heading: Capitalization Features

text: We define a random lookup table for these features , and learn its parameters during training .
heading: Capitalization Features

text: LS Vectors
Contrarily to previous features , lexical vectors are computed offline and are not adjusted during training .
heading: LS Vectors

text: We found useful in practice to apply a MinMax scaler in the range [ ? 1 , + 1 ] to each LS vector we computed ; thus , [.. , 0.095 , .. , 0.20 , .. , 0.76 , .. ] becomes [.. , ? 1 , .. , ? 0.67 , .. , 1 , ..].
heading: LS Vectors

text: Experiments
Data and Evaluation
We consider two well - established NER benchmarks :
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: CONLL-2003 and ONTONOTES 5.0 . provides an overview of the two datasets .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: As we can see , ONTONOTES is much larger .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: For both datasets , we convert the IOB encoding to BILOU , since found the latter to perform better .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: In keeping with others , we report mention - level F 1 score using the conlleval script 2 .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: The ) is a well known collection of Reuters newswire articles that contains a large portion of sports news .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: It is annotated with four entity types : Person ( PER ) , Location ( LOC ) , Organization ( ORG ) and Miscellaneous ( MISC ) .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: The four entity types are fairly evenly distributed , and the train / dev / test datasets present a similar type distribution. , magazine ( 120 k ) , newswire ( 625 k ) , and web data ( 300 k ) .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: This dataset is annotated with 18 entity types , and is much larger than CONLL .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: Following previous researches , we use the official train / dev / test split of the CoNLL - 2012 shared task .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: Also , we exclude ( both during training and testing ) the New Testaments portion as it does not contain gold NE annotations .
heading: Data and Evaluation

text: Training and Implementation
Training is carried out by mini-batch stochastic gradient descent ( SGD ) with a momentum of 0.9 and a gradient clipping of 5.0 .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: The mini-batch is 10 for both datasets , and learning rates are 0.009 and 0.013 for CONLL and ONTONOTES respectively .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: More sophisticated optimization algorithms such as AdaDelta or Adam ( Kingma and Ba , 2014 ) converge faster , but none outperformed SGD with exponential learning rate decay in our experiments .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: Our system uses a single Bi - LSTM layer at the word level whose hidden dimensions are set to 128 and 256 for CONLL and ONTONOTES respectively .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: For both models , the character embedding size was set to 25 , and the hidden dimension of the forward and backward character LSTMs are set to 50 .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: To mitigate overfitting , we apply a dropout mask with a probability of 0.5 on the input and output vectors of the Bi - LSTM layer .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: For both datasets , we set the dimension of capitalization embeddings to 25 and trained the models up to 50 epochs .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: We tuned the hyper - parameters by grid search , and used early stopping based on the performance on the development set .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: We varied dropout . 65 ] ) , hidden units ) , capitalization ) and char ) embedding dimensions , learning rate ( [ 0.001 , 0.015 ] by step 0.002 ) , and optimization algorithms and fixed the other hyper - parameters .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: We implemented our system using the Tensorflow library , and ran our models on a GeForce GTX TITAN Xp GPU .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: Training requires about 2.5 hours for CONLL and 8 hours for ONTONOTES .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: shows the development set performance of our final models on each dataset compared to the work of .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: The authors use an architecture similar to ours , but use a binary gazetteer feature set , while we use our LS representation .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: Since our systems involve random initialization , we report the mean as well as the standard deviation over five runs .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: The improvements yielded by our model on the CONLL dataset are significant although modest , while those observed on ONTONOTES are more substantial .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: We also observe a lower variance of our system over the 5 runs .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: First , we observe that our model significantly outperforms models that use extensive sets of handcrafted features ) as well as the system of Standard deviation on the test set is reported in 2015 ) that uses NE and Entity Linking annotations to jointly optimize the performance on both tasks .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: Second , our model outperforms as well other NN models that only use standard word embeddings , which indicates that our lexical feature vector is complementary to standard word embeddings .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: Third , our system matches state - of - the - art performances of models that use either more complex architectures or more elaborate features .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: use three layers of stacked residual RNN ( Bi - LSTM ) with bias decoding .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: Our model is much simpler and faster .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: They report a performance of 90.43 when using an architecture similar to ours .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: The two systems that have slightly higher F 1 scores on the CONLL dataset both use embeddings obtained from a forward and a backward Language Model trained on the One Billion Word Benchmark .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: They report gains between 0.8 and 1.2 points by using such LM embeddings , which suggests that LS vectors are indeed efficient .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: Unfortunately , due to time and resource constraints , 4 we were notable to measure whether both features complement each other .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: This is left for future investigations .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: reports the F 1 score of our system compared to the performance reported by others on the ONTONOTES test set .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: To the best of our knowledge , we surpass previously reported F 1 scores on this dataset .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: In particular , our system significantly outperforms the Bi - LSTM - CNN - CRF models of ( Chiu and Nichols , 2016 ) and by an absolute gain of 1.68 and 0.96 points respectively .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: Less surprisingly , it surpasses systems with hand - crafted features , including that use gazetteers , and the system of which uses coreference annotation in ONTONOTES to jointly model NER , entity linking , and coreference resolution tasks .
heading: Training and Implementation

text: Results on the Development Set
CONLL
Results on CONLL
Results on ONTONOTES
Model
We also observe that models that use both feature sets significantly outperform other configurations .
heading: Model

text: To confirm that the gains came from our feature vector and not from increasing the number of hidden units , we tested several SSKIP models by increasing the LSTM hidden layer dimension so that number of parameters is the same as the model with LS vectors .
heading: Model

text: We observed a degradation of performance on both datasets , mostly due to overfitting on the training set .
heading: Model

text: From those results , we conclude that our lexical representation and the SSKIP one are complementary .
heading: Model

text: Ablation Results
In this experiment , we directly compare the LS representation with the SSKIP word - embedding feature set .
heading: Ablation Results

text: In order to maintain a high level of performance , both character and capitalization features are used in all configurations .
heading: Ablation Results

text: We want to point out that LS vectors are not adapted during training , contrarily to the SSKIP embeddings .
heading: Ablation Results

text: Similarly to Section 5.3 , we report in , for each feature configuration , the average F 1 score as well as the standard deviation over five runs .
heading: Ablation Results

text: We observe that on both CONLL and ONTONOTES , the SSKIP model outperforms our feature vector approach by 0.65 F1 points on average .
heading: Ablation Results

text: The difference is not has high as we first expected , especially since the SSKIP model is adjusted during training , while our representation is not .
heading: Ablation Results

text: Still , LS vectors seem to encode a large portion of the information needed to model the NER task .
heading: Ablation Results

text: Also , it is worth mentioning that our embeddings are trained on 1.3B words compared to 42B for SSKIP .
heading: Ablation Results

text: Related Works
Traditional approaches to NER , like CRF - based and Perceptron - based systems ( Ratinov and Roth , 2009 ) have dominated the field for over a decade .
heading: Related Works

text: They rely heavily on hand - engineered features and external resources such as gazetteers .
heading: Related Works

text: One major drawback of such an approach is its weak generalization power .
heading: Related Works

text: Current state - of - the art systems use a combination of Convolutional Neural Networks ( CNNs ) , Bi - LSTMs , along with a CRF decoder .
heading: Related Works

text: CNNs are used to encode character - level features ( prefix and suffix ) , while LSTM is used to encode word - level features .
heading: Related Works

text: Finally , a CRF is placed on top of those models in order to decode the best tag sequence .
heading: Related Works

text: Pre-trained embeddings obtained by unsupervised learning are core features of those models .
heading: Related Works

text: In this work , we show that deep NN architectures can also benefit from lexical features , at least when encoded in the compact form we propose .
heading: Related Works

text: and propose an alternative approach different from ours .
heading: Related Works

text: They incorporate LM embeddings that were pre-trained on a large unlabelled corpus as features for NER .
heading: Related Works

text: These embeddings allow to generate a representation fora word depending on its context .
heading: Related Works

text: For instance , the LM embeddings of the word France in " France is a developed country " is different than that in " Anatole France began his literary career " .
heading: Related Works

text: Such embeddings are trained on very large amount of texts .
heading: Related Works

text: Our feature set is crafted from distant supervision applied to Wikipedia , a much less time - consuming process which we showed to be nevertheless adapted to rare words .
heading: Related Works

text: Chiu and Nichols ( 2016 ) used gazetteer features in order to establish state - of - the - art performance on both CONLL and ONTONOTES .
heading: Related Works

text: They mined DBPedia in order to compile 4 lists of named - entities that contain over 2.3 M entries .
heading: Related Works

text: We show that LS representations outperform their gazetteer features .
heading: Related Works

text: Conclusion and Future Work
We have explored the idea of generating lexical features for NER out of Wikipedia data automatically annotated with fine - grained entity types .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: We used WiFiNE , a Wikipedia dump annotated with fine entity type mentions , for training a vector space that jointly embeds words and named - entities .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: This vector space is used to compute a 120 dimensional vector per word , which encodes the similarity of the word to each of the entity types .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: Our results show that our proposed lexical representation , even though it is not adjusted at training time , matches state - of - the - art results compared to more complex approaches on the well - studied CONLL dataset , and delivers anew state - of - the - art F 1 score of 87.95 on the more diversified ONTONOTES dataset .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: We further observe larger gains on collections with more unfrequent words .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: The source code and the data we used in this work are publicly available at http://rali.iro. umontreal.ca/rali/en/wikipedia-lex-sim , with the hope that other researchers will report gains , when using our lexical representation .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: As a future work , we want to investigate the usefulness of our LS feature representation on other NER tasks , including NER in tweets where out - of - vocabulary and low - frequency words represent a challenge ; as well as finer - grained NER which suffers from the lack of manually annotated training data .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: title
A Neural Transition - based Model for Nested Mention Recognition
heading: title

text: abstract
It is common that entity mentions can contain other mentions recursively .
heading: abstract

text: This paper introduces a scalable transition - based method to model the nested structure of mentions .
heading: abstract

text: We first map a sentence with nested mentions to a designated forest where each mention corresponds to a constituent of the forest .
heading: abstract

text: Our shiftreduce based system then learns to construct the forest structure in a bottom - up manner through an action sequence whose maximal length is guaranteed to be three times of the sentence length .
heading: abstract

text: Based on Stack - LSTM which is employed to efficiently and effectively represent the states of the system in a continuous space , our system is further incorporated with a character - based component to capture letterlevel patterns .
heading: abstract

text: Our model achieves the stateof - the - art results on ACE datasets , showing its effectiveness in detecting nested mentions .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction

There has been an increasing interest in named entity recognition or more generally recognizing entity mentions 2 ) that the nested hierarchical structure of entity mentions should betaken into account to better facilitate downstream tasks like question answering , relation extraction , event extraction , and coreference resolution .
heading: Introduction

text: Practically , the mentions with nested structures frequently exist in news and biomedical documents .
heading: Introduction

text: For example in Traditional sequence labeling models such as conditional random fields ( CRF ) do not allow hierarchical structures between segments , making them incapable to handle such problems .
heading: Introduction

text: presented a chart - based parsing approach where each sentence with nested mentions is mapped to a rooted constituent tree .
heading: Introduction

text: The issue of using a chart - based parser is its cubic time complexity in the number of words in the sentence .
heading: Introduction

text: To achieve a scalable and effective solution for recognizing nested mentions , we design a transition - based system which is inspired by the recent success of employing transition - based methods for constituent parsing ) and named entity recognition , especially when they are paired with neural networks .
heading: Introduction

text: Generally , each sentence with nested mentions is mapped to a forest where each outermost mention forms a tree consisting of its inner mentions .
heading: Introduction

text: Then our transition - based system learns to construct this forest through a sequence of shift - reduce actions .
heading: Introduction

text: shows an example of such a forest .
heading: Introduction

text: In contrast , the tree structure by further uses a root node to connect all tree elements .
heading: Introduction

text: Our forest representation eliminates the root node so that the number of actions required to construct it can be reduced significantly .
heading: Introduction

text: Following , we employ Stack - LSTM to represent the system 's state , which consists of the states of input , stack and action history , in a continuous space incrementally .
heading: Introduction

text: The ( partially ) processed nested mentions in the stack are encoded with recursive neural networks where composition functions are used to capture dependencies between nested mentions .
heading: Introduction

text: Based on the observation that letter - level patterns such as capitalization and prefix can be beneficial in detecting mentions , we incorporate a characterlevel LSTM to capture such morphological information .
heading: Introduction

text: Meanwhile , this character - level component can also help deal with the out - of - vocabulary problem of neural models .
heading: Introduction

text: We conduct experiments in three standard datasets .
heading: Introduction

text: Our system achieves the state - of - the - art performance on ACE datasets and comparable performance in GENIA dataset .
heading: Introduction

text: Related Work

Entity mention recognition with nested structures has been explored first with rule - based approaches where the authors first detected the innermost mentions and then relied on rule - based postprocessing methods to identify outer mentions .
heading: Related Work

text: proposed a structured multi-label model to represent overlapping segments in a sentence .
heading: Related Work

text: but it came with a cubic time complexity in the number of words .
heading: Related Work

text: proposed several ways to combine multiple conditional random fields ( CRF ) for such tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: Their best results were obtained by cascading several CRF models in a specific order while each model is responsible for detecting mentions of a particular type .
heading: Related Work

text: However , such an approach can not model nested mentions of the same type , which frequently appear .
heading: Related Work

text: and proposed new representations of mention hypergraph and mention separator to model overlapping mentions .
heading: Related Work

text: However , the nested structure is not guaranteed in such approaches since overlapping structures additionally include the crossing structures 3 , which rarely exist in practice .
heading: Related Work

text: Also , their representations did not model the dependencies between nested mentions explicitly , which may limit their performance .
heading: Related Work

text: In contrast , the chart - based parsing method can capture the dependencies between nested mentions with composition rules which allow an outer entity to be influenced by its contained entities .
heading: Related Work

text: However , their cubic time complexity makes them not scalable to large datasets .
heading: Related Work

text: As neural network based approaches are proven effective in entity or mention recognition , recent efforts focus on incorporating neural components for recognizing nested mentions .
heading: Related Work

text: dynamically stacked multiple LSTM - CRF layers , detecting mentions in an inside - out manner until no outer entities are extracted .
heading: Related Work

text: used recurrent neural networks to extract features fora hypergraph which encodes all nested mentions based on the BILOU tagging scheme .
heading: Related Work

text: Model
Specifically , given a sequence of words {x 0 , x 1 , . . . , x n } , the goal of our system is to output a set of mentions where nested structures are allowed .
heading: Model

text: We use the forest structure to model the nested mentions scattered in a sentence , as shown in .
heading: Model

text: The mapping is straightforward : each outermost mention forms a tree where the mention is the root and its contained mentions correspond to constituents of the tree .
heading: Model

text: Shift - Reduce System
Our transition - based model is based on the shiftreduce parser for constituency parsing ( Watan - abe and Sumita , 2015 ) , which adopts .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: Generally , our system employs a stack to store ( partially ) processed nested elements .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: The system 's state is defined as [ S , i , A ] which denotes stack , buffer front index and action history respectively .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: In each step .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: an action is applied to change the system 's state .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: Our system consists of three types of transition actions , which are also summarized in :
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: SHIFT pushes the next word from buffer to the stack .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: REDUCE - X pops the top two items t 0 and t 1 from the tack and combines them as anew tree element { X ? t 0 t 1 } which is then pushed onto the stack .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: UNARY - X pops the top item t 0 from the stack and constructs anew tree element { X ? t 0 } which is pushed back to the stack .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: Since the shift - reduce system assumes unary and binary branching , we binarize the trees in each forest in a left - branching manner .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: For example , if three consecutive words A , B , C are annotated as Person , we convert it into a binary tree { P erson ?
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: { P erson * ?
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: A , B} , C} where P erson * is a temporary label for P erson .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: Hence , the X in reduce - actions will also include such temporary labels .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: Note that since most words are not contained in any mention , they are only shifted to the stack and not involved in any reduce - or unary - actions .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: An example sequence of transitions can be found in .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: Our shift - reduce system is different from previous parsers in terms of the terminal state .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: 1 ) It does not require the terminal stack to be a rooted tree .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: Instead , the final stack should be a forest consisting of multiple nested elements with tree structures .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: 2 ) To conveniently determine the ending of our transition process , we add an auxiliary symbol $ to each sentence .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: Once it is pushed to the stack , it implies that all deductions of actual words are finished .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: Since we do not allow unary rules between labels like X1 ?
heading: Shift - Reduce System

text: X2 , the length of maximal action sequence is 3 n .
heading: Shift - Reduce System

Generally , the buffer and action history are encoded using two vanilla LSTMs .

We employ the greedy strategy to maximize the log -likelihood of the local action classifier in ( 1 ) .

We mainly evaluate our models on the standard ACE - 04 , , and GENIA datasets with the same splits used by previous research efforts .

text: Results
The main results are reported in .
heading: Results

text: Our neural transition - based model achieves the best results in ACE datasets and comparable results in GENIA dataset in terms of F 1 measure .
heading: Results

text: We hypothesize that the performance gain of our model compared with other methods is largely due to improved performance on the portions of nested mentions in our datasets .
heading: Results

text: To verify this , we design an experiment to evaluate how well a system can recognize nested mentions .
heading: Results

text: Handling Nested Mentions
The idea is that we split the test data into two portions : sentences with and without nested mentions .
heading: Handling Nested Mentions

text: The results of GENIA are listed in .
heading: Handling Nested Mentions

text: We can observe that the margin of improvement is more significant in the portion of nested mentions , revealing our model 's effectiveness in handling nested mentions .
heading: Handling Nested Mentions

text: This observation helps explain why our model achieves greater improvement in ACE than in GENIA in since the former has much more nested structures than the latter .
heading: Handling Nested Mentions

text: Moreover , performs better when it comes to non-nested mentions possibly due to the CRF they used , which globally normalizes each stacked layer .

text: Conclusion and Future Work
In this paper , we present a transition - based model for nested mention recognition using a forest representation .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: Coupled with Stack - LSTM for representing the system 's state , our neural model can capture dependencies between nested mentions efficiently .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: Moreover , the character - based component helps capture letter - level patterns in words .

text: The system achieves the state - of - the - art performance in ACE datasets .

text: One potential drawback of the system is the greedy training and decoding .

heading: Conclusion and Future Work
