heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: title
BERT : Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding
heading: title

text: abstract
We introduce anew language representation model called BERT , which stands for Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers .
heading: abstract

text: Unlike recent language representation models ( Peters et al. , 2018 a ; Radford et al. , 2018 ) , BERT is designed to pretrain deep bidirectional representations from unlabeled text by jointly conditioning on both left and right context in all layers .
heading: abstract

text: As a result , the pre-trained BERT model can be finetuned with just one additional output layer to create state - of - the - art models fora wide range of tasks , such as question answering and language inference , without substantial taskspecific architecture modifications .
heading: abstract

text: BERT is conceptually simple and empirically powerful .
heading: abstract

text: It obtains new state - of - the - art results on eleven natural language processing tasks , including pushing the GLUE score to 80.5 % ( 7.7 % point absolute improvement ) , MultiNLI accuracy to 86.7 % ( 4.6 % absolute improvement ) , SQ u AD v 1.1 question answering Test F1 to 93.2 ( 1.5 point absolute improvement ) and SQ u AD v2.0 Test F1 to 83.1 ( 5.1 point absolute improvement ) .
heading: abstract

text: Jeremy Howard and Sebastian Ruder . 2018 .
heading: abstract

text: Universal language model fine - tuning for text classification .
heading: abstract

text: In ACL .
heading: abstract

text: Association for Computational Linguistics .
Introduction
Language model pre-training has been shown to be effective for improving many natural language processing tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: These include sentence - level tasks such as natural language inference and paraphrasing , which aim to predict the relationships between sentences by analyzing them holistically , as well as token - level tasks such as named entity recognition and question answering , where models are required to produce fine - grained output at the token level .
heading: Introduction

text: There are two existing strategies for applying pre-trained language representations to downstream tasks : feature - based and fine - tuning .
heading: Introduction

text: The feature - based approach , such as ELMo , uses task - specific architectures that include the pre-trained representations as additional features .
heading: Introduction

text: The fine - tuning approach , such as the Generative Pre-trained Transformer ( OpenAI GPT ) , introduces minimal task - specific parameters , and is trained on the downstream tasks by simply fine - tuning all pretrained parameters .
heading: Introduction

text: The two approaches share the same objective function during pre-training , where they use unidirectional language models to learn general language representations .
heading: Introduction

text: We argue that current techniques restrict the power of the pre-trained representations , especially for the fine - tuning approaches .
heading: Introduction

text: The major limitation is that standard language models are unidirectional , and this limits the choice of architectures that can be used during pre-training .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , in Open AI GPT , the authors use a left - toright architecture , where every token can only attend to previous tokens in the self - attention layers of the Transformer .
heading: Introduction

text: Such restrictions are sub-optimal for sentence - level tasks , and could be very harmful when applying finetuning based approaches to token - level tasks such as question answering , where it is crucial to incorporate context from both directions .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we improve the fine - tuning based approaches by proposing BERT : Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers .
heading: Introduction

text: BERT alleviates the previously mentioned unidirectionality constraint by using a " masked language model " ( MLM ) pre-training objective , inspired by the Cloze task .
heading: Introduction

text: The masked language model randomly masks some of the tokens from the input , and the objective is to predict the original vocabulary id of the masked word based only on its context .
heading: Introduction

text: Unlike left - toright language model pre-training , the MLM objective enables the representation to fuse the left and the right context , which allows us to pretrain a deep bidirectional Transformer .
heading: Introduction

text: In addition to the masked language model , we also use a " next sentence prediction " task that jointly pretrains text - pair representations .
heading: Introduction

text: The contributions of our paper are as follows :
heading: Introduction

text: We demonstrate the importance of bidirectional pre-training for language representations .
heading: Introduction

text: Unlike , which uses unidirectional language models for pre-training , BERT uses masked language models to enable pretrained deep bidirectional representations .
heading: Introduction

text: This is also in contrast to , which uses a shallow concatenation of independently trained left - to - right and right - to - left LMs .
heading: Introduction

text: We show that pre-trained representations reduce the need for many heavily - engineered taskspecific architectures .
heading: Introduction

text: BERT is the first finetuning based representation model that achieves state - of - the - art performance on a large suite of sentence - level and token - level tasks , outperforming many task - specific architectures .
heading: Introduction

text: BERT advances the state of the art for eleven NLP tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: The code and pre-trained models are available at https://github.com/
heading: Introduction

text: google-research/bert .
heading: Introduction

text: Related Work
There is along history of pre-training general language representations , and we briefly review the most widely - used approaches in this section .
heading: Related Work

text: Unsupervised Feature - based Approaches
heading: Related Work

text: Learning widely applicable representations of words has been an active area of research for decades , including non-neural and neural methods .
heading: Related Work

text: Pre-trained word embeddings are an integral part of modern NLP systems , offering significant improvements over embeddings learned from scratch .
heading: Related Work

text: To pretrain word embedding vectors , left - to - right language modeling objectives have been used , as well as objectives to discriminate correct from incorrect words in left and right context .
heading: Related Work

text: These approaches have been generalized to coarser granularities , such as sentence embeddings or paragraph embeddings .
heading: Related Work

text: To train sentence representations , prior work has used objectives to rank candidate next sentences , left - to - right generation of next sentence words given a representation of the previous sentence , or denoising autoencoder derived objectives .
heading: Related Work

text: ELMo and its predecessor generalize traditional word embedding research along a different dimension .
heading: Related Work

text: They extract context - sensitive features from a left - to - right and a right - to - left language model .
heading: Related Work

text: The contextual representation of each token is the concatenation of the left - to - right and right - to - left representations .
heading: Related Work

text: When integrating contextual word embeddings with existing task - specific architectures , ELMo advances the state of the art for several major NLP benchmarks including question answering , sentiment analysis , and named entity recognition .
heading: Related Work

text: proposed learning contextual representations through a task to predict a single word from both left and right context using LSTMs .
heading: Related Work

text: Similar to ELMo , their model is feature - based and not deeply bidirectional .
heading: Related Work

text: shows that the cloze task can be used to improve the robustness of text generation models .
heading: Related Work

text: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches
As with the feature - based approaches , the first works in this direction only pre-trained word embedding parameters from unlabeled text .
heading: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches

text: More recently , sentence or document encoders which produce contextual token representations have been pre-trained from unlabeled text and fine - tuned fora supervised downstream task .
heading: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches

text: The advantage of these approaches is that few parameters need to be learned from scratch .
heading: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches

text: At least partly due to this advantage , OpenAI achieved previously state - of - the - art results on many sentencelevel tasks from the GLUE benchmark .
heading: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches

text: Left - to - right language model - BERT BERT E E 1 E ...
heading: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches

text: Overall pre-training and fine - tuning procedures for BERT .
heading: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches

text: Apart from output layers , the same architectures are used in both pre-training and fine - tuning .
heading: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches

text: The same pre-trained model parameters are used to initialize models for different down - stream tasks .
heading: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches

text: During fine - tuning , all parameters are fine - tuned .
heading: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches

text: [ CLS ] is a special symbol added in front of every input example , and [ SEP ] is a special separator token ( e.g. separating questions / answers ) .
heading: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches

text: ing and auto - encoder objectives have been used for pre-training such models .
heading: Unsupervised Fine- tuning Approaches

text: Transfer Learning from Supervised Data
There has also been work showing effective transfer from supervised tasks with large datasets , such as natural language inference and machine translation .
heading: Transfer Learning from Supervised Data

text: Computer vision research has also demonstrated the importance of transfer learning from large pre-trained models , where an effective recipe is to fine - tune models pre-trained with I ma - geNet .
heading: Transfer Learning from Supervised Data

text: BERT
We introduce BERT and its detailed implementation in this section .
heading: BERT

text: There are two steps in our framework : pre-training and fine - tuning .
heading: BERT

text: During pre-training , the model is trained on unlabeled data over different pre-training tasks .
heading: BERT

text: For finetuning , the BERT model is first initialized with the pre-trained parameters , and all of the parameters are fine - tuned using labeled data from the downstream tasks .
heading: BERT

text: Each downstream task has separate fine - tuned models , even though they are initialized with the same pre-trained parameters .
heading: BERT

text: The question - answering example in will serve as a running example for this section .
heading: BERT

text: A distinctive feature of BERT is its unified architecture across different tasks .
heading: BERT

text: There is mini-mal difference between the pre-trained architecture and the final downstream architecture .
heading: BERT

text: Model Architecture
BERT 's model architecture is a multi - layer bidirectional Transformer encoder based on the original implementation and released in the tensor2 tensor library .
heading: Model Architecture

text: Because the use of Transformers has become common and our implementation is almost identical to the original , we will omit an exhaustive background description of the model architecture and refer readers to as well as excellent guides such as " The Annotated Transformer . "
heading: Model Architecture

text: In this work , we denote the number of layers ( i.e. , Transformer blocks ) as L , the hidden size as H , and the number of self - attention heads as A .
heading: Model Architecture

text: We primarily report results on two model sizes : BERT BASE ( L=12 , H = 768 , A = 12 , Total Param-eters=110M ) and BERT LARGE ( L=24 , H = 1024 , A = 16 , Total Parameters=340M ) .
heading: Model Architecture

text: BERT BASE was chosen to have the same model size as OpenAI GPT for comparison purposes .
heading: Model Architecture

text: Critically , however , the BERT Transformer uses bidirectional self - attention , while the GPT Transformer uses constrained self - attention where every token can only attend to context to its left .
heading: Model Architecture

text: Input / Output Representations

To make BERT handle a variety of down - stream tasks , our input representation is able to unambiguously represent both a single sentence and a pair of sentences ( e.g. , Question , Answer ) in one token sequence .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: Throughout this work , a " sentence " can bean arbitrary span of contiguous text , rather than an actual linguistic sentence .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: A " sequence " refers to the input token sequence to BERT , which maybe a single sentence or two sentences packed together .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: We use WordPiece embeddings
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: ( Wu et al. , 2016 ) with a 30,000 token vocabulary .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: The first token of every sequence is always a special classification token ( [ CLS ] ) .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: The final hidden state corresponding to this token is used as the aggregate sequence representation for classification tasks .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: Sentence pairs are packed together into a single sequence .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: We differentiate the sentences in two ways .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: First , we separate them with a special token ( [ SEP ] ) .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: Second , we add a learned embedding to every token indicating whether it belongs to sentence A or sentence B .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: As shown in , we denote input embedding as E , the final hidden vector of the special [ CLS ] token as C ? R H , and the final hidden vector for the i th input token as
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: For a given token , its input representation is constructed by summing the corresponding token , segment , and position embeddings .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: A visualization of this construction can be seen in . ( 2018 ) , we do not use traditional left - to - right or right - to - left language models to pre-train BERT .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: Instead , we pre-train BERT using two unsupervised tasks , described in this section .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: This step is presented in the left part of .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: Task # 1 : Masked LM
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: Intuitively , it is reasonable to believe that a deep bidirectional model is strictly more powerful than either a left - to - right model or the shallow concatenation of a left - toright and a right - to - left model .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: Unfortunately , standard conditional language models can only be trained left - to - right or right - to - left , since bidirectional conditioning would allow each word to indirectly " see itself " , and the model could trivially predict the target word in a multi - layered context .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: former is often referred to as a " Transformer encoder " while the left - context - only version is referred to as a " Transformer decoder " since it can be used for text generation .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: In order to train a deep bidirectional representation , we simply mask some percentage of the input tokens at random , and then predict those masked tokens .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: We refer to this procedure as a " masked LM " ( MLM ) , although it is often referred to as a Cloze task in the literature .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: In this case , the final hidden vectors corresponding to the mask tokens are fed into an output softmax over the vocabulary , as in a standard LM .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: In all of our experiments , we mask 15 % of all WordPiece tokens in each sequence at random .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: In contrast to denoising auto - encoders , we only predict the masked words rather than reconstructing the entire input .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: Although this allows us to obtain a bidirectional pre-trained model , a downside is that we are creating a mismatch between pre-training and fine - tuning , since the [ MASK ] token does not appear during fine - tuning .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: To mitigate this , we do not always replace " masked " words with the actual [ MASK ] token .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: The training data generator chooses 15 % of the token positions at random for prediction .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: If the i - th token is chosen , we replace the i - th token with ( 1 ) the [ MASK ] token 80 % of the time ( 2 ) a random token 10 % of the time ( 3 ) the unchanged i - th token 10 % of the time .
heading: Input / Output Representations

text: Then ,
Ti will be used to predict the original token with cross entropy loss .
heading: Then ,

text: We compare variations of this procedure in Appendix C.2 .
heading: Then ,

text: Task # 2 : Next Sentence Prediction ( NSP ) Many important downstream tasks such as Question Answering ( QA ) and Natural Language Inference ( NLI ) are based on understanding the relationship between two sentences , which is not directly captured by language modeling .
heading: Then ,

text: In order to train a model that understands sentence relationships , we pre-train fora binarized next sentence prediction task that can be trivially generated from any monolingual corpus .
heading: Then ,

text: Specifically , when choosing the sentences A and B for each pretraining example , 50 % of the time B is the actual next sentence that follows A ( labeled as IsNext ) , and 50 % of the time it is a random sentence from the corpus ( labeled as NotNext ) .
heading: Then ,

text: As we show in , C is used for next sentence prediction ( NSP ) .
heading: Then ,

text: 5 Despite its simplicity , we demonstrate in Section 5.1 that pre-training towards this task is very beneficial to both QA and NLI .
heading: Then ,

text: 5 The final model achieves 97 % - 98 % accuracy on NSP .
heading: Then ,

text: The vector C is not a meaningful sentence representation without fine - tuning , since it was trained with NSP .
heading: Then ,

text: Position
Embeddings : BERT input representation .
heading: Position

text: The input embeddings are the sum of the token embeddings , the segmentation embeddings and the position embeddings .
heading: Position

text: The NSP task is closely related to representationlearning objectives used in Jernite et al. and Logeswaran and Lee ( 2018 ) .
heading: Position

text: However , in prior work , only sentence embeddings are transferred to down - stream tasks , where BERT transfers all parameters to initialize end - task model parameters .
heading: Position

text: Pre-training data
heading: Position

text: The pre-training procedure largely follows the existing literature on language model pre-training .
heading: Position

text: For the pre-training corpus we use the Books Corpus ( 800M words ) and English Wikipedia ( 2,500 M words ) .
heading: Position

text: For Wikipedia we extract only the text passages and ignore lists , tables , and headers .
heading: Position

text: It is critical to use a document - level corpus rather than a shuffled sentence - level corpus such as the Billion Word Benchmark in order to extract long contiguous sequences .
heading: Position

text: Fine- tuning BERT
heading: Position

text: Fine- tuning is straightforward since the selfattention mechanism in the Transformer allows BERT to model many downstream tasks whether they involve single text or text pairs - by swapping out the appropriate inputs and outputs .
heading: Position

text: For applications involving text pairs , a common pattern is to independently encode text pairs before applying bidirectional cross attention , such as Parikh et al. ; Seo et al. ( 2017 ) .
heading: Position

text: BERT instead uses the self - attention mechanism to unify these two stages , as encoding a concatenated text pair with self - attention effectively includes bidirectional cross attention between two sentences .
heading: Position

text: For each task , we simply plugin the taskspecific inputs and outputs into BERT and finetune all the parameters end - to - end .
heading: Position

text: At the input , sentence A and sentence B from pre-training are analogous to ( 1 ) sentence pairs in paraphrasing , ( 2 ) hypothesis - premise pairs in entailment , ( 3 ) question - passage pairs in question answering , and ( 4 ) a degenerate text -?
heading: Position

text: pair in text classification or sequence tagging .
heading: Position

text: At the output , the token representations are fed into an output layer for tokenlevel tasks , such as sequence tagging or question answering , and the [ CLS ] representation is fed into an output layer for classification , such as entailment or sentiment analysis .
heading: Position

text: Compared to pre-training , fine - tuning is relatively inexpensive .
heading: Position

text: All of the results in the paper can be replicated in at most 1 hour on a single Cloud TPU , or a few hours on a GPU , starting from the exact same pre-trained model .
heading: Position

text: We describe the task - specific details in the corresponding subsections of Section 4 .
heading: Position

text: More details can be found in Appendix A.5 .
heading: Position

The Situations With Adversarial Generations ( SWAG ) dataset contains 113 k sentence - pair completion examples that evaluate grounded commonsense inference .

text: Ablation Studies
In this section , we perform ablation experiments over a number of facets of BERT in order to better understand their relative importance .
heading: Ablation Studies

text: Additional : Ablation over the pre-training tasks using the BERT BASE architecture .
heading: Ablation Studies

text: " No NSP " is trained without the next sentence prediction task .
heading: Ablation Studies

text: " LTR & No NSP " is trained as a left - to - right LM without the next sentence prediction , like OpenAI GPT .
heading: Ablation Studies

text: " + BiLSTM " adds a randomly initialized BiLSTM on top of the " LTR + No NSP " model during fine - tuning .
heading: Ablation Studies

text: ablation studies can be found in Appendix C.
heading: Ablation Studies

text: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

We demonstrate the importance of the deep bidirectionality of BERT by evaluating two pretraining objectives using exactly the same pretraining data , fine - tuning scheme , and hyperparameters as BERT BASE :
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: No NSP :
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: A bidirectional model which is trained using the " masked LM " ( MLM ) but without the " next sentence prediction " ( NSP ) task .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: LTR & No NSP :
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: A left - context - only model which is trained using a standard Left - to - Right ( LTR ) LM , rather than an MLM .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: The left - only constraint was also applied at fine - tuning , because removing it introduced a pre-train / fine - tune mismatch that degraded downstream performance .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: Additionally , this model was pre-trained without the NSP task .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: This is directly comparable to OpenAI GPT , but using our larger training dataset , our input representation , and our fine - tuning scheme .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: We first examine the impact brought by the NSP task .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: In , we show that removing NSP hurts performance significantly on QNLI , MNLI , and SQu AD 1.1 .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: Next , we evaluate the impact of training bidirectional representations by comparing " No NSP " to " LTR & No NSP " .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: The LTR model performs worse than the MLM model on all tasks , with large drops on MRPC and SQuAD .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: For SQuAD it is intuitively clear that a LTR model will perform poorly at token predictions , since the token - level hidden states have no rightside context .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: In order to make a good faith attempt at strengthening the LTR system , we added a randomly initialized BiLSTM on top .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: This does significantly improve results on SQuAD , but the results are still far worse than those of the pretrained bidirectional models .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: The BiLSTM hurts performance on the GLUE tasks .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: We recognize that it would also be possible to train separate LTR and RTL models and represent each token as the concatenation of the two models , as ELMo does .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: However : ( a ) this is twice as expensive as a single bidirectional model ; ( b ) this is non-intuitive for tasks like QA , since the RTL model would not be able to condition the answer on the question ; ( c ) this it is strictly less powerful than a deep bidirectional model , since it can use both left and right context at every layer .
heading: Effect of Pre-training Tasks

text: Effect of Model Size
In this section , we explore the effect of model size on fine - tuning task accuracy .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: We trained a number of BERT models with a differing number of layers , hidden units , and attention heads , while otherwise using the same hyperparameters and training procedure as described previously .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: Results on selected GLUE tasks are shown in .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: In this table , we report the average Dev Set accuracy from 5 random restarts of fine - tuning .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: We can see that larger models lead to a strict accuracy improvement across all four datasets , even for MRPC which only has 3,600 labeled training examples , and is substantially different from the pre-training tasks .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: It is also perhaps surprising that we are able to achieve such significant improvements on top of models which are already quite large relative to the existing literature .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: For example , the largest Transformer explored in is ( L=6 , H = 1024 , A = 16 ) with 100M parameters for the encoder , and the largest Transformer we have found in the literature is ( L=64 , H = 512 , A=2 ) with 235M parameters .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: By contrast , BERT BASE contains 110M parameters and BERT LARGE contains 340M parameters .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: It has long been known that increasing the model size will lead to continual improvements on large - scale tasks such as machine translation and language modeling , which is demonstrated by the LM perplexity of held - out training data shown in .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: However , we believe that this is the first work to demonstrate convincingly that scaling to extreme model sizes also leads to large improvements on very small scale tasks , provided that the model has been sufficiently pre-trained .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: presented mixed results on the downstream task impact of increasing the pre-trained bi - LM size from two to four layers and mentioned in passing that increasing hidden dimension size from 200 to 600 helped , but increasing further to 1,000 did not bring further improvements .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: Both of these prior works used a featurebased approach - we hypothesize that when the model is fine - tuned directly on the downstream tasks and uses only a very small number of randomly initialized additional parameters , the taskspecific models can benefit from the larger , more expressive pre-trained representations even when downstream task data is very small .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: Feature - based Approach with BERT
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: All of the BERT results presented so far have used the fine - tuning approach , where a simple classification layer is added to the pre-trained model , and all parameters are jointly fine - tuned on a downstream task .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: However , the feature - based approach , where fixed features are extracted from the pretrained model , has certain advantages .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: First , not all tasks can be easily represented by a Transformer encoder architecture , and therefore require a task - specific model architecture to be added .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: Second , there are major computational benefits to pre-compute an expensive representation of the training data once and then run many experiments with cheaper models on top of this representation .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: In this section , we compare the two approaches by applying BERT to the CoNLL - 2003 Named Entity Recognition ( NER ) task .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: In the input to BERT , we use a case - preserving WordPiece model , and we include the maximal document context provided by the data .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: Following standard practice , we formulate this as a tagging task but do not use a CRF layer in the output .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: We use the representation of the first sub-token as the input to the token - level classifier over the NER label set .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: To ablate the fine - tuning approach , we apply the feature - based approach by extracting the activations from one or more layers without fine - tuning any parameters of BERT .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: These contextual embeddings are used as input to a randomly initialized two - layer 768 - dimensional BiLSTM before the classification layer .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: Results are presented in .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: BERT LARGE performs competitively with state - of - the - art methods .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: The best performing method concatenates the token representations from the top four hidden layers of the pre-trained Transformer , which is only 0.3 F1 behind fine - tuning the entire model .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: This demonstrates that BERT is effective for both finetuning and feature - based approaches .
heading: Effect of Model Size

text: Conclusion
Recent empirical improvements due to transfer learning with language models have demonstrated that rich , unsupervised pre-training is an integral part of many language understanding systems .
heading: Conclusion

text: In particular , these results enable even low - resource tasks to benefit from deep unidirectional architectures .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our major contribution is further generalizing these findings to deep bidirectional architectures , allowing the same pre-trained model to successfully tackle abroad set of NLP tasks .
heading: Conclusion

text: We organize the appendix into three sections :
heading: Conclusion

text: Additional implementation details for BERT are presented in Appendix A ;
heading: Conclusion

text: Additional details for our experiments are presented in Appendix B ; and
heading: Conclusion

text: Additional ablation studies are presented in Appendix C.
heading: Conclusion

text: We present additional ablation studies for BERT including :
heading: Conclusion

text: - Effect of Number of Training Steps ; and - Ablation for Different Masking Procedures .
heading: Conclusion

text: A Additional Details for BERT
A.1 Illustration of the Pre-training Tasks
We provide examples of the pre-training tasks in the following .
heading: A.1 Illustration of the Pre-training Tasks

text: Masked LM and the Masking Procedure Assuming the unlabeled sentence is my dog is hairy , and during the random masking procedure we chose the 4 - th token ( which corresponding to hairy ) , our masking procedure can be further illustrated by The purpose of this is to bias the representation towards the actual observed word .
heading: A.1 Illustration of the Pre-training Tasks

text: The advantage of this procedure is that the Transformer encoder does not know which words it will be asked to predictor which have been replaced by random words , so it is forced to keep a distributional contextual representation of every input token .
heading: A.1 Illustration of the Pre-training Tasks

text: Additionally , because random replacement only occurs for 1.5 % of all tokens ( i.e. , 10 % of 15 % ) , this does not seem to harm the model 's language understanding capability .
heading: A.1 Illustration of the Pre-training Tasks

text: In Section C.2 , we evaluate the impact this procedure .
heading: A.1 Illustration of the Pre-training Tasks

text: Compared to standard langauge model training , the masked LM only make predictions on 15 % of tokens in each batch , which suggests that more pre-training steps maybe required for the model to converge .
heading: A.1 Illustration of the Pre-training Tasks

text: In Section C.1 we demonstrate that MLM does converge marginally slower than a leftto - right model ( which predicts every token ) , but the empirical improvements of the MLM model far outweigh the increased training cost .
heading: A.1 Illustration of the Pre-training Tasks

text: Next Sentence Prediction
The next sentence prediction task can be illustrated in the following examples .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: To generate each training input sequence , we sample two spans of text from the corpus , which we refer to as " sentences " even though they are typically much longer than single sentences ( but can be shorter also ) .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: The first sentence receives the A embedding and the second receives the B embedding .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: 50 % of the time B is the actual next sentence that follows A and 50 % of the time it is a random sentence , which is done for the " next sentence prediction " task .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: They are sampled such that the combined length is ? 512 tokens .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: The LM masking is applied after WordPiece tokenization with a uniform masking rate of 15 % , and no special consideration given to partial word pieces .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: We train with batch size of 256 sequences ( 256 sequences * 512 tokens = 128,000 tokens / batch ) for 1,000,000 steps , which is approximately 40 epochs over the 3.3 billion word corpus .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: We use Adam with learning rate of 1 e - 4 , ? 1 = 0.9 , ? 2 = 0.999 , L2 weight decay of 0.01 , learning rate warmup over the first 10,000 steps , and linear decay of the learning rate .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: We use a dropout probability of 0.1 on all layers .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: We use a gelu activation rather than the standard relu , following OpenAI GPT .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: The training loss is the sum of the mean masked LM likelihood and the mean next sentence prediction likelihood .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: Training of BERT BASE was performed on 4 Cloud TPUs in Pod configuration ( 16 TPU chips total ) .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: 13 Training of BERT LARGE was performed on 16 Cloud TPUs ( 64 TPU chips total ) .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: Each pretraining took 4 days to complete .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: Longer sequences are disproportionately expensive because attention is quadratic to the sequence length .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: To speedup pretraing in our experiments , we pre-train the model with sequence length of 128 for 90 % of the steps .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: Then , we train the rest 10 % of the steps of sequence of 512 to learn the positional embeddings .
heading: Next Sentence Prediction

text: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure
For fine - tuning , most model hyperparameters are the same as in pre-training , with the exception of the batch size , learning rate , and number of training epochs .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: The dropout probability was always kept at 0.1 .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: The optimal hyperparameter values are task - specific , but we found the following range of possible values to work well across all tasks :
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: Batch size : 16 , 32
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: Learning rate ( Adam ) : 5 e - 5 , 3 e - 5 , 2 e - 5 Number of epochs : 2 , 3 , 4
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: We also observed that large data sets ( e.g. , 100 k + labeled training examples ) were far less sensitive to hyperparameter choice than small data sets .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: Fine - tuning is typically very fast , so it is reasonable to simply run an exhaustive search over the above parameters and choose the model that performs best on the development set .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: The comparisons between the model architectures are shown visually in .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: Note that in addition to the architecture differences , BERT and OpenAI GPT are finetuning approaches , while ELMo is a feature - based approach .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: The most comparable existing pre-training method to BERT is OpenAI GPT , which trains a left - to - right Transformer LM on a large text corpus .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: In fact , many of the design decisions in BERT were intentionally made to make it as close to GPT as possible so that the two methods could be minimally compared .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: The core argument of this work is that the bi-directionality and the two pretraining tasks presented in Section 3.1 account for the majority of the empirical improvements , but we do note that there are several other differences between how BERT and GPT were trained :
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: GPT is trained on the Books Corpus ( 800M words ) ; BERT is trained on the Books Corpus ( 800M words ) and Wikipedia ( 2,500 M words ) .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: GPT was trained for 1 M steps with a batch size of 32,000 words ; BERT was trained for 1 M steps with a batch size of 128,000 words .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: GPT used the same learning rate of 5 e - 5 for all fine - tuning experiments ; BERT chooses a task - specific fine - tuning learning rate which performs the best on the development set .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: To isolate the effect of these differences , we perform ablation experiments in Section 5.1 which demonstrate that the majority of the improvements are in fact coming from the two pre-training tasks and the bidirectionality they enable .
heading: A.3 Fine- tuning Procedure

text: A.5 Illustrations of Fine - tuning on Different Tasks
The illustration of fine - tuning BERT on different tasks can be seen in .
heading: A.5 Illustrations of Fine - tuning on Different Tasks

text: Our task - specific models are formed by incorporating BERT with one additional output layer , so a minimal number of parameters need to be learned from scratch .
heading: A.5 Illustrations of Fine - tuning on Different Tasks

text: Among the tasks , ( a ) and MNLI Multi - Genre Natural Language Inference is a large - scale , crowdsourced entailment classification task .
heading: A.5 Illustrations of Fine - tuning on Different Tasks

text: Given a pair of sentences , the goal is to predict whether the second sentence is an entailment , contradiction , or neutral with respect to the first one .
heading: A.5 Illustrations of Fine - tuning on Different Tasks

text: QQP
Quora Question
Pairs is a binary classification task where the goal is to determine if two questions asked on Quora are semantically equivalent .
heading: Quora Question

text: BERT E [ CLS ]
heading: Quora Question

text: SST - 2
heading: Quora Question

text: The Stanford Sentiment Treebank is a binary single - sentence classification task consisting of sentences extracted from movie reviews with human annotations of their sentiment .
heading: Quora Question

text: CoLA
The Corpus of Linguistic Acceptability is a binary single - sentence classification task , where the goal is to predict whether an English sentence is linguistically " acceptable " or not .
heading: CoLA

text: STS - B
heading: CoLA

text: The Semantic Textual Similarity
Benchmark is a collection of sentence pairs drawn from news headlines and other sources .
heading: The Semantic Textual Similarity

text: They were annotated with a score from 1 to 5 denoting how similar the two sentences are in terms of semantic meaning .
heading: The Semantic Textual Similarity

text: MRPC

Microsoft Research Paraphrase Corpus consists of sentence pairs automatically extracted from online news sources , with human annotations for whether the sentences in the pair are semantically equivalent .
heading: MRPC

text: RTE
Recognizing Textual Entailment is a binary entailment task similar to MNLI , but with much less training data ) .
heading: RTE

text: 14 WNLI Winograd NLI is a small natural language inference dataset .
heading: RTE

text: The GLUE webpage notes that there are issues with the construction of this dataset , 15 and every trained system that 's been submitted to GLUE has performed worse than the 65.1 baseline accuracy of predicting the majority class .
heading: RTE

text: We therefore exclude this set to be fair to OpenAI GPT .
heading: RTE

text: For our GLUE submission , we always predicted the ma-jority class .
heading: RTE

text: C Additional Ablation Studies
C.1 Effect of Number of Training Steps presents MNLI
Dev accuracy after finetuning from a checkpoint that has been pre-trained fork steps .
heading: C.1 Effect of Number of Training Steps presents MNLI

text: This allows us to answer the following questions :
heading: C.1 Effect of Number of Training Steps presents MNLI
C.1 Effect of Number of Training Steps presents MNLI

text: Question :
heading: C.1 Effect of Number of Training Steps presents MNLI

text: Does BERT really need such a large amount of pre-training ( 128,000 words / batch * 1,000,000 steps ) to achieve high fine - tuning accuracy ?
heading: C.1 Effect of Number of Training Steps presents MNLI

text: Answer : Yes , BERT BASE achieves almost 1.0 % additional accuracy on MNLI when trained on 1 M steps compared to 500 k steps .
heading: C.1 Effect of Number of Training Steps presents MNLI

text: 2 . Question :
heading: C.1 Effect of Number of Training Steps presents MNLI

text: Does MLM pre-training converge slower than LTR pre-training , since only 15 % of words are predicted in each batch rather than every word ?
heading: C.1 Effect of Number of Training Steps presents MNLI

text: Answer : The MLM model does converge slightly slower than the LTR model .
heading: C.1 Effect of Number of Training Steps presents MNLI

text: However , in terms of absolute accuracy the MLM model begins to outperform the LTR model almost immediately .
heading: C.1 Effect of Number of Training Steps presents MNLI

text: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures
In Section 3.1 , we mention that BERT uses a mixed strategy for masking the target tokens when pre-training with the masked language model ( MLM ) objective .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: The following is an ablation study to evaluate the effect of different masking strategies .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: Note that the purpose of the masking strategies is to reduce the mismatch between pre-training and fine - tuning , as the [ MASK ] symbol never appears during the fine - tuning stage .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: We report the Dev results for both MNLI and NER .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: For NER , we report both fine - tuning and feature - based approaches , as we expect the mismatch will be amplified for the feature - based approach as the model will not have the chance to adjust the representations .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: The results are presented in .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: In the table , MASK means that we replace the target token with the [ MASK ] symbol for MLM ; SAME means that we keep the target token as is ; RND means that we replace the target token with another random token .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: The numbers in the left part of the table represent the probabilities of the specific strategies used during MLM pre-training ( BERT uses 80 % , 10 % , 10 % ) .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: The right part of the paper represents the Dev set results .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: For the feature - based approach , we concatenate the last 4 layers of BERT as the features , which was shown to be the best approach in Section 5.3 .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: From the table it can be seen that fine - tuning is surprisingly robust to different masking strategies .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: However , as expected , using only the MASK strategy was problematic when applying the featurebased approach to NER .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: Interestingly , using only the RND strategy performs much worse than our strategy as well .
heading: C.2 Ablation for Different Masking Procedures

text: title
Data and text mining BioBERT : a pre-trained biomedical language representation model for biomedical text mining
heading: title

text: abstract
Motivation :
heading: abstract

text: Biomedical text mining is becoming increasingly important as the number of biomedical documents rapidly grows .
heading: abstract

text: With the progress in natural language processing ( NLP ) , extracting valuable information from biomedical literature has gained popularity among researchers , and deep learning has boosted the development of effective biomedical text mining models .
heading: abstract

text: However , directly applying the advancements in NLP to biomedical text mining often yields unsatisfactory results due to a word distribution shift from general domain corpora to biomedical corpora .
heading: abstract

text: In this article , we investigate how the recently introduced pre-trained language model BERT can be adapted for biomedical corpora .
heading: abstract

text: Results :
heading: abstract

text: We introduce BioBERT ( Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers for Biomedical Text Mining ) , which is a domain - specific language representation model pre-trained on large - scale biomedical corpora .
heading: abstract

text: With almost the same architecture across tasks , BioBERT largely outperforms BERT and previous state - of - the - art models in a variety of biomedical text mining tasks when pre-trained on biomedical corpora .
heading: abstract

text: While BERT obtains performance comparable to that of previous state - of - the - art models , BioBERT significantly outperforms them on the following three representative biomedical text mining tasks : biomedical named entity recognition ( 0.62 % F1 score improvement ) , biomedical relation extraction ( 2.80 % F1 score improvement ) and biomedical question answering ( 12.24 % MRR improvement ) .
heading: abstract

text: Our analysis results show that pre-training BERT on biomedical corpora helps it to understand complex biomedical texts .
heading: abstract

text: Availability and implementation :
heading: abstract

text: We make the pre-trained weights of BioBERT freely available at https://github. com/naver/biobert-pretrained , and the source code for fine - tuning
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
The volume of biomedical literature continues to rapidly increase .
heading: Introduction

text: On average , more than 3000 new articles are published everyday in peer-reviewed journals , excluding pre-prints and technical reports such as clinical trial reports in various archives .
heading: Introduction

text: PubMed alone has a total of 29M articles as of January 2019 .
heading: Introduction

text: Reports containing valuable information about new discoveries and new insights are continuously added to the already overwhelming amount of literature .
heading: Introduction

text: Consequently , there is increasingly more demand for accurate biomedical text mining tools for extracting information from the literature .
heading: Introduction

text: Recent progress of biomedical text mining models was made possible by the advancements of deep learning techniques used in natural language processing ( NLP ) .
heading: Introduction

text: For instance , Long Short - Term Memory ( LSTM ) and Conditional Random Field ( CRF ) have greatly improved performance in biomedical named entity recognition ( NER ) over the last few years .
heading: Introduction

text: Other deep learning based models have made improvements in biomedical text mining tasks such as relation extraction ( RE ) and question answering ( QA ) .
heading: Introduction

text: However , directly applying state - of - the - art NLP methodologies to biomedical text mining has limitations .
heading: Introduction

text: First , as recent word representation models such as Word2 Vec , ELMo and BERT are trained and tested mainly on datasets containing general domain texts ( e.g. Wikipedia ) , it is difficult to estimate their performance on datasets containing biomedical texts .
heading: Introduction

text: Also , the word distributions of general and biomedical corpora are quite different , which can often be a problem for biomedical text mining models .
heading: Introduction

text: As a result , recent models in biomedical text mining rely largely on adapted versions of word representations .
heading: Introduction

text: In this study , we hypothesize that current state - of - the - art word representation models such as BERT need to be trained on biomedical corpora to be effective in biomedical text mining tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: Previously , Word2 Vec , which is one of the most widely known context independent word representation models , was trained on biomedical corpora which contain terms and expressions that are usually not included in a general domain corpus .
heading: Introduction

text: While ELMo and BERT have proven the effectiveness of contextualized word representations , they can not obtain high performance on biomedical corpora because they are pre-trained on only general domain corpora .
heading: Introduction

text: As BERT achieves very strong results on various NLP tasks while using almost the same structure across the tasks , adapting BERT for the biomedical domain could potentially benefit numerous biomedical NLP researches .
heading: Introduction

text: Approach
In this article , we introduce BioBERT , which is a pre-trained language representation model for the biomedical domain .
heading: Approach

text: The overall process of pre-training and fine - tuning BioBERT is illustrated in .
heading: Approach

text: First , we initialize BioBERT with weights from BERT , which was pretrained on general domain corpora ( English Wikipedia and Books Corpus ) .
heading: Approach

text: Then , BioBERT is pre-trained on biomedical domain corpora ( PubMed abstracts and PMC full - text articles ) .
heading: Approach

text: To show the effectiveness of our approach in biomedical text mining , BioBERT is fine - tuned and evaluated on three popular biomedical text mining tasks .
heading: Approach

text: We test various pre-training strategies with different combinations and sizes of general domain corpora and biomedical corpora , and analyze the effect of each corpus on pre-training .
heading: Approach

text: We also provide in - depth analyses of BERT and BioBERT to show the necessity of our pre-training strategies .
heading: Approach

text: The contributions of our paper are as follows :
heading: Approach

text: BioBERT is the first domain - specific BERT based model pretrained on biomedical corpora for 23 days on eight NVIDIA V100 GPUs .
heading: Approach

text: We show that pre-training BERT on biomedical corpora largely improves its performance .
heading: Approach

text: BioBERT obtains higher F 1 scores in biomedical NER ( 0.62 ) and biomedical RE ( 2.80 ) , and a higher MRR score ( 12.24 ) in biomedical QA than the current state - of the - art models .
heading: Approach

text: Compared with most previous biomedical text mining models that are mainly focused on a single task such as NER or QA , our model BioBERT achieves state - of - the - art performance on various biomedical text mining tasks , while requiring only minimal architectural modifications .
heading: Approach

text: We make our pre-processed datasets , the pre-trained weights of BioBERT and the source code for fine - tuning BioBERT publicly available .
heading: Approach

text: Materials and methods
BioBERT basically has the same structure as BERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We briefly discuss the recently proposed BERT , and then we describe in detail the pre-training and fine - tuning process of BioBERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: BERT : bidirectional encoder representations from transformers
heading: Materials and methods

text: Learning word representations from a large amount of unannotated text is a long - established method .
heading: Materials and methods

text: While previous models ( e.g. Word2 Vec , GloVe ) focused on learning context independent word representations , recent works have focused on learning context dependent word representations .
heading: Materials and methods

text: For instance , ELMo uses a bidirectional language model , while uses machine translation to embed context information into word representations .
heading: Materials and methods

text: BERT is a contextualized word representation model that is based on a masked language model and pretrained using bidirectional transformers .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Due to the nature of language modeling where future words can not be seen , previous language models were limited to a combination of two unidirectional language models ( i.e. left - to - right and right - toleft ) .
heading: Materials and methods

text: BERT uses a masked language model that predicts randomly masked words in a sequence , and hence can be used for learning bidirectional representations .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Also , it obtains state - of - the - art performance on most NLP tasks , while requiring minimal task - specific architectural modification .
heading: Materials and methods

text: According to the authors of BERT , incorporating information from bidirectional representations , rather than unidirectional representations , is crucial for representing words in natural language .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We hypothesize that such bidirectional representations are also critical in biomedical text mining as complex relationships between biomedical terms often exist in a biomedical corpus .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Due to the space limitations , we refer readers to fora more detailed description of BERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Pre-training BioBERT
heading: Materials and methods

text: As a general purpose language representation model , BERT was pretrained on English Wikipedia and Books Corpus .
heading: Materials and methods

text: However , biomedical domain texts contain a considerable number of domain - specific .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Overview of the pre-training and fine - tuning of BioBERT proper nouns ( e.g. BRCA1 , c.248T > C ) and terms ( e.g. transcriptional , antimicrobial ) , which are understood mostly by biomedical researchers .
heading: Materials and methods

text: As a result , NLP models designed for general purpose language understanding often obtains poor performance in biomedical text mining tasks .
heading: Materials and methods

text: In this work , we pre-train BioBERT on PubMed abstracts ( PubMed ) and PubMed Central full - text articles ( PMC ) .
heading: Materials and methods

text: The text corpora used for pre-training of BioBERT are listed in , and the tested combinations of text corpora are listed in .
heading: Materials and methods

text: For computational efficiency , whenever the Wiki Books corpora were used for pre-training , we initialized BioBERT with the pre-trained BERT model provided by .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We define BioBERT as a language representation model whose pre-training corpora includes biomedical corpora ( e.g. BioBERT ( PubMed ) ) .
heading: Materials and methods

text: For tokenization , BioBERT uses WordPiece tokenization , which mitigates the out - of - vocabulary issue .
heading: Materials and methods

text: With WordPiece tokenization , any new words can be represented by frequent subwords ( e.g. Immunoglobulin >
heading: Materials and methods

text: I ##mm ##uno ##g ##lo # #bul # #in ) .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We found that using cased vocabulary ( not lowercasing ) results in slightly better performances in downstream tasks .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Although we could have constructed new WordPiece vocabulary based on biomedical corpora , we used the original vocabulary of BERT BASE for the following reasons : ( i ) compatibility of BioBERT with BERT , which allows BERT pre-trained on general domain corpora to be re-used , and makes it easier to interchangeably use existing models based on BERT and BioBERT and ( ii ) any new words may still be represented and fine - tuned for the biomedical domain using the original WordPiece vocabulary of BERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Fine-tuning BioBERT
heading: Materials and methods

text: With minimal architectural modification , BioBERT can be applied to various downstream text mining tasks .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We fine - tune BioBERT on the following three representative biomedical text mining tasks : NER , RE and QA .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Named entity recognition is one of the most fundamental biomedical text mining tasks , which involves recognizing numerous domain - specific proper nouns in a biomedical corpus .
heading: Materials and methods

text: While most previous works were built upon different combinations of LSTMs and CRFs , BERT has a simple architecture based on bidirectional transformers .
heading: Materials and methods

text: BERT uses a single output layer based on the representations from its last layer to compute only token level BIO2 probabilities .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Note that while previous works in biomedical NER often used word embeddings trained on PubMed or PMC corpora , BioBERT directly learns WordPiece embeddings during pre-training and fine - tuning .
heading: Materials and methods

text: For the evaluation metrics of NER , we used entity level precision , recall and F1 score .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Relation extraction is a task of classifying relations of named entities in a biomedical corpus .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We utilized the sentence classifier of the original version of BERT , which uses a [ CLS ] token for the classification of relations .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Sentence classification is performed using a single output layer based on a [ CLS ] token representation from BERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We anonymized target named entities in a sentence using pre-defined tags such as @ GENE $ or @DISEASE $ .
heading: Materials and methods

text: For instance , a sentence with two target entities ( gene and disease in this case ) is represented as " Serine at position 986 of @GENE $ maybe an independent genetic predictor of angiographic @DISEASE $ . "
heading: Materials and methods

text: The precision , recall and F 1 scores on the RE task are reported .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Question answering is a task of answering questions posed in natural language given related passages .
heading: Materials and methods

text: To fine - tune BioBERT for QA , we used the same BERT architecture used for SQuAD .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We used the BioASQ factoid datasets because their format is similar to that of SQuAD .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Token level probabilities for the start / end location of answer phrases are computed using a single output layer .
heading: Materials and methods

text: However , we observed that about 30 % of the BioASQ factoid questions were unanswerable in an extractive QA setting as the exact answers did not appear in the given passages .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Like , we excluded the samples with unanswerable questions from the training sets .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Also , we used the same pre-training process of , which uses SQuAD , and it largely improved the performance of both BERT and BioBERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We used the following evaluation metrics from BioASQ : strict accuracy , lenient accuracy and mean reciprocal rank .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Results
Datasets
The statistics of biomedical NER datasets are listed in .
heading: Datasets

text: We used the pre-processed versions of all the NER datasets provided by except the 2010 i 2 b2 / VA , JNLPBA and Species - 800 datasets .
heading: Datasets

text: The pre-processed NCBI Disease dataset has fewer annotations than the original dataset due to the removal of duplicate articles from its training set .
heading: Datasets

text: We used the CoNLL format ( https :// github.com/spyysalo/standoff2conll ) for pre-processing the 2010 i 2b2 / VA and JNLPBA datasets .
heading: Datasets

text: The Species - 800 dataset was preprocessed and split based on the dataset of Pyysalo ( https://github. com/spyysalo/s800 ) .
heading: Datasets

text: We did not use alternate annotations for the BC2 GM dataset , and all NER evaluations are based on entity - level exact matches .
heading: Datasets

text: Note that although there are several other recently introduced high quality biomedical NER datasets , we use datasets that are frequently used by many biomedical NLP researchers , which makes it much easier to compare our work with theirs .
heading: Datasets

text: The RE datasets contain gene - disease relations and protein - chemical relations ) .
heading: Datasets

text: Pre-processed GAD and EU - ADR datasets are available with our provided codes .
heading: Datasets

text: For the CHEMPROT dataset , we used the same pre-processing procedure described in .
heading: Datasets

text: We used the BioASQ factoid datasets , which can be converted into the same format as the SQuAD dataset ) .
heading: Datasets

text: We used full abstracts ( PMIDs ) and related questions and answers provided by the BioASQ organizers .
heading: Datasets

text: We have made the pre-processed BioASQ datasets publicly available .
heading: Datasets

text: For all the datasets , we used the same dataset splits used in previous works ) fora fair evaluation ; however , the splits of LINAAEUS and Species - 800 could not be found from and maybe different .
heading: Datasets

text: Like previous work , we reported the performance of 10 - fold cross-validation on datasets that do not have separate test sets ( e.g. GAD , EU - ADR ) .
heading: Datasets

text: We compare BERT and BioBERT with the current state - of - theart models and report their scores .
heading: Datasets

text: Note that the state - of - the - art models each have a different architecture and training procedure .
heading: Datasets

text: For instance , the state - of - the - art model by trained on the JNLPBA dataset is based on multiple Bi - LSTM CRF models with character level CNNs , while the state - of - the - art model by trained on the LINNAEUS dataset uses a Bi - LSTM CRF model with character level LSTMs and is additionally trained on silver - standard datasets .
heading: Datasets

text: On the other hand , BERT and BioBERT have exactly the same structure , and use only the gold standard datasets and not any additional datasets .
heading: Datasets

text: Experimental setups
We used the BERT BASE model pre-trained on English Wikipedia and Books Corpus for 1 M steps .
heading: Experimental setups

text: BioBERT v1.0 ( PubMed PMC ) is the version of BioBERT ( PubMed PMC ) trained for 470 K steps .
heading: Experimental setups

text: When using both the PubMed and PMC corpora , we found that 200K and 270K pre-training steps were optimal for PubMed and PMC , respectively .
heading: Experimental setups

text: We also used the ablated versions of BioBERT v1.0 , which were pre-trained on only PubMed for 200 K steps ( Bio BERT v1.0 ( PubMed ) ) and PMC for 270K steps ( Bio BERT v1.0 ( PMC ) ) .
heading: Experimental setups

text: After our initial release of BioBERT v 1.0 , we pre-trained BioBERT on PubMed for 1 M steps , and we refer to this version as BioBERT v 1.1 ( PubMed ) .
heading: Experimental setups

text: Other hyper - parameters such as batch size and learning rate scheduling for pre-training BioBERT are the same as those for pre-training BERT unless stated otherwise .
heading: Experimental setups

text: We pre-trained BioBERT using Naver Smart Machine Learning ( NSML ) , which is utilized for large - scale experiments that need to be run on several GPUs .
heading: Experimental setups

text: We used eight NVIDIA V100 ( 32GB ) GPUs for the pre-training .
heading: Experimental setups

text: The maximum sequence length was fixed to 512 and the mini-batch size was set to 192 , resulting in 98 304 words per iteration .
heading: Experimental setups

text: It takes more than 10 days to pre-train BioBERT v 1.0 ( PubMed PMC ) nearly 23 days for BioBERT v 1.1 ( PubMed ) in this setting .
heading: Experimental setups

text: Despite our best efforts to use BERT LARGE , we used only BERT BASE due to the computational complexity of BERT LARGE .
heading: Experimental setups

text: We used a single NVIDIA Titan Xp ( 12GB ) GPU to fine - tune BioBERT on each task .
heading: Experimental setups

text: Note that the fine - tuning process is more computationally efficient than pre-training BioBERT .
heading: Experimental setups

text: For finetuning , a batch size of 10 , 16 , 32 or 64 was selected , and a learning rate of 5e5 , 3e5 or 1e5 was selected .
heading: Experimental setups

text: Fine - tuning BioBERT on QA and RE tasks took less than an hour as the size of the training data is much smaller than that of the training data used by .
heading: Experimental setups

text: On the other hand , it takes more than 20 epochs for BioBERT to reach its highest performance on the NER datasets .
heading: Experimental setups

text: Experimental results
The results of NER are shown in .
heading: Experimental results

text: First , we observe that BERT , which was pre-trained on only the general domain corpus is quite effective , but the micro averaged F 1 score of BERT was lower ( 2.01 lower ) than that of the state - of - the - art models .
heading: Experimental results

text: On the other hand , BioBERT achieves higher scores than BERT on all the datasets .
heading: Experimental results

text: BioBERT outperformed the state - of - the - art models on six out of nine datasets , and BioBERT v 1.1 ( PubMed ) outperformed the state - of - the - art models by 0.62 in terms of micro averaged F1 score .
heading: Experimental results

text: The relatively low scores on the LINNAEUS dataset can be attributed to the following : ( i ) the lack of a silver - standard dataset for training previous state - of - the - art models and ( ii ) different training / test set splits used in previous work , which were unavailable .
heading: Experimental results

text: The RE results of each model are shown in .
heading: Experimental results

text: BERT achieved better performance than the state - of - the - art model on the CHEMPROT dataset , which demonstrates its effectiveness in RE .
heading: Experimental results

text: On average ( micro ) , BioBERT v1.0 ( PubMed ) obtained a higher F1 score ( 2.80 higher ) than the state - of - the - art models .
heading: Experimental results

text: Also , BioBERT achieved the highest F 1 scores on 2 out of 3 biomedical datasets .
heading: Experimental results

text: The QA results are shown in .
heading: Experimental results

text: We micro averaged the best scores of the state - of - the - art models from each batch .
heading: Experimental results

text: BERT obtained a higher micro averaged MRR score ( 7.0 higher ) than the state - of - the - art models .
heading: Experimental results

text: All versions of BioBERT significantly outperformed BERT and the state - of - the - art models , and in particular , BioBERT v1.1 ( PubMed ) obtained a strict accuracy of 38.77 , a lenient accuracy of 53.81 and a mean reciprocal rank score of 44.77 , all of which were micro averaged .
heading: Experimental results

text: On all the biomedical QA datasets , BioBERT achieved new state - of - the - art performance in terms of MRR .
heading: Experimental results

text: Discussion
We used additional corpora of different sizes for pre-training and investigated their effect on performance .
heading: Discussion

text: For BioBERT v1.0 ( PubMed ) , we set the number of pre-training steps to 200K and varied the size of the PubMed corpus .
heading: Discussion

text: shows that the performance of BioBERT v 1.0 ( PubMed ) on three NER datasets ( NCBI Disease , BC2GM , BC4CHEMD ) changes in relation to the size of the PubMed corpus .
heading: Discussion

text: Pre-training on 1 billion words is quite effective , and the performance on each dataset mostly improves until 4.5 billion words .
heading: Discussion

text: We also saved the pre-trained weights from BioBERT v 1.0 ( PubMed ) at different pre-training steps to measure how the number of pre-training steps affects its performance on fine - tuning tasks .
heading: Discussion

text: shows the performance changes of BioBERT v 1.0 ( PubMed ) on the same three NER datasets in relation to the number of pre-training steps .
heading: Discussion

text: The results clearly show that the performance on each dataset improves as the number of pre-training steps increases .
heading: Discussion

text: Finally , shows the absolute performance improvements of BioBERT v 1.0 ( PubMed PMC ) over BERT on all 15 datasets .
heading: Discussion

text: F1 scores were used for NER / RE , and MRR scores were used for QA .
heading: Discussion

text: BioBERT significantly improves performance on most of the datasets .
heading: Discussion

text: As shown in , we sampled predictions from BERT and BioBERT v 1.1 ( PubMed ) to seethe effect of pre-training on downstream tasks .
heading: Discussion

text: Conclusion
In this article , we introduced BioBERT , which is a pre-trained language representation model for biomedical text mining .
heading: Conclusion

text: We showed that pre-training BERT on biomedical corpora is crucial in applying it to the biomedical domain .
heading: Conclusion

text: Requiring minimal task - specific architectural modification , BioBERT outperforms previous models on biomedical text mining tasks such as NER , RE and QA .
heading: Conclusion

text: The pre-released version of BioBERT ( January 2019 ) has already been shown to be very effective in many biomedical text mining tasks such as NER for clinical notes , human phenotype - gene RE and clinical temporal RE .
heading: Conclusion

text: The following updated versions of BioBERT will be available to the bioNLP community : ( i ) BioBERT BASE and BioBERT LARGE trained on only PubMed abstracts without initialization from the existing BERT model and ( ii ) BioBERT BASE and BioBERT LARGE trained on domain - specific vocabulary based on WordPiece .
