title
Open Question Answering with Weakly Supervised Embedding Models
heading: title

text: abstract
Building computers able to answer questions on any subject is along standing goal of artificial intelligence .
heading: abstract

text: Promising progress has recently been achieved by methods that learn to map questions to logical forms or database queries .
heading: abstract

text: Such approaches can be effective but at the cost of either large amounts of human - labeled data or by defining lexicons and grammars tailored by practitioners .
heading: abstract

text: In this paper , we instead take the radical approach of learning to map questions to vectorial feature representations .
heading: abstract

text: By mapping answers into the same space one can query any knowledge base independent of its schema , without requiring any grammar or lexicon .
heading: abstract

text: Our method is trained with anew optimization procedure combining stochastic gradient descent followed by a fine - tuning step using the weak supervision provided by blending automatically and collaboratively generated resources .
heading: abstract

text: We empirically demonstrate that our model can capture meaningful signals from its noisy supervision leading to major improvements over paralex , the only existing method able to be trained on similar weakly labeled data .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
This paper addresses the challenging problem of open - domain question answering , which consists of building systems able to answer questions from any domain .
heading: Introduction

text: Any advance on this difficult topic would bring a huge leap forward in building new ways of accessing knowledge .
heading: Introduction

text: An important development in this area has been the creation of large - scale Knowledge Bases ( KBs ) , such as Freebase and DBpedia which store huge amounts of general - purpose information .
heading: Introduction

text: They are organized as databases of triples connecting pairs of entities by various relationships and of the form ( left entity , relationship , right entity ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Question answering is then defined as the task of retrieving the correct entity or set of entities from a KB given a query expressed as a question in natural language .
heading: Introduction

text: The use of KBs simplifies the problem by separating the issue of collecting and organizing information ( i.e. information extraction ) from the one of searching through it ( i.e. question answering or natural language interfacing ) .
heading: Introduction

text: However , open question answering remains challenging because of the scale of these KBs ( billions of triples , millions of entities and relationships ) and of the difficulty for machines to interpret natural language .
heading: Introduction

text: Recent progress has been made by tackling this problem with semantic parsers .
heading: Introduction

text: These methods convert questions into logical forms or database queries ( e.g. in SPARQL ) which are then subsequently used to query KBs for answers .
heading: Introduction

text: Even if such systems have shown the ability to handle large - scale KBs , they require practitioners to hand - craft lexicons , grammars , and KB schema for the parsing to be effective .
heading: Introduction

text: This nonnegligible human intervention might not be generic enough to conveniently scale up to new databases with other schema , broader vocabularies or other languages than English .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we instead take the approach of converting questions to ( uninterpretable ) vectorial representations which require no pre-defined grammars or lexicons and can query any KB independent of its schema .
heading: Introduction

text: Following , we focus on answering simple factual questions on abroad range of topics , more specifically , those for which single KB triples stand for both the question and an answer ( of which there maybe many ) .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , ( parrotfish.e , live - in.r , southern - water .e ) stands for
heading: Introduction

text: What is parrotfish 's habitat ?
heading: Introduction

text: and southern - water.e and ( cantonese.e , be-major - language - in.r , hong - kong.e ) for
heading: Introduction

text: What is the main language of Hong - Kong ?
heading: Introduction

text: and cantonese.e.
heading: Introduction

text: In this task , the main difficulties come from lexical variability rather than from complex syntax , having multiple answers per question , and the absence of a supervised training signal .
heading: Introduction

text: Our approach is based on learning low - dimensional vector embeddings of words and of KB triples so that representations of questions and corresponding answers end up being similar in the embedding space .
heading: Introduction

text: Unfortunately , we do not have access to any human labeled ( query , answer ) supervision for this task .
heading: Introduction

text: In order to avoid transferring the cost of manual intervention to the one of labeling large amounts of data , we make use of weak supervision .
heading: Introduction

text: We show empirically that our model is able to take advantage of noisy and indirect supervision by ( i ) automatically generating questions from KB triples and treating this as training data ; and ( ii ) supplementing this with a data set of questions collaboratively marked as paraphrases but with no associated answers .
heading: Introduction

text: We end up learning meaningful vectorial representations for questions involving up to 800 k words and for triples of an mostly automatically created KB with 2.4 M entities and 600 k relationships .
heading: Introduction

text: Our method strongly outperforms previous results on the WikiAnswers + ReVerb evaluation data set introduced by .
heading: Introduction

text: Even if the embeddings obtained after training are of good quality , the scale of the optimization problem makes it hard to control and to lead to convergence .
heading: Introduction

text: Thus , we propose a method to fine - tune embedding - based models by carefully optimizing a matrix parameterizing the similarity used in the embedding space , leading to a consistent improvement in performance .
heading: Introduction

text: The rest of the paper is organized as follows .
heading: Introduction

text: Section 2 discusses some previous work and Section 3 introduces the problem of open question answering .
heading: Introduction

text: Then , Section 4 presents our model and Section 5 our experimental results .
heading: Introduction

text: Related Work
Large - scale question answering has along history , mostly initiated via the TREC tracks .
heading: Related Work

text: The first successful systems transformed the questions into queries which were fed to web search engines , the answer being subsequently extracted from top returned pages or snippets .
heading: Related Work

text: Such approaches require significant engineering to hand - craft queries and then parse and search over results .
heading: Related Work

text: The emergence of large - scale KBs , such as Freebase or DBpedia , changed the setting by transforming open question answering into a problem of querying a KB using natural language .
heading: Related Work

text: This is a challenging problem , which would require huge amount of labeled data to be tackled properly by purely supervised machine learning methods because of the great variability of language and of the large scale of KBs .
heading: Related Work

text: The earliest methods for open question - answering with KBs , based on hand - written templates , were not robust enough to such variability over possibly evolving KBs ( addition / deletion of triples and entities ) .
heading: Related Work

text: The solution to gain more expressiveness via machine learning comes from distant or indirect supervision to circumvent the issue of labeled data .
heading: Related Work

text: Initial works attempting to learn to connect KBs and natural language with less supervision have actually been tackling the information extraction problem .
heading: Related Work

text: Recently , new systems for learning question answering systems with few labeled data have been introduced based on semantic parsers .
heading: Related Work

text: Such works tend to require realistic amounts of manual intervention via labeled examples , but still need vast efforts to carefully design lexicons , grammars and the KB .
heading: Related Work

text: In contrast , proposed a framework for open question answering requiring little human annotation .
heading: Related Work

text: Their system , Paralex , answers questions with more limited semantics than those introduced in , but does so at a very large scale in an open - domain manner .
heading: Related Work

text: It is trained using automatically and collaboratively generated data and using the KB ReVerb .
heading: Related Work

text: In this work , we follow this trend by proposing an embedding - based model for question answering that is also trained under weak and cheap supervision .
heading: Related Work

text: Embedding - based models are getting more and more popular in natural language processing .
heading: Related Work

text: Starting from the neural network language model of , these methods have now reached near state - of - the - art performance on many standard tasks while usually requiring less hand - crafted features .
heading: Related Work

text: Recently , some embedding models have been proposed to perform a connection between natural language and KBs for word - sense disambiguation and for information extraction .
heading: Related Work

text: Our work builds on these approaches to instead learn to perform open question answering under weak supervision , which to our knowledge has not been attempted before .
heading: Related Work

text: Open-domain Question Answering
heading: Related Work

text: In this paper , we follow the question answering framework of and use the same data .
heading: Related Work

text: Hence , relatively little labeling or feature engineering has been used .
heading: Related Work

text: Task Definition
Our work considers the task of question answering as in : given a question q , the corresponding answer is given by a triplet from a KB .
heading: Task Definition

text: This means that we consider questions for which a set of triples t provide an interpretation of the question and it s answer , such as : Here , we only give a singlet per question , but many can exist .
heading: Task Definition

text: In the remainder , the KB is denoted K and its set of entities and relationships is E .
heading: Task Definition

text: The word vocabulary for questions is termed V. n v and n e are the sizes of V and E respectively .
heading: Task Definition

text: Our model consists in learning a function S ( ) , which can score questionanswer triple pairs ( q , t ) .
heading: Task Definition

text: Hence , finding the top - ranked answert ( q ) to a question q is directly carried out by : t
heading: Task Definition

text: To handle multiple answer , we instead present the results as a ranked list , rather than taking the top prediction , and evaluate that instead .
heading: Task Definition

text: Using the scoring function S ( ) allows to directly query the KB without needing to define an intermediate structured logical representation for questions as in semantic parsing systems .
heading: Task Definition

text: We aim at learning S ( ) , with no human - labeled supervised data in the form ( question , answer ) pairs , but only by indirect supervision , generated either automatically or collaboratively .
heading: Task Definition

text: We detail in the rest of this section our process for creating training data .
heading: Task Definition

text: Training Data

Our training data consists of two sources : an automatically created KB , Re - Verb , from which we generate questions and a set of pairs of questions collaboratively labeled as paraphrases from the website WikiAnswers .
heading: Training Data

text: Knowledge Base
The set of potential answers K is given by the KB ReVerb .
heading: Knowledge Base

text: ReVerb is an open - source database composed of more than 14M triples , made of more than 2 M entities and 600 k relationships , which have been automatically extracted from the ClueWeb09 corpus .
heading: Knowledge Base

text: In the following , entities are denoted with a .e suffix and relationships with a .r suffix .
heading: Knowledge Base

text: ReVerb contains broad and general knowledge harvested with very little human intervention , which suits the realistically supervised setting .
heading: Knowledge Base

text: But , as a result , ReVerb is ambiguous and noisy with many useless triples and entities as well as numerous duplicates .
heading: Knowledge Base

text: For instance , winston - churchill.e , churchill.e and even roosevelt - and - churchill.e are all distinct entities .. 2 presents some examples of triples : some make sense , some others are completely unclear or useless .
heading: Knowledge Base

text: In contrast to highly curated databases such Freebase , ReVerb has more noise but also many more relation types ( Freebase has around 20 k ) .
heading: Knowledge Base

text: So for some types of triple it has much better coverage , despite the larger size of Freebase ; for example Freebase does not cover verbs like afraid - of or suffer - from .
heading: Knowledge Base

text: Paraphrases
The automatically generated examples are useful to connect KB triples and natural language .

text: However , they do not allow fora satisfactory modeling of English language because of their poor wording .
heading: Paraphrases

text: To overcome this issue , we again follow and supplement our training data with an indirect supervision signal made of pairs of question paraphrases collected from the WikiAnswers website .

text: Embedding - based Model
Our model ends up learning vector embeddings of symbols , either for entities or relationships from ReVerb , or for each word of the vocabulary .
heading: Embedding - based Model

text: Question - KB Triple Scoring
heading: Embedding - based Model

text: Architecture
Our framework concerns the learning of a function S ( q , t ) , based on embeddings , that is designed to score the similarity of a question q and a triplet from K.
heading: Architecture

text: Our scoring approach is inspired by previous work for labeling images with words , which we adapted , replacing images and labels by questions and triples .
heading: Architecture

text: Intuitively , it consists of projecting questions , treated as a bag of words ( and possibly n-grams as well ) , on the one hand , and triples on the other hand , into a shared embedding space and then computing a similarity measure ( the dot product in this paper ) between both projections .
heading: Architecture

text: The scoring function is then :
heading: Architecture

text: with f ( ) a function mapping words from questions into Contrary to previous work modeling KBs with embeddings ( e.g. ) , in our model , an entity does not have the same embedding when appearing in the lefthand or in the right - hand side of a triple .
heading: Architecture

text: Since , g ( ) sums embeddings of all constituents of a triple , we need to use 2 embeddings per entity to encode for the fact that relationships in the KB are not symmetric and so that appearing as a left - hand or right - hand entity is different .
heading: Architecture

text: This approach can be easily applied attest time to score any ( question , triple ) pairs .
heading: Architecture

text: Multitask Training with Paraphrases Pairs
heading: Architecture

text: We multitask the training of our model by training on pairs of paraphrases of questions ( q 1 , q 2 ) from P as well as training on the pseudolabeled data constructed in D .
heading: Architecture

Training of S prp is also conducted with SGD ( and adagrad ) as for S , but , in this case , negative examples are created by replacing one of the questions from the pair by another question chosen at random in P.
heading: Architecture

text: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings
The scale of the problem forced us to keep our architecture simple : with n e ? 3.5M ( with 2 embeddings for each entity ) and n v ? 800 k , we have to learn around 4.3 M embeddings .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: With an embedding space of dimension k = 64 , this leads to around 275M parameters to learn .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: The training algorithm must also stay simple to scale on a training set of around 250 M of examples ( D and P combined ) ; SGD appears as the only viable option .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: SGD , combined with adagrad for adapting the learning rate on the course of training , is a powerful algorithm .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: However , the scale of the optimization problem makes it very hard to control and conduct properly until convergence .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: When SGD stops after a pre-defined number of epochs , we are almost certain that the problem is not fully solved and that some room for improvement remains : we observed that embeddings were able to often rank correct answers near the top of the candidates list , but not always in the first place .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: In this paper , we introduce away to fine - tune our embedding - based model so that correct answers might end up more often at the top of the list .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: Updating the embeddings involves working on too many parameters , but ultimately , these embeddings are meant to be used in a dot -product that computes the similarity between q and t.
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: We propose to learn a matrix M ?
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: R kk parameterizing the similarity between words and triples embeddings .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: The scoring function becomes :
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: M has only k 2 parameters and can be efficiently determined by solving the following convex problem ( fixing the embedding matrices W and V ) :
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: where X F is the Frobenius norm of X .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: We solve this problem in a few minutes using L - BFGS on a subset of m = 10 M examples from D .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: We first use 4 M examples to train and 6M as validation set to determine the value of the regularization parameter ?.
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: We then retrain the model on the whole 10M examples using the selected value , which happened to be ? = 1.7 10 ?5 .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: This fine - tuning is related to learning anew metric in the embedding space , but since the resulting M is not symmetric , it does not define a dot-product .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: Still , M is close to a constant factor times identity ( as in the original score S ( ) ) .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: The fine - tuning does not deeply alter the ranking , but , as expected , allows fora slight change in the triples ranking , which ends in consistent improvement in performance , as we show in the experiments .
heading: Fine - tuning the Similarity between Embeddings

text: Experiments
Evaluation Protocols
We first detail the data and metrics which were chosen to assess the quality of our embedding model .
heading: Evaluation Protocols

text: Test Set
The data set WikiAnswers + ReVerb contains no labeled examples but some are needed for evaluating models .
heading: Test Set

text: We used the test set which has been created by in the following way : ( 1 ) they identified 37 questions from a heldout portion of WikiAnswers which were likely to have at least one answer in ReVerb , ( 2 ) they added all valid paraphrases of these questions to obtain a set of 691 questions , ( 3 ) they ran various versions of their paralex system on them to gather candidate triples ( for a total of 48 k ) , which they finally hand - labeled .
heading: Test Set

text: Reranking
We first evaluated different versions of our model against the paralex system in a reranking setting .
heading: Reranking

text: For each question q from the WikiAn - swers + ReVerb test set , we take the provided candidate triples t and rerank them by sorting by the score S ( q , t ) or S ft ( q , t ) of our model , depending whether we use fine - tuning or not .
heading: Reranking

text: As in , we then compute the precision , recall and F1 -score of the highest ranked answer as well as the mean average precision ( MAP ) of the whole output , which measures the average precision overall levels of recall .
heading: Reranking

text: Full Ranking

We hence decided to filter out some candidates before ranking by using a simple string matching strategy : after pos-tagging the question , we construct a set of candidate strings containing ( i ) all noun phrases that appear less than 1,000 .
heading: Full Ranking

text: Examples of nearest neighboring entities and relationships from REVERB for some words from our vocabulary .
heading: Full Ranking

R : , indicates the embedding of an entity when appearing in left - hand side , resp. right - hand side , of triples .

text: Results
This section now discusses our empirical performance .
Reranking and present the results of the reranking experiments .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: We compare various versions of our model against two versions of paralex , whose results were given in .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: First , we can see that multitasking with paraphrase data is essential since it improves F1 from 0.60 to 0.68 .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: Paraphrases allow for the embeddings to encode a richer connection between KB constituents and words , as well as between words themselves .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: Note that the WikiAnswers data provides word alignment between paraphrases , which we did not use , unlike paralex .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: We also tried to use n-grams ( 2.5 M most frequent ) as well as the words to represent the question , but this did not bring any improvement , which might at first seem counter - intuitive .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: We believe this is due to two factors : it is hard to learn good embeddings for n-grams since their frequency is usually very low and ( 2 ) our automatically generated questions have a poor syntax and hence , many n-grams in this data set do not make sense .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: We actually conducted experiments with several variants of our model , which tried to take the word ordering into account ( e.g. with convolutions ) , and they all failed to outperform our best performance without word order , once again perhaps because the supervision is not clean enough to allow for such elaborated language modeling .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: Fine - tuning the embedding model is very beneficial to optimize the top of the list and grants a bump of 5 points of F1 : carefully tuning the similarity makes a clear difference .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: All versions of our system greatly outperform paralex : the fine - tuned model improves the F1 - score by almost 20 points and , according to , is better in precision for all levels of recall .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: paralex works by starting with an initial lexicon mapping from the KB to language and then gradually increasing its coverage by iterating on the WikiAnswers + ReVerb data .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: Most of its predictions come from automatically acquired templates and rules : this allows fora good precision but it is not flexible enough across language variations to grant a satisfying recall .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: Most of our improvement comes from a much better recall .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: However , as we said earlier , this reranking setting is detrimental for paralex because paralex was evaluated on the task of reranking some of its own predictions .
heading: This section now discusses our empirical performance .

text: The results provided for paralex , while not corresponding to those of a full ranking among all triples from ReVerb ( it is still reranking among a subset of candidates ) , concerns an evaluation setting more complicated than for our model .

As expected , string matching greatly improves results , both in precision and recall , and also significantly reduces evaluation time .

text: Evaluation on WebQuestions
Our initial objective was to be able to perform open - domain question answering .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: In this last experimental section , we tend to evaluate how generic our learned system is .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: To this end , we propose to ask our model to answer questions coming from another dataset from the literature , but without retraining it with labeled data , just by directly using the parameters learned on WikiAnswers + ReVerb .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: We chose the data set WebQuestions , which consists of natural language questions matched with answers corresponding to entities of Freebase : in this case , no triple has to be returned , only a single entity .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: We used exact string matching to find the ReVerb entities corresponding to the Freebase answers from the test set of WebQuestions and obtained 1,538 questions labeled with ReVerb out of the original 2,034 .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: Results of different versions of our model are displayed in .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: For each test question , we record the rank of the first ReVerb triple containing the answer entity .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: Top - 1 and Top - 10 are computed on questions for which the system returned at least one answer ( around 1,000 questions using string matching ) , while F1 is computed for all questions .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: Of course , performance is not great and can not be directly compared with that of the best system reported in ( more than 0.30 of F1 ) .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: One of the main reasons is that most questions of WebQuestions , such as Who was vice - president after Kennedy died ? , should be represented by multiple triples , a setting for which our system has not been designed .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: Still , fora system trained with almost no manual annotation nor prior information on another dataset , with another - very noisy - KB , the results can be seen as particularly promising .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: Besides , evaluation is broad since , in ReVerb , most entities actually appear many times under different names as explained in Section 3 .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: Hence , there might be higher ranked answers but they are missed by our evaluation script .
heading: Evaluation on WebQuestions

text: Conclusion
This paper introduces anew framework for learning to perform open question answering with very little supervision .
heading: Conclusion

text: Using embeddings as its core , our approach can be successfully trained on imperfect labeled data and indirect supervision and significantly outperforms previous work for answering simple factual questions .
heading: Conclusion

text: Besides , we introduce anew way to fine - tune embedding models for cases where their optimization problem can not be completely solved .
heading: Conclusion

text: In spite of these promising results , some exciting challenges remain , especially in order to scale up this model to questions with more complex semantics .
heading: Conclusion

text: Due to the very low supervision signal , our work can only answer satisfactorily simple factual questions , and does not even take into account the word ordering when modeling them .
heading: Conclusion

text: Further , much more work has to be carried out to encode the semantics of more complex questions into the embedding space .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Convolutional Neural Network Architectures for Matching Natural Language Sentences
abstract
Semantic matching is of central importance to many natural language tasks [ 2,28 ] .
heading: abstract

text: A successful matching algorithm needs to adequately model the internal structures of language objects and the interaction between them .
heading: abstract

text: As a step toward this goal , we propose convolutional neural network models for matching two sentences , by adapting the convolutional strategy in vision and speech .
heading: abstract

text: The proposed models not only nicely represent the hierarchical structures of sentences with their layerby - layer composition and pooling , but also capture the rich matching patterns at different levels .
heading: abstract

text: Our models are rather generic , requiring no prior knowledge on language , and can hence be applied to matching tasks of different nature and in different languages .
heading: abstract

text: The empirical study on a variety of matching tasks demonstrates the efficacy of the proposed model on a variety of matching tasks and its superiority to competitor models .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Matching two potentially heterogenous language objects is central to many natural language applications .
heading: Introduction

text: It generalizes the conventional notion of similarity ( e.g. , in paraphrase identification ) or relevance ( e.g. , in information retrieval ) , since it aims to model the correspondence between " linguistic objects " of different nature at different levels of abstractions .
heading: Introduction

text: Examples include top -k re-ranking in machine translation ( e.g. , comparing the meanings of a French sentence and an English sentence ) and dialogue ( e.g. , evaluating the appropriateness of a response to a given utterance ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Natural language sentences have complicated structures , both sequential and hierarchical , that are essential for understanding them .
heading: Introduction

text: A successful sentence - matching algorithm therefore needs to capture not only the internal structures of sentences but also the rich patterns in their interactions .
heading: Introduction

text: Towards this end , we propose deep neural network models , which adapt the convolutional strategy ( proven successful on image and speech ) to natural language .
heading: Introduction

text: To further explore the relation between representing sentences and matching them , we devise a novel model that can naturally host both the hierarchical composition for sentences and the simple - to - comprehensive fusion of matching patterns with the same convolutional architecture .
heading: Introduction

text: Our model is generic , requiring no prior knowledge of natural language ( e.g. , parse tree ) and putting essentially no constraints on the matching tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: This is part of our continuing effort 1 in understanding natural language objects and the matching between them .
heading: Introduction

text: Our main contributions can be summarized as follows .
heading: Introduction

text: First , we devise novel deep convolutional network architectures that can naturally combine 1 ) the hierarchical sentence modeling through layer - by - layer composition and pooling , and 2 ) the capturing of the rich matching patterns at different levels of abstraction ; Second , we perform extensive empirical study on tasks with different scales and characteristics , and demonstrate the superior power of the proposed architectures over competitor methods .
heading: Introduction

text: Roadmap
We start by introducing a convolution network in Section 2 as the basic architecture for sentence modeling , and how it is related to existing sentence models .
heading: Roadmap

text: Based on that , in Section 3 , we propose two architectures for sentence matching , with a detailed discussion of their relation .
heading: Roadmap

text: In Section 4 , we briefly discuss the learning of the proposed architectures .
heading: Roadmap

text: Then in Section 5 , we report our empirical study , followed by a brief discussion of related work in Section 6 .
heading: Roadmap

text: Convolutional Sentence Model
We start with proposing anew convolutional architecture for modeling sentences .
heading: Convolutional Sentence Model

text: As illustrated in , it takes as input the embedding of words ( often trained beforehand with unsupervised methods ) in the sentence aligned sequentially , and summarize the meaning of a sentence through layers of convolution and pooling , until reaching a fixed length vectorial representation in the final layer .
heading: Convolutional Sentence Model

text: As inmost convolutional models , we use convolution units with a local " receptive field " and shared weights , but we design a large feature map to adequately model the rich structures in the composition of words .
heading: Convolutional Sentence Model

text: Convolution
As shown in , the convolution in Layer - 1 operates on sliding windows of words ( width k 1 ) , and the convolutions in deeper layers are defined in a similar way .
heading: Convolution

text: Generally , with sentence input x , the convolution unit for feature map of type -f ( among F of them ) on Layer - is
heading: Convolution

text: and it s matrix form is z
heading: Convolution

text: gives the output of feature map of type - f for location i in Layer - ;
heading: Convolution

text: w ( , f ) is the parameters for f on Layer - , with matrix form
heading: Convolution

text: ? ( ) is the activation function ( e.g. , Sigmoid or Relu )
heading: Convolution

text: ( ?1 ) i denotes the segment of Layer - ?
heading: Convolution

text: 1 for the convolution at location i , whil
heading: Convolution

text: concatenates the vectors fork 1 ( width of sliding window ) words from sentence input x .
heading: Convolution

text: Max - Pooling
We take a max - pooling in every two - unit window for every f , after each convolution
heading: Max - Pooling

text: The effects of pooling are two - fold :
heading: Max - Pooling

text: 1 ) it shrinks the size of the representation by half , thus quickly absorbs the differences in length for sentence representation , and 2 ) it filters out undesirable composition of words ( see Section 2.1 for some analysis ) .
heading: Max - Pooling

text: Length Variability
The variable length of sentences in a fairly broad range can be readily handled with the convolution and pooling strategy .
heading: Length Variability

text: More specifically , we put all - zero padding vectors after the last word of the sentence until the maximum length .
heading: Length Variability

text: To eliminate the boundary effect caused by the great variability of sentence lengths , we add to the convolutional unit agate which sets the output vectors to all - zeros if the input is all zeros .
heading: Length Variability

text: For any given sentence input x , the output of type - f filter for location i in the th layer is given by
heading: Length Variability

text: ( 2 ) where g ( v ) = 0 if all the elements in vector v equals 0 , otherwise g ( v ) = 1 . This gate , working with max - pooling and positive activation function ( e.g. , Sigmoid ) , keeps away the artifacts from padding in all layers .
heading: Length Variability

text: Actually it creates a natural hierarchy of all - zero padding ( as illustrated in ) , consisting of nodes in the neural net that would not contribute in the forward process ( as in prediction ) and backward propagation ( as in learning ) .
heading: Length Variability

text: The convolutional unit , when combined with max - pooling , can act as the compositional operator with local selection mechanism as in the recursive autoencoder .
heading: Length Variability

text: gives an example on what could happen on the first two layers with input sentence " The cat sat on the mat " .
heading: Length Variability

text: Just for illustration purpose , we present a dramatic choice of parameters ( by turning off some elements in W ) to make the convolution units focus on different segments within a 3 - word window .
heading: Length Variability

text: For example , some feature maps ( group 2 ) give compositions for " the cat " and " cat sat " , each being a vector .
heading: Length Variability

text: Different feature maps offer a variety of compositions , with confidence encoded in the values ( color coded in output of convolution layer in ) .
heading: Length Variability

text: The pooling then chooses , for each composition type , between two adjacent sliding windows , e.g. , between " on the " and " the mat " for feature maps group 2 from the rightmost two sliding windows .
heading: Length Variability

text: Some Analysis on the Convolutional Architecture
Relation to Recursive Models
Our convolutional model differs from Recurrent Neural Network ( RNN , ) and Recursive Auto - Encoder ( RAE , ) in several important ways .
heading: Relation to Recursive Models

text: First , unlike RAE , it does not take a single path of word / phrase composition determined either by a separate gating function , an external parser , or just natural sequential order .
heading: Relation to Recursive Models

text: Instead , it takes multiple choices of composition via a large feature map ( encoded in w ( , f ) for different f ) , and leaves the choices to the pooling afterwards to pick the more appropriate segments ( in every adjacent two ) for each composition .
heading: Relation to Recursive Models

text: With any window width k ? 3 , the type of composition would be much richer than that of RAE .
heading: Relation to Recursive Models

text: Second , our convolutional model can take supervised training and tune the parameters fora specific task , a property vital to our supervised learning - to - match framework .
heading: Relation to Recursive Models

text: However , unlike recursive models , the convolutional architecture has a fixed depth , which bounds the level of composition it could do .
heading: Relation to Recursive Models

text: For tasks like matching , this limitation can be largely compensated with a network afterwards that can take a " global " synthesis on the learned sentence representation .
heading: Relation to Recursive Models

text: Relation to " Shallow " Convolutional Models

The proposed convolutional sentence model takes simple architectures such as ( essentially the same convolutional architecture as SENNA ) , which consists of a convolution layer and a max - pooling over the entire sentence for each feature map .
heading: Relation to " Shallow " Convolutional Models

text: This type of models , with local convolutions and a global pooling , essentially do a " soft " local template matching and is able to detect local features useful fora certain task .
heading: Relation to " Shallow " Convolutional Models

text: Since the sentencelevel sequential order is inevitably lost in the global pooling , the model is incapable of modeling more complicated structures .
heading: Relation to " Shallow " Convolutional Models

text: It is not hard to see that our convolutional model degenerates to the SENNA - type architecture if we limit the number of layers to be two and set the pooling window infinitely large .
heading: Relation to " Shallow " Convolutional Models

text: Convolutional Matching Models
Based on the discussion in Section 2 , we propose two related convolutional architectures , namely ARC - I and ARC - II ) , for matching two sentences .
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: Architecture - I ( ARC - I )
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: Architecture - I ( ARC - I ) , as illustrated in , takes a conventional approach :
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: It first finds the representation of each sentence , and then compares the representation for the two sentences with a multi - layer perceptron ( MLP ) .
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: It is essentially the Siamese architecture introduced in , which has been applied to different tasks as a nonlinear similarity function .
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: Although ARC - I enjoys the flexibility brought by the convolutional sentence model , it suffers from a drawback inherited from the Siamese architecture : it defers the interaction between two sentences ( in the final MLP ) to until their individual representation matures ( in the convolution model ) , therefore runs at the risk of losing details ( e.g. , a city name ) important for the matching task in representing the sentences .
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: In other words , in the forward phase ( prediction ) , the representation of each sentence is formed without knowledge of each other .
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: This can not be adequately circumvented in backward phase ( learning ) , when the convolutional model learns to extract structures informative for matching on a population level .
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: Architecture - II ( ARC - II )
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: In view of the drawback of Architecture - I , we propose Architecture - II ( ARC - II ) that is built directly on the interaction space between two sentences .
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: It has the desirable property of letting two sentences meet before their own high - level representations mature , while still retaining the space for the individual development of abstraction of each sentence .
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: Basically , in Layer - 1 , we take sliding windows on both sentences , and model all the possible combinations of them through " one-dimensional " ( 1D ) convolutions .
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: For segment ion S X and segment j on S Y , we have the feature map
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: where ?
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: i , j ? R 2 k1 De simply concatenates the vectors for sentence segments for S X and S Y : z
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: Clearly the 1D convolution preserves the location information about both segments .
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: After that in Layer - 2 , it performs a 2D max - pooling in non-overlapping 2 2 windows ( illustrated in )
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: ( 4 ) In Layer - 3 , we perform a 2D convolution on k 3 k 3 windows of output from Layer - 2 :
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: This could goon for more layers of 2D convolution and 2D max - pooling , analogous to that of convolutional architecture for image input .
heading: Convolutional Matching Models

text: The 2D - Convolution

After the first convolution , we obtain a low level representation of the interaction between the two sentences , and from then we obtain a high level representation z ( ) i , j which encodes the information from both sentences .
heading: The 2D - Convolution

text: The general two - dimensional convolution is formulated as z ( )
heading: The 2D - Convolution

text: where ?
heading: The 2D - Convolution

text: concatenates the corresponding vectors from its 2 D receptive field in Layer -?1 .
heading: The 2D - Convolution

text: This pooling has different mechanism as in the 1D case , for it selects not only among compositions on different segments but also among different local matchings .
heading: The 2D - Convolution

text: This pooling strategy resembles the dynamic pooling in in a similarity learning context , but with two distinctions :
heading: The 2D - Convolution

text: 1 ) it happens on a fixed architecture and 2 ) it has much richer structure than just similarity .
heading: The 2D - Convolution

text: contains information about the words in S X before those in z ( ) i + 1 , j , although they maybe generated with slightly different segments in S Y , due to the 2D pooling ( illustrated in .
heading: The 2D - Convolution

text: The orders is however retained in a " conditional " sense .
heading: The 2D - Convolution

text: Our experiments show that when ARC - II is trained on the ( S X , S Y ,S Y ) triples whereS Y randomly shuffles the words in S Y , it consistently gains some ability of finding the correct S Y in the usual contrastive negative sampling setting , which however does not happen with ARC - I.
heading: The 2D - Convolution

text: Model Generality
It is not hard to show that ARC - II actually subsumes ARC - I as a special case .
heading: Model Generality

text: Indeed , in ARC - II if we choose ( by turning off some parameters in W ( , ) ) to keep the representations of the two sentences separated until the final MLP , ARC - II can actually act fully like ARC - I , as illustrated in .
heading: Model Generality

text: More specifically , if we let the feature maps in the first convolution layer to be either devoted to S X or devoted to S Y ( instead of taking both as in general case ) , the output of each segment - pair is naturally divided into two corresponding groups .
heading: Model Generality

text: As a result , the output for each filter f , denoted z
heading: Model Generality

text: ( 1 , f ) 1:n , 1:n ( n is the number of sliding windows ) , will be of rank - one , possessing essentially the same information as the result of the first convolution layer in ARC - I .
heading: Model Generality

text: Clearly the 2D pooling that follows will reduce to 1 D pooling , with this separateness preserved .
heading: Model Generality

text: If we further limit the parameters in the second convolution units ( more specifically w ( 2 , f ) ) to those for S X and S Y , we can ensure the individual development of different levels of abstraction on each side , and fully recover the functionality of ARC - I .
heading: Model Generality

text: As suggested by the order - preserving property and the generality of ARC - II , this architecture offers not only the capability but also the inductive bias for the individual development of internal abstraction on each sentence , despite the fact that it is built on the interaction between two sentences .
heading: Model Generality

text: As a result , ARC - II can naturally blend two seemingly diverging processes :
heading: Model Generality

text: 1 ) the successive composition within each sentence , and 2 ) the extraction and fusion of matching patterns between them , hence is powerful for matching linguistic objects with rich structures .
heading: Model Generality

text: This intuition is verified by the superior performance of ARC - II in experiments ( Section 5 ) on different matching tasks .
heading: Model Generality

text: Training
We employ a discriminative training strategy with a large margin objective .
heading: Training

text: Suppose that we are given the following triples ( x , y + , y ? )
heading: Training

text: from the oracle , with x matched with y + better than with y ? .
heading: Training

text: We have the following ranking - based loss as objective :
heading: Training

text: where s ( x , y) is predicted matching score for ( x , y ) , and ?
heading: Training

text: includes the parameters for convolution layers and those for the MLP .
heading: Training

text: The optimization is relatively straightforward for both architectures with the standard back - propagation .
heading: Training

text: The gating function ( see Section 2 ) can be easily adopted into the gradient by discounting the contribution from convolution units that have been turned off by the gating function .
heading: Training

text: In other words , We use stochastic gradient descent for the optimization of models .
heading: Training

text: All the proposed models perform better with mini-batch ( 100 ? 200 in sizes ) which can be easily parallelized on single machine with multi-cores .
heading: Training

text: For regularization , we find that for both architectures , early stopping is enough for models with medium size and large training sets ( with over 500K instances ) .
heading: Training

text: For small datasets ( less than 10 k training instances ) however , we have to combine early stopping and dropout to deal with the serious overfitting problem .
heading: Training

text: We use 50 - dimensional word embedding trained with the Word2 Vec : the embedding for English words ( Section 5.2 & 5.4 ) is learnt on Wikipedia ( ?1B words ) , while that for Chinese words ( Section 5.3 ) is learnt on Weibo data (? 300 M words ) .
heading: Training

text: Our other experiments ( results omitted here ) suggest that fine - tuning the word embedding can further improve the performances of all models , at the cost of longer training .
heading: Training

text: We vary the maximum length of words for different tasks to cope with its longest sentence .
heading: Training

text: We use 3 - word window throughout all experiments 2 , but test various numbers of feature maps ( typically from 200 to 500 ) , for optimal performance .
heading: Training

text: ARC - II models for all tasks have eight layers ( three for convolution , three for pooling , and two for MLP ) , while ARC - I performs better with less layers ( two for convolution , two for pooling , and two for MLP ) and more hidden nodes .
heading: Training

text: We use ReLu as the activation function for all of models ( convolution and MLP ) , which yields comparable or better results to sigmoid - like functions , but converges faster .
heading: Training

text: Experiments
We report the performance of the proposed models on three matching tasks of different nature , and compare it with that of other competitor models .
heading: Experiments

text: Among them , the first two tasks ( namely , Sentence Completion and Tweet - Response Matching ) are about matching of language objects of heterogenous natures , while the third one ( paraphrase identification ) is a natural example of matching homogeneous objects .
heading: Experiments

text: Moreover , the three tasks involve two languages , different types of matching , and distinctive writing styles , proving the broad applicability of the proposed models .
heading: Experiments

text: Competitor Methods
WORDEMBED : We first represent each short - text as the sum of the embedding of the words it contains .
heading: Competitor Methods

text: The matching score of two short - texts are calculated with an MLP with the embedding of the two documents as input ; DEEPMATCH : We take the matching model in and train it on our datasets with 3 hidden layers and 1,000 hidden nodes in the first hidden layer ; URAE+ MLP :
heading: Competitor Methods

text: We use the Unfolding Recursive Autoencoder to get a 100 dimensional vector representation of each sentence , and put an MLP on the top as in WORDEMBED ; SENNA + MLP / SIM :
heading: Competitor Methods

text: We use the SENNA - type sentence model for sentence representation ;
heading: Competitor Methods

text: SENMLP : We take the whole sentence as input ( with word embedding aligned sequentially ) , and use an MLP to obtain the score of coherence .
heading: Competitor Methods

text: All the competitor models are trained on the same training set as the proposed models , and we report the best test performance over different choices of models ( e.g. , the number and size of hidden layers in MLP ) .
heading: Competitor Methods

text: Experiment I : Sentence
Completion
This is an artificial task designed to elucidate how different matching models can capture the correspondence between two clauses within a sentence .
heading: Completion

text: Basically , we take a sentence from Reuterswith two " balanced " clauses ( with 8 ? 28 words ) divided by one comma , and use the first clause as S X and the second as S Y .
heading: Completion

text: The task is then to recover the original second clause for any given first clause .
heading: Completion

text: The matching here is considered heterogeneous since the relation between the two is nonsymmetrical on both lexical and semantic levels .
heading: Completion

text: We deliberately make the task harder by using negative second clauses similar to the original ones 4 , both in training and testing .
heading: Completion

text: One representative example is given as follows :
heading: Completion

text: All models are trained on 3 million triples ( from 600K positive pairs ) , and tested on 50K positive pairs , each accompanied by four negatives , with results shown in .
heading: Completion

text: The two proposed models get nearly half of the cases right 5 , with large margin over other sentence models and models without explicit sequence modeling .
heading: Completion

text: ARC - II outperforms ARC - I significantly , showing the power of joint modeling of matching and sentence meaning .
heading: Completion

text: As another convolutional model , SENNA + MLP performs fairly well on this task , although still running behind the proposed convolutional architectures since it is too shallow to adequately model the sentence .
heading: Completion

text: It is a bit surprising that URAE comes last on this task , which might be caused by the facts that 1 ) the representation model ( including word - embedding ) is not trained on Reuters , and 2 ) the split - sentence setting hurts the parsing , which is vital to the quality of learned sentence representation ..
heading: Completion

text: This task is slightly easier than Experiment I , with more training instances and purely random negatives .
heading: Completion

text: It requires less about the grammatical rigor but more on detailed modeling of loose and local matching patterns ( e.g. , work - overtime ? rest ) .
heading: Completion

text: Again ARC - II beats other models with large margins , while two convolutional sentence models ARC - I and SENNA + MLP come next .
heading: Completion

text: Experiment II : Matching A Response to A Tweet
Experiment III : Paraphrase Identification
heading: Experiment II : Matching A Response to A Tweet

text: Paraphrase identification aims to determine whether two sentences have the same meaning , a problem considered a touchstone of natural language understanding .
heading: Experiment II : Matching A Response to A Tweet

text: is included to test our methods on matching homogenous objects .
heading: Experiment II : Matching A Response to A Tweet

text: Here we use the benchmark MSRP dataset , which contains 4,076 instances for training and 1,725 for test .
heading: Experiment II : Matching A Response to A Tweet

text: We use all the training instances and report the test performance from early stopping .
heading: Experiment II : Matching A Response to A Tweet

text: As stated earlier , our model is not specially tailored for modeling synonymy , and generally requires ? 100K instances to work favorably .
heading: Experiment II : Matching A Response to A Tweet

text: Nevertheless , our generic matching models still manage to perform reasonably well , achieving an accuracy and F1 score close to the best performer in 2008 based on hand - crafted features , but still significantly lower than the state - of - the - art ( 76.8%/83.6 % ) , achieved with unfolding - RAE and other features designed for this task .
heading: Experiment II : Matching A Response to A Tweet

text: Discussions
ARC - II outperforms others significantly when the training instances are relatively abundant ( as in Experiment I & II ) .
heading: Discussions

text: It s superiority over ARC - I , however , is less salient when the sentences have deep grammatical structures and the matching relies lesson the local matching patterns , as in Experiment - I .
heading: Discussions

text: This therefore raises the interesting question about how to balance the representation of matching and the representations of objects , and whether we can guide the learning process through something like curriculum learning .
heading: Discussions

text: As another important observation , convolutional models ( ARC - I & II , SENNA + MLP ) perform favorably over bag - of - words models , indicating the importance of utilizing sequential structures in understanding and matching sentences .
heading: Discussions

text: Quite interestingly , as shown by our other experiments , ARC - I and ARC - II trained purely with random negatives automatically gain some ability in telling whether the words in a given sentence are in right sequential order ( with around 60 % accuracy for both ) .
heading: Discussions

text: It is therefore a bit surprising that an auxiliary task on identifying the correctness of word order in the response does not enhance the ability of the model on the original matching tasks .
heading: Discussions

text: We noticed that simple sum of embedding learned via Word2 Vec yields reasonably good results on all three tasks .
heading: Discussions

text: We hypothesize that the Word2 Vec embedding is trained in such away that the vector summation can act as a simple composition , and hence retains a fair amount of meaning in the short text segment .
heading: Discussions

text: This is in contrast with other bag - of - words models like DEEPMATCH .
heading: Discussions

text: Related Work
Matching structured objects rarely goes beyond estimating the similarity of objects in the same domain , with few exceptions like .
heading: Related Work

text: When dealing with language objects , most methods still focus on seeking vectorial representations in a common latent space , and calculating the matching score with inner product .
heading: Related Work

text: Few work has been done on building a deep architecture on the interaction space for texts - pairs , but it is largely based on a bag - of - words representation of text .
heading: Related Work

text: Our models are related to the long thread of work on sentence representation .
heading: Related Work

text: Aside from the models with recursive nature ( as discussed in Section 2.1 ) , it is fairly common practice to use the sum of word - embedding to represent a short - text , mostly for classification .
heading: Related Work

text: There is very little work on convolutional modeling of language .
heading: Related Work

text: In addition to , there is a very recent model on sentence representation with dynamic convolutional neural network .
heading: Related Work

text: This work relies heavily on a carefully designed pooling strategy to handle the variable length of sentence with a relatively small feature map , tailored for classification problems with modest sizes .
heading: Related Work

text: Conclusion
We propose deep convolutional architectures for matching natural language sentences , which can nicely combine the hierarchical modeling of individual sentences and the patterns of their matching .
heading: Conclusion

text: Empirical study shows our models can outperform competitors on a variety of matching tasks .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Large - scale Simple Question Answering with Memory Networks
abstract
Training large - scale question answering systems is complicated because training sources usually cover a small portion of the range of possible questions .
heading: abstract

text: This paper studies the impact of multitask and transfer learning for simple question answering ; a setting for which the reasoning required to answer is quite easy , as long as one can retrieve the correct evidence given a question , which can be difficult in large - scale conditions .
heading: abstract

text: To this end , we introduce anew dataset of 100 k questions that we use in conjunction with existing benchmarks .
heading: abstract

text: We conduct our study within the framework of Memory Networks ( Weston et al. , 2015 ) because this perspective allows us to eventually scale up to more complex reasoning , and show that Memory Networks can be successfully trained to achieve excellent performance .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Open-domain Question Answering ( QA ) systems aim at providing the exact answer ( s ) to questions formulated in natural language , without restriction of domain .
heading: Introduction

text: While there is along history of QA systems that search for textual documents or on the Web and extract answers from them ( see e.g. ) , recent progress has been made with the release of large Knowledge Bases ( KBs ) such as Freebase , which contain consolidated knowledge stored as atomic facts , and extracted from different sources , such as free text , tables in webpages or collaborative input .
heading: Introduction

text: Existing approaches for QA from KBs use learnable components to either transform the question into a structured KB query or learn to embed questions and facts in a low dimensional vector space and retrieve the answer by computing similarities in this embedding space .
heading: Introduction

text: However , while most recent efforts have focused on designing systems with higher reasoning capabilities , that could jointly retrieve and use multiple facts to answer , the simpler problem of answering questions that refer to a single fact of the KB , which we call Simple Question Answering in this paper , is still far from solved .
heading: Introduction

text: Hence , existing benchmarks are small ; they mostly cover the head of the distributions of facts , and are restricted in their question types and their syntactic and lexical variations .
heading: Introduction

text: As such , it is still unknown how much the existing systems perform outside the range of the specific question templates of a few , small benchmark datasets , and it is also unknown whether learning on a single dataset transfers well on other ones , and whether such systems can learn from different training sources , which we believe is necessary to capture the whole range of possible questions .
heading: Introduction

text: Besides , the actual need for reasoning , i.e. constructing the answer from more than a single fact from the KB , depends on the actual structure of the KB .
heading: Introduction

text: As we shall see , for instance , a simple preprocessing of Freebase tremendously increases the coverage of simple QA in terms of possible questions that can be answered with a single fact , including list questions that expect more than a single answer .
heading: Introduction

text: In fact , the task of simple QA itself might already cover a wide range of practical usages , if the KB is properly organized .
heading: Introduction

text: This paper presents two contributions .
heading: Introduction

text: First , as an effort to study the coverage of existing systems and the possibility to train jointly on different data sources via multitasking , we collected the first large - scale dataset of questions and answers based on a KB , called SimpleQuestions .
heading: Introduction

text: This dataset , which is presented in Section 2 , contains more than 100 k questions written by human anno-What American cartoonist is the creator of Andy Lippincott ?
heading: Introduction

text: Which forest is Fires Creek in ?
heading: Introduction

text: What is an active ingredient in childrens earache relief ?
heading: Introduction

text: tators and associated to Freebase facts , while the largest existing benchmark , WebQuestions , contains less than 6 k questions created automatically using the Google suggest API .
heading: Introduction

text: Second , in sections 3 and 4 , we present an embedding - based QA system developed under the framework of Memory Networks ( Mem NNs ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Memory Networks are learning systems centered around a memory component that can be read and written to , with a particular focus on cases where the relationship between the input and response languages ( here natural language ) and the storage language ( here , the facts from KBs ) is performed by embedding all of them in the same vector space .
heading: Introduction

text: The setting of the simple QA corresponds to the elementary operation of performing a single lookup in the memory .
heading: Introduction

text: While our model bares similarity with previous embedding models for QA , using the framework of MemNNs opens the perspective to more involved inference schemes in future work , since MemNNs were shown to perform well on complex reasoning toy QA tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: We discuss related work in Section 5 .
heading: Introduction

text: We report experimental results in Section 6 , where we show that our model achieves excellent results on the benchmark WebQuestions .
heading: Introduction

text: We also show that it can learn from two different QA datasets to improve its performance on both .
heading: Introduction

text: We also present the first successful application of transfer learning for QA .
heading: Introduction

text: Using the Reverb KB and QA datasets , we show that Reverb facts can be added to the memory and used to answer without retraining , and that MemNNs achieve better results than some systems designed on this dataset .
heading: Introduction

text: Simple Question Answering
Knowledge Bases contain facts expressed as triples where subject and object are entities and relationship describes the type of ( directed ) link between these entities .
heading: Simple Question Answering

text: The simple QA prob - lem we address here consist in finding the answer to questions that can be rephrased as queries of the form , asking for all objects linked to subject by relationship .
heading: Simple Question Answering

text: The question
What do Jamaican people speak ? , for instance , could be rephrased as the Freebase query ( jamaica , language spoken , ? ) .
heading: The question

text: In other words , fetching a single fact from a KB is sufficient to answer correctly .
heading: The question

text: The term simple QA refers to the simplicity of the reasoning process needed to answer questions , since it involves a single fact .
heading: The question

text: However , this does not mean that the QA problem is easy per se , since retrieving this single supporting fact can be very challenging as it involves to search over millions of alternatives given a query expressed in natural language .
heading: The question

text: shows that , with a KB with many types of relationships like
heading: The question

text: Freebase , the range of questions that can be answered with a single fact is already very broad .
heading: The question

text: Besides , as we shall see , modiying slightly the structure of the KB can make some QA problems simpler by adding direct connections between entities and hence allow to bypass the need for more complex reasoning .
heading: The question

text: Knowledge Bases
We use the KB Freebase 1 as the basis of our QA system , our source of facts and answers .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: All Freebase entities and relationships are typed and the lexicon for types and relationships is closed .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: Freebase data is collaboratively collected and curated , to ensure a high reliability of the facts .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: Each entity has an internal identifier and a set of strings that are usually used to refer to that entity in text , termed aliases .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: We consider two extracts of Freebase , whose statistics are given in .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: FB2M , which was used in , contains about 2 M entities and 5 k relationships .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: FB5M , is much larger with about 5 M entities and more than 7.5 k relationships .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: We also use the KB Reverb as a secondary source of facts to study how well a model trained to answer questions using Freebase facts could be used to answer using Reverb 's as well , without being trained on Reverb data .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: This is a pure setting of transfer learning .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: Reverb is interesting for this experiment because it differs a lot from Freebase .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: Its data was extracted automatically from text with minimal human intervention and is highly unstructured : entities are unique strings and the lexicon for relationships is open .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: This leads to many more relationships , but entities with multiple references are not deduplicated , ambiguous referents are not resolved , and the reliability of the stored facts is much lower than in Freebase .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: We used the full extraction from , which contains 2 M entities and 600 k relationships .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: The SimpleQuestions dataset
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: Existing resources for QA such as WebQuestions are rather small ( few thousands questions ) and hence do not provide a very thorough coverage of the variety of questions that could be answered using a KB like Freebase , even in the context of simple QA .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: Hence , in this paper , we introduce anew dataset of much larger scale for the task of simple QA called SimpleQuestions .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: This dataset consists of a total of 108,442 questions written in natural language by human English - speaking annotators each paired with a corresponding fact from FB2M that provides the answer and explains it .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: We randomly shuffle these questions and use 70 % of them ( 75910 ) as training set , 10 % as validation set , and the remaining 20 % as test set .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: Examples of questions and facts are given in .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: We collected SimpleQuestions in two phases .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: The first phase consisted of shortlisting the set of facts from Freebase to be annotated with questions .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: We used FB2M as background KB and removed all facts with undefined relationship type i.e. containing the word freebase .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: We also removed all facts for which the ( subject , relationship ) pair had more than a threshold number of objects .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: This filtering step is crucial to remove facts
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: 2 The dataset is available from http://fb.ai/babi. which would result in trivial uninformative questions , such as , Name a person who is an actor ?.
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: The threshold was set to 10 .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: In the second phase , these selected facts were sampled and delivered to human annotators to generate questions from them .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: For the sampling , each fact was associated with a probability which defined as a function of its relationship frequency in the KB : to favor variability , facts with relationship appearing more frequently were given lower probabilities .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: For each sampled facts , annotators were shown the facts along with hyperlinks to freebase.com to provide some context while framing the question .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: Given this information , annotators were asked to phrase a question involving the subject and the relationship of the fact , with the answer being the object .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: The annotators were explicitly instructed to phrase the question differently as much as possible , if they encounter multiple facts with similar relationship .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: They were also given the option of skipping facts if they wish to do so .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: This was very important to avoid the annotators to write a boilerplate questions when they had no background knowledge about some facts .
heading: Knowledge Bases

text: Memory Networks for Simple QA
A Memory Network consists of a memory ( an indexed array of objects ) and a neural network that is trained to query it given some inputs ( usually questions ) .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: It has four components : Input map ( I ) , Generalization ( G ) , Output map ( O ) and Response ( R ) which we detail below .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: But first , we describe the MemNNs workflow used to setup a model for simple QA .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: This proceeds in three steps :
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: Storing Freebase : this first phase parses
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: Freebase ( either FB2M or FB5M depending on the setting ) and stores it in memory .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: It uses the Input module to preprocess the data .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: Training : this second phase trains the Mem NN to answer question .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: This uses Input , Output and Response modules , the training concerns mainly the parameters of the embedding model at the core of the Output module .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: Connecting Reverb : this third phase adds new facts coming from
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: Reverb to the memory .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: This is done after training to test the ability of MemNNs to handle new facts without having to be re-trained .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: It uses the Input module to preprocess Reverb facts and the Generalization module to connect them to the facts already stored .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: After these three stages , the MemNN is ready to answer any question by running the I , O and R modules in turn .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: We now detail the implementation of the four modules .
heading: Memory Networks for Simple QA

text: Input module
This module preprocesses the three types of data that are input to the network :
heading: Input module

text: Freebase facts that are used to populate the memory , questions that the system need to answer , and Reverb facts that we use , in a second phase , to extend the memory .
heading: Input module

text: Preprocessing Freebase
The Freebase data is initially stored as atomic facts involving single entities as subject and object , plus a relationship between them .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase

text: However , this storage needs to be adapted to the QA task in two aspects .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase

text: First , in order to answer list questions , which expect more than one answer , we redefine a fact as being a triple containing a subject , a relationship , and the set of all objects linked to the subject by the relationship .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase

text: This grouping process transforms atomic facts into grouped facts , which we simply refer to as facts in the following .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase

text: shows the impact of this grouping : on FB2M , this decreases the number of facts from 14 M to 11 M and , on FB5 M , from 22 M to 12M .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase

text: Second , the underlying structure of Freebase is a hypergraph , in which more than two entities can be linked .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase

text: For instance dates can be linked together with two entities to specify the time period over which the link was valid .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase

text: The underlying triple storage involves mediator nodes for each such fact , effectively making entities linked through paths of length 2 , instead of 1 .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase

text: To obtain direct links between entities in such cases , we created a single fact for these facts by removing the intermediate node and using the second relationship as the relationship for the new condensed fact .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase

text: This step reduces the need for searching the answer outside the immediate neighborhood of the subject referred to in the question , widely increasing the scope of the simple QA task on Freebase .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase

text: On WebQuestions , a benchmark not primarily designed for simple QA , removing mediator nodes allows to jump from around 65 % to 86 % of questions that can be answered with a single fact .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase

text: Preprocessing Freebase facts
A fact with k objects y = ( s , r , {o 1 , ... , o k } ) is represented by a bag - of - symbol vector f ( y ) in RN S , where NS is the number of entities and relationships .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase facts

text: Each dimension off ( y ) corresponds to a relationship or an entity ( independent of whether it appears as subject or object ) .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase facts

text: The entries of the subject and of the relationship have value 1 , and the entries of the objects are set to 1 / k .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase facts

text: All other entries are 0 .
heading: Preprocessing Freebase facts

text: Preprocessing questions
A question q is mapped to a bag - of - ngrams representation g ( q ) of dimension RN V where NV is the size of the vocabulary .
heading: Preprocessing questions

text: The vocabulary contains all individual words that appear in the questions of our datasets , together with the aliases of Freebase entities , each alias being a single n-gram .
heading: Preprocessing questions

text: The entries of g ( q ) that correspond to words and n-grams of q are equal to 1 , all other ones are set to 0 .
heading: Preprocessing questions

text: Preprocessing Reverb facts
In our experiments with Reverb , each fact y = ( s , r , o) is represented as a vector h ( y ) ?
heading: Preprocessing Reverb facts

text: RN S +N V .
heading: Preprocessing Reverb facts

text: This vector is a bagof - symbol for the subject sand the object o , and a bag - of - words for the relationship r.
heading: Preprocessing Reverb facts

text: The exact composition of h is provided by the Generalization module , which we describe now .
heading: Preprocessing Reverb facts

text: Generalization module
This module is responsible for adding new elements to the memory .
heading: Generalization module

text: In our case , the memory has a multigraph structure where each node is a Freebase entity and labeled arcs in the multigraph are Freebase relationships : after their preprocessing , all Freebase facts are stored using this structure .
heading: Generalization module
