text: We also consider the case where new facts , with a different structure ( i.e. new kinds of relationship ) , are provided to the MemNNs by using Reverb .
heading: Generalization module

text: In this case , the generalization module is then used to connect Reverb facts to the Freebase - based memory structure , in order to make them usable and searchable by the MemNN .
heading: Generalization module

text: To link the subject and the object of a Reverb fact to Freebase entities , we use precomputed entity links .
heading: Generalization module

text: If such links do not give any result for an entity , we search for Freebase entities with at least one alias that matches the Reverb entity string .
heading: Generalization module

text: These two processes allowed to match 17 % of Reverb entities to Freebase ones .
heading: Generalization module

text: The remainder of entities were encoded using bag - of - words representation of their strings , since we had no other way of matching them to Freebase entities .
heading: Generalization module

text: All Reverb relationships were encoded using bag - of - words of their strings .
heading: Generalization module

text: Using this approximate process , we are able to store each Reverb fact as a bag - of - symbols ( words or Freebase entities ) all already seen by the MemNN during its training phase based on Freebase .
heading: Generalization module

text: We can then hope that what had been learned there could also be successfully used to query Reverb facts .
heading: Generalization module

text: Output module
The output module performs the memory lookups given the input to return the supporting facts destined to eventually provide the answer given a question .
heading: Output module

text: In our case of simple QA , this module only returns a single supporting fact .
heading: Output module

text: To avoid scoring all the stored facts , we first perform an approximate entity linking step to generate a small set of candidate facts .
heading: Output module

text: The supporting fact is the candidate fact that is most similar to the question according to an embedding model .
heading: Output module

text: Candidate generation
To generate candidate facts , we match n-grams of words of the question to aliases of Freebase entities and select a few matching entities .
heading: Candidate generation

text: All facts having one of these entities as subject are scored in a second step .
heading: Candidate generation

text: We first generate all possible n-grams from the question , removing those that contain an interrogative pronoun or 1 - grams that belong to a list of stopwords .
heading: Candidate generation

text: We only keep the n-grams which are an alias of an entity , and then discard all n-grams that area subsequence of another n-gram , except if the longer n-gram only differs by in , of , for or the at the beginning .
heading: Candidate generation

text: We finally keep the two entities with the most links in Freebase retrieved for each of the five longest matched n-grams .
heading: Candidate generation

text: Scoring Scoring is performed using an embedding model .
heading: Candidate generation

text: Given two embedding matrices WV ?
heading: Candidate generation

text: R dN V and W S ?
heading: Candidate generation

text: R dN S , which respectively contain , in columns , the d-dimensional embeddings of the words / n - grams of the vocabulary and the embeddings of the Freebase entities and relationships , the similarity between question q and a Freebase candidate fact y is computed as :
heading: Candidate generation

text: with cos ( ) the cosine similarity .
heading: Candidate generation

text: When scoring a fact y from Reverb , we use the same embeddings and build the matrix WV S ? R d( N V +N S ) , which contains the concatenation in columns of WV and W S , and also compute the cosine similarity :
heading: Candidate generation

text: S RV B ( q , y ) = cos ( W V g ( q ) , WV S h ( y ) ) .
heading: Candidate generation

text: The dimension dis a hyperparameter , and the embedding matrices WV and W S are the parameters learned with the training algorithm of Section 4 .
heading: Candidate generation

text: Response module
In Memory Networks , the Response module postprocesses the result of the Output module to compute the intended answer .
heading: Response module

text: In our case , it returns the set of objects of the selected supporting fact .
heading: Response module

text: Training
This section details how we trained the scoring function of the Output module using a multitask training process on four different sources of data .
heading: Training

text: First , in addition to the new SimpleQuestions dataset described in Section 2 , we also used We-bQuestions , a benchmark for QA introduced in : questions are labeled with answer strings from aliases of Freebase entities , and many questions expect multiple answers .
heading: Training

text: Table 3 details the statistics of both datasets .
heading: Training

text: We also train on automatic questions generated from the KB , that is FB2M or FB5M depending on the setting , which are essential to learn embeddings for the entities not appearing in either WebQuestions or SimpleQuestions .
heading: Training

text: Statistics of FB2M or FB5M are given in ; we generated one training question per fact following the same process as that used in .
heading: Training

text: Following previous work such as , we also use the indirect supervision signal of pairs of question paraphrases .
heading: Training

text: We used a subset of the large set of paraphrases extracted from WIKIANSWERS and introduced in .
heading: Training

text: Our Paraphrases dataset is made of 15M clusters containing 2 or more paraphrases each .
heading: Training

text: Multitask training
As in previous work on embedding models and Memory Networks , the embeddings are trained with a ranking criterion .
heading: Multitask training

text: For QA datasets the goal is that in the embedding space , a supporting fact is more similar to the question than any other non-supporting fact .
heading: Multitask training

text: For the paraphrase dataset , a question should be more similar to one of its paraphrases than to any another question .
heading: Multitask training

text: The multitask learning of the embedding matrices WV and W S is performed by alternating stochastic gradient descent ( SGD ) steps over the loss function on the different datasets .
heading: Multitask training

text: For the QA datasets , given a question / supporting fact pair ( q , y) and a non-supporting fact y ? , we perform a step to minimize the loss function ? QA ( q , y , y ? ) = ? ? S QA ( q , y ) + S QA ( q , y ? ) + , where [. ] + is the positive part and ?
heading: Multitask training

text: is a margin hyperparameter .
heading: Multitask training

text: For the paraphrase dataset , the similarity score between two questions q and q ?
heading: Multitask training

text: is also the cosine between their embeddings , i.e. S QQ ( q , q ? ) = cos ( W V g ( q ) , WV g ( q ? ) ) , and given a paraphrase pair ( q , q ? ) and another question q ??
heading: Multitask training

text: , the loss is :
heading: Multitask training

text: The embeddings ( i.e. the columns of WV and W S ) are projected onto the L 2 unit ball after each update .
heading: Multitask training

text: At each time step , a sample from the paraphrase dataset is drawn with probability 0.2 ( this probability is arbitrary ) .
heading: Multitask training

text: Otherwise , a sample from one of the three QA datasets , chosen uniformly at random , is taken .
heading: Multitask training

text: We use the WARP loss
heading: Multitask training

text: Distant supervision
Unlike for SimpleQuestions or the synthetic QA data generated from Freebase , for WebQuestions only answer strings are provided for questions : the supporting facts are unknown .
heading: Distant supervision

text: In order to generate the supervision , we use the candidate fact generation algorithm of Section 3.3 .
heading: Distant supervision

text: For each candidate fact , the aliases of its objects are compared to the set of provided answer strings .
heading: Distant supervision

text: The fact ( s ) which can generate the maximum number of answer strings from their objects ' aliases are then kept .
heading: Distant supervision

text: If multiple facts are obtained for the same question , the ones with the minimal number of objects are considered as supervision facts .
heading: Distant supervision

text: This last selection avoids favoring irrelevant relationships that would be kept only because they point to many objects but would not be specific enough .
heading: Distant supervision

text: If no answer string could be found from the objects of the initial candidates , the question is discarded from the training set .
heading: Distant supervision

text: Future work should investigate the process of weak supervised training of MemNNs recently introduced in that allows to train them without any supervision coming from the supporting facts . :
heading: Distant supervision

text: Training and evaluation datasets .
heading: Distant supervision

text: Questions automatically generated from the KB and paraphrases can also be used in training .
heading: Distant supervision

text: WebQuestions SimpleQuestions
heading: Distant supervision

text: Reverb
Generating negative examples
heading: Reverb

text: As in , learning is performed with gradient descent , so that negative examples ( non - supporting facts or non-paraphrases ) are generated according to a randomized policy during training .
heading: Reverb

text: For paraphrases , given a pair ( q , q ? ) , a nonparaphrase pair is generated as ( q , q ?? )
heading: Reverb

text: where q ??
heading: Reverb

text: is a random question of the dataset , not belonging to the cluser of q .
heading: Reverb

text: For question / supporting fact pairs , we use two policies .
heading: Reverb

text: The default policy to obtain a non-supporting fact is to corrupt the answer fact by exchanging it s subject , its relationship or its object ( s ) with that of another fact chosen uniformly at random from the KB .
heading: Reverb

text: In this policy , the element of the fact to corrupt is chosen randomly , with a small probability ( 0.3 ) of corrupting more than one element of the answer fact .
heading: Reverb

text: The second policy we propose , called candidates as negatives , is to take as non-supporting fact a randomly chosen fact from the set of candidate facts .
heading: Reverb

text: While the first policy is standard in learning embeddings , the second one is more original , and , as we see in the experiments , gives slightly better performance .
heading: Reverb

text: Related Work

The first approaches to open - domain QA were search engine - based systems , where keywords extracted from the question are sent to a search engine , and the answer is extracted from the top results .
heading: Related Work

text: This method has been adapted to KB - based QA , and obtained competitive results with respect to semantic parsing and embedding - based approaches .
heading: Related Work

text: Semantic parsing approaches perform a functional parse of the sentence that can be interpreted as a KB query .
heading: Related Work

text: Even though these approaches are difficult to train at scale because of the complexity of their inference , their advantage is to provide a deep interpretation of the question .
heading: Related Work

text: Some of these approaches require little to no question - answer pairs , relying on simple rules to tranform the semantic interpretation to a KB query .
heading: Related Work

text: Like our work , embedding - based methods for QA can be seen as simple MemNNs .
heading: Related Work

text: The algorithms of use an approach similar to ours but are based on Reverb rather than Freebase , and relied purely on bag - of - word for both questions and facts .
heading: Related Work

text: The approach of ( Yang et al. , 2014 ) uses a different representation of questions , in which recognized entities are replaced by an entity token , and a different training data using entity mentions from WIKIPEDIA .
heading: Related Work

text: Our model is closest to the one presented in , which is discussed in more details in the experiments .
heading: Related Work

text: Experiments

This section provides an extensive evaluation of our MemNNs implementation against state - of the - art QA methods as well as an empirical study of the impact of using multiple training sources on the prediction performance .
heading: Experiments

text: details the dimensions of the test sets of WebQuestions , SimpleQuestions and Reverb which we used for evaluation .
heading: Experiments

text: Evaluation and baselines

On WebQuestions , we evaluate against previous results on this benchmark in terms of F1 - score as defined in , which is the average , overall test questions , of the F1 - score of the sets of predicted answers .
heading: Evaluation and baselines

text: Since no previous result was published on SimpleQuestions , we only compare different versions of MemNNs .
heading: Evaluation and baselines

text: SimpleQuestions questions are labeled with their entire Freebase fact , so we evaluate in terms of path - level accuracy , in which a prediction is correct if the subject and the relationship were correctly retrieved by the system .
heading: Evaluation and baselines

text: The Reverb test set , based on the KB of the same name and introduced in is used for evaluation only .
heading: Evaluation and baselines

text: It contains 691 questions .
heading: Evaluation and baselines

text: We consider the task of re-ranking a small set of candidate answers , which are Reverb facts and are labeled as corrector incorrect .
heading: Evaluation and baselines

text: We compare our approach to the original system , to and to the original MemNNs , in terms of accuracy , which is the percentage of questions for which the top - ranked candidate fact is correct .
heading: Evaluation and baselines

text: Experimental setup
All models were trained with at least the dataset made of synthetic questions created from the KB .
heading: Experimental setup

text: The hyperparameters were chosen to maximize the F1-score on WebQuestions validation set , independently of the testing dataset .
heading: Experimental setup

text: The embedding dimension and the learning rate were chosen among { 64 , 128 , 256 } and { 1 , 0.1 , ... , 1.0e ? 4 } respectively , and the margin ?
heading: Experimental setup

text: was set to 0.1 .
heading: Experimental setup

text: For each configuration of hyperparameters , the F1score on the validation set was computed regularly during learning to perform early stopping .
heading: Experimental setup

text: We tested additional configurations for our algorithm .
heading: Experimental setup

text: First , in the Candidates as Negatives setting ( negative facts are sampled from the candidate set , see Section 4 ) , abbreviated CANDS AS NEGS , the experimental protocol is the same as in the default setting but the embeddings are initialized with the best configuration of the default setup .
heading: Experimental setup

text: Second , our model shares some similarities with an approach studied in , in which the authors noticed important gains using a subgraph representation of answers .
heading: Experimental setup

text: For completeness , we also added such a subgraph representation of objects .
heading: Experimental setup

text: In that setting , called Subgraph , each object o of a fact is itself represented as a bag - of - entities that encodes the immediate neighborhood of o .
heading: Experimental setup

text: This Subgraph model is trained similarly as our main approach and only the results of a post -hoc ensemble combination of the two models ( where the scores are added ) are presented .
heading: Experimental setup

text: We also report the results obtained by an ensemble of the 5 best models on validation ( subgraph excepted ) ; this is denoted 5 models .
heading: Experimental setup

text: Results
Comparative results
The results of the comparative experiments are given in .
heading: Comparative results

text: On the main benchmark WebQuestions , our best results use all data sources , the bigger extract from Freebase and the CANDS AS NEGS setting .
heading: Comparative results

text: The two ensembles achieve excellent results , with F1 -
heading: Comparative results

text: WebQuestions SimpleQuestions
heading: Comparative results

text: Reverb F1-SCORE ( % ) ACCURACY ( % ) ACCURACY ( % ) BASELINES Random guess 1.9 4.9 35 31.3 n / a n / a n / a n / a 54 29.7 n / a 73 ) - using path 35.3 n/ a n / a ) - using path + subgraph 39.2 n / a n / a 39.9 n/ a n/ a 41.3 n/ a n / a of SimpleQuestions questions .
heading: Comparative results

text: This shows that MemNNs are effective at re-ranking the candidates , but also that simple QA is still not solved .
heading: Comparative results

text: Our approach bares similarity to ) - using path .
heading: Comparative results

text: They use FB2M , and so their result ( 35.3 % F1 - score on WebQuestions ) should be compared to our 36.2 % .
heading: Comparative results

text: The models are slightly different in that they replace the entity string with the subject entity in the question representation and that we use the cosine similarity instead of the dot product , which gave consistent improvements .
heading: Comparative results

text: Still , the major differences come from how we use Freebase .
heading: Comparative results

text: First , the removal of the mediator nodes allows us to restrict ourselves to single supporting facts , while they search in paths of length 2 with a heuristic to select the paths to follow ( otherwise , inference is too costly ) , which makes our inference simpler and more efficient .
heading: Comparative results

text: Second , using grouped facts , we integrate multiple answers during learning ( through the distant supervision ) , while they use a grouping heuristic attest time .
heading: Comparative results

text: Grouping facts also allows us to scale much better and to train on FB5M .
heading: Comparative results

text: On WebQuestions , not specifically designed as a simple QA dataset , 86 % of the questions can now be answered with a single supporting fact , and performance increases significantly ( from 36.2 % to 41.0 % F1-score ) .
heading: Comparative results

text: Using the bigger FB5M as KB does not change performance on SimpleQuestions because it was based on FB2M , but the results show that our model is robust to the addition of more entities than necessary .
heading: Comparative results

text: Transfer learning on Reverb
In this set of experiments , all Reverb facts are added to the memory , without any retraining , and we test our ability to rerank answers on the companion QA set .
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: Thus , ( last column ) presents the result of our model without training on Reverb against methods specifically developed on that dataset .
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: Our best results are 67 % accuracy ( and 68 % for the ensemble of 5 models ) , which are better than the 54 % of the original paper and close to the stateof - the - art 73 % of .
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: These results show that the Memory Network approach can integrate and use new entities and links .
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: presents the results on the three datasets when our model is trained with different data sources .
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: We first notice that models trained on a single QA dataset perform poorly on the other datasets ( e.g. 46.6 % accuracy on SimpleQuestions for the model trained on WebQuestions only ) , which shows that the performance on We-bQuestions does not necessarily guarantee high coverage for simple QA .
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: On the other hand , training on both datasets only improves performance ; in particular , the model is able to capture all question patterns of the two datasets ; there is no " negative interaction " .
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: Importance of data sources
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: The bottom half of
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: While paraphrases do not seem to help much on WebQuestions and SimpleQuestions , except when training only with synthetic questions , they have a dramatic impact on the performance on Reverb .
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: This is because WebQuestions and SimpleQuestions questions follow simple patterns and are well formed , while Reverb questions have more syntactic and lexical variability .
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: Thus , paraphrases are important to avoid overfitting on specific question patterns of the training sets .
heading: Transfer learning on Reverb

text: Conclusion
This paper presents an implementation of MemNNs for the task of large - scale simple QA .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our results demonstrate that , if properly trained , MemNNs are able to handle natural language and a very large memory ( millions of entries ) , and hence can reach state - of - the - art on the popular benchmark WebQuestions .
heading: Conclusion

text: We want to emphasize that many of our findings , especially those regarding how to format the KB , do not only concern MemNNs but potentially any QA system .
heading: Conclusion

text: This paper also introduced the new dataset SimpleQuestions , which , with 100 k examples , is one order of magnitude bigger than WebQuestions : we hope that it will foster interesting new research in QA , simple or not .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Sentence Similarity Learning by Lexical Decomposition and Composition
abstract

Most conventional sentence similarity methods only focus on similar parts of two input sentences , and simply ignore the dissimilar parts , which usually give us some clues and semantic meanings about the sentences .
heading: abstract

text: In this work , we propose a model to take into account both the similarities and dissimilarities by decomposing and composing lexical semantics over sentences .
heading: abstract

text: The model represents each word as a vector , and calculates a semantic matching vector for each word based on all words in the other sentence .
heading: abstract

text: Then , each word vector is decomposed into a similar component and a dissimilar component based on the semantic matching vector .
heading: abstract

text: After this , a two - channel CNN model is employed to capture features by composing the similar and dissimilar components .
heading: abstract

text: Finally , a similarity score is estimated over the composed feature vectors .
heading: abstract

text: Experimental results show that our model gets the state - of - the - art performance on the answer sentence selection task , and achieves a comparable result on the paraphrase identification task .
heading: abstract

text: Sentence similarity is a fundamental metric to measure the degree of likelihood between a pair of sentences .
heading: abstract

text: It plays an important role fora variety of tasks in both NLP and IR communities .
heading: abstract

text: For example , in paraphrase identification task , sentence similarity is used to determine whether two sentences are paraphrases or not ( Yin and Schtze , 2015 ; He et al. , 2015 ) .
heading: abstract

text: For question answering and information retrieval tasks , sentence similarities between query - answer pairs are used for assessing the relevance and ranking all the candidate answers ( Severyn and Moschitti , 2015 ; Wang and Ittycheriah , 2015 ) .
heading: abstract

text: However , sentence similarity learning has following challenges :
heading: abstract

text: There is a lexical gap between semantically equivalent sentences .
heading: abstract

text: Take the E 1 and E 2 in Table 1 for example , they have the similar meaning but with different lexicons .
heading: abstract

text: 2 . Semantic similarity should be measured at different levels of granularity ( word - level , phrase - level and syntax - level ) .
heading: abstract

text: E.g. , " not related " in E 2 is an indivisible phrase when matching with " irrelevant " in E 1 ( shown in square brackets ) .
heading: abstract

text: The dissimilarity ( shown in angle brackets ) between two sentences is also a significant clue ( Qiu et al. , 2006 ) .
heading: abstract

text: For example , by judging the dissimilar parts , we can easily identify that E 3 and E 5 share the similar meaning " The study is about salmon " , because " sockeye " belongs to the salmon family , and " flounder " does not .
heading: abstract

text: Whereas the meaning of E 4 is quite different from E 3 , which emphasizes " The study is about red ( a special kind of ) salmon " , because both " sockeye " and " coho " are in the salmon family .
heading: abstract

text: How we can extract and utilize those information becomes another challenge .
heading: abstract

text: In order to handle the above challenges , researchers have been working on sentence similarity algorithms fora longtime .
heading: abstract

text: To bridge the lexical gap ( challenge 1 ) , some word similarity metrics were proposed to match different but semantically related words .
heading: abstract

text: Examples include knowledge - based metrics ( Resnik , 1995 ) and corpus - based metrics ( Jiang and Conrath , 1997 ; Yin and Schtze , 2015 ; He et al. , 2015 ) .
heading: abstract

text: To measure sentence similarity from various granularities ( challenge 2 ) , researchers have explored features extracted from n-grams , continuous phrases , discontinuous phrases , and parse trees ( Yin and Schtze , 2015 ; He et al. , 2015 ; Heilman and Smith , 2010 ) .
heading: abstract

text: The third challenge did not get much
heading: abstract

text: narrative
heading: abstract

text: E1
The research is to sockeye .
heading: E1

text: E2
The study is [ not related ] to salmon .
heading: E2

text: E3
The research is relevant to salmon .
heading: E3

text: E4
The study is relevant to sockeye , instead of coho .
heading: E4

text: E5
The study is relevant to sockeye , rather than flounder .:
heading: E5

text: Examples for sentence similarity learning , where sockeye means " red salmon " , and coho means " silver salmon " .
heading: E5

text: " coho " and " sockeye " are in the salmon family , while " flounder " is not .
heading: E5

text: attention in the past , the only related work of explored the dissimilarity between sentences in a pair for paraphrase identification task , but they require human annotations in order to train a classifier , and their performance is still below the state of the art .
heading: E5

text: In this paper , we propose a novel model to tackle all these challenges jointly by decomposing and composing lexical semantics over sentences .
heading: E5

text: Given a sentence pair , the model represents each word as a low -dimensional vector ( challenge 1 ) , and calculates a semantic matching vector for each word based on all words in the other sentence ( challenge 2 ) .
heading: E5

text: Then based on the semantic matching vector , each word vector is decomposed into two components : a similar component and a dissimilar component ( challenge 3 ) .
heading: E5

text: We use similar components of all the words to represent the similar parts of the sentence pair , and dissimilar components of every word to model the dissimilar parts explicitly .
heading: E5

text: After this , a two - channel CNN operation is performed to compose the similar and dissimilar components into a feature vector ( challenge 2 and 3 ) .
heading: E5

text: Finally , the composed feature vector is utilized to predict the sentence similarity .
heading: E5

text: Experimental results on two tasks show that our model gets the state - of - the - art performance on the answer sentence selection task , and achieves a comparable result on the paraphrase identification task .
heading: E5

text: In following parts , we start with a brief overview of our model ( Section 2 ) , followed by the details of our end - to - end implementation ( Section 3 ) .
heading: E5

text: Then we evaluate our model on answer sentence selection and paraphrase identifications tasks ( Section 4 ) .
heading: E5

text: Model Overview
In this section , we propose a sentence similarity learning model to tackle all three challenges ( mentioned in Section 1 ) .
heading: Model Overview

text: To deal with the first challenge , we represent each word as a distributed vector , so that we can calculate similarities for formally different but semantically related words .
heading: Model Overview

text: To tackle the second challenge , we assume that each word can be semantically matched by several words in the other sentence , and we calculate a semantic matching vector for each word vector based on all the word vectors in the other side .
heading: Model Overview

text: To cope with the third challenge , we assume that each semantic unit ( word ) can be partially matched , and can be decomposed into a similar component and a dissimilar component based on its semantic matching vector .
heading: Model Overview

text: shows an overview of our sentence similarity model .
heading: Model Overview

text: Given a pair of sentences Sand T , our task is to calculate a similarity score sim ( S , T ) in following steps :
heading: Model Overview

text: Word Representation .

Word embedding of is an effective way to handle the lexical gap challenge in the sentence similarity task , as it represents each word with a distributed vector , and words appearing in similar contexts tend to have similar meanings .
heading: Word Representation .

text: With those pre-trained embeddings , we transform Sand T into sentence matrixes S = [ s 1 , ... , s i , ... , s m ] and T = [t 1 , ... , t j , ... , tn ] , where s i and t j are d-dimension vectors of the corresponding words , and m and n are sentence length of Sand T respectively .
heading: Word Representation .

text: Semantic Matching .
In order to judge the similarity between two sentences , we need to check whether each semantic unit in one sentence is covered by the other sentence , or vice versa .
heading: Semantic Matching .

text: For example , in , to check whether E 2 is a paraphrase of E 1 , we need to know the single word " irrelevant " in E 1 is matched or covered by the phrase " not related " in E 2 .
heading: Semantic Matching .

text: In our model , we treat each word as a primitive semantic unit , and calculate a semantic matching vector ?
heading: Semantic Matching .

text: i for each word s i by composing part or full word vectors in the other sentence T .
heading: Semantic Matching .

text: In this way , we can match a word s i to a word or phrase in T . Similarly , for the reverse direction , we also calculate all semantic matching vectorst j in T .
heading: Semantic Matching .

text: We explore different f match functions later in Section 3 .
heading: Semantic Matching .

text: Decomposition .
After the semantic matching phase , we have the semantic matching vectors of ?
heading: Decomposition .

text: i and t j .
heading: Decomposition .

text: We interpret ?
heading: Decomposition .

text: i ( ort j ) as a semantic coverage of word s i ( or t j ) by the sentence T ( or S ) .
heading: Decomposition .

text: However , it is not necessary that all the semantics of s i ( or t j ) are fully covered by ?
heading: Decomposition .

text: i ( ort j ) .
heading: Decomposition .

text: Take the E 1 and E 2 in for example , the word " sockeye " in E 1 is only partially matched by the word " salmon " ( the similar part ) in E 2 , as the full meaning of " sockeye " is " red salmon " ( the semantic meaning of " red " is the dissimilar part ) .
heading: Decomposition .

text: Motivated by this phenomenon , our model further decomposes word s i ( or t j ) , based on its semantic matching vector ?
heading: Decomposition .

text: i ( ort j ) , into two components : similar component s + i ( or t + j ) and dissimilar component s ? i ( or t ? j ) .
heading: Decomposition .

text: Formally , we define the decomposition function as :
heading: Decomposition .

text: , our goal in this step is how to utilize those information .
heading: Decomposition .

text: Besides the suggestion from that the significance of the dissimilar parts alone between two sentences has a great effect of their similarity , we also think that the dissimilar and similar components have strong connections .
heading: Decomposition .

text: For example , in , if we only look at the dissimilar or similar part alone , it is hard to judge which one between E 4 and E 5 is more similar to E 3 .
heading: Decomposition .

text: We can easily identify that E 5 is more similar to E 3 , when we consider both the similar and dissimilar parts .
heading: Decomposition .

text: Therefore , our model composes the similar component matrix and dissimilar component matrix into a feature vector S ( or T ) with the composition function :
heading: Decomposition .

text: Similarity assessing .
heading: Decomposition .

text: In the final stage , we concatenate the two feature vectors ( Sand T ) and predict the final similarity score :
heading: Decomposition .

text: 3 An End - to - End Implementation Section 2 gives us a glance of our model .
heading: Decomposition .

text: In this section , we describe details of each phase .
heading: Decomposition .

text: Composition Functions
The aim of composition function f comp in Eq. is to extract features from both the similar component matrix and the dissimilar component matrix .
heading: Composition Functions

text: We also want to acquire similarities and dissimilarities of various granularity during the composition phase .
heading: Composition Functions

text: Inspired from Kim , we utilize a two - channel convolutional neural networks ( CNN ) and design filters based on various order of n-grams , e.g. , unigram , bigram and trigram .
heading: Composition Functions

text: The CNN model involves two sequential operations : convolution and max - pooling .
heading: Composition Functions

text: For the convolution operation , we define a list of filters {w o }.
heading: Composition Functions

text: The shape of each filter is d h , where dis the dimension of word vectors and h is the window size .
heading: Composition Functions

text: Each filter is applied to two patches ( a window size h of vectors ) from both similar and dissimilar channels , and generates a feature .
heading: Composition Functions

text: Eq. ( 10 ) expresses this process .
heading: Composition Functions

text: To deal with variable feature size , we perform a max - pooling operation over co by selecting the maximum value co = max co .
heading: Composition Functions

text: Therefore , after these two operations , each filter generates only one feature .
heading: Composition Functions

text: We define several filters by varying the window size and the initial values .
heading: Composition Functions

text: Eventually , a vector of features is captured by composing the two component matrixes , and the feature dimension is equal to the number of filters .

text: Similarity Assessment Function
The similarity assessment function f sim in Eq. ( 4 ) predicts a similarity score by taking two feature vectors as input .
heading: Similarity Assessment Function

text: We employ a linear function to sum up all the features and apply a sigmoid function to constrain the similarity within the range [ 0 , 1 ] .
heading: Similarity Assessment Function

text: Training
We train our sentence similariy model by maximizing the likelihood on a training set .
heading: Training

text: Each training instance in the training set is represented as a triple ( S i , Ti , Li ) , where Si and Ti area pair of sentences , and Li ? { 0 , 1 } indicates the similarity between them .
heading: Training

text: We assign Li = 1 if Ti is a paraphrase of Si for the paraphrase identification task , or Ti is a correct answer for Si for the answer sentence selection task .
heading: Training

text: Otherwise , we assign Li = 0 .
heading: Training

text: We implement the mathematical expressions with Theano and use Adam for optimization .
heading: Training

text: Experiment
Experimental Setting
We evaluate our model on two tasks : answer sentence selection and paraphrase identification .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: The answer sentence selection task is to rank a list of candidate answers based on their similarities to a question sentence , and the performance is measured by mean average precision ( MAP ) and mean reciprocal rank ( MRR ) .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: We experiment on two datasets : QASent and Wiki QA .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: The statistics of the two datasets can be found in , where QASent was created from the TREC QA track , and WikiQA ( Yang et al. , 2015 ) is constructed from real queries of Bing and Wikipedia .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: The paraphrase identification task is to detect whether two sentences are paraphrases based on the similarity between them .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: The metrics include the accuracy and the positive class F 1 score .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: We experiment on the Microsoft Research Paraphrase corpus ( MSRP ) , which includes 2753 true and 1323 false instances in the training set , and 1147 true and 578 false instances in the test set .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: We build a development set by randomly selecting 100 true and 100 false instances from the training set .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: In all experiments , we set the size of word vector dimension as d = 300 , and pre-train the vectors with the word2 vec toolkit on the English Gigaword ( LDC2011T07 ) .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: Model Properties
There are several alternative options in our model , e.g. , the semantic matching functions , the decomposition operations , and the filter types .
heading: Model Properties

text: The choice of these options may affect the final performance .
heading: Model Properties

text: In this subsection , we present some experiments to demonstrate the properties of our model , and find a good configuration that we use to evaluate our final model .
heading: Model Properties

text: All the experiments in this subsection were performed on the QASent dataset and evaluated on the development set .
heading: Model Properties

text: First , we evaluated the effectiveness of various semantic matching functions .
heading: Model Properties

text: We switched the semantic matching functions among { max , global , local - l} , where l ? { 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 } , and fixed the other options as : the linear decomposition , the filter types including {unigram , bigram , trigram } , and 500 filters for each type .
heading: Model Properties

text: presents the results .
heading: Model Properties

text: We found that the max function worked better than the global function on both MAP and MRR .
heading: Model Properties

text: By increasing the window size , the local -l function acquired progressive improvements when the window size is smaller than 4 .
heading: Model Properties

text: But after we enlarged the window size to 4 , the performance dropped .
heading: Model Properties

text: The local - 3 function worked better than the max function in term of the MAP , and also got a comparable MRR .
heading: Model Properties

text: Therefore , we use the local - 3 function in the following experiments .
heading: Model Properties

text: Second , we studied the effect of various decomposition operations .
heading: Model Properties

text: We varied the decomposition operation among { rigid , linear , orthogonal } , and kept the other options unchanged .
heading: Model Properties

text: shows the performance .
heading: Model Properties

text: We found that the rigid operation got the worst result .
heading: Model Properties

text: This is reasonable , because the rigid operation decomposes word vectors by exactly matching words .
heading: Model Properties

text: The orthogonal operation got a similar MAP as the linear operation , and it worked better in term of MRR .
heading: Model Properties

text: Therefore , we choose the orthogonal operation in the following experiments .
heading: Model Properties

text: Third , we tested the influence of various filter types .
heading: Model Properties

text: We constructed 5 groups of filters : win - 1 contains only the unigram filters , win - 2 contains both unigram and bigram filters , win - 3 contains all the filters in win - 2 plus trigram filters , win - 4 extends filters in win - 3 with 4 - gram filters , and win - 5 adds 5 - gram filters into win - 4 .
heading: Model Properties

text: We generate 500 filters for each filter type ( with different initial values ) .
heading: Model Properties

text: Experimental results are shown in .
heading: Model Properties

text: At the beginning , adding higher - order ngram filters was helpful for the performance .
heading: Model Properties

text: The performance reached to the peak , when we used the win - 3 filters .
heading: Model Properties

text: After that , adding more complex filters decreased the performance .
heading: Model Properties

text: Therefore , the trigram is the best granularity for our model .
heading: Model Properties

text: In the following experiments , we utilize filter types in win - 3 .
heading: Model Properties

text: Comparing with State - of - the - art Models
heading: Model Properties

text: In this subsection , we evaluated our model on the test sets of QASent , WikiQA and MSRP .
heading: Model Properties

text: QASent dataset .
heading: Model Properties

text: presents the performances of the state - of - the - art systems and our model , where the performances were evaluated with the standard trec eval - 8.1 script
heading: Model Properties

text: Given a pair of sentences , Severyn and Moschitti ( 2015 ) employed a CNN model to compose each sentence into a vector separately , and joined the two sentence vectors to compute the sentence similarity .

text: Related Work
The semantic matching functions in subsection 3.1 are inspired from the attention - based neural machine translation .
heading: Related Work

text: However , most of the previous work using the attention mechanism in only LSTM models .
heading: Related Work

text: Whereas our model introduces the attention mechanism into the CNN model .
heading: Related Work

text: A similar work is the attention - based CNN model proposed by .
heading: Related Work

text: They first build an attention matrix fora sentence pair , and then directly take the attention matrix as anew channel of the CNN model .
heading: Related Work

text: Differently , our model uses the attention matrix ( or similarity matrix ) to decompose the original sentence matrix into a similar component matrix and a dissimilar component matrix , and then feeds these two matrixes into a two - channel CNN model .
heading: Related Work

text: The model can then focus much on the interactions between similar and dissimilar parts of a sentence pair .
heading: Related Work

text: Conclusion
In this work , we proposed a model to assess sentence similarity by decomposing and composing lexical semantics .
heading: Conclusion

text: To bridge the lexical gap problem , our model represents each word with its context vector .
heading: Conclusion

text: To extract features from both the similarity and dissimilarity of a sentence pair , we designed several methods to decompose the word vector into a similar component and a dissimilar component .
heading: Conclusion

text: To extract features at multiple levels of granularity , we employed a two - channel CNN model and equipped it with multiple types of ngram filters .
heading: Conclusion

text: Experimental results show that our model is quite effective on both the answer sentence selection task and the paraphrase identification task .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
A Parallel - Hierarchical Model for Machine Comprehension on Sparse Data
heading: title

text: abstract
Understanding unstructured text is a major goal within natural language processing .
heading: abstract

text: Comprehension tests pose questions based on short text passages to evaluate such understanding .
heading: abstract

text: In this work , we investigate machine comprehension on the challenging MCTest benchmark .
heading: abstract

text: Partly because of its limited size , prior work on MCTest has focused mainly on engineering better features .
heading: abstract

text: We tackle the dataset with a neural approach , harnessing simple neural networks arranged in a parallel hierarchy .
heading: abstract

text: The parallel hierarchy enables our model to compare the passage , question , and answer from a variety of trainable perspectives , as opposed to using a manually designed , rigid feature set .
heading: abstract

text: Perspectives range from the word level to sentence fragments to sequences of sentences ; the networks operate only on word - embedding representations of text .
heading: abstract

text: When trained with a methodology designed to help cope with limited training data , our Parallel - Hierarchical model sets anew state of the art for MCTest , outperforming previous feature - engineered approaches slightly and previous neural approaches by a significant margin ( over 15 % absolute ) .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Humans learn in a variety of ways - by communication with each other , and by study , the reading of text .
heading: Introduction

text: Comprehension of unstructured text by machines , at a near- human level , is a major goal for natural language processing .
heading: Introduction

text: It has garnered significant attention from the machine learning research community in recent years .
heading: Introduction

text: Machine comprehension ( MC ) is evaluated by posing a set of questions based on a text passage ( akin to the reading tests we all took in school ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Such tests are objectively gradable and can be used to assess a range of abilities , from basic understanding to causal reasoning to inference .
heading: Introduction

text: Given a text passage and a question about its content , a system is tested on its ability to determine the correct answer .
heading: Introduction

text: In this work , we focus on MCTest , a complex but data - limited comprehension benchmark , whose multiple - choice questions require not only extraction but also inference and limited reasoning .
heading: Introduction

text: Inference and reasoning are important human skills that apply broadly , beyond language .
heading: Introduction

text: We present a parallel - hierarchical approach to machine comprehension designed to work well in a data - limited setting .
heading: Introduction

text: There are many use-cases in which comprehension over limited data would be handy : for example , user manuals , internal documentation , legal contracts , and soon .
heading: Introduction

text: Moreover , work towards more efficient learning from any quantity of data is important in its own right , for bringing machines more inline with the way humans learn .
heading: Introduction

text: Typically , artificial neural networks require numerous parameters to capture complex patterns , and the more parameters , the more training data is required to tune them .
heading: Introduction

text: Likewise , deep models learn to extract their own features , but this is a data - intensive process .
heading: Introduction

text: Our model learns to comprehend at a high level even when data is sparse .
heading: Introduction

text: The key to our model is that it compares the question and answer candidates to the text using several distinct perspectives .
heading: Introduction

text: We refer to a question combined with one of its answer candidates as a hypothesis ( to be detailed below ) .
heading: Introduction

text: The semantic perspective compares the hypothesis to sentences in the text viewed as single , self - contained thoughts ; these are represented using a sum and transformation of word embedding vectors , similarly to in .
heading: Introduction

text: The word - by - word perspective focuses on similarity matches between individual words from hypothesis and text , at various scales .
heading: Introduction

text: As in the semantic perspective , we consider matches over complete sentences .
heading: Introduction

text: We also use a sliding window acting on a subsentential scale ( inspired by the work of ) , which implicitly considers the linear distance between matched words .
heading: Introduction

text: Finally , this word - level sliding window operates on two different views of text sentences : the sequential view , where words appear in their natural order , and the dependency view , where words are reordered based on a linearization of the sentence 's dependency graph .
heading: Introduction

text: Words are represented throughout by embedding vectors .
heading: Introduction

text: These distinct perspectives naturally form a hierarchy that we depict in .
heading: Introduction

text: Language is hierarchical , so it makes sense that comprehension relies on hierarchical levels of understanding .
heading: Introduction

text: The perspectives of our model can be considered a type of feature .
heading: Introduction

text: However , they are implemented by parametric differentiable functions .
heading: Introduction

text: This is in contrast to most previous efforts on MCTest , whose numerous hand - engineered features can not be trained .
heading: Introduction

text: Our model , significantly , can be trained end - to - end with backpropagation .
heading: Introduction

text: To facilitate learning with limited data , we also develop a unique training scheme .
heading: Introduction

text: We initialize the model 's neural networks to perform specific heuristic functions that yield decent ( thought not impressive ) performance on the dataset .
heading: Introduction

text: Thus , the training scheme gives the model a safe , reasonable baseline from which to start learning .
heading: Introduction

text: We call this technique training wheels .
heading: Introduction

text: Computational models that comprehend ( insofar as they perform well on MC datasets ) have developed contemporaneously in several research groups .
heading: Introduction

text: Models designed specifically for MCTest include those of , and more recently , , and .
heading: Introduction

text: In experiments , our Parallel - Hierarchical model achieves state - of - the - art accuracy on MCTest , outperforming these existing methods .
heading: Introduction

text: Below we describe related work , the mathematical details of our model , and our experiments , then analyze our results .
heading: Introduction

text: The Problem
In this section we borrow from , who laid out the MC problem nicely .
heading: The Problem

text: Machine comprehension requires machines to answer questions based on unstructured text .
heading: The Problem

text: This can be viewed as selecting the best answer from a set of candidates .
heading: The Problem

text: In the multiple - choice case , candidate answers are predefined , but candidate answers may also be undefined yet restricted ( e.g. , to yes , no , or any noun phrase in the text ) .
heading: The Problem

text: For each question q , let T be the unstructured text and A = {a i } the set of candidate answers to q .
heading: The Problem

text: The machine comprehension task reduces to selecting the answer that has the highest evidence given T .
heading: The Problem

text: As in , we combine an answer and a question into a hypothesis , hi = f ( q , a i ) .
heading: The Problem

text: To facilitate comparisons of the text with the hypotheses , we also breakdown the passage into sentences t j , T = {t j }.
heading: The Problem

text: In our setting , q , a i , and t j each represent a sequence of embedding vectors , one for each word and punctuation mark in the respective item .
heading: The Problem

text: Related Work
Machine comprehension is currently a hot topic within the machine learning community .
heading: Related Work

text: In this section we will focus on the best - performing models applied specifically to MCTest , since it is somewhat unique among MC datasets ( see Section 5 ) .
heading: Related Work

text: Generally , models can be divided into two categories : those that use fixed , engineered features , and neural models .
heading: Related Work

text: The bulk of the work on MCTest falls into the former category .
heading: Related Work

text: Manually engineered features often require significant effort on the part of a designer , and / or various auxiliary tools to extract them , and they can not be modified by training .
heading: Related Work

text: On the other hand , neural models can be trained end - to - end and typically harness only a single feature : vectorrepresentations of words .
heading: Related Work

text: Word embeddings are fed into a complex and possibly deep neural network which processes and compares text to question and answer .
heading: Related Work

text: Among deep models , mechanisms of attention and working memory are common , as in and .
heading: Related Work

text: 3.1 Feature - engineering models treated MCTest as a structured prediction problem , searching fora latent answerentailing structure connecting question , answer , and text .
heading: Related Work

text: This structure corresponds to the best latent alignment of a hypothesis with appropriate snippets of the text .
heading: Related Work

text: The process of ( latently ) selecting text snippets is related to the attention mechanisms typically used in deep networks designed for MC and machine translation .
heading: Related Work

text: The model uses event and entity coreference links across sentences along with a host of other features .
heading: Related Work

text: These include specifically trained word vectors for synonymy ; antonymy and class - inclusion relations from external database sources ; dependencies and semantic role labels .
heading: Related Work

text: The model is trained using a latent structural SVM extended to a multitask setting , so that questions are first classified using a pretrained top - level classifier .
heading: Related Work

text: This enables the system to use different processing strategies for different question categories .
heading: Related Work

text: The model also combines question and answer into a well - formed statement using the rules of Cucerzan and Agichtein ( 2005 ) .
heading: Related Work

text: Our model is simpler than that of in terms of the features it takes in , the training procedure ( stochastic gradient descent vs. alternating minimization ) , question classification ( we use none ) , and question - answer combination ( simple concatenation or mean vs. a set of rules ) .
heading: Related Work

text: augmented the baseline feature set from with features for syntax , frame semantics , coreference chains , and word embeddings .
heading: Related Work

text: They combined features using a linear latent - variable classifier trained to minimize a max - margin loss function .
heading: Related Work

text: As in , questions and answers are combined using a set of manually written rules .
heading: Related Work

text: The method of achieved the previous state of the art , but has significant complexity in terms of the feature set .
heading: Related Work

text: Space does not permit a full description of all models in this category , but see also and .
heading: Related Work

text: Despite its relative lack of features , the Parallel - Hierarchical model improves upon the featureengineered state of the art for MCTest by a small amount ( about 1 % absolute ) as detailed in Section 5 .
heading: Related Work

text: Neural models
Neural models have , to date , performed relatively poorly on MCTest .
heading: Neural models

text: This is because the dataset is sparse and complex .
heading: Neural models

text: investigated deep - learning approaches concurrently with the present work .
heading: Neural models

text: They measured the performance of the Attentive Reader and the Neural Reasoner , both deep , end - to - end recurrent models with attention mechanisms , and also developed an attention - based convolutional network , the HABCNN .
heading: Neural models

text: Their network operates on a hierarchy similar to our own , providing further evidence of the promise of hierarchical perspectives .
heading: Neural models

text: Specifically , the HABCNN processes text at the sentence level and the snippet level , where the latter combines adjacent sentences ( as we do through an n-gram input ) .
heading: Neural models

text: Embedding vectors for the question and the answer candidates are combined and encoded by a convolutional network .
heading: Neural models

text: This encoding modulates attention over sentence and snippet encodings , followed by maxpooling to determine the best matches between question , answer , and text .
heading: Neural models

text: As in the present work , matching scores are given by cosine similarity .
heading: Neural models

text: The HABCNN also makes use of a question classifier .
heading: Neural models

text: Despite the shared concepts between the HABCNN and our approach , the Parallel - Hierarchical model performs significantly better on MCTest ( more than 15 % absolute ) as detailed in Section 5 .
heading: Neural models

text: Other neural models tested in fare even worse .
heading: Neural models

text: The Parallel - Hierarchical Model
Let us now define our machine comprehension model in full .
heading: The Parallel - Hierarchical Model

text: We first describe each of the perspectives separately , then describe how they are combined .
heading: The Parallel - Hierarchical Model

text: Below , we use subscripts to index elements of sequences , like word vectors , and superscripts to indicate whether elements come from the text , question , or answer .
heading: The Parallel - Hierarchical Model

text: In particular , we use the subscripts k , m , n , p to index sequences from the text , question , answer , and hypothesis , respectively , and superscripts t , q , a , h. We depict the model schematically in .
heading: The Parallel - Hierarchical Model

text: Semantic Perspective
The semantic perspective is similar to the Memory Networks approach for embedding inputs into memory space .
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: Each sen - tence of the text is a sequence of d-dimensional word vectors :
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: The semantic vector st is computed by embedding the word vectors into a D-dimensional space using a two - layer network that implements weighted sum followed by an affine tranformation and a nonlinearity ; i.e. ,
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: The matrix At ? R Dd , the bias vector b t A ? RD , and for f we use the leaky ReLU function .
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: The scalar ?
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: k is a trainable weight associated to each word in the vocabulary .
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: These scalar weights implement a kind of exogenous or bottomup attention that depends only on the input stimulus .
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: They can , for example , learn to perform the function of stopword lists in a soft , trainable way , to nullify the contribution of unimportant filler words .
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: The semantic representation of a hypothesis is formed analogously , except that we combine the question word vectors q m and answer word vectors an as a single sequence {h p } = {q m , an }.
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: For semantic vector sh of the hypothesis , we use a unique transformation matrix A h ?
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: R Dd and bias vector b h A ?
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: RD .
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: These transformations map a text sentence and a hypothesis into a common space where they can be compared .
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: We compute the semantic match be-tween text sentence and hypothesis using the cosine similarity , M sem = cos ( s t , sh ) .
heading: Semantic Perspective

text: Word - by - Word Perspective
The first step in building the word - by - word perspective is to transform word vectors from a text sentence , question , and answer through respective neural functions .
heading: Word - by - Word Perspective

text: For the text ,
heading: Word - by - Word Perspective

text: RD and f is again the leaky ReLU .
heading: Word - by - Word Perspective

text: We transform the question and the answer toq m and n analogously using distinct matrices and bias vectors .
heading: Word - by - Word Perspective

text: In contrast with the semantic perspective , we keep the question and answer candidates separate in the wordby - word perspective .
heading: Word - by - Word Perspective

text: This is because matches to answer words are inherently more important than matches to question words , and we want our model to learn to use this property .
heading: Word - by - Word Perspective

text: Sentential
Inspired by the work of in paraphrase detection , we compute matches between hypotheses and text sentences at the word level .
heading: Sentential

text: This computation uses the cosine similarity as before :
heading: Sentential

text: ca kn = cos (t k , n ) .
heading: Sentential

text: The word - by - word match between a text sentence and question is determined by taking the maximum over k ( finding the text word that best matches each question word ) and then taking a weighted mean over m ( finding the average match over the full question ) :
heading: Sentential

text: Here , ?
heading: Sentential

text: m is the word weight for the question word and Z normalizes these weights to sum to one over the question .
heading: Sentential

text: We define the match between a sentence and answer candidate , M a , analogously .
heading: Sentential

text: Finally , we combine the matches to question and answer according to
heading: Sentential

text: Here the ?
heading: Sentential

text: are trainable parameters that control the relative importance of the terms .
heading: Sentential

text: Sequential Sliding Window
The sequential sliding window is related to the original MCTest baseline by .
heading: Sequential Sliding Window

text: Our sliding window decays from its focus word according to a Gaussian distribution , which we extend by assigning a trainable weight to each location in the window .
heading: Sequential Sliding Window

text: This modification enables the window to use information about the distance between word matches ; the original baseline used distance information through a predefined function .
heading: Sequential Sliding Window

text: The sliding window scans over the words of the text as one continuous sequence , without sentence breaks .
heading: Sequential Sliding Window

text: Each window is treated like a sentence in the previous subsection , but we include a location - based weight ?( k ) .
heading: Sequential Sliding Window

text: This weight is based on a word 's position in the window , which , given a window , depends on its global position k.
heading: Sequential Sliding Window

text: The cosine similarity is adapted as
heading: Sequential Sliding Window

text: for the question and analogously for the answer .
heading: Sequential Sliding Window

text: We initialize the location weights with a Gaussian and fine - tune them during training .
heading: Sequential Sliding Window

text: The final matching score , denoted as M sws , is computed as in and with sq km replacing c q km .
heading: Sequential Sliding Window

text: Dependency Sliding Window
The dependency sliding window operates identically to the linear sliding window , but on a different view of the text passage .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: The output of this component is M swd and is formed analogously to M sws .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: The dependency perspective uses the Stanford Dependency Parser as an auxiliary tool .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: Thus , the dependency graph can be considered a fixed feature .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: Moreover , linearization of the dependency graph , because it relies on an eigendecomposition , is not differentiable .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: However , we handle the linearization in data preprocessing so that the model sees only reordered word - vector inputs .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: Specifically , we run the Stanford Dependency Parser on each text sentence to build a dependency graph .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: This graph has n w vertices , one for each word in the sentence .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: From the dependency graph we form the Laplacian matrix L ?
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: R nwnw and determine its eigenvectors .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: The second eigenvector u 2 of the Laplacian is known as the Fiedler vector .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: It is the solution to the minimization
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: where vi are the vertices of the graph , and ?
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: ij is the weight of the edge from vertex i to vertex j.
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: The Fiedler vector maps a weighted graph onto a line such that connected nodes stay close , modulated by the connection weights .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: This enables us to reorder the words of a sentence based on their proximity in the dependency graph .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: The reordering of the words is given by the ordered index set I = arg sort ( u 2 ) .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: To give an example of how this works , consider the following sentence from MCTest and its dependency - based reordering :
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: Jenny , Mrs. Mustard 's helper , called the police .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: the police , called Jenny helper , Mrs. 's Mustard .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: Sliding - window - based matching on the original sentence will answer the question
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: Who called the police ? with Mrs. Mustard .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: The dependency reordering enables the window to determine the correct answer , Jenny .
heading: Dependency Sliding Window

text: Combining Distributed
Evidence
It is important in comprehension to synthesize information found throughout a document .
heading: Evidence

text: MCTest was explicitly designed to ensure that it could not be solved by lexical techniques alone , but would instead require some form of inference or limited reasoning .
heading: Evidence

text: It therefore includes questions where the evidence for an answer spans several sentences .
heading: Evidence

text: To perform synthesis , our model also takes in ngrams of sentences , i.e. , sentence pairs and triples strung together .
heading: Evidence

text: The model treats these exactly as it does single sentences , applying all functions detailed above .
heading: Evidence

text: A later pooling operation combines scores across all n-grams ( including the singlesentence input ) .
heading: Evidence

text: This is described in the next subsection .
heading: Evidence

text: With n-grams , the model can combine information distributed across contiguous sentences .
heading: Evidence

text: In some cases , however , the required evidence is spread across distant sentences .
heading: Evidence

text: To give our model some capacity to deal with this scenario , we take the top N sentences as scored by all the preceding functions , and then repeat the scoring computations viewing these top N as a single sentence .
heading: Evidence

text: The reasoning behind these approaches can be explained well in a probabilistic setting .
heading: Evidence

text: If we consider our similarity scores to model the likelihood of a text sentence given a hypothesis , p (t j |h i ) , then the n-gram and top N approaches model a joint probability p (t j 1 , t j 2 , . . . , t j k |h i ) .
heading: Evidence

text: We can not model the joint probability as a product of individual terms ( score values ) because distributed pieces of evidence are likely not independent .
heading: Evidence

text: Combining Perspectives
We use a multilayer perceptron to combine M sem , M word , M swd , and M sws as a final matching score M i for each answer candidate .
heading: Combining Perspectives

text: This network also pools and combines the separate n-gram scores , and uses a linear activation function .
heading: Combining Perspectives

text: Our overall training objective is to minimize the ranking loss
heading: Combining Perspectives

text: where is a constant margin , i * indexes the correct answer , and we take the maximum over i so that we are ranking the correct answer over the best - ranked incorrect answer ( of which there are three ) .
heading: Combining Perspectives

text: This approach worked better than comparing the correct answer to the incorrect answers individually as in .
heading: Combining Perspectives

text: Our implementation of the Parallel - Hierarchical model , using the Keras framework , is available on Github .
heading: Combining Perspectives

text: Training Wheels
Before training , we initialized the neural - network components of our model to perform sensible heuristic functions .
heading: Training Wheels

text: Training did not converge on the small MCTest without this vital approach .
heading: Training Wheels

text: Empirically , we found that we could achieve above 50 % accuracy on MCTest using a simple sum of word vectors followed by a dot product between the question sum and the hypothesis sum .
heading: Training Wheels

text: Therefore , we initialized the network for the semantic perspective to perform this sum , by initializing A x as the identity matrix and bx A as the zero vector , x ? {t , h} .
heading: Training Wheels

text: Recall that the activation function is a ReLU so that positive outputs are unchanged .
heading: Training Wheels

text: We also found basic word - matching scores to be helpful , so we initialized the word - by - word networks likewise .
heading: Training Wheels

text: The network for perspectivecombination was initialized to perform a sum of individual scores , using a zero bias - vector and a weight matrix of ones , since we found that each perspective contributed positively to the overall result .
heading: Training Wheels

text: This training wheels approach is related to other techniques from the literature .
heading: Training Wheels

text: For instance , proposed the identity - matrix initialization in the context of recurrent neural networks in order to preserve the error signal through backpropagation .
heading: Training Wheels

text: In residual networks , shortcut connections bypass certain layers in the network so that a simpler function can be trained in conjunction with the full model .
heading: Training Wheels

text: Experiments
The Dataset
MCTest is a collection of 660 elementary - level children 's stories and associated questions , written by human subjects .
heading: The Dataset

text: The stories are fictional , ensuring that the answer must be found in the text itself , and carefully limited to what a young child can understand .
heading: The Dataset

text: The more challenging variant consists of 500 stories with four multiple - choice questions each .
heading: The Dataset

text: Despite the elementary level , stories and questions are more natural and more complex than those found in synthetic MC datasets like bAb I and CNN .
heading: The Dataset

text: MCTest is challenging because it is both complicated and small .
heading: The Dataset

text: As per , " it is very difficult to train statistical models only on MCTest . "
heading: The Dataset

text: It s size limits the number of parameters that can be trained , and prevents learning any complex language modeling simultaneously with the capacity to answer questions .
heading: The Dataset

text: Training and Model Details
In this section we describe important details of the training procedure and model setup .
heading: Training and Model Details

text: For a complete list of hyperparameter settings , our stopword list , and other minutiae , we refer interested readers to our Github repository .
heading: Training and Model Details

text: For word vectors we use Google 's publicly available embeddings , trained with word2vec on the 100 - billion - word News corpus .
heading: Training and Model Details

text: These vectors are kept fixed throughout training , since we found that training them was not helpful ( likely because of MCTest 's size ) .
heading: Training and Model Details

text: The vectors are 300 - dimensional ( d = 300 ) .
heading: Training and Model Details

text: We do not use a stopword list for the text passage , instead relying on the trainable word weights to ascribe global importance ratings to words .
heading: Training and Model Details

text: These weights are initialized with the inverse document frequency ( IDF ) statistic computed over the MCTest corpus .
heading: Training and Model Details

text: However , we douse a short stopword list for questions .
heading: Training and Model Details

text: This list nullifies query words such as { Who , what , when , where , how} , along with conjugations of the verbs to do and to be .
heading: Training and Model Details

text: Following earlier methods , we use a heuristic to improve performance on negation questions .
heading: Training and Model Details

text: Analysis reveals that most of our system 's test failures occur on questions about quantity ( e.g. , How many ...? ) and temporal order ( e.g. , Who was invited last ? ) .

heading: Analysis and Discussion

text: However , it maybe that human language processing can be factored into separate processes of comprehension and reasoning .
heading: Analysis and Discussion
