text: Indeed , if we train the method exclusively on single questions then its results become even more impressive : we can achieve a test accuracy of 79.1 % on MCTest - 500 .
heading: Analysis and Discussion

text: Conclusion
We have presented the novel Parallel - Hierarchical model for machine comprehension , and evaluated it on the small but complex MCTest .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our model achieves state - of - the - art results , outperforming several feature - engineered and neural approaches .
heading: Conclusion

text: Working with our model has emphasized to us the following ( not necessarily novel ) concepts , which we record hereto promote further empirical validation .
heading: Conclusion

text: Good comprehension of language is supported by hierarchical levels of understanding ( Cf. ) .
heading: Conclusion

text: Exogenous attention ( the trainable word weights ) maybe broadly helpful for NLP .
heading: Conclusion

text: The training wheels approach , that is , initializing neural networks to perform sensible heuristics , appears helpful for small datasets .
heading: Conclusion

text: Reasoning over language is challenging , but easily simulated in some cases .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Iterative Alternating Neural Attention for Machine Reading
abstract
We propose a novel neural attention architecture to tackle machine comprehension tasks , such as answering Cloze - style queries with respect to a document .
heading: abstract

text: Unlike previous models , we do not collapse the query into a single vector , instead we deploy an iterative alternating attention mechanism that allows a fine - grained exploration of both the query and the document .
heading: abstract

text: Our model outperforms state - of - the - art baselines in standard machine comprehension benchmarks such as CNN news articles and the Children 's Book Test ( CBT ) dataset .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Recently , the idea of training machine comprehension models that can read , understand , and answer questions about a text has come closer to reality principally through two factors .
heading: Introduction

text: The first is the advent of deep learning techniques , which allow manipulation of natural language beyond its surface forms and generalize beyond relatively small amounts of labeled data .
heading: Introduction

text: The second factor is the formulation of standard machine comprehension benchmarks based on Cloze - style queries , which permit fast integration loops between model conception and experimental evaluation .
heading: Introduction

text: Cloze - style queries are created by deleting a particular word in a natural - language statement .
heading: Introduction

text: The task is to guess which word was deleted .
heading: Introduction

text: Ina pragmatic approach , recent work formed such questions by extracting a sentence from a larger document .
heading: Introduction

text: In contrast to considering a stand - alone statement , the system is now required to handle a larger amount of information that may possibly influence the prediction of the missing word .
heading: Introduction

text: Such contextual dependencies may also be injected by removing a word from a short human - crafted summary of a larger body of text .
heading: Introduction

text: The abstractive nature of the summary is likely to demand a higher level of comprehension of the original text .
heading: Introduction

text: In both cases , the machine comprehension system is presented with an ablated query and the document to which the original query refers .
heading: Introduction

text: The missing word is assumed to appear in the document .
heading: Introduction

text: Encouraged by the recent success of deep learning attention architectures , we propose a novel neural attention - based inference model designed to perform machine reading comprehension tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: The model first reads the document and the query using a recurrent neural network .
heading: Introduction

text: Then , it deploys an iterative inference process to uncover the inferential links that exist between the missing query word , the query , and the document .
heading: Introduction

text: This phase involves a novel alternating attention mechanism ; it first attends to some parts of the query , then finds their corresponding matches by attending to the document .
heading: Introduction

text: The result of this alternating search is fed back into the iterative inference process to seed the next search step .
heading: Introduction

text: This permits our model to reason about different parts of the query in a sequential way , based on the information that has been gathered previously from the document .
heading: Introduction

text: After a fixed number of iterations , the model uses a summary of its inference process to predict the answer .
heading: Introduction

text: This paper makes the following contributions .
heading: Introduction

text: We present a novel iterative , alternating attention mechanism that , unlike existing models , does not compress the query to a single representation , but instead alternates its attention between the query and the document to obtain a fine - grained query representation within a fixed computation time .
heading: Introduction

text: Our architecture tightly integrates previous ideas related to bidirectional readers and iterative attention processes .
heading: Introduction

text: It obtains state - of - theart results on two machine comprehension datasets and shows promise for application to abroad range of natural language processing tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: Task Description
One of the advantages of using Cloze - style questions to evaluate machine comprehension systems is that a sufficient amount of training and test data can be obtained without human intervention .
heading: Task Description

text: The CBT and corpora are two such datasets .
heading: Task Description

text: The CBT 1 corpus was generated from well - known children 's books available through Project Gutenberg .
heading: Task Description

text: Documents consist of 20 - sentence excerpts from these books .
heading: Task Description

text: The related query is formed from an excerpt 's 21st sentence by replacing a single word with an anonymous placeholder token .
heading: Task Description

text: The dataset is divided into four subsets depending on the type of the word replaced .
heading: Task Description

text: The subsets are named entity , common noun , verb , and preposition .
heading: Task Description

text: We will focus our evaluation solely on the first two subsets , i.e. CBT - NE ( named entity ) and CBT - CN ( common nouns ) , since the latter two are relatively simple as demonstrated by .
heading: Task Description

text: The CNN 2 corpus was generated from news articles available through the CNN website .
heading: Task Description

text: The documents are given by the full articles themselves , which are accompanied by short , bullet - point summary statements .
heading: Task Description

text: Instead of extracting a query from the articles themselves , the authors replace a named entity within each article summary with an anonymous placeholder token .
heading: Task Description

text: For both datasets , the training and evaluation data consist of tuples ( Q , D , A , a ) , where Q is the query ( represented as a sequence of words ) , Dis the document , A is the set of possible answers , and a ?
heading: Task Description

text: A is
Alternating Iterative Attention
Our model is represented in .
heading: Alternating Iterative Attention

text: It s workflow has three steps .
heading: Alternating Iterative Attention

text: First is the encoding phase , in which we compute a set of vector representations , acting as a memory of the content of the input document and query .
heading: Alternating Iterative Attention

text: Next , the inference phase aims to untangle the complex semantic relationships linking the document and the query in order to provide sufficiently strong evidence for the answer prediction to be successful .
heading: Alternating Iterative Attention

text: To accomplish this , we use an iterative process that , at each iteration , alternates attentive memory accesses to the query and the document .
heading: Alternating Iterative Attention

text: Finally , the prediction phase uses the information gathered from the repeated attentions through the query and the document to maximize the probability of the correct answer .
heading: Alternating Iterative Attention

text: We describe each of the phases in the following sections .
heading: Alternating Iterative Attention

text: Bidirectional Encoding
The input to the encoding phase is a sequence of words X = ( x 1 , . . . , x | X | ) , such as a document or a query , drawn from a vocabulary V .
heading: Bidirectional Encoding

text: Each word is represented by a continuous word embedding x ?
heading: Bidirectional Encoding

text: Rd stored in a word embedding matrix X ? R | V |d .
heading: Bidirectional Encoding

text: The sequence X is processed using a recurrent neural network encoder with gated recurrent units ( GRU ) .
heading: Bidirectional Encoding

text: For each position i in the input sequence , the GRU takes as input the word embedding xi and updates a hidden Figure 1 : Our model first encodes the query and the document by means of bidirectional GRU networks .
heading: Bidirectional Encoding

text: Then , it deploys an iterative inference mechanism that alternates between attending query encodings ( 1 ) and document encodings ( 2 ) given the query attended state .
heading: Bidirectional Encoding

text: The results of the alternating attention is gated and fed back into the inference GRU .
heading: Bidirectional Encoding

text: Even if the encodings are computed only once , the query representation is dynamic and changes throughout the inference process .
heading: Bidirectional Encoding

text: After a fixed number of steps T , the weights of the document attention are used to estimate the probability of the answer P ( a|Q , D ) .
heading: Bidirectional Encoding

text: Iterative Alternating Attention
This phase can be considered a means to uncover a possible inference chain that starts at the query and the document and leads to the answer .
heading: Iterative Alternating Attention

text: The inference is modelled by an additional recurrent GRU network .
heading: Iterative Alternating Attention

text: The recurrent network iteratively performs an alternating search step to gather information that maybe useful to predict the answer .
heading: Iterative Alternating Attention

text: In particular , at each time step : ( 1 ) it performs an attentive read on the query encodings , resulting in a query glimpse , qt , and ( 2 ) given the current query glimpse , it extracts a conditional document glimpse , d t , representing the parts of the document that are relevant to the current query glimpse .
heading: Iterative Alternating Attention

text: In turn , both attentive reads are conditioned on the previous hidden state of the inference GRU s t ?1 , summarizing the information that has been gathered from the query and the document up to time t.
heading: Iterative Alternating Attention

text: The inference GRU uses both glimpses to update its recurrent state and thus decides which information needs to be gathered to complete the inference process .
heading: Iterative Alternating Attention

text: Query Attentive Read
Given the query encodings {q i } , we formulate a query glimpse qt at timestep t by :

heading: Query Attentive Read

text: The attention we use here is similar to the formulation used in , but with two differences .
heading: Query Attentive Read

text: First , we use a bilinear term instead of a simple dot product in order to compute the importance of each query term in the current time step .
heading: Query Attentive Read

text: This simple bilinear attention has been successfully used in .
heading: Query Attentive Read

text: Second , we add a term a q that allows to bias the attention mechanism towards words which tend to be important across the questions independently of the search key s t?1 .
heading: Query Attentive Read

text: This is similar to what is achieved by the original attention mechanism proposed in without the burden of the additional tanh layer .
heading: Query Attentive Read

text: Document Attentive Read
The alternating attention continues by probing the document given the current query glimpse qt .
heading: Document Attentive Read

text: In particular , the document attention weights are computed based on both the previous search state and the currently selected query glimpse qt :
heading: Document Attentive Read

text: where d i , tare the attention weights for each word in the document and A d ?

heading: Document Attentive Read

text: Note that the document attention is also conditioned on s t?1 .
heading: Document Attentive Read

text: This allows the model to perform transitive reasoning on the document side , i.e. to use previously obtained document information to bias future attended locations , which is particularly important for natural language inference tasks .
heading: Document Attentive Read

text: Gating Search Results
In order to update its recurrent state , the inference GRU may evolve on the basis of the information gathered from the current inference step , i.e.
heading: Gating Search Results

text: However , the current query glimpse maybe too general or the document may not contain the information specified in the query glimpse , i.e. the query or the document attention weights maybe nearly uniform .
heading: Gating Search Results

text: We include a gating mechanism that is designed to reset the current query and document glimpses in the case that the current search is not fruitful .
heading: Gating Search Results

text: The gate g takes the form of a 2 - layer feed - forward network with sigmoid output unit activation .
heading: Gating Search Results

text: The fourth argument of the gate takes into account multiplicative interactions between query and document glimpses , making it easier to determine the degree of matching between them .

text: Given a query gate g q , producing r q , and a document gate g d , producing rd , the inputs of the inference GRU are given by the reset version of the query and document glimpses , i.e. ,
heading: Gating Search Results

text: Intuitively , the model reviews the query glimpse with respect to the contents of the document glimpse and vice versa .

text: Answer Prediction

After a fixed number of time - steps T , the document attention weights obtained in the last search step d i , T are used to predict the probability of the answer given the document and the query P ( a|Q , D ) .

text: Training Details
To train our model , we used stochastic gradient descent with the ADAM optimizer ( Kingma and Ba , 2014 ) , with an initial learning rate of 0.001 .
heading: Training Details

text: We set the batch size to 32 and we decay the learning rate by 0.8 if the accuracy on the validation set does not increase after a half - epoch , i.e. 2000 batches ( for CBT ) and 5000 batches for ( CNN ) .
heading: Training Details

text: We initialize all weights of our model by sampling from the normal distribution N ( 0 , 0.05 ) .
heading: Training Details

text: Following , the GRU recurrent weights are initialized to be orthogonal and biases are initialized to zero .
heading: Training Details

text: In order to stabilize the learning , we clip the gradients if their norm is greater than 5 and those marked with 2 are from .
heading: Training Details

heading: Training Details

text: We found that setting embedding regularization to 0.0001 , T = 8 , d = 384 , h = 128 , s = 512 worked robustly across the datasets .
heading: Training Details

text: Our model is implemented in Theano , using the Keras library .
heading: Training Details

text: Computational Complexity Similar to previous state - of - the - art models which use a bidirectional encoder , the major bottleneck of our method is computing the document and query encodings .
heading: Training Details

text: The alternating attention mechanism runs only fora fixed number of steps ( T = 8 in our tests ) , which is orders of magnitude smaller than atypical document or query in our datasets ( see ) .
heading: Training Details

text: The repeated attentions each require a softmax over ? 1000 locations which is typically fast on recent GPU architectures .
heading: Training Details

text: Thus , our computation cost is comparable to , but we outperform the latter models on the datasets tested .
heading: Training Details

Main result
Our model ( line 7 ) sets anew stateof - the - art on the common noun category by gaining 3.6 and 5.6 points in validation and test over the best baseline AS Reader ( line 5 ) .

text: This performance gap is only partially reflected on the CBT - NE dataset .

text: In CBT - NE , the missing word is a named entity appearing in the story which is likely to be less frequent than a common noun .
heading: Main result

text: We found that approximatively 27.5 % of validation examples and 29.6 % of test examples contain an answer that has never been predicted in the training set .
heading: Main result

text: These numbers are considerably lower for the CBT - CN , for which only 2.5 % and 4.6 % of validation and test examples respectively contain an answer that has not been previously seen .
heading: Main result

text: Ensembles
We also report the results using ensembled models .
heading: Ensembles

text: Similarly to the single model case , our ensembles achieve state - of - the - art test performance of 75.2 and 76.1 on validation and test respectively , outperforming previously published results .
heading: Ensembles

text: Category analysis classified a sample of 100 CNN stories based on the type of inference required to guess the answer .
heading: Ensembles

text: Categories that only require local context matching around the placeholder and the answer in the text are Exact Match , Paraphrasing , and Partial Clue , while those which require higher reasoning skills are Multiple Sentences and Ambiguous .
heading: Ensembles

text: For example , in Exact Match examples , the question placeholder and the answer in the document share several neighboring exact words .
heading: Ensembles

text: Category - specific results are reported in : Per-category performance of the Stanford AR and our system .
heading: Ensembles

text: The first three categories require local context matching , the next two global context matching and coreference errors are unanswerable questions .
heading: Ensembles

text: tackled by the neural models , which perform similarly .
heading: Ensembles

text: It seems that the iterative alternating attention inference is better able to solve more difficult examples such as Ambiguous / Hard .
heading: Ensembles

text: One hypothesis is that , in contrast to Stanford AR , which uses only one fixedquery attention step , our iterative attention may better explore the documents and queries .
heading: Ensembles

text: Finally , Coreference Errors ( ? 25 % of the corpus ) includes examples with critical coreference resolution errors which may make the questions " unanswerable " .
heading: Ensembles

text: This is a barrier to achieving accuracies considerably above 75 % .
heading: Ensembles

text: If this estimate is accurate , our ensemble model ( 76.1 % ) maybe approaching near-optimal performance on this dataset .
heading: Ensembles

We inspect the query and document attention weights for an example article from the CNN dataset .

heading: Discussion

text: At step 3 , the most likely candidates are " European Union " and " Rome " ( @entity159 ) .
heading: Discussion

text: As the timesteps unfold , the model learns that " needs " maybe important to infer the correct entity , i.e. " Italian " .
heading: Discussion

text: The query sits on the same attended location , while the document attention evolves to become more confident about the answer .
heading: Discussion

text: We find that , across CBT and CNN examples , the query attention wanders near or focuses on the placeholder location , attempting to discriminate its identity using only local context .
heading: Discussion

text: For these particular datasets , the majority of questions can be answered after attending only to the words directly neighbouring the placeholder .
heading: Discussion

text: This aligns with the findings of concerning CNN , which state that the required reasoning and inference levels for this dataset are quite simple .
heading: Discussion

text: It would be worthwhile to formulate a dataset in which the placeholder is harder to infer using only local neighboring words , and thereby necessitates deeper query exploration .
heading: Discussion

text: Finally , across this work we fixed the number of inference steps T .
heading: Discussion

text: We found that using 8 timesteps works well consistently across the tested datasets .
heading: Discussion

text: However , we hypothesize that more ( fewer ) timesteps would benefit harder ( easier ) examples .
heading: Discussion

text: A straight - forward extension of the model would be to dynamically select the number of inference steps conditioned on each example .
heading: Discussion

text: Related Works
Neural attention models have been applied recently to a smrgsbord of machine learning and natural language processing problems .
heading: Related Works

text: These include , but are not limited to , handwriting recognition , digit classification , machine translation , question answering and caption generation .
heading: Related Works

text: In general , attention models keep a memory of states that can be accessed at will by learned attention policies .
heading: Related Works

text: In our case , the memory is represented by the set of document and query contextual encodings .
heading: Related Works

text: Our model is closely related to , which were also applied to question answering .
heading: Related Works

text: The pointer - style attention mechanism that we use to perform the final answer prediction has been proposed by , which in turn was based on the earlier Pointer Networks of .
heading: Related Works

text: However , differently from our work , perform only one attention step and embed the query into a single vector representation , corresponding to the concatenation of the last state of the forward and backward GRU networks .
heading: Related Works

text: To our knowledge , embedding the query into a single vector representation is a choice that is shared by most machine reading comprehension models .
heading: Related Works

text: In our model , the repeated , tight integration between query attention and document attention allows the model to explore dynamically which parts of the query are most important to predict the answer , and then to focus on the parts of the document that are most salient to the currently - attended query components .
heading: Related Works

text: A similar attempt in attending different components of the query maybe found in .
heading: Related Works

text: In that model , the document is processed once for each query word .
heading: Related Works

text: This can be computationally intractable for large documents , since it involves unrolling a bidirectional recurrent neural network over the entire document multiple times .
heading: Related Works

text: In contrast , our model only estimates query and document encodings once and can learn how to attend different parts of those encodings in a fixed number of steps .
heading: Related Works

text: The inference network is responsible for making sense of the current attention step with respect to what has been gathered before .
heading: Related Works

text: In addition to achieving state - of the - art performance , this technique may also prove to be more scalable than alternative query attention models .
heading: Related Works

text: Finally , our iterative inference process shares similarities to the iterative hops in Memory Networks .
heading: Related Works

text: In that model , the query representation is updated iteratively from hop to hop , although its different components are not attended to separately .
heading: Related Works

text: Moreover , we substitute the simple linear update with a GRU network .
heading: Related Works

text: The gating mechanism of the GRU network made it possible to use multiple steps of attention and to propagate the learning signal effectively back through to the first timestep .
heading: Related Works

text: Conclusion
We presented an iterative neural attention model and applied it to machine comprehension tasks .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our architecture deploys a novel alternating attention mechanism , and tightly integrates successful ideas from past works in machine reading comprehension to obtain state - of - the - art results on three datasets .
heading: Conclusion

text: The iterative alternating attention mechanism continually refines its view of the query and document while aggregating the information required to answer a query .
heading: Conclusion

text: Multiple future research directions maybe envisioned .
heading: Conclusion

text: We plan to dynamically select the optimal number of inference steps required for each example .
heading: Conclusion

text: Moreover , we suspect that shifting towards stochastic attention should permit us to learn more interesting search policies .
heading: Conclusion

text: Finally , we believe that our model is fully general and maybe applied in a straightforward way to other tasks such as information retrieval .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Published as a conference paper at ICLR 2017 QUERY - REDUCTION NETWORKS FOR QUESTION ANSWERING
heading: title

text: abstract
In this paper , we study the problem of question answering when reasoning over multiple facts is required .
heading: abstract

text: We propose Query - Reduction Network ( QRN ) , a variant of Recurrent Neural Network ( RNN ) that effectively handles both short - term ( local ) and long - term ( global ) sequential dependencies to reason over multiple facts .
heading: abstract

text: QRN considers the context sentences as a sequence of state - changing triggers , and reduces the original query to a more informed query as it observes each trigger ( context sentence ) through time .
heading: abstract

text: Our experiments show that QRN produces the state - of - the - art results in bAbI QA and dialog tasks , and in areal goal - oriented dialog dataset .
heading: abstract

text: In addition , QRN formulation allows parallelization on RNN 's time axis , saving an order of magnitude in time complexity for training and inference .
heading: abstract

text: INTRODUCTION
In this paper , we address the problem of question answering ( QA ) when reasoning over multiple facts is required .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: For example , consider we know that Frogs eat insects and Flies are insects .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Then answering Do frogs eat flies ?
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: requires reasoning over both of the above facts .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Question answering , more specifically context - based QA , has been extensively studied in machine comprehension tasks .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: However , most of the datasets are primarily focused on lexical and syntactic understanding , and hardly concentrate on inference over multiple facts .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Recently , several datasets aimed for testing multi-hop reasoning have emerged ; among them are story - based QA and the dialog task .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Recurrent Neural Network ( RNN ) and its variants , such as Long Short - Term Memory ( LSTM ) and Gated Recurrent Unit ( GRU ) , are popular choices for modeling natural language .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: However , when used for multi-hop reasoning in question answering , purely RNN - based models have shown to perform poorly .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: This is largely due to the fact that RNN 's internal memory is inherently unstable over along term .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: For this reason , most recent approaches in the literature have mainly relied on global attention mechanism and shared external memory .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: The attention mechanism allows these models to focus on a single sentence in each layer .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: They can sequentially read multiple relevant sentences from the memory with multiple layers to perform multi-hop reasoning .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: However , one major drawback of these standard attention mechanisms is that they are insensitive to the time step ( memory address ) of the sentences when accessing them .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Our proposed model , Query - Reduction Network 1 ( QRN ) , is a single recurrent unit that addresses the long - term dependency problem of most RNN - based models by simplifying the recurrent update , while taking the advantage of RNN 's capability to model sequential data ) .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: QRN considers the context sentences as a sequence of state - changing triggers , and transforms ( reduces ) the original query to a more informed query as it observes each trigger through time .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: For instance in , the original question , Where is the apple ? , can not be directly answered by any single sentence from the story .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: After observing the first sentence , Sandra got the apple there , QRN transforms the original question to a reduced query
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Where is Sandra ? , which is presumably . ? and ?
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: are update gate and reduce functions , respectively .?
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: is assigned to be h 2 5 , the local query at the last time step in the last layer .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Also , red-colored text is the inferred meanings of the vectors ( see. easier to answer than the original question given the context provided by the first sentence .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: 2 Unlike RNN - based models , QRN 's candidate state ( h t in ) does not depend on the previous hidden state ( h t?1 ) .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Compared to memory - based approaches , QRN can better encodes locality information because it does not use a global memory access controller ( circle nodes in ) , and the query updates are performed locally .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: In short , the main contribution of QRN is threefold .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: First , QRN is a simple variant of RNN that reduces the query given the context sentences in a differentiable manner .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Second , QRN is situated between the attention mechanism and RNN , effectively handling time dependency and long - term dependency problems of each technique , respectively .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Hence it is well - suited for sequential data with both local and global interactions ( note that QRN is not the replacement of RNN , which is arguably better for modeling complex local interactions ) .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Third , unlike most RNN - based models , QRN can be parallelized overtime by computing candidate reduced queries ( h t ) directly from local input queries ( q t ) and context sentence vectors ( x t ) .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: In fact , the parallelizability of QRN implies that QRN does not suffer from the vanishing gradient problem of RNN , hence effectively addressing the long - term dependency .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: We experimentally demonstrate these contributions by achieving the state - of - the - art results on story - based QA and interactive dialog datasets .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: MODEL

In story - based QA ( or dialog dataset ) , the input is the context as a sequence of sentences ( story or past conversations ) and a question in natural language ( equivalent to the user 's last utterance in the dialog ) .
heading: MODEL

text: The output is the predicted answer to the question in natural language ( the system 's next utterance in the dialog ) .
heading: MODEL

text: The only supervision provided during training is the answer to the question .
heading: MODEL

text: In this paper we particularly focus on end - to - end solutions , i.e. , the only supervision comes from questions and answers , and we restrain from using manually defined rules or external language resources , such as lexicon or dependency parser .
heading: MODEL

text: PARALLELIZATION
An important advantage of QRN is that the recurrent updates in Equation 3 and 5 can be computed in parallel across time .
heading: PARALLELIZATION

text: This is in contrast with most RNN - based models that can not be parallelized , where computing the candidate hidden state at time t explicitly requires the previous hidden state .
heading: PARALLELIZATION

text: In QRN , the final reduced queries ( h t ) can be decomposed into computing over candidate reduced queries ( h t ) , without looking at the previous reduced query .

text: RELATED WORK
heading: Figure

text: QRN is inspired by RNN - based models with gating mechanism , such as LSTM and GRU .
heading: Figure

text: While GRU and LSTM use the previous hidden state and the current input to obtain the candidate hidden state , QRN only uses the current two inputs to obtain the candidate reduced query ( equivalent to candidate hidden state ) .
heading: Figure

text: We conjecture that this not only gives computational advantage via parallelization , but also makes training easier , i.e. , avoiding vanishing gradient ( which is critical for long - term dependency ) , overfitting ( by simplifying the model ) , and converging to local minima .
heading: Figure

text: The idea of structurally simplifying ( constraining ) RNNs for learning longer - term patterns has been explored in recent previous work , such as Structurally Constrained Recurrent Network and Strongly - Typed Recurrent Neural Network ( STRNN ) .
heading: Figure

text: QRN is similar to STRNN in that both architectures use gating mechanism , and the gates and the candidate hidden states do not depend on the previous hidden states , which simplifies the recurrent relation .
heading: Figure

text: However , QRN can be distinguished from STRNN in three ways .
heading: Figure

text: First , QRN 's update gate simulates attention mechanism , measuring the relevance between the input sentence and query .
heading: Figure

text: On the other hand , the gates in STRNN can be considered as the simplification of LSTM / GRU by removing their dependency on previous hidden state .
heading: Figure

text: Second , QRN is an RNN that is natively compatible with context - based QA tasks , where the QRN unit accepts two inputs , i.e. each context sentence and query .
heading: Figure

text: This is distinct from STRNN which has only one input .
heading: Figure

text: Third , we show that QRN is timewise - parallelizable on GPUs .
heading: Figure

text: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .
End - to - end Memory Network ( N2N ) uses external memory with multi - layer attention mechanism to focus on sentences that are relevant to the question .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: There are two key differences between N2N and our QRN .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: First , N2N summarizes the entire memory in each layer to control the attention in the next layer ( circle nodes in ) .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: Instead , QRN does not have any controller node ) and is able to focus on relevant sentences through the update gate that is internally embodied within its unit .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: Second , N2N adds time - dependent trainable weights to the sentence representations to model the time dependency of the sentences ( as discussed in Section 1 ) .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: QRN does not need such additional weights as its inherent RNN architecture allows QRN to effectively model the time dependency .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: Neural Reasoner and Gated End - toend Memory Network ) are variants of MemN2N that share its fundamental characteristics .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: Improved Dynamic Memory Network ( DMN + ) uses the hybrid of the attention mechanism and the RNN architecture to model the sequence of sentences .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: It consists of two distinct GRUs , one for the time axis ( rectangle nodes in ) and one for the layer axis ( circle nodes in ) .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: Note that the update gate of the GRU for the time axis is replaced with external softmax attention weights .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: DMN + uses the time - axis GRU to summarizes the entire memory in each layer , and then the layer - axis GRU controls the attention weights in each layer .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: In contrast , QRN is simply a single recurrent unit without any controller node .
heading: Our parallelization algorithm is also applicable to STRNN .

text: EXPERIMENTS
5.1 DATA bAb
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: I story - based QA dataset bAb I story - based QA dataset is composed of 20 different tasks ( Appendix A ) , each of which has 1,000 ( 1 k ) synthetically - generated story - question pair .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: A story can be as short as two sentences and as long as 200 + sentences .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: A system is evaluated on the accuracy of getting the correct answers to the questions .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The answers are single words or lists ( e.g. " football , apple " ) .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Answering questions in each task requires selecting a set of relevant sentences and applying different kinds of logical reasoning over them .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The dataset also includes 10 k training data ( for each task ) , which allows training more complex models .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Note that DMN + only reports on the 10k dataset .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: bAb
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: I dialog dataset bAb I dialog dataset consists of 5 different tasks , each of which has 1 k synthetically - generated goal - oriented dialogs between a user and the system in the domain of restaurant reservation .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Each dialog is as long as 96 utterances and comes with external knowledge base ( KB ) providing information of each restaurant .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: The authors also provide Out - Of - Vocabulary ( OOV ) version of the dataset , where many of the words and KB keywords in test data are not seen during training .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: A system is evaluated on the accuracy of its response to each utterance of the user , choosing from up to 2500 possible candidate responses .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: A system is required not only to understand the user 's request but also refer to previous conversations in order to obtain the context information of the current conversation .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: DSTC2 ( Task 6 ) dialog dataset transformed the Second Dialog State Tracking Challenge ( DSTC2 ) dataset into the same format as the bAbI dialog dataset , for the measurement of performance on areal dataset .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Each dialog can be as long as 800 + utterances , and a system needs to choose from 2407 possible candidate responses for each utterance of the user .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: Note that the evaluation metric of the original DSTC2 is different from that of the transformed DSTC2 , so previous work on the original DSTC2 should not be directly compared to our work .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: We will refer to this transformed DSTC2 dataset by " Task 6 " of dialog dataset .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: MODEL DETAILS
heading: EXPERIMENTS

In the input module , we are given sentences ( previous conversations in dialog ) x t and a question ( most recent user utterance ) q , and we want to obtain their vector representations , x t , q ?

Then the final answer ?
heading: RV d is a weight matrix .

text: is simply the argmax word inv .

text: To handle questions with multiple - word answers , we consider each of them as a single word that contains punctuations such as space and comma , and put it in the vocabulary .

text: Output Module for dialog .
We use a fixed number single - layer softmax classifiers , each of which is similar to that of the sotry - based QA model , to sequentially output each word of the system 's response .
heading: Output Module for dialog .

text: While it is similar in spirit to the RNN decoder , our output module does not have a recurrent hidden state or gating mechanism .
heading: Output Module for dialog .

text: Instead , it solely uses the final ouptut of the QRN , ? , and the current word output to influence the prediction of the next word among possible candidates .
heading: Output Module for dialog .

text: Training .
We withhold 10 % of the training for development .
heading: Training .

text: We use the hidden state size of 50 by deafult .
heading: Training .

text: Batch sizes of 32 for bAbI story - based QA 1k , bAb I dialog and DSTC2 dialog , and 128 for bAbI QA 10 k are used .
heading: Training .

text: The weights in the input and output modules are initialized with zero mean and the standard deviation of 1 / ? d.
heading: Training .

text: Weights in the QRN unit are initialized using techniques by , and are tied across the layers .
heading: Training .

text: Forget bias of 2.5 is used for update gates ( no bias for reset gates ) .
heading: Training .

text: L2 weight decay of 0.001 ( 0.0005 for QA 10 k ) is used for all weights .
heading: Training .

text: The loss function is the cross entropy betweenv and the one - hot vector of the true answer .
heading: Training .

text: The loss is minimized by stochastic gradient descent for maximally 500 epochs , but training is early stopped if the loss on the development data does not decrease for 50 epochs .
heading: Training .

text: The learning rate is controlled by AdaGrad with the initial learning rate of 0.5 ( 0.1 for QA 10 k ) .
heading: Training .

text: Since the model is sensitive to the weight initialization , we repeat each training procedure 10 times ( 50 times for 10 k ) with the new random initialization of the weights and report the result on the test data with the lowest loss on the development data .
heading: Training .

text: RESULTS .
We compare our model with baselines and previous state - of - the - art models on story - based and dialog tasks .
heading: RESULTS .

text: These include LSTM , End - to - end Memory Networks ( N2N ) , Dynamic Memory Networks ( DMN + ) , Gated End - to - end Memory Networks ( GMe m N2N ) , and Differentiable Neural Computer ( DNC ) .
heading: RESULTS .

text: Story - based QA .
Table 1 ( top ) reports the summary of results of our model ( QRN ) and previous work on b AbI QA ( task - wise results are shown in in Appendix ) .
heading: Story - based QA .

text: In 1 k data , QRN 's ' 2 r' ( 2 layers + reset gate + d = 50 ) outperforms all other models by a large margin ( 2.8 + % ) .
heading: Story - based QA .

text: In 10 k dataset , the average accuracy of QRN 's ' 6r200 ' ( 6 layers + reset gate + d = 200 ) model outperforms all previous models by a large margin ( 2.5 + % ) , achieving a nearly perfect score of 99.7 % .
heading: Story - based QA .

text: Dialog . Table 1 ( bottom ) reports the summary of the results of our model ( QRN ) and previous work on bAbI dialog and Task 6 dialog ( task - wise results are shown in in Appendix ) .
heading: Story - based QA .

text: As done in previous work , we also report results when we use ' Match ' for dialogs .
heading: Story - based QA .

text: ' Match ' is the extension to the model which additionally takes as input whether each answer candidate matches with context ( more details on Appendix ) .
heading: Story - based QA .

text: QRN outperforms previous work by a large margin ( 2.0 + % ) in every comparison .
heading: Story - based QA .

text: Ablations .

We test four types of ablations ( also discussed in Section 2.2 ) : number of layers ( 1 , 2 , 3 , or 6 ) , reset gate ( r ) , and gate vectorization ( v ) and the dimension of the hidden vector ( 50 , 100 ) .
heading: Ablations .

text: We show a subset of combinations of the ablations for bAbI QA in ; other combinations performed poorly and / or did not give interesting observations .
heading: Ablations .

text: According to the ablation results , we infer that : ( a ) When the number of layers is only one , the model lacks reasoning capability .
heading: Ablations .

text: In the case of 1 k dataset , when there are too many layers ( 6 ) , it seems correctly training the model becomes increasingly difficult .
heading: Ablations .

text: In the case of 10 k dataset , many layers ( 6 ) and hidden dimensions ( 200 ) helps reasoning , most notably in difficult task such as task 16 .
heading: Ablations .

text: ( b ) Adding the reset gate helps .
heading: Ablations .

text: ( c ) Including vector gates hurts in 1 k datasets , as the model either overfits to the training data or converges to local minima .
heading: Ablations .

text: On the other hand , vector gates in bAbI story - based QA 10 k dataset sometimes help .
heading: Ablations .

text: ( d ) Increasing the dimension of the hidden state to 100 in the dialog 's Task 6 ( DSTC2 ) helps , while there is not much improvement in the dialog 's Task 1 - 5 .
heading: Ablations .

text: It can be hypothesized that a larger hidden state is required for real data . Parallelization .
heading: Ablations .

text: We implement QRN with and without parallelization in TensorFlow ) on a single Titan X GPU to qunaitify the computational gain of the parallelization .
heading: Ablations .

text: For QRN without parallelization , we use the RNN library provided by TensorFlow .
heading: Ablations .

text: QRN with parallelization gives 6.2 times faster training and inference than QRN without parallelization on average .
heading: Ablations .

text: We expect that the speedup can be even higher for datasets with larger context .
heading: Ablations .

text: Interpretations .
An advantage of QRN is that the intermediate query updates are interpretable .
heading: Interpretations .

text: shows intermediate local queries ( q kt ) interpreted in natural language , such as " Where is Sandra ? " .
heading: Interpretations .

text: In order to obtain these , we place a decoder on the input question embedding q and add it s loss for recovering the question to the classification loss ( similarly to ) .
heading: Interpretations .

text: We then use the same decoder to decode the intermediate queries .
heading: Interpretations .

text: This helps us understand the flow of information in the networks .
heading: Interpretations .

text: In , the question Where is apple ?
heading: Interpretations .

heading: Interpretations .

heading: Interpretations .

text: We obtain Where is Daniel ?
heading: Interpretations .

text: at time t = 3 , and it is propagated until t = 5 , where we observe a sentence ( fact ) that can be used to answer the query .
heading: Interpretations .

text: CONCLUSION
In this paper , we introduce Query - Reduction Network ( QRN ) to answer context - based questions and carryout conversations with users that require multi-hop reasoning .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: We show the state - of - theart results in the three datasets of story - based QA and dialog .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: We model a story or a dialog as a sequence of state - changing triggers and compute the final answer to the question or the system 's next utterance by recurrently updating ( or reducing ) the query .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: QRN is situated between the attention mechanism and RNN , effectively handling time dependency and long - term dependency problems of each technique , respectively .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: It addresses the long - term dependency problem of most RNNs by simplifying the recurrent update , in which the candidate hidden state ( reduced query ) does not depend on the previous state .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: Moreover , QRN can be parallelized and can address the well - known problem of RNN 's vanishing gradients .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: title
Neural Semantic Encoders
heading: title

text: abstract
We present a memory augmented neural network for natural language understanding : Neural Semantic Encoders .
heading: abstract

text: NSE is equipped with a novel memory update rule and has a variable sized encoding memory that evolves overtime and maintains the understanding of input sequences through read , compose and write operations .
heading: abstract

text: NSE can also access 1 multiple and shared memories .
heading: abstract

text: In this paper , we demonstrated the effectiveness and the flexibility of NSE on five different natural language tasks : natural language inference , question answering , sentence classification , document sentiment analysis and machine translation where NSE achieved state - of - the - art performance when evaluated on publically available benchmarks .
heading: abstract

text: For example , our shared - memory model showed an encouraging result on neural machine translation , improving an attention - based baseline by approximately 1.0 BLEU .
heading: abstract

text: Recurrent neural networks ( RNNs ) have been successful for modeling sequences
heading: abstract

text: Particularly , RNNs equipped with internal short memories , such as long short - term memories ( LSTM )
heading: abstract

text: [ 2 ] have achieved a notable success in sequential tasks [ 3 , 4 ] .
heading: abstract

text: LSTM is powerful because it learns to control it s short term memories .
heading: abstract

text: However , the short term memories in LSTM area part of the training parameters .
heading: abstract

text: This imposes some practical difficulties in training and modeling long sequences with LSTM .
heading: abstract

text: Recently several studies have explored ways of extending the neural networks with an external memory [ 5 ] [ 6 ] [ 7 ] .
heading: abstract

text: Unlike LSTM , the short term memories and the training parameters of such a neural network are no longer coupled and can be adapted .
heading: abstract

text: In this paper we propose a novel class of memory augmented neural networks called Neural Semantic Encoders ( NSE ) for natural language understanding .
heading: abstract

text: NSE offers several desirable properties .
NSE has a variable sized encoding memory which allows the model to access entire input sequence during the reading process ; therefore efficiently delivering long - term dependencies overtime .
heading: NSE offers several desirable properties .

text: The encoding memory evolves overtime and maintains the memory of the input sequence through read , compose and write operations .
heading: NSE offers several desirable properties .

text: NSE sequentially processes the input and supports word compositionality inheriting both temporal and hierarchical nature of human language .
heading: NSE offers several desirable properties .

text: NSE can read from and write to a set of relevant encoding memories simultaneously or multiple NSEs can access a shared encoding memory effectively supporting knowledge and representation sharing .
heading: NSE offers several desirable properties .

text: NSE is flexible , robust and suitable for practical NLU tasks and can be trained easily by any gradient descent optimizer .
heading: NSE offers several desirable properties .

text: We evaluate NSE on five different real tasks .
For four of them , our models set new state - of - theart results .
heading: We evaluate NSE on five different real tasks .

text: Our results suggest that a NN model with the shared memory between encoder and decoder is a promising approach for sequence transduction problems such as machine translation and abstractive summarization .
heading: We evaluate NSE on five different real tasks .

text: In particular , we observe that the attention - based neural machine translation can be further improved by shared - memory models .
heading: We evaluate NSE on five different real tasks .

text: We also analyze memory access pattern and compositionality in NSE and show that our model captures semantic and syntactic structures of input sentence .
heading: We evaluate NSE on five different real tasks .
We evaluate NSE on five different real tasks .

text: By access we mean changing the memory states by the read , compose and write operations .
heading: We evaluate NSE on five different real tasks .

text: Related Work
One of the pioneering work that attempts to extend deep neural networks with an external memory is Neural Turing Machines ( NTM ) .
heading: Related Work

text: NTM implements a centralized controller and a fixed - sized random access memory .
heading: Related Work

text: The NTM memory is addressable by both content ( i.e. soft attention ) and location based access mechanisms .
heading: Related Work

text: The authors evaluated NTM on algorithmic tasks such as copying and sorting sequences .
heading: Related Work

text: Comparison with Neural Turing Machines : NSE addresses certain drawbacks of NTM .
heading: Related Work

text: NTM has a single centralized controller , which is usually an MLP or RNN while NSE takes a modular approach .
heading: Related Work

text: The main controller in NSE is decomposed into three separate modules , each of which performs for read , compose or write operation .
heading: Related Work

text: In NSE , the compose module is introduced in addition to the standard memory update operations ( i.e. read - write ) in order to process the memory entries and input information .
heading: Related Work

text: The main advantage of NSE over NTM is in its memory update .
heading: Related Work

text: Despite its sophisticated addressing mechanism , the NTM controller does not have mechanism to avoid information collision in the memory .
heading: Related Work

text: Particularly the NTM controller emits two separate set of access weights ( i.e. read weight and erase and write weights ) that do not explicitly encode the knowledge about where information is read from and written to .
heading: Related Work

text: Moreover the fixed - size memory in NTM has no memory allocation or de-allocation protocol .
heading: Related Work

text: Therefore unless the controller is intelligent enough to track the previous read / write information , which is hard for an RNN when processing long sequences , the memory content is overlapped and information is overwritten throughout different time scales .
heading: Related Work

text: We think that this is a potential reason that makes NTM hard to train and makes the training not stable .
heading: Related Work

text: We also note that the effectiveness of the location based addressing introduced in NTM is unclear .
heading: Related Work

text: In NSE , we introduce a novel and systematic memory update approach based on the soft attention mechanism .
heading: Related Work

text: NSE writes new information to the most recently read memory locations .
heading: Related Work

text: This is accomplished by sharing the same memory key vector between the read and write modules .
heading: Related Work

text: The NSE memory update is scalable and potentially more robust to train .
heading: Related Work

text: NSE is provided with a variable sized memory and thus unlike NTM , the size of the NSE memory is more relaxed .
heading: Related Work

text: The novel memory update mechanism and the variable sized memory together prevent NSE from the information collision issue and avoid the need of the memory allocation or de-allocation protocols .
heading: Related Work

text: Each memory location of the NSE memory stores a token representation in input sequence during encoding .
heading: Related Work

text: This provides NSE with an anytime - access to the entire input sequence including the tokens from the future time scales , which is not permitted in NTM , RNN and attention - based encoders .
heading: Related Work

text: Lastly , NTM addresses small algorithmic problems while NSE focuses on a set of large - scale language understanding tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: The RNNSearch model proposed in can be seen as a variation of memory augmented networks due to its ability to read the historic output states of RNNs with soft attention .
heading: Related Work

text: The work of combines the soft attention with Memory Networks ( Mem NNs ) .
heading: Related Work

text: Similar to RNNSearch , MemNNs are designed with non-writable memories .
heading: Related Work

text: It constructs layered memory representations and showed promising results on both artificial and real question answering tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: We note that RNNSearch and MemNNs avoid the memory update and management overhead by simply using a non-writable memory storage .
heading: Related Work

text: Another variation of MemNNs is Dynamic Memory Network that is equipped with an episodic memory and seems to be flexible in different settings .
heading: Related Work

text: Although NSE differs from other memory - augumented NN models in many aspects , they all use soft attention mechanism with a type of similarity measures to retrieve relevant information from the external memory .
heading: Related Work

text: For example , NTM implements cosine similarity and MemNNs use vector dot product .
heading: Related Work

text: NSE uses the vector dot product for the similarity measure in NSE because it is faster to compute .
heading: Related Work

text: Other related work includes Neural Program - Interpreters , which learns to run sub-programs and to compose them for high - level programs .
heading: Related Work

text: It uses execution traces to provide the full supervision .
heading: Related Work

text: Researchers have also explored ways to add unbounded memory to LSTM using a particular data structure .
heading: Related Work

text: Although this type of architecture provides a flexible capacity to store information , the memory access is constrained by the data structure used for the memory bank , such as stack and queue .
heading: Related Work

text: Overall it is expensive to train and to scale the previously proposed memory - based models .
heading: Related Work

text: Most models required a set of clever engineering tricks to work successfully .
heading: Related Work

text: Most of the aforementioned memory augmented neural networks have been tested on synthetic tasks whereas in this paper we evaluated NSE on a wide range of real and large - scale natural language applications .
heading: Related Work

text: Read , Compose and Write
NSE performs three main operations in every time step .
heading: Read , Compose and Write

text: After initializing the memory slots with the corresponding input representations , NSE processes an embedding vector x t and retrieves a memory slot m r,t that is expected to be associatively coherent ( i.e. semantically associated ) with the current input word wt .
heading: Read , Compose and Write

text: The slot location r ( ranging from 1 to l ) is defined by a key vector z t which the read module emits by attending over the memory slots .
heading: Read , Compose and Write

text: The compose module implements a composition operation that combines the memory slot with the current input .
heading: Read , Compose and Write

text: The write module then transforms the composition output to the encoding memory space and writes the resulting new representation into the slot location of the memory .
heading: Read , Compose and Write

text: Instead of composing the raw embedding vector x t , we use the hidden state o t produced by the read module at time t
heading: Read , Compose and Write

text: where 1 is a matrix of ones , ?

text: denotes the outer product which duplicates it s left vector l or k times to form a matrix .
heading: Read , Compose and Write

text: The read function f LST
Mr sequentially maps the word embeddings to the internal space of the memory M t?1 .
heading: The read function f LST

text: Then Equation 2 looks for the slots related to the input by computing association degree between each memory slot and the hidden state o t .
heading: The read function f LST

text: We calculate the association degree by the dot product and transform this scores to the fuzzy key vector z t by normalizing with sof tmax function .
heading: The read function f LST

text: Since our key vector is fuzzy , the slot to be composed is retrieved by taking weighted sum of the all slots as in Equation .
heading: The read function f LST

text: This process can also be seen as the soft attention mechanism .
heading: The read function f LST

text: In Equation 4 and 5 , we compose and process the retrieved slot with the current hidden state and map the resulting vector to the encoder output space .
heading: The read function f LST

text: Finally , we write the new representation to the memory location pointed by the key vector in where the key vector z t emitted by the read module is reused to inform the write module of the most recently read slots .
heading: The read function f LST

text: First the slot information that was retrieved is erased and then the new representation is located .
heading: The read function f LST

text: NSE performs this iterative process until all words in the input sequence are read .
heading: The read function f LST

text: The encoding memories { M } T t=1 and output states {h} T t=1 are further used for the tasks .
heading: The read function f LST

text: Although NSE reads a single word at a time , it has an anytime - access to the entire sequence stored in the encoding memory .
heading: The read function f LST

text: With the encoding memory , NSE maintains a mental image of the input sequence .
heading: The read function f LST

text: The memory is initialized with the raw embedding vector at time t = 0 .
heading: The read function f LST

text: We term such a freshly initialized memory a baby memory .
heading: The read function f LST

text: As NSE reads more input content in time , the baby memory evolves and refines the encoded mental image .
heading: The read function f LST

text: Shared and Multiple Memory Accesses
heading: The read function f LST

text: For sequence to sequence transduction tasks like question answering , natural language inference and machine translation , it is beneficial to access other relevant memories in addition to its own one .
heading: The read function f LST

text: The shared or the multiple memory access allows a set of NSEs to exchange knowledge representations and to communicate with each other to accomplish a particular task throughout the encoding memory .
heading: The read function f LST

text: NSE can be extended easily , so that it is able to read from and write to multiple memories simultaneously or multiple NSEs are able to access a shared memory .
heading: The read function f LST

text: In MMA - NSE , the different memory slots are retrieved from the shared memories depending on their encoded semantic representations .

text: Experiments
We describe in this section experiments on five different tasks , in order to show that NSE can be effective and flexible in different settings .
heading: Experiments

text: We report results on natural language inference , question answering ( QA ) , sentence classification , document sentiment analysis and machine translation .
heading: Experiments

text: All five tasks challenge a model in terms of language understanding and semantic reasoning .
heading: Experiments

text: The models are trained using Adam with hyperparameters selected on development set .
heading: Experiments

text: We chose two one - layer LSTM for read / write modules on the tasks other than QA on which we used two - layer LSTM .
heading: Experiments

text: The pre-trained 300 - D Glove 840B vectors and 100 - D Glove 6B vectors were obtained for the word embeddings .
heading: Experiments

text: The word embeddings are fixed during training .
The embeddings for out - of - vocabulary words were set to zero vector .
heading: The word embeddings are fixed during training .

text: We crop or pad the input sequence to a fixed length .
heading: The word embeddings are fixed during training .

text: A padding vector was inserted when padding .
The models were regularized by using dropouts and an l 2 weight decay .
heading: A padding vector was inserted when padding .

text: Natural Language Inference
heading: A padding vector was inserted when padding .

text: The natural language inference is one of the main tasks in language understanding .
heading: A padding vector was inserted when padding .

text: This task tests the ability of a model to reason about the semantic relationship between two sentences .
heading: A padding vector was inserted when padding .

text: In order to perform well on the task , NSE should be able to capture sentence semantics and be able to reason the relation between a sentence pair , i.e. , whether a premise - hypothesis pair is entailing , contradictory or neutral .
heading: A padding vector was inserted when padding .

text: We conducted experiments on the Stanford Natural Language Inference ( SNLI ) dataset , which consists of 549,367/9,842/9,824 premise-hypothesis pairs for train / dev / test sets and target label indicating their relation .
heading: A padding vector was inserted when padding .

text: Following the setting in the NSE output for each sentence was the input to a MLP , where the input layer computes the concatenation [ h pl ; h h l ] , absolute difference hp l ?

text: h h land elementwise product hp l h h l of the two sentence representations .
heading: A padding vector was inserted when padding .

text: In addition , the MLP has a hidden layer with 1024 units with ReLU activation and a sof tmax layer .
heading: A padding vector was inserted when padding .

text: We set the batch size to 128 , the initial learning rate to 3e - 4 and l 2 regularizer strength to 3 e - 5 , and train each model for 40 epochs .
heading: A padding vector was inserted when padding .

text: The write / read neural nets and the last linear layer were regularized by using 30 % dropouts .
heading: A padding vector was inserted when padding .

text: We evaluated three different variations of NSE show in .

text: The NSE model encodes each sentence simultaneously by using a separate memory for each sentence .

text: The second model - MMA - NSE first encodes the premise and then the hypothesis sentence by sharing the premise encoded memory in addition to the hypothesis memory .
heading: A padding vector was inserted when padding .

text: Machine Translation
Lastly , we conducted an experiment on neural machine translation ( NMT ) .
heading: Machine Translation

text: The NMT problem is mostly defined within the encoder - decoder framework .
heading: Machine Translation

text: The encoder provides the semantic and syntactic information about the source sentences to the decoder and the decoder generates the target sentences by conditioning on this information and its partially produced translation .
heading: Machine Translation

text: For an efficient encoding , the attention - based NTM was introduced .
heading: Machine Translation

text: For NTM , we implemented three different models .
The first model is a baseline model and is similar to the one proposed in ( RNNSearch ) .
heading: For NTM , we implemented three different models .

text: This model ( LSTM - LSTM ) has two LSTM for the encoder / decoder and has the soft attention neural net , which attends over the source sentence and constructs a focused encoding vector for each target word .
heading: For NTM , we implemented three different models .

text: The second model is an NSE - LSTM encoder - decoder which encodes the source sentence with NSE and generates the targets with the LSTM network by using the NSE output states and the attention network .
heading: For NTM , we implemented three different models .

text: The last model is an NSE - NSE setup , where the encoding part is the same as the NSE - LSTM while the decoder NSE now uses the output state and has an access to the encoder memory , i.e. , the encoder and the decoder NSEs access a shared memory .
heading: For NTM , we implemented three different models .

text: The memory is encoded by the first NSEs and then read / written by the decoder NSEs .
heading: For NTM , we implemented three different models .
