11 5 Qualitative Analysis
heading: We report BLEU score for each models .

text: Memory Access and Compositionality
NSE is capabable of performing multiscale composition by retrieving associative slots fora particular input at a time step .
heading: Memory Access and Compositionality

text: We analyzed the memory access order and the compositionality of memory slot and the input word in the NSE model trained on the SNLI data .
heading: Memory Access and Compositionality

text: shows the word association graphs for the two sentence picked from SNLI test set .
heading: Memory Access and Compositionality

text: The association graph was constructed by inspecting the key vector z .
heading: Memory Access and Compositionality

text: For an input word , we connect it to the most active slot pointed by z 12 .
heading: Memory Access and Compositionality

text: Note the graph components clustered around the semantically rich words : " sits " , " wall " and " autumn " ( a ) and " Three " , " puppies " , " tub " and " vet " ( b ) .
heading: Memory Access and Compositionality

text: The memory slots corresponding to words that are semantically rich in the current context are the most frequently accessed .
heading: Memory Access and Compositionality

text: The graph is able to capture certain syntactic structures including phrases ( e.g. , " hand built rock wall " ) and modifier relations ( between " sits " and " quietly " and between " tub " and " sprayed with water " ) .
heading: Memory Access and Compositionality

text: Another interesting property is that the model tends to perform sensible compositions while processing the input sentence .
heading: Memory Access and Compositionality

text: For example , NSE retrieved the memory slot corresponding to " wall " or " Three " when reading the input " rock " or " are " .
heading: Memory Access and Compositionality

text: In Appendix
A , we show a step - by - step visualization of NSE memory states for the first sentence .
heading: In Appendix

text: Note how the encoding memory is evolved overtime .
In time step four ( t = 4 ) , the memory slot for " quietly " encodes information about " quiet ( ly ) little child " .
heading: Note how the encoding memory is evolved overtime .

text: When t = 6 , the model forms another composition involving " quietly " , " quietly sits " .
heading: Note how the encoding memory is evolved overtime .

text: In the last time step , we are able to find the most or the least frequently accessed slots in the memory .
heading: Note how the encoding memory is evolved overtime .

text: The least accessed slots correspond to function words while the frequently accessed slots are content words and tend to carryout rich semantics and intrinsic compositions found in the input sentence .
heading: Note how the encoding memory is evolved overtime .

text: Overall the model is less constrained and is able to compose multiword expressions .
heading: Note how the encoding memory is evolved overtime .

text: Conclusion
Our proposed memory augmented neural networks have achieved the state - of - the - art results when evaluated on five representative NLP tasks .
heading: Conclusion

text: NSE is capable of building an efficient architecture of the single , shared and multiple memory accesses fora specific NLP task .
heading: Conclusion

text: For example , for the NLI task NSE accesses premise encoded memory when processing hypothesis .
heading: Conclusion

text: For the QA task , NSE accesses answer encoded memory when reading question for QA .
heading: Conclusion

text: In machine translation , NSE shares a single encoded memory between encoder and decoder .
heading: Conclusion

text: Such flexibility in the architectural choice of the NSE memory access allows for the robust models fora better performance .
heading: Conclusion

text: The initial state of the NSE memory stores information about each word in the input sequence .
heading: Conclusion

text: We in this paper used word embeddings to represent the words in the memory .
heading: Conclusion

text: Different variations of word representations such as character - based models are left to be evaluated for memory initialization in the future .
heading: Conclusion

text: We plan to extend NSE so that it learns to select and access a relevant subset from a memory set .
heading: Conclusion

text: One could also explore unsupervised variations of NSE , for example , to train them to produce encoding memory and representation vector of entire sentences or documents using either new or existing models such as the skip - gram model .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
MACHINE COMPREHENSION USING MATCH - LSTM AND ANSWER POINTER
abstract
heading: MACHINE COMPREHENSION USING MATCH - LSTM AND ANSWER POINTER

text: Machine comprehension of text is an important problem in natural language processing .
heading: MACHINE COMPREHENSION USING MATCH - LSTM AND ANSWER POINTER

text: A recently released dataset , the Stanford Question Answering Dataset ( SQuAD ) , offers a large number of real questions and their answers created by humans through crowdsourcing .
heading: MACHINE COMPREHENSION USING MATCH - LSTM AND ANSWER POINTER

text: SQuAD provides a challenging testbed for evaluating machine comprehension algorithms , partly because compared with previous datasets , in SQuAD the answers do not come from a small set of candidate answers and they have variable lengths .
heading: MACHINE COMPREHENSION USING MATCH - LSTM AND ANSWER POINTER

text: We propose an end - to - end neural architecture for the task .
heading: MACHINE COMPREHENSION USING MATCH - LSTM AND ANSWER POINTER

text: The architecture is based on match - LSTM , a model we proposed previously for textual entailment , and Pointer Net , a sequence - to - sequence model proposed by Vinyals et al. ( 2015 ) to constrain the output tokens to be from the input sequences .
heading: MACHINE COMPREHENSION USING MATCH - LSTM AND ANSWER POINTER

text: We propose two ways of using Pointer Net for our task .
heading: MACHINE COMPREHENSION USING MATCH - LSTM AND ANSWER POINTER

text: Our experiments show that both of our two models substantially outperform the best results obtained by Rajpurkar et al. ( 2016 ) using logistic regression and manually crafted features .
heading: MACHINE COMPREHENSION USING MATCH - LSTM AND ANSWER POINTER

text: INTRODUCTION
Machine comprehension of text is one of the ultimate goals of natural language processing .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: While the ability of a machine to understand text can be assessed in many different ways , in recent years , several benchmark datasets have been created to focus on answering questions as away to evaluate machine comprehension .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: In this setup , typically the machine is first presented with apiece of text such as a news article or a story .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: The machine is then expected to answer one or multiple questions related to the text .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: In most of the benchmark datasets , a question can be treated as a multiple choice question , whose correct answer is to be chosen from a set of provided candidate answers .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Presumably , questions with more given candidate answers are more challenging .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: The Stanford Question Answering Dataset ( SQuAD ) introduced recently by contains such more challenging questions whose correct answers can be any sequence of tokens from the given text .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Moreover , unlike some other datasets whose questions and answers were created automatically in Cloze style , the questions and answers in SQu AD were created by humans through crowdsourcing , which makes the dataset more realistic .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Given these advantages of the SQuAD dataset , in this paper , we focus on this new dataset to study machine comprehension of text .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: A sample piece of text and three of its associated questions are shown in .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Traditional solutions to this kind of question answering tasks rely on NLP pipelines that involve multiple steps of linguistic analyses and feature engineering , including syntactic parsing , named entity recognition , question classification , semantic parsing , etc .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Recently , with the advances of applying neural network models in NLP , there has been much interest in building end - to - end neural architectures for various NLP tasks , including several pieces of work on machine comprehension .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: However , given the properties of previous machine comprehension datasets , existing end - to - end neural architectures for the task either rely on the candidate answers or assume that the In 1870 , Tesla moved to Karlovac , to attend school at the Higher Real Gymnasium , where he was profoundly influenced by a math teacher Martin Sekuli ?.
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: The classes were held in German , as it was a school within the Austro-Hungarian Military Frontier .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Tesla was able to perform integral calculus in his head , which prompted his teachers to believe that he was cheating .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: He finished a four - year term in three years , graduating in 1873 .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: In what language were the classes given ?
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: German
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: 2 . Who was Tesla 's main influence in Karlovac ?
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Martin Sekuli ?
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: 3 . Why did Tesla go to Karlovac ?
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: attend school at the Higher Real Gymnasium :
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: A paragraph from Wikipedia and three associated questions together with their answers , taken from the SQuAD dataset .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: The tokens in bold in the paragraph are our predicted answers while the texts next to the questions are the ground truth answers .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: answer is a single token , which make these methods unsuitable for the SQuAD dataset .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: In this paper , we propose anew end - to - end neural architecture to address the machine comprehension problem as defined in the SQuAD dataset .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Specifically , observing that in the SQuAD dataset many questions are paraphrases of sentences from the original text , we adopt a match - LSTM model that we developed earlier for textual entailment .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: We further adopt the Pointer Net ( Ptr - Net ) model developed by , which enables the predictions of tokens from the input sequence only rather than from a larger fixed vocabulary and thus allows us to generate answers that consist of multiple tokens from the original text .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: We propose two ways to apply the Ptr - Net model for our task : a sequence model and a boundary model .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: We also further extend the boundary model with a search mechanism .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Experiments on the SQuAD dataset show that our two models both outperform the best performance reported by .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Moreover , using an ensemble of several of our models , we can achieve very competitive performance on SQuAD .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Our contributions can be summarized as follows :
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: ( 1 ) We propose two new end - to - end neural network models for machine comprehension , which combine match - LSTM and Ptr- Net to handle the special properties of the SQuAD dataset .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: ( 2 ) We have achieved the performance of an exact match score of 67.9 % and an F1 score of 77.0 % on the unseen test dataset , which is much better than the featureengineered solution .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Our performance is also close to the state of the art on SQuAD , which is 71.6 % in terms of exact match and 80.4 % in terms of F1 from Salesforce Research .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: ( 3 ) Our further analyses of the models reveal some useful insights for further improving the method .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Beisdes , we also made our code available online 1 .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: METHOD
In this section , we first briefly review match - LSTM and Pointer Net .
heading: METHOD

text: These two pieces of existing work lay the foundation of our method .
heading: METHOD

text: We then present our end - to - end neural architecture for machine comprehension .
heading: METHOD

text: MATCH - LSTM
I na recent work on learning natural language inference , we proposed a match - LSTM model for predicting textual entailment .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: In textual entailment , two sentences are given where one is a premise and the other is a hypothesis .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: To predict whether the premise entails the hypothesis , the match - LSTM model goes through the tokens of the hypothesis sequentially .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: At each position of the hypothesis , attention mechanism is used to obtain a weighted vector representation of the premise .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: This weighted premise is then to be combined with a vector representation of the current token of the hypothesis and fed into an LSTM , which we call the match - LSTM .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: The match - LSTM essentially sequentially aggregates the matching of the attention - weighted premise to each token of the hypothesis and uses the aggregated matching result to make a final prediction . :
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: An overview of our two models .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: Both models consist of an LSTM preprocessing layer , a match - LSTM layer and an Answer Pointer layer .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: For each match - LSTM in a particular direction , h q i , which is defined as H q ?
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: i , is computed using the ?
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: in the corresponding direction , as described in either Eqn. ( 2 ) or Eqn. ( 5 ) .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: proposed a Pointer Network ( Ptr - Net ) model to solve a special kind of problems where we want to generate an output sequence whose tokens must come from the input sequence .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: Instead of picking an output token from a fixed vocabulary , Ptr - Net uses attention mechanism as a pointer to select a position from the input sequence as an output symbol .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: The pointer mechanism has inspired some recent work on language processing .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: Here we adopt Ptr- Net in order to construct answers using tokens from the input text .
heading: MATCH - LSTM

text: POINTER NET
OUR METHOD
Formally , the problem we are trying to solve can be formulated as follows .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: We are given apiece of text , which we refer to as a passage , and a question related to the passage .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: The passage is represented by matrix P ?
heading: OUR METHOD

text: R dP , where P is the length ( number of tokens ) of the passage and dis the dimensionality of word embeddings .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: Similarly , the question is represented by matrix Q ?
heading: OUR METHOD

text: R d Q where Q is the length of the question .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: Our goal is to identify a subsequence from the passage as the answer to the question .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: As pointed out earlier , since the output tokens are from the input , we would like to adopt the Pointer Net for this problem .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: A straightforward way of applying Ptr - Net here is to treat an answer as a sequence of tokens from the input passage but ignore the fact that these tokens are consecutive in the original passage , because Ptr - Net does not make the consecutivity assumption .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: Specifically , we represent the answer as a sequence of integers a = ( a 1 , a 2 , . . . ) , where each a i is an integer between 1 and P , indicating a certain position in the passage .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: Alternatively , if we want to ensure consecutivity , that is , if we want to ensure that we indeed select a subsequence from the passage as an answer , we can use the Ptr-Net to predict only the start and the end of an answer .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: In this case , the Ptr - Net only needs to select two tokens from the input passage , and all the tokens between these two tokens in the passage are treated as the answer .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: Specifically , we can represent the answer to be predicted as two integers a = ( a s , a e ) , where a s an a e are integers between 1 and P .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: We refer to the first setting above as a sequence model and the second setting above as a boundary model .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: For either model , we assume that a set of training examples in the form of triplets {( P n , Q n , an ) } N n=1 are given .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: An overview of the two neural network models are shown in .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: Both models consist of three layers :
heading: OUR METHOD

text: ( 1 ) An LSTM preprocessing layer that preprocesses the passage and the question using LSTMs .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: ( 2 ) A match - LSTM layer that tries to match the passage against the question .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: ( 3 ) An Answer Pointer ( Ans - Ptr ) layer that uses Ptr-Net to select a set of tokens from the passage as the answer .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: The difference between the two models only lies in the third layer .
heading: OUR METHOD

text: LSTM
Preprocessing Layer
heading: LSTM

text: The purpose for the LSTM preprocessing layer is to incorporate contextual information into the representation of each token in the passage and the question .
heading: LSTM

text: We use a standard one - directional LSTM 2 to process the passage and the question separately , as shown below :
heading: LSTM

heading: LSTM

text: R lQ are hidden representations of the passage and the question , where l is the dimensionality of the hidden vectors .
heading: LSTM

text: In other words , the i th column vector hp i ( or h q i ) in H p ( or H q ) represents the i th token in the passage ( or the question ) together with some contextual information from the left .
heading: LSTM

text: We apply the match - LSTM model proposed for textual entailment to our machine comprehension problem by treating the question as a premise and the passage as a hypothesis .

heading: LSTM

heading: LSTM

text: The top layer , the Answer Pointer ( Ans - Ptr ) layer , is motivated by the Pointer Net introduced by .

text: Recall that we have two different models :

text: The sequence model produces a sequence of answer tokens but these tokens may not be consecutive in the original passage .
heading: LSTM

text: The boundary model produces only the start token and the end token of the answer , and then all the tokens between these two in the original passage are considered to be the answer .
heading: LSTM

text: We now explain the two models separately .

text: The Sequence Model :

text: The boundary model works in away very similar to the sequence model above , except that instead of predicting a sequence of indices a 1 , a 2 , . . . , we only need to predict two indices a sand a e .

Here " Search " refers to globally searching the spans with no more than 15 tokens , " b " refers to using bi-directional pre-processing LSTM , and " en " refers to ensemble method .

text: EXPERIMENTS
In this section , we present our experiment results and perform some analyses to better understand how our models works .
heading: EXPERIMENTS

text: DATA
We use the Stanford Question Answering Dataset ( SQuAD ) v 1.1 to conduct our experiments .
heading: DATA

text: Passages in SQuAD come from 536 articles from Wikipedia covering a wide range of topics .
heading: DATA

text: Each passage is a single paragraph from a Wikipedia article , and each passage has around 5 questions associated with it .
heading: DATA

text: In total , there are 23,215 passages and 107,785 questions .
heading: DATA

text: The data has been split into a training set ( with 87,599 question - answer pairs ) , a development set ( with 10,570 questionanswer pairs ) and a hidden test set .
heading: DATA

text: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS
We first tokenize all the passages , questions and answers .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: The resulting vocabulary contains 117K unique words .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: We use word embeddings from GloVe to initialize the model .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: Words not found in Glo Ve are initialized as zero vectors .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: The word embeddings are not updated during the training of the model .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: The dimensionality l of the hidden layers is set to be 150 or 300 .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: We use ADAMAX with the coefficients ? 1 = 0.9 and ? 2 = 0.999 to optimize the model .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: Each update is computed through a minibatch of 30 instances .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: We do not use L2-regularization .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: The performance is measured by two metrics : percentage of exact match with the ground truth answers , and word - level F 1 score when comparing the tokens in the predicted answers with the tokens in the ground truth answers .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: Note that in the development set and the test set each question has around three ground truth answers .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: F1 scores with the best matching answers are used to compute the average F1 score .
heading: EXPERIMENT SETTINGS

text: RESULTS
The results of our models as well as the results of the baselines given by and are shown in .
heading: RESULTS

text: We can see that both of our two models have clearly outper - :
heading: RESULTS

text: Visualization of the attention weights ?
heading: RESULTS

text: for three questions associated with the same passage .
heading: RESULTS

text: outperformed the logistic regression model by , which relies on carefully designed features .
heading: RESULTS

text: Furthermore , our boundary model has outperformed the sequence model , achieving an exact match score of 61.1 % and an F1 score of 71.2 % .
heading: RESULTS

text: In particular , in terms of the exact match score , the boundary model has a clear advantage over the sequence model .
heading: RESULTS

text: The improvement of our models over the logistic regression model shows that our end - to - end neural network models without much feature engineering are very effective on this task and this dataset .
heading: RESULTS

text: Considering the effectiveness of boundary model , we further explore this model .
heading: RESULTS

text: Observing that most of the answers are the spans with relatively small sizes , we simply limit the largest predicted span to have no more than 15 tokens and conducted experiment with span searching
heading: RESULTS

text: This resulted in 1.5 % improvement in F1 on the development data and that outperformed the DCR model , which also introduced some language features such as POS and NE into their model .
heading: RESULTS

text: Besides , we tried to increase the memory dimension l in the model or add bi-directional pre-processing LSTM or add bi-directional Ans - Ptr .
heading: RESULTS

text: The improvement on the development data using the first two methods is quite small .
heading: RESULTS

text: While by adding Bi - Ans - Ptr with bi-directional pre-processing LSTM , we can get 1.2 % improvement in F1 .
heading: RESULTS

text: Finally , we explore the ensemble method by simply computing the product of the boundary probabilities collected from 5 boundary models and then searching the most likely span with no more than 15 tokens .
heading: RESULTS

text: This ensemble method achieved the best performance as shown in the table .
heading: RESULTS

text: FURTHER ANALYSES
To better understand the strengths and weaknesses of our models , we perform some further analyses of the results below .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: First , we suspect that longer answers are harder to predict .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: To verify this hypothesis , we analysed the performance in terms of both exact match and F 1 score with respect to the answer length on the development set .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: For example , for questions whose answers contain more than 9 tokens , the F 1 score of the boundary model drops to around 55 % and the exact match score drops to only around 30 % , compared to the F 1 score and exact match score of close to 72 % and 67 % , respectively , for questions with single - token answers .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: And that supports our hypothesis .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: Next , we analyze the performance of our models on different groups of questions .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: We use a crude way to split the questions into different groups based on a set of question words we have defined , including " what , " " how , " " who , " " when , " " which , " " where , " and " why . "
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: These different question words roughly refer to questions with different types of answers .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: For example , " when " questions look for temporal expressions as answers , whereas " where " questions look for locations as answers .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: According to the performance on the development data set , our models work the best for " when " questions .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: This maybe because in this dataset temporal expressions are relatively easier to recognize .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: Other groups of questions whose answers are noun phrases , such as " what " questions , " which " questions and " where " questions , also get relatively better results .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: On the other hand , " why " questions are the hardest to answer .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: This is not surprising because the answers to " why " questions can be very diverse , and they are not restricted to any certain type of phrases .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: Finally , we would like to check whether the attention mechanism used in the match - LSTM layer is effective in helping the model locate the answer .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: We show the attention weights ?
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: in .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: In the figure the darker the color is the higher the weight is .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: We can see that some words have been well aligned based on the attention weights .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: For example , the word " German " in the passage is aligned well to the word " language " in the first question , and the model successfully predicts " German " as the answer to the question .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: For the question word " who " in the second question , the word " teacher " actually receives relatively higher attention weight , and the model has predicted the phrase " Martin Sekulic " after that as the answer , which is correct .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: For the last question that starts with " why " , the attention weights are more evenly distributed and it is not clear which words have been aligned to " why " .
heading: FURTHER ANALYSES

text: RELATED WORK
Machine comprehension of text has gained much attention in recent years , and increasingly researchers are building data - drive , end - to - end neural network models for the task .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: We will first review the recently released datasets and then some end - to - end models on this task .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: DATASETS
A number of datasets for studying machine comprehension were created in Cloze style by removing a single token from a sentence in the original corpus , and the task is to predict the missing word .
heading: DATASETS

text: was also created by human annotators .
heading: DATASETS

text: Different from the previous two , however , the SQuAD dataset does not provide candidate answers , and thus all possible subsequences from the given passage have to be considered as candidate answers .
heading: DATASETS

text: Besides the datasets above , there are also a few other datasets created for machine comprehension , such as WikiReading dataset and bAbI dataset , but they are quite different from the datasets above in nature .
heading: DATASETS

text: END- TO- END NEURAL NETWORK MODELS FOR MACHINE COMPREHENSION
There have been a number of studies proposing end - to - end neural network models for machine comprehension .
heading: END- TO- END NEURAL NETWORK MODELS FOR MACHINE COMPREHENSION

text: A common approach is to use recurrent neural networks ( RNNs ) to process the given text and the question in order to predictor generate the answers .
heading: END- TO- END NEURAL NETWORK MODELS FOR MACHINE COMPREHENSION

text: Attention mechanism is also widely used on top of RNNs in order to match the question with the given passage .
heading: END- TO- END NEURAL NETWORK MODELS FOR MACHINE COMPREHENSION

text: Given that answers often come from the given passage , Pointer Network has been adopted in a few studies in order to copy tokens from the given passage as answers .
heading: END- TO- END NEURAL NETWORK MODELS FOR MACHINE COMPREHENSION

text: Compared with existing work , we use match - LSTM to match a question and a given passage , and we use Pointer Network in a different way such that we can generate answers that contain multiple tokens from the given passage .
heading: END- TO- END NEURAL NETWORK MODELS FOR MACHINE COMPREHENSION

text: CONCLUSIONS
In this paper , We developed two models for the machine comprehension problem defined in the Stanford Question Answering ( SQuAD ) dataset , both making use of match - LSTM and Pointer Network .
heading: CONCLUSIONS

text: Experiments on the SQuAD dataset showed that our second model , the boundary model , could achieve an exact match score of 67.6 % and an F 1 score of 77 % on the test dataset , which is better than our sequence model and 's feature - engineered model .
heading: CONCLUSIONS

text: In the future , we plan to look further into the different types of questions and focus on those questions which currently have low performance , such as the " why ' questions .
heading: CONCLUSIONS

text: We also plan to test how our models could be applied to other machine comprehension datasets .
heading: CONCLUSIONS

text: shows the numbers of answers with different lengths .
heading: CONCLUSIONS

text: Bottom : Plot ( 3 ) shows the performance our the two models on different types of questions .
heading: CONCLUSIONS

text: Plot ( 4 ) shows the numbers of different types of questions .
heading: CONCLUSIONS

text: A APPENDIX
We show the performance breakdown by answer lengths and question types for our sequence model , boundary model and the ensemble model in .
heading: A APPENDIX

text: title
LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING
abstract
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: The reading comprehension task , that asks questions about a given evidence document , is a central problem in natural language understanding .
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: Recent formulations of this task have typically focused on answer selection from a set of candidates pre-defined manually or through the use of an external NLP pipeline .
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: However , Rajpurkar et al . ( 2016 ) recently released the SQUAD dataset in which the answers can be arbitrary strings from the supplied text .
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: In this paper , we focus on this answer extraction task , presenting a novel model architecture that efficiently builds fixed length representations of all spans in the evidence document with a recurrent network .
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: We show that scoring explicit span representations significantly improves performance over other approaches that factor the prediction into separate predictions about words or start and end markers .
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: Our approach improves upon the best published results of Wang & Jiang ( 2016 ) by 5 % and decreases the error of Rajpurkar et al. 's baseline by > 50 %.
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: Recently , Rajpurkar et al. ( 2016 ) released the less restricted SQUAD dataset 1 that does not place any constraints on the set of allowed answers , other than that they should be drawn from the evidence document .
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: Rajpurkar et al. proposed a baseline system that chooses answers from the constituents identified by an existing syntactic parser .
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: This allows them to prune the O ( N 2 ) answer candidates in each document of length N , but it also effectively renders 20.7 % of all questions unanswerable .
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: Subsequent work by Wang & Jiang ( 2016 ) significantly improve upon this baseline by using an endto - end neural network architecture to identify answer spans by labeling either individual words , or the start and end of the answer span .
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: Both of these methods do not make independence assumptions about substructures , but they are susceptible to search errors due to greedy training and decoding .
heading: LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING
LEARNING RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATIONS FOR EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING

text: INTRODUCTION
A primary goal of natural language processing is to develop systems that can answer questions about the contents of documents .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: The reading comprehension task is of practical interest - we want computers to be able to read the world 's text and then answer our questions - and , since we believe it requires deep language understanding , it has also become a flagship task in NLP research .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: A number of reading comprehension datasets have been developed that focus on answer selection from a small set of alternatives defined by annotators or existing NLP pipelines that can not be trained end - to - end .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: Subsequently , the models proposed for this task have tended to make use of the limited set of candidates , basing their predictions on mention - level attention weights , or centering classifiers , or network memories on candidate locations .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: In contrast , here we argue that it is beneficial to simplify the decoding procedure by enumerating all possible answer spans .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: By explicitly representing each answer span , our model can be globally normalized during training and decoded exactly during evaluation .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: A naive approach to building the O ( N 2 ) spans of up to length N would require a network that is cubic in size with respect to the passage length , and such a network would be untrainable .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: To overcome this , we present a novel neural architecture called RASOR that builds fixed - length span representations , reusing recurrent computations for shared substructures .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: We demonstrate that directly classifying each of the competing spans , and training with global normalization overall possible spans , leads to a significant increase in performance .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: In our experiments , we show an increase in performance over of 5 % in terms of exact match to a reference answer , and 3.6 % in terms of predicted answer F1 with respect to the reference .
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: On both of these metrics , we close the gap between Rajpurkar et al. 's baseline and the human - performance upper-bound by > 50 %.
heading: INTRODUCTION

text: EXTRACTIVE QUESTION ANSWERING
TASK DEFINITION

Extractive question answering systems take as input a question q = {q 0 , . . . , q n } and a passage of text p = {p 0 , . . . , pm } from which they predict a single answer span a = a start , a end , represented as a pair of indices into p.
heading: TASK DEFINITION

text: Machine learned extractive question answering systems , such as the one presented here , learn a predictor function f ( q , p ) ?
heading: TASK DEFINITION

text: a from a training dataset of q , p , a triples .
heading: TASK DEFINITION

text: RELATED WORK
For the SQUAD dataset , the original paper from implemented a linear model with sparse features based on n-grams and part - of - speech tags present in the question and the candidate answer .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: Other than lexical features , they also used syntactic information in the form of dependency paths to extract more general features .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: They set a strong baseline for following work and also presented an in depth analysis , showing that lexical and syntactic features contribute most strongly to their model 's performance .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: Subsequent work by use an end - to - end neural network method that uses a Match - LSTM to model the question and the passage , and uses pointer networks to extract the answer span from the passage .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: This model resorts to greedy decoding and falls short in terms of performance compared to our model ( see Section 5 for more detail ) .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: While we only compare to published baselines , there are other unpublished competitive systems on the SQUAD leaderboard , as listed in footnote
heading: RELATED WORK

text: A task that is closely related to extractive question answering is the Cloze task , in which the goal is to predict a concealed span from a declarative sentence given a passage of supporting text .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: presented a Cloze dataset in which the task is to predict the correct entity in an incomplete sentence given an abstractive summary of a news article .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: Hermann et al .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: also present various neural architectures to solve the problem .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: Although this dataset is large and varied in domain , recent analysis by shows that simple models can achieve close to the human upper bound .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: As noted by the authors of the SQUAD paper , the annotated answers in the SQUAD dataset are often spans that include non-entities and can be longer phrases , unlike the Cloze datasets , thus making the task more challenging .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: Another , more traditional line of work has focused on extractive question answering on sentences , where the task is to extract a sentence from a document , given a question .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: Relevant datasets include datasets from the annual TREC evaluations and WikiQA , where the latter dataset specifically focused on Wikipedia passages .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: There has been a line of interesting recent publications using neural architectures , focused on this variety of extractive question answering .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: These methods model the question and a candidate answer sentence , but do not focus on possible candidate answer spans that may contain the answer to the given question .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: In this work , we focus on the more challenging problem of extracting the precise answer span .
heading: RELATED WORK

text: MODEL
We propose a model architecture called RASOR 2 illustrated in , that explicitly computes embedding representations for candidate answer spans .
heading: MODEL

text: In most structured prediction problems ( e.g. sequence labeling or parsing ) , the number of possible output structures is exponential in the input length , and computing representations for every candidate is prohibitively expensive .
heading: MODEL

text: However , we exploit the simplicity of our task , where we can trivially and tractably enumerate all candidates .
heading: MODEL

text: This facilitates an expressive model that computes joint representations of every answer span , that can be globally normalized during learning .
heading: MODEL

text: In order to compute these span representations , we must aggregate information from the passage and the question for every answer candidate .
heading: MODEL

text: For the example in , RASOR computes an embedding for the candidate answer spans : fixed to , fixed to the , to the , etc .
heading: MODEL

text: A naive approach for these aggregations would require a network that is cubic in size with respect to the passage length .
heading: MODEL

text: Instead , our model reduces this to a quadratic size by reusing recurrent computations for shared substructures ( i.e. common passage words ) from different spans .
heading: MODEL

text: Since the choice of answer span depends on the original question , we must incorporate this information into the computation of the span representation .
heading: MODEL

text: We model this by augmenting the passage word embeddings with additional embedding representations of the question .
heading: MODEL

text: In this section , we motivate and describe the architecture for RASOR in a top - down manner .
heading: MODEL

text: SCORING ANSWER SPANS
The goal of our extractive question answering system is to predict the single best answer span among all candidates from the passage p , denoted as A ( p ) .
heading: SCORING ANSWER SPANS

text: Therefore , we define a probability distribution overall possible answer spans given the question q and passage p , and the predictor function finds the answer span with the maximum likelihood :
heading: SCORING ANSWER SPANS

text: One might be tempted to introduce independence assumptions that would enable cheaper decoding .
heading: SCORING ANSWER SPANS

text: For example , this distribution can be modeled as ( 1 ) a product of conditionally independent distributions ( binary ) for every word or ( 2 ) a product of conditionally independent distributions ( over words ) for the start and end indices of the answer span .
heading: SCORING ANSWER SPANS

text: However , we show in Section 5.2 that such independence assumptions hurt the accuracy of the model , and instead we only assume a fixed - length representation ha of each candidate span that is scored and normalized with a softmax layer ( Span score and Softmax in ) :
heading: SCORING ANSWER SPANS

text: where FFNN ( ) denotes a fully connected feed - forward neural network that provides a non-linear mapping of its input embedding .
heading: SCORING ANSWER SPANS

text: RASOR : RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATION
The previously defined probability distribution depends on the answer span representations , ha .
heading: RASOR : RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATION

text: When computing ha , we assume access to representations of individual passage words that have been augmented with a representation of the question .
heading: RASOR : RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATION

text: We denote these question - focused passage word embeddings as {p * 1 , . . . , p * m } and describe their creation in Section 3.3 .
heading: RASOR : RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATION

text: In order to reuse computation for shared substructures , we use a bidirectional LSTM to encode the left and right context of every p * i ( Passage - level BiLSTM in ) .
heading: RASOR : RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATION

text: This allows us to simply concatenate the bidirectional LSTM ( BiLSTM ) outputs at the endpoints of a span to jointly encode its inside and outside information ( Span embedding in :
heading: RASOR : RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATION

text: where BILSTM ( ) denotes a BiLSTM over it s input embedding sequence and p * i is the concatenation of forward and backward outputs at time - step i .
heading: RASOR : RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATION

text: While the visualization in shows a single layer BiLSTM for simplicity , we use a multi - layer BiLSTM in our experiments .
heading: RASOR : RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATION

text: The concatenated output of each layer is used as input for the subsequent layer , allowing the upper layers to depend on the entire passage .
heading: RASOR : RECURRENT SPAN REPRESENTATION

text: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING
Computing the question - focused passage word embeddings {p * 1 , . . . , p * m } requires integrating question information into the passage .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: The architecture for this integration is flexible and likely depends on the nature of the dataset .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: For the SQUAD dataset , we find that both passage - aligned and passageindependent question representations are effective at incorporating this contextual information , and experiments will show that their benefits are complementary .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: To incorporate these question representations , we simply concatenate them with the passage word embeddings ( Question - focused passage word embedding in ) .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: We use fixed pretrained embeddings to represent question and passage words .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: Therefore , in the following discussion , notation for the words are interchangeable with their embedding representations .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: Question - independent passage word embedding
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: The first component simply looks up the pretrained word embedding for the passage word , pi .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: Passage - aligned question representation
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: In this dataset , the question - passage pairs often contain large lexical overlap or similarity near the correct answer span .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: To encourage the model to exploit these similarities , we include a fixed - length representation of the question based on soft - alignments with the passage word .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: The alignments are computed via neural attention , and we use the variant proposed by , where attention scores are dot products between non-linear mappings of word embeddings .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: q align i = n j=1 a ij q j
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: Passage - independent question representation
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: We also include a representation of the question that does not depend on the passage and is shared for all passage words .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: Similar to the previous question representation , an attention score is computed via a dot -product , except the question word is compared to a universal learned embedding rather any particular passage word .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: Additionally , we incorporate contextual information with a BiLSTM before aggregating the outputs using this attention mechanism .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: The goal is to generate a coarse - grained summary of the question that depends on word order .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: Formally , the passage - independent question representation q indep is computed as follows :
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: This representation is a bidirectional generalization of the question representation recently proposed by fora different question - answering task .
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: Given the above three components , the complete question - focused passage word embedding for pi is their concatenation :
heading: QUESTION - FOCUSED PASSAGE WORD EMBEDDING

text: LEARNING
Given the above model specification , learning is straightforward .
heading: LEARNING

text: We simply maximize the loglikelihood of the correct answer candidates and backpropagate the errors end - to - end .
heading: LEARNING

text: EXPERIMENTAL SETUP
We represent each of the words in the question and document using 300 dimensional GloVe embeddings trained on a corpus of 840 bn words .
heading: EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

text: These embeddings cover 200 k words and all out of vocabulary ( OOV ) words are projected onto one of 1 m randomly initialized 300d embeddings .
heading: EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

text: We couple the input and forget gates in our LSTMs , as described in , and we use a single dropout mask to apply dropout across all LSTM time - steps as proposed by .
heading: EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

text: Hidden layers in the feed forward neural networks use rectified linear units .
heading: EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

text: Answer candidates are limited to spans with at most 30 words .
heading: EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

text: To choose the final model configuration , we ran grid searches over : the dimensionality of the LSTM hidden states ; the width and depth of the feed forward neural networks ; dropout for the LSTMs ; the number of stacked LSTM layers ; and the decay multiplier [ 0.9 , 0.95 , 1.0 ] with which we multiply the learning rate every 10 k steps .
heading: EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

text: The best model uses 50d LSTM states ; two - layer BiLSTMs for the span encoder and the passage - independent question representation ; dropout of 0.1 throughout ; and a learning rate decay of 5 % every 10 k steps .
heading: EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

text: All models are implemented using TensorFlow 3 and trained on the SQUAD training set using the ADAM optimizer with a mini-batch size of 4 and trained using 10 asynchronous training threads on a single machine .
heading: EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

text: RESULTS
We train on the 80 k ( question , passage , answer span ) triples in the SQUAD training set and report results on the 10k examples in the SQUAD development and test sets .
heading: RESULTS

text: All results are calculated using the official SQUAD evaluation script , which reports exact answer match and F1 overlap of the unigrams between the predicted answer and the closest labeled answer from the 3 reference answers given in the SQUAD development set .
heading: RESULTS

text: COMPARISONS TO OTHER WORK
Our model with recurrent span representations ( RASOR ) is compared to all previously published systems
heading: COMPARISONS TO OTHER WORK

text: 4 . published a logistic regression baseline as well as human performance on the SQUAD task .
heading: COMPARISONS TO OTHER WORK

text: The logistic regression baseline uses the output of an existing syntactic parser both as a constraint on the set of allowed answer spans , and as a method of creating sparse features for an answer -centric scoring model .
heading: COMPARISONS TO OTHER WORK

text: Despite not having access to any external representation of linguistic structure , RASOR achieves an error reduction of more than 50 % over this baseline , both in terms of exact match and F1 , relative to the human performance upper bound .
heading: COMPARISONS TO OTHER WORK

text: More closely related to RASOR is the boundary model with Match - LSTMs and Pointer Networks by .
heading: COMPARISONS TO OTHER WORK

text: Their model similarly uses recurrent networks to learn embeddings of each passage word in the context of the question , and it can also capture interactions between endpoints , since the end index probability distribution is conditioned on the start index .
heading: COMPARISONS TO OTHER WORK

text: However , both training and evaluation are greedy , making their system susceptible to search errors when decoding .
heading: COMPARISONS TO OTHER WORK

text: In contrast , RASOR can efficiently and explicitly model the quadratic number of possible answers , which leads to a 14 % error reduction over the best performing Match - LSTM model .
heading: COMPARISONS TO OTHER WORK

text: MODEL VARIATIONS
We investigate two main questions in the following ablations and comparisons .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: ( 1 ) How important are the two methods of representing the question described in Section 3.3 ?
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: ( 2 ) What is the impact of learning a loss function that accurately reflects the span prediction task ?
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Question representations shows the performance of RASOR when either of the two question representations described in Section 3.3 is removed .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: The passage - aligned question representation is crucial , since lexically similar regions of the passage provide strong signal for relevant answer spans .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: If the question is only integrated through the inclusion of a passage - independent representation , performance drops drastically .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: The passage - independent question representation over the BiLSTM is less important , but it still accounts for over 3 % exact match and F 1 .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: The input of both of these components is analyzed qualitatively in Section 6 .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Question representation EM F1
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Only passage - independent 48.7 56.6 Only passage - aligned 63.1 71.3 RASOR 66.4 74.9
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: ( a ) Ablation of question representations .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Learning objective EM F1
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Membership prediction 57.9 69.7 BIO sequence prediction 63.9 73.0 Endpoints prediction 65.3 75.1 Span prediction w/ log loss 65.2 73.6 ( b ) Comparisons for different learning objectives given the same passage - level BiLSTM .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Learning objectives
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Given a fixed architecture that is capable of encoding the input questionpassage pairs , there are many ways of setting up a learning objective to encourage the model to predict the correct span .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: In , we provide comparisons of some alternatives ( learned end - toend ) given only the passage - level BiLSTM from RASOR .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: In order to provide clean comparisons , we restrict the alternatives to objectives that are trained and evaluated with exact decoding .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: The simplest alternative is to consider this task as binary classification for every word ( Membership prediction in ) .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: In this baseline , we optimize the logistic loss for binary labels indicating whether passage words belong to the correct answer span .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: At prediction time , a valid span can be recovered in linear time by finding the maximum contiguous sum of scores .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: proposed a sequence - labeling scheme that is similar to the above baseline ( BIO sequence prediction in ) .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: We follow their proposed model and learn a conditional random field ( CRF ) layer after the passage - level BiLSTM to model transitions between the different labels .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: At prediction time , a valid span can be recovered in linear time using Viterbi decoding , with hard transition constraints to enforce a single contiguous output .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: We also consider a model that independently predicts the two endpoints of the answer span ( Endpoints prediction in ) .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: This model uses the softmax loss over passage words during learning .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: When decoding , we only need to enforce the constraint that the start index is no greater than the end index .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Without the interactions between the endpoints , this can be computed in linear time .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Note that this model has the same expressivity as RASOR if the span - level FFNN were removed .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Lastly , we compare with a model using the same architecture as RASOR but is trained with a binary logistic loss rather than a softmax loss over spans ( Span prediction w/ logistic loss in ) .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: The trend in shows that the model is better at leveraging the supervision as the learning objective more accurately reflects the fundamental task at hand : determining the best answer span .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: First , we observe general improvements when using labels that closely align with the task .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: For example , the labels for membership prediction simply happens to provide single contiguous spans in the supervision .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: The model must consider far more possible answers than it needs to ( the power set of all words ) .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: The same problem holds for BIO sequence predictionthe model must do additional work to learn the semantics of the BIO tags .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: On the other hand , in RASOR , the semantics of an answer span is naturally encoded by the set of labels .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Second , we observe the importance of allowing interactions between the endpoints using the spanlevel FFNN .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: RASOR outperforms the endpoint prediction model by 1.1 inexact match , The interaction between endpoints enables RASOR to enforce consistency across its two substructures .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: While this does not provide improvements for predicting the correct region of the answer ( captured by the F1 metric , which drops by 0.2 ) , it is more likely to predict a clean answer span that matches human judgment exactly ( captured by the exact - match metric ) .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: shows how the performances of RASOR and the endpoint predictor introduced in Section 5.2 degrade as the lengths of their predictions increase .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: It is clear that explicitly modeling interactions between end markers is increasingly important as the span grows in length .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: The passageindependent question representation pays most attention to the words that could attach to the answer in the passage ( " brought " , " against " ) or describe the answer category ( " people " ) .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: Meanwhile , the passage - aligned question representation pays attention to similar words .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: The top predictions for both examples are all valid syntactic constituents , and they all have the correct semantic category .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: However , RASOR assigns almost as much probability mass to it 's incorrect third prediction " British " as it does to the top scoring correct prediction " Egyptian " .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: This showcases a common failure case for RASOR , where it can find an answer of the correct type close to a phrase that overlaps with the question - but it can not accurately represent the semantic dependency on that phrase .
heading: MODEL VARIATIONS

text: ANALYSIS
CONCLUSION
We have shown a novel approach for perform extractive question answering on the SQUAD dataset by explicitly representing and scoring answer span candidates .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: The core of our model relies on a recurrent network that enables shared computation for the shared substructure across span candidates .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: We explore different methods of encoding the passage and question , showing the benefits of including both passage - independent and passage - aligned question representations .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: While we show that this encoding method is beneficial for the task , this is orthogonal to the core contribution of efficiently computing span representation .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: In future work , we plan to explore alternate architectures that provide input to the recurrent span representations .
heading: CONCLUSION

text: title
End - to - End Relation Extraction using LSTMs on Sequences and Tree Structures
heading: title

text: abstract
We present a novel end - to - end neural model to extract entities and relations between them .
heading: abstract

text: Our recurrent neural network based model captures both word sequence and dependency tree substructure information by stacking bidirectional treestructured LSTM - RNNs on bidirectional sequential LSTM - RNNs .
heading: abstract

text: This allows our model to jointly represent both entities and relations with shared parameters in a single model .
heading: abstract

text: We further encourage detection of entities during training and use of entity information in relation extraction via entity pretraining and scheduled sampling .
heading: abstract

text: Our model improves over the stateof - the - art feature - based model on end -toend relation extraction , achieving 12.1 % and 5.7 % relative error reductions in F1score on ACE2005 and ACE2004 , respectively .
heading: abstract

text: We also show that our LSTM - RNN based model compares favorably to the state - of - the - art CNN based model ( in F1-score ) on nominal relation classification ( Sem Eval - 2010 Task 8 ) .
heading: abstract

text: Finally , we present an extensive ablation analysis of several model components .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Extracting semantic relations between entities in text is an important and well - studied task in information extraction and natural language processing ( NLP ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Traditional systems treat this task as a pipeline of two separated tasks , i.e. , named entity recognition ( NER ) ) and relation extraction , but recent studies show that end - to - end ( joint ) modeling of entity and relation is important for high performance since relations interact closely with entity information .
heading: Introduction

text: For instance , to learn that Toefting and Bolton have an Organization - Affiliation ( ORG - AFF ) relation in the sentence Toefting transferred to Bolton , the entity information that Toefting and Bolton are Person and Organization entities is important .
heading: Introduction

text: Extraction of these entities is in turn encouraged by the presence of the context words transferred to , which indicate an employment relation .
heading: Introduction

text: Previous joint models have employed feature - based structured learning .
heading: Introduction

text: An alternative approach to this end - to - end relation extraction task is to employ automatic feature learning via neural network ( NN ) based models .
heading: Introduction

text: There are two ways to represent relations between entities using neural networks : recurrent / recursive neural networks ( RNNs ) and convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Among these , RNNs can directly represent essential linguistic structures , i.e. , word sequences and constituent / dependency trees .
heading: Introduction

text: Despite this representation ability , for relation classification tasks , the previously reported performance using long short - term memory ( LSTM ) based RNNs is worse than one using CNNs .
heading: Introduction

text: These previous LSTM - based systems mostly include limited linguistic structures and neural architectures , and do not model entities and relations jointly .
heading: Introduction

text: We are able to achieve improvements over state - of - the - art models via endto - end modeling of entities and relations based on richer LSTM - RNN architectures that incorporate complementary linguistic structures .
heading: Introduction

text: Word sequence and tree structure are known to be complementary information for extracting relations .
heading: Introduction

text: For instance , dependencies between words are not enough to predict that source and U.S. have an ORG - AFF relation in the sentence " This is ... " , one U.S. source said , and the context word said is required for this prediction .
heading: Introduction

text: Many traditional , feature - based relation classification models extract features from both sequences and parse trees .
heading: Introduction

text: However , previous RNNbased models focus on only one of these linguistic structures .
heading: Introduction

text: We present a novel end - to - end model to extract relations between entities on both word sequence and dependency tree structures .
heading: Introduction

text: Our model allows joint modeling of entities and relations in a single model by using both bidirectional sequential ( left - to - right and right - to - left ) and bidirectional tree - structured ( bottom - up and top - down ) LSTM - RNNs .
heading: Introduction

text: Our model first detects entities and then extracts relations between the detected entities using a single incrementally - decoded NN structure , and the NN parameters are jointly updated using both entity and relation labels .
heading: Introduction

text: Unlike traditional incremental end - to - end relation extraction models , our model further incorporates two enhancements into training : entity pretraining , which pretrains the entity model , and scheduled sampling , which replaces ( unreliable ) predicted labels with gold labels in a certain probability .
heading: Introduction

text: These enhancements alleviate the problem of low - performance entity detection in early stages of training , as well as allow entity information to further help downstream relation classification .
heading: Introduction

text: On end - to - end relation extraction , we improve over the state - of - the - art feature - based model , with 12.1 % ( ACE2005 ) and 5.7 % ( ACE2004 ) relative error reductions in F1-score .
heading: Introduction

text: On nominal relation classification ( Sem Eval - 2010 Task 8 ) , our model compares favorably to the state - of - the - art CNNbased model in F1-score .
heading: Introduction

text: Finally , we also ablate and compare our various model components , which leads to some key findings ( both positive and negative ) about the contribution and effectiveness of different RNN structures , input dependency relation structures , different parsing models , external resources , and joint learning settings .
heading: Introduction

text: Related Work
LSTM - RNNs have been widely used for sequential labeling , such as clause identification , phonetic labeling , and NER .
heading: Related Work

text: showed that building a conditional random field ( CRF ) layer on top of bidirectional LSTM - RNNs performs comparably to the state - of - the - art methods in the partof - speech ( POS ) tagging , chunking , and NER .
heading: Related Work

text: For relation classification , in addition to traditional feature / kernel - based approaches , several neural models have been proposed in the , including embedding - based models , , and RNN - based models .
heading: Related Work

text: Recently , and showed that the shortest dependency paths between relation arguments , which were used in feature / kernel - based systems , are also useful in NN - based models .
heading: Related Work

text: also showed that LSTM - RNNs are useful for relation classification , but the performance was worse than CNN - based models .
heading: Related Work

text: compared separate sequence - based and tree - structured LSTM - RNNs on relation classification , using basic RNN model structures .
heading: Related Work

text: Research on tree - structured LSTM - RNNs fixes the direction of information propagation from bottom to top , and also can not handle an arbitrary number of typed children as in a typed dependency tree .
heading: Related Work

text: Furthermore , no RNNbased relation classification model simultaneously uses word sequence and dependency tree information .
heading: Related Work

text: We propose several such novel model structures and training settings , investigating the simultaneous use of bidirectional sequential and bidirectional tree - structured LSTM - RNNs to jointly capture linear and dependency context for end - toend extraction of relations between entities .
heading: Related Work

text: As for end - to - end ( joint ) extraction of relations between entities , all existing models are featurebased systems ( and no NN - based model has been proposed ) .
heading: Related Work

text: Such models include structured prediction , integer linear programming , card - pyramid parsing ( Kate and Mooney , 2010 ) , and global probabilistic graphical models .
heading: Related Work

text: Among these , structured prediction methods are state - of - the - art on several corpora .
heading: Related Work

text: We present an improved , NN - based alternative for the end - to - end relation extraction .
heading: Related Work

text: Model
We design our model with LSTM - RNNs that represent both word sequences and dependency tree structures , and perform end - to - end extraction of relations between entities on top of these RNNs.
heading: Model

text: illustrates the overview of the model .
heading: Model

text: The model mainly consists of three representation layers : a word embeddings layer ( embedding layer ) , a word sequence based LSTM - RNN layer ( sequence layer ) , and finally a dependency subtree based LSTM - RNN layer ( dependency layer ) .
heading: Model

text: During decoding , we build greedy , left - to - right entity detection on the sequence layer and realize relation classification on the dependency layers , where each subtree based LSTM - RNN corresponds to a relation candidate between two detected entities .
heading: Model

text: After decoding the entire model structure , we update the parameters simultaneously via backpropagation through time ( BPTT ) .
heading: Model

text: The dependency layers are stacked on the sequence layer , so the embedding and sequence layers are shared by both entity detection and relation classification , and the shared parameters are affected by both entity and relation labels .
heading: Model

text: Embedding Layer
The embedding layer handles embedding representations .
heading: Embedding Layer

text: n w , n p , n d and n e - dimensional vectors v , v ( p ) , v and v ( e ) are embedded to words , part - of - speech ( POS ) tags , dependency types , and entity labels , respectively .
heading: Embedding Layer

text: Sequence Layer
The sequence layer represents words in a linear sequence using the representations from the embedding layer .
heading: Sequence Layer

text: This layer represents sentential context information and maintains entities , as shown in bottom - left part of .
heading: Sequence Layer

text: We represent the word sequence in a sentence with bidirectional LSTM - RNNs .
heading: Sequence Layer

text: The LSTM unit at t-th word consists of a collection of n ls - dimensional vectors : an input gate it , a forget gate ft , an output gate o t , a memory cell ct , and a hidden state ht .
heading: Sequence Layer

text: Entity Detection
We treat entity detection as a sequence labeling task .
heading: Entity Detection

text: We assign an entity tag to each word using a commonly used encoding scheme BILOU ( Begin , Inside , Last , Outside , Unit ) ( Ratinov and , where each entity tag represents the entity type and the position of a word in the entity .
heading: Entity Detection

text: For example , in , we assign B - PER and L - PER ( which denote the beginning and last words of a person entity type , respectively ) to each word in Sidney Yates to represent this phrase as a PER ( person ) entity type .
heading: Entity Detection

text: We perform entity detection on top of the sequence layer .
heading: Entity Detection

text: We employ a two - layered NN with an n he - dimensional hidden layer h ( e ) and a softmax output layer for entity detection .
heading: Entity Detection

text: Here , Ware weight matrices and bare bias vectors .
heading: Entity Detection

text: We assign entity labels to words in a greedy , left - to - right manner .
heading: Entity Detection

text: 1 During this decoding , we use the predicted label of a word to predict the label of the next word so as to take label dependencies into account .
heading: Entity Detection

text: The NN above receives the concatenation of its corresponding outputs in the sequence layer and the label embedding for its previous word ) .
heading: Entity Detection

text: Dependency Layer

The dependency layer represents a relation between a pair of two target words ( corresponding to a relation candidate in relation classification ) in the dependency tree , and is in charge of relationspecific representations , as is shown in top - right part of .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: This layer mainly focuses on the shortest path between a pair of target words in the dependency tree ( i.e. , the path between the least common node and the two target words ) since these paths are shown to be effective in relation classification .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: For example , we show the shortest path between Yates and Chicago in the bottom of , and this path well captures the key phrase of their relation , i.e. , born in .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: We employ bidirectional tree - structured LSTM - RNNs ( i.e. , bottom - up and top - down ) to represent a relation candidate by capturing the dependency structure around the target word pair .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: This bidirectional structure propagates to each node not only the information from the leaves but also information from the root .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: This is especially important for relation classification , which makes use of argument nodes near the bottom of the tree , and our top - down LSTM - RNN sends information from the top of the tree to such near - leaf nodes ( unlike in standard bottom - up LSTM - RNNs ) .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: 2 Note that the two variants of tree - structured LSTM - RNNs by are notable to represent our target structures which have a variable number of typed children : the Child - Sum Tree - LSTM does not deal with types and the N - ary Tree assumes a fixed number of children .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: We thus propose anew variant of tree - structured LSTM - RNN that shares weight matrices U s for same - type children and also allows variable number of children .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: For this variant , we calculate n lt - dimensional vectors in the LSTM unit at t-th node with C ( t ) children using following equations :
heading: Dependency Layer

text: where m ( ) is a type mapping function .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: To investigate appropriate structures to represent relations between two target word pairs , we experiment with three structure options .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: We primarily employ the shortest path structure ( SP - Tree ) , which captures the core dependency path between a target word pair and is widely used in relation classification models , e.g. , .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: We also try two other dependency structures : SubTree and Full - Tree .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: SubTree is the subtree under the lowest common ancestor of the target word pair .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: This provides additional modifier information to the path and the word pair in SPTree .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: FullTree is the full dependency tree .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: This captures context from the entire sentence .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: While we use one node type for SPTree , we define two node types for SubTree and FullTree , i.e. , one for nodes on shortest paths and one for all other nodes .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: We use the type mapping function m ( ) to distinguish these two nodes types .
heading: Dependency Layer

text: Stacking Sequence and Dependency Layers
We stack the dependency layers ( corresponding to relation candidates ) on top of the sequence layer to incorporate both word sequence and dependency tree structure information into the output .
heading: Stacking Sequence and Dependency Layers

text: The dependency - layer LSTM unit at the t - th word receives as input

heading: Stacking Sequence and Dependency Layers

text: Relation Classification
We incrementally build relation candidates using all possible combinations of the last words of detected entities , i.e. , words with L or U labels in the BILOU scheme , during decoding .
heading: Relation Classification

text: For instance , in , we build a relation candidate using Yates with an L - PER label and Chicago with an U - LOC label .
heading: Relation Classification

text: For each relation candidate , we realize the dependency layer d p ( described above ) corresponding to the path between the word pair pin the relation candidate , and the NN receives a relation candidate vector constructed from the output of the dependency tree layer , and predicts its relation label .
heading: Relation Classification

text: We treat a pair as a negative relation when the detected entities are wrong or when the pair has no relation .
heading: Relation Classification

text: We represent relation labels by type and direction , except for negative relations that have no direction .
heading: Relation Classification

text: The relation candidate vector is constructed as the concatenation d p = [?h p A ; ?h p 1 ; ?h p 2 ] , where ?h p

text: We use the dependency to the parent since the number of children varies .

text: Dependency types can also be incorporated into m ( ) , but this did not help in initial experiments .
heading: Relation Classification

text: unit in the bottom - up LSTM - RNN ( representing the lowest common ancestor of the target word pair p ) , and ?h p 1 , ?h p 2 are the hidden state vectors of the two LSTM units representing the first and second target words in the top - down LSTM - RNN .
heading: Relation Classification

text: All the corresponding arrows are shown in .
heading: Relation Classification

text: Similarly to the entity detection , we employ a two - layered NN with an n hr -dimensional hidden layer h ( r ) and a softmax output layer ( with weight matrices W , bias vectors b ) .
heading: Relation Classification

text: We construct the input d p for relation classification from tree - structured LSTM - RNNs stacked on sequential LSTM - RNNs , so the contribution of sequence layer to the input is indirect .
heading: Relation Classification

text: Furthermore , our model uses words for representing entities , so it can not fully use the entity information .
heading: Relation Classification

text: To alleviate these problems , we directly concatenate the average of hidden state vectors for each entity from the sequence layer to the input d p to relation classification , i.e. , d p =
