text: Training

We update the model parameters including weights , biases , and embeddings by BPTT and Adam ( Kingma and Ba , 2015 ) with gradient clipping , parameter averaging , and L2-regularization ( we regularize weights W and U , not the bias terms b ) .
heading: Training

text: We also apply dropout to the embedding layer and to the final hidden layers for entity detection and relation classification .
heading: Training

text: We employ two enhancements , scheduled sampling and entity pretraining , to alleviate the problem of unreliable prediction of entities in the early stage of training , and to encourage building positive relation instances from the detected entities .
heading: Training

text: In scheduled sampling , we use gold labels as prediction in the probability of i that depends on the number of epochs i during training if the gold labels are legal .
heading: Training

text: As for i , we choose the inverse sigmoid decay i = k / ( k + exp ( i / k ) ) , where k( ?
heading: Training

text: 1 ) is a hyper - parameter that adjusts how often we use the gold labels as prediction .
heading: Training

text: Entity pretraining is inspired by , and we pretrain the entity detection model using the training data before training the entire model parameters .
heading: Training

text: Results and Discussion
Data and Task Settings
We evaluate on three datasets : ACE05 and ACE04 for end - to - end relation extraction , and SemEval - 2010 Task 8 for relation classification .
heading: Data and Task Settings

text: We use the first two datasets as our primary target , and use the last one to thoroughly analyze and ablate the relation classification part of our model .
heading: Data and Task Settings

text: ACE05 defines 7 coarse - grained entity types and 6 coarse - grained relation types between entities .
heading: Data and Task Settings

text: We use the same data splits , preprocessing , and task settings as .
heading: Data and Task Settings

text: We report the primary micro F1 -scores as well as micro precision and recall on both entity and relation extraction to better explain model performance .
heading: Data and Task Settings

text: We treat an entity as correct when it s type and the region of its head are correct .
heading: Data and Task Settings

text: We treat a relation as correct when it s type and argument entities are correct ; we thus treat all non-negative relations on wrong entities as false positives .
heading: Data and Task Settings

text: ACE04 defines the same 7 coarse - grained entity types as ACE05 , but defines 7 coarse - grained relation types .
heading: Data and Task Settings

text: We follow the cross-validation setting of Chan and and , and the preprocessing and evaluation metrics of ACE05 .
heading: Data and Task Settings

text: SemEval-2010
Task 8 defines 9 relation types between nominals and a tenth type
heading: SemEval-2010

text: Other when two nouns have none of these relations .
heading: SemEval-2010

text: We treat this Other type as a negative relation type , and no direction is considered .
heading: SemEval-2010

text: The dataset consists of 8,000 training and 2,717 test sentences , and each sentence is annotated with a relation between two given nominals .
heading: SemEval-2010

text: We randomly selected 800 sentences from the training set as our development set .
heading: SemEval-2010

text: We followed the official task setting , and report the official macro -averaged F1 - score ( Macro - F1 ) on the 9 relation types .
heading: SemEval-2010

text: For more details of the data and task settings , please refer to the supplementary material .
heading: SemEval-2010

text: Experimental Settings
We implemented our model using the cnn library .
heading: Experimental Settings

text: We parsed the texts using the Stanford neural dependency parser 7 ( Chen and Manning , 2014 ) with the original Stanford Dependencies .
heading: Experimental Settings

text: Based on preliminary tuning , we fixed embedding dimensions n w to 200 , n p , n d , n e to 25 , and dimensions of intermediate layers ( n ls , n lt of LSTM - RNNs and n he , n hr of hidden layers ) to 100 .
heading: Experimental Settings

text: We initialized word vectors via word2 vec trained on Wikipedia 8 and randomly initialized all other parameters .
heading: Experimental Settings

text: We tuned hyper - parameters using development sets for ACE05 and SemEval - 2010 Task 8 to achieve high primary ( Micro - and Macro - ) F1-scores .
heading: Experimental Settings

text: 9 For ACE04 , we directly employed the best parameters for ACE05 .
heading: Experimental Settings

text: The hyperparameter settings are shown in the supplementary material .
heading: Experimental Settings

text: For SemEval-2010
Task 8 , we also omitted the entity detection and label embeddings since only target nominals are annotated and the task defines no entity types .
heading: For SemEval-2010

text: Our statistical significance results are based on the Approximate Randomization ( AR ) test .
heading: For SemEval-2010

Shared parameters ) ; we first train the entity detection model , detect entities with the model , and build a separate relation extraction model using the detected entities , i.e. , without entity detection .

heading: For SemEval-2010

heading: For SemEval-2010

text: We finally show results with two counterparts of sequence - based LSTM - RNNs using the shortest path ( last two rows in ) .
heading: For SemEval-2010

text: SPSeq is a bidirectional LSTM - RNN on the shortest path .
heading: For SemEval-2010

text: The LSTM unit receives input from the sequence layer concatenated with embeddings for the surrounding dependency types and directions .
heading: For SemEval-2010

text: We concatenate the outputs of the two RNNs for the relation candidate .
heading: For SemEval-2010

text: SPX u is our adaptation of the shortest path LSTM - RNN proposed by to match our sequence - layer based model .
heading: For SemEval-2010

text: 11 This has two LSTM - RNNs for the left and right subpaths of the shortest path .
heading: For SemEval-2010

text: We first calculate the max pooling of the LSTM units for each of these two RNNs , and then concatenate the outputs of the pooling for the relation candidate .
heading: For SemEval-2010

text: The comparison with these sequence - based LSTM - RNNs indicates that a tree - structured LSTM - RNN is comparable to sequence - based ones in representing shortest paths .
heading: For SemEval-2010

text: Overall , the performance comparison of the LSTM - RNN structures in show that for end - to - end relation extraction , selecting the appropriate tree structure representation of the input ( i.e. , the shortest path ) is more important than the choice of the LSTM - RNN structure on that input ( i.e. , sequential versus tree - based ) .
heading: For SemEval-2010

To thoroughly analyze the relation classification part alone , e.g. , comparing different LSTM structures , architecture components such as hidden layers and input information , and classification task settings , we use the SemEval - 2010 Task 8 .

heading: Settings

heading: Settings

text: Conclusion

We presented a novel end - to - end relation extraction model that represents both word sequence and dependency tree structures by using bidirectional sequential and bidirectional tree - structured LSTM - RNNs .
heading: Conclusion

text: This allowed us to represent both entities and relations in a single model , achieving gains over the state - of - the - art , feature - based system on end - to - end relation extraction ( ACE04 and ACE05 ) , and showing favorably comparable performance to recent state - of - the - art CNNbased models on nominal relation classification ( Sem Eval - 2010 Task 8 ) .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our evaluation and ablation led to three key findings .
heading: Conclusion

text: First , the use of both word sequence and dependency tree structures is effective .
heading: Conclusion

text: Second , training with the shared parameters improves relation extraction accuracy , especially when employed with entity pretraining , scheduled sampling , and label embeddings .
heading: Conclusion

text: Finally , the shortest path , which has been widely used in relation classification , is also appropriate for representing tree structures in neural LSTM models .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Joint Extraction of Entities and Relations Based on a Novel Tagging Scheme
heading: title

text: abstract
Joint extraction of entities and relations is an important task in information extraction .
heading: abstract

text: To tackle this problem , we firstly propose a novel tagging scheme that can convert the joint extraction task to a tagging problem .
heading: abstract

text: Then , based on our tagging scheme , we study different end - toend models to extract entities and their relations directly , without identifying entities and relations separately .
heading: abstract

text: We conduct experiments on a public dataset produced by distant supervision method and the experimental results show that the tagging based methods are better than most of the existing pipelined and joint learning methods .
heading: abstract

text: What 's more , the end - to - end model proposed in this paper , achieves the best results on the public dataset .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Joint extraction of entities and relations is to detect entity mentions and recognize their semantic relations simultaneously from unstructured text , as shows .
heading: Introduction

text: Different from open information extraction ( Open IE ) ) whose relation words are extracted from the given sentence , in this task , relation words are extracted from a predefined relation set which may not appear in the given sentence .
heading: Introduction

text: It is an important issue in knowledge extraction and automatic construction of knowledge base .
heading: Introduction

text: Traditional methods handle this task in a pipelined manner , i.e. , extracting the entities first and then recognizing their relations .
heading: Introduction

text: This separated framework makes the task easy to deal with , and each component can be more flexible .
heading: Introduction

text: But it neglects the relevance between these two sub - tasks and each subtask is an independent model .
heading: Introduction

text: The results of entity recognition may affect the performance of relation classification and lead to erroneous delivery .
heading: Introduction

text: Different from the pipelined methods , joint learning framework is to extract entities together with relations using a single model .
heading: Introduction

text: It can effectively integrate the information of entities and relations , and it has been shown to achieve better results in this task .
heading: Introduction

text: However , most existing joint methods are feature - based structured systems .
heading: Introduction

text: They need complicated feature engineering and heavily rely on the other NLP toolkits , which might also lead to error propagation .
heading: Introduction

text: In order to reduce the manual work in feature extraction , recently , presents a neural network - based method for the end - to - end entities and relations extraction .
heading: Introduction

text: Although the joint models can represent both entities and relations with shared parameters in a single model , they also extract the entities and relations separately and produce redundant information .
heading: Introduction

text: For instance , the sentence in contains three entities : " United States " , " Trump " and " Apple Inc " .
heading: Introduction

text: But only " United States " and " Trump " hold a fix relation " Country - President " .
heading: Introduction

text: Entity " Apple Inc " has no obvious relationship with the other entities in this sentence .
heading: Introduction

text: Hence , the extracted result from this sentence is { United States e 1 , Country - President r , Trump e 2 } , which called triplet here .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we focus on the extraction of triplets that are composed of two entities and one relation between these two entities .
heading: Introduction

text: Therefore , we can model the triplets directly , rather than extracting the entities and relations separately .
heading: Introduction

text: Based on the motivations , we propose a tagging scheme accompanied with the end - to - end model to settle this problem .
heading: Introduction

text: We design a kind of novel tags which contain the information of entities and the relationships they hold .
heading: Introduction

text: Based on this tagging scheme , the joint extraction of entities and relations can be transformed into a tagging problem .
heading: Introduction

text: In this way , we can also easily use neural networks to model the task without complicated feature engineering .
heading: Introduction

text: Recently , end - to - end models based on LSTM have been successfully applied to various tagging tasks :
heading: Introduction

text: Named Entity Recognition , CCG
heading: Introduction

text: Supertagging , Chunking et al .
heading: Introduction

text: LSTM is capable of learning long - term dependencies , which is beneficial to sequence modeling tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: Therefore , based on our tagging scheme , we investigate different kinds of LSTM - based end - to - end models to jointly extract the entities and relations .
heading: Introduction

text: We also modify the decoding method by adding a biased loss to make it more suitable for our special tags .
heading: Introduction

text: The method we proposed is a supervised learning algorithm .
heading: Introduction

text: In reality , however , the process of manually labeling a training set with a large number of entity and relation is too expensive and error-prone .
heading: Introduction

text: Therefore , we conduct experiments on a public dataset 1 which is produced by distant supervision method to validate our approach .
heading: Introduction

text: The experimental results show that our tagging scheme is effective in this task .
heading: Introduction

text: In addition , our end - to - end model can achieve the best results on the public dataset .
heading: Introduction

text: The major contributions of this paper are : ( 1 ) A novel tagging scheme is proposed to jointly extract entities and relations , which can easily transform the extraction problem into a tagging task .
heading: Introduction

text: ( 2 ) Based on our tagging scheme , we study different kinds of end - to - end models to settle the problem .
heading: Introduction

text: The tagging - based methods are better than most of the existing pipelined and joint learning methods .
heading: Introduction

text: ( 3 ) Furthermore , we also develop an end - to - 1 https://github.com/shanzhenren/Co
heading: Introduction

text: Type end model with biased loss function to suit for the novel tags .
heading: Introduction

text: It can enhance the association between related entities .
heading: Introduction

text: Related Works
Entities and relations extraction is an important step to construct a knowledge base , which can be benefit for many NLP tasks .
heading: Related Works

text: Two main frameworks have been widely used to solve the problem of extracting entity and their relationships .
heading: Related Works

text: One is the pipelined method and the other is the joint learning method .
heading: Related Works

text: The pipelined method treats this task as two separated tasks , i.e. , named entity recognition ( NER ) and relation classification ( RC ) .
heading: Related Works

text: Classical NER models are linear statistical models , such as Hidden Markov Models ( HMM ) and Conditional Random Fields ( CRF ) .
heading: Related Works

text: Recently , several neural network architectures have been successfully applied to NER , which is regarded as a sequential token tagging task .
heading: Related Works

text: Existing methods for relation classification can also be divided into handcrafted feature based methods and neural network based methods .
heading: Related Works

text: While joint models extract entities and relations using a single model .
heading: Related Works

text: Most of the joint methods are feature - based structured systems .
heading: Related Works

text: Recently , uses a LSTMbased model to extract entities and relations , which can reduce the manual work .
heading: Related Works

text: Different from the above methods , the method proposed in this paper is based on a special tagging manner , so that we can easily use end - toend model to extract results without NER and RC .
heading: Related Works

text: end - to - end method is to map the input sentence into meaningful vectors and then back to produce a sequence .
heading: Related Works

text: It is widely used in machine translation and sequence tagging tasks .
heading: Related Works

text: Most methods apply bidirectional LSTM to encode the input sentences , but the decoding methods are always different .
heading: Related Works

text: For examples , use a CRF layers to decode the tag sequence , while apply LSTM layer to produce the tag sequence .
heading: Related Works

text: Method
We propose a novel tagging scheme and an end -toend model with biased objective function to jointly extract entities and their relations .
heading: Method

text: In this section , we firstly introduce how to change the extraction problem to a tagging problem based on our tagging method .
heading: Method

text: Then we detail the model we used to extract results .
heading: Method

text: is an example of how the results are tagged .
heading: Method

text: Each word is assigned a label that contributes to extract the results .
heading: Method

text: Tag " O " represents the " Other " tag , which means that the corresponding word is independent of the extracted results .
heading: Method

text: In addition to " O " , the other tags consist of three parts : the word position in the entity , the relation type , and the relation role .
heading: Method

text: We use the " BIES " ( Begin , Inside , End , Single ) signs to represent the position information of a word in the entity .
heading: Method

text: The relation type information is obtained from a predefined set of relations and the relation role information is represented by the numbers " 1 " and " 2 " .
heading: Method

text: An extracted result is represented by a triplet : ( Entity 1 , Relation T ype , Entity 2 ) .
heading: Method

text: " 1 " means that the word belongs to the first entity in the triplet , while " 2 " belongs to second entity that behind the relation type .
heading: Method

text: Thus , the total number of tags is N t = 2 * 4 * | R | + 1 , where | R | is the size of the predefined relation set .
heading: Method

text: is an example illustrating our tagging method .
heading: Method

text: The input sentence contains two triplets : { United States , Country - President , Trump } and { Apple Inc , Company - Founder , Steven Paul Jobs } , where " Country - President " and " Company - Founder " are the predefined relation types .
heading: Method

text: The Tagging Scheme
The words " United " , " States " , " Trump " , " Apple " , " Inc " , " Steven " , " Paul " and " Jobs " are all related to the final extracted results .
heading: The Tagging Scheme

text: Thus they are tagged based on our special tags .
heading: The Tagging Scheme

text: For example , the word of " United " is the first word of entity " United States " and is related to the relation " Country - President " , so its tag is " B - CP - 1 " .
heading: The Tagging Scheme

text: The other entity " Trump " , which is corresponding to " United States " , is labeled as " S - CP - 2 " .
heading: The Tagging Scheme

text: Besides , the other words irrelevant to the final result are labeled as " O " .
heading: The Tagging Scheme

text: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

From the tag sequence in , we know that " Trump " and " United States " share the same relation type " Country - President " , " Apple Inc " and " Steven Paul Jobs " share the same relation type " Company - Founder " .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: We combine entities with the same relation type into a triplet to get the final result .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: Accordingly , " Trump " and " United States " can be combined into a triplet whose relation type is " Country - President " .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: Because , the relation role of " Trump " is " 2 " and " United States " is " 1 " , the final result is { United States , Country - President , Trump } .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: The same applies to { Apple Inc , Company - Founder , Steven Paul Jobs } .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: Besides , if a sentence contains two or more triplets with the same relation type , we combine every two entities into a triplet based on the nearest principle .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: For example , if the relation type " Country - President " in is " Company - Founder " , then there will be four entities in the given sentence with the same relation type .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: " United States " is closest to entity " Trump " and the " Apple Inc " is closest to " Jobs " , so the results will be { United States , Company - Founder , Trump } and { Apple Inc , Company - Founder , Steven Paul Jobs } .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: In this paper , we only consider the situation where an entity belongs to a triplet , and we leave identification of overlapping relations for future work .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: The End - to - end Model
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: In recent years , end - to - end model based on neural network is been widely used in sequence tagging task .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: In this paper , we investigate an end - toend model to produce the tags sequence as shows .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: It contains a bi-directional Long Short Term Memory ( Bi - LSTM ) layer to encode the input sentence and a LSTM - based decoding layer with biased loss .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: The biased loss can enhance the relevance of entity tags .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: The Bi - LSTM Encoding Layer .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: In sequence tagging problems , the Bi - LSTM encoding layer has been shown the effectiveness to capture the semantic information of each word .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: It contains forward lstm layer , backward lstm layer and the concatenate layer .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: The word embedding layer converts the word with 1 - hot representation to an embedding vector .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: Hence , a sequence of words can be represented as : Gold standard annotation for an example sentence based on our tagging scheme , where " CP " is short for " Country - President " and " CF " is short for " Company - Founder " .

heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: After word embedding layer , there are two parallel LSTM layers : forward LSTM layer and backward LSTM layer .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: The LSTM architecture consists of a set of recurrently connected subnets , known as memory blocks .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: Each time - step is a LSTM memory block .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: The LSTM memory block in Bi - LSTM encoding layer is used to compute current hidden vector ht based on the previous hidden vector h t?1 , the previous cell vector c t?1 and the current input word embedding wt .

text: The LSTM Decoding Layer .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: We also adopt a LSTM structure to produce the tag sequence .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: When detecting the tag of word wt , the inputs of decoding layer are : ht obtained from Bi - LSTM encoding layer , former predicted tag embedding T t?1 , former cell value c ( 2 ) t? 1 , and the former hidden vector in decoding layer h ( 2 ) t?1 .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: The structure diagram of the memory block in LSTM dis shown in , and detail operations are defined as follows :
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: The final softmax layer computes normalized entity tag probabilities based on the tag predicted vector T t :

heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: Because T is similar to tag embedding and LSTM is capable of learning long - term dependencies , the decoding manner can model tag interactions .
heading: From Tag Sequence To Extracted Results

text: The Bias Objective Function .
We train our model to maximize the log-likelihood of the data and the optimization method we used is RM - Sprop proposed by Hinton in .
heading: The Bias Objective Function .

text: The objective function can be defined as :
heading: The Bias Objective Function .

heading: The Bias Objective Function .

text: Besides , I ( O ) is a switching function to distinguish the loss of tag ' O ' and relational tags that can indicate the results .

text: Experiments
Experimental setting
Dataset
To evaluate the performance of our methods , we use the public dataset NYT 2 which is produced by distant supervision method .
heading: Dataset

text: A large amount of training data can be obtained by means of distant supervision methods without manually labeling .
heading: Dataset

text: While the test set is manually labeled to ensure its quality .
heading: Dataset

text: In total , the training data contains 353 k triplets , and the test set contains 3 , 880 triplets .
heading: Dataset

text: Besides , the size of relation set is 24 .
heading: Dataset

text: Evaluation
We adopt standard Precision ( Prec ) , Recall ( Rec ) and F 1 score to evaluate the results .
heading: Evaluation

text: Different from classical methods , our method can extract triplets without knowing the information of entity types .
heading: Evaluation

text: In other words , we did not use the label of entity types to train the model , therefore we do not need to consider the entity types in the evaluation .
heading: Evaluation

text: A triplet is regarded as correct when its relation type and the head offsets of two corresponding entities are both correct .
heading: Evaluation

text: Besides , the groundtruth relation mentions are given and " None " label is excluded as did .
heading: Evaluation

text: We create a validation set by randomly sampling 10 % data from test set and use the remaining data as evaluation based on ) 's suggestion .
heading: Evaluation

text: We run 10 times for each experiment then report the average results and their standard deviation as shows .
heading: Evaluation

text: Hyperparameters
Our model consists of a Bi - LSTM encoding layer and a LSTM decoding layer with bias objective function .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: The word embeddings used in the encoding part are initialed by running word2vec 3 on NYT training corpus .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: The dimension of the word embeddings is d = 300 .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: We regularize our network using dropout on embedding layer and the dropout ratio is 0.5 .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: The number of lstm units in encoding layer is 300 and the number in decoding layer is 600 .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: The bias parameter ?
heading: Hyperparameters

text: corresponding to the results in is 10 .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: The dataset can be downloaded at : https://github.com/shanzhenren/CoType.
heading: Hyperparameters

text: There are three data sets in the public resource and we only use the NYT dataset .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: Because more than 50 % of the data in BioInfer has overlapping relations which is beyond the scope of this paper .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: As for dataset Wiki - KBP , the number of relation type in the test set is more than that of the train set , which is also not suitable fora supervised training method .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: Details of the data can be found in is the pipelined methods and the second part ( row 4 to 6 ) is the jointly extracting methods .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: Our tagging methods are shown in part three ( row 7 to 9 ) .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: In this part , we not only report the results of precision , recall and F1 , we also compute their standard deviation .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: Baselines

We compare our method with several classical triplet extraction methods , which can be divided into the following categories : the pipelined methods , the jointly extracting methods and the end - to - end methods based our tagging scheme .
heading: Baselines

text: For the pipelined methods , we follow ) 's settings :
heading: Baselines

text: The NER results are obtained by CoType then several classical relation classification methods are applied to detect the relations .
heading: Baselines

text: These methods are :
heading: Baselines

text: ( 1 ) DS-logistic ) is a distant supervised and feature based method , which combines the advantages of supervised IE and unsupervised IE features ; ( 2 ) LINE is a network embedding method , which is suitable for arbitrary types of information networks ;
heading: Baselines

text: ( 3 ) FCM ) is a compositional model that combines lexicalized linguistic context and word embeddings for relation extraction .
heading: Baselines

text: The jointly extracting methods used in this paper are listed as follows : ( 4 ) DS - Joint ) is a supervised method , which jointly extracts entities and relations using structured perceptron on human - annotated dataset ; ( 5 ) MultiR is a typical distant supervised method based on multi-instance learning algorithms to combat the noisy training data ; ( 6 ) CoType ) is a domain independent framework by jointly embedding entity mentions , relation mentions , text features and type labels into meaningful representations .
heading: Baselines

text: In addition , we also compare our method with two classical end - to - end tagging models : LSTM- CRF and LSTM - LSTM .
heading: Baselines

text: LSTM - CRF is proposed for entity recognition by using a bidirectional LSTM to encode input sentence and a conditional random fields to predict the entity tag sequence .
heading: Baselines

text: Different from LSTM - CRF , LSTM - LSTM uses a LSTM layer to decode the tag sequence instead of CRF .
heading: Baselines

text: They are used for the first time to jointly extract entities and relations based on our tagging scheme .
heading: Baselines

We report the results of different methods as shown in .

heading: Experimental Results

heading: Experimental Results

text: Furthermore , from , we also can see that the jointly extracting methods are better than pipelined methods , and the tagging methods are better than most of the jointly extracting methods .

heading: Experimental Results

text: When compared with the traditional methods , the precisions of the end - to - end models are significantly improved .
heading: Experimental Results

heading: Experimental Results

heading: Experimental Results

text: The methods based on neural networks can well fit the data .
heading: Experimental Results

text: Therefore , they can learn the common features of the training set well and may lead to the lower expansibility .
heading: Experimental Results

text: We also find that the LSTM - LSTM model is better than LSTM - CRF model based on our tagging scheme .
heading: Experimental Results

text: Because , LSTM is capable of learning long - term dependencies and CRF is good at capturing the joint probability of the entire sequence of labels .
heading: Experimental Results

heading: Experimental Results

LSTM decoding manner is a little better than CRF .

text: Case Study

In this section , we observe the prediction results of end - to - end methods , and then select several representative examples to illustrate the advantages and disadvantages of the methods as shows .
heading: Case Study

text: Each example contains three row , the first row is the gold standard , the second and the third rows are the extracted results of model LSTM - LSTM and LSTM - LSTM - Bias respectively .
heading: Case Study

text: S1 represents the situation that the distance between the two interrelated entities is faraway from each other , which is more difficult to detect their relationships .

In this paper , we propose a novel tagging scheme and investigate the end - to - end models to jointly extract entities and relations .

heading: Conclusion

text: In the future work , we will replace the softmax function in the output layer with multiple classifier , so that a word can has multiple tags .
heading: Conclusion

text: In this way , a word can appear in multiple triplet results , which can solve the problem of overlapping relations .
heading: Conclusion

text: Although , our model can enhance the effect of entity tags , the association between two corresponding entities still requires refinement in next works .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Joint entity recognition and relation extraction as a multi-head selection problem
heading: title

text: abstract

State - of - the - art models for joint entity recognition and relation extraction strongly rely on external natural language processing ( NLP ) tools such as POS ( part - of - speech ) taggers and dependency parsers .
heading: abstract

text: Thus , the performance of such joint models depends on the quality of the features obtained from these NLP tools .
heading: abstract

text: However , these features are not always accurate for various languages and contexts .
heading: abstract

text: In this paper , we propose a joint neural model which performs entity recognition and relation extraction simultaneously , without the need of any manually extracted features or the use of any external tool .
heading: abstract

text: Specifically , we model the entity recognition task using a CRF ( Conditional Random Fields ) layer and the relation extraction task as a multi-head selection problem ( i.e. , potentially identify multiple relations for each entity ) .
heading: abstract

text: We present an extensive experimental setup , to demonstrate the effectiveness of our method using datasets from various contexts ( i.e. , news , biomedical , real estate ) and languages ( i.e. , English , Dutch ) .
heading: abstract

text: Our model outperforms the previous neural models that use automatically extracted features , while it performs within a reasonable margin of feature - based neural models , or even beats them .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
The goal of the entity recognition and relation extraction is to discover relational structures of entity mentions from unstructured texts .
heading: Introduction

text: It is a central problem in information extraction since it is critical for tasks such as knowledge base population and question answering .
heading: Introduction

text: The problem is traditionally approached as two separate subtasks , namely ( i ) named entity recognition ( NER ) and ( ii ) relation extraction ( RE ) , in a pipeline setting .
heading: Introduction

text: The main limitations of the pipeline models are : ( i ) error propagation between the components ( i.e. , NER and RE ) and ( ii ) possible useful information from the one task is not exploited by the other ( e.g. , identifying a Works for relation might be helpful for the NER module in detecting the type of the two entities , i.e. , PER , ORG and vice versa ) .
heading: Introduction

text: On the other hand , more recent studies propose to use joint models to detect entities and their relations overcoming the aforementioned issues and achieving state - of - the - art performance .
heading: Introduction

text: The previous joint models heavily rely on hand - crafted features .
heading: Introduction

text: Recent advances in neural networks alleviate the issue of manual feature engineering , but some of them still depend on NLP tools ( e.g. , POS taggers , dependency parsers ) .
heading: Introduction

text: propose a Recurrent Neural Network ( RNN ) - based joint model that uses a bidirectional sequential LSTM ( Long Short Term Memory ) to model the entities and a tree - LSTM that takes into account dependency tree information to model the relations between the entities .
heading: Introduction

text: The dependency information is extracted using an external dependency parser .
heading: Introduction

text: Similarly , in the work of for entity and relation extraction from biomedical text , a model which also uses tree - LSTMs is applied to extract dependency information .
heading: Introduction

text: propose a method that relies on RNNs but uses a lot of hand - crafted features and additional NLP tools to extract features such as POS - tags , etc. replicate the context around the entities with Convolutional Neural Networks ( CNNs ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Note that the aforementioned works examine pairs of entities for relation extraction , rather than modeling the whole sentence directly .
heading: Introduction

text: This means that relations of other pairs of entities in the same sentence - which could be helpful in deciding on the relation type fora particular pair - are not taken into account .
heading: Introduction

text: propose a neural joint model based on LSTMs where they model the whole sentence at once , but still they do not have a principled way to deal with multiple relations .
heading: Introduction

text: introduce a quadratic scoring layer to model the two tasks simultaneously .
heading: Introduction

text: The limitation of this approach is that only a single relation can be assigned to a token , while the time complexity for the entity recognition task is increased compared to the standard approaches with linear complexity .
heading: Introduction

text: In this work , we focus on anew general purpose joint model that performs the two tasks of entity recognition and relation extraction simultaneously , and that can handle multiple relations together .
heading: Introduction

text: Our model achieves state - of - the - art performance in a number of different contexts ( i.e. , news , biomedical , real estate ) and languages ( i.e. , English , Dutch ) without relying on any manually engineered features nor additional NLP tools .
heading: Introduction

text: In summary , our proposed model ( which will be detailed next in Section 3 ) solves several shortcomings that we identified in related works ( Section 2 ) for joint entity recognition and relation extraction : ( i ) our model does not rely on external NLP tools nor hand - crafted features , ( ii ) entities and relations within the same text fragment ( typically a sentence ) are extracted simultaneously , where ( iii ) an entity can be involved in multiple relations at once .
heading: Introduction

text: Specifically , the model of depends on dependency parsers , which perform particularly well on specific languages ( i.e. , English ) and contexts ( i.e. , news ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Yet , our ambition is to develop a model that generalizes well in various setups , therefore using only automatically extracted features that are learned during training .
heading: Introduction

text: For instance , and use exactly the same model in different contexts , i.e. , news ( ACE04 ) and biomedical data ( ADE ) , respectively .
heading: Introduction

text: Comparing our results to the ADE dataset , we obtain a 1.8 % improvement on the NER task and ? 3 % on the RE task .
heading: Introduction

text: On the other hand , our model performs within a reasonable margin ( ? 0.6 % in the NER task and ? 1 % on the RE task ) on the ACE04 dataset without the use of pre-calculated features .
heading: Introduction

text: This shows that the model of strongly relies on the features extracted by the dependency parsers and can not generalize well into different contexts where dependency parser features are weak .
heading: Introduction

text: Comparing to , we train our model by modeling all the entities and the relations of the sentence at once .
heading: Introduction

text: This type of inference is beneficial in obtaining information about neighboring entities and relations instead of just examining a pair of entities each time .
heading: Introduction

text: Finally , we solve the underlying problem of the models proposed by and , who essentially assume classes ( i.e. , relations ) to be mutually exclusive : we solve this by phrasing the relation extraction component as a multi-label prediction problem .
heading: Introduction

text: To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method , we conduct the largest experimental evaluation to date ( to the best of our knowledge ) in jointly performing both entity recognition and relation extraction ( see Section 4 and Section 5 ) , using different datasets from various domains ( i.e. , news , biomedical , real estate ) and languages ( i.e. , English , Dutch ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Specifically , we apply our method to four datasets , namely ACE04 ( news ) , Adverse Drug Events ( ADE ) , Dutch Real Estate Classifieds ( DREC ) and CoNLL'04 ( news ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Our method outperforms all state - of - the - art methods that do not rely on any additional features or tools , while performance is very close ( or even better in the biomedical dataset ) compared to methods that do exploit hand - engineered features or NLP tools .
heading: Introduction

text: Related work
The tasks of entity recognition and relation extraction can be applied either one by one in a pipeline setting or in a joint model .
heading: Related work

text: In this section , we present related work for each task ( i.e. , named entity recognition and relation extraction ) as well as prior work into joint entity and relation extraction .
heading: Related work

text: Note that another difference is that we use a CRF layer for the NER part , while Katiyar & Cardie ( 2017 ) uses a softmax and uses a quadratic scoring layer ; see further , when we discuss performance comparison results in Section 5 .
heading: Related work

text: Named entity recognition

We formulate the entity identification task as a sequence labeling problem , similar to previous work on joint learning models and named entity recognition using the BIO ( Beginning , Inside , Outside ) encoding scheme .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: Each entity consists of multiple sequential tokens within the sentence and we should assign a tag for every token in the sentence .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: That way we are able to identify the entity arguments ( start and end position ) and its type ( e.g. , ORG ) .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: To do so , we assign the B - type ( beginning ) to the first token of the entity , the I - type ( inside ) to every other token within the entity and the O tag ( outside ) if a token is not part of an entity .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: shows an example of the BIO encoding tags assigned to the tokens of the sentence .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: In the CRF layer , one can observe that we assign the B - ORG and I - ORG tags to indicate the beginning and the inside tokens of the entity " Disease Control Center " , respectively .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: On top of the BiLSTM layer , we employ either a softmax or a CRF layer to calculate the most probable entity tag for each token .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: We calculate the score of each token w i for each entity tag :
heading: Named entity recognition

text: where the superscript ( e ) is used for the notation of the NER task , f ( ) is an elementwise activation function ( i.e. , relu , tanh ) ,
heading: Named entity recognition

text: with d as the hidden size of the LSTM , p the number of NER tags ( e.g. , B - ORG ) and
heading: Named entity recognition

text: l the layer width .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: We calculate the probabilities of all the candidate tags fora give n
heading: Named entity recognition

text: we employ the softmax approach only for the entity classification ( EC ) task ( which is similar to NER ) where we need to predict only the entity types ( e.g. , PER ) for each token assuming boundaries are given .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: The CRF approach is used for the NER task which includes both entity type and boundaries recognition .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: In the softmax approach , we assign entity types to tokens in a greedy way at prediction time ( i.e. , the selected tag is just the highest scoring tag overall possible set of tags ) .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: Although assuming an independent tag distribution is beneficial for entity classification tasks ( e.g. , POS tagging ) , this is not the case when there are strong de-pendencies between the tags .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: Specifically , in NER , the BIO tagging scheme forces several restrictions ( e.g. , B - LOC can not be followed by I - PER ) .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: The softmax method allows local decisions ( i.e. , for the tag of each token w i ) even though the BiLSTM captures information about the neighboring words .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: Still , the neighboring tags are not taken into account for the tag decision of a specific token .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: For example , in the entity " John Smith " , tagging " Smith " as PER is useful for deciding that " John " is B - PER .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: To this end , for NER , we use a linear - chain CRF , similar to Lample et al .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: where an improvement of ? 1 % F 1 NER points is reported when using CRF .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: In our case , with the use of CRF we also report a ? 1 % overall performance improvement as observed in
heading: Named entity recognition

text: is the score of the predicted tag for token w i , T is a square transition matrix in which each entry represents transition scores from one tag to another .
heading: Named entity recognition

heading: Named entity recognition

heading: Named entity recognition

text: We apply Viterbi to obtain the tag sequence ? ( e ) with the highest score .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: We train both the softmax ( for the EC task ) and the CRF layer ( for NER ) by minimizing the cross - entropy loss L NER .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: We also use the entity tags as input to our relation extraction layer by learning label embeddings , motivated by where an improvement of 2 % F 1 is reported ( with the use of label embeddings ) .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: In our case , label embeddings lead to an increase of 1 % F 1 score as reported in ( see Section 5.2 ) .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: The input to the next layer is twofold : the output states of the LSTM and the learned label embedding representation , encoding the intuition that knowledge of named enti-ties can be useful for relation extraction .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: During training , we use the gold entity tags , while at prediction time we use the predicted entity tags as input to the next layer .
heading: Named entity recognition

text: The input to the next layer is the concatenation of the hidden LSTM state hi with the label embedding g i for token w i :
heading: Named entity recognition

text: Relation extraction
We consider relation extraction as the second task of our joint model .
heading: Relation extraction

text: The main approaches for relation extraction rely either on hand - crafted features or neural networks .
heading: Relation extraction

text: Feature - based methods focus on obtaining effective hand - crafted features , for instance defining kernel functions and designing lexical , syntactic , semantic features , etc . .
heading: Relation extraction

text: Neural network models have been proposed to overcome the issue of manually designing hand - crafted features leading to improved performance .
heading: Relation extraction

text: CNN - and models have been introduced to automatically extract lexical and sentence level features leading to a deeper language understanding .
heading: Relation extraction

text: combine CNNs and RNNs using an ensemble scheme to achieve state - of - the - art results .
heading: Relation extraction

text: Joint entity and relation extraction
Entity and relation extraction includes the task of ( i ) identifying the entities ( described in Section 2.1 ) and ( ii ) extracting the relations among them ( described in Section 2.2 ) .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: Feature - based joint models have been proposed to simultaneously solve the entity recognition and relation extraction ( RE ) subtasks .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: These methods rely on the availability of NLP tools ( e.g. , POS taggers ) or manually designed features and thus ( i ) require additional effort for the data preprocessing , ( ii ) perform poorly in different application and language settings where the NLP tools are not reliable , and ( iii ) increase the computational complexity .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: In this paper , we introduce a joint neural network model to overcome the aforementioned issues and to automatically perform end - to - end relation extraction without the need of any manual feature engineering or the use of additional NLP components .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: Neural network approaches have been considered to address the problem in a joint setting ( end - to - end relation extraction ) and typically include the use of RNNs and CNNs .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: Specifically , propose the use of bidirectional tree - structured RNNs to capture dependency tree information ( where parse trees are extracted using state - of - the - art dependency parsers ) which has been proven beneficial for relation extraction .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: apply the work of to biomedical text , reporting state - of - the - art performance for two biomedical datasets .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: propose the use of a lot of hand - crafted features along with RNNs .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: solve the entity classification task ( which is different from NER since in entity classification the boundaries of the entities are known and only the type of the entity should be predicted ) and relation extraction problems using an approximation of a global normalization objective ( i.e. , CRF ) : they replicate the context of the sentence ( left and right part of the entities ) to feed one entity pair at a time to a CNN for relation extraction .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: Thus , they do not simultaneously infer other potential entities and relations within the same sentence .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: and The input of our model is the words of the sentence which are then represented as word vectors ( i.e. , embeddings ) .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: The BiLSTM layer extracts a more complex representation for each word .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: Then the CRF and the sigmoid layers are able to produce the outputs for the two tasks .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: The outputs for each token ( e.g. , Smith ) are : ( i ) an entity recognition label ( e.g. , I - PER ) and ( ii ) a set of tuples comprising the head tokens of the entity and the types of relations between them ( e.g. , {( Center , Works for ) , ( Atlanta , Lives in ) } ) .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: tional complexity described by , by dividing the loss functions into a NER and a relation extraction component .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: Moreover , we are able to handle multiple relations instead of just predicting single ones , as was described for the application of structured real estate advertisements of .
heading: Joint entity and relation extraction

text: Joint model
In this section , we present our multi-head joint model illustrated in .
heading: Joint model

text: The model is able to simultaneously identify the entities ( i.e. , types and boundaries ) and all the possible relations between them at once .
heading: Joint model

text: We formulate the problem as a multi-head selection problem extending previous work as described in Section 2.3 .
heading: Joint model

text: By multi-head , we mean that any particular entity maybe the CoNLL04 dataset is presented .
heading: Joint model

text: The input of our model is a sequence of tokens ( i.e. , words of the sentence ) which are then represented as word vectors ( i.e. , word embeddings ) .
heading: Joint model

text: The BiLSTM layer is able to extract a more complex representation for each word that incorporates the context via the RNN structure .
heading: Joint model

text: Then the CRF and the sigmoid layers are able to produce the outputs for the two tasks .
heading: Joint model

text: The outputs for each token ( e.g. , Smith ) are twofold : ( i ) an entity recognition label ( e.g. , I - PER , denoting the token is inside a named entity of type PER ) and ( ii ) a set of tuples comprising the head tokens of the entity and the types of relations between them ( e.g. , {( Center , Works for ) , ( Atlanta , Lives in ) } ) .
heading: Joint model

text: Since we assume token - based encoding , we consider only the last token of the entity as head of another token , eliminating redundant relations .
heading: Joint model

text: For instance , there is a Works for relation between entities " John Smith " and " Disease Control Center " .
heading: Joint model

text: Instead of connecting all tokens of the entities , we connect only " Smith " with " Center " .
heading: Joint model

text: Also , for the case of no relation , we introduce the " N " label and we predict the token itself as the head .
heading: Joint model

text: Embedding layer
Given a sentence w = w 1 , ... , w n as a sequence of tokens , the word embedding layer is responsible to map each token to a word vector ( w word2vec ) .
heading: Embedding layer

text: We use pre-trained word embeddings using the Skip - Gram word2vec model .
heading: Embedding layer

text: In this work , we also use character embeddings since they are commonly applied to neural NER .
heading: Embedding layer

text: This type of embeddings is able to capture morphological features such as prefixes and suffixes .
heading: Embedding layer

text: For instance , in the Adverse Drug Events ( ADE ) dataset , the suffix " toxicity " can specify an adverse drug event entity such as " neurotoxicity " or " hepatotoxicity " and thus it is very informative .
heading: Embedding layer

text: Another example might be the Dutch suffix " kamer " ( " room " in English ) in the Dutch Real Estate Classifieds ( DREC ) dataset which is used to specify the space entities " badkamer " ( " bathroom " in English ) and " slaapkamer " ( " bedroom " in English ) .
heading: Embedding layer

text: Character - level embeddings are learned during training , similar to Ma & Hovy and .
heading: Embedding layer

text: In the work of Lample et al. , character embeddings lead to a performance improvement of up to 3 % in terms of NER F 1 score .
heading: Embedding layer

text: In our work , by incorporating character embeddings , we report in an increase of ? 2 %
heading: Embedding layer

text: overall F 1 scoring points .
heading: Embedding layer

Bidirectional LSTM encoding layer
RNNs are commonly used in modeling sequential data and have been successfully applied in various NLP tasks .
heading: Bidirectional LSTM encoding layer

text: In this work , we use multi - layer LSTMs , a specific kind of RNNs which are able to capture long term dependencies well .
heading: Bidirectional LSTM encoding layer

text: We employ a BiLSTM which is able to encode information from left to right ( past to future ) and right to left ( future to past ) .
heading: Bidirectional LSTM encoding layer

text: This way , we can combine bidirectional information for each word by concatenating the forward ( hi ) and the backward ( hi ) output at timestep i .
heading: Bidirectional LSTM encoding layer

text: The BiLSTM output at timestep i can be written as :
heading: Bidirectional LSTM encoding layer

text: Edmonds ' algorithm
Our model is able to simultaneously extract entity mentions and the relations between them .
heading: Edmonds ' algorithm

text: To demonstrate the effectiveness and the general purpose nature of our model , we also test it on the recently introduced Dutch real estate classifieds ( DREC ) dataset where the entities need to form a tree structure .
heading: Edmonds ' algorithm

text: By using thresholded inference , a tree structure of relations is not guaranteed .
heading: Edmonds ' algorithm

text: Thus we should enforce tree structure constraints to our model .
heading: Edmonds ' algorithm

text: To this end , we post-process the output of our system with Edmonds ' maximum spanning tree algorithm for directed graphs .
heading: Edmonds ' algorithm

text: A fully connected directed graph G = ( V , E ) is constructed ,
heading: Edmonds ' algorithm

text: where the vertices
heading: Edmonds ' algorithm

text: V represent the last tokens of the identified entities ( as predicted by NER ) and the edges E represent the highest scoring relations with their scores as weights .
heading: Edmonds ' algorithm

text: Edmonds ' algorithm is applied in cases a tree is not already formed by thresholded inference .
heading: Edmonds ' algorithm

text: Finally , we compare our model with previous work
Analysis of feature contribution
We conduct ablation tests on the ACE04 dataset reported in to analyze the effectiveness of the various parts of our joint model .
heading: Analysis of feature contribution

text: The performance of the RE task decreases ( ? 1 % in terms of F 1 score ) when we remove the label embeddings layer and only use the LSTM hidden states as inputs for the RE task .
heading: Analysis of feature contribution

text: This shows that the NER labels , as expected , provide meaningful information for the RE component .
heading: Analysis of feature contribution

text: Removing character embeddings also degrades the performance of both NER ( ? 1 % ) and RE ( ? 2 % ) tasks by a relatively large margin .
heading: Analysis of feature contribution

text: This illustrates that composing words by the representation of characters is effective , and our method benefits from additional information such as capital letters , suffixes and prefixes within the token ( i.e. , its character sequences ) .
heading: Analysis of feature contribution

text: Finally , we conduct experiments for the NER task by removing the CRF loss layer and substituting it with a softmax .
heading: Analysis of feature contribution

text: Assuming independent distribution of labels ( i.e. , softmax ) leads to a slight decrease in the F 1 performance of the NER module and a ? 2 % decrease in the performance of the RE task .
heading: Analysis of feature contribution

text: This happens because the CRF loss is able to capture the strong tag dependencies ( e.g. , I - LOC can not follow B - PER ) that are present in the dataset instead of just assuming that the tag decision for each token is independent from tag decisions of neighboring tokens .
heading: Analysis of feature contribution

text: Conclusion
In this work , we present a joint neural model to simultaneously extract entities and relations from textual data .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our model comprises a CRF layer for the entity recognition task and a sigmoid layer for the relation extraction task .
heading: Conclusion

text: Specifically , we model the relation extraction task as a multi-head selection problem since one entity can have multiple relations .
heading: Conclusion

text: Previous models on this task rely heavily on external NLP tools ( i.e. , POS taggers , dependency parsers ) .
heading: Conclusion

text: Thus , the performance of these models is affected by the accuracy of the extracted features .
heading: Conclusion

text: Unlike previous studies , our model produces automatically generated features rather than relying on hand - crafted ones , or existing NLP tools .
heading: Conclusion

text: Given its independence from such NLP or other feature generating tools , our approach can be easily adopted for any language and context .
heading: Conclusion

text: We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach by conducting a large scale experimental study .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our model is able to outperform neural methods that automatically generate features while the results are marginally similar ( or sometimes better ) compared to feature - based neural network approaches .
heading: Conclusion

text: As future work , we aim to explore the effectiveness of entity pre-training for the entity recognition module .
heading: Conclusion

text: This approach has been proven beneficial in the work of Miwa & Bansal ( 2016 ) for both the entity and the relation extraction modules .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Adversarial training for multi-context joint entity and relation extraction
heading: title

text: abstract
Adversarial training ( AT ) is a regularization method that can be used to improve the robustness of neural network methods by adding small perturbations in the training data .
heading: abstract

text: We show how to use AT for the tasks of entity recognition and relation extraction .
heading: abstract

text: In particular , we demonstrate that applying AT to a general purpose baseline model for jointly extracting entities and relations , allows improving the state - of - the - art effectiveness on several datasets in different contexts ( i.e. , news , biomedical , and real estate data ) and for different languages ( English and Dutch ) .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Many neural network methods have recently been exploited in various natural language processing ( NLP ) tasks , such as parsing , POS tagging , relation extraction , translation , and joint tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: However , observed that intentional small scale perturbations ( i.e. , adversarial examples ) to the input of such models may lead to incorrect decisions ( with high confidence ) .
heading: Introduction

text: proposed adversarial training ( AT ) ( for image recognition ) as a regularization method which uses a mixture of clean and adversarial examples to enhance the robustness of the model .
heading: Introduction

text: Although AT has recently been applied in NLP tasks ( e.g. , text classification ) , this paper - to the best of our knowledge - is the first attempt investigating regularization effects of AT in a joint setting for two related tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: We start from a baseline joint model that performs the tasks of named entity recognition and relation extraction at once .
heading: Introduction

text: Previously proposed models ( summarized in Section 2 ) exhibit several issues that the neural network - based baseline approach ( detailed in Section 3.1 ) overcomes : ( i ) our model uses automatically extracted features without the need of external parsers nor manually extracted features ( see ; ; ) , ( ii ) all entities and the corresponding relations within the sentence are extracted at once , instead of examining one pair of entities at a time ( see ) , and ( iii ) we model relation extraction in a multi-label setting , allowing multiple relations per entity ( see ; ) .
heading: Introduction

text: The core contribution of the paper is the use of AT as an extension in the training procedure for the joint extraction task ( Section 3.2 ) .
heading: Introduction

text: To evaluate the proposed AT method , we perform a large scale experimental study in this joint task ( see Section 4 ) , using datasets from different contexts ( i.e. , news , biomedical , real estate ) and languages ( i.e. , English , Dutch ) .
heading: Introduction

text: We use a strong baseline that outperforms all previous models that rely on automatically extracted features , achieving state - of - the - art performance ( Section 5 ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Compared to the baseline model , applying AT during training leads to a consistent additional increase in joint extraction effectiveness .
heading: Introduction

text: Related work
Joint entity and relation extraction :
heading: Related work

text: Joint models that are based on manually extracted features have been proposed for performing both the named entity recognition ( NER ) and relation extraction subtasks at once .
heading: Related work

text: These methods rely on the availability of NLP tools ( e.g. , POS taggers ) or manually designed features leading to additional complexity .
heading: Related work

text: Neural network methods have been exploited to overcome this feature design issue and usually involve RNNs and CNNs .
heading: Related work

text: Specifically , as well as apply bidirectional tree - structured RNNs for different contexts ( i.e. , news , biomedical ) to capture syntactic information ( using external dependency parsers ) .
heading: Related work

text: propose the use of various manually extracted features along with RNNs .
heading: Related work

text: solve the simpler problem of entity classification ( EC , assuming entity boundaries are given ) , instead of NER , and they replicate the context around the entities , feeding entity pairs to the relation extraction layer .
heading: Related work

text: investigate RNNs with attention without taking into account that relation labels are not mutually exclusive .
heading: Related work

text: Finally , use LSTMs in a joint model for extracting just one relation at a time , but increase the complexity of the NER part .
heading: Related work

text: Our baseline model enables simultaneous extraction of multiple relations from the same input .
heading: Related work

text: Then , we further extend this strong baseline using adversarial training .
heading: Related work

text: Adversarial training ( AT ) has been proposed to make classifiers more robust to input perturbations in the context of image recognition .
heading: Related work

text: In the context of NLP , several variants have been proposed for different tasks such as text classification , relation extraction and POS tagging .
heading: Related work

text: AT is considered as a regularization method .
heading: Related work

text: Unlike other regularization methods ( i.e. , dropout , word dropout ) that introduce random noise , AT generates perturbations that are variations of examples easily misclassified by the model .
heading: Related work

text: Model
Joint learning as head selection
heading: Model

text: The baseline model , described in detail in , is illustrated in .
heading: Model

text: It aims to detect ( i ) the type and the boundaries of the entities and ( ii ) the relations between them .
heading: Model

text: The input is a sequence of tokens ( i.e. , sentence ) w = w 1 , ... , w n .
heading: Model

text: We use character level embeddings to implicitly capture morphological features ( e.g. , prefixes and suffixes ) , representing each character by a vector ( embedding ) .
heading: Model

text: The character embeddings are fed to a bidirectional LSTM ( BiLSTM ) to obtain the character - based representation of the word .
heading: Model

text: We also use pre-trained word embeddings .
heading: Model

text: Word and character embeddings are concatenated to form the final token representation , which is then fed to a BiLSTM layer to extract sequential information .
heading: Model

text: For the NER task , we adopt the BIO ( Beginning , Inside , Outside ) encoding scheme .
heading: Model

text: In , the B - PER tag is assigned to the beginning token of a ' person ' ( PER ) entity .
heading: Model

text: For the prediction of the entity tags , we use : ( i ) a softmax approach for the entity classification ( EC ) task ( assuming entity boundaries given ) or ( ii ) a CRF approach where we identify both the type and the boundaries for each entity .
heading: Model

text: During decoding , in the softmax setting , we greedily detect the entity types of the tokens ( i.e. , independent prediction ) .
heading: Model

text: Although independent distribution of types is reasonable for EC tasks , this is not the case when there are strong correlations between neighboring tags .
heading: Model

text: For instance , the BIO encoding scheme imposes several constraints in the NER task ( e.g. , the B - PER and I - LOC tags can not be sequential ) .
heading: Model

text: Motivated by this intuition , we use a linear - chain CRF for the NER task .
heading: Model

text: For decoding , in the CRF setting , we use the Viterbi algorithm .
heading: Model

text: During training , for both EC ( softmax ) and NER tasks ( CRF ) , we minimize the cross - entropy loss L NER .
heading: Model

text: The entity tags are later fed into the relation extraction layer as label embeddings ( see ) , assuming that knowledge of the entity types is beneficial in predicting the relations between the involved entities .
