text: Results
Our results demonstrate that AT outperforms the neural baseline model consistently , considering our experiments across multiple and more diverse datasets than typical related works .
heading: Results

text: The im - provement of AT over our baseline ( depending on the dataset ) ranges from ? 0.4 % to ? 0.9 % in terms of overall F 1 score .
heading: Results

text: This seemingly small performance increase is mainly due to the limited performance benefit for the NER component , which is in accordance with the recent advances in NER using neural networks that report similarly small gains ( e.g. , the performance improvement in and on the CoNLL - 2003 test set is 0.01 % and 0.17 % F 1 percentage points , while in the work of , a 0.07 % F 1 improvement on CoNLL - 2000 using AT for NER is reported ) .
heading: Results

text: However , the relation extraction performance increases by ? 1 % F 1 scoring points , except for the ACE04 dataset .
heading: Results

text: Further , as seen in , the improvement for CoNLL04 is particularly small on the evaluation set .
heading: Results

text: This may indicate a correlation between the dataset size and the benefit of adversarial training in the context of joint models , but this needs further investigation in future work .
heading: Results

text: Conclusion
We proposed to use adversarial training ( AT ) for the joint task of entity recognition and relation extraction .
heading: Conclusion

text: The contribution of this study is twofold : ( i ) investigation of the consistent effectiveness of AT as a regularization method over a multi-context baseline joint model , with ( ii ) a large scale experimental evaluation .
heading: Conclusion

text: Experiments show that AT improves the results for each task separately , as well as the overall performance of the baseline joint model , while reaching high performance already during the first epochs of the training procedure .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Graph Convolution over Pruned Dependency Trees Improves Relation Extraction
abstract
Dependency trees help relation extraction models capture long - range relations between words .
heading: abstract

text: However , existing dependency - based models either neglect crucial information ( e.g. , negation ) by pruning the dependency trees too aggressively , or are computationally inefficient because it is difficult to parallelize over different tree structures .
heading: abstract

text: We propose an extension of graph convolutional networks that is tailored for relation extraction , which pools information over arbitrary dependency structures efficiently in parallel .
heading: abstract

text: To incorporate relevant information while maximally removing irrelevant content , we further apply a novel pruning strategy to the input trees by keeping words immediately around the shortest path between the two entities among which a relation might hold .
heading: abstract

text: The resulting model achieves state - of - the - art performance on the large - scale TACRED dataset , outperforming existing sequence and dependency - based neural models .
heading: abstract

text: We also show through detailed analysis that this model has complementary strengths to sequence models , and combining them further improves the state of the art .
heading: abstract

text: * Equal contribution .
heading: abstract

text: The order of authorship was decided by a tossed coin .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Relation extraction involves discerning whether a relation exists between two entities in a sentence ( often termed subject and object , respectively ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Successful relation extraction is the cornerstone of applications requiring relational understanding of unstructured text on a large scale , such as question answering , knowledge base population , and biomedical knowledge discovery .
heading: Introduction

text: Models making use of dependency parses of the input sentences , or dependency - based models , : An example modified from the TAC KBP challenge corpus .
heading: Introduction

text: A subtree of the original UD dependency tree between the subject ( " he " ) and object ( " Mike Cane " ) is also shown , where the shortest dependency path between the entities is highlighted in bold .
heading: Introduction

text: Note that negation ( " not " ) is off the dependency path .
heading: Introduction

text: have proven to be very effective in relation extraction , because they capture long - range syntactic relations that are obscure from the surface form alone ( e.g. , when long clauses or complex scoping are present ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Traditional feature - based models are able to represent dependency information by featurizing dependency trees as overlapping paths along the trees .
heading: Introduction

text: However , these models face the challenge of sparse feature spaces and are brittle to lexical variations .
heading: Introduction

text: More recent neural models address this problem with distributed representations built from their computation graphs formed along parse trees .
heading: Introduction

text: One common approach to leverage dependency information is to perform bottom - up or top - down computation along the parse tree or the subtree below the lowest common ancestor ( LCA ) of the entities .
heading: Introduction

text: Another popular approach , inspired by , is to reduce the parse tree to the shortest dependency path between the entities .
heading: Introduction

text: However , these models suffer from several drawbacks .
heading: Introduction

text: Neural models operating directly on parse trees are usually difficult to parallelize and thus computationally inefficient , because aligning trees for efficient batch training is usually nontrivial .
heading: Introduction

text: Models based on the shortest dependency path between the subject and object are computationally more efficient , but this simplifying assumption has major limitations as well .
heading: Introduction

text: shows a real - world example where crucial information ( i.e. , negation ) would be excluded when the model is restricted to only considering the dependency path .
heading: Introduction

text: In this work , we propose a novel extension of the graph convolutional network ) that is tailored for relation extraction .
heading: Introduction

text: Our model encodes the dependency structure over the input sentence with efficient graph convolution operations , then extracts entity - centric representations to make robust relation predictions .
heading: Introduction

text: We also apply a novel path - centric pruning technique to remove irrelevant information from the tree while maximally keeping relevant content , which further improves the performance of several dependencybased models including ours .
heading: Introduction

text: We test our model on the popular SemEval 2010 Task 8 dataset and the more recent , larger TAC - RED dataset .
heading: Introduction

text: On both datasets , our model not only outperforms existing dependency - based neural models by a significant margin when combined with the new pruning technique , but also achieves a 10 - 100x speedup over existing tree - based models .
heading: Introduction

text: On TACRED , our model further achieves the state - of - the - art performance , surpassing a competitive neural sequence model baseline .
heading: Introduction

text: This model also exhibits complementary strengths to sequence models on TACRED , and combining these two model types through simple prediction interpolation further improves the state of the art .
heading: Introduction

text: To recap , our main contributions are : ( i ) we propose a neural model for relation extraction based on graph convolutional networks , which allows it to efficiently pool information over arbitrary dependency structures ; ( ii ) we present anew pathcentric pruning technique to help dependencybased models maximally remove irrelevant information without damaging crucial content to improve their robustness ; ( iii ) we present detailed analysis on the model and the pruning technique , and show that dependency - based models have complementary strengths with sequence models .
heading: Introduction

text: Models
In this section , we first describe graph convolutional networks ( GCNs ) over dependency tree structures , and then we introduce an architecture that uses GCNs at its core for relation extraction .
heading: Models

text: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees
The graph convolutional network is an adaptation of the convolutional neural network for encoding graphs .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: Given a graph with n nodes , we can represent the graph structure with an n n adjacency matrix A where A ij = 1 if there is an edge going from node i to node j.
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: In an L-layer GCN , if we denote by h ( l?1 ) i the input vector and h ( l ) i the output vector of node i at the l - th layer , a graph convolution operation can be written as
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: where W ( l ) is a linear transformation , b ( l ) a bias term , and ?
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: a nonlinear function ( e.g. , ReLU ) .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: Intuitively , during each graph convolution , each node gathers and summarizes information from its neighboring nodes in the graph .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: We adapt the graph convolution operation to model dependency trees by converting each tree into its corresponding adjacency matrix A , where A ij = 1 if there is a dependency edge between tokens i and j .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: However , naively applying the graph convolution operation in Equation ( 1 ) could lead to node representations with drastically different magnitudes , since the degree of a token varies a lot .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: This could bias our sentence representation towards favoring high - degree nodes regardless of the information carried in the node ( see details in Section 2.2 ) .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: Furthermore , the information in h ( l?1 ) i is never carried over to hi , since nodes never connect to themselves in a dependency tree .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: We resolve these issues by normalizing the activations in the graph convolution before feeding it through the nonlinearity , and adding self - loops to each node in the graph :
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: where = A + I with I being then n identity matrix , and d i = n j=1 ij is the degree of token i in the resulting graph . :
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: Relation extraction with a graph convolutional network .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: The left side shows the overall architecture , while on the right side , we only show the detailed graph convolution computation for the word " relative " for clarity .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: A full unlabeled dependency parse of the sentence is also provided for reference .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: Stacking this operation over
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: L layers gives us a deep GCN network , where we set h Moreover , the propagation of information between tokens occurs in parallel , and the runtime does not depend on the depth of the dependency tree .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: Note that the GCN model presented above uses the same parameters for all edges in the dependency graph .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: We also experimented with : ( 1 ) using different transformation matrices W for topdown , bottom - up , and self - loop edges ; and ( 2 ) adding dependency relation - specific parameters for edge - wise gating , similar to .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: We found that modeling directions does not lead to improvement , 1 and adding edgewise gating further hurts performance .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: We hypothesize that this is because the presented GCN model is usually already able to capture dependency edge patterns that are informative for classifying relations , and modeling edge directions and types does not offer additional discriminative power to the network before it leads to overfitting .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: For example , the relations entailed by " A 's son , B " and " B 's son , A " can be readily distinguished with " 's " attached to different entities , even when edge directionality is not considered .
heading: Graph Convolutional Networks over Dependency Trees

text: Encoding Relations with GCN
We now formally define the task of relation extraction .
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: Let X = [ x 1 , ... , x n ] denote a sentence , where xi is the i th token .
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: A subject entity and an object entity are identified and correspond to two spans in the sentence :
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: Given X , X s , and X o , the goal of relation extraction is to predict a relation r ?
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: R ( a predefined relation set ) that holds between the entities or " no relation " otherwise .
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: After applying an L-layer GCN over word vectors , we obtain hidden representations of each token that are directly influenced by its neighbors no more than L edges apart in the dependency tree .
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: To make use of these word representations for relation extraction , we first obtain a sentence representation as follows ( see also left ) :
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: where h ( l ) denotes the collective hidden representations at layer l of the GCN , and f : R dn ?
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: Rd is a max pooling function that maps from n output vectors to the sentence vector .
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: We also observe that information close to entity tokens in the dependency tree is often central to relation classification .
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: Therefore , we also obtain a subject representation h s from h ( L ) as follows
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: as well as an object representation ho similarly .
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: Inspired by recent work on relational learning between entities , we obtain the final representation used for classification by concatenating the sentence and the entity representations , and feeding them through a feed - forward neural network ( FFNN ) :
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: This h final representation is then fed into a linear layer followed by a softmax operation to obtain a probability distribution over relations .
heading: Encoding Relations with GCN

text: Contextualized GCN
The network architecture introduced so far learns effective representations for relation extraction , but it also leaves a few issues inadequately addressed .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: First , the input word vectors do not contain contextual information about word order or disambiguation .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: Second , the GCN highly depends on a correct parse tree to extract crucial information from the sentence ( especially when pruning is performed ) , while existing parsing algorithms produce imperfect trees in many cases .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: To resolve these issues , we further apply a Contextualized GCN ( C - GCN ) model , where the input word vectors are first fed into a bi-directional long short - term memory ( LSTM ) network to generate contextualized representations , which are then used ash ( 0 ) in the original model .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: This BiL - STM contextualization layer is trained jointly with the rest of the network .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: We show empirically in Section 5 that this augmentation substantially improves the performance over the original model .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: We note that this relation extraction model is conceptually similar to graph kernel - based models , in that it aims to utilize local dependency tree patterns to inform relation classification .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: Our model also incorporates crucial off - path information , which greatly improves its robustness compared to shortest dependency pathbased approaches .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: Compared to tree - structured models ( e.g. , Tree - LSTM
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: ( Tai et al. , 2015 ) ) , it not only is able to capture more global information through the use of pooling functions , but also achieves substantial speedup by not requiring recursive operations that are difficult to parallelize .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: For example , we observe that on a Titan Xp GPU , training a Tree - LSTM model over a minibatch of 50 examples takes 6.54 seconds on average , while training the original GCN model takes only 0.07 seconds , and the C - GCN model 0.08 seconds .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: Incorporating Off - path Information with Path - centric Pruning
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: Dependency trees provide rich structures that one can exploit in relation extraction , but most of the information pertinent to relations is usually contained within the subtree rooted at the lowest common ancestor ( LCA ) of the two entities .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: Previous studies have shown that removing tokens outside this scope helps relation extraction by eliminating irrelevant information from the sentence .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: It is therefore desirable to combine our GCN models with tree pruning strategies to further improve performance .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: However , pruning too aggressively ( e.g. , keeping only the dependency path ) could lead to loss of crucial information and conversely hurt robustness .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: For instance , the negation in is neglected when a model is restricted to only looking at the dependency path between the entities .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: Similarly , in the sentence " She was diagnosed with cancer last year , and succumbed this June " , the dependency path She?diagnosed ?
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: cancer is not sufficient to establish that cancer is the cause of death for the subject unless the conjunction dependency to succumbed is also present .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: Motivated by these observations , we propose path - centric pruning , a novel technique to incorporate information off the dependency path .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: This is achieved by including tokens that are up to distance K away from the dependency path in the LCA subtree .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: K = 0 , corresponds to pruning the tree down to the path , K = 1 keeps all nodes that are directly attached to the path , and K = ?
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: retains the entire LCA subtree .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: We combine this pruning strategy with our GCN model , by directly feeding the pruned trees into the graph convolutional layers .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: We show that pruning with K = 1 achieves the best balance between including relevant information ( e.g. , negation and conjunction ) and keeping irrelevant content out of the resulting pruned tree as much as possible .
heading: Contextualized GCN

text: Related Work
At the core of fully - supervised and distantlysupervised relation extraction approaches are statistical classifiers , many of which find syntactic information beneficial .
heading: Related Work

text: For example , explored adding syntactic features to a statistical classifier and found them to be useful when sentences are long .
heading: Related Work

text: Various kernel - based approaches also leverage syntactic information to measure similarity between training and test examples to predict the relation , finding that tree - based kernels and dependency path - based kernels ( Bunescu and Mooney , 2005 ) are effective for this task .
heading: Related Work

text: Recent studies have found neural models effective in relation extraction .
heading: Related Work

text: first applied a one - dimensional convolutional neural network ( CNN ) with manual features to encode relations .
heading: Related Work

text: showed that combining a CNN with a recurrent neural network ( RNN ) through a voting scheme can further improve performance .
heading: Related Work

text: and proposed to use attention mechanisms over RNN and CNN architectures for this task .
heading: Related Work

text: Apart from neural models over word sequences , incorporating dependency trees into neural models has also been shown to improve relation extraction performance by capturing long - distance relations .
heading: Related Work

text: generalized the idea of dependency path kernels by applying a LSTM network over the shortest dependency path between entities .
heading: Related Work

text: Liu et al. first applied a recursive network over the subtrees rooted at the words on the dependency path and then applied a CNN over the path .
heading: Related Work

text: Miwa and Bansal ( 2016 ) applied a Tree - LSTM , a generalized form of LSTM over dependency trees , in a joint entity and relation extraction setting .
heading: Related Work

text: They found it to be most effective when applied to the subtree rooted at the LCA of the two entities .
heading: Related Work

text: More recently , and have shown that relatively simple neural models ( CNN and augmented LSTM , respectively ) can achieve comparable or superior performance to dependency - based models when trained on larger datasets .
heading: Related Work

text: In this paper , we study dependency - based models in depth and show that with a properly designed architecture , they can outperform and have complementary advantages to sequence models , even in a large - scale setting .
heading: Related Work

text: Finally , we note that a technique similar to pathcentric pruning has been applied to reduce the space of possible arguments in semantic role labeling .
heading: Related Work

text: The authors showed pruning words too faraway from the path between the predicate and the root to be beneficial , but reported the best pruning distance to be 10 , which almost always retains the entire tree .
heading: Related Work

text: Our method differs in that it is applied to the shortest dependency path between entities , and we show that in our technique the best pruning distance is 1 for several dependency - based relation extraction models .
heading: Related Work

text: Experiments
Baseline Models
We compare our models with several competitive dependency - based and neural sequence models .
heading: Baseline Models

text: Dependency - based models .
heading: Baseline Models

text: In our main experiments we compare with three types of dependency - based models .
heading: Baseline Models

text: ( 1 ) A logistic regression ( LR ) classifier which combines dependencybased features with other lexical features .
heading: Baseline Models

text: ( 2 ) Shortest Dependency Path LSTM ( SDP - LSTM ) , which applies a neural sequence model on the shortest path between the subject and object entities in the dependency tree .
heading: Baseline Models

text: Tree - LSTM , which is a recursive model that generalizes the LSTM to arbitrary tree structures .
heading: Baseline Models

text: We investigate the child - sum variant of Tree - LSTM , and apply it to the dependency tree ( or part of it ) .
heading: Baseline Models

text: In practice , we find that modifying this model by concatenating dependency label embeddings to the input of forget gates improves its performance on relation extraction , and therefore use this variant in our experiments .
heading: Baseline Models

text: Earlier , our group compared and with sequence models , and we report these results ; for ( 3 ) we report results with our own implementation .
heading: Baseline Models

text: Neural sequence model .
heading: Baseline Models

text: Our group presented a competitive sequence model that employs a position - aware attention mechanism over LSTM outputs ( PA - LSTM ) , and showed that it outperforms several CNN and dependency - based models by a substantial margin .
heading: Baseline Models

text: We compare with this strong baseline , and use its open implementation in further analysis .
heading: Baseline Models

text: Experimental Setup
We conduct experiments on two relation extraction datasets :
heading: Experimental Setup

text: ( 1 ) TACRED : Introduced in , TACRED contains over 106 k mention pairs drawn from the yearly TAC KBP 4 challenge .
heading: Experimental Setup

text: It represents 41 relation types and a special no relation class when the mention pair does not have a relation between them within these categories .
heading: Experimental Setup

text: Mentions in TACRED are typed , with subjects categorized into person and organization , and objects into 16 fine - grained types ( e.g. , date and location ) .
heading: Experimental Setup

text: We report micro-averaged F 1 scores on this dataset as is conventional .
heading: Experimental Setup

text: For fair comparisons on the TACRED dataset , we follow the evaluation protocol used in by selecting the model with the median dev F 1 from 5 independent runs and reporting its test F 1 .
heading: Experimental Setup

text: We also use the same " entity mask " strategy where we replace each subject ( and object similarly ) entity with a special SUBJ - < NER > token .
heading: Experimental Setup

text: For all models , we also adopt the " multichannel " strategy by concatenating the input word embeddings with POS and NER embeddings .
heading: Experimental Setup

text: Traditionally , evaluation on SemEval is conducted without entity mentions masked .
heading: Experimental Setup

text: However , as we will discuss in Section 6.4 , this method encourages models to overfit to these mentions and fails to test their actual ability to generalize .
heading: Experimental Setup

text: We therefore report results with two evaluation protocols : ( 1 ) with- mention , where mentions are kept for comparison with previous work ; and ( 2 ) maskmention , where they are masked to test the generalization of our model in a more realistic setting .
heading: Experimental Setup

text: Due to space limitations , we report model training details in the supplementary material .
heading: Experimental Setup

text: Effect of Path - centric
heading: Results on the SemEval Dataset

text: Pruning
To show the effectiveness of path - centric pruning , we compare the two GCN models and the Tree - LSTM when the pruning distance K is varied .
heading: Pruning

text: We experimented with K ? { 0 , 1 , 2 , ?} on the TACRED dev set , and also include results when the full tree is used .
heading: Pruning

text: As shown in , the performance of all three models peaks when K = 1 , outperforming their respective dependency path - based counterpart ( K = 0 ) .
heading: Pruning

text: This confirms our hypothesis in Section 3 that incorporating off - path information is crucial to relation extraction .
heading: Pruning

text: Miwa and Bansal ( 2016 ) reported that a Tree - LSTM achieves similar performance when the dependency path and the LCA subtree are used respectively .
heading: Pruning

text: Our experiments confirm this , and further show that the result can be improved by path - centric pruning with K = 1 .
heading: Pruning

text: We find that all three models are less effective when the entire dependency tree is present , indicating that including extra information hurts performance .
heading: Pruning

text: Finally , we note that contextualizing the GCN makes it less sensitive to changes in the tree structures provided , presumably because the model can use word sequence information in the LSTM layer to recover any off - path information that it needs for correct relation extraction .
heading: Pruning

text: Understanding Model Behavior
To gain more insights into the C - GCN model 's behavior , we visualized the partial dependency tree it is processing and how much each token 's final representation contributed to h sent ( ) .
heading: Understanding Model Behavior

text: We find that the model often focuses on the dependency path , but sometimes also incorporates offpath information to help reinforce its prediction .
heading: Understanding Model Behavior

text: The model also learns to ignore determiners ( e.g. , " the " ) as they rarely affect relation prediction .
heading: Understanding Model Behavior

In our study , we observed a high correlation between the entity mentions in a sentence and its relation label in the SemEval dataset .
heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

text: The first example shows that the C - GCN is effective at leveraging long - range dependencies while reducing noise with the help of pruning ( while the PA - LSTM predicts no relation twice , org : alternate names twice , and org : parents once in this case ) .
heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

text: The second example shows that the PA - LSTM is better at leveraging the proximity of the word " migrated " regardless of attachment errors in the parse ( while the C - GCN is misled to predict per :country of birth three times , and no relation twice ) .
heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

text: phenomenon .
heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

text: We started by simplifying every sentence in the SemEval training and dev sets to " subject and object " , where subject and object are the actual entities in the sentence .
heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

text: Surprisingly , a trained PA - LSTM model on this data is able to achieve 65.1 F 1 on the dev set if Glo Ve is used to initialize word vectors , and 47.9 dev F 1 even without GloVe initialization .
heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

text: To further evaluate the model in a more realistic setting , we trained one model with the original SemEval training set ( unmasked ) and one with mentions masked in the training set , following what we have done for TACRED ( masked ) .
heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

text: While the unmasked model achieves a 83.6 F 1 on the original SemEval dev set , F 1 drops drastically to 62.4 if we replace dev set entity mentions with a special < UNK > token to simulate the presence of unseen entities .
heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

text: In contrast , the masked model is unaffected by unseen entity mentions and achieves a stable dev F 1 of 74.7 .
heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

text: This suggests that models trained without entities masked generalize poorly to new examples with unseen entities .
heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

text: Our findings call for more careful evaluation that takes dataset biases into account in future relation extraction studies .
heading: Entity Bias in the SemEval Dataset

text: Conclusion
We showed the success of a neural architecture based on a graph convolutional network for relation extraction .
heading: Conclusion

text: We also proposed path - centric pruning to improve the robustness of dependencybased models by removing irrelevant content without ignoring crucial information .
heading: Conclusion

text: We showed through detailed analysis that our model has complementary strengths to sequence models , and that the proposed pruning technique can be effectively applied to other dependency - based models .
heading: Conclusion

text: A Experimental Details
A.1 Hyperparameters TACRED
We set LSTM hidden size to 200 in all neural models .

heading: A.1 Hyperparameters TACRED

text: title
End - to - end neural relation extraction using deep biaffine attention
heading: title

text: abstract
We propose a neural network model for joint extraction of named entities and relations between them , without any hand - crafted features .
heading: abstract

text: The key contribution of our model is to extend a BiLSTM - CRF - based entity recognition model with a deep biaffine attention layer to model second - order interactions between latent features for relation classification , specifically attending to the role of an entity in a directional relationship .
heading: abstract

text: On the benchmark " relation and entity recognition " dataset CoNLL04 , experimental results show that our model outperforms previous models , producing new state - of - the - art performances .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Extracting entities and their semantic relations from raw text is a key information extraction task .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , given the sentence " David Foster is the AP 's Northwest regional reporter , based in Seattle " in the CoNLL04 dataset , our goal is to recognize " David Foster " as person , " AP " as organization , and " Northwest " and " Seattle " as location entities , then classifiy entity pairs to extract structured information : Work For ( David Foster , AP ) , OrgBased In ( AP , Northwest ) and OrgBased In ( AP , Seattle ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Such information is useful in many other NLP tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: Especially in IR applications such as entity search , structured search and question answering , it helps provide end users with significantly better search experience .
heading: Introduction

text: A common relation extraction approach is to construct pipeline systems with separate sub-systems for the two tasks of named entity recognition and relation classification .
heading: Introduction

text: More recently , end - to - end systems which jointly learn to extract entities and relations have been proposed with strong potential to obtain high performance .
heading: Introduction

text: Traditional joint approaches are feature - based supervised learning methods which employ numerous syntactic and lexical features based on external NLP tools as well as knowledge base resources .
heading: Introduction

text: State - of - the - art relation extraction performance has been obtained by end - to - end models based on neural networks .
heading: Introduction

text: Specifically , proposed a RNNbased model which achieved top results on the CoNLL04 dataset .
heading: Introduction

text: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .
Other neural models employ dependency parsing - based information .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: In particular , applied bottom - up and top - down tree - structured LSTMs to model dependency paths between entities .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: integrated implicit syntactic information by using latent feature representations extracted from a pre-trained BiLSTM - based dependency parser .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: entity recognition , and a CNN on top of the BiLSTM for classifying relations .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: Adel and Schtze ( 2017 ) assumed that entity boundaries are given , and trained a CNN to extract context features around the entities , and using these features for entity and relation classification .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: Recently , formulated the joint entity and relation extraction problem as a directed graph and proposed a BiLSTM - and transition - based approach to generate the graph incrementally . [ 4 ] extended the multi-head selection - based joint model with adversarial training .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: In , the joint task is formulated as a sequence tagging problem , and a BiLSTM with a softmax output layer can then be used for joint prediction .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: In this paper , we present a novel end - to - end neural model for joint entity and relation extraction .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: As illustrated in , our model architecture can be viewed as a mixture of a named entity recognition ( NER ) component and a relation classification ( RC ) component .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: Our NER component employs a BiLSTM - CRF architecture to predict entities from input word tokens .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: Based on both the input words and the predicted NER labels , the RC component uses another BiLSTM to learn latent features relevant for relation classification .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: In most previous neural joint models , the relation classification part relies on a common " linear " concatenation - based mechanism over the latent features associated with entity pairs , i.e. the latent features are first concatenated into a single feature vector which is then linearly transformed before being fed into a softmax classifier .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: In contrast , our RC component takes into account second - order interactions over the latent features via a tensor .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: In particular , for relation classification we propose a novel use of the deep biaffine attention mechanism which was first introduced in dependency parsing .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: Experimental results on the benchmark " relation and entity recognition " dataset CoNLL04 show that our model outperforms previous models , obtaining new stateof - the - art scores .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: In addition , using the biaffine attention improves the performance compared to using the linear mechanism significantly .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: We also provide an ablation study to investigate effects of different contributing factors in our model .
heading: Their approach relies on various manually extracted features .

text: Our proposed model
This section details our end - to - end relation extraction model .
heading: Our proposed model

text: Given an input sequence of n word tokens w 1 , w 2 , ... , w n , we use a vector vi to represent each i th word w i by concatenating word embedding e
heading: Our proposed model

text: Here , for each word type w , we use a one - layer BiLSTM ( BiLSTM char ) to learn its character - level word embedding e ( C ) w.
heading: Our proposed model

text: Named entity recognition ( NER ) :
heading: Our proposed model

text: The NER component feeds the sequence of vectors v 1:n with an additional context position index i into another BiLSTM ( BiLSTM NER ) to learn a " latent " feature vector representing the i th word token .
heading: Our proposed model

text: Then the NER component performs linear transformation of each latent feature vector by using a single - layer feed - forward network ( FFNN NER ) :
heading: Our proposed model

text: The output layer size of FFNN NER is the number of BIOLU - based NER labels .
heading: Our proposed model

text: The NER component feeds the output vectors h 1:n into a linear - chain CRF layer for NER label prediction .
heading: Our proposed model

text: A cross-entropy loss L NER is computed during training , while the Viterbi algorithm is used for decoding .
heading: Our proposed model

text: Our NER component thus is the BiLSTM - CRF model with additional LSTM - based character - level word embeddings .
heading: Our proposed model

text: Relation classification ( RC ) : Assume that t 1 , t 2 , ... , tn are NER labels predicted by the NER component for the input words .
heading: Our proposed model

text: We represent each i th predicted label by a vector embedding e ti .
heading: Our proposed model

text: We create a sequence of vectors x 1:n in which each x i is computed as :
heading: Our proposed model

text: As for NER , the RC component also uses a BiLSTM ( BiLSTM RC ) to learn another set of latent feature vectors , but from the sequence x 1:n :
heading: Our proposed model

text: The RC component further uses these latent vectors r i for relation classification .
heading: Our proposed model

text: We propose a novel use of the deep biaffine attention mechanism for relation classification .
heading: Our proposed model

text: The biaffine attention mechanism was proposed for dependency parsing , helping to produce the best reported parsing performance to date .
heading: Our proposed model

text: First , to encode the directionality of a relation , we use two single - layer feed - forward networks to project each r i into head and tail vector representations which correspond to whether the i th word serves as the head or tail argument of the relation :
heading: Our proposed model

text: Following , our RC component incrementally constructs relation candidates using all possible combinations of the last word tokens of predicted entities , i.e. words with L or U labels .
heading: Our proposed model

text: We assign an entity pair to a negative relation class ( NEG ) when the pair has no relation or when the predicted entities are not correct .
heading: Our proposed model

text: For example , for , we would have two relation candidates : NEG ( Paris , International ) and OrgBased In ( International , Paris ) .
heading: Our proposed model

text: Then for each head - tail candidate pair ( w j , wk ) , we apply the biaffine attention operator :
heading: Our proposed model

heading: Our model is implemented using DYNET v 2.0 .

Metric : Similar to previous works in , we use the macro -averaged F1 - score over the entity classes to score NER / EC and over the relation classes to score RC .

text: In contrast , we do not find any significant difference in Setup 2 scores when not using either the character - level embeddings or the CRF layer , clearly showing the usefulness of the given gold entity boundaries .
heading: A similar observation is also found in .

text: The 3 remaining factors , including removing NER label embeddings and not taking either the Bilinear or Linear part ( in Equation 8 ) into the Biaffine attention layer , do not affect the NER / EC score .
heading: A similar observation is also found in .

text: However , they significantly decrease the RC score .
This is reasonable because those 3 factors are part of the RC component only , thus helpful in predicting relations .
heading: However , they significantly decrease the RC score .

text: More specifically , using the Biaffine attention produces about 1.5 % significant improvements to a common Linear transformation mechanism in relation classification , i.e. , " w / o Bilinear " results against the full results in : 65.4 % vs. 66.9 % and 72.0 % vs. 73.3 % ( although using Biaffine increases training time over using Linear by 35 % , relatively ) .
heading: However , they significantly decrease the RC score .

text: Conclusion
In this paper , we have presented an end - to - end neural network - based relation extraction model .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our model employs a BiLSTM - CRF architecture for entity recognition and a biaffine attention mechanism for relation classification .
heading: Conclusion

text: On the benchmark CoNLL04 dataset , our model produces new state - of - the - art performance .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Semantic Relation Classification via Bidirectional LSTM Networks with Entity - aware Attention using Latent Entity Typing
heading: title

text: abstract
Classifying semantic relations between entity pairs in sentences is an important task in Natural Language Processing ( NLP ) .
heading: abstract

text: Most previous models for relation classification rely on the high - level lexical and syntatic features obtained by NLP tools such as WordNet , dependency parser , part - ofspeech ( POS ) tagger , and named entity recognizers ( NER ) .
heading: abstract

text: In addition , state - of - the - art neural models based on attention mechanisms do not fully utilize information of entity that maybe the most crucial features for relation classification .
heading: abstract

text: To address these issues , we propose a novel end - to - end recurrent neural model which incorporates an entity - aware attention mechanism with a latent entity typing ( LET ) method .
heading: abstract

text: Our model not only utilizes entities and their latent types as features effectively but also is more interpretable by visualizing attention mechanisms applied to our model and results of LET .
heading: abstract

text: Experimental results on the SemEval - 2010 Task 8 , one of the most popular relation classification task , demonstrate that our model outperforms existing state - of the - art models without any high - level features .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Classifying semantic relations between entity pairs in sentences plays a vital role in various NLP tasks , such as information extraction , question answering and knowledge base population .
heading: Introduction

text: A task of relation classification is defined as predicting a semantic relationship between two tagged entities in a sentence .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , given a sentence with tagged entity pair , crash and attack , this sentence is classified into the re-lation Cause - Effect ( e1 , e2 ) 1 between the entity pair like .
heading: Introduction

text: A first entity is surrounded by e 1 and / e 1 , and a second entity is surrounded by e 2 and / e 2 .
heading: Introduction

text: Most previous relation classification models rely heavily on high - level lexical and syntactic features obtained from NLP tools such as WordNet , dependency parser , part - of - speech ( POS ) tagger , and named entity recognizer ( NER ) .
heading: Introduction

text: The classification models relying on such features suffer from propagation of implicit error of the tools and they are computationally expensive .
heading: Introduction

text: Recently , many studies therefore propose end - toend neural models without the high - level features .
heading: Introduction

text: Among them , attention - based models , which focus to the most important semantic information in a sentence , show state - of - the - art results in a lot of NLP tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: Since these models are mainly proposed for solving translation and language modeling tasks , they could not fully utilize the information of tagged entities in relation classification task .
heading: Introduction

text: However , tagged entity pairs could be powerful hints for solving relation classification task .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , even if we do not consider other words except the crash and attack , we intuitively know that the entity pair has a relation Cause - Effect ( e1 , e2 ) 1 better than Component - Whole ( e1 , e2 ) 1 in To address these issues , We propose a novel endto - end recurrent neural model which incorporates an entity - aware attention mechanism with a latent entity typing ( LET ) .
heading: Introduction

text: To capture the context of sentences , We obtain word representations by self attention mechanisms and build the recurrent neural architecture with Bidirectional Long Short - Term Memory ( LSTM ) networks .
heading: Introduction

text: Entity - aware attention focuses on the most important semantic information considering entity pairs with word positions relative to these pairs and latent types obtained by LET .
heading: Introduction

text: The contributions of our work are summarized as follows :
heading: Introduction

text: We propose an novel end - to - end recurrent neural model and an entity - aware attention mechanism with a LET which focuses to semantic information of entities and their latent types ; ( 2 ) Our model obtains 85.2 % F1 - score in SemEval- 2010 Task 8 and it outper - forms existing state - of - the - art models without any highlevel features ;
heading: Introduction

text: We show that our model is more interpretable since it 's decision making process could be visualized with self attention , entity - aware attention , and LET .
heading: Introduction

text: Related Work
There are several studies for solving relation classification task .
heading: Related Work

text: Early methods used handcrafted features through a series of NLP tools or manually designing kernels .
heading: Related Work

text: These approaches use high - level lexical and syntactic features obtained from NLP tools and manually designing kernels , but the classification models relying on such features suffer from propagation of implicit error of the tools .
heading: Related Work

text: On the other hands , deep neural networks have shown outperform previous models using handcraft features .
heading: Related Work

text: Especially , many researches tried to solve the problem based on end - to - end models using only raw sentences and pre-trained word representations learned by Skip - gram and Continuous Bag - of - Words .
heading: Related Work

text: Zeng et al .
heading: Related Work

text: employed a deep convolutional neural network ( CNN ) for extracting lexical and sentence level features .
heading: Related Work

text: Dos Santos et al.
heading: Related Work

text: proposed model for learning vector of each relation class using ranking loss to reduce the impact of artificial classes .
heading: Related Work

text: Zhang and Wang used bidirectional recurrent neural network ( RNN ) to learn long - term dependency between entity pairs .
heading: Related Work

text: Fur-thermore , Zhang et al. proposed bidirectional LSTM network ( BLSTM ) utilizing position of words , POS tags , named entity information , dependency parse .
heading: Related Work

text: This model resolved vanishing gradient problem appeared in RNNs by using BLSTM .
heading: Related Work

text: Recently , some researcher have proposed attentionbased models which can focus to the most important semantic information in a sentence .
heading: Related Work

text: Zhou et al. combined attention mechanisms with BLSTM .
heading: Related Work

text: Xiao and Liu split the sentence into two entities and used two attention - based BLSTM hierarchically .
heading: Related Work

text: Shen and Huang proposed attention - based CNN using word level attention mechanism that is able to better determine which parts of the sentence are more influential .
heading: Related Work

text: In contrast with end - to - end model , several works proposed models utilizing the shortest dependency path ( SDP ) between entity pairs of dependency parse trees .
heading: Related Work

text: SDP - LSTM model proposed by Yan et al .
heading: Related Work

text: and deep recurrent neural networks ( DRNNs ) model proposed by Xu et al eliminate irrelevant words out of SDP and use neural network based on the meaningful words composing SDP .
heading: Related Work

text: Model
In this section , we introduce a novel recurrent neural model that incorporate an entity - aware attention mechanism with a LET method in detail .
heading: Model

text: As shown inure 2 , our model consists of four main components : Word Representation that maps each word in a sentence into vector representations ; ( 2 ) Self Attention that captures the meaning of the correlation between words based on multi-head attention ; ( 3 ) BLSTM which sequentially encodes the representations of self attention layer ; ( 4 ) Entity - aware Attention that calculates attention weights with respect to the entity pairs , word positions relative to these pairs , and their latent types obtained by LET .
heading: Model

text: After that , the features are averaged along the time steps to produce the sentencelevel features .
heading: Model

heading: Word Representation

We can obtain the richer word representations by using self attentions .
heading: Self Attention

Network

For sequentially encoding the output of self attention layer , we use a BLSTM that consists of two sub LSTM networks : a forward LSTM network which encodes the context of a input sentence and a backward LSTM network which encodes that one of the reverse sentence .
heading: Network

text: Entity - aware Attention Mechanism
heading: Network

text: Although many models with attention mechanism achieved state - of - the - art performance in many NLP tasks .
heading: Network

text: However , for the relation classification task , these models lack of prior knowledge forgiven entity pairs , which could be powerful hints for solving the task .
heading: Network

text: Relation classification differs from sentence classification in that information about entities is given along with sentences .
heading: Network

text: We propose a novel entity - aware attention mechanism for fully utilizing informative factors in given entity pairs .
heading: Network

text: Relative Position Features
In relation classification , the position of each word relative to entities has been widely used for word representations .
heading: Relative Position Features

text: Recently , position - aware attention is published as away to use the relative position features more effectively .
heading: Relative Position Features

text: It is a variant of attention mechanisms , which use not only outputs of BLSTM but also the relative position features when calculating attention weights .

text: Entity Features with Latent Type

Since entity pairs are powerful hints for solving relation classification task , we involve the entity pairs and their types in the attention mechanism to effectively train relations between entity pairs and other words in a sentence .
heading: Entity Features with Latent Type

text: We employ the two entity - aware features .
heading: Entity Features with Latent Type

text: The first is the hidden states of BLSTM corresponding to positions of entity pairs , which are high - level features representing entities .

heading: Entity Features with Latent Type

text: Using types as features can be a great way to improve performance , since the types of entities alone can be inferred the approximate relations .
heading: Entity Features with Latent Type

text: Because the annotated types are not given , we use the latent type representations by applying the LET inspired by latent topic clustering , a method for predicting latent topic of texts in question answering task .

text: Experiments
Dataset and Evaluation Metrics

We evaluate our model on the SemEval - 2010 Task 8 dataset , which is an commonly used benchmark for relation classification and compare the results with the state - of - the - art models in this area .
heading: Dataset and Evaluation Metrics

text: The dataset contains 10 distinguished relations , Cause - Effect , Instrument - Agency , Product - Producer , Content - Container , Entity - Origin , Entity - Destination , Component - Whole , Member - Collection , Message - Topic , and Other .
heading: Dataset and Evaluation Metrics

text: The former 9 relations have two directions , whereas Other is not directional , so the total number of relations is 19 .
heading: Dataset and Evaluation Metrics

text: There are 10,717 annotated sentences which consist of 8,000 samples for training and 2,717 samples for testing .
heading: Dataset and Evaluation Metrics

text: We adopt the official evaluation metric of SemEval - 2010 Task 8 , which is based on the macro -averaged F1 - score ( excluding Other ) , and takes into consideration the directionality .
heading: Dataset and Evaluation Metrics

text: Implementation Details
We tune the hyperparameters for our model on the development set randomly sampled 800 sentences for validation .
heading: Implementation Details

text: The best hyperparameters in our proposed model are shown in following .
heading: Implementation Details

text: Hyperparameter

Description Value We use pre-trained weights of the publicly available Glo Ve model to initialize word embeddings in our model , and other weights are randomly initialized from zero-mean Gaussian distribution .

text: compares our Entity - aware Attention LSTM model with state - of - theart models on this relation classification dataset .
heading: Hyperparameter

text: We divide the models into three groups , Non-Neural Model , SDP - based Model , and End - to - End Model .

text: First , the SVM , Non-Neural Model , was top of the SemEval - 2010 task , during the official competition period .
heading: Hyperparameter

text: As a result , they achieved an F1-score of 82.2 % .
heading: Hyperparameter

text: The second is SDP - based Model such as MVRNN , FCM , DepNN , de pLCNN + NS , SDP - LSTM , and DRNNs .
heading: Hyperparameter

text: The SDP is reasonable features for detecting semantic structure of sentences .
heading: Hyperparameter

text: Actually , the SDP - based models show high performance , but SDP may not always be accurate and the parsing time is exponentially increased by long sentences .
heading: Hyperparameter

text: The last model is End - to - End Model automatically learned internal representations can occur between the original inputs and the final outputs in deep learning .
heading: Hyperparameter

text: There are CNN - based models such as CNN , CR - CNN , and Attention - CNN and RNN - based models such as BLSTM , Attention - BLSTM , and Hierarchical - BLSTM ( Hier - BLSTM ) for this task .
heading: Hyperparameter

text: Experimental Results
Model F1
Non Our proposed model achieves an F1-score of 85.2 % which outperforms all competing state - of - theart approaches except depLCNN + NS , DRNNs , and Attention - CNN .
heading: Model F1

text: However , they rely on high - level lexical features such as WordNet , dependency parse trees , POS tags , and NER tags from NLP tools .

text: Visualization
There are three different visualization to demonstrate that our model is more interpretable .
heading: Visualization

text: First , the visualization of self attention shows where each word focus on parts of a sentence .
heading: Visualization

text: By showing the words that the entity pair attends , we can find the words that well represent the relation between them .
heading: Visualization

text: Next , the entity - aware attention visualization shows where the model pays attend to a sentence .
heading: Visualization

text: This visualization result highlights important words in a sentence , which are usually important keywords for classification .
heading: Visualization

text: Finally , we visualize representation of type in LET by using t- SNE , a method for dimensionality reduction , and group the whole entities in the dataset by the its latent types .
heading: Visualization

text: Entity - aware Attention
heading: Visualization

text: Latent Entity Type
Conclusion

In this paper , we proposed entity - aware attention mechanism with latent entity typing and a novel end - to - end recurrent neural model which incorporates this mechanism for relation classification .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our model achieves 85.2 % F1 - score in SemEval- 2010
heading: Conclusion

text: Task 8 using only raw sentence and word embeddings without any high - level features from NLP tools and it outperforms existing state - of - the - art methods .
heading: Conclusion

text: In addition , our three visualizations of attention mechanisms applied to the model demonstrate that our model is more interpretable than previous models .
heading: Conclusion

text: We expect our model to be extended not only the relation classification task but also other tasks that entity plays an important role .
heading: Conclusion

text: Especially , latent entity typing can be effectively applied to sequence modeling task using entity information without NER .
heading: Conclusion

text: In the future , we will propose anew method in question answering or knowledge base population based on relations between entities extracted from our model .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Data and text mining BioBERT : a pre-trained biomedical language representation model for biomedical text mining
heading: title

text: abstract
Motivation :
heading: abstract

text: Biomedical text mining is becoming increasingly important as the number of biomedical documents rapidly grows .
heading: abstract

text: With the progress in natural language processing ( NLP ) , extracting valuable information from biomedical literature has gained popularity among researchers , and deep learning has boosted the development of effective biomedical text mining models .
heading: abstract

text: However , directly applying the advancements in NLP to biomedical text mining often yields unsatisfactory results due to a word distribution shift from general domain corpora to biomedical corpora .
heading: abstract

text: In this article , we investigate how the recently introduced pre-trained language model BERT can be adapted for biomedical corpora .
heading: abstract

text: Results :
heading: abstract

text: We introduce BioBERT ( Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers for Biomedical Text Mining ) , which is a domain - specific language representation model pre-trained on large - scale biomedical corpora .
heading: abstract

text: With almost the same architecture across tasks , BioBERT largely outperforms BERT and previous state - of - the - art models in a variety of biomedical text mining tasks when pre-trained on biomedical corpora .
heading: abstract

text: While BERT obtains performance comparable to that of previous state - of - the - art models , BioBERT significantly outperforms them on the following three representative biomedical text mining tasks : biomedical named entity recognition ( 0.62 % F1 score improvement ) , biomedical relation extraction ( 2.80 % F1 score improvement ) and biomedical question answering ( 12.24 % MRR improvement ) .
heading: abstract

text: Our analysis results show that pre-training BERT on biomedical corpora helps it to understand complex biomedical texts .
heading: abstract

text: Availability and implementation :
heading: abstract

text: We make the pre-trained weights of BioBERT freely available at https://github. com/naver/biobert-pretrained , and the source code for fine - tuning
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
The volume of biomedical literature continues to rapidly increase .
heading: Introduction

text: On average , more than 3000 new articles are published everyday in peer-reviewed journals , excluding pre-prints and technical reports such as clinical trial reports in various archives .
heading: Introduction

text: PubMed alone has a total of 29M articles as of January 2019 .
heading: Introduction

text: Reports containing valuable information about new discoveries and new insights are continuously added to the already overwhelming amount of literature .
heading: Introduction

text: Consequently , there is increasingly more demand for accurate biomedical text mining tools for extracting information from the literature .
heading: Introduction

text: Recent progress of biomedical text mining models was made possible by the advancements of deep learning techniques used in natural language processing ( NLP ) .
heading: Introduction

text: For instance , Long Short - Term Memory ( LSTM ) and Conditional Random Field ( CRF ) have greatly improved performance in biomedical named entity recognition ( NER ) over the last few years .
heading: Introduction

text: Other deep learning based models have made improvements in biomedical text mining tasks such as relation extraction ( RE ) and question answering ( QA ) .
heading: Introduction

text: However , directly applying state - of - the - art NLP methodologies to biomedical text mining has limitations .
heading: Introduction

text: First , as recent word representation models such as Word2 Vec , ELMo and BERT are trained and tested mainly on datasets containing general domain texts ( e.g. Wikipedia ) , it is difficult to estimate their performance on datasets containing biomedical texts .
heading: Introduction

text: Also , the word distributions of general and biomedical corpora are quite different , which can often be a problem for biomedical text mining models .
heading: Introduction

text: As a result , recent models in biomedical text mining rely largely on adapted versions of word representations .
heading: Introduction

text: In this study , we hypothesize that current state - of - the - art word representation models such as BERT need to be trained on biomedical corpora to be effective in biomedical text mining tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: Previously , Word2 Vec , which is one of the most widely known context independent word representation models , was trained on biomedical corpora which contain terms and expressions that are usually not included in a general domain corpus .
heading: Introduction

text: While ELMo and BERT have proven the effectiveness of contextualized word representations , they can not obtain high performance on biomedical corpora because they are pre-trained on only general domain corpora .
heading: Introduction

text: As BERT achieves very strong results on various NLP tasks while using almost the same structure across the tasks , adapting BERT for the biomedical domain could potentially benefit numerous biomedical NLP researches .
heading: Introduction

text: Approach
In this article , we introduce BioBERT , which is a pre-trained language representation model for the biomedical domain .
heading: Approach

text: The overall process of pre-training and fine - tuning BioBERT is illustrated in .
heading: Approach

text: First , we initialize BioBERT with weights from BERT , which was pretrained on general domain corpora ( English Wikipedia and Books Corpus ) .
heading: Approach

text: Then , BioBERT is pre-trained on biomedical domain corpora ( PubMed abstracts and PMC full - text articles ) .
heading: Approach

text: To show the effectiveness of our approach in biomedical text mining , BioBERT is fine - tuned and evaluated on three popular biomedical text mining tasks .
heading: Approach

text: We test various pre-training strategies with different combinations and sizes of general domain corpora and biomedical corpora , and analyze the effect of each corpus on pre-training .
heading: Approach

text: We also provide in - depth analyses of BERT and BioBERT to show the necessity of our pre-training strategies .
heading: Approach

text: The contributions of our paper are as follows :
heading: Approach

text: BioBERT is the first domain - specific BERT based model pretrained on biomedical corpora for 23 days on eight NVIDIA V100 GPUs .
heading: Approach

text: We show that pre-training BERT on biomedical corpora largely improves its performance .
heading: Approach

text: BioBERT obtains higher F 1 scores in biomedical NER ( 0.62 ) and biomedical RE ( 2.80 ) , and a higher MRR score ( 12.24 ) in biomedical QA than the current state - of the - art models .
heading: Approach

text: Compared with most previous biomedical text mining models that are mainly focused on a single task such as NER or QA , our model BioBERT achieves state - of - the - art performance on various biomedical text mining tasks , while requiring only minimal architectural modifications .
heading: Approach

text: We make our pre-processed datasets , the pre-trained weights of BioBERT and the source code for fine - tuning BioBERT publicly available .
heading: Approach

text: Materials and methods
BioBERT basically has the same structure as BERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We briefly discuss the recently proposed BERT , and then we describe in detail the pre-training and fine - tuning process of BioBERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: BERT : bidirectional encoder representations from transformers
heading: Materials and methods

text: Learning word representations from a large amount of unannotated text is a long - established method .
heading: Materials and methods

text: While previous models ( e.g. Word2 Vec , GloVe ) focused on learning context independent word representations , recent works have focused on learning context dependent word representations .
heading: Materials and methods

text: For instance , ELMo uses a bidirectional language model , while uses machine translation to embed context information into word representations .
heading: Materials and methods

text: BERT is a contextualized word representation model that is based on a masked language model and pretrained using bidirectional transformers .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Due to the nature of language modeling where future words can not be seen , previous language models were limited to a combination of two unidirectional language models ( i.e. left - to - right and right - toleft ) .
heading: Materials and methods

text: BERT uses a masked language model that predicts randomly masked words in a sequence , and hence can be used for learning bidirectional representations .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Also , it obtains state - of - the - art performance on most NLP tasks , while requiring minimal task - specific architectural modification .
heading: Materials and methods

text: According to the authors of BERT , incorporating information from bidirectional representations , rather than unidirectional representations , is crucial for representing words in natural language .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We hypothesize that such bidirectional representations are also critical in biomedical text mining as complex relationships between biomedical terms often exist in a biomedical corpus .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Due to the space limitations , we refer readers to fora more detailed description of BERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Pre-training BioBERT
heading: Materials and methods

text: As a general purpose language representation model , BERT was pretrained on English Wikipedia and Books Corpus .
heading: Materials and methods

text: However , biomedical domain texts contain a considerable number of domain - specific .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Overview of the pre-training and fine - tuning of BioBERT proper nouns ( e.g. BRCA1 , c.248T > C ) and terms ( e.g. transcriptional , antimicrobial ) , which are understood mostly by biomedical researchers .
heading: Materials and methods

text: As a result , NLP models designed for general purpose language understanding often obtains poor performance in biomedical text mining tasks .
heading: Materials and methods

text: In this work , we pre-train BioBERT on PubMed abstracts ( PubMed ) and PubMed Central full - text articles ( PMC ) .
heading: Materials and methods

text: The text corpora used for pre-training of BioBERT are listed in , and the tested combinations of text corpora are listed in .
heading: Materials and methods

text: For computational efficiency , whenever the Wiki Books corpora were used for pre-training , we initialized BioBERT with the pre-trained BERT model provided by .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We define BioBERT as a language representation model whose pre-training corpora includes biomedical corpora ( e.g. BioBERT ( PubMed ) ) .
heading: Materials and methods

text: For tokenization , BioBERT uses WordPiece tokenization , which mitigates the out - of - vocabulary issue .
heading: Materials and methods

text: With WordPiece tokenization , any new words can be represented by frequent subwords ( e.g. Immunoglobulin >
heading: Materials and methods

text: I ##mm ##uno ##g ##lo # #bul # #in ) .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We found that using cased vocabulary ( not lowercasing ) results in slightly better performances in downstream tasks .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Although we could have constructed new WordPiece vocabulary based on biomedical corpora , we used the original vocabulary of BERT BASE for the following reasons : ( i ) compatibility of BioBERT with BERT , which allows BERT pre-trained on general domain corpora to be re-used , and makes it easier to interchangeably use existing models based on BERT and BioBERT and ( ii ) any new words may still be represented and fine - tuned for the biomedical domain using the original WordPiece vocabulary of BERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Fine-tuning BioBERT
heading: Materials and methods

text: With minimal architectural modification , BioBERT can be applied to various downstream text mining tasks .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We fine - tune BioBERT on the following three representative biomedical text mining tasks : NER , RE and QA .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Named entity recognition is one of the most fundamental biomedical text mining tasks , which involves recognizing numerous domain - specific proper nouns in a biomedical corpus .
heading: Materials and methods

text: While most previous works were built upon different combinations of LSTMs and CRFs , BERT has a simple architecture based on bidirectional transformers .
heading: Materials and methods

text: BERT uses a single output layer based on the representations from its last layer to compute only token level BIO2 probabilities .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Note that while previous works in biomedical NER often used word embeddings trained on PubMed or PMC corpora , BioBERT directly learns WordPiece embeddings during pre-training and fine - tuning .
heading: Materials and methods

text: For the evaluation metrics of NER , we used entity level precision , recall and F1 score .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Relation extraction is a task of classifying relations of named entities in a biomedical corpus .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We utilized the sentence classifier of the original version of BERT , which uses a [ CLS ] token for the classification of relations .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Sentence classification is performed using a single output layer based on a [ CLS ] token representation from BERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We anonymized target named entities in a sentence using pre-defined tags such as @ GENE $ or @DISEASE $ .
heading: Materials and methods

text: For instance , a sentence with two target entities ( gene and disease in this case ) is represented as " Serine at position 986 of @GENE $ maybe an independent genetic predictor of angiographic @DISEASE $ . "
heading: Materials and methods

text: The precision , recall and F 1 scores on the RE task are reported .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Question answering is a task of answering questions posed in natural language given related passages .
heading: Materials and methods

text: To fine - tune BioBERT for QA , we used the same BERT architecture used for SQuAD .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We used the BioASQ factoid datasets because their format is similar to that of SQuAD .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Token level probabilities for the start / end location of answer phrases are computed using a single output layer .
heading: Materials and methods

text: However , we observed that about 30 % of the BioASQ factoid questions were unanswerable in an extractive QA setting as the exact answers did not appear in the given passages .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Like , we excluded the samples with unanswerable questions from the training sets .
heading: Materials and methods

text: Also , we used the same pre-training process of , which uses SQuAD , and it largely improved the performance of both BERT and BioBERT .
heading: Materials and methods

text: We used the following evaluation metrics from BioASQ : strict accuracy , lenient accuracy and mean reciprocal rank .
heading: Materials and methods

Datasets
The statistics of biomedical NER datasets are listed in .

heading: Datasets

heading: Datasets

text: Note that although there are several other recently introduced high quality biomedical NER datasets , we use datasets that are frequently used by many biomedical NLP researchers , which makes it much easier to compare our work with theirs .
heading: Datasets

text: The RE datasets contain gene - disease relations and protein - chemical relations ) .
heading: Datasets

heading: Datasets

text: For the CHEMPROT dataset , we used the same pre-processing procedure described in .

heading: Datasets

heading: Datasets

text: Like previous work , we reported the performance of 10 - fold cross-validation on datasets that do not have separate test sets ( e.g. GAD , EU - ADR ) .
heading: Datasets

heading: Datasets

text: Note that the state - of - the - art models each have a different architecture and training procedure .
heading: Datasets

text: For instance , the state - of - the - art model by trained on the JNLPBA dataset is based on multiple Bi - LSTM CRF models with character level CNNs , while the state - of - the - art model by trained on the LINNAEUS dataset uses a Bi - LSTM CRF model with character level LSTMs and is additionally trained on silver - standard datasets .
heading: Datasets

text: On the other hand , BERT and BioBERT have exactly the same structure , and use only the gold standard datasets and not any additional datasets .
