text: Experimental setups
We used the BERT BASE model pre-trained on English Wikipedia and Books Corpus for 1 M steps .
heading: Experimental setups

text: BioBERT v1.0 ( PubMed PMC ) is the version of BioBERT ( PubMed PMC ) trained for 470 K steps .
heading: Experimental setups

text: When using both the PubMed and PMC corpora , we found that 200K and 270K pre-training steps were optimal for PubMed and PMC , respectively .
heading: Experimental setups

text: We also used the ablated versions of BioBERT v1.0 , which were pre-trained on only PubMed for 200 K steps ( Bio BERT v1.0 ( PubMed ) ) and PMC for 270K steps ( Bio BERT v1.0 ( PMC ) ) .
heading: Experimental setups

text: After our initial release of BioBERT v 1.0 , we pre-trained BioBERT on PubMed for 1 M steps , and we refer to this version as BioBERT v 1.1 ( PubMed ) .
heading: Experimental setups

text: Other hyper - parameters such as batch size and learning rate scheduling for pre-training BioBERT are the same as those for pre-training BERT unless stated otherwise .
heading: Experimental setups

text: We pre-trained BioBERT using Naver Smart Machine Learning ( NSML ) , which is utilized for large - scale experiments that need to be run on several GPUs .
heading: Experimental setups

text: We used eight NVIDIA V100 ( 32GB ) GPUs for the pre-training .
heading: Experimental setups

text: The maximum sequence length was fixed to 512 and the mini-batch size was set to 192 , resulting in 98 304 words per iteration .
heading: Experimental setups

text: It takes more than 10 days to pre-train BioBERT v 1.0 ( PubMed PMC ) nearly 23 days for BioBERT v 1.1 ( PubMed ) in this setting .
heading: Experimental setups

text: Despite our best efforts to use BERT LARGE , we used only BERT BASE due to the computational complexity of BERT LARGE .
heading: Experimental setups

text: We used a single NVIDIA Titan Xp ( 12GB ) GPU to fine - tune BioBERT on each task .
heading: Experimental setups

text: Note that the fine - tuning process is more computationally efficient than pre-training BioBERT .
heading: Experimental setups

text: For finetuning , a batch size of 10 , 16 , 32 or 64 was selected , and a learning rate of 5e5 , 3e5 or 1e5 was selected .
heading: Experimental setups

text: Fine - tuning BioBERT on QA and RE tasks took less than an hour as the size of the training data is much smaller than that of the training data used by .
heading: Experimental setups

text: On the other hand , it takes more than 20 epochs for BioBERT to reach its highest performance on the NER datasets .
heading: Experimental setups

text: Conclusion
In this article , we introduced BioBERT , which is a pre-trained language representation model for biomedical text mining .
heading: Conclusion

text: We showed that pre-training BERT on biomedical corpora is crucial in applying it to the biomedical domain .
heading: Conclusion

text: Requiring minimal task - specific architectural modification , BioBERT outperforms previous models on biomedical text mining tasks such as NER , RE and QA .
heading: Conclusion

text: The pre-released version of BioBERT ( January 2019 ) has already been shown to be very effective in many biomedical text mining tasks such as NER for clinical notes , human phenotype - gene RE and clinical temporal RE .
heading: Conclusion

text: The following updated versions of BioBERT will be available to the bioNLP community : ( i ) BioBERT BASE and BioBERT LARGE trained on only PubMed abstracts without initialization from the existing BERT model and ( ii ) BioBERT BASE and BioBERT LARGE trained on domain - specific vocabulary based on WordPiece .

title
Extracting Multiple - Relations in One - Pass with Pre-Trained Transformers
heading: title

text: abstract
The state - of - the - art solutions for extracting multiple entity - relations from an input paragraph always require a multiple - pass encoding on the input .
heading: abstract

text: This paper proposes anew solution that can complete the multiple entityrelations extraction task with only one - pass encoding on the input corpus , and achieve anew state - of - the - art accuracy performance , as demonstrated in the ACE 2005 benchmark .
heading: abstract

text: Our solution is built on top of the pre-trained self - attentive models ( Transformer ) .
heading: abstract

text: Since our method uses a single - pass to compute all relations at once , it scales to larger datasets easily ; which makes it more usable in real - world applications .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Relation extraction ( RE ) aims to find the semantic relation between a pair of entity mentions from an input paragraph .
heading: Introduction

text: A solution to this task is essential for many downstream NLP applications such as automatic knowledge - base completion , knowledge base question answering , and symbolic approaches for visual question answering , etc .
heading: Introduction

text: One particular type of the RE task is multiplerelations extraction ( MRE ) that aims to recognize relations of multiple pairs of entity mentions from an input paragraph .
heading: Introduction

text: Because in real - world applications , whose input paragraphs dominantly contain multiple pairs of entities , an efficient and effective solution for MRE has more important and more practical implications .
heading: Introduction

text: However , nearly all existing approaches for MRE tasks 2014 ; adopt some variations of the singlerelation extraction ( SRE ) approach , which treats each pair of entity mentions as an independent instance , and requires multiple passes of encoding for the multiple pairs of entities .
heading: Introduction

text: The drawback of this approach is obvious - it is computationally expensive and this issue becomes more severe when the input paragraph is large , making this solution impossible to implement when the encoding step involves deep models .
heading: Introduction

text: This work presents a solution that can resolve the inefficient multiple - passes issue of existing solutions for MRE by encoding the input only once , which significantly increases the efficiency and scalability .
heading: Introduction

text: Specifically , the proposed solution is built on top of the existing transformer - based , pretrained general - purposed language encoders .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper we use Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers ( BERT ) as the transformer - based encoder , but this solution is not limited to using BERT alone .
heading: Introduction

text: The two novel modifications to the original BERT architecture are : ( 1 ) we introduce a structured prediction layer for predicting multiple relations for different entity pairs ; and ( 2 ) we make the selfattention layers aware of the positions of all en-tities in the input paragraph .
heading: Introduction

text: To the best of our knowledge , this work is the first promising solution that can solve MRE tasks with such high efficiency ( encoding the input in one - pass ) and effectiveness ( achieve anew state - of - the - art performance ) , as proved on the ACE 2005 benchmark .
heading: Introduction

text: Background
MRE is an important task as it is an essential prior step for many downstream tasks such as automatic knowledge - base completion and questionanswering .
heading: Background

text: Popular MRE benchmarks include ACE and ERE .

In MRE , given as a text paragraph x = {x 1 , . . . , x N } and M mentions e = {e 1 , . . . , e M } as input , the goal is to predict the relation r ij for each mention pair ( e i , e j ) either belongs to one class of a list of pre-defined relations R or falls into a special class NA indicating no relation .
heading: Popular MRE benchmarks include ACE and ERE .

text: This paper uses " entity mention " , " mention " and " entity " interchangeably .
heading: Popular MRE benchmarks include ACE and ERE .

text: Existing MRE approaches are based on either feature and model architecture selection techniques , or domain adaptations approaches .
heading: Popular MRE benchmarks include ACE and ERE .

text: But these approaches require multiple passes of encoding over the paragraph , as they treat a MRE task as multiple passes of a SRE task .
heading: Popular MRE benchmarks include ACE and ERE .

text: Proposed Approach
This section describes the proposed one - pass encoding MRE solution .
heading: Proposed Approach

text: The solution is built upon BERT with a structured prediction layer to enable BERT to predict multiple relations with onepass encoding , and an entity - aware self - attention mechanism to infuse the relational information with regard to multiple entities at each layer of hidden states .
heading: Proposed Approach

text: The framework is illustrated in 1 .
It is worth mentioning that our solution can easily use other transformer - based encoders besides BERT , e.g..
heading: The framework is illustrated in 1 .

text: Structured Prediction with BERT for MRE
heading: The framework is illustrated in 1 .

text: The BERT model has been successfully applied to various NLP tasks .
heading: The framework is illustrated in 1 .

text: However , the final prediction layers used in the original model is not applicable to MRE tasks .
heading: The framework is illustrated in 1 .

text: The MRE task essentially requires to perform edge predictions over a graph with entities as nodes .
heading: The framework is illustrated in 1 .

text: Inspired by , we propose that we can first encode the input paragraph using BERT .
heading: The framework is illustrated in 1 .

text: Thus , the representation fora pair of entity mentions ( e i , e j ) can be denoted as oi and o j respectively .
heading: The framework is illustrated in 1 .

text: In the case of a mention e i consist of multiple hidden states ( due to the byte pair encoding ) , oi is aggregated via average - pooling over the hidden states of the corresponding tokens in the last BERT layer .
heading: The framework is illustrated in 1 .

text: We then concatenate oi and o j denoted as [ o i : o j ] , and pass it to a linear classifier 2 to predict the relation

text: Entity - Aware Self - Attention based on Relative Distance
heading: R 2 dzl .

text: This section describes how we encode multiplerelations information into the model .
heading: R 2 dzl .

text: The key concept is to use the relative distances between words and entities to encode the positional information for each entity .
heading: R 2 dzl .

text: This information is propagated through different layers via attention computations .
heading: R 2 dzl .

text: Following , for each pair of word tokens ( x i , x j ) with the input representations from the previous layer ash i and h j , we extend the computation of self - attention z i as :
heading: R 2 dzl .

text: are the parameters of the model , and dz is the dimension of the output from the self - attention layer .
heading: R 2 dzl .

text: R dz are extra , which could be viewed as the edge representation between the input element x i and x j .
heading: R 2 dzl .

text: Specifically , we devise a V ij and a K ij to encourage each token to be aware of the relative distance to different entity mentions , and vice versa .
heading: R 2 dzl .

text: Adapted from , we argue that the relative distance information will not help if the distance is beyond a certain threshold .

heading: R 2 dzl .

text: As defined above , if either token xi or x j belongs to an entity , we will introduce a relative positional representation according to their distance .
heading: R 2 dzl .

text: Experiments
We demonstrate the advantage of our method on a popular MRE benchmark , ACE 2005 , and a more recent MRE benchmark , SemEval 2018 Task 7 .
heading: Experiments

text: We also evaluate on a commonly used SRE benchmark SemEval 2010 task 8 , and achieve state - of - the - art performance .
heading: Experiments

text: Settings

Data For ACE 2005 , we adopt the multi-domain setting and split the data following : we train on the union of news domain ( nw and bn ) , tune hyperparameters on half of the broadcast conversation ( bc ) domain , and evaluate on the remainder of broadcast conversation ( bc ) , the telephone speech ( cts ) , usenet newsgroups ( un ) , and weblogs ( wl ) domains .
heading: Settings

text: For Se-m
Eval 2018
Task 7 , we evaluate on its sub-task 1.1 .
heading: Eval 2018

text: We use the same data split in the shared task .
heading: Eval 2018

text: The passages in this task is usually much longer compared to ACE .
heading: Eval 2018

text: Therefore we adopt the following pre-processing step - for the entity pair in each relation , we assume the tokens related to their relation labeling are always within a range from the fifth token ahead of the pair to the fifth token after it .
heading: Eval 2018

text: Therefore , the tokens in the original passage that are not covered by the range of ANY input relations , will be removed from the input .
heading: Eval 2018

text: Methods

We compare our solution with previous works that predict a single relation per pass , our model that predicts single relation per pass for MRE , and with the following naive modifications of BERT that could achieve MRE in one - pass .
heading: Methods

text: BERT SP : BERT with structured prediction only , which includes proposed improvement in 3.1 .
heading: Methods

text: Entity - Aware BERT SP : our full model , which includes both improvements in 3.1 and 3.2 .
heading: Methods

text: BERT SP with position embedding on the final attention layer .
heading: Methods

text: This is a more straightforward way to achieve MRE in one - pass derived from previous works using position embeddings .
heading: Methods

text: In this method , the BERT model encode the paragraph to the last attention - layer .
heading: Methods

text: Then , for each entity pair , it takes the hidden states , adds the relative position embeddings corresponding to the target entities , and finally makes the relation prediction for this pair .
heading: Methods

text: BERT SP with entity indicators on input layer : it replaces our structured attention layer , and adds indicators of entities ( transformed to embeddings )
heading: Methods

It works for the singlerelation per pass setting , but the performance lags behind using only indicators of the two target entities .
heading: Summing up the vectors confuses this information .

text: prior state - of - the - art level of the methods without domain adaptation .
heading: Summing up the vectors confuses this information .

text: Our full model , with the structured fine - tuning of attention layers , brings further improvement of about 5.5 % , in the MRE one - pass setting , and achieves anew state - of - the - art performance when compared to the methods with domain adaptation .
heading: Summing up the vectors confuses this information .

text: It also beats the other two methods on BERT in Multi- Relation per Pass .
heading: Summing up the vectors confuses this information .

text: Performance Gap between MRE in One - Pass and Multi - Pass
heading: Summing up the vectors confuses this information .

text: The MRE - in - one - pass models can also be used to train and test with one entity pair per pass ( Single - Relation per Pass results in ) .
heading: Summing up the vectors confuses this information .

text: Therefore , we compare the same methods when applied to the multi-relation and singlerelation settings .
heading: Summing up the vectors confuses this information .

text: For BERT SP with entity indicators on inputs , it is expected to perform slightly better in the single - relation setting , because of the mixture of information from multiple pairs .
heading: Summing up the vectors confuses this information .

text: A 2 % gap is observed as expected .
By comparison , our full model has a much smaller performance gap between two different settings ( and no consistent performance drop over different domains ) .
heading: A 2 % gap is observed as expected .

text: The BERT SP is not expected to have a gap as shown in the table .
heading: A 2 % gap is observed as expected .

text: For BERT SP with position embeddings on the final attention layer , we train the model in the single - relation setting and test with two different settings , so the results are the same .
heading: A 2 % gap is observed as expected .

text: Training and Inference Time
Through our experiment , 4 we verify that the full model with MRE is significantly faster compared to all other methods for both training and inference .
heading: Training and Inference Time

text: The training time for full model with MRE is 3.5 x faster than it with SRE .
heading: Training and Inference Time

text: As for inference speed , the former could reach 126 relation per second compared the later at 23 relation per second .
heading: Training and Inference Time

text: It is also much faster when compared to the second best performing approach , BERT SP w / pos-emb on final attlayer , which is at 76 relation per second , as it runs the last layer for every entity pair .
heading: Training and Inference Time

text: evaluates the usage of different prediction layers , including replacing our linear layer in Eq .
heading: Training and Inference Time

text: Prediction Module Selection
heading: Training and Inference Time

text: ( 1 ) with MLP or Biaff .
heading: Training and Inference Time

text: Results show that the usage of the linear predictor gives better results .
heading: Training and Inference Time

text: This is consistent with the motivation of the pre-trained encoders : by unsupervised pre-training the encoders are expected to be sufficiently powerful thus adding more complex layers on top does not improve the capacity but leads to more free parameters and higher risk of over-fitting .
heading: Training and Inference Time

text: Results on SemEval 2018
Task 7
The results on SemEval 2018 Task 7 are shown in .
heading: Task 7

text: Our Entity - Aware BERT SP gives comparable results to the top - ranked system in the shared task , with slightly lower Macro - F1 , which is the official metric of the task , and slightly higher Micro - F1 .
heading: Task 7

text: When predicting multiple relations in one - pass , we have 0.9 % drop on Macro - F1 , but a further 0.8 % improvement on Micro - F1 .
heading: Task 7

text: Note that the system ( Rotsztejn et al. , 2018 ) integrates many techniques like feature - engineering , model combination , pretraining embeddings on in - domain data , and artificial data generation , while our model is almost a direct adaption from the ACE architecture .
heading: Task 7

text: On the other hand , compared to the top singlemodel result , which makes use of additional word and entity embeddings pretrained on in - domain data , our methods demonstrate clear advantage as a single model .
heading: Task 7

text: Additional SRE
Results
We conduct additional experiments on the relation classification task , SemEval 2010 Task 8 , to com -
heading: Results

text: Method
Averaged F1 Macro Micro
heading: Method

text: Top 3 in the Shared Task 81.7 82.8 78.9 - 76 . pare with models developed on this benchmark .
heading: Method

text: From the results in , our proposed techniques also outperforms the state - of - the - art on this single - relation benchmark .
heading: Method

text: On this single relation task , the out - of - box BERT achieves a reasonable result after finetuning .
heading: Method

text: Adding the entity - aware attention gives about 8 % improvement , due to the availability of the entity information during encoding .
heading: Method

text: Adding structured prediction layer to BERT ( i.e. , BERT SP ) also leads to a similar amount of improvement .
heading: Method

text: However , the gap between BERT SP method with and without entity - aware attention is small .
heading: Method

text: This is likely because of the bias of data distribution : the assumption that only two target entities exist , makes the two techniques have similar effects .
heading: Method

text: Conclusion
In summary , we propose a first - of - its - kind solution that can simultaneously extract multiple relations with one - pass encoding of an input paragraph for MRE tasks .
heading: Conclusion

text: With the proposed structured prediction and entity - aware self - attention layers on top of BERT , we achieve anew state - of - the - art results with high efficiency on the ACE 2005 benchmark .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our idea of encoding a passage regarding multiple entities has potentially broader applications beyond relation extraction , e.g. , entity - centric passage encoding in question answering .
heading: Conclusion

text: In the future work , we will explore the usage of this method with other applications .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
SCIBERT : A Pretrained Language Model for Scientific Text
abstract
Obtaining large - scale annotated data for NLP tasks in the scientific domain is challenging and expensive .
heading: abstract

text: We release SCIBERT , a pretrained language model based on BERT ( Devlin et al. , 2019 ) to address the lack of high - quality , large - scale labeled scientific data .
heading: abstract

text: SCIBERT leverages unsupervised pretraining on a large multi-domain corpus of scientific publications to improve performance on downstream scientific NLP tasks .
heading: abstract

text: We evaluate on a suite of tasks including sequence tagging , sentence classification and dependency parsing , with datasets from a variety of scientific domains .
heading: abstract

text: We demonstrate statistically significant improvements over BERT and achieve new state - of - theart results on several of these tasks .
heading: abstract

text: The code and pretrained models are available at https://github.com/allenai/scibert/.
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
The exponential increase in the volume of scientific publications in the past decades has made NLP an essential tool for large - scale knowledge extraction and machine reading of these documents .
heading: Introduction

text: Recent progress in NLP has been driven by the adoption of deep neural models , but training such models often requires large amounts of labeled data .
heading: Introduction

text: In general domains , large - scale training data is often possible to obtain through crowdsourcing , but in scientific domains , annotated data is difficult and expensive to collect due to the expertise required for quality annotation .
heading: Introduction

text: As shown through ELMo , and BERT , unsupervised pretraining of language models on large corpora significantly improves performance on many NLP tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: These models return contextualized embeddings for each token which can be passed into minimal task - specific neural architectures .
heading: Introduction

text: Leveraging the success of unsupervised pretraining has become especially important especially when task - specific annotations are difficult to obtain , like in scientific NLP .
heading: Introduction

text: Yet while both BERT and ELMo have released pretrained models , they are still trained on general domain corpora such as news articles and Wikipedia .
heading: Introduction

text: In this work , we make the following contributions :
heading: Introduction

text: ( i ) We release SCIBERT , anew resource demonstrated to improve performance on a range of NLP tasks in the scientific domain .
heading: Introduction

text: SCIBERT is a pretrained language model based on BERT but trained on a large corpus of scientific text .
heading: Introduction

text: ( ii ) We perform extensive experimentation to investigate the performance of finetuning versus task - specific architectures atop frozen embeddings , and the effect of having an in - domain vocabulary .
heading: Introduction

text: ( iii ) We evaluate SCIBERT on a suite of tasks in the scientific domain , and achieve new state - of the - art ( SOTA ) results on many of these tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: Methods
Background
The BERT model architecture is based on a multilayer bidirectional Transformer .
heading: Background

text: Instead of the traditional left - to - right language modeling objective , BERT is trained on two tasks : predicting randomly masked tokens and predicting whether two sentences follow each other .
heading: Background

text: SCIB - ERT follows the same architecture as BERT but is instead pretrained on scientific text .
heading: Background

text: Vocabulary BERT uses WordPiece for unsupervised tokenization of the input text .
heading: Background

text: The vocabulary is built such that it contains the most frequently used words or subword units .
heading: Background

text: We refer to the original vocabulary released with BERT as BASEVOCAB .
heading: Background

text: We construct SCIVOCAB , anew WordPiece vocabulary on our scientific corpus using the Sen - tencePiece 1 library .
heading: Background

text: We produce both cased and uncased vocabularies and set the vocabulary size to 30 K to match the size of BASEVOCAB .
heading: Background

text: The resulting token overlap between BASEVOCAB and SCIVOCAB is 42 % , illustrating a substantial difference in frequently used words between scientific and general domain texts .
heading: Background

text: Corpus
We train SCIBERT on a random sample of 1.14 M papers from Semantic Scholar .
heading: Corpus

text: This corpus consists of 18 % papers from the computer science domain and 82 % from the broad biomedical domain .
heading: Corpus

text: We use the full text of the papers , not just the abstracts .
heading: Corpus

text: The average paper length is 154 sentences ( 2,769 tokens ) resulting in a corpus size of 3.17B tokens , similar to the 3.3B tokens on which BERT was trained .
heading: Corpus

text: We split sentences using Scispa Cy , 2 which is optimized for scientific text .
heading: Corpus

text: 3 Experimental Setup
heading: Corpus

text: Tasks
We experiment on the following core NLP tasks :
heading: Tasks

text: Named Entity Recognition ( NER )
heading: Tasks

text: 2 . PICO Extraction ( PICO )
heading: Tasks

text: 3 . Text Classification ( CLS )
heading: Tasks

text: 4 . Relation Classification ( REL )
heading: Tasks

text: 5 . Dependency Parsing ( DEP )
heading: Tasks

text: PICO , like NER , is a sequence labeling task where the model extracts spans describing the Participants , Interventions , Comparisons , and Outcomes in a clinical trial paper .
heading: Tasks

text: REL is a special case of text classification where the model predicts the type of relation expressed between two entities , which are encapsulated in the sentence by inserted special tokens .
heading: Tasks

text: Datasets
For brevity , we only describe the newer datasets here , and refer the reader to the references in Table 1 for the older datasets .
heading: Datasets

text: EBM - NLP annotates PICO spans in clinical trial abstracts .
heading: Datasets

text: SciERC annotates entities and relations from computer science ab - 1 https://github.com/google/sentencepiece
heading: Datasets

text: 2 https://github.com/allenai/SciSpaCy stracts . ACL - ARC and Sci -Cite assign intent labels ( e.g. Comparison , Extension , etc. ) to sentences from scientific papers that cite other papers .
heading: Datasets

text: The Paper Field dataset is built from the Microsoft Academic Graph 3 and maps paper titles to one of 7 fields of study .
heading: Datasets

text: Each field of study ( i.e. geography , politics , economics , business , sociology , medicine , and psychology ) has approximately 12 K training examples .
heading: Datasets

text: Pretrained BERT
Variants
BERT - Base
heading: Variants

text: We use the pretrained weights for BERT - Base released with the original BERT code .
heading: Variants

text: The vocabulary is BASE - VOCAB .
heading: Variants

text: We evaluate both cased and uncased versions of this model .
heading: Variants

text: SCIBERT
We use the original BERT code to train SCIBERT on our corpus with the same configuration and size as BERT - Base .
heading: SCIBERT

text: We train 4 different versions of SCIBERT : ( i ) cased or uncased and ( ii ) BASEVOCAB or SCIVOCAB .
heading: SCIBERT

text: The two models that use BASEVOCAB are finetuned from the corresponding BERT - Base models .
heading: SCIBERT

text: The other two models that use the new SCIVOCAB are trained from scratch .
heading: SCIBERT

text: Pretraining BERT for long sentences can be slow .
heading: SCIBERT

text: Following the original BERT code , we set a maximum sentence length of 128 tokens , and train the model until the training loss stops decreasing .
heading: SCIBERT

text: We then continue training the model allowing sentence lengths up to 512 tokens .
heading: SCIBERT

text: We use a single TPU v 3 with 8 cores .
heading: SCIBERT

text: Training the SCIVOCAB models from scratch on our corpus takes 1 week 5 ( 5 days with max length 128 , then 2 days with max length 512 ) .
heading: SCIBERT

text: The BASEVOCAB models take 2 fewer days of training because they are n't trained from scratch .
heading: SCIBERT

text: All pretrained BERT models are converted to be compatible with PyTorch using the pytorchtransformers library .
heading: SCIBERT

text: All our models ( Sections 3.4 and 3.5 ) are implemented in PyTorch using AllenNLP .
heading: SCIBERT

text: Casing
We follow in using the cased models for NER and the uncased models for all other tasks .
heading: Casing

text: We also use the cased models for parsing .
heading: Casing

text: Some light experimentation showed that the uncased models perform slightly better ( even sometimes on NER ) than cased models .
heading: Casing

text: Finetuning BERT
We mostly follow the same architecture , optimization , and hyperparameter choices used in .
heading: Finetuning BERT

text: For text classification ( i.e. CLS and REL ) , we feed the final BERT vector for the [ CLS ] token into a linear classification layer .
heading: Finetuning BERT

text: For sequence labeling ( i.e. NER and PICO ) , we feed the final BERT vector for each token into a linear classification layer with softmax output .
heading: Finetuning BERT

text: We differ slightly in using an additional conditional random field , which made evaluation easier by guaranteeing well - formed entities .
heading: Finetuning BERT

text: For DEP , we use the model from with dependency tag and arc embeddings of size 100 and biaffine matrix attention over BERT vectors instead of stacked BiLSTMs .
heading: Finetuning BERT

text: In all settings , we apply a dropout of 0.1 and optimize cross entropy loss using Adam .
heading: Finetuning BERT

text: We finetune for 2 to 5 epochs using a batch size of 32 and a learning rate of 5 e - 6 , 1 e - 5 , 2 e - 5 , or 5 e - 5 with a slanted triangular schedule which is equivalent to the linear warmup followed by linear decay .
heading: Finetuning BERT

text: For each dataset and BERT variant , we pick the best learning rate and number of epochs on the development set and report the corresponding test results .
heading: Finetuning BERT

text: We found the setting that works best across most datasets and models is 2 or 4 epochs and a learning rate of 2 e - 5 .
heading: Finetuning BERT

text: While task - dependent , optimal hyperparameters for each task are often the same across BERT variants .
heading: Finetuning BERT

text: Frozen BERT
Embeddings
We also explore the usage of BERT as pretrained contextualized word embeddings , like ELMo ) , by training simple task - specific models atop frozen BERT embeddings .
heading: Embeddings

text: For text classification , we feed each sentence of BERT vectors into a 2 - layer BiLSTM of size 200 and apply a multilayer perceptron ( with hidden size 200 ) on the concatenated first and last BiLSTM vectors .
heading: Embeddings

text: For sequence labeling , we use the same BiLSTM layers and use a conditional random field to guarantee well - formed predictions .
heading: Embeddings

text: For DEP , we use the full model from with dependency tag and arc embeddings of size 100 and the same BiLSTM setup as other tasks .
heading: Embeddings

text: We did not find changing the depth or size of the BiLSTMs to significantly impact results .
heading: Embeddings

text: We optimize cross entropy loss using Adam , but holding BERT weights frozen and applying a dropout of 0.5 .
heading: Embeddings

text: We train with early stopping on the development set ( patience of 10 ) using a batch size of 32 and a learning rate of 0.001 .
heading: Embeddings

text: We did not perform extensive hyperparameter search , but while optimal hyperparameters are going to be task - dependent , some light experimentation showed these settings work fairly well across most tasks and BERT variants .
heading: Embeddings

text: summarizes the experimental results .
heading: Embeddings

text: We observe that SCIBERT outperforms BERT - Base on scientific tasks ( + 2.11 F1 with finetuning and + 2.43 F1 without )
heading: Embeddings

text: 8 . We also achieve new SOTA results on many of these tasks using SCIBERT .
heading: Embeddings

text: Results
Biomedical Domain
We observe that SCIBERT outperforms BERT - Base on biomedical tasks ( + 1.92 F1 with finetuning and + 3.59 F1 without ) .
heading: Biomedical Domain

text: In addition , SCIB - ERT achieves new SOTA results on BC5 CDR and ChemProt , and EBM - NLP .
heading: Biomedical Domain

text: SCIBERT performs slightly worse than SOTA on 3 datasets .
heading: Biomedical Domain

text: The SOTA model for JNLPBA is a BiLSTM - CRF ensemble trained on multiple NER datasets not just JNLPBA .
heading: Biomedical Domain

text: The SOTA model for NCBI - disease is BIOBERT , which is BERT - Base finetuned on 18B tokens from biomedical papers .
heading: Biomedical Domain

text: The SOTA result for GENIA is in Nguyen and Verspoor ( 2019 ) which uses the model from with partof - speech ( POS ) features , which we do not use .
heading: Biomedical Domain

text: In , we compare SCIBERT results with reported BIOBERT results on the subset of datasets included in .
heading: Biomedical Domain

text: Interesting , SCIBERT outperforms BIOBERT results on 7 The SOTA paper did not report a single score .
heading: Biomedical Domain

text: We compute the average of the reported results for each class weighted by number of examples in each class .
heading: Biomedical Domain

text: 8 Forrest of this paper , all results reported in this manner are averaged over datasets excluding UAS for DEP since we already include LAS .
heading: Biomedical Domain

text: BC5 CDR and ChemProt , and performs similarly on JNLPBA despite being trained on a substantially smaller biomedical corpus .
heading: Biomedical Domain

text: Computer Science Domain
We observe that SCIBERT outperforms BERT - Base on computer science tasks ( + 3.55 F1 with finetuning and + 1.13 F1 without ) .
heading: Computer Science Domain

text: In addition , SCIBERT achieves new SOTA results on ACL - ARC , and the NER part of SciERC .
heading: Computer Science Domain

text: For relations in Sci - ERC , our results are not comparable with those in because we are performing relation classification given gold entities , while they perform joint entity and relation extraction .
heading: Computer Science Domain

text: Multiple Domains
We observe that SCIBERT outperforms BERT - Base on the multidomain tasks ( + 0.49 F1 with finetuning and + 0.93 F1 without ) .
heading: Multiple Domains

text: In addition , SCIBERT outperforms the SOTA on Sci - Cite .
heading: Multiple Domains

text: No prior published SOTA results exist for the Paper Field dataset .
heading: Multiple Domains

text: Discussion
Effect of Finetuning
We observe improved results via BERT finetuning rather than task - specific architectures atop frozen embeddings ( + 3.25 F1 with SCIBERT and + 3.58 with BERT - Base , on average ) .
heading: Effect of Finetuning

text: For each scientific domain , we observe the largest effects of finetuning on the computer science ( + 5.59 F1 with SCIB - ERT and + 3.17 F1 with BERT - Base ) and biomedical tasks ( + 2.94 F1 with SCIBERT and + 4.61 F1 with BERT - Base ) , and the smallest effect on multidomain tasks ( + 0.7 F1 with SCIBERT and + 1.14 F1 with BERT - Base ) .
heading: Effect of Finetuning

text: On every dataset except BC5 CDR and SciCite , BERT - Base with finetuning outperforms ( or performs similarly to ) a model using frozen SCIBERT embeddings .
heading: Effect of Finetuning

text: Effect of SCIVOCAB
We assess the importance of an in - domain scientific vocabulary by repeating the finetuning experiments for SCIBERT with BASEVOCAB .
heading: Effect of SCIVOCAB

text: We find the optimal hyperparameters for SCIBERT - BASEVOCAB often coincide with those of SCIB - ERT - SCIVOCAB .
heading: Effect of SCIVOCAB

text: Averaged across datasets , we observe + 0.60 F1 when using SCIVOCAB .
heading: Effect of SCIVOCAB

text: For each scientific do - main , we observe + 0.76 F1 for biomedical tasks , + 0.61 F1 for computer science tasks , and + 0.11 F1 for multidomain tasks .
heading: Effect of SCIVOCAB

text: Given the disjoint vocabularies ( Section 2 ) and the magnitude of improvement over BERT - Base ( Section 4 ) , we suspect that while an in - domain vocabulary is helpful , SCIBERT benefits most from the scientific corpus pretraining .
heading: Effect of SCIVOCAB

text: Related Work
Recent work on domain adaptation of BERT includes BIOBERT and CLIN - ICALBERT .
heading: Related Work

text: BIOBERT is trained on PubMed abstracts and PMC full text articles , and CLIN - ICALBERT is trained on clinical text from the MIMIC - III database .
heading: Related Work

text: In contrast , SCIBERT is trained on the full text of 1.14 M biomedical and computer science papers from the Semantic Scholar corpus .
heading: Related Work

text: Furthermore , SCIBERT uses an in - domain vocabulary ( SCIVOCAB ) while the other abovementioned models use the original BERT vocabulary ( BASEVOCAB ) .
heading: Related Work

text: Conclusion and Future Work
We released SCIBERT , a pretrained language model for scientific text based on BERT .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: We evaluated SCIBERT on a suite of tasks and datasets from scientific domains .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: SCIBERT significantly outperformed BERT - Base and achieves new SOTA results on several of these tasks , even compared to some reported BIOBERT ) results on biomedical tasks .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: For future work , we will release aversion of SCIBERT analogous to BERT - Large , as well as experiment with different proportions of papers from each domain .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: Because these language models are costly to train , we aim to build a single resource that 's useful across multiple domains .
heading: Conclusion and Future Work

text: title
Character - level Convolutional Networks for Text Classification

heading: Character - level Convolutional Networks for Text Classification

text: abstract
This article offers an empirical exploration on the use of character - level convolutional networks ( ConvNets ) for text classification .
heading: abstract

text: We constructed several largescale datasets to show that character - level convolutional networks could achieve state - of - the - art or competitive results .
heading: abstract

text: Comparisons are offered against traditional models such as bag of words , n-grams and their TFIDF variants , and deep learning models such as word - based ConvNets and recurrent neural networks .
heading: abstract

text: There are also related works that use character - level features for language processing .
heading: abstract

text: These include using character - level n-grams with linear classifiers [ 15 ] , and incorporating character - level features to ConvNets [ 28 ] [ 29 ] .
heading: abstract

text: In particular , these ConvNet approaches use words as a basis , in which character - level features extracted at word [ 28 ] or word n-gram [ 29 ] level form a distributed representation .
heading: abstract

text: Improvements for part - of - speech tagging and information retrieval were observed .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Text classification is a classic topic for natural language processing , in which one needs to assign predefined categories to free - text documents .
heading: Introduction

text: The range of text classification research goes from designing the best features to choosing the best possible machine learning classifiers .
heading: Introduction

text: To date , almost all techniques of text classification are based on words , in which simple statistics of some ordered word combinations ( such as n-grams ) usually perform the best .
heading: Introduction

text: On the other hand , many researchers have found convolutional networks ( ConvNets ) are useful in extracting information from raw signals , ranging from computer vision applications to speech recognition and others .
heading: Introduction

text: In particular , time - delay networks used in the early days of deep learning research are essentially convolutional networks that model sequential data .
heading: Introduction

text: In this article we explore treating text as a kind of raw signal at character level , and applying temporal ( one-dimensional ) ConvNets to it .
heading: Introduction

text: For this article we only used a classification task as away to exemplify ConvNets ' ability to understand texts .
heading: Introduction

text: Historically we know that ConvNets usually require large - scale datasets to work , therefore we also build several of them .
heading: Introduction

text: An extensive set of comparisons is offered with traditional models and other deep learning models .
heading: Introduction

text: Applying convolutional networks to text classification or natural language processing at large was explored in literature .
heading: Introduction

text: It has been shown that ConvNets can be directly applied to distributed or discrete embedding of words , without any knowledge on the syntactic or semantic structures of a language .
heading: Introduction

text: These approaches have been proven to be competitive to traditional models .
heading: Introduction

text: from previous research that ConvNets do not require the knowledge about the syntactic or semantic structure of a language .
heading: Introduction

text: This simplification of engineering could be crucial fora single system that can work for different languages , since characters always constitute a necessary construct regardless of whether segmentation into words is possible .
heading: Introduction

text: Working on only characters also has the advantage that abnormal character combinations such as misspellings and emoticons maybe naturally learnt .
heading: Introduction

text: Character - level Convolutional Networks
heading: Introduction

text: In this section , we introduce the design of character - level ConvNets for text classification .
heading: Introduction

text: The design is modular , where the gradients are obtained by back - propagation to perform optimization .
heading: Introduction

text: Key Modules
The main component is the temporal convolutional module , which simply computes a 1 - D convolution .
heading: Key Modules

text: Suppose we have a discrete input function g ( x ) ?
heading: Key Modules

text: Rand a discrete kernel function
heading: Key Modules

text: where c = k ? d + 1 is an offset constant .
heading: Key Modules

text: Just as in traditional convolutional networks in vision , the module is parameterized by a set of such kernel functions f ij ( x ) ( i = 1 , 2 , . . . , m and j = 1 , 2 , . . . , n) which we call weights , on a set of inputs g i ( x ) and outputs h j ( y ) .
heading: Key Modules

text: We call each g i ( or h j ) input ( or output ) features , and m ( or n) input ( or output ) feature size .
heading: Key Modules

text: The outputs h j ( y ) is obtained by a sum over i of the convolutions between g i ( x ) and f ij ( x ) .
heading: Key Modules

text: One key module that helped us to train deeper models is temporal max - pooling .
heading: Key Modules

text: It is the 1 - D version of the max - pooling module used in computer vision .
heading: Key Modules

text: Given a discrete input function g ( x ) ?
heading: Key Modules

text: R , the max - pooling function h ( y ) ?
heading: Key Modules

text: R of g ( x ) is defined as
heading: Key Modules

text: where c = k ? d + 1 is an offset constant .
heading: Key Modules

text: This very pooling module enabled us to train ConvNets deeper than 6 layers , where all others fail .
heading: Key Modules

text: The analysis by might shed some light on this .
heading: Key Modules

text: The non-linearity used in our model is the rectifier or thresholding function h ( x ) = max {0 , x} , which makes our convolutional layers similar to rectified linear units ( ReLUs ) .
heading: Key Modules

text: The algorithm used is stochastic gradient descent ( SGD ) with a minibatch of size 128 , using momentum 0.9 and initial step size 0.01 which is halved every 3 epoches for 10 times .
heading: Key Modules

text: Each epoch takes a fixed number of random training samples uniformly sampled across classes .
heading: Key Modules

text: This number will later be detailed for each dataset sparately .
heading: Key Modules

text: The implementation is done using Torch 7 .
heading: Key Modules

text: Character quantization
Our models accept a sequence of encoded characters as input .
heading: Character quantization

text: The encoding is done by prescribing an alphabet of size m for the input language , and then quantize each character using 1 - of - m encoding ( or " one - hot " encoding ) .
heading: Character quantization

text: Then , the sequence of characters is transformed to a sequence of such m sized vectors with fixed length l 0 .
heading: Character quantization

text: Any character exceeding length l 0 is ignored , and any characters that are not in the alphabet including blank characters are quantized as all - zero vectors .
heading: Character quantization

text: The character quantization order is backward so that the latest reading on characters is always placed near the begin of the output , making it easy for fully connected layers to associate weights with the latest reading .
heading: Character quantization

text: Later we also compare with models that use a different alphabet in which we distinguish between upper-case and lower - case letters .
heading: Character quantization

text: Model Design
We designed 2 ConvNets - one large and one small .
heading: Model Design

text: They are both 9 layers deep with 6 convolutional layers and 3 fully - connected layers .
heading: Model Design

text: gives an illustration .
heading: Model Design

text: Some Text
Convolutions
Max - pooling Length Feature Quantization ...
heading: Convolutions

text: Conv. and Pool. layers
Fully - connected :
heading: Conv. and Pool. layers

text: Illustration of our model
heading: Conv. and Pool. layers

text: The input have number of features equal to 70 due to our character quantization method , and the input feature length is 1014 .
heading: Conv. and Pool. layers

text: It seems that 1014 characters could already capture most of the texts of interest .
heading: Conv. and Pool. layers

heading: Conv. and Pool. layers

For different problems the input lengths maybe different ( for example in our case l 0 = 1014 ) , and so are the frame lengths .

Data Augmentation using Thesaurus
Many researchers have found that appropriate data augmentation techniques are useful for controlling generalization error for deep learning models .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: These techniques usually work well when we could find appropriate invariance properties that the model should possess .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: In terms of texts , it is not reasonable to augment the data using signal transformations as done in image or speech recognition , because the exact order of characters may form rigorous syntactic and semantic meaning .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: Therefore , the best way to do data augmentation would have been using human rephrases of sentences , but this is unrealistic and expensive due the large volume of samples in our datasets .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: As a result , the most natural choice in data augmentation for us is to replace words or phrases with their synonyms .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: We experimented data augmentation by using an English thesaurus , which is obtained from the mytheas component used in LibreOffice 1 project .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: That thesaurus in turn was obtained from Word - Net , where every synonym to a word or phrase is ranked by the semantic closeness to the most frequently seen meaning .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: To decide on how many words to replace , we extract all replaceable words from the given text and randomly chooser of them to be replaced .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: The probability of number r is determined by a geometric distribution with parameter pin which P [ r ] ? pr .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: The index s of the synonym chosen given a word is also determined by a another geometric distribution in which P [ s ] ? q s .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: This way , the probability of a synonym chosen becomes smaller when it moves distant from the most frequently seen meaning .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: We will report the results using this new data augmentation technique with p = 0.5 and q = 0.5 .
heading: Data Augmentation using Thesaurus

text: Comparison Models
To offer fair comparisons to competitive models , we conducted a series of experiments with both traditional and deep learning methods .
heading: Comparison Models

text: We tried our best to choose models that can provide comparable and competitive results , and the results are reported faithfully without any model selection .
heading: Comparison Models

text: Traditional Methods
We refer to traditional methods as those that using a hand - crafted feature extractor and a linear classifier .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: The classifier used is a multinomial logistic regression in all these models .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: Bag - of - words and its TFIDF .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: For each dataset , the bag - of - words model is constructed by selecting 50,000 most frequent words from the training subset .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: For the normal bag - of - words , we use the counts of each word as the features .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: For the TFIDF ( term-frequency inverse - document - frequency ) version , we use the counts as the term-frequency .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: The inverse document frequency is the logarithm of the division between total number of samples and number of samples with the word in the training subset .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: The features are normalized by dividing the largest feature value .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: Bag - of - ngrams and its TFIDF .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: The bag - of - ngrams models are constructed by selecting the 500,000 most frequent n-grams ( up to 5 - grams ) from the training subset for each dataset .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: The feature values are computed the same way as in the bag - of - words model .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: Bag - of - means on word embedding .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: We also have an experimental model that uses k-means on word2vec learnt from the training subset of each dataset , and then use these learnt means as representatives of the clustered words .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: We take into consideration all the words that appeared more than 5 times in the training subset .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: The dimension of the embedding is 300 .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: The bag - of - means features are computed the same way as in the bag - of - words model .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: The number of means is 5000 .
heading: Traditional Methods

text: Deep Learning Methods
Recently deep learning methods have started to be applied to text classification .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: We choose two simple and representative models for comparison , in which one is word - based ConvNet and the other a simple long - short term memory ( LSTM ) recurrent neural network model .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: Word - based ConvNets .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: Among the large number of recent works on word - based ConvNets for text classification , one of the differences is the choice of using pretrained or end - to - end learned word representations .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: We offer comparisons with both using the pretrained word2vec embedding and using lookup tables .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: The embedding size is 300 in both cases , in the same way as our bagof - means model .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: To ensure fair comparison , the models for each case are of the same size as our character - level ConvNets , in terms of both the number of layers and each layer 's output size .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: Experiments using a thesaurus for data augmentation are also conducted .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: Long - short term memory .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: The LSTM model used in our case is word - based , using pretrained word2vec embedding of size 300 as in previous models .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: The model is formed by taking mean of the outputs of all LSTM cells to form a feature vector , and then using multinomial logistic regression on this feature vector .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: The output dimension is 512 .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

text: The variant of LSTM we used is the common " vanilla " architecture [ 8 ] .
heading: Deep Learning Methods

Choice of Alphabet
For the alphabet of English , one apparent choice is whether to distinguish between upper-case and lower - case letters .
heading: Choice of Alphabet

text: We report experiments on this choice and observed that it usually ( but not always ) gives worse results when such distinction is made .
heading: Choice of Alphabet

text: One possible explanation might be that semantics do not change with different letter cases , therefore there is a benefit of regularization .
heading: Choice of Alphabet

text: Large - scale Datasets and Results

Previous research on ConvNets in different areas has shown that they usually work well with largescale datasets , especially when the model takes in low - level raw features like characters in our case .
heading: Large - scale Datasets and Results

text: However , most open datasets for text classification are quite small , and large - scale datasets are splitted with a significantly smaller training set than testing .
heading: Large - scale Datasets and Results

text: Therefore , instead of confusing our community more by using them , we built several large - scale datasets for our experiments , ranging from hundreds of thousands to several millions of samples .

Plots comparing word - based deep models ( figures 3 c , 3 d and 3 e ) show that character - level ConvNets work better for less curated user - generated texts .

heading: Answers .

text: Conclusion and Outlook
This article offers an empirical study on character - level convolutional networks for text classification .
heading: Conclusion and Outlook

text: We compared with a large number of traditional and deep learning models using several largescale datasets .
heading: Conclusion and Outlook

text: On one hand , analysis shows that character - level ConvNet is an effective method .
heading: Conclusion and Outlook

text: On the other hand , how well our model performs in comparisons depends on many factors , such as dataset size , whether the texts are curated and choice of alphabet .
heading: Conclusion and Outlook

text: In the future , we hope to apply character - level ConvNets fora broader range of language processing tasks especially when structured outputs are needed .
heading: Conclusion and Outlook

text: title
Supervised and Semi- Supervised Text Categorization using LSTM for Region Embeddings
heading: title

text: abstract
One - hot CNN ( convolutional neural network ) has been shown to be effective for text categorization ( Johnson & Zhang , 2015a ; b ) .
heading: abstract

text: We view it as a special case of a general framework which jointly trains a linear model with a non-linear feature generator consisting of ' text region embedding + pooling ' .
heading: abstract

text: Under this framework , we explore a more sophisticated region embedding method using Long Short - Term Memory ( LSTM ) .
heading: abstract

text: LSTM can embed text regions of variable ( and possibly large ) sizes , whereas the region size needs to be fixed in a CNN .
heading: abstract

text: We seek effective and efficient use of LSTM for this purpose in the supervised and semi-supervised settings .
heading: abstract

text: The best results were obtained by combining region embeddings in the form of LSTM and convolution layers trained on unlabeled data .
heading: abstract

text: The results indicate that on this task , embeddings of text regions , which can convey complex concepts , are more useful than embeddings of single words in isolation .
heading: abstract

text: We report performances exceeding the previous best results on four benchmark datasets .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction

Text categorization is the task of assigning labels to documents written in a natural language , and it has numerous real - world applications including sentiment analysis as well as traditional topic assignment tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: The state - of - the art methods for text categorization had long been linear predictors ( e.g. , SVM with a linear kernel ) with either bag - ofword or bag - of - n- gram vectors ( hereafter bow ) as input , e.g. , .
heading: Introduction

text: This , however , A convolutional neural network ( CNN ) ) is a feedforward neural network with convolution layers interleaved with pooling layers , originally developed for image processing .
heading: Introduction

text: In its convolution layer , a small region of data ( e.g. , a small square of image ) at every location is converted to a low-dimensional vector with information relevant to the task being preserved , which we loosely term ' embedding ' .
heading: Introduction

text: The embedding function is shared among all the locations , so that useful features can be detected irrespective of their locations .
heading: Introduction

text: In its simplest form , onehot CNN works as follows .
heading: Introduction

text: A document is represented as a sequence of one - hot vectors ( each of which indicates a word by the position of a 1 ) ; a convolution layer converts small regions of the document ( e.g. , " I love it " ) to low-dimensional vectors at every location ( embedding of text regions ) ; a pooling layer aggregates the region embedding results to a document vector by taking componentwise maximum or average ; and the top layer classifies a document vector with a linear model .
heading: Introduction

text: The onehot CNN and its semi-supervised extension were shown to be superior to a number of previous methods .
heading: Introduction

text: In this work , we consider a more general framework ( subsuming one - hot CNN ) which jointly trains a feature generator and a linear model , where the feature generator consists of ' region embedding + pooling ' .
heading: Introduction

text: The specific region embedding function of one - hot CNN takes the simple form v ( x ) = max (0 , Wx + b ) ,
heading: Introduction

text: where x is a concatenation of one - hot vectors ( therefore , ' one - hot ' in the name ) of the words in the - th region ( of a fixed size ) , and the weight matrix W and the bias vector b need to be trained .
heading: Introduction

text: It is simple and fast to compute , and considering its simplicity , the method works surprisingly well if the region size is appropriately set .
heading: Introduction

text: However , there are also potential shortcomings .
The region size must be fixed , which may not be optimal as the size of relevant regions may vary .
heading: However , there are also potential shortcomings .

text: Practically , the region size can not be very large as the number of parameters to be learned ( components of W ) depends on it .
heading: However , there are also potential shortcomings .

text: JZ15 proposed variations to alleviate these issues .
For example , a bow - input variation allows x above to be a bow vector of the region .
heading: JZ15 proposed variations to alleviate these issues .

text: This enables a larger region , but at the expense of losing word order in the region and so its use maybe limited .
heading: JZ15 proposed variations to alleviate these issues .

text: In this work , we build on the general framework of ' region embedding + pooling ' and explore a more sophisticated region embedding via Long Short - Term Memory ( LSTM ) , seeking to overcome the shortcomings above , in the supervised and semi-supervised settings .
heading: JZ15 proposed variations to alleviate these issues .

text: LSTM ) is a recurrent neural network .
In its typical applications to text , an LSTM takes words in a sequence one by one ; i.e. , at time t , it takes as input the t- th word and the output from time t ?
heading: LSTM ) is a recurrent neural network .

text: 1 . Therefore , the output from each time step can be regarded as the embedding of the sequence of words that have been seen so far ( or a relevant part of it ) .
heading: LSTM ) is a recurrent neural network .

text: It is designed to enable learning of dependencies over larger time lags than feasible with traditional recurrent networks .
heading: LSTM ) is a recurrent neural network .

text: That is , an LSTM can be used to embed text regions of variable ( and possibly large ) sizes .
heading: LSTM ) is a recurrent neural network .

text: We pursue the best use of LSTM for our purpose , and then compare the resulting model with the previous best methods including one - hot CNN and previous LSTM .
heading: LSTM ) is a recurrent neural network .

text: Our strategy is to simplify the model as much as possible , including elimination of a word embedding layer routinely used to produce input to LSTM .
heading: LSTM ) is a recurrent neural network .

text: Our findings are threefold .
First , in the supervised setting , our simplification strategy leads to higher accuracy and faster training than previous LSTM .
heading: Our findings are threefold .

text: Second , accuracy can be further improved by training LSTMs on unlabeled data for learning useful region embeddings and using them to produce additional input .
heading: Our findings are threefold .

text: Third , both our LSTM models and one - hot CNN strongly outperform other methods including previous LSTM .
heading: Our findings are threefold .

text: The best results are obtained by combining the two types of region embeddings ( LSTM embed - dings and CNN embeddings ) trained on unlabeled data , indicating that their strengths are complementary .
heading: Our findings are threefold .

text: Overall , our results show that for text categorization , embeddings of text regions , which can convey higher - level concepts than single words in isolation , are useful , and that useful region embeddings can be learned without going through word embedding learning .
heading: Our findings are threefold .

text: We report performances exceeding the previous best results on four benchmark datasets .
heading: Our findings are threefold .

text: Our code and experimental details are available at http://riejohnson.com/cnn download.html .
heading: Our findings are threefold .

text: Preliminary
On text , LSTM has been used for labeling or generating words .
heading: Preliminary

text: It has been also used for representing short sentences mostly for sentiment analysis , and some of them rely on syntactic parse trees ; see e.g. , .
heading: Preliminary

text: Unlike these studies , this work as well as JZ15 focuses on classifying general full - length documents without any special linguistic knowledge .
heading: Preliminary

text: Similarly , DL15 applied LSTM to categorizing general full - length documents .
heading: Preliminary

text: Therefore , our empirical comparisons will focus on DL15 and JZ15 , both of which reported new state of the art results .
heading: Preliminary

text: Let us first introduce the general LSTM formulation , and then briefly describe DL15 's model as it illustrates the challenges in using LSTMs for this task .
heading: Preliminary

text: LSTM
While several variations exist , we base our work on the following LSTM formulation , which was used in , e.g. ,
heading: LSTM

text: where denotes element - wise multiplication and ?
heading: LSTM

text: is an element - wise squash function to make the gating values in [ 0 , 1 ] .
heading: LSTM

text: We fix ? to sigmoid .
heading: LSTM

text: x t ?
heading: LSTM

text: Rd is the input from the lower layer at time step t , where d would be , for example , size of vocabulary if the input was a one - hot vector representing a word , or the dimensionality of word vector if the lower layer was a word embedding layer .
heading: LSTM

text: With q LSTM units , the dimensionality of the weight matrices and bias vectors , which need to be trained , are W ( ) ? R qd , U ( ) ? R qq , and b ( ) ?
heading: LSTM

text: R q for all types .

The centerpiece of LSTM is the memory cells ct , designed to counteract the risk of vanishing / exploding gradients , thus enabling learning of dependencies over larger time lags than feasible with traditional recurrent networks .
heading: R q for all types .

text: The forget gate ft is for resetting the memory cells .
heading: R q for all types .

text: The input gate it and output gate o t control the input and output of the memory cells .
heading: R q for all types .

text: Word - vector LSTM ( wv - LSTM ) [ DL15 ] DL15 's application of LSTM to text categorization is straightforward .
heading: R q for all types .

text: As illustrated in , for each document , the output of the LSTM layer is the output of the last time step ( corresponding to the last word of the document ) , which represents the whole document ( document embedding ) .
heading: R q for all types .

text: Like many other studies of LSTM on text , words are first converted to low - dimensional dense word vectors via a word embedding layer ; therefore , we call it word - vector LSTM or wv - LSTM .
heading: R q for all types .

text: DL15 observed that wv - LSTM underperformed linear predictors and its training was unstable .
heading: R q for all types .

text: This was attributed to the fact that documents are long .
heading: R q for all types .

text: In addition , we found that training and testing of wv - LSTM is time / resource consuming .
heading: R q for all types .

text: To put it into perspective , using a GPU , one epoch of wv - LSTM training takes nearly 20 times longer than that of one - hot CNN training even though it achieves poorer accuracy ( the first two rows of ) .
heading: R q for all types .

text: This is due to the sequential nature of LSTM , i.e. , computation at time t requires the output of time t ? 1 , whereas modern computation depends on parallelization for speedup .
heading: R q for all types .

text: Documents in a mini-batch can be processed in parallel , but the variability of document lengths reduces the degree of parallelization 1 .
heading: R q for all types .

text: It was shown in DL15 that training becomes stable and accuracy improves drastically when LSTM and the word embedding layer are jointly pre-trained with either the language model learning objective ( predicting the next word ) or autoencoder objective ( memorizing the document ) .
heading: R q for all types .

text: Supervised LSTM for text categorization
Within the framework of ' region embedding + pooling ' for text categorization , we seek effective and efficient use of LSTM as an alternative region embedding method .
heading: Supervised LSTM for text categorization

text: This section focuses on an end - to - end supervised setting so that there is no additional data ( e.g. , unlabeled data ) or additional algorithm ( e.g. , for learning a word embedding ) .
heading: Supervised LSTM for text categorization

text: Our general strategy is to simplify the model as much as possible .
heading: Supervised LSTM for text categorization

text: We start with elimination of the word embedding layer so that one - hot vectors are directly fed to LSTM , which we call one - hot LSTM in short .
heading: Supervised LSTM for text categorization

text: Elimination of the word embedding layer
Facts : A word embedding is a linear operation that can be written as Vx t with x t being a one - hot vector and columns of V being word vectors .
heading: Elimination of the word embedding layer

text: Therefore , by replacing the LSTM weights W ( ) with W ( ) V and removing the word embedding layer , a word - vector LSTM can be turned into a one - hot LSTM without changing the model behavior .
heading: Elimination of the word embedding layer

text: Thus , word - vector LSTM is not more expressive than one - hot LSTM ; rather , a merit , if any , of training with a word embedding layer would be through imposing restrictions ( e.g. , a low - rank V makes a less expressive model ) to achieve good prior / regularization effects .
heading: Elimination of the word embedding layer

text: In the end - to - end supervised setting , a word embedding matrix V would need to be initialized randomly and trained as part of the model .
heading: Elimination of the word embedding layer

text: In the preliminary experiments under our framework , we were unable to improve accuracy over one - hot LSTM by inclusion of such a randomly initialized word embedding layer ; i.e. , random vectors failed to provide good prior effects .
heading: Elimination of the word embedding layer

text: Instead , demerits were evident - more meta-parameters to tune , poor accuracy with lowdimensional word vectors , and slow training / testing with high - dimensional word vectors as they are dense .
heading: Elimination of the word embedding layer

text: If a word embedding is appropriately pre-trained with unlabeled data , its inclusion is a form of semi-supervised learning and could be useful .
heading: Elimination of the word embedding layer

text: We will show later , however , that this type of approach falls behind our approach of learning region embeddings through training one - hot LSTM on unlabeled data .
heading: Elimination of the word embedding layer

text: Altogether , elimination of the word embedding layer was found to be useful ; thus , we base our work on one - hot LSTM .
heading: Elimination of the word embedding layer

text: More simplifications
We introduce four more useful modifications to wv - LSTM that lead to higher accuracy or faster training .
heading: More simplifications

text: Pooling : simplifying sub - problems
Our framework of ' region embedding + pooling ' has a simplification effect as follows .
heading: Pooling : simplifying sub - problems

text: In wv - LSTM , the sub-problem that LSTM needs to solve is to represent the entire document by one vector ( document embedding ) .
heading: Pooling : simplifying sub - problems

text: We make this easy by changing it to detecting regions of text ( of arbitrary sizes ) that are relevant to the task and representing them by vectors ( region embedding ) .
heading: Pooling : simplifying sub - problems

text: As illustrated in , we let the LSTM layer emit vectors ht at each time step , and let pooling aggregate them into a document vector .
heading: Pooling : simplifying sub - problems

text: With wv - LSTM , LSTM has to remember relevant information until it gets to the end of the document even if relevant information was observed 10 K words away .
heading: Pooling : simplifying sub - problems

text: The task of our LSTM is easier as it is allowed to forget old things via the forget gate and can focus on representing the concepts conveyed by smaller segments such as phrases or sentences .
heading: Pooling : simplifying sub - problems

text: A related architecture appears in the Deep Learning Tutorials 2 though it uses a word embedding .
heading: Pooling : simplifying sub - problems

text: Another related work is , which combined pooling with non -LSTM recurrent networks and a word embedding .
heading: Pooling : simplifying sub - problems

text: Chopping for speeding up training
In addition to simplifying the sub-problem , pooling has the merit of enabling faster training via chopping .
heading: Chopping for speeding up training

text: Since we set the goal of LSTM to embedding text regions instead of documents , it is no longer crucial to go through the document from the beginning to the end sequentially .
heading: Chopping for speeding up training

text: At the time of training , we can chop each document into segments of a fixed length that is sufficiently long ( e.g. , 50 or 100 ) and process all the segments in a mini batch in parallel as if these segments were individual documents .
heading: Chopping for speeding up training

text: ( Note that this is done only in the LSTM layer and pooling is done over the entire document . )
heading: Chopping for speeding up training

text: We perform testing without chopping .
That is , we train LSTM with approximations of sequences for speedup and test with real sequences for better accuracy .
heading: We perform testing without chopping .

text: There is a risk of chopping important phrases ( e.g. , " do n't | like it " ) , and this can be easily avoided by having segments slightly overlap .
heading: We perform testing without chopping .

text: However , we found that gains from overlapping segments tend to be small and so our experiments reported below were done without overlapping .
heading: We perform testing without chopping .

text: Removing the input / output gates

We found that when LSTM is followed by pooling , the presence of input and output gates typically does not improve accuracy , while removing them nearly halves the time and memory required for training and testing .
heading: Removing the input / output gates

text: It is intuitive , in particular , that pooling can make the output gate unnecessary ; the role of the output gate is to prevent undesirable information from entering the output ht , and such irrelevant information can be filtered out by max - pooling .
heading: Removing the input / output gates

text: Without the input and output gates , the LSTM formulation can be simplified to :
heading: Removing the input / output gates

text: This is equivalent to fixing it and o t to all ones .
heading: Removing the input / output gates

text: It is in spirit similar to Gated Recurrent Units but simpler , having fewer gates .
heading: Removing the input / output gates

text: Bidirectional LSTM for better accuracy
The changes from wv - LSTM above substantially reduce the time and 2 http://deeplearning.net/tutorial/lstm.html
heading: Bidirectional LSTM for better accuracy

text: One - hot vectors memory required for training and make it practical to add one more layer of LSTM going in the opposite direction for accuracy improvement .
heading: Bidirectional LSTM for better accuracy

text: As shown in , we concatenate the output of a forward LSTM ( left to right ) and a backward LSTM ( right to left ) , which is referred to as bidirectional LSTM in the literature .
heading: Bidirectional LSTM for better accuracy

text: The resulting model is a one - hot bidirectional LSTM with pooling , and we abbreviate it to oh - 2 LSTMp .
heading: Bidirectional LSTM for better accuracy

text: shows how much accuracy and / or training speed can be improved by elimination of the word embedding layer , pooling , chopping , removing the input / output gates , and adding the backward LSTM .
heading: Bidirectional LSTM for better accuracy

The previous best performance on 20NG is 15.3 ( not shown in the table ) of DL15 , obtained by pre-training wv - LSTM of 1024 units with labeled training data .

text: The previous best results on the other datasets use unlabeled data , and we will review them with our semi-supervised results .
