text: Semi-supervised LSTM
heading: Comparison with the previous best results on 20 NG

text: To exploit unlabeled data as an additional resource , we use a non-linear extension of two - view feature learning , whose linear version appeared in our earlier work .
heading: Comparison with the previous best results on 20 NG

text: This was used in JZ15 b to learn from unlabeled data a region embedding embodied by a convolution layer .
heading: Comparison with the previous best results on 20 NG

text: In this work we use it to learn a region embedding embodied by a one - hot LSTM .
heading: Comparison with the previous best results on 20 NG

text: Let us start with a brief review of non-linear two - view feature learning .
heading: Comparison with the previous best results on 20 NG

text: Two - view embedding ( tv-embedding ) [ JZ15 b ]
heading: Comparison with the previous best results on 20 NG

text: A rough sketch is as follows .
Consider two views of the input .
An embedding is called a tv-embedding if the embedded view is as good as the original view for the purpose of predicting the other view .
heading: Consider two views of the input .

text: If the two views and the labels ( classification targets ) are related to one another only through some hidden states , then the tv-embedded view is as good as the original view for the purpose of classification .
heading: Consider two views of the input .

text: Such an embedding is useful provided that its dimensionality is much lower than the original view .
heading: Consider two views of the input .

text: JZ15 b applied this idea by regarding text regions embedded by the convolution layer as one view and their surrounding context as the other view and training a tv-embedding ( embodied by a convolution layer ) on unlabeled data .
heading: Consider two views of the input .

text: The obtained tv-embeddings were used to produce additional input to a supervised region embedding of one - hot CNN , resulting in higher accuracy .
heading: Consider two views of the input .

text: we consider the following two views : the words we have already seen in the document ( view - 1 ) , and the next few words ( view - 2 ) .
heading: Consider two views of the input .

text: The task of tv-embedding learning is to predict view - 2 based on view - 1 .
heading: Consider two views of the input .

text: We train one - hot LSTMs in both directions , as in , on unlabeled data .
heading: Consider two views of the input .

text: For this purpose , we use the input and output gates as well as the forget gate as we found them to be useful .
heading: Consider two views of the input .

text: Learning LSTM tv-embeddings

The theory of tv-embedding says that the region embeddings obtained in this way are useful for the task of interest if the two views are related to each other through the concepts relevant to the task .
heading: Learning LSTM tv-embeddings

text: To reduce undesirable relations between the views such as syntactic relations , JZ15 b performed vocabulary control to remove function words from ( and only from ) the vocabulary of the target view , which we found useful also for LSTM .
heading: Learning LSTM tv-embeddings

text: We use the tv-embeddings obtained from unlabeled data to produce additional input to LSTM by replacing and ( 3 ) by the following :
heading: Learning LSTM tv-embeddings

text: x j t is the output of a tv-embedding ( an LSTM trained with unlabeled data ) indexed by j at time step t , and S is a set of tv-embeddings which contains the two LSTMs going forward and backward as in .
heading: Learning LSTM tv-embeddings

text: Although it is possible to fine - tune the tv-embeddings with labeled data , for simplicity and faster training , we fixed them in our experiments .
heading: Learning LSTM tv-embeddings

text: Combining LSTM tv-embeddings and CNN tv-embeddings

It is easy to see that the set S above can be expanded with any tv-embeddings , not only those in the form of LSTM ( LSTM tv-embeddings ) but also with the tv-embeddings in the form of convolution layers ( CNN tv-embeddings ) such as those obtained in JZ15 b .
heading: Combining LSTM tv-embeddings and CNN tv-embeddings

text: Similarly , it is possible to use LSTM tv-embeddings to produce additional input to CNN .
heading: Combining LSTM tv-embeddings and CNN tv-embeddings

text: While both LSTM tv-embeddings and CNN tv-embeddings are region embeddings , their formulations are very different from each other ; therefore , we expect that they complement each other and bring further performance improvements when combined .
heading: Combining LSTM tv-embeddings and CNN tv-embeddings

text: We will empirically confirm these conjectures in the experiments below .
heading: Combining LSTM tv-embeddings and CNN tv-embeddings

text: Note that being able to naturally combine several tv-embeddings is a strength of 2100 - dim LSTM tv-embed .
heading: Combining LSTM tv-embeddings and CNN tv-embeddings

heading: Combining LSTM tv-embeddings and CNN tv-embeddings

heading: Combining LSTM tv-embeddings and CNN tv-embeddings

text: Conclusion
Within the general framework of ' region embedding + pooling ' for text categorization , we explored region embeddings via one - hot LSTM .
heading: Conclusion

text: The region embedding of onehot LSTM rivaled or outperformed that of the state - of - the art one - hot CNN , proving its effectiveness .
heading: Conclusion

text: We also found that the models with either one of these two types of region embedding strongly outperformed other methods including previous LSTM .
heading: Conclusion

text: The best results were obtained by combining the two types of region embedding trained on unlabeled data , suggesting that their strengths are complementary .
heading: Conclusion

text: As a result , we reported substantial improvements over the previous best results on benchmark datasets .
heading: Conclusion

text: At a high level , our results indicate the following .
heading: Conclusion

text: First , on this task , embeddings of text regions , which can convey higher - level concepts , are more useful than embeddings of single words in isolation .
heading: Conclusion

text: Second , useful region embeddings can be learned by working with one - hot vectors directly , either on labeled data or unlabeled data .
heading: Conclusion

text: Finally , a promising future direction might be to seek , under this framework , new region embedding methods with complementary benefits .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Bag of Tricks for Efficient Text Classification
heading: title

text: abstract
This paper explores a simple and efficient baseline for text classification .
heading: abstract

text: Our experiments show that our fast text classifier fastText is often on par with deep learning classifiers in terms of accuracy , and many orders of magnitude faster for training and evaluation .
heading: abstract

text: We can train fastText on more than one billion words in less than ten minutes using a standard multicore CPU , and classify half a million sentences among 312K classes in less than a minute .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Text classification is an important task in Natural Language Processing with many applications , such as web search , information retrieval , ranking and document classification .
heading: Introduction

text: Recently , models based on neural networks have become increasingly popular .
heading: Introduction

text: While these models achieve very good performance in practice , they tend to be relatively slow both at train and test time , limiting their use on very large datasets .
heading: Introduction

text: Meanwhile , linear classifiers are often considered as strong baselines for text classification problems .
heading: Introduction

text: Despite their simplicity , they often obtain stateof - the - art performances if the right features are used .
heading: Introduction

text: They also have the potential to scale to very large corpus .
heading: Introduction

text: In this work , we explore ways to scale these baselines to very large corpus with a large output space , in the context of text classification .
heading: Introduction

text: Inspired by the recent work in efficient word representation learning , we show that linear models with a rank constraint and a fast loss approximation can train on a billion words within ten minutes , while achieving performance on par with the state - of - the - art .
heading: Introduction

text: We evaluate the quality of our approach fastText 1 on two different tasks , namely tag prediction and sentiment analysis .
heading: Introduction

text: Model architecture
A simple and efficient baseline for sentence classification is to represent sentences as bag of words ( BoW ) and train a linear classifier , e.g. , a logistic regression or an SVM .
heading: Model architecture

text: However , linear classifiers do not share parameters among features and classes .
heading: Model architecture

text: This possibly limits their generalization in the context of large output space where some classes have very few examples .
heading: Model architecture

text: Common solutions to this problem are to factorize the linear classifier into low rank matrices or to use multilayer neural networks .
heading: Model architecture

text: shows a simple linear model with rank constraint .
heading: Model architecture

text: The first weight matrix A is a look - up table over the words .
heading: Model architecture

text: The word representations are then averaged into a text representation , which is in turn fed to a linear classifier .
heading: Model architecture

text: The text representa - tion is an hidden variable which can be potentially be reused .
heading: Model architecture

text: This architecture is similar to the cbow model of , where the middle word is replaced by a label .
heading: Model architecture

text: We use the softmax function f to compute the probability distribution over the predefined classes .
heading: Model architecture

text: For a set of N documents , this leads to minimizing the negative loglikelihood over the classes :
heading: Model architecture

text: where x n is the normalized bag of features of the nth document , y n the label , A and B the weight matrices .
heading: Model architecture

text: This model is trained asynchronously on multiple CPUs using stochastic gradient descent and a linearly decaying learning rate .
heading: Model architecture

text: Hierarchical softmax
When the number of classes is large , computing the linear classifier is computationally expensive .
heading: Hierarchical softmax

text: More precisely , the computational complexity is O ( kh ) where k is the number of classes and h the dimension of the text representation .
heading: Hierarchical softmax

text: In order to improve our running time , we use a hierarchical softmax ) based on the Huffman coding tree .
heading: Hierarchical softmax

text: During training , the computational complexity drops to O ( h log 2 ( k ) ) .
heading: Hierarchical softmax

text: The hierarchical softmax is also advantageous attest time when searching for the most likely class .
heading: Hierarchical softmax

text: Each node is associated with a probability that is the probability of the path from the root to that node .
heading: Hierarchical softmax

text: If the node is at depth l + 1 with parents n 1 , . . . , n l , it s probability is
heading: Hierarchical softmax

text: This means that the probability of anode is always lower than the one of its parent .
heading: Hierarchical softmax

text: Exploring the tree with a depth first search and tracking the maximum probability among the leaves allows us to discard any branch associated with a small probability .
heading: Hierarchical softmax

text: In practice , we observe a reduction of the complexity to O ( h log 2 ( k ) ) attest time .
heading: Hierarchical softmax

text: This approach is further extended to compute the T - top targets at the cost of O ( log ( T ) ) , using a binary heap .
heading: Hierarchical softmax

text: N - gram features
Bag of words is invariant to word order but taking explicitly this order into account is often computationally very expensive .
heading: N - gram features

text: Instead , we use a bag of n-grams as additional features to capture some partial information about the local word order .
heading: N - gram features

text: This is very efficient in practice while achieving comparable results to methods that explicitly use the order .
heading: N - gram features

text: We maintain a fast and memory efficient mapping of the n-grams by using the hashing trick with the same hashing function as in and 10M bins if we only used bigrams , and 100M otherwise .
heading: N - gram features

text: Experiments
We evaluate fastText on two different tasks .
First , we compare it to existing text classifers on the problem of sentiment analysis .
heading: We evaluate fastText on two different tasks .

text: Then , we evaluate its capacity to scale to large output space on a tag prediction dataset .
heading: We evaluate fastText on two different tasks .

text: Note that our model could be implemented with the Vowpal Wabbit library , 2 but we observe in practice , that our tailored implementation is at least 2 - 5 faster .
heading: We evaluate fastText on two different tasks .

Datasets and baselines .
We employ the same 8 datasets and evaluation protocol of .

heading: Datasets and baselines .

text: We report their main baselines as well as their two approaches based on recurrent networks ( Conv - GRNN and LSTM - GRNN ) .
heading: Datasets and baselines .

We present the results in .
We use 10 hidden units and run fastText for 5 epochs with a learning rate selected on a validation set from { 0.05 , 0.1 , 0.25 , 0.5 } .
heading: We present the results in .

text: On this task , adding bigram information improves the performance by 1 - 4 % .

text: Tag prediction
Dataset and baselines .
To test scalability of our approach , further evaluation is carried on the YFCC100M dataset which consists of almost 100M images with captions , titles and tags .
heading: Dataset and baselines .

text: We focus on predicting the tags according to the title and caption ( we do not use the images ) .
heading: Dataset and baselines .

text: We remove the words and tags occurring less than 100 times and split the data into a train , validation and test set .
heading: Dataset and baselines .

text: The train set contains 91,188,648 examples ( 1.5B tokens ) .
heading: Dataset and baselines .

text: The validation has 930,497 examples and the test set 543,424 .

text: Discussion and conclusion
In this work , we propose a simple baseline method for text classification .
heading: Discussion and conclusion

text: Unlike unsupervisedly trained word vectors from word2vec , our word features can be averaged together to form good sentence representations .
heading: Discussion and conclusion

text: In several tasks , fastText obtains performance on par with recently proposed methods inspired by deep learning , while being much faster .
heading: Discussion and conclusion

text: Although deep neural networks have in theory much higher representational power than shallow models , it is not clear if simple text classification problems such as sentiment analysis are the right ones to evaluate them .
heading: Discussion and conclusion

text: We will publish our code so that the research community can easily build on top of our work .
heading: Discussion and conclusion

text: title
On the Role of Text Preprocessing in Neural Network Architectures : An Evaluation Study on Text Categorization and Sentiment Analysis
heading: title

text: abstract
Text preprocessing is often the first step in the pipeline of a Natural Language Processing ( NLP ) system , with potential impact in its final performance .
heading: abstract

text: Despite its importance , text preprocessing has not received much attention in the deep learning literature .
heading: abstract

text: In this paper we investigate the impact of simple text preprocessing decisions ( particularly tokenizing , lemmatizing , lowercasing and multiword grouping ) on the performance of a standard neural text classifier .
heading: abstract

text: We perform an extensive evaluation on standard benchmarks from text categorization and sentiment analysis .
heading: abstract

text: While our experiments show that a simple tokenization of input text is generally adequate , they also highlight significant degrees of variability across preprocessing techniques .
heading: abstract

text: This reveals the importance of paying attention to this usually - overlooked step in the pipeline , particularly when comparing different models .
heading: abstract

text: Finally , our evaluation provides insights into the best preprocessing practices for training word embeddings .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Words are often considered as the basic constituents of texts for many languages , including English .
heading: Introduction

text: The first module in an NLP pipeline is a tokenizer which transforms texts to sequences of words .
heading: Introduction

text: However , in practise , other preprocessing techniques can be ( and are ) further used together with tokenization .
heading: Introduction

text: These include lemmatization , lowercasing and 1 Note that although word - based models are mainstream in NLP in general and text classification in particular , recent work has also considered other linguistic units , such as characters or word senses .
heading: Introduction

text: These techniques require a different kind of preprocessing and , while they have been shown effective in various settings , in this work we only focus on the mainstream word - based models .
heading: Introduction

text: multiword grouping , among others .
heading: Introduction

text: Although these preprocessing decisions have been studied in the context of conventional text classification techniques , little attention has been paid to them in the more recent neural - based models .
heading: Introduction

text: The most similar study to ours is , which analyzed different encoding levels for English and Asian languages such as Chinese , Japanese and Korean .
heading: Introduction

text: As opposed to our work , their analysis was focused on UTF - 8 bytes , characters , words , romanized characters and romanized words as encoding levels , rather than the preprocessing techniques analyzed in this paper .
heading: Introduction

text: Additionally , word embeddings have been shown to play an important role in boosting the generalization capabilities of neural systems .
heading: Introduction

text: However , while some studies have focused on intrinsically analyzing the role of lemmatization in their underlying training corpus , the impact on their extrinsic performance when integrated into a neural network architecture has remained understudied .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper we focus on the role of preprocessing the input text , particularly in how it is split into individual ( meaning - bearing ) tokens and how it affects the performance of standard neural text classification models based on .
heading: Introduction

text: CNNs have proven to be effective in a wide range of NLP applications , in - cluding text classification tasks such as topic categorization and polarity detection , which are the tasks considered in this work .
heading: Introduction

text: The goal of our evaluation study is to find answers to the following two questions :
heading: Introduction

text: Are neural network architectures ( in particular CNNs ) affected by seemingly small preprocessing decisions in the input text ?
heading: Introduction

text: Does the preprocessing of the embeddings ' underlying training corpus have an impact on the final performance of a state - of - the - art neural network text classifier ?
heading: Introduction

text: According to our experiments in topic categorization and polarity detection , these decisions are important in certain cases .
heading: Introduction

text: Moreover , we shed some light on the motivations of each preprocessing decision and provide some hints on how to normalize the input corpus to better suit each setting .
heading: Introduction

text: The accompanying materials of this submission can be downloaded at the following repository : github.com/pedrada88/preproc-textclassification .
heading: Introduction

text: Text Preprocessing
Given an input text , words are gathered as input units of classification models through tokenization .
heading: Text Preprocessing

text: We refer to the corpus which is only tokenized as vanilla .
heading: Text Preprocessing

text: For example , given the sentence " Apple is asking its manufacturers to move Mac - Book Air production to the United States . " ( running example ) , the vanilla tokenized text would be as follows ( white spaces delimiting different word units ) :
heading: Text Preprocessing

text: Apple is asking its manufacturers to move MacBook Air production to the United States .
heading: Text Preprocessing

text: We additionally consider three simple preprocessing techniques to be applied to an input text : lowercasing ( Section 2.1 ) , lemmatizing ( Section 2.2 ) and multiword grouping ( Section 2.3 ) .
heading: Text Preprocessing

text: Lowercasing
This is the simplest preprocessing technique which consists of lowercasing each single token of the input text :
heading: Lowercasing

text: apple is asking its manufacturers to move macbook air production to the united states .
heading: Lowercasing

text: Due to its simplicity , lowercasing has been a popular practice in modules of deep learning libraries and word embedding packages .
heading: Lowercasing

text: Despite its desirable property of reducing sparsity and vocabulary size , lowercasing may negatively impact system 's performance by increasing ambiguity .
heading: Lowercasing

text: For instance , the Apple company in our example and the apple fruit would be considered as identical entities .
heading: Lowercasing

text: Lemmatizing
The process of lemmatizing consists of replacing a given token with its corresponding lemma :
heading: Lemmatizing

text: Apple be ask its manufacturer to move Mac - Book Air production to the United States .
heading: Lemmatizing

text: Lemmatization has been traditionally a standard preprocessing technique for linear text classification systems .
heading: Lemmatizing

text: However , it is rarely used as a preprocessing stage in neural - based systems .
heading: Lemmatizing

text: The main idea behind lemmatization is to reduce sparsity , as different inflected forms of the same lemma may occur infrequently ( or not at all ) during training .
heading: Lemmatizing

text: However , this may come at the cost of neglecting important syntactic nuances .
heading: Lemmatizing

text: Multiword grouping
This last preprocessing technique consists of grouping consecutive tokens together into a single token if found in a given inventory :
heading: Multiword grouping

text: Apple is asking its manufacturers to move MacBook Air production to the United States .
heading: Multiword grouping

text: The motivation behind this step lies in the idiosyncratic nature of multiword expressions , e.g. United States in the example .
heading: Multiword grouping

text: The meaning of these multiword expressions are often hardly traceable from their individual tokens .
heading: Multiword grouping

text: As a result , treating multiwords as single units may lead to better training of a given model .
heading: Multiword grouping

text: Because of this , word embedding toolkits such as Word2vec propose statistical approaches for extracting these multiwords , or directly include multiwords along with single words in their pretrained embedding spaces .
heading: Multiword grouping

text: We considered two tasks for our experiments : topic categorization , i.e. assigning a topic to a given document from a pre-defined set of topics , and polarity detection , i.e. detecting if the sentiment of a given piece of text is positive or negative .
heading: Multiword grouping

text: Two different settings were studied : ( 1 ) word embedding 's training corpus and the evaluation dataset were preprocessed in a similar manner ( Section 3.2 ) ; and ( 2 ) the two were preprocessed differently ( Section 3.3 ) .
heading: Multiword grouping

text: In what follows we describe the common experimental setting as well as the datasets and preprocessing used for the evaluation .
heading: Multiword grouping

text: Experimental setup
We tried with two classification models .
The first one is a standard CNN model similar to that of , using ReLU as non-linear activation function .
heading: We tried with two classification models .

text: In the second model , we add a recurrent layer ( specifically an LSTM ) before passing the pooled features directly to the fully connected softmax layer .
heading: We tried with two classification models .

text: The inclusion of this LSTM layer has been shown to be able to effectively replace multiple layers of convolution and be beneficial particularly for large inputs .
heading: We tried with two classification models .

text: These models were used for both topic categorization and polarity detection tasks , with slight hyperparameter variations given their different natures ( mainly in their text size ) which were fixed across all datasets .
heading: We tried with two classification models .

text: The embedding layer was initialized using 300 - dimensional CBOW Word2vec embeddings trained on the 3B - word UMBC WebBase corpus with standard hyperparameters
heading: We tried with two classification models .
We tried with two classification models .

text: Evaluation datasets .

For the topic categorization task we used the BBC news dataset 5 , 20 News , Reuters 6 and The code for this CNN implementation is the same as in , which is available at https://github.com/pilehvar/sensecnn
heading: Evaluation datasets .

text: 4 Context window of 5 words and hierarchical softmax .
heading: Evaluation datasets .

text: 5 http://mlg.ucd.ie/datasets/bbc.html
heading: Evaluation datasets .

text: 6 Due to the large number of labels in the original Reuters ( i.e. 91 ) and to be consistent with the other datasets , we reduce the dataset to its 8 most frequent labels , a reduction already performed in previous works .
heading: Evaluation datasets .

text: Preprocessing .
Four different techniques ( see Section 2 ) were used to preprocess the datasets as well as the corpus which was used to train word embeddings ( i.e. UMBC ) .
heading: Preprocessing .

text: For tokenization and lemmatization we relied on Stanford CoreNLP .
heading: Preprocessing .

text: As for multiwords , we used the phrases from the pre-trained Google News Word2vec vectors , which were obtained using a simple statistical approach .
heading: Preprocessing .

text: 12 shows the accuracy 13 of the classification models using our four preprocessing techniques .
heading: Preprocessing .

text: We observe a certain variability of results depending on the preprocessing techniques used ( aver -7 ftp://medir.ohsu.edu/pub/ohsumed
heading: Preprocessing .

text: 8 Both PL04 and PL05 were downloaded from http://www.cs.cornell.edu/people/pabo/movie-review-data/
heading: Preprocessing .

text: 9 http://www.rottentomatoes.com
heading: Preprocessing .

text: 10 We mapped the numerical value of phrases to either negative ( from 0 to 0.4 ) or positive ( from 0.6 to 1 ) , removing the neutral phrases according to the scale ( from 0.4 to 0.6 ) .
heading: Preprocessing .

text: For the datasets with train - test partitions , the sizes of the test sets are the following : 7,532 for 20 News ; 12,733 for Ohsumed ; 25,000 for IMDb ; and 1,000 for RTC .
heading: Preprocessing .

text: For future work it would be interesting to explore more complex methods to learn embeddings for multiword expressions .
heading: Preprocessing .

text: Computed by averaging accuracy of two different runs .

The statistical significance was calculated according to an unpaired t- test at the 5 % significance level . age variability 14 of 2.4 % for the CNN + LSTM model , including a statistical significance gap in seven of the nine datasets ) , which proves the influence of preprocessing on the final results .
heading: Computed by averaging accuracy of two different runs .

text: It is perhaps not surprising that the lowest variance of results is seen in the datasets with the larger training data ( i.e. RTC and Stanford ) .
heading: Computed by averaging accuracy of two different runs .

text: This suggests that the preprocessing decisions are not so important when the training data is large enough , but they are indeed relevant in benchmarks where the training data is limited .
heading: Computed by averaging accuracy of two different runs .

text: As far as the individual preprocessing techniques are concerned , the vanilla setting ( tokenization only ) proves to be consistent across datasets and tasks , as it performs in the same ballpark as the best result in 8 of the 9 datasets for both models ( with no noticeable differences between topic categorization and polarity detection ) .
heading: Computed by averaging accuracy of two different runs .

text: The only topic categorization dataset in which tokenization does not seem enough is Ohsumed , which , unlike the more general nature of other categorization datasets ( news ) , belongs to a specialized domain ( medical ) for which fine - grained distinctions are required to classify cardiovascular diseases .
heading: Computed by averaging accuracy of two different runs .

text: In particular for this dataset , word embeddings trained on a general - domain corpus like UMBC may not accurately capture the specialized meaning of medical terms and hence , sparsity becomes an issue .
heading: Computed by averaging accuracy of two different runs .

text: In fact , lowercasing and lemmatizing , which are mainly aimed at reducing sparsity , outperform the vanilla setting by over six points in the CNN + LSTM setting and clearly outperform the other preprocessing techniques on the single CNN model as well .
heading: Computed by averaging accuracy of two different runs .

text: Experiment 1 : Preprocessing effect
Nevertheless , the use of more complex preprocessing techniques such as lemmatization and multiword grouping does not help in general .
heading: Experiment 1 : Preprocessing effect

text: Even though lemmatization has proved useful in conventional linear models as an effective way to deal with sparsity , neural network architectures seem to be more capable of overcoming sparsity thanks to the generalization power of word embeddings .
heading: Experiment 1 : Preprocessing effect

text: Experiment 2 : Cross-preprocessing
This experiment aims at studying the impact of using different word embeddings ( with differently preprocessed training corpora ) on tokenized datasets ( vanilla setting ) .
heading: Experiment 2 : Cross-preprocessing

text: shows the results for this experiment .
heading: Experiment 2 : Cross-preprocessing

text: In this experiment we observe a different trend , with multiwordenhanced vectors exhibiting a better performance both on the single CNN model ( best overall performance in seven of the nine datasets ) and on the CNN + LSTM model ( best performance in four datasets and in the same ballpark as the best results in four of the remaining five datasets ) .
heading: Experiment 2 : Cross-preprocessing

text: In this case the same set of words is learnt but single tokens inside multiword expressions are not trained .
heading: Experiment 2 : Cross-preprocessing

text: Instead , these single tokens are considered in isolation only , without the added noise when considered inside the multiword expression as well .
heading: Experiment 2 : Cross-preprocessing

text: For instance , the word Apple has a clearly different meaning in isolation from the one inside :
heading: Experiment 2 : Cross-preprocessing

text: Cross - preprocessing evaluation : accuracy on the topic categorization and polarity detection tasks using different sets of word embeddings to initialize the embedding layer of the two classifiers .
heading: Experiment 2 : Cross-preprocessing

text: All datasets were preprocessed similarly according to the vanilla setting .
heading: Experiment 2 : Cross-preprocessing

text: indicates results that are statistically significant with respect to the top result .
heading: Experiment 2 : Cross-preprocessing

text: the multiword expression Big Apple , hence it can be seen as beneficial not to train the word
heading: Experiment 2 : Cross-preprocessing

text: Apple when part of this multiword expression .

Interestingly , using multiword - wise embeddings on the vanilla setting leads to consistently better results than using them on the same multiwordgrouped preprocessed dataset in eight of the nine datasets .
heading: Apple when part of this multiword expression .

text: This could provide hints on the excellent results provided by pre-trained Word2vec embeddings trained on the Google News corpus , which learns multiwords similarly to our setting .
heading: Apple when part of this multiword expression .

text: Apart from this somewhat surprising finding , the use of the embeddings trained on a simple tokenized corpus ( i.e. vanilla ) proved again competitive , as different preprocessing techniques such as lowercasing and lemmatizing do not seem to help .
heading: Apple when part of this multiword expression .

text: In fact , the relatively weaker performance of lemmatization and lowercasing in this crossprocessing experiment is somehow expected as the coverage of word embeddings in vanilla - tokenized datasets is limited , e.g. , many entities which are capitalized in the datasets are not covered in the case of lowercasing , and inflected forms are missing in the case of lemmatizing .
heading: Apple when part of this multiword expression .

text: Conclusions
In this paper we analyzed the impact of simple text preprocessing decisions on the performance of a standard word - based neural text classifier .
heading: Conclusions

text: Our evaluations highlight the importance of being careful in the choice of how to preprocess our data and to be consistent when comparing different systems .
heading: Conclusions

text: In general , a simple tokenization works equally or better than more complex pre-processing techniques such as lemmatization or multiword grouping , except for domain - specific datasets ( such as the medical dataset in our experiments ) in which sole tokenization performs poorly .
heading: Conclusions

text: Additionally , word embeddings trained on multiword - grouped corpora perform surprisingly well when applied to simple tokenized datasets .
heading: Conclusions

text: This property has often been overlooked and , to the best of our knowledge , we test the hypothesis for the first time .
heading: Conclusions

text: In fact , this finding could partially explain the long - lasting success of pre-trained Word2vec embeddings , which specifically learn multiword embeddings as part of their pipeline .
heading: Conclusions

text: Moreover , our analysis shows that there is a high variance in the results depending on the preprocessing choice ( 2.4 % on average for the best performing model ) , especially when the training data is not large enough to generalize .
heading: Conclusions

text: Further analysis and experimentation would be required to fully understand the significance of these results ; but , this work can be viewed as a starting point for studying the impact of text preprocessing in deep learning models .
heading: Conclusions

text: We hope that our findings will encourage future researchers to carefully select and report these preprocessing decisions when evaluating or comparing different models .
heading: Conclusions

text: Finally , as future work , we plan to extend our analysis to other tasks ( e.g. question answering ) , languages ( particularly morphologically rich languages for which these results may vary ) and preprocessing techniques ( e.g. stopword removal or part - of - speech tagging ) .
heading: Conclusions

text: title
Learning Context - Sensitive Convolutional Filters for Text Processing
abstract
Convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ) have recently emerged as a popular building block for natural language processing ( NLP ) .
heading: abstract

text: Despite their success , most existing CNN models employed in NLP share the same learned ( and static ) set of filters for all input sentences .
heading: abstract

text: In this paper , we consider an approach of using a small meta network to learn contextsensitive convolutional filters for text processing .
heading: abstract

text: The role of meta network is to abstract the contextual information of a sentence or document into a set of input -aware filters .
heading: abstract

text: We further generalize this framework to model sentence pairs , where a bidirectional filter generation mechanism is introduced to encapsulate co-dependent sentence representations .
heading: abstract

text: In our benchmarks on four different tasks , including ontology classification , sentiment analysis , answer sentence selection , and paraphrase identification , our proposed model , a modified CNN with context - sensitive filters , consistently outperforms the standard CNN and attention - based CNN baselines .
heading: abstract

text: By visualizing the learned context - sensitive filters , we further validate and rationalize the effectiveness of proposed framework .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction

In the last few years , convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ) have demonstrated remarkable progress in various natural language processing applications , including sentence / document classification , text sequence matching , generic text representations , language modeling , machine translation and abstractive sentence summarization .
heading: Introduction

text: CNNs are typically applied to tasks where feature extrac-tion and a corresponding supervised task are approached jointly .
heading: Introduction

text: As an encoder network for text , CNNs typically convolve a set of filters , of window size n , with an inputsentence embedding matrix obtained via word2vec or Glove .
heading: Introduction

text: Different filter sizes n maybe used within the same model , exploiting meaningful semantic features from different n-gram fragments .
heading: Introduction

text: The learned weights of CNN filters , inmost cases , are assumed to be fixed regardless of the input text .
heading: Introduction

text: As a result , the rich contextual information inherent in natural language sequences may not be fully captured .
heading: Introduction

text: As demonstrated in , the context of a word tends to greatly influence its contribution to the final supervised tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: This observation is consistent with the following intuition : when reading different types of documents , e.g. , academic papers or newspaper articles , people tend to adopt distinct strategies for better and more effective understanding , leveraging the fact that the same words or phrases may have different meaning or imply different things , depending on context .
heading: Introduction

text: Several research efforts have sought to incorporate contextual information into CNNs to adaptively extract text representations .
heading: Introduction

text: One common strategy is the attention mechanism , which is typically employed on top of a CNN ( or Long Short - Term Memory ( LSTM ) ) layer to guide the extraction of semantic features .
heading: Introduction

text: For the embedding of a single sentence , proposed a selfattentive model that attends to different parts of a sentence and combines them into multiple vector representations .
heading: Introduction

text: However , their model needs considerably more parameters to achieve performance gains over traditional CNNs .
heading: Introduction

text: To match sentence pairs , introduced an attentionbased CNN model , which re-weights the convolution inputs or outputs , to extract interdepen - dent sentence representations . ; explore a compare and aggregate framework to directly capture the wordby - word matching between two paired sentences .
heading: Introduction

text: However , these approaches suffer from the problem of high matching complexity , since a similarity matrix between pairwise words needs to be computed , and thus it is computationally inefficient or even prohibitive when applied to long sentences .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we propose a generic approach to learn context - sensitive convolutional filters for natural language understanding .
heading: Introduction

text: In contrast to traditional CNNs , the convolution operation in our framework does not have a fixed set of filters , and thus provides the network with stronger modeling flexibility and capacity .
heading: Introduction

text: Specifically , we introduce a meta network to generate a set of contextsensitive filters , conditioned on specific input sentences ; these filters are adaptively applied to either the same ( Section 3.2 ) or different ( Section 3.3 ) text sequences .
heading: Introduction

text: In this manner , the learned filters vary from sentence to sentence and allow for more fine - grained feature abstraction .
heading: Introduction

text: Moreover , since the generated filters in our framework can adapt to different conditional information available ( labels or paired sentences ) , they can be naturally generalized to model sentence pairs .
heading: Introduction

text: In this regard , we propose a novel bidirectional filter generation mechanism to allow interactions between sentence pairs while constructing context - sensitive representations .
heading: Introduction

text: We investigate the effectiveness of our Adaptive Context - sensitive CNN ( ACNN ) framework on several text processing tasks : ontology classification , sentiment analysis , answer sentence selection and paraphrase identification .
heading: Introduction

text: We show that the proposed methods consistently outperforms the standard CNN and attention - based CNN baselines .
heading: Introduction

text: Our work provides anew perspective on how to incorporate contextual information into text representations , which can be combined with more sophisticated structures to achieve even better performance in the future .
heading: Introduction

text: Related Work
Learning deep text representations has attracted much attention recently , since they can potentially benefit a wide range of NLP applications .
heading: Related Work

text: CNNs have been extensively investigated as the encoder networks of natural language .
heading: Related Work

text: Our work is inline with previous efforts on improving the adaptivity and flexibility of convolutional neural networks .
heading: Related Work

text: proposed to enhance the transformation modeling capacity of CNNs by adaptively learning the filter shapes through backpropagation .
heading: Related Work

text: De introduced an architecture to generate the future frames conditioned on given image ( s ) , by adapting the CNN filter weights to the motion within previous video frames .
heading: Related Work

text: Although CNNs have been widely adopted in a large number of NLP applications , improving the adaptivity of vanilla CNN modules has been considerably less studied .
heading: Related Work

text: To the best of our knowledge , the work reported in this paper is the first attempt to develop more flexible and adjustable CNN architecture for modeling sentences .
heading: Related Work

text: Our use of a meta network to generate parameters for another network is directly inspired by the recent success of hypernetworks for textgeneration tasks , and dynamic parameter - prediction for video - frame generation .
heading: Related Work

text: In contrast to these works that focus on generation problems , our model is based on context - sensitive CNN filters and is aimed at abstracting more informative and predictive sentence features .
heading: Related Work

text: Most similar to our work , designed a meta network to generate compositional functions over tree - structured neural networks for encapsulating sentence features .
heading: Related Work

text: However , their model is only suitable for encoding individual sentences , while our framework can be readily generalized to capture the interactions between sentence pairs .
heading: Related Work

text: Moreover , our framework is based on CNN models , which is advantageous due to fewer parameters and highly parallelizable computations relative to sequential - based models .
heading: Related Work

text: Model
Basic CNN for text representations
heading: Model

text: The CNN architectures in are typically utilized for extracting sentence representations , by a composition of a convolutional layer and a max - pooling operation overall resulting feature maps .
heading: Model

text: Let the words of a sentence of length T ( padded where necessary ) be x 1 , x 2 , ... , x T .
heading: Model

text: The sentence can be represented as a matrix X ?
heading: Model

text: R d T , where each column represents a d-dimensional embedding of the corresponding word .
heading: Model

text: In the convolutional layer , a set of filters with weights W ?
heading: Model

text: R Khd is convolved with every window of h words within the sentence , i.e. , {x 1:h , x 2:h+1 , . . . , x T ?h+1:T } , where K is the number of output feature maps ( and filters ) .
heading: Model

text: In this manner , feature maps p for these h-gram text fragments are generated as :
heading: Model

text: where i = 1 , 2 , ... , T ? h + 1 and denotes the convolution operator at the ith shift location .
heading: Model

text: Parameter b ?
heading: Model

text: R K is the bias term and f ( ) is a non-linear function , implemented as a rectified linear unit ( ReLU ) in our experiments .
heading: Model

text: The output feature maps of the convolutional layer , i.e. , p ? R K(T ?h+1 ) are then passed to the pooling layer , which takes the maximum value in every row of p , forming a K-dimensional vector , z.
heading: Model

text: This operation attempts to keep the most salient feature detected by every filter and discard the information from less fundamental text fragments .
heading: Model

text: Moreover , the max - over - time nature of the pooling operation guarantees that the size of the obtained representation is independent of the sentence length .
heading: Model

text: Note that in basic CNN sentence encoders , filter weights are the same for different inputs , which maybe suboptimal for feature extraction , especially in the case where conditional information is available .
heading: Model

text: Learning context - sensitive filters
heading: Model

text: The proposed architecture to learn contextsensitive filters is composed of two principal modules : ( i ) a filter generation module , which produces a set of filters conditioned on the input sentence ; and ( ii ) an adaptive convolution module , which applies the generated filters to an input sentence ( this sentence maybe either the same as or different from the first input , as discussed further in Section 3.3 ) .
heading: Model

text: The two modules are jointly differentiable , and the overall architecture can be trained in an end - to - end manner .
heading: Model

text: Since the generated filters are sample - specific , our ACNN feature extractor for text tends to have stronger predictive power than a basic CNN encoder .
heading: Model

text: The general ACNN framework is shown schematically in .
heading: Model

text: Convolution module
Context - aware Filters
heading: Convolution module

text: Filter generation module
heading: Convolution module

text: I 'll go back and try other dishes Filter generation module Instead of utilizing fixed filter weights W for different inputs ( as ( 1 ) ) , our model generates a set of filters conditioned on the input sentence X. Given an input X , the filter - generation module can be implemented , in principle , as any deep ( differentiable ) architecture .
heading: Convolution module

text: However , in order to handle input sentences of variable length common in natural language , we design a generic filter generation module to produce filters with a predefined size .
heading: Convolution module

text: First , the input X is encapsulated into a fixedlength vector ( code ) z with the dimension of l , via a basic CNN model , where one convolutional layer is employed along with the pooling operation ( as described in Section 3.1 ) .
heading: Convolution module

text: On top of this hidden representation z , a deconvolutional layer , which performs transposed operations of convolutions , is further applied to produce a unique set of filters for X ( as illustrated in ) :
heading: Convolution module

text: where ?
heading: Convolution module

text: e and ?
heading: Convolution module

text: dare the learned parameters in each layer of the filter - generating module , respectively .
heading: Convolution module

text: Specifically , we convolve z with a filter of size ( f s , l , k x , k y ) , where f sis the number of generated filters and the kernel size is ( k x , k y ) .
heading: Convolution module

text: The output will be a tensor of shape ( f s , k x , k y ) .
heading: Convolution module

text: Since the dimension of hidden representation z is independent of input - sentence length , this framework guarantees that the generated filters are of the same shape and size for every sentence .
heading: Convolution module

text: Intuitively , the encoding part of filter generation module abstracts the information from sentence X into z .
heading: Convolution module

text: Based on this representation , the deconvolutional up - sampling layer determines a set of fixedsize , fine - grained filters f for the specific input .
heading: Convolution module

text: Adaptive convolution module
heading: Convolution module

text: The adaptive convolution module takes as inputs the generated filters f and an input sentence .
heading: Convolution module

text: This sentence and the input to the filter - generation module maybe identical ( as in ) or different ( as in .
heading: Convolution module

text: With the sample - specific filters , the input sentence is adaptively encoded , again , via a basic CNN architecture as in Section 3.1 , i.e. , one convolutional and one pooling layer .
heading: Convolution module

text: Notably , there are no additional parameters in the adaptive convolution module ( no bias term is employed ) .
heading: Convolution module

text: Our ACNN framework can be seen as a generalization of the basic CNN , which can be represented as an ACNN by setting the outputs of the filter - generation module to a constant , regardless of the contextual information from input sentence ( s ) .
heading: Convolution module

text: Because of the learning - to - learn nature of the proposed ACNN framework , it tends to have greater representational power than the basic CNN .
heading: Convolution module

text: Extension to text sequence matching
heading: Convolution module

text: Considering the ability of our ACNN framework to generate context - sensitive filters , it can be naturally generalized to the task of text sequence matching .
heading: Convolution module

text: In this section , we will describe the proposed Adaptive Question Answering ( AdaQA ) model in the context of answer sentence selection task .
heading: Convolution module

text: Note that the corresponding model can be readily adapted to other sentence matching problems as well ( see Section 5.2 ) .
heading: Convolution module

text: Given a factual question q ( associated with a list of candidate answers {a 1 , a 2 , . . . , am } and their corresponding labels y = {y 1 , y 2 , . . . , y m } ) , the goal of the model is to identify the correct answers from the set of candidates .
heading: Convolution module

text: For i = 1 , 2 , . . . , m , if a i correctly answers q , then y i = 1 , and otherwise y i =
heading: Convolution module

text: 0 . Therefore , the task can be cast as a classification problem where , given an unlabeled question - answer pair ( q i , a i ) , we seek to predict the judgement y i .
heading: Convolution module

text: Conventionally , a question q and an answer a are independently encoded by two basic CNNs to fixed - length vector representations , denoted h q and ha , respectively .
heading: Convolution module

text: They are then directly employed to predict the judgement y .
heading: Convolution module

text: This strategy could be suboptimal , since no communication ( information sharing ) occurs between the questionanswer pair until the top prediction layer .
heading: Convolution module

text: The key idea is to abstract informa-tion from the answer ( or question ) that is pertinent to the corresponding question ( or answer ) .

text: Notably , we share the weights of filter generating networks for both the question and answer , so that the model adaptivity for answer selection can be improved without an excessive increase in the number of parameters .

text: Connections to attention mechanism
heading: Convolution module

text: The adaptive context - sensitive filter generation mechanism proposed here bears close resemblance to attention mechanism ) widely adopted in the NLP community , in the sense that both methods intend to incorporate rich contextual information into text representations .
heading: Convolution module

text: However , attention is typically operated on top of the hidden units preprocessed by CNN or LSTM layers , and assigns different weights to each unit according to a context vector .
heading: Convolution module

text: By contrast , in our context - sensitive filter generation mechanism , the contextual information is inherently encoded into the convolutional filters , which directly interact with the input sentence during the convolution encoding operation .
heading: Convolution module

text: Notably , according to our experiments , the proposed filter generation module can be readily combined with ( standard ) attention mechanisms to further enhance the modeling expressiveness of CNN encoder .
heading: Convolution module

text: Experimental Setup
Datasets
We investigate the effectiveness of the proposed ACNN framework on both document classification and text sequence matching tasks .
heading: Datasets

text: Specifically , we consider two large - scale document classification datasets :
heading: Datasets

text: Yelp Reviews Polarity , and DBPedia ontology datasets .
heading: Datasets

text: For Yelp reviews , we seek to predict a binary label ( positive or negative ) regarding one review about a restaurant .
heading: Datasets

text: DBpedia is extracted from Wikipedia by crowd - sourcing and is categorized into 14 non-overlapping ontology classes , including Company , Athlete , Natural Place , etc .
heading: Datasets

text: We sample 15 % of the training data as the validation set , to select hyperparameters for our models and perform early stopping .
heading: Datasets

text: For sentence matching , we evaluate the AdaQA model on two datasets for open - domain question answering : Wiki QA and SelQA .
heading: Datasets

text: Given a question , the task is to rank the corresponding candidate answers , which , in the case of WikiQA , are sentences extracted from the summary section of a related Wikipedia article .
heading: Datasets

text: To facilitate comparison with existing results , we truncate the candidate answers to a maximum length of 40 tokens for all experiments on the WikiQA dataset .
heading: Datasets

text: We also consider the task of paraphrase identification with the Quora Question Pairs dataset , with the same data splits as in .
heading: Datasets

text: A summary of all datasets is presented in .
heading: Datasets

text: Training Details
For the document classification experiments , we randomly initialize the word embeddings uniformly within [ ? 0.001 , 0.001 ] and update them during training .
heading: Training Details

text: For the generated filters , we set the window size as h = 5 , with K = 100 feature maps ( the dimension of z is set as 100 ) .
heading: Training Details

text: For direct comparison , we employ the same filter shape / size settings as in our basic CNN implementation .
heading: Training Details

text: A one - layer architec - ture is utilized for both the CNN baseline and the ACNN model , since we did not observe significant performance gains with a multilayer architecture .
heading: Training Details

text: The minibatch size is set as 128 , and a dropout rate of 0.2 is utilized on the embedding layer .
heading: Training Details

text: We observed that a larger dropout rate ( e.g. , 0.5 ) will hurt performance on document classifications and make training significantly slower .
heading: Training Details

text: For the sentence matching tasks , we initialized the word embeddings with 50 - dimensional Glove word vectors pretrained from Wikipedia 2014 and Gigaword 5 for all model variants .
heading: Training Details

text: As for the filters , we set the window size as h = 5 , with K = 300 feature maps .
heading: Training Details

text: As described in Section 3.3 , the vector t , output from the matching module , is fed to the prediction layer , implemented as a one - layer MLP followed by the sigmoid function .
heading: Training Details

text: We use Adam to train the models , with a learning rate of 3 10 ?4 .
heading: Training Details

text: Dropout , with a rate of 0.5 , is employed on the word embedding layer .
heading: Training Details

text: The hyperparameters are selected by choosing the best model on the validation set .
heading: Training Details

text: All models are implemented with TensorFlow and are trained using one NVIDIA GeForce GTX TITAN X GPU with 12 GB memory .
heading: Training Details

text: Baselines

For document classification , we consider several baseline models : ( i ) ngrams , a bag - of - means method based on TFIDF representations built by choosing the 500,000 most frequent n-grams ( up to 5 - grams ) from the training set and use their corresponding counts as features ; ( ii ) small / large word CNN : 6 layer word - based convolutional networks , with 256/1024 features at each layer , denoted as small / large , respectively ; ( iii ) deep CNN : deep convolutional neural networks with 9/17 /29 layers .
heading: Baselines

text: To evaluate the effectiveness of proposed AdaQA model , we compare it with several CNN - based sequence matching baselines , including Vanilla CNN , attentive pooling networks , and ABCNN ( where an attention mechanism is employed over the two sentence representations ) .
heading: Baselines

text: Evaluation Metrics
For document categorization and paraphrase identification tasks , we em - , are reported by , and are reported by .
heading: Evaluation Metrics

text: ploy the percentage of correct predictions on the test set to evaluate and compare different models .
heading: Evaluation Metrics

text: For the answer sentence selection task , mean average precision ( MAP ) and mean reciprocal rank ( MRR ) are utilized as the corresponding evaluation metrics .
heading: Evaluation Metrics

text: Experimental Results
Document Classification

To explicitly explore whether our ACNN model can leverage the input-aware filter weights for better sentence representation , we perform a comparison between the basic CNN and ACNN models with only a single filter , which are denoted as S - CNN , S - ACNN , respectively ( this setting may not yield best overall performance , since only a single filter is used , but it allows us to isolate the impact of adaptivity ) .
heading: Document Classification

text: As illustrated in , S - ACNN significantly outperforms S - CNN on both datasets , demonstrating the advantage of the filtergeneration module in our ACNN framework .
heading: Document Classification

text: As a result , with only one convolutional filter and thus very limited modeling capacity , our S - ACNN model tends to be much more expressive than the basic CNN model , due to the flexibility of applying different filters to different sentences .
heading: Document Classification

text: We further experiment on both ACNN and CNN models with multiple filters .
heading: Document Classification

text: The corresponding document categorization accuracies are presented in .
heading: Document Classification

text: Although we only use one convolution layer for our ACNN model , it already outperforms other CNN baseline methods with much deeper architectures .
heading: Document Classification

text: Moreover , our method exhibits higher accuracy than n-grams , which is a very strong baseline as shown in .
heading: Document Classification

text: We attribute the superior performance of the ACNN framework to its stronger ( adaptive ) feature - extraction ability .
heading: Document Classification

text: Moreover , our M - ACNN also achieves slightly better performance than self - attentive sentence embeddings proposed in , which requires significant more parameters than our method .
heading: Document Classification

text: Effect of number of filters
heading: Document Classification

text: To further demonstrate that the performance gains in document categorization experiments originates from the improved adaptivity of our ACNN framework , we implement the basic CNN model with different numbers of filter sizes , ranging from 1 to 1000 .
heading: Document Classification

text: As illustrated in ( a ) , when the filter size is larger than 100 , the test accuracy of the standard CNN model does not show any noticeable improvement with more filters .
heading: Document Classification

text: More importantly , even with a filter size of 1000 , the classification accuracy of the CNN is worse than that of the ACNN model with the filter number restricted to 100 .
heading: Document Classification

text: Given these observations , we believe that the boosted categorization accuracy does come from the improved flexibility and thus better feature extraction of our ACNN framework .
heading: Document Classification

text: Answer Sentence Selection

To elucidate the role of different parts ( modules ) in our AdaQA model , we implement several model variants for comparison : ( i ) a " vanilla " CNN model that independently encodes two sentence representations for matching ; ( ii ) a self - adaptive , and marked with are from .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: ACNN - based model where the question / answer sentence generates adaptive filters only to convolve with the input itself ; ( iii ) a one - way ACNN model where only the answer sentence representation is extracted with adaptive filters , which are generated conditioned on the question ; ( iv ) a two - way AdaQA model as described in Section 2.4 , where both sentences are adaptively encoded , with filters generated conditioned on the other sequence ; ( v ) considering that the proposed filter generation mechanism is complementary to the attention layer typically employed in sequence matching tasks ( see Section 3.4 ) , we experiment with another model variant that combines the proposed context - sensitive filter generation mechanism with the multi-perspective attention layer introduced in .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: show experimental results of our models on WikiQA and Se lQA datasets , along with other state - of - the - art methods .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: Note that the self - adaptive ACNN model variant , which generates filters only for the input itself ( without any interactions before the top matching module ) , slightly outperforms the vanilla CNN Siamese model .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: Combined with the results in document categorization experiments , we believe that our ACNN framework , in its simplest form , can be utilized as a powerful feature extractor for transforming natural language sentences into fixed - length vectors .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: More importantly , our two - way AdaQA model exhibits superior results compared with the one - way variant as well as other CNN - based baseline models on the WikiQA dataset .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: This observation indicates that the bidirectional filter gener - Model Accuracy Siamese - CNN 0.7960
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: Multi-Perspective-CNN 0 . 8138 AdaQA ( two-way ) 0.8516 AdaQA ( two-way ) + att. 0.8794 ation mechanism is strongly associated with the performance gains .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: While combined with the multi-perspective attention layers , adopted after the ACNN encoding layer , our two - way AdaQA model achieves even better performance .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: This suggests that the proposed strategy is complementary , in terms of the incorporation of rich contextual information , to the standard attention mechanism .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: The same trend is also observed on the SelQA dataset ( as shown in ) , which is a much larger dataset than Wiki QA .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: Notably , our model yields significantly better results than an attentive pooling network and ABCNN ( attention - based CNN ) baselines .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: We attribute the improvement to two potential advantages of our AdaQA model : ( i ) for the two previous baseline methods , the interaction between question and answer takes place either before or after convolution .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: However , in our AdaQA model , the communication between two sentences is inherent in the convolution operation , and thus can provide the abstracted features with more flexibility ; ( ii ) the bidirectional filter generation mechanism in our AdaQA model generates co-dependent representations for the question and candidate answer , which could enable the model to recover from initial local maxima corresponding to incorrect predictions .
heading: Answer Sentence Selection

text: Paragraph Identification

Considering that the proposed AdaQA model can be readily generalized to other text sequence matching problems , we further evaluate the proposed framework on the paraphrase identification task with the Quora question pairs dataset .
heading: Paragraph Identification

text: To ensure a fair comparison , we employ the same data splits as in .
heading: Paragraph Identification

text: As illustrated in , our twoway AdaQA model again exhibits superior performances compared with basic CNN models ( as reported in ) .
heading: Paragraph Identification

text: Discussion
Reasoning ability

To associate the improved answer sentence selection results with the reasoning capabilities of our AdaQA model , we further categorize the questions in the WikiQA test set into 5 types containing : ' What ' , ' Where ' , ' How ' , ' When ' or ' Who ' .
heading: Reasoning ability

text: We then calculate the MAP scores of the basic CNN and our AdaQA model on different question types .
heading: Reasoning ability

text: Similar to the findings in , we observe that the ' How ' question is the hardest to answer , with the lowest MAP scores .
heading: Reasoning ability

text: However , our AdaQA model improves most over the basic CNN on the ' How ' type question , see ( b ) .
heading: Reasoning ability

text: Further comparing our results with NASM in , our AdaQA model ( with a MAP score of 0.579 ) outperforms their reported ' How ' question MAP scores ( 0.524 ) by a large margin , indicating that the adaptive convolutional filter - generation mechanism improves the model 's ability to read and reason over natural language sentences .
heading: Reasoning ability

text: Filter visualization
To better understand what information has been encoded into our contextsensitive filters , we visualize one of the filters for sentences within the test set ( on the DBpedia dataset ) with t- SNE .
heading: Filter visualization

text: The corresponding results are shown in ( c ) .
heading: Filter visualization

text: It can be observed that the filters for documents with the same label ( ontology ) are grouped into clusters , indicating that for different types of document , ACNN has leveraged distinct convolutional filters for better feature extraction .
heading: Filter visualization

text: We presented a context - sensitive convolutional filter - generation mechanism , introducing a meta network to adaptively produce a set of input -aware filters .
heading: Filter visualization

text: In this manner , the filter weights vary from sample to sample , providing the CNN encoder network with more modeling flexibility and capacity .
heading: Filter visualization

text: This framework is further generalized to model question - answer sentence pairs , leveraging a twoway feature abstraction process .
heading: Filter visualization

text: We evaluate our models on several document - categorization and sentence matching benchmarks , and they consistently outperform the standard CNN and attentionbased CNN baselines , demonstrating the effectiveness of our framework .
heading: Filter visualization

text: title
Universal Language Model Fine - tuning for Text Classification
heading: title

text: abstract
Inductive transfer learning has greatly impacted computer vision , but existing approaches in NLP still require task - specific modifications and training from scratch .
heading: abstract

text: We propose Universal Language Model Fine - tuning ( ULMFiT ) , an effective transfer learning method that can be applied to any task in NLP , and introduce techniques that are key for fine - tuning a language model .
heading: abstract

text: Our method significantly outperforms the state - of - the - art on six text classification tasks , reducing the error by 18 - 24 % on the majority of datasets .
heading: abstract

text: Furthermore , with only 100 labeled examples , it matches the performance of training from scratch on 100 more data .
heading: abstract

text: We opensource our pretrained models and code 1 .
Introduction
Inductive transfer learning has had a large impact on computer vision ( CV ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Applied CV models ( including object detection , classification , and segmentation ) are rarely trained from scratch , but instead are fine - tuned from models that have been pretrained on ImageNet , MS - COCO , and other datasets .
heading: Introduction

text: Text classification is a category of Natural Language Processing ( NLP ) tasks with real - world applications such as spam , fraud , and bot detection , emergency response , and commercial document classification , such as for legal discovery .
heading: Introduction

text: 1 http://nlp.fast.ai/ulmfit.
heading: Introduction

text: Equal contribution .
Jeremy focused on the algorithm development and implementation , Sebastian focused on the experiments and writing .
heading: Equal contribution .

text: While Deep Learning models have achieved state - of - the - art on many NLP tasks , these models are trained from scratch , requiring large datasets , and days to converge .
heading: Equal contribution .

text: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

For inductive transfer , fine - tuning pretrained word embeddings , a simple transfer technique that only targets a model 's first layer , has had a large impact in practice and is used inmost state - of - the - art models .
heading: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

text: Recent approaches that concatenate embeddings derived from other tasks with the input at different layers ) still train the main task model from scratch and treat pretrained embeddings as fixed parameters , limiting their usefulness .
heading: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

text: In light of the benefits of pretraining , we should be able to do better than randomly initializing the remaining parameters of our models .
heading: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

text: However , inductive transfer via finetuning has been unsuccessful for NLP .
heading: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

text: first proposed finetuning a language model ( LM ) but require millions of in - domain documents to achieve good performance , which severely limits its applicability .
heading: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

text: We show that not the idea of LM fine - tuning but our lack of knowledge of how to train them effectively has been hindering wider adoption .
heading: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

text: LMs overfit to small datasets and suffered catastrophic forgetting when fine - tuned with a classifier .
heading: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

text: Compared to CV , NLP models are typically more shallow and thus require different fine - tuning methods .
heading: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

text: We propose anew method , Universal Language Model Fine - tuning ( ULMFiT ) that addresses these issues and enables robust inductive transfer learning for any NLP task , akin to fine - tuning Image Net models :
heading: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

text: The same 3 - layer LSTM architecturewith the same hyperparameters and no additions other than tuned dropout hyperparametersoutperforms highly engineered models and trans - fer learning approaches on six widely studied text classification tasks .
heading: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

text: On IMDb , with 100 labeled examples , ULMFiT matches the performance of training from scratch with 10 and - given 50 k unlabeled examples - with 100 more data .
heading: Research in NLP focused mostly on transductive transfer .

text: Contributions
Our contributions are the following :
heading: Contributions

text: 1 ) We propose Universal Language Model Fine - tuning ( ULMFiT ) , a method that can be used to achieve CV - like transfer learning for any task for NLP .
heading: Contributions

text: 2 ) We propose discriminative fine - tuning , slanted triangular learning rates , and gradual unfreezing , novel techniques to retain previous knowledge and avoid catastrophic forgetting during fine - tuning .
heading: Contributions

text: 3 ) We significantly outperform the state - of - the - art on six representative text classification datasets , with an error reduction of 18 - 24 % on the majority of datasets .
heading: Contributions

text: 4 ) We show that our method enables extremely sample - efficient transfer learning and perform an extensive ablation analysis .
heading: Contributions

text: 5 ) We make the pretrained models and our code available to enable wider adoption .
heading: Contributions

text: Related work
Transfer learning in CV Features in deep neural networks in CV have been observed to transition from general to task - specific from the first to the last layer .
heading: Related work

text: For this reason , most work in CV focuses on transferring the first layers of the model .
heading: Related work

text: Sharif achieve state - of - theart results using features of an Image Net model as input to a simple classifier .
heading: Related work

text: In recent years , this approach has been superseded by fine - tuning either the last or several of the last layers of a pretrained model and leaving the remaining layers frozen .
heading: Related work

text: Hypercolumns
In NLP , only recently have methods been proposed that go beyond transferring word embeddings .
heading: Hypercolumns

text: The prevailing approach is to pretrain embeddings that capture additional context via other tasks .
heading: Hypercolumns

text: Embeddings at different levels are then used as features , concatenated either with the word embeddings or with the inputs at intermediate layers .
heading: Hypercolumns

text: This method is known as hypercolumns in CV 2 and is used by , who use language modeling , paraphrasing , entailment , and Machine Translation ( MT ) respectively for pretraining .
heading: Hypercolumns

text: require engineered custom architectures , while we show state - of - the - art performance with the same basic architecture across a range of tasks .
heading: Hypercolumns

text: In CV , hypercolumns have been nearly entirely superseded by end - to - end fine - tuning .
heading: Hypercolumns

text: Multi - task learning
A related direction is multi-task learning ( MTL ) .
heading: Multi - task learning

text: This is the approach taken by and who add a language modeling objective to the model that is trained jointly with the main task model .
heading: Multi - task learning

text: MTL requires the tasks to be trained from scratch every time , which makes it inefficient and often requires careful weighting of the taskspecific objective functions .
heading: Multi - task learning

text: Fine - tuning

Fine- tuning has been used successfully to transfer between similar tasks , e.g. in QA , for distantly supervised sentiment analysis , or MT domains but has been shown to fail between unrelated ones .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: also fine - tune a language model , but overfit with 10 k labeled examples and require millions of in - domain documents for good performance .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: In contrast , ULMFiT leverages general - domain pretraining and novel finetuning techniques to prevent overfitting even with only 100 labeled examples and achieves state - of the - art results also on small datasets .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: Universal Language Model Fine- tuning
heading: Fine - tuning

text: We are interested in the most general inductive transfer learning setting for NLP ( Pan and Yang , 2010 ) :
heading: Fine - tuning

text: Given a static source task T Sand any target task T T with T S = T T , we would like to improve performance on T T .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: Language modeling can be seen as the ideal source task and a counterpart of ImageNet for NLP :
heading: Fine - tuning

text: It captures many facets of language relevant for downstream tasks , such as long - term dependencies , hierarchical relations , and sentiment .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: In contrast to tasks like and entailment , it provides data in near- unlimited quantities for most domains and languages .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: Additionally , a pretrained LM can be easily adapted to the idiosyncrasies of a target
heading: Fine - tuning

text: The full LM is fine - tuned on target task data using discriminative fine - tuning ( ' Discr ' ) and slanted triangular learning rates ( STLR ) to learn task - specific features .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: c)
heading: Fine - tuning

text: The classifier is fine - tuned on the target task using gradual unfreezing , ' Discr ' , and STLR to preserve low - level representations and adapt high - level ones ( shaded : unfreezing stages ; black : frozen ) .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: task , which we show significantly improves performance ( see Section 5 ) .
heading: Fine - tuning
