text: Moreover , language modeling already is a key component of existing tasks such as MT and dialogue modeling .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: Formally , language modeling induces a hypothesis space H that should be useful for many other NLP tasks .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: We propose Universal Language Model Finetuning ( ULMFiT ) , which pretrains a language model ( LM ) on a large general - domain corpus and fine - tunes it on the target task using novel techniques .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: The method is universal in the sense that it meets these practical criteria :
heading: Fine - tuning

text: 1 ) It works across tasks varying in document size , number , and label type ; 2 ) it uses a single architecture and training process ; 3 ) it requires no custom feature engineering or preprocessing ; and 4 ) it does not require additional in - domain documents or labels .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: In our experiments , we use the state - of - theart language model AWD - LSTM , a regular LSTM ( with no attention , short - cut connections , or other sophisticated additions ) with various tuned dropout hyperparameters .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: Analogous to CV , we expect that downstream performance can be improved by using higherperformance language models in the future .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: ULMFiT consists of the following steps , which we show in : a) General - domain LM pretraining ( 3.1 ) ; b ) target task LM fine - tuning ( 3.2 ) ; and c ) target task classifier fine - tuning ( 3.3 ) .
heading: Fine - tuning

text: We discuss these in the following sections .
General - domain LM pretraining
An Image Net - like corpus for language should be large and capture general properties of language .
heading: General - domain LM pretraining

text: We pretrain the language model on Wikitext - 103 consisting of 28,595 preprocessed Wikipedia articles and 103 million words .
heading: General - domain LM pretraining

text: Pretraining is most beneficial for tasks with small datasets and enables generalization even with 100 labeled examples .
heading: General - domain LM pretraining

text: We leave the exploration of more diverse pretraining corpora to future work , but expect that they would boost performance .
heading: General - domain LM pretraining

text: While this stage is the most expensive , it only needs to be performed once and improves performance and convergence of downstream models .
heading: General - domain LM pretraining

text: Target task LM fine - tuning
No matter how diverse the general - domain data used for pretraining is , the data of the target task will likely come from a different distribution .
heading: Target task LM fine - tuning

text: We thus fine - tune the LM on data of the target task .
heading: Target task LM fine - tuning

text: Given a pretrained general - domain LM , this stage converges faster as it only needs to adapt to the idiosyncrasies of the target data , and it allows us to train a robust LM even for small datasets .
heading: Target task LM fine - tuning

text: We propose discriminative fine - tuning and slanted triangular learning rates for fine - tuning the LM , which we introduce in the following .
heading: Target task LM fine - tuning

text: Discriminative fine - tuning
As different layers capture different types of information , they should be fine - tuned to different extents .
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: To this end , we propose a novel fine - tuning method , discriminative fine - tuning 3 .
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: Instead of using the same learning rate for all layers of the model , discriminative fine - tuning allows us to tune each layer with different learning rates .
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: For context , the regular stochastic gradient descent ( SGD ) update of a model 's parameters ?
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: at time step t looks like the following :
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: where ?
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: is the learning rate and ? ?
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: J ( ? ) is the gradient with regard to the model 's objective function .
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: For discriminative fine - tuning , we split the parameters ? into {?
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: L } where ?
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: l contains the parameters of the model at the l - th layer and L is the number of layers of the model .
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: Similarly , we obtain {? 1 , . . . , ?
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: L } where ?
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: l is the learning rate of the l - th layer .
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: The SGD update with discriminative finetuning is then the following :
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: We empirically found it to work well to first choose the learning rate ?
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: L of the last layer by fine - tuning only the last layer and using ?
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: l?1 = ? l / 2.6 as the learning rate for lower layers .
heading: Discriminative fine - tuning

text: Slanted triangular learning rates

For adapting its parameters to task - specific features , we would like the model to quickly converge to a suitable region of the parameter space in the beginning of training and then refine its parameters .
heading: Slanted triangular learning rates

text: Using the same learning rate ( LR ) or an annealed learning rate throughout training is not the best way to achieve this behaviour .
heading: Slanted triangular learning rates

text: Instead , we propose slanted triangular learning rates ( STLR ) , which first linearly increases the learning rate and then linearly decays it according to the following update schedule , which can be seen in :
heading: Slanted triangular learning rates

text: where T is the number of training iterations 4 , cut f rac is the fraction of iterations we increase 3 An unrelated method of the same name exists for deep Boltzmann machines
heading: Slanted triangular learning rates

text: In other words , the number of epochs times the number of updates per epoch .
heading: Slanted triangular learning rates

text: the LR , cut is the iteration when we switch from increasing to decreasing the LR , p is the fraction of the number of iterations we have increased or will decrease the LR respectively , ratio specifies how much smaller the lowest LR is from the maximum LR ? max , and ?
heading: Slanted triangular learning rates

text: t is the learning rate at iteration t.
heading: Slanted triangular learning rates

text: We generally use cut f rac = 0.1 , ratio = 32 and ? max = 0.01 .
heading: Slanted triangular learning rates

text: STLR modifies triangular learning rates ( Smith , 2017 ) with a short increase and along decay period , which we found key for good performance .
heading: Slanted triangular learning rates

text: In Section 5 , we compare against aggressive cosine annealing , a similar schedule that has recently been used to achieve state - of - the - art performance in CV .
heading: Slanted triangular learning rates

text: 6 : The slanted triangular learning rate schedule used for ULMFiT as a function of the number of training iterations .
heading: Slanted triangular learning rates

text: Target task classifier fine - tuning
Finally , for fine - tuning the classifier , we augment the pretrained language model with two additional linear blocks .
heading: Target task classifier fine - tuning

text: Following standard practice for CV classifiers , each block uses batch normalization and dropout , with ReLU activations for the intermediate layer and a softmax activation that outputs a probability distribution over target classes at the last layer .
heading: Target task classifier fine - tuning

text: Note that the parameters in these task - specific classifier layers are the only ones that are learned from scratch .
heading: Target task classifier fine - tuning

text: The first linear layer takes as the input the pooled last hidden layer states .
heading: Target task classifier fine - tuning

text: Concat pooling
The signal in text classification tasks is often contained in a few words , which may occur anywhere in the document .
heading: Concat pooling

text: As input documents can consist of hundreds of words , information may get lost if we only consider the last hidden state of the model .
heading: Concat pooling

text: For this reason , we concatenate the hidden state at the last time step h T of the document with both the max - pooled and the mean - pooled representation of the hidden states over as many time steps as fit in GPU memory H = {h 1 , . . . , h T }:
heading: Concat pooling

text: where [ ] is concatenation .
heading: Concat pooling

text: Fine - tuning the target classifier is the most critical part of the transfer learning method .
heading: Concat pooling

text: Overly aggressive fine - tuning will cause catastrophic forgetting , eliminating the benefit of the information captured through language modeling ; too cautious fine - tuning will lead to slow convergence ( and resultant overfitting ) .
heading: Concat pooling

text: Besides discriminative finetuning and triangular learning rates , we propose gradual unfreezing for fine - tuning the classifier .
heading: Concat pooling

text: Gradual unfreezing

Rather than fine - tuning all layers at once , which risks catastrophic forgetting , we propose to gradually unfreeze the model starting from the last layer as this contains the least general knowledge :
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: We first unfreeze the last layer and fine - tune all unfrozen layers for one epoch .
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: We then unfreeze the next lower frozen layer and repeat , until we finetune all layers until convergence at the last iteration .
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: This is similar to ' chain - thaw ' , except that we add a layer at a time to the set of ' thawed ' layers , rather than only training a single layer at a time .
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: While discriminative fine - tuning , slanted triangular learning rates , and gradual unfreezing all are beneficial on their own , we show in Section 5 that they complement each other and enable our method to perform well across diverse datasets .
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: BPTT for Text Classification ( BPT3C )
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: Language models are trained with backpropagation through time ( BPTT ) to enable gradient propagation for large input sequences .
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: In order to make fine - tuning a classifier for large documents feasible , we propose BPTT for Text Classification ( BPT3C ) :
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: We divide the document into fixedlength batches of size b.
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: At the beginning of each batch , the model is initialized with the final state of the previous batch ; we keep track of the hidden states for mean and max - pooling ; gradients are back - propagated to the batches whose hidden states contributed to the final prediction .
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: In practice , we use variable length backpropagation sequences .
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: Bidirectional language model Similar to existing work ( Peters et al. , 2017 , 2018 ) , we are not limited to fine - tuning a unidirectional language model .
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: For all our experiments , we pretrain both a forward and a backward LM .
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: We fine - tune a classifier for each LM independently using BPT3C and average the classifier predictions .
heading: Gradual unfreezing

text: Experiments
While our approach is equally applicable to sequence labeling tasks , we focus on text classification tasks in this work due to their important realworld applications .
heading: Experiments

text: Experimental setup
Datasets and tasks

We evaluate our method on six widely - studied datasets , with varying numbers of documents and varying document length , used by state - of - the - art text classification and transfer learning approaches as instances of three common text classification tasks : sentiment analysis , question classification , and topic classification .
heading: Datasets and tasks

text: We show the statistics for each dataset and task in .
heading: Datasets and tasks

text: TBCNN 4.0 Virtual 5.9 LSTM- CNN 3.9 ULMFiT ( ours ) 4.6 ULMFiT ( ours ) 3.6 : Test error rates ( % ) on text classification datasets used by .
heading: Datasets and tasks

text: Topic classification
For topic classification , we evaluate on the large - scale AG news and DBpedia ontology datasets created by .
heading: Topic classification

text: Pre-processing
We use the same pre-processing as in earlier work .
heading: Pre-processing

text: In addition , to allow the language model to capture aspects that might be relevant for classification , we add special tokens for upper-case words , elongation , and repetition .
heading: Pre-processing

text: Hyperparameters
We are interested in a model that performs robustly across a diverse set of tasks .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: To this end , if not mentioned otherwise , we use the same set of hyperparameters across tasks , which we tune on the IMDb validation set .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: We use the AWD - LSTM language model with an embedding size of 400 , 3 layers , 1150 hidden activations per layer , and a BPTT batch size of 70 .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: We apply dropout of 0.4 to layers , 0.3 to RNN layers , 0.4 to input embedding layers , 0.05 to embedding layers , and weight dropout of 0.5 to the RNN hidden - to - hidden matrix .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: The classifier has a hidden layer of size 50 .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: We use Adam with ? 1 = 0.7 instead of the default ? 1 = 0.9 and ? 2 = 0.99 , similar to .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: We use a batch size of 64 , abase learning rate of 0.004 and 0.01 for finetuning the LM and the classifier respectively , and tune the number of epochs on the validation set of each task 7 .
heading: Hyperparameters

text: We otherwise use the same practices used in .
Baselines and comparison models
For each task , we compare against the current state - of - theart .
heading: Baselines and comparison models

text: For the IMDb and TREC - 6 datasets , we compare against CoVe , a stateof - the - art transfer learning method for NLP .
heading: Baselines and comparison models

text: For the AG , Yelp , and DBpedia datasets , we compare against the state - of - the - art text categorization method by .
heading: Baselines and comparison models

text: Results
For consistency , we report all results as error rates ( lower is better ) .
heading: Results

text: We show the test error rates on the IMDb and TREC - 6 datasets used by in .
heading: Results

text: Our method outperforms both CoVe , a state - of - the - art transfer learning method based on hypercolumns , as well as the state - of - the - art on both datasets .
heading: Results

text: On IMDb , we reduce the error dramatically by 43.9 % and 22 % with regard to CoVe and the state - of - the - art respectively .
heading: Results

text: This is promising as the existing stateof - the - art requires complex architectures , multiple forms of attention and sophisticated embedding schemes , while our method employs a regular LSTM with dropout .
heading: Results

text: We note that the language model fine - tuning approach of only achieves an error of 7.64 vs. 4.6 for our method on IMDb , demonstrating the benefit of transferring knowledge from a large Image Net - like corpus using our fine - tuning techniques .
heading: Results

text: IMDb in particular is reflective of realworld datasets :
heading: Results

text: It s documents are generally a few paragraphs long - similar to emails ( e.g for legal discovery ) and online comments ( e.g for community management ) ; and sentiment analysis is similar to many commercial applications , e.g. product response tracking and support email routing .
heading: Results

text: On TREC - 6 , our improvement - similar as the improvements of state - of - the - art approaches - is not statistically significant , due to the small size of the 500 - examples test set .
heading: Results

text: Nevertheless , the competitive performance on TREC - 6 demonstrates that our model performs well across different dataset sizes and can deal with examples that range from single sentences - in the case of TREC - 6to several paragraphs for IMDb .
heading: Results

text: Note that despite pretraining on more than two orders of magnitude less data than the 7 million sentence pairs used by , we consistently outperform their approach on both datasets .
heading: Results

text: We show the test error rates on the larger AG , DBpedia , Yelp - bi , and Yelp - full datasets in .
heading: Results

text: Our method again outperforms the state - of the - art significantly .
heading: Results

text: On AG , we observe a similarly dramatic error reduction by 23.7 % compared to the state - of - the - art .
heading: Results

text: On DBpedia , Yelp - bi , and Yelp - full , we reduce the error by 4.8 % , 18.2 % , 2.0 % respectively .
heading: Results

text: Analysis
In order to assess the impact of each contribution , we perform a series of analyses and ablations .
heading: Analysis

text: We run experiments on three corpora , IMDb , TREC - 6 , and AG that are representative of different tasks , genres , and sizes .
heading: Analysis

text: For all experiments , we split off 10 % of the training set and report error rates on this validation set with unidirectional LMs .
heading: Analysis

text: We fine - tune the classifier for 50 epochs and train all methods but ULMFiT with early stopping .
heading: Analysis

text: Low - shot learning
One of the main benefits of transfer learning is being able to train a model for
heading: Low - shot learning

text: Pretraining
IMDb TREC - 6 AG Without pretraining 5.63 10.67 5.52 With pretraining 5.00 5.69 5.38 : Validation error rates for ULMFiT with and without pretraining .
heading: Pretraining

text: a task with a small number of labels .
heading: Pretraining

text: We evaluate ULMFiT on different numbers of labeled examples in two settings : only labeled examples are used for LM fine - tuning ( 'supervised ' ) ; and all task data is available and can be used to fine - tune the LM ( ' semi-supervised ' ) .
heading: Pretraining

text: We compare ULM - FiT to training from scratch - which is necessary for hypercolumn - based approaches .
heading: Pretraining

text: We split off balanced fractions of the training data , keep the validation set fixed , and use the same hyperparameters as before .
heading: Pretraining

text: We show the results in .

On IMDb and AG , supervised ULMFiT with only 100 labeled examples matches the performance of training from scratch with 10 and 20 more data respectively , clearly demonstrating the benefit of general - domain LM pretraining .
heading: We show the results in .

text: If we allow ULMFiT to also utilize unlabeled examples ( 50 k for IMDb , 100 k for AG ) , at 100 labeled examples , we match the performance of training from scratch with 50 and 100 more data on AG and IMDb respectively .
heading: We show the results in .

text: On TREC - 6 , ULMFiT significantly improves upon training from scratch ; as examples are shorter and fewer , supervised and semi-supervised ULMFiT achieve similar results .
heading: We show the results in .

text: Impact of pretraining
We compare using no pretraining with pretraining on WikiText - 103 in .
heading: Impact of pretraining

text: Pretraining is most useful for small and medium - sized datasets , which are most common in commercial applications .
heading: Impact of pretraining

text: However , even for large datasets , pretraining improves performance .
heading: Impact of pretraining

text: Impact of LM quality
In order to gauge the importance of choosing an appropriate LM , we compare a vanilla LM with the same hyperparameters without any dropout 8 with the AWD - LSTM LM with tuned dropout parameters in .
heading: Impact of LM quality

text: Using our fine - tuning techniques , even a regular LM reaches surprisingly good performance on the larger datasets .
heading: Impact of LM quality

text: On the smaller TREC - 6 , a vanilla LM without dropout runs the risk of overfitting , which decreases performance .
heading: Impact of LM quality

text: Impact of LM fine - tuning

We compare no finetuning against fine - tuning the full model ( ' Full ' ) , the most commonly used fine - tuning method , with and without discriminative fine - tuning ( ' Discr ' ) and slanted triangular learning rates ( ' Stlr ' ) in .
heading: Impact of LM fine - tuning

text: Fine - tuning the LM is most beneficial for larger datasets .
heading: Impact of LM fine - tuning

text: ' Discr ' and ' Stlr ' improve performance across all three datasets and are necessary on the smaller TREC - 6 , where regular fine - tuning is not beneficial .
heading: Impact of LM fine - tuning

text: Impact of classifier fine - tuning
We compare training from scratch , fine - tuning the full model ( ' Full ' ) , only fine - tuning the last layer ( ' Last ' ) , ' Chain - thaw ' , and gradual unfreezing ( ' Freez ' ) .
heading: Impact of classifier fine - tuning

text: We furthermore assess the importance of discriminative fine - tuning ( ' Discr ' ) and slanted triangular learning rates ( ' Stlr ' ) .
heading: Impact of classifier fine - tuning

text: We compare the latter to an alternative , aggressive cosine annealing schedule ( ' Cos ' ) .
heading: Impact of classifier fine - tuning

text: We use a learning rate ? L = 0.01 for ' Discr ' , learning rates
heading: Impact of classifier fine - tuning

text: To avoid overfitting , we only train the vanilla LM classifier for 5 epochs and keep dropout of 0.4 in the classifier . of 0.001 and 0.0001 for the last and all other layers respectively for ' Chain - thaw ' as in , and a learning rate of 0.001 otherwise .
heading: Impact of classifier fine - tuning

text: We show the results in .

Fine - tuning the classifier significantly improves over training from scratch , particularly on the small TREC - 6 . ' Last ' , the standard fine - tuning method in CV , severely underfits and is never able to lower the training error to 0 . ' Chainthaw ' achieves competitive performance on the smaller datasets , but is outperformed significantly on the large AG .
heading: We show the results in .

text: ' Freez ' provides similar performance as ' Full ' .
heading: We show the results in .

text: ' Discr ' consistently boosts the performance of ' Full ' and ' Freez ' , except for the large AG .
heading: We show the results in .

text: Cosine annealing is competitive with slanted triangular learning rates on large data , but under-performs on smaller datasets .
heading: We show the results in .

text: Finally , full ULMFiT classifier fine - tuning ( bottom row ) achieves the best performance on IMDB and TREC - 6 and competitive performance on AG .
heading: We show the results in .

text: Importantly , ULMFiT is the only method that shows excellent performance across the board - and is therefore the only universal method .
heading: We show the results in .

text: Classifier fine - tuning behavior

While our results demonstrate that how we fine - tune the classifier makes a significant difference , fine - tuning for inductive transfer is currently under-explored in NLP as it mostly has been thought to be unhelpful .
heading: Classifier fine - tuning behavior

text: To better understand the fine - tuning behavior of our model , we compare the validation error of the classifier fine - tuned with ULMFiT and ' Full ' during training in .
heading: Classifier fine - tuning behavior

text: On all datasets , fine - tuning the full model leads to the lowest error comparatively early in training , e.g. already after the first epoch on IMDb .
heading: Classifier fine - tuning behavior

text: The error then increases as the model starts to overfit and knowledge captured through pretraining is lost .
heading: Classifier fine - tuning behavior

text: In contrast , ULMFiT is more stable and suffers from no such catastrophic forgetting ; performance remains similar or improves until late epochs , which shows the positive effect of the learning rate schedule .
heading: Classifier fine - tuning behavior

text: Impact of bidirectionality
At the cost of training a second model , ensembling the predictions of a forward and backwards LM - classifier brings a performance boost of around 0.5 - 0.7 .
heading: Impact of bidirectionality

text: On IMD b we lower the test error from 5.30 of a single model to 4.58 for the bidirectional model .
heading: Impact of bidirectionality

text: Discussion and future directions

While we have shown that ULMFiT can achieve state - of - the - art performance on widely used text classification tasks , we believe that language model fine - tuning will be particularly useful in the following settings compared to existing transfer learning approaches : a) NLP for non-English languages , where training data for supervised pretraining tasks is scarce ; b ) new NLP tasks where no state - of - the - art architecture exists ; and c) tasks with limited amounts of labeled data ( and some amounts of unlabeled data ) .
heading: Discussion and future directions

text: Given that transfer learning and particularly fine - tuning for NLP is under - explored , many future directions are possible .
heading: Discussion and future directions

text: One possible direction is to improve language model pretraining and fine - tuning and make them more scalable : for Image Net , predicting far fewer classes only incurs a small performance drop , while recent work shows that an alignment between source and target task label sets is important ) - focusing on predicting a subset of words such as the most frequent ones might retain most of the performance while speeding up training .
heading: Discussion and future directions

text: Language modeling can also be augmented with additional tasks in a multi-task learning fashion or enriched with additional supervision , e.g. syntax - sensitive dependencies to create a model that is more general or better suited for certain downstream tasks , ideally in a weakly - supervised manner to retain its universal properties .
heading: Discussion and future directions

text: Another direction is to apply the method to novel tasks and models .
heading: Discussion and future directions

text: While an extension to sequence labeling is straightforward , other tasks with more complex interactions such as entailment or question answering may require novel ways to pretrain and fine - tune .
heading: Discussion and future directions

text: Finally , while we have provided a series of analyses and ablations , more studies are required to better understand what knowledge a pretrained language model captures , how this changes during fine - tuning , and what information different tasks require .
heading: Discussion and future directions

text: Conclusion
We have proposed ULMFiT , an effective and extremely sample - efficient transfer learning method that can be applied to any NLP task .
heading: Conclusion

text: We have also proposed several novel fine - tuning techniques that in conjunction prevent catastrophic forgetting and enable robust learning across a diverse range of tasks .
heading: Conclusion

text: Our method significantly outperformed existing transfer learning techniques and the stateof - the - art on six representative text classification tasks .
heading: Conclusion

text: We hope that our results will catalyze new developments in transfer learning for NLP .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Universal Sentence Encoder
abstract
We present models for encoding sentences into embedding vectors that specifically target transfer learning to other NLP tasks .
heading: abstract

text: The models are efficient and result in accurate performance on diverse transfer tasks .
heading: abstract

text: Two variants of the encoding models allow for trade - offs between accuracy and compute resources .
heading: abstract

text: For both variants , we investigate and report the relationship between model complexity , resource consumption , the availability of transfer task training data , and task performance .
heading: abstract

text: Comparisons are made with baselines that use word level transfer learning via pretrained word embeddings as well as baselines do not use any transfer learning .
heading: abstract

text: We find that transfer learning using sentence embeddings tends to outperform word level transfer .
heading: abstract

text: With transfer learning via sentence embeddings , we observe surprisingly good performance with minimal amounts of supervised training data fora transfer task .
heading: abstract

text: We obtain encouraging results on Word Embedding Association Tests ( WEAT ) targeted at detecting model bias .
heading: abstract

text: Our pre-trained sentence encoding models are made freely available for download and on TF Hub .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Limited amounts of training data are available for many NLP tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: This presents a challenge for data hungry deep learning methods .
heading: Introduction

text: Given the high cost of annotating supervised training data , very large training sets are usually not available for most research or industry NLP tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: Many models address the problem by implicitly performing limited transfer learning through the use of pre-trained word embeddings such as those produced by word2vec or Glo Ve .
heading: Introduction

text: However , recent work has demonstrated strong transfer task performance using pre-trained sentence level embeddings .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we present two models for producing sentence embeddings that demonstrate good transfer to a number of other of other NLP tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: We include experiments with varying amounts of transfer task training data to illustrate the relationship between transfer task performance and training set size .
heading: Introduction

text: We find that our sentence embeddings can be used to obtain surprisingly good task performance with remarkably little task specific training data .
heading: Introduction

text: The sentence encoding models are made publicly available on TF Hub .
heading: Introduction

text: Engineering characteristics of models used for transfer learning are an important consideration .
heading: Introduction

text: We discuss modeling trade - offs regarding memory requirements as well as compute time on CPU and GPU .
heading: Introduction

text: Resource consumption comparisons are made for sentences of varying lengths .
heading: Introduction

text: import tensorflow_hub as hub embed = hub.Module ( " https://tfhub.dev/google/ " " universal- sentence - encoder / 1 " ) embedding = embed ( [
heading: Introduction

text: " The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog . " ] )
heading: Introduction

text: Listing 1 : Python example code for using the universal sentence encoder .
heading: Introduction

text: Model Toolkit
We make available two new models for encoding sentences into embedding vectors .
heading: Model Toolkit

text: One makes use of the transformer architecture , while the other is formulated as a deep averaging network ( DAN ) .
heading: Model Toolkit

text: Both models are implemented in TensorFlow and are available to download from TF Hub : 1 https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder/1
heading: Model Toolkit

text: The models take as input English strings and produce as output a fixed dimensional embedding representation of the string .
heading: Model Toolkit

text: Listing 1 provides a minimal code snippet to convert a sentence into a tensor containing its sentence embedding .
heading: Model Toolkit

text: The embedding tensor can be used directly or incorporated into larger model graphs for specific tasks .
heading: Model Toolkit

text: As illustrated in , the sentence embeddings can be trivially used to compute sentence level semantic similarity scores that achieve excellent performance on the semantic textual similarity ( STS ) Benchmark .
heading: Model Toolkit

text: When included within larger models , the sentence encoding models can be fine tuned for specific tasks using gradient based updates .
heading: Model Toolkit

text: Encoders
We introduce the model architecture for our two encoding models in this section .
heading: Encoders

text: Our two encoders have different design goals .
heading: Encoders

text: One based on the transformer architecture targets high accuracy at the cost of greater model complexity and resource consumption .
heading: Encoders

text: The other targets efficient inference with slightly reduced accuracy .
heading: Encoders

text: Transformer
The transformer based sentence encoding model constructs sentence embeddings using the encoding sub - graph of the transformer architecture .
heading: Transformer

text: This sub - graph uses attention to compute context aware representations of words in a sentence that take into account both the ordering and identity of all the other words .
heading: Transformer

text: The context aware word representations are converted to a fixed length sentence encoding vector by computing the element - wise sum of the representations at each word position .
heading: Transformer

text: The encoder takes as input a lowercased PTB tokenized string and outputs a 512 dimensional vector as the sentence embedding .
heading: Transformer

text: The encoding model is designed to be as general purpose as possible .
heading: Transformer

text: This is accomplished by using multi-task learning whereby a single encoding model is used to feed multiple downstream tasks .
heading: Transformer

text: The supported tasks include : a Skip - Thought like task for the unsupervised learning from arbitrary running text ; a conversational input - response task for the inclusion of parsed conversational data ; and classification tasks for training on supervised data .
heading: Transformer

text: The Skip - Thought task replaces the LSTM used in the original formulation with a model based on the Transformer architecture .
heading: Transformer

text: As will be shown in the experimental results below , the transformer based encoder achieves the best overall transfer task performance .
heading: Transformer

text: However , this comes at the cost of compute time and memory usage scaling dramatically with sentence length .
heading: Transformer

text: Deep Averaging Network ( DAN )
heading: Transformer

text: The second encoding model makes use of a deep averaging network ( DAN ) whereby input embeddings for words and bi-grams are first averaged together and then passed through a feedforward deep neural network ( DNN ) to produce sentence embeddings .
heading: Transformer

text: Similar to the Transformer encoder , the DAN encoder takes as input a lowercased PTB tokenized string and outputs a 512 dimensional sentence embedding .
heading: Transformer

text: The DAN encoder is trained similarly to the Transformer based encoder .
heading: Transformer

text: We make use of mul-titask learning whereby a single DAN encoder is used to supply sentence embeddings for multiple downstream tasks .
heading: Transformer

text: The primary advantage of the DAN encoder is that compute time is linear in the length of the input sequence .
heading: Transformer

text: Similar to , our results demonstrate that DANs achieve strong baseline performance on text classification tasks .
heading: Transformer

text: Encoder Training Data
Unsupervised training data for the sentence encoding models are drawn from a variety of web sources .
heading: Encoder Training Data

text: The sources are Wikipedia , web news , web question - answer pages and discussion forums .
heading: Encoder Training Data

text: We augment unsupervised learning with training on supervised data from the Stanford Natural Language Inference ( SNLI ) corpus .
heading: Encoder Training Data

text: Similar to the findings of , we observe that training to SNLI improves transfer performance .
heading: Encoder Training Data

text: Transfer Tasks
This section presents an overview of the data used for the transfer learning experiments and the Word Embedding Association Test ( WEAT ) data used to characterize model bias .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: summarizes the number of samples provided by the test portion of each evaluation set and , when available , the size of the dev and training data .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: MR : Movie review snippet sentiment on a five star scale .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: CR : Sentiment of sentences mined from customer reviews .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: SUBJ : Subjectivity of sentences from movie reviews and plot summaries .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: MPQA : Phrase level opinion polarity from news data .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: TREC : Fine grained question classification sourced from TREC .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: SST : Binary phrase level sentiment classification .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: STS Benchmark : Semantic textual similarity ( STS ) between sentence pairs scored by Pearson correlation with human judgments .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: WEAT : Word pairs from the psychology literature on implicit association tests ( IAT ) that are used to characterize model bias .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: For sentence classification transfer tasks , the output of the transformer and DAN sentence encoders are provided to a task specific DNN .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: For the pairwise semantic similarity task , we directly assess the similarity of the sentence embeddings produced by our two encoders .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: As shown Eq. 1 , we first compute the cosine similarity of the two sentence embeddings and then use arccos to convert the cosine similarity into an angular distance .
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: 5 sim ( u , v ) = 1 ? arccos u v | | u || | | v|| /?
heading: Transfer Tasks

text: Baselines
For each transfer task , we include baselines that only make use of word level transfer and baselines that make use of no transfer learning at all .
heading: Baselines

text: For word level transfer , we use word embeddings from a word2 vec skip - gram model trained on a corpus of news data .
heading: Baselines

text: The pretrained word embeddings are included as input to two model types : a convolutional neural network models ( CNN ) ; a DAN .
heading: Baselines

text: The baselines that use pretrained word embeddings allow us to contrast word versus sentence level transfer .
heading: Baselines

text: Additional baseline CNN and DAN models are trained without using any pretrained word or sentence embeddings .
heading: Baselines

text: Combined Transfer Models
We explore combining the sentence and word level transfer models by concatenating their representations prior to feeding the combined representation :
heading: Combined Transfer Models

text: Model performance on transfer tasks .
heading: Combined Transfer Models

text: USE
T is the universal sentence encoder ( USE ) using Transformer .
heading: USE

text: USE
Dis the universal encoder DAN model .
heading: USE

text: Models tagged with w2 v w.e. make use of pre-training word2vec skip - gram embeddings for the transfer task model , while models tagged with lrn w.e. use randomly initialized word embeddings that are learned only on the transfer task data .
heading: USE

text: Accuracy is reported for all evaluations except STS Bench where we report the Pearson correlation of the similarity scores with human judgments .
heading: USE

text: Pairwise similarity scores are computed directly using the sentence embeddings from the universal sentence encoder as in Eq. ( 1 ) .
heading: USE

text: to the transfer task classification layers .
heading: USE

text: For completeness , we also explore concatenating the representations from sentence level transfer models with the baseline models that do not make use of word level transfer learning .
heading: USE

text: Experiments
Transfer task model hyperparamaters are tuned using a combination of Vizier and light manual tuning .
heading: Experiments

text: When available , model hyperparameters are tuned using task dev sets .
heading: Experiments

text: Otherwise , hyperparameters are tuned by crossvalidation on the task training data when available or the evaluation test data when neither training nor dev data are provided .
heading: Experiments

text: Training repeats ten times for each transfer task model with different randomly initialized weights and we report evaluation results by averaging across runs .
heading: Experiments

text: Transfer learning is critically important when training data fora target task is limited .
heading: Experiments

text: We explore the impact on task performance of varying the amount of training data available for the task both with and without the use of transfer learning .
heading: Experiments

text: Contrasting the transformer and DAN based encoders , we demonstrate trade - offs in model complexity and the amount of data required to reach a desired level of accuracy on a task .
heading: Experiments

text: To assess bias in our encoding models , we evaluate the strength of various associations learned by our model on WEAT word lists .
heading: Experiments

text: We compare our result to those of who discovered that word embeddings could be used to reproduce human performance on implicit association tasks for both benign and potentially undesirable associations .
heading: Experiments

text: Results
Transfer task performance is summarized in Table 2 .
heading: Results

text: We observe that transfer learning from the transformer based sentence encoder usually performs as good or better than transfer learning from the DAN encoder .
heading: Results

text: Hoewver , transfer learning using the simpler and fast DAN encoder can for some tasks perform as well or better than the more sophisticated transformer encoder .
heading: Results

text: Models that make use of sentence level transfer learning tend to perform better than models that only use word level transfer .
heading: Results

text: The best performance on most tasks is obtained by models that make use of both sentence and word level transfer .
heading: Results

text: illustrates transfer task performance for varying amounts of training data .
heading: Results

text: We observe that , for smaller quantities of data , sentence level transfer learning can achieve surprisingly good task performance .
heading: Results

text: As the training set size increases , models that do not make use of transfer learning approach the performance of the other models .
heading: Results

text: contrasts 's findings on bias within GloVe embeddings with the DAN variant of the universal encoder .
heading: Results

text: Similar to GloVe , our model reproduces human associations between flowers vs. insects and pleasantness vs. unpleasantness .
heading: Results

text: However , our model demonstrates weaker associations than GloVe for probes targeted at revealing at ageism , racism and sexism .
heading: Results

text: The differences in word association patterns can be attributed to differences in the training data composition and the mixture of tasks used to train the sentence embeddings .
heading: Results

text: Discussion
Transfer learning leads to performance improvements on many tasks .
heading: Discussion

text: Using transfer learning is more critical when less training data is available .
heading: Discussion

text: When task performance is close , the correct modeling choice should take into account engineering trade - offs regarding the memory and compute 6 Researchers and developers are strongly encouraged to independently verify whether biases in their overall model or model components impacts their use case .
heading: Discussion

text: For resources on ML fairness visit https://developers.google.com/machinelearning/fairness-overview/.
heading: Discussion

text: resource requirements introduced by the different models that could be used .
heading: Discussion

text: Resource Usage
This section describes memory and compute resource usage for the transformer and DAN sentence encoding models for different sentence lengths .
heading: Resource Usage

text: Figure 2 plots model resource usage against sentence length .
heading: Resource Usage

text: Compute Usage
The transformer model time complexity is O ( n 2 ) in sentence length , while the DAN model is O ( n ) .
heading: Compute Usage

text: As seen in ( a - b ) , for short sentences , the transformer encoding model is only moderately slower than the much simpler DAN model .
heading: Compute Usage

text: However , compute time for transformer increases noticeably as sentence length increases .
heading: Compute Usage

text: In contrast , the compute time for the DAN model stays nearly constant as sentence length is increased .
heading: Compute Usage

text: Since the DAN model is remarkably computational efficient , using GPUs over CPUs will often have a much larger practical impact for the transformer based encoder .
heading: Compute Usage

text: Memory Usage

The transformer model space complexity also scales quadratically , O ( n 2 ) , in sentence length , while the DAN model space complexity is constant in the length of the sentence . Similar to compute usage , memory usage for the transformer model increases quickly with sentence length , while the memory usage for the DAN model remains constant .
heading: Memory Usage

text: We note that , for the DAN model , memory usage is dominated by the parameters used to store the model unigram and bigram embeddings .
heading: Memory Usage

text: Since the transformer model only needs to store unigram embeddings , for short sequences it requires nearly half as much memory as the DAN model .
heading: Memory Usage

text: Conclusion
Both the transformer and DAN based universal encoding models provide sentence level embeddings that demonstrate strong transfer performance on a number of NLP tasks .
heading: Conclusion

text: The sentence level embeddings surpass the performance of transfer learning using word level embeddings alone .
heading: Conclusion

text: Models that make use of sentence and word level transfer achieve the best overall performance .
heading: Conclusion

text: We observe that transfer learning is most helpful when limited training data is available for the transfer task .
heading: Conclusion

text: The encoding models make different trade - offs regarding accuracy and model complexity that should be considered when choosing the best model fora particular application .
heading: Conclusion

text: The pre-trained encoding models will be made publicly available for research and use in applications that can benefit from a better understanding of natural language .
heading: Conclusion

text: title
Investigating Capsule Networks with Dynamic Routing for Text Classification
abstract
In this study , we explore capsule networks with dynamic routing for text classification .
heading: abstract

text: We propose three strategies to stabilize the dynamic routing process to alleviate the disturbance of some noise capsules which may contain " background " information or have not been successfully trained .
heading: abstract

text: A series of experiments are conducted with capsule networks on six text classification benchmarks .
heading: abstract

text: Capsule networks achieve competitive results over the compared baseline methods on 4 out of 6 datasets , which shows the effectiveness of capsule networks for text classification .
heading: abstract

text: We additionally show that capsule networks exhibit significant improvement when transfer single - label to multi-label text classification over the competitors .
heading: abstract

text: To the best of our knowledge , this is the first work that capsule networks have been empirically investigated for text modeling 1 . * Corresponding author ( min.yang@siat.ac.cn )
heading: abstract

text: 1 Codes are publicly available at : https://github.com/andyweizhao/capsule_text_classification .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Modeling articles or sentences computationally is a fundamental topic in natural language processing .
heading: Introduction

text: It could be as simple as a keyword / phrase matching problem , but it could also be a nontrivial problem if compositions , hierarchies , and structures of texts are considered .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , a news article which mentions a single phrase " US election " maybe categorized into the political news with high probability .
heading: Introduction

text: But it could be very difficult fora computer to predict which presidential candidate is favored by its author , or whether the author 's view in the article is more liberal or more conservative .
heading: Introduction

text: Earlier efforts in modeling texts have achieved limited success on text categorization using a simple bag - of - words classifier , implying understanding the meaning of the individual word or n-gram is a necessary step towards more sophisticated models .
heading: Introduction

text: It is therefore not a surprise that distributed representations of words , a.k.a. word embeddings , have received great attention from NLP community addressing the question " what " to be modeled at the basic level .
heading: Introduction

text: In order to model higher level concepts and facts in texts , an NLP researcher has to think cautiously the so - called " what " question : what is actually modeled beyond word meanings .
heading: Introduction

text: A common approach to the question is to treat the texts as sequences and focus on their spatial patterns , whose representatives include convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ) and long shortterm memory networks ( LSTMs ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Another common approach is to completely ignore the order of words but focus on their compositions as a collection , whose representatives include probabilistic topic modeling and Earth Mover 's Distance based modeling .
heading: Introduction

text: Those two approaches , albeit quite different from the computational perspective , actually follow a common measure to be diagnosed regarding their answers to the " what " question .
heading: Introduction

text: In neural network approaches , spatial patterns aggregated at lower levels contribute to representing higher level concepts .
heading: Introduction

text: Here , they form a recursive process to articulate what to be modeled .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , CNN builds convolutional feature detectors to extract local patterns from a window of vector sequences and uses max - pooling to select the most prominent ones .
heading: Introduction

text: It then hierarchically builds such pattern extraction pipelines at multiple levels .
heading: Introduction

text: Being a spatially sensitive model , CNN pays a price for the inefficiency of replicating feature detectors on a grid .
heading: Introduction

text: As argued in , one has to choose between replicating detectors whose size grows exponentially with the number of dimensions , or increasing the volume of the labeled training set in a similar exponential way .
heading: Introduction

text: On the other hand , methods that are spatially insensitive are perfectly efficient at the inference time regardless of any order of words or local patterns .
heading: Introduction

text: However , they are unavoidably more restricted to encode rich structures presented in a sequence .
heading: Introduction

text: Improving the efficiency to encode spatial patterns while keeping the flexibility of their representation capability is thus a central issue .
heading: Introduction

text: A recent method called capsule network introduced by possesses this attractive potential to address the aforementioned issue .
heading: Introduction

text: They introduce an iterative routing process to decide the credit attribution between nodes from lower and higher layers .
heading: Introduction

text: A metaphor ( also as an argument ) they made is that human visual system intelligently assigns parts to wholes at the inference time without hard - coding patterns to be perspective relevant .
heading: Introduction

text: As an outcome , their model could encode the intrinsic spatial relationship between apart and a whole constituting viewpoint invariant knowledge that automatically generalizes to novel viewpoints .
heading: Introduction

text: In our work , we follow a similar spirit to use this technique in modeling texts .
heading: Introduction

text: Three strategies are proposed to stabilize the dynamic routing process to alleviate the disturbance of some noise capsules which may contain " background " information such as stop words and the words that are unrelated to specific categories .
heading: Introduction

text: We conduct a series of experiments with capsule networks on top of the pre-trained word vectors for six text classification benchmarks .
heading: Introduction

text: More importantly , we show that capsule networks achieves significant improvement when transferring singlelabel to multi-label text classifications over strong baseline methods .
heading: Introduction

text: Our Model
Our capsule network , depicted in , is a variant of the capsule networks proposed in .
heading: Our Model

text: It consists of four layers : ngram convolutional layer , primary capsule layer , convolutional capsule layer , and fully connected capsule layer .
heading: Our Model

text: In addition , we explore two capsule frameworks to integrate these four components in different ways .
heading: Our Model

text: Child - Parent Relationships
As argued in , capsule network tries to address the representational limitation and exponential inefficiencies of convolutions with transformation matrices .
heading: Child - Parent Relationships

text: It allows the networks to automatically learn child - parent ( or partwhole ) relationships .
heading: Child - Parent Relationships

text: In text classification tasks , different sentences with the same category are supposed to have the similar topic but with different viewpoints .
heading: Child - Parent Relationships

text: In this paper , we explore two different types of transformation matrices to generate prediction vector ( vote ) j|i ?

heading: Child - Parent Relationships

text: Dynamic Routing
The basic idea of dynamic routing is to construct a non-linear map in an iterative manner ensuring that the output of each capsule gets sent to an appropriate parent in the subsequent layer :
heading: Dynamic Routing

text: For each potential parent , the capsule network can increase or decrease the connection strength by dynamic routing , which is more effective than the primitive routing strategies such as max - pooling in CNN that essentially detects whether a feature is present in any position of the text , but loses spatial information about the feature .
heading: Dynamic Routing

text: We explore three strategies to boost the accuracy of routing process by alleviating the disturbance of some noisy capsules :
heading: Dynamic Routing

text: Orphan Category

Inspired by , an additional " orphan " category is added to the network , which can capture the " background " information of the text such as stop words and the words that are unrelated to specific categories , helping the capsule network model the child - parent relationship more efficiently .
heading: Orphan Category

text: Adding " orphan " category in the text is more effective than in image since there is no single consistent " background " object in images , while the stop words are consistent in texts such as predicate " s " , " am " and pronouns " his " , " she " .
heading: Orphan Category

text: Leaky - Softmax
We explore Leaky - Softmax in the place of standard softmax while updating connection strength between the children capsules and their parents .
heading: Leaky - Softmax

text: Despite the orphan category in the last capsule layer , we also need a light - weight method between two consecutive layers to route the noise child capsules to extra dimension without any additional parameters and computation consuming .
heading: Leaky - Softmax

text: Coefficients Amendment
We also attempt to use the probability of existence of child capsules in the layer below to iteratively amend the connection strength as Eq.6 .
heading: Coefficients Amendment

text: The Architectures of Capsule Network
We explore two capsule architectures ( denoted as Capsule - A and Capsule - B ) to integrate these four
heading: The Architectures of Capsule Network

text: Capsule - B Capsule - A starts with an embedding layer which transforms each word in the corpus to a 300 - dimensional ( V = 300 ) word vector , followed by a 3 - gram ( K 1 = 3 ) convolutional layer with 32 filters ( B = 32 ) and astride of 1 with ReLU non-linearity .
heading: The Architectures of Capsule Network

text: All the other layers are capsule layers starting with a B d primary capsule layer with 32 filters ( C = 32 ) , followed by a 3 C d d ( K 2 = 3 ) convolutional capsule layer with 16 filters ( D = 16 ) and a fully connected capsule layer in sequence .
heading: The Architectures of Capsule Network

text: Each capsule has 16 - dimensional ( d = 16 ) instantiated parameters and their length ( norm ) can describe the probability of the existence of capsules .
heading: The Architectures of Capsule Network

text: The capsule layers are connected by the transformation matrices , and each connection is also multiplied by a routing coefficient that is dynamically computed by routing by agreement mechanism .
heading: The Architectures of Capsule Network

text: The basic structure of Capsule - B is similar to Capsule - A except that we adopt three parallel networks with filter windows ( N ) of 3 , 4 , 5 in the N - gram convolutional layer ( see ) .
heading: The Architectures of Capsule Network

text: The final output of the fully connected capsule layer is fed into the average pooling to produce the final results .
heading: The Architectures of Capsule Network

text: In this way , Capsule - B can learn more meaningful and comprehensive text representation .
heading: The Architectures of Capsule Network

text: 3 Experimental Setup
heading: The Architectures of Capsule Network

text: Experimental Datasets

In order to evaluate the effectiveness of our model , we conduct a series of experiments on six bench - marks including : movie reviews ( MR ) , Stanford Sentiment Treebankan extension of MR ( SST - 2 ) , Subjectivity dataset ( Subj ) , TREC question dataset ( TREC ) , customer review ( CR ) , and AG 's news corpus .
heading: Experimental Datasets

text: These benchmarks cover several text classification tasks such as sentiment classification , question categorization , news categorization .
heading: Experimental Datasets

text: The detailed statistics are presented in
heading: Experimental Datasets

text: Implementation Details
In the experiments , we use 300 - dimensional word2vec vectors to initialize embedding vectors .
heading: Implementation Details

text: We conduct mini-batch with size 50 for AG 's news and size 25 for other datasets .
heading: Implementation Details

text: We use Adam optimization algorithm with 1e - 3 learning rate to train the model .
heading: Implementation Details

text: We use 3 iteration of routing for all datasets since it optimizes the loss faster and converges to a lower loss at the end .
heading: Implementation Details

text: Baseline methods

In the experiments , we evaluate and compare our model with several strong baseline methods including : LSTM / Bi - LSTM , tree - structured LSTM ( Tree - LSTM ) , LSTM regularized by linguistic knowledge ( LR - LSTM ) , CNNrand / CNN - static / CNN - non-static ( Kim , 2014 ) , very deep convolutional network ( VD - CNN ) , and character - level convolutional network ( CL - CNN ) .
heading: Baseline methods

text: Experimental Results
Quantitative Evaluation
In our experiments , the evaluation metric is classification accuracy .
heading: Quantitative Evaluation

text: We summarize the experimental results in .
heading: Quantitative Evaluation

text: From the results , we observe that the capsule networks achieve best results on 4 out of 6 benchmarks , which verifies the effectiveness of the capsule networks .
heading: Quantitative Evaluation

text: In particular , our model substantially and consistently outperforms
heading: Quantitative Evaluation

text: Ablation Study

To analyze the effect of varying different components of our capsule architecture for text classification , we also report the ablation test of the capsule - B model in terms of using different setups of the capsule network .
heading: Ablation Study

text: The experimental results are summarized in .
heading: Ablation Study

text: Generally , all three proposed dynamic routing strategies contribute to the effectiveness of Capsule - B by alleviating the disturbance of some noise capsules which may contain " background " information such as stop words and the words that are unrelated to specific categories .
heading: Ablation Study

text: More comprehensive comparison results are demonstrated in . 4 in Supplementary Material .
heading: Ablation Study

text: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification
Capsule network demonstrates promising performance in single - label text classification which as - signs a label from a predefined set to a text ( see ) .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: Multi-label text classification is , however , a more challenging practical problem .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: From singlelabel to multi-label ( with n category labels ) text classification , the label space is expanded from n to 2 n , thus more training is required to cover the whole label space .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: For single - label texts , it is practically easy to collect and annotate the samples .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: However , the burden of collection and annotation fora large scale multi-label text dataset is generally extremely high .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: How deep neural networks ( e.g. , CNN and LSTM ) best cope with multi-label text classification still remains a problem since obtaining large scale of multi-label dataset is a timeconsuming and expensive process .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: In this section , we investigate the capability of capsule network on multi-label text classification by using only the single - label samples as training data .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: With feature property as part of the information extracted by capsules , we may generalize the model better to multi-label text classification without an over extensive amount of labeled data .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: The evaluation is carried on the Reuters - 21578 dataset .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: This dataset consists of 10,788 documents from the Reuters financial newswire service , where each document contains either multiple labels or a single label .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: We reprocess the corpus to evaluate the capability of capsule networks of transferring from single - label to multi-label text classification .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: For dev and training , we only use the single - label documents in the Reuters dev and training sets .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: For testing , Reuters - Multi - label only uses the multi-label documents in testing dataset , while Reuters - Full includes all documents in test set .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: The characteristics of these two datasets are described in .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: Following ( Sorower , 2010 ) , we adopt Micro Averaged Precision ( Precision ) , Micro Averaged Recall ( Recall ) and Micro Averaged F1 scores ( F1 ) as the evaluation metrics for multi-label text classification .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: Any of these scores are firstly computed on individual class labels and then averaged overall classes , called label - based measures .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: In addition , we also measure the Exact Match Ratio ( ER ) which considers partially correct prediction as incorrect and only counts fully correct samples .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: The experimental results are summarized in .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: From the results , we can observe that the capsule networks have substantial and significant improvement in terms of all four evaluation metrics over the strong baseline methods on the test sets in both Reuters - Multi-label and Reuters - Full datasets .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: In particular , larger improvement is achieved on Reuters - Multi - label dataset which only contains the multi-label documents in the test set .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: This is within our expectation since the capsule network is capable of preserving the instantiated parameters of the categories trained by singlelabel documents .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: The capsule network has much stronger transferring capability than the conventional deep neural networks .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: In addition , the good results on Reuters - Full also indicate that the capsule network has robust superiority over competitors on single - label documents .
heading: Single - Label to Multi - Label Text Classification

text: Related Work

Early methods for text classification adopted the typical features such as bag - of - words , n-grams , and their TF - IDF features as input of machine learning algorithms such as support vector machine ( SVM ) , naive Bayes ( NB ) for classification .
heading: Related Work

text: However , these models usually heavily relied on laborious feature engineering or massive extra linguistic resources .
heading: Related Work

text: Recent advances in deep neural networks and representation learning have substantially improved the performance of text classification tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: The dominant approaches are recurrent neural net -works , in particular LSTMs and CNNs. reported on a series of experiments with CNNs trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence - level classification tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: The CNN models improved upon the state of the art on 4 out of 7 tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: offered an empirical exploration on the use of character - level convolutional networks ( Convnets ) for text classification and the experiments showed that Convnets outperformed the traditional models .
heading: Related Work

text: proposed a simple and efficient text classification method fastText , which could be trained on a billion words within ten minutes .
heading: Related Work

text: proposed a very deep convolutional networks ( with 29 convolutional layers ) for text classification .
heading: Related Work

text: generalized the LSTM to the tree - structured network topologies ( Tree - LSTM ) that achieved best results on two text classification tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: Recently , a novel type of neural network is proposed using the concept of capsules to improve the representational limitations of firstly introduced the concept of " capsules " to address the representational limitations of CNNs and RNNs .
heading: Related Work

text: Capsules with transformation matrices allowed networks to automatically learn part - whole relationships .
heading: Related Work

text: Consequently , proposed capsule networks that replaced the scalar - output feature detectors of CNNs with vector - output capsules and max - pooling with routing - by - agreement .
heading: Related Work

text: The capsule network has shown its potential by achieving a state - of - the - art result on MNIST data .
heading: Related Work

text: Unlike max - pooling in CNN , however , Capsule network do not throwaway information about the precise position of the entity within the region .
heading: Related Work

text: For lowlevel capsules , location information is placecoded by which capsule is active .
heading: Related Work

text: further tested out the application of capsule networks on CIFAR data with higher dimensionality .
heading: Related Work

text: proposed anew iterative routing procedure between capsule layers based on the EM algorithm , which achieves significantly better accuracy on the small NORB data set .
heading: Related Work

text: generalized existing routing methods within the framework of weighted kernel density estimation .
heading: Related Work

text: To date , no work investigates the performance of capsule networks in NLP tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: This study herein takes the lead in this topic .
heading: Related Work

text: Conclusion
In this paper , we investigated capsule networks with dynamic routing for text classification .
heading: Conclusion

text: Three strategies were proposed to boost the performance of the dynamic routing process to alleviate the disturbance of noisy capsules .
heading: Conclusion

text: Extensive experiments on six text classification benchmarks show the effectiveness of capsule networks in text classification .
heading: Conclusion

text: More importantly , capsule networks also show significant improvement when transferring single - label to multi-label text classifications over strong baseline methods .
heading: Conclusion
