title
Baseline Needs More Love : On Simple Word - Embedding - Based Models and Associated Pooling Mechanisms
heading: title

text: abstract
Many deep learning architectures have been proposed to model the compositionality in text sequences , requiring a substantial number of parameters and expensive computations .
heading: abstract

text: However , there has not been a rigorous evaluation regarding the added value of sophisticated compositional functions .
heading: abstract

text: In this paper , we conduct a point - by - point comparative study between Simple Word - Embeddingbased Models ( SWEMs ) , consisting of parameter - free pooling operations , relative to word - embedding - based RNN / CNN models .
heading: abstract

text: Surprisingly , SWEMs exhibit comparable or even superior performance in the majority of cases considered .
heading: abstract

text: Based upon this understanding , we propose two additional pooling strategies over learned word embeddings : ( i ) a max - pooling operation for improved interpretability ; and ( ii ) a hierarchical pooling operation , which preserves spatial ( n - gram ) information within text sequences .
heading: abstract

text: We present experiments on 17 datasets encompassing three tasks : ( i ) ( long ) document classification ; ( ii ) text sequence matching ; and ( iii ) short text tasks , including classification and tagging .
heading: abstract

text: The source code and datasets can be obtained from https://github.com/dinghanshen/SWEM .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction
Word embeddings , learned from massive unstructured text data , are widely - adopted building blocks for Natural Language Processing ( NLP ) .
heading: Introduction

text: By representing each word as a fixed - length vector , these embeddings can group semantically similar words , while implicitly encoding rich linguis - tic regularities and patterns .
heading: Introduction

text: Leveraging the word - embedding construct , many deep architectures have been proposed to model the compositionality in variable - length text sequences .
heading: Introduction

text: These methods range from simple operations like addition , to more sophisticated compositional functions such as Recurrent Neural Networks ( RNNs ) , Convolutional Neural Networks ( CNNs ) and Recursive Neural Networks .
heading: Introduction

text: Models with more expressive compositional functions , e.g. , RNNs or CNNs , have demonstrated impressive results ; however , they are typically computationally expensive , due to the need to estimate hundreds of thousands , if not millions , of parameters .
heading: Introduction

text: In contrast , models with simple compositional functions often compute a sentence or document embedding by simply adding , or averaging , over the word embedding of each sequence element obtained via , e.g. , word2vec , or Glo Ve .
heading: Introduction

text: Generally , such a Simple Word - Embedding - based Model ( SWEM ) does not explicitly account for spatial , word - order information within a text sequence .
heading: Introduction

text: However , they possess the desirable property of having significantly fewer parameters , enjoying much faster training , relative to RNN - or CNN - based models .
heading: Introduction

text: Hence , there is a computation - vs. - expressiveness tradeoff regarding how to model the compositionality of a text sequence .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we conduct an extensive experimental investigation to understand when , and why , simple pooling strategies , operated over word embeddings alone , already carry sufficient information for natural language understanding .
heading: Introduction

text: To ac- count for the distinct nature of various NLP tasks that may require different semantic features , we compare SWEM - based models with existing recurrent and convolutional networks in a pointby - point manner .
heading: Introduction

text: Specifically , we consider 17 datasets , including three distinct NLP tasks : document classification ( Yahoo news , Yelp reviews , etc. ) , natural language sequence matching ( SNLI , WikiQA , etc. ) and ( short ) sentence classification / tagging ( Stanford sentiment treebank , .
heading: Introduction

text: Surprisingly , SWEMs exhibit comparable or even superior performance in the majority of cases considered .
heading: Introduction

text: In order to validate our experimental findings , we conduct additional investigations to understand to what extent the word - order information is utilized / required to make predictions on different tasks .
heading: Introduction

text: We observe that in text representation tasks , many words ( e.g. , stop words , or words that are not related to sentiment or topic ) do not meaningfully contribute to the final predictions ( e.g. , sentiment label ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Based upon this understanding , we propose to leverage a max - pooling operation directly over the word embedding matrix of a given sequence , to select its most salient features .
heading: Introduction

text: This strategy is demonstrated to extract complementary features relative to the standard averaging operation , while resulting in a more interpretable model .
heading: Introduction

text: Inspired by a case study on sentiment analysis tasks , we further propose a hierarchical pooling strategy to abstract and preserve the spatial information in the final representations .
heading: Introduction

text: This strategy is demonstrated to exhibit comparable empirical results to LSTM and CNN on tasks that are sensitive to word - order features , while maintaining the favorable properties of not having compositional parameters , thus fast training .
heading: Introduction

text: Our work presents a simple yet strong baseline for text representation learning that is widely ignored in benchmarks , and highlights the general computation - vs. - expressiveness tradeoff associated with appropriately selecting compositional functions for distinct NLP problems .
heading: Introduction

text: Furthermore , we quantitatively show that the word - embeddingbased text classification tasks can have the similar level of difficulty regardless of the employed models , using the subspace training to constrain the trainable parameters .
heading: Introduction

text: Thus , according to Occam 's razor , simple models are preferred .
heading: Introduction

text: Related Work
A fundamental goal in NLP is to develop expressive , yet computationally efficient compositional functions that can capture the linguistic structure of natural language sequences .
heading: Related Work

text: Recently , several studies have suggested that on certain NLP applications , much simpler word - embedding - based architectures exhibit comparable or even superior performance , compared with more - sophisticated models using recurrence or convolutions .
heading: Related Work

text: Although complex compositional functions are avoided in these models , additional modules , such as attention layers , are employed on top of the word embedding layer .
heading: Related Work

text: As a result , the specific role that the word embedding plays in these models is not emphasized ( or explicit ) , which distracts from understanding how important the word embeddings alone are to the observed superior performance .
heading: Related Work

text: Moreover , several recent studies have shown empirically that the advantages of distinct compositional functions are highly dependent on the specific task .
heading: Related Work

text: Therefore , it is of interest to study the practical value of the additional expressiveness , on a wide variety of NLP problems .
heading: Related Work

text: SWEMs bear close resemblance to Deep Averaging Network ( DAN ) or fast - Text , where they show that average pooling achieves promising results on certain NLP tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: However , there exist several key differences that make our work unique .
heading: Related Work

text: First , we explore a series of pooling operations , rather than only average - pooling .
heading: Related Work

text: Specifically , a hierarchical pooling operation is introduced to incorporate spatial information , which demonstrates superior results on sentiment analysis , relative to average pooling .
heading: Related Work

text: Second , our work not only explores when simple pooling operations are enough , but also investigates the underlying reasons , i.e. , what semantic features are required for distinct NLP problems .
heading: Related Work

text: Third , DAN and fast Text only focused on one or two problems at a time , thus a comprehensive study regarding the effectiveness of various compositional functions on distinct NLP tasks , e.g. , categorizing short sentence / long documents , matching natural language sentences , has heretofore been absent .
heading: Related Work

text: In response , our work seeks to perform a comprehensive comparison with respect to simple - vs. - complex compositional func- tions , across a wide range of NLP problems , and reveals some general rules for rationally selecting models to tackle different tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: Models & training

Consider a text sequence represented as X ( either a sentence or a document ) , composed of a sequence of words : {w 1 , w 2 , .... , w L } , where L is the number of tokens , i.e. , the sentence / document length .
heading: Models & training

text: Let {v 1 , v 2 , .... , v L } denote the respective word embeddings for each token , where v l ?
heading: Models & training

text: R K .
The compositional function , X ? z , aims to combine word embeddings into a fixed - length sentence / document representation z .
heading: R K .

text: These representations are then used to make predictions about sequence X. Below , we describe different types of functions considered in this work .
heading: R K .

text: Recurrent Sequence Encoder
heading: R K .

text: A widely adopted compositional function is defined in a recurrent manner : the model successively takes word vector v tat position t , along with the hidden unit h t?1 from the last position t ?
heading: R K .

text: 1 , to update the current hidden unit via
heading: R K .

text: To address the issue of learning long - term dependencies , f ( ) is often defined as Long Short - Term Memory ( LSTM ) , which employs gates to control the flow of information abstracted from a sequence .
heading: R K .

text: We omit the details of the LSTM and refer the interested readers to the work by for further explanation .
heading: R K .

text: Intuitively , the LSTM encodes a text sequence considering its word - order information , but yields additional compositional parameters that must be learned .
heading: R K .

text: Convolutional Sequence Encoder
heading: R K .

text: The Convolutional Neural Network ( CNN ) architecture is another strategy extensively employed as the compositional function to encode text sequences .
heading: R K .

text: The convolution operation considers windows of n consecutive words within the sequence , where a set of filters ( to be learned ) are applied to these word windows to generate corresponding feature maps .
heading: R K .

text: Subsequently , an aggregation operation ( such as max - pooling ) is used on top of the feature maps to abstract the most salient semantic features , resulting in the final representation .
heading: R K .

text: For most experiments , we consider a single - layer CNN text model .
heading: R K .

text: However , Deep CNN text models have also been developed , and are considered in a few of our experiments .
heading: R K .

text: Simple Word - Embedding Model
heading: R K .

text: ( SWEM )
heading: R K .

text: To investigate the raw modeling capacity of word embeddings , we consider a class of models with no additional compositional parameters to encode natural language sequences , termed SWEMs .
heading: R K .

text: Among them , the simplest strategy is to compute the element - wise average over word vectors fora given sequence :
heading: R K .

text: The model in can be seen as an average pooling operation , which takes the mean over each of the K dimensions for all word embeddings , resulting in a representation z with the same dimension as the embedding itself , termed here SWEM - aver .
heading: R K .

text: Intuitively , z takes the information of every sequence element into account via the addition operation .
heading: R K .

text: Max Pooling

Motivated by the observation that , in general , only a small number of key words contribute to final predictions , we propose another SWEM variant , that extracts the most salient features from every word - embedding dimension , by taking the maximum value along each dimension of the word vectors .
heading: Max Pooling

text: This strategy is similar to the max - over - time pooling operation in convolutional neural networks :
heading: Max Pooling

text: We denote this model variant as SWEM - max .
heading: Max Pooling

text: Here the j - th component of z is the maximum element in the set {v 1 j , . . . , v Lj } , where v 1j is , for example , the j - th component of v 1 .
heading: Max Pooling

text: With this pooling operation , those words that are unimportant or unrelated to the corresponding tasks will be ignored in the encoding process ( as the components of the embedding vectors will have small amplitude ) , unlike SWEM - aver where every word contributes equally to the representation .
heading: Max Pooling

text: Considering that SWEM - aver and SWEM - max are complementary , in the sense of accounting for different types of information from text sequences ,
heading: Max Pooling

text: Model
Parameter s Speed CNN 541K 171s LSTM 1.8M 598s SWEM 61K 63s
heading: Model

text: Interestingly , for the sentiment analysis tasks , both CNN and LSTM compositional functions perform better than SWEM , suggesting that wordorder information maybe required for analyzing sentiment orientations .
heading: Model

text: This finding is consistent with , where they hypothesize that the positional information of a word in text sequences maybe beneficial to predict sentiment .
heading: Model

text: This is intuitively reasonable since , for instance , the phrase " not really good " and " really not good " convey different levels of negative sentiment , while being different only by their word orderings .
heading: Model

text: Contrary to SWEM , CNN and LSTM models can both capture this type of information via convolutional filters or recurrent transition functions .
heading: Model

text: However , as suggested above , such word - order patterns maybe much less useful for predicting the topic of a document .
heading: Model

text: This maybe attributed to the fact that word embeddings alone already provide sufficient topic information of a document , at least when the text sequences considered are relatively long .
heading: Model

text: Parameters
Complexity Sequential
Ops we also propose a third SWEM variant , where the two abstracted features are concatenated together to form the sentence embeddings , denoted here as SWEM - concat .
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: For all SWEM variants , there are no additional compositional parameters to be learned .
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: As a result , the models only exploit intrinsic word embedding information for predictions .
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: Hierarchical Pooling Both SWEM - aver and SWEM - max do not take word - order or spatial information into consideration , which could be useful for certain NLP applications .
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: So motivated , we further propose a hierarchical pooling layer .
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: Let v i:i+n?1 refer to the local window consisting of n consecutive words words ,
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: First , an average - pooling is performed on each local window , v i:i+n?1 .
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: The extracted features from all windows are further down - sampled with a global max - pooling operation on top of the representations for every window .
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: We call this approach SWEM - hier due to its layered pooling .
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: This strategy preserves the local spatial information of a text sequence in the sense that it keeps track of how the sentence / document is constructed from individual word windows , i.e. , n-grams .
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: This formulation is related to bag - of - n- grams method .
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: However , SWEM - hier learns fixed - length representations for the n-grams that appear in the corpus , rather than just capturing their occurrences via count features , which may potentially advantageous for prediction purposes .
heading: Complexity Sequential

text: Parameters & Computation
Comparison
We compare CNN , LSTM and SWEM wrt their parameters and computational speed .
heading: Comparison

text: K denotes the dimension of word embeddings , as above .
heading: Comparison

text: For the CNN , we use n to denote the filter width ( assumed constant for all filters , for simplicity of analysis , but in practice variable n is commonly used ) .
heading: Comparison

text: We defined as the dimension of the final sequence representation .
heading: Comparison

text: Specifically , d represents the dimension of hidden units or the number of filters in LSTM or CNN , respectively .
heading: Comparison

text: We first examine the number of compositional parameters for each model .
heading: Comparison

text: As shown in , both the CNN and LSTM have a large number of parameters , to model the semantic compositionality of text sequences , whereas SWEM has no such parameters .
heading: Comparison

text: Similar to , we then consider the computational complexity and the minimum number of sequential operations required for each model .
heading: Comparison

text: SWEM tends to be more efficient than CNN and LSTM in terms of computation complexity .
heading: Comparison

text: For example , considering the case where K = d , SWEM is faster than CNN or LSTM by a factor of nd or d , respectively .
heading: Comparison

text: Further , the computations in SWEM are highly parallelizable , unlike LSTM that requires O ( L ) sequential steps .
heading: Comparison

text: Experiments

We evaluate different compositional functions on a wide variety of supervised tasks , including document categorization , text sequence matching ( given a sentence pair , X 1 , X 2 , predict their relationship , y) as well as ( short ) sentence classification .
heading: Experiments

text: We experiment on 17 datasets concerning natural language understanding , with corresponding data statistics summarized in the Supplementary Material .
heading: Experiments

text: We use Glo Ve word embeddings with K = 300 as initialization for all our models .
heading: Experiments

text: Out - Of - Vocabulary ( OOV ) words are initialized from a uniform distribution with range [ ? 0.01 , 0.01 ] .
heading: Experiments

text: The Glo Ve embeddings are employed in two ways to learn refined word embeddings : ( i ) directly updating each word embedding during training ; and ( ii ) training a 300 dimensional Multilayer Perceptron ( MLP ) layer with ReLU activation , with Glo Ve embeddings as input to the MLP and with output defining the refined word embeddings .
heading: Experiments

text: The latter approach corresponds to learning an MLP model that adapts GloVe embeddings to the dataset and task of interest .
heading: Experiments

text: The advantages of these two methods differ from dataset to dataset .
heading: Experiments

text: We choose the better strategy based on their corresponding performances on the validation set .
heading: Experiments

text: The final classifier is implemented as an MLP layer with dimension selected from the set [ 100 , 300 , 500 , 1000 ] , followed by a sigmoid or softmax function , depending on the specific task .
heading: Experiments

text: Adam ) is used to optimize all models , with learning rate selected from .
heading: Experiments

text: Surprisingly , on topic prediction tasks , our SWEM model exhibits stronger performances , relative to both LSTM and CNN compositional architectures , this by leveraging both the average and max - pooling features from word embeddings .
heading: Experiments

text: Specifically , our SWEM - concat model even outperforms a 29 - layer deep CNN model , when predicting topics .
heading: Experiments

text: On the ontology classification problem ( DBpedia dataset ) , we observe the same trend , that SWEM exhibits comparable or even superior results , relative to CNN or LSTM models .
heading: Experiments

text: Since there are no compositional parameters in SWEM , our models have an order of magnitude fewer parameters ( excluding embeddings ) than LSTM or CNN , and are considerably more computationally efficient .
heading: Experiments

text: As illustrated in Table 4 , SWEM - concat achieves better results on Yahoo !
heading: Experiments

text: Answer than CNN / LSTM , with only 61 K parameters ( one - tenth the number of LSTM parameters , or one - third the number of CNN parameters ) , while taking a fraction of the training time relative to the CNN or LSTM .
heading: Experiments

text: Interpreting model predictions

Although the proposed SWEM - max variant generally performs a slightly worse than SWEM - aver , it extracts complementary features from SWEMaver , and hence inmost cases SWEM - concat exhibits the best performance among all SWEM variants .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: More importantly , we found that the word embeddings learned from SWEM - max tend to be sparse .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: We trained our SWEM - max model on the Yahoo datasets ( randomly initialized ) .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: With the learned embeddings , we plot the values for each of the word embedding dimensions , for the entire vocabulary .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: As shown in , most of the values are highly concentrated around zero , indicating that the word embeddings learned are very sparse .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: On the contrary , the Glo Ve word embeddings , for the same vocabulary , are considerably denser than the embeddings learned from SWEM - max .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: This suggests that the model may only depend on a few key words , among the entire vocabulary , for predictions ( since most words do not contribute to the max - pooling operation in SWEM - max ) .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: Through the embedding , the model learns the important words fora given task ( those words with non -zero embedding components ) .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: In this regard , the nature of max - pooling pro - cess gives rise to a more interpretable model .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: For a document , only the word with largest value in each embedding dimension is employed for the final representation .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: Thus , we suspect that semantically similar words may have large values in some shared dimensions .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: So motivated , after training the SWEM - max model on the Yahoo dataset , we selected five words with the largest values , among the entire vocabulary , for each word embedding dimension ( these words are selected preferentially in the corresponding dimension , by the max operation ) .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: As shown in , the words chosen wrt each embedding dimension are indeed highly relevant and correspond to a common topic ( the topics are inferred from words ) .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: For example , the words in the first column of are all political terms , which could be assigned to the Politics & Government topic .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: Note that our model can even learn locally interpretable structure that is not explicitly indicated by the label information .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: For instance , all words in the fifth column are Chemistry - related .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: However , we do not have a chemistry label in the dataset , and regardless they should belong to the Science topic .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: Text Sequence Matching
heading: Interpreting model predictions

text: To gain a deeper understanding regarding the modeling capacity of word embeddings , we further investigate the problem of sentence matching , including natural language inference , answer sentence selection and paraphrase identification .
heading: Interpreting model predictions

Surprisingly , on most of the datasets considered ( except WikiQA ) , SWEM demonstrates the best results compared with those with CNN or the LSTM encoder .

heading: The corresponding performance metrics are shown in .

text: As a result , with only 120K parameters , our SWEM - max achieves a test accuracy of 83.8 % , which is very competitive among state - of the - art sentence encoding - based models ( in terms of both performance and number of parameters )
heading: The corresponding performance metrics are shown in .
The corresponding performance metrics are shown in .

text: The strong results of the SWEM approach on these tasks may stem from the fact that when matching natural language sentences , it is sufficient inmost cases to simply model the word - level alignments between two sequences .

text: From this perspective , word - order information becomes much less useful for predicting relationship between sentences .
heading: The corresponding performance metrics are shown in .

text: Moreover , considering the simpler model architecture of SWEM , they could be much easier to be optimized than LSTM or CNN - based models , and thus give rise to better empirical results .
heading: The corresponding performance metrics are shown in .

text: Importance of word - order information
One possible disadvantage of SWEM is that it ignores the word - order information within a text sequence , which could be potentially captured by CNN - or LSTM - based models .
heading: Importance of word - order information

text: However , we empirically found that except for sentiment analysis , SWEM exhibits similar or even superior performance as the CNN or LSTM on a variety of tasks .
heading: Importance of word - order information

text: In this regard , one natural question would be : how important are word - order features for these tasks ?
heading: Importance of word - order information

text: To this end , we randomly shuffle the words for every sentence in the training set , while keeping the original word order for samples in the test set .
heading: Importance of word - order information

text: The motivation here is to remove the word - order features from the training set and examine how sensitive the performance on different tasks are to word - order information .
heading: Importance of word - order information

text: We use LSTM as the model for this purpose since it can captures wordorder information from the original training set .
heading: Importance of word - order information

text: The results on three distinct tasks are shown in .
heading: Importance of word - order information

text: Somewhat surprisingly , for Yahoo and SNLI datasets , the LSTM model trained on shuffled training set shows comparable accuracies to those trained on the original dataset , indicating that word - order information does not contribute significantly on these two problems , i.e. , topic categorization and textual entailment .
heading: Importance of word - order information

text: However , on the Yelp polarity dataset , the results drop noticeably , further suggesting that word - order does matter for sentiment analysis ( as indicated above from a different perspective ) .
heading: Importance of word - order information

text: Notably , the performance of LSTM on the Yelp dataset with a shuffled training set is very close to our results with SWEM , indicating that the main difference between LSTM and SWEM maybe due to the ability of the former to capture word - order features .
heading: Importance of word - order information

text: Both observations are in consistent with our experimental results in the previous section .
heading: Importance of word - order information

text: Case Study
To understand what type of sentences are sensitive to word - order information , we further show those samples that are wrongly predicted because of the shuffling of training data in .
heading: Case Study

text: Taking the first sentence as an example , several words in the review are generally positive , i.e. friendly , nice , okay , great and likes .
heading: Case Study

text: However , the most vital features for predicting the sentiment of this sentence could be the phrase / sentence ' is just okay ' , ' not great ' or ' makes me wonder why everyone likes ' , which can not be captured without considering word - order features .
heading: Case Study

text: It is worth noting the hints for predictions in this case are actually ngram phrases from the input document .
heading: Case Study

text: SWEM - hier for sentiment analysis
As demonstrated in Section 4.2.1 , word - order information plays a vital role for sentiment analysis tasks .
heading: SWEM - hier for sentiment analysis

text: However , according to the case study above , the most important features for sentiment prediction maybe some key n-gram phrase / words from Negative :
heading: SWEM - hier for sentiment analysis

text: Friendly staff and nice selection of vegetarian options .
Food is just okay , not great .
Makes me wonder why everyone likes food fight so much .
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: Positive :
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: The store is small , but it carries specialties that are difficult to find in Pittsburgh .
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: I was particularly excited to find middle eastern chili sauce and chocolate covered turkish delights .
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: the input document .
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: We hypothesize that incorporating information about the local word - order , i.e. , n-gram features , is likely to largely mitigate the limitations of the above three SWEM variants .
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: Inspired by this observation , we propose using another simple pooling operation termed as hierarchical ( SWEM - hier ) , as detailed in Section 3.3 .
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: We evaluate this method on the two documentlevel sentiment analysis tasks and the results are shown in the last row of .
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: SWEM - hier greatly outperforms the other three SWEM variants , and the corresponding accuracies are comparable to the results of CNN or LSTM ) .
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: This indicates that the proposed hierarchical pooling operation manages to abstract spatial ( word - order ) information from the input sequence , which is beneficial for performance in sentiment analysis tasks .
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: Short Sentence Processing
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: We now consider sentence - classification tasks ( with approximately 20 words on average ) .
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: We experiment on three sentiment classification datasets , i.e. , MR , SST - 1 , SST - 2 , as well as subjectivity classification ( Subj ) and question classification ( TREC ) .
heading: Food is just okay , not great .

text: The corresponding results are shown in .
Compared with CNN / LSTM compositional functions , SWEM yields inferior accuracies on sentiment analysis datasets , consistent with our observation in the case of document categorization .
heading: The corresponding results are shown in .

text: However , SWEM exhibits comparable performance on the other two tasks , again with much less parameters and faster training .
heading: The corresponding results are shown in .

text: Further , we investigate two sequence tagging tasks : the standard CoNLL2000 chunking and CoNLL2003 NER datasets .
heading: The corresponding results are shown in .

text: Results are shown in the Supplementary Material , where LSTM and CNN again perform better than SWEMs .
heading: The corresponding results are shown in .

text: Generally , SWEM is less effective at extracting representations from short sentences than from long documents .
heading: The corresponding results are shown in .

text: This maybe due to the fact that fora shorter text sequence , word - order features tend to be more important since the semantic information provided byword embeddings alone is relatively limited .
heading: The corresponding results are shown in .

text: Moreover , we note that the results on these relatively small datasets are highly sensitive to model regularization techniques due to the overfitting issues .
heading: The corresponding results are shown in .

text: In this regard , one interesting future direction maybe to develop specific regularization strategies for the SWEM framework , and thus make them work better on small sentence classification datasets .
heading: The corresponding results are shown in .

text: Discussion
Comparison via subspace training
We use subspace training to measure the model complexity in text classification problems .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: It constrains the optimization of the trainable parameters in a subspace of low dimension d , the intrinsic dimension dint defines the minimum d that yield a good solution .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: Two models are studied : the SWEM - max variant , and the CNN model including a convolutional layer followed by a FC layer .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: We consider two settings :
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: ( 1 ) The word embeddings are randomly intialized , and optimized jointly with the model parameters .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: We show the performance of direct and subspace training on AG News dataset in ( a ) ( b ) .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: The two models trained via direct method share almost identical perfomrnace on training and testing .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: The subspace training yields similar accuracy with direct training for very small d , even when model parameters are not trained at all ( d = 0 ) .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: This is because the word embeddings have the full degrees of freedom to adjust to achieve good solutions , regardless of the employed models .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: SWEM seems to have an easier loss landspace than CNN for word embeddings to find the best solutions .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: According to Occam 's razor , simple models are preferred , if all else are the same .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: ( 2 ) The pre-trained GloVe are frozen for the word embeddings , and only the model parameters are optimized .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: The results on testing datasets of AG News and Yelp P. are shown in ( c ) ( d ) , respectively .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: SWEM shows significantly higher accuracy than CNN fora large range of low subspace dimension , indicating that SWEM is more parameter - efficient to get a decent solution .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: In ( c ) , if we set the performance threshold Model MR SST - 1 SST - 2 Subj TREC RAE 77.7 43.2 82.4 --MV-RNN 79.0 44.4 82.9 --LSTM - 46.4 84.9 --RNN 77.2 --93.7 90.2 Constituency Tree-LSTM - 51.0 88.0 -- Dynamic CNN - 48.5 86.8 - 93.0 CNN 81 as 80 % testing accuracy , SWEM exhibits a lower dint than CNN on AG News dataset .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: However , in , CNN can leverage more trainable parameters to achieve higher accuracy when dis large .
heading: Comparison via subspace training

text: Linear classifiers

To further investigate the quality of representations learned from SWEMs , we employ a linear classifier on top of the representations for prediction , instead of a non-linear MLP layer as in the previous section .
heading: Linear classifiers

text: It turned out that utilizing a linear classifier only leads to a very small performance drop for both Yahoo !
heading: Linear classifiers

text: Ans. ( from 73.53 % to 73.18 % ) and Yelp P. datasets ( from 93.76 % to 93.66 % ) .
heading: Linear classifiers

text: This observation highlights that SWEMs are able to extract robust and informative sentence representations despite their simplicity .
heading: Linear classifiers

text: Extension to other languages

We have also tried our SWEM - concat and SWE Mhier models on Sogou news corpus ( with the same experimental setup as ) , which is a Chinese dataset represented by Pinyin ( a phonetic romanization of Chinese ) .
heading: Extension to other languages

text: SWEMconcat yields an accuracy of 91.3 % , while SWEM - hier ( with a local window size of 5 ) obtains an accuracy of 96.2 % on the test set .
heading: Extension to other languages

text: Notably , the performance of SWEM - hier is comparable to the best accuracies of CNN ( 95.6 % ) and LSTM ( 95.2 % ) , as reported in .
heading: Extension to other languages

text: This indicates that hierarchical pooling is more suitable than average / max pooling for Chinese text classification , by taking spatial information into account .
heading: Extension to other languages

text: It also implies that Chinese is more sensitive to local word - order features than English .
heading: Extension to other languages

text: Conclusions
We have performed a comparative study between SWEM ( with parameter - free pooling operations ) and CNN or LSTM - based models , to represent text sequences on 17 NLP datasets .
heading: Conclusions

text: We further validated our experimental findings through additional exploration , and revealed some general rules for rationally selecting compositional functions for distinct problems .
heading: Conclusions

text: Our findings regarding when ( and why ) simple pooling operations are enough for text sequence representations are summarized as follows :
heading: Conclusions

text: Simple pooling operations are surprisingly effective at representing longer documents ( with hundreds of words ) , while recurrent / convolutional compositional functions are most effective when constructing representations for short sentences .
heading: Conclusions

text: Sentiment analysis tasks are more sensitive to word - order features than topic categorization tasks .
heading: Conclusions

text: However , a simple hierarchical pooling layer proposed here achieves comparable results to LSTM / CNN on sentiment analysis tasks .
heading: Conclusions

text: To match natural language sentences , e.g. , textual entailment , answer sentence selection , etc. , simple pooling operations already exhibit similar or even superior results , compared to CNN and LSTM .
heading: Conclusions

text: We consider a wide range of text - representationbased tasks in this paper , including document categorization , text sequence matching and ( short ) sentence classification .
heading: Conclusions

text: For document classification tasks , we use the same data splits in ( downloaded from https://goo.gl/QaRpr7 ) ; for short sentence classification , we employ the same training / testing data and preprocessing procedure with .
heading: Conclusions

text: The statistics and corresponding types of these datasets are summarized in Datasets #w #c Train Types SWEM - CRF indicates that CRF is directly operated on top of the word embedding layer and make predictions for each word ( there is no contextual / word - order information before CRF layer , compared to CNN - CRF or BI - LSTM - CRF ) .
heading: Conclusions

text: As shown above , CNN - CRF and BI - LSTM - CRF consistently outperform SWEM - CRF on both sequence tagging tasks , although the training takes around 4 to 5 times longer ( for BI - LSTM - CRF ) than SWEM - CRF .
heading: Conclusions

text: This suggests that for chunking and NER , compositional functions such as LSTM or CNN are very necessary , because of the sequential ( order-sensitive ) nature of sequence tagging tasks .
heading: Conclusions

text: What are the key words used for predictions ?
heading: Conclusions

text: Given the sparsity of word embeddings , one natural question would be : What are those key words that are leveraged by the model to make predictions ?
heading: Conclusions

text: To this end , after training SWEM - max on Yahoo !
heading: Conclusions

text: Answer dataset , we selected the top - 10 words ( with the maximum values in that dimension ) for every word embedding dimension .
heading: Conclusions

text: The results are visualized in .
These words are indeed very predictive since they are likely to occur in documents with a specific topic , as discussed above .
heading: The results are visualized in .

text: Another interesting observation is that the frequencies of these words are actually quite low in the training set ( e.g. colston : 320 , repubs : 255 win32 : 276 ) , considering the large size of the training set ( 1,400 K ) .
heading: The results are visualized in .

text: This suggests that the model is utilizing those relatively rare , yet representative words of each topic for the final predictions .
heading: The results are visualized in .

text: information of a text sequence is the word embedding .
heading: The results are visualized in .

text: Thus , it is of interest to see how many word embedding dimensions are needed fora SWEM architecture to perform well .
heading: The results are visualized in .

text: To this end , we vary the dimension from 3 to 1000 and train a SWEMconcat model on the Yahoo dataset .
heading: The results are visualized in .

text: For fair comparison , the word embeddings are randomly initialized in this experiment , since there are no pretrained word vectors , such as GloVe , for some dimensions we consider .
heading: The results are visualized in .

text: As shown in , the model exhibits higher accuracy with larger word embedding dimensions .
heading: The results are visualized in .

text: This is not surprising since with more embedding dimensions , more semantic features could be potentially encapsulated .
heading: The results are visualized in .

text: However , we also observe that even with only 10 dimensions , SWEM demonstrates comparable results relative to the case with 1000 dimensions , suggesting that word embeddings are very efficient at abstracting semantic information into fixed - length vectors .
heading: The results are visualized in .

text: This property indicates that we may further reduce the number of model parameters with lowerdimensional word embeddings , while still achieving competitive results .
heading: The results are visualized in .

text: Sensitivity of compositional functions to sample size

To explore the robustness of different compositional functions , we consider another application scenario , where we only have a limited number of training data , e.g. , when labeled data are expensive to obtain .
heading: Sensitivity of compositional functions to sample size

text: To investigate this , we re-run the experiments on Yahoo and SNLI datasets , while employing increasing proportions of the original training set .
heading: Sensitivity of compositional functions to sample size

text: Specifically , we use 0.1 % , 0.2 % , 0.6 % , 1.0 % , 10 % , 100 % for comparison ; the corresponding results are shown in .
heading: Sensitivity of compositional functions to sample size

text: Surprisingly , SWEM consistently outperforms CNN and LSTM models by a large margin , on a wide range of training data proportions .
heading: Sensitivity of compositional functions to sample size

text: For instance , with 0.1 % of the training samples from Yahoo dataset ( around 1.4 K labeled data ) , SWEM achieves an accuracy of 56. 10 % , which is much better than that of models with CNN ( 25.32 % ) or LSTM ( 42.37 % ) .
heading: Sensitivity of compositional functions to sample size

text: On the SNLI dataset , we also noticed the same trend that the SWEM architecture result in much better accuracies , with a fraction of training data .
heading: Sensitivity of compositional functions to sample size

text: This observation indicates that overfitting issues in CNN or LSTMbased models on text data mainly stems from overcomplicated compositional functions , rather than the word embedding layer .
heading: Sensitivity of compositional functions to sample size

text: More importantly , SWEM tends to be afar more robust model when only limited data are available for training .
heading: Sensitivity of compositional functions to sample size

text: title
Translations as Additional Contexts for Sentence Classification
abstract
In sentence classification tasks , additional contexts , such as the neighboring sentences , may improve the accuracy of the classifier .
heading: abstract

text: However , such contexts are domain - dependent and thus can not be used for another classification task with an inappropriate domain .
heading: abstract

text: In contrast , we propose the use of translated sentences as domain - free context that is always available regardless of the domain .
heading: abstract

text: We find that naive feature expansion of translations gains only marginal improvements and may decrease the performance of the classifier , due to possible inaccurate translations thus producing noisy sentence vectors .
heading: abstract

text: To this end , we present multiple context fixing attachment ( MCFA ) , a series of modules attached to multiple sentence vectors to fix the noise in the vectors using the other sentence vectors as context .
heading: abstract

text: We show that our method performs competitively compared to previous models , achieving best classification performance on multiple data sets .
heading: abstract

text: We are the first to use translations as domainfree contexts for sentence classification .
heading: abstract

text: Introduction

One of the primary tasks in natural language processing ( NLP ) is sentence classification , where given a sentence ( e.g. a sentence of a review ) as input , we are tasked to classify it into one of multiple classes ( e.g. into positive or negative ) .
heading: Introduction

text: This task is important as it is widely used in almost all subareas of NLP such as sentiment classification for sentiment analysis and question type classification for question answering , to name a few .
heading: Introduction

text: While past methods require feature engineering , recent methods enjoy neural - based methods to automatically encode the sentences into low - dimensional dense vectors .
heading: Introduction

text: Despite the success of these methods , the major challenge in this task is that extracting features from a single sentence limits the performance .
heading: Introduction

text: To overcome this limitation , recent works attempted to augment different kinds of features to the sentence , such as the neighboring sentences and the topics of the sentences .
heading: Introduction

text: However , these methods used domain - dependent contexts that are only effective when the domain of the task is appropriate .
heading: Introduction

text: For one thing , neighboring sentences may not be available in some tasks such as question type classification .
heading: Introduction

text: Moreover , topics inferred using topic models may produce less useful topics when the data set is domain - specific such as movie review sentiment classification .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we propose the usage of translations as compelling and effective domain - free contexts , or contexts that are always available no matter what the task domain is .
heading: Introduction

text: We observe two opportunities when using translations .
heading: Introduction

text: First , each language has its own linguistic and cultural characteristics that may contain different signals to effectively classify a specific class .
heading: Introduction

text: contrasts the sentence vectors of the original English sentences and their Arabictranslated sentences in the question type classification task .
heading: Introduction

text: A yellow circle signifies a clear separation of a class .
heading: Introduction

text: For example , the green class , or the numeric question type , is circled in the Arabic space as it is clearly separated from other classes , while such separation can not be observed in English .
heading: Introduction

text: Meanwhile , location type questions ( in orange ) are better classified in English .
heading: Introduction

text: Second , the original sentences may include languagespecific ambiguity , which maybe resolved when presented with its translations .
heading: Introduction

text: Consider the example English sentence " The movie is terribly amazing " for the sentiment classification task .
heading: Introduction

text: In this case , terribly can be used in both positive and negative sense , thus introduces ambiguity in the sentence .
heading: Introduction

text: When translated to Korean , it becomes " ? ? ?? ?? ? ? ? ?? ? ?? ? ? ? ? ? ? ?? ? ?? ?? ? " which means " The movie is greatly magnificent " , removing the ambiguity .
heading: Introduction

text: The above two observations hold only when translations are supported for ( nearly ) arbitrary language pairs with sufficiently high quality .
heading: Introduction

text: Thankfully , translation services ( e.g. Google Translate )
heading: Introduction

text: Moreover , recent research on neural machine translation ( NMT ) improved the efficiency and even enabled zero - shot translation of models for languages with no parallel data .
heading: Introduction

text: This provides an opportunity to leverage on as many languages as possible to any domain , providing a much wider context compared to the limited contexts provided by past studies .
heading: Introduction

text: However , despite the maturity of translation , naively concatenating their vectors to the original sentence vector may introduce more noise than signals .
heading: Introduction

text: The unaltered translation space on the left of shows an example where translation noises make the two classes indistinguishable .
heading: Introduction

text: In this paper , we propose a method to mitigate the possible problems when using translated sentences as context based on the following observations .
heading: Introduction

text: Suppose there are two translated sentences a and b with slight errors .
heading: Introduction

text: We posit that a can be used to fix b when a is used as a context of b , and vice versa
heading: Introduction

text: Revisiting the example above , to fix the vector of the English sentence " The movie is terribly amazing " , we use the Korean translation to move the vector towards the location where the vector " The movie is greatly magnificent " is .
heading: Introduction

text: Based on these observations , we present a neural attentionbased multiple context fixing attachment ( MCFA ) .
heading: Introduction

text: MCFA is a series of modules that uses all the sentence vectors ( e.g. Arabic , English , Korean , etc. ) as context to fix a sentence vector ( e.g. Korean ) .
heading: Introduction

text: Fixing the vectors is done by selectively moving the vectors to a location in the same vector space that better separates the class , as shown in .
heading: Introduction

text: Noises from translation may cause adverse effects to the vector itself ( e.g. when a noisy vector is directly used for the task ) and relatively to other vectors ( e.g. when a noisy vector is used to fix another noisy vector ) .
heading: Introduction

text: MCFA computes two sentence usability metrics to control the noise when fixing vectors : ( a ) self usability ? i ( a ) weighs the confidence of using sentence a in solving the task .
heading: Introduction

text: ( b ) relative usability ? r ( a , b ) weighs the confidence of using sentence a in fixing sentence b.
heading: Introduction

text: Listed below are the three main strengths of the MCFA attachment .
heading: Introduction

text: ( 1 ) MCFA is attached after encoding the sentence , which makes it widely adaptable to other models .
heading: Introduction

text: ( 2 ) MCFA is extensible and improves the accuracy as the number of translated sentences increases .
heading: Introduction

text: ( 3 ) MCFA moves the vectors inside the same space , thus preserves the meaning of vector dimensions .
heading: Introduction

text: Results show that a convolutional neural network ( CNN ) attached with MCFA significantly improves the classification performance of CNN , achieving state of the 1 Hereon , we mean to " fix " as to " correct , repair , or alter . " art performance over multiple data sets .
heading: Introduction

text: Preliminaries
Problem : Translated Sentences as Context

In this paper , the ultimate task that we solve is the sentence classification task where given a sentence and a list of classes , one is task to classify which class ( e.g. positive or negative sentiment ) among the list of classes does the sentence belong .
heading: Problem : Translated Sentences as Context

text: However , the main challenge that we tackle is the task on how to utilize translated sentences as additional context in order to improve the performance of the classifier .
heading: Problem : Translated Sentences as Context

text: Specifically , the problem states : given the original sentence s , the goal is to use t 1 , t 2 , ... , tn , or sentences in other languages which are translated from s , as additional context .
heading: Problem : Translated Sentences as Context

text: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .
The base model used is the convolutional neural network ( CNN ) for sentences .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: It is a simple variation of the original CNN for texts to be used on sentences .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: Let xi ?
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: Rd be the d-dimensional word vector of the i - th word in a sentence of length n .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: A convolution operation involves applying a filter matrix W ?
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: R hd to a window of h words and producing anew feature vector c i using the equation
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: bias vector and f ( . ) is a non-linear function .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: By doing this on all possible windows of words we produce a feature map c = [ c 1 , c 2 , ... ] .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: We then apply a max - over - time pooling operation over the feature map and take the maximum value as the feature vector of the filter .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: We do this on all feature vectors and concatenate all the feature vectors to obtain the final feature vector v.
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: We can then use this vector as input features to train a classifier such as logistic regression .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: We use CNN to create sentence vectors for all sentences s , t 1 , t 2 , ... , tn .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: From hereon , we refer to these vectors as v s , v t1 , v t2 , ... , v tn , respectively .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: We refer to them collectively as V .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: Baseline 1 : Naive Concatenation .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: A simple method in order to use the translated sentences as additional context is to naively concatenate their vectors with the vector of the original sentence .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: That is , we create a wide vectorv = [ v s ; v t1 ; ... ; v tn ] , and use this as the input feature vector of the sentence to the classifier .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: This method works fine if the translated sentences are translated properly .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: However , sentences translated using machine translation models usually contain incorrect translation .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: In effect , this method will have adverse effects on the overall performance of the classifier .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: This will especially be very evident if the number of additional sentences increases .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: Baseline 2 : L2 Regularization .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: In order to alleviate the problems above , we can use L2 regularization to automatically select useful features by weakening the appropriate weights .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: The main problem of this method occurs when almost all of the weights coming from the vectors of the translated sentence are weakened .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: This leads to making the additional context vectors useless and to having a similar performance when there are no additional context .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: Ultimately , this method does not make use of the full potential of the additional context .
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: usability usability ( a ) Self and relative usability modules
heading: Base Model : Convolutional Neural Network .

text: Model

To solve the problems of the baselines discussed above , we introduce an attention - based neural multiple context fixing attachment ( MCFA ) 2 , a series of modules attached to the sentence vectors V .
heading: Model

text: MCFA attachment is used to fix the sentence vectors , by slightly modifying the per-dimension values of the vector , before concatenating them into the final feature vector .
heading: Model

text: The sentence vectors are altered using other sentence vectors as context ( e.g. v t 1 is altered using v s , v t2 , ... , v tn ) .
heading: Model

text: This results to moving the vectors in the same vector space .
heading: Model

text: The full architecture is shown in .
heading: Model

text: Self Usability Module
To fix a source sentence vector 3 , we use the other sentence vectors as guide to know which dimensions to fix and to what extent do we need to fix them .
heading: Self Usability Module

text: However , other vectors might also contain errors which may reflect to the fixing of the source sentence vector .
heading: Self Usability Module

text: In order to cope with this , we introduce self usability modules .
heading: Self Usability Module

text: A self usability module contains the self usability of the vector ? i ( a ) , which measures how confident sentence a is for the task at hand .
heading: Self Usability Module

text: For example , an ambiguous sentence ( e.g. " The movie is terribly amazing " ) may receive a low self usability , while a clear and definite sentence ( e.g. " The movie is very good " ) may receive a high self usability .
heading: Self Usability Module

text: Mathematically , we calculate the self usability of the vector vi of sentence i , denoted as ? i ( v i ) , using the equation
heading: Self Usability Module

text: is a matrix to be learned .
heading: Self Usability Module

text: The produced value is a single real number from 0 to 1 .
heading: Self Usability Module

text: We pre-calculate the self usability of all sentence vectors vi ?
heading: Self Usability Module

text: V .
These are used in the next module , the relative usability module .
heading: V .

text: Relative Usability
Module
Relative usability ? r ( a , b ) measures how useful a can be when fixing b , relative to other sentences .
heading: Module

text: There are two main differences between ? i ( a ) and ? r ( a , b ) .
heading: Module

text: First , ? i ( a ) is calculated before a knows about b while ? r ( a , b ) is calculated when a knows about b.
heading: Module

text: Second , ? r ( a , b ) can below even though ? i ( a ) is not .
heading: Module

text: This means that a is notable to help in fixing the wrong information in b .
heading: Module

text: Here , we extend the additive attention module and use it as a method to calculate the relative usability of two sentences of different languages .
heading: Module

text: To better visualize the original attention mechanism , we present the equations below .
heading: Module

text: One major challenge in using the attention mechanism in our problem is that the sentence vectors do not belong to the same vector space .
heading: Module

text: Moreover , one characteristic of our problem is that the sentence vectors can be both a source and a context vector ( e.g. v scan be both sand ti in Equation 1 ) .
heading: Module

text: Because of these , we can not directly use the additive attention module .
heading: Module

text: We extend the module such that ( 1 ) each sentence vector v k has its own projection matrix X k ?
heading: Module

text: R dd , and ( 2 ) each projection matrix X k can be used as projection matrix of both the source ( e.g. when sentence k is the current source ) and the context vectors .
heading: Module

text: Finally , we incorporate the self usability function ?
heading: Module

text: i ( v k ) to reflect the self usability of a sentence .
heading: Module

text: Ultimately , the relative usability denoted as ? r ( v i , v j ) is calculated using the equations below , where is the multiplication of a vector and a scalar through broadcasting .
heading: Module

text: Vector Fixing Module
The vector fixing module applies the attention weights to the sentence vectors and creates an integrated context vector .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: We then use this vector alongside with the source sentence vector to create a weighted gate vector .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: The weighted gate vector is used to determine to what extent should a dimension of the source sentence vector be altered .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: The common way to apply the attention weights to the context vectors and create an integrated context vector c i is to directly do weighted sum of all the context vectors .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: However , this is not possible because the context vectors are not on the same space .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: Thus , we use a projection matrix U k ?
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: R dd to linearly project the sentence vector v k to transform the sentence vectors into a common vector space .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: The integrated context vector c i is then calculated as
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: Finally , we construct a weighted gate vector wk and use it to fix the source sentence vectors using the equations below , where V k ?
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: R 2dd is a trainable parameter and ?
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: is the element - wise multiplication procedure .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: The weighted gate vector is a vector of real numbers between 0 and 1 to modify the intensity of per-dimension values of the sentence vector .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: This causes the vector to move in the same vector space towards the correct direction .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: An alternative approach to do vector correction is using a residual - style correction , where instead of multiplying agate vector , a residual vector is added to the original vector .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: However , this approach makes the correction not interpretable ; it is hard to explain what does adding a value to a specific dimension mean .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: One major advantage of MCFA is that the corrections in the vectors are interpretable ; the weights in the gate vector correspond to the importance of the per-dimension features of the vector .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: The altered vector ? v s , ... , v tn are then concatenated and fed directly as an input vector to the logistic regression classifier for training .
heading: Vector Fixing Module

text: Experiments
Experimental Setting
We test our model on four different data sets as listed below and summarized in .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: ( a ) MR 4 : Movie reviews data where the task is to classify whether the review sentence has positive or negative sentiment .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: ( b ) SUBJ : Subjectivity data where the task is to classify whether the sentence is subjective or objective .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: ( c ) CR 5 : Customer reviews where
heading: Experimental Setting

text: The task is to classify whether the review sentence is positive or negative .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: ( d ) TREC 6 : TREC question data set the task is to classify the type of question .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: All our data sets are in English .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: For the additional contexts , we use ten other languages , selected based on their diversity and their performance on prior experiments : Arabic , Finnish , French , Italian , Korean , Mongolian , Norwegian , Polish , Russian , and Ukranian .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: We translate the data sets using Google Translate .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: Tokenization is done using the polyglot library 7 .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: We experiment on using only one additional context ( N = 1 ) and using all ten languages at once ( N = 10 ) .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: For N = 1 , we only show the accuracy of the best classifier for conciseness .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: For our CNN , we use rectified linear units and three filters with different window sizes h = 3 , 4 , 5 with 100 feature maps each , following .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: For the final sentence vector , we concatenate the feature maps to get a 300 - dimension vector .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: We use dropout on all nonlinear connections with a dropout rate of 0.5 .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: We also use an l 2 constraint of 3 , following for accurate comparisons .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: We use FastText pre-trained vectors 8 for all our data sets and their corresponding additional context .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: During training , we use mini-batch size of 50 .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: Training is done via stochastic gradient descent over shuffled mini-batches with the Adadelta update rule .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: We perform early stopping using a random 10 % of the training set as the development set .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: We present several competing models , listed below to compare the performance of our model .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: uses topics as additional contexts and changes the CNN architecture .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: TopCNN uses two types of topics : word- specific topic and sentence - specific topic ; and ( D ) CNN+ B1 and CNN +
heading: Experimental Setting

text: B2 are the two baselines presented in this paper .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: We do not show results from RNN models because they were shown to be less effective in sentence classification in our prior experiments .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: For models with additional context , we further use an ensemble classification model using a commonly used method by averaging the class probability scores generated by the multiple variants ( in our model 's case , N = 1 and N = 10 models ) , following .
heading: Experimental Setting

text: Results and Discussion
We report the classification accuracy of the competing models in .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: We show that CNN + MCFA achieves state of the art performance on three of the four data sets and performs competitively on one data set .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: When N = 1 , MCFA increases the performance of a normal CNN from 85.0 to 87.6 , beating the current state of the art on the CR data set .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: When N = 10 , MCFA additionally beats the state of the art on the TREC data set .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: Finally , our ensemble classifier additionally outperforms all competing models on the MR data set .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: We emphasize that we only use the basic CNN as our sentence encoder for our experiments , yet still achieve state of the art performance :
heading: Results and Discussion

text: Classification accuracies of competing models .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: C refers to the additional context , N refers to the number of translations .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: In TopCNN , word refers to using word - specific topic while sentence refers to using sentence - specific topic .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: Accuracies colored red are accuracies that perform worse than CNN .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: Previous state of the art results and the results of our best model are bold - faced .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: The winning result is underlined .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: The number inside the parenthesis indicates the increase from the base model , CNN . on most data sets .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: Hence , MCFA is successful in effectively using translations as additional context to improve the performance of the classifier .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: We compare our model ( CNN + MCFA ) and the baselines discussed above ( CNN + B1 , CNN + B2 ) .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: On all settings , our model outperforms the baselines .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: When N = 10 , the performance of our model increases over the performance when N = 1 , however the performance of CNN + B1 decreases when compared to the performance when N = 1 .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: We also show the accuracies of the worst classifiers when N = 1 in .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: On all data sets except SUBJ , the accuracy of CNN + B1 decreases from the base CNN accuracy , while the accuracy of our model always improves from the base CNN accuracy .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: This is resolved by CNN + B2 by applying L2 regularization , however the increase in performance is marginal .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: We also compare two different kinds of additional context : topics ( TopCNN ) and translations ( CNN + B1 , CNN + B2 , CNN + MCFA ) .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: Overall , we conclude that translations are better additional contexts than topics .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: When using a single context ( i.e. TopCNN word , TopCNN sent , and our models when N = 1 ) , translations always outperform topics even when using the baseline methods .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: Using topics as additional context also decreases the performance of the CNN classifier on most data sets , giving an adverse effect to the CNN classifier .
heading: Results and Discussion

text: Related Work
One way to improve the performance of a sentence classifier is to introduce new context .
heading: Related Work

text: Common and obvious kinds of context are the neighboring sentences of the sentence , and the document where the sentence belongs .
heading: Related Work

text: Topics of the words in the sentence induced by a topic model were also used as contexts .
heading: Related Work

text: In this paper , we introduce yet another type of additional context , sentence translations , which to the best of our knowledge have not been used previously .
heading: Related Work

text: Sentence encoders trained from neural machine translation ( NMT ) systems were also used for transfer learning .
heading: Related Work

text: demonstrated that altered - length sentence vectors from NMT encoders outperform sentence vectors from monolingual encoders on semantic similarity tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: Recent work used representation of each word in the sentence to create a sentence representation suitable for multiple NLP tasks .
heading: Related Work

text: Our work shares the commonality of using NMT for another task , but instead of using NMT to encode our sentences , we use it to translate the sentences into new contexts .
heading: Related Work

text: Increasing the number of data instances of the training set has also been explored to improve the performance of a classifier .
heading: Related Work

text: Recent methods include the usage of thesaurus , paraphrases , among others .
heading: Related Work

text: These simple variation techniques are preferred because they are found to be very effective despite their simplicity .
heading: Related Work

text: Our work similarly augments training data , not by adding data instances ( vertical augmentation ) , but rather by adding more context ( horizontal augmentation ) .
heading: Related Work

text: Though the paraphrase of p can be alternatively used as an augmented context , this could not leverage the added semantics coming from another language , as discussed in Section 1 .
heading: Related Work

text: Conclusion
This paper investigates the use of translations as better additional contexts for sentence classification .
heading: Conclusion

text: To answer the problem on mistranslations , we propose multiple context fixing attachment ( MCFA ) to fix the context vectors using other context vectors .
heading: Conclusion

text: We show that our method improves the classification performance and achieves state - of - the - art perfor - mance on multiple data sets .
heading: Conclusion

text: In our future work , we plan to use and extend our model to other complex NLP tasks .
heading: Conclusion
